DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 1, or the 23rd day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-PARTY RACE FOR RECONCILIATION WITH BEIJING 'UNHELPFUL': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that it is "unhelpful" that political parties in Taiwan scramble to try to sign accords with Beijing.

It does not benefit Taiwan to have political parties competing among themselves to demonstrate their "openness" in cross-strait relations by seeking to forge agreements with Beijing, Hsieh said. He did not elaborate on why he considers it "unhelpful."

Commenting on opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's visit to China and the 10-point consensus Chiang reached with Chinese authorities on a number of cross-strait issues, Hsieh said that any talks between KMT representatives and those of the Chinese Communist Party on their past conflict or on reconciliation are strictly a "party-to-party" matter. He stressed that they do not represent "public affairs, " which he said is solely the responsibility of the government.

As to reports that the Chinese authorities might be willing to help Taiwan obtain World Health Assembly observer status, Hsieh said that joining the WHA, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO), is a basic right of Taiwan and that the WHA needs Taiwan in order to close the loopholes in its global disease-prevention network.
Seeking to join the WHO is an established policy of the country, and the administration will continue in this effort relentlessly, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MATERIALIZING 10-POINT CONSENSUS UP TO ADMINISTRATION: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: It is up to the administration whether to materialize the 10-point consensus for the well-being of the people of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached between the Kuomintang (KMT) delegation visiting Beijing and Chinese authorities, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday.

Commenting on KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's 10-point consensus reached with officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing on a number of cross-strait issues, Wang, who also serves as a KMT vice chairman, said that it is something the Democratic Progressive Party administration could not achieve.

That 10-point consensus on a wide range of issues, including cross-strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese business people, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market, is also crucially important for the government as well as the people in Taiwan, Wang added.
Any consensus, however, is futile if the administration disregards it, Wang stressed.

Wang made the remarks in response to Premier Frank Hsieh's comments earlier the same day that any talks between KMT representatives and those of the Chinese Communist Party on their past conflict or on reconciliation are strictly a "party-to-party" matter. "They do not represent 'public affairs, ' which is solely the responsibility of the government," Hsieh said.
The 27-member KMT delegation, led by Chiang, embarked on its five-day visit Monday, making it the party's first official delegation to visit China.

Members of the delegation first paid tribute at the cemetery of 72 martyrs who sacrificed their lives in the KMT-led Huanghuagang Uprising against China's last empire, the Ching Dynasty, in Guangzhou, southern Guangdong Province, Tuesday. The death of the 72 martyrs March 29, 1911, is designated as the Republic of China's National Youth Day.
The group then paid tribute at the mausoleum of ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing Wednesday before heading north to Beijing later in the day.
It is has been widely speculated that the visit by Chiang's delegation could mark a stepping stone to a landmark visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in the near future.
Chiang and his delegation are scheduled to return home Friday after wrapping up their visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE URGED TO REMAIN ALERT WHILE TRAVELING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan were urged again Friday to remain vigilant at all times when traveling in mainland China on business or for pleasure.

Hosting a press conference for a Taiwanese businessman who was robbed in his hotel room in the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen recently, two legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called for Taiwan tourists and businesspeople traveling to the mainland to remain alert at all times for their personal safety.

According to the businessman, identified as Chi Chien-chuan, he checked into a hotel in Shenzhen March 23 during a business trip. At around midnight of the same day, someone knocked on his hotel room door claiming that it was a routine inspection by public security officers. When Chi opened his door, three men attacked him, tying him up with rope and robbing him of his cash and valuables.
Chi claimed that after he reported the crime to a local police station, the public security officers dealt with the case in a perfunctory manner.
The businessman said he will not go to the mainland again if his case remains unsolved.

DPP Legislator Tsai Chi-chang said that Taiwan people make more than a million trips to the mainland every year. He urged all Taiwan people heading to China to bear in mind the hidden risks of visiting the country.

Shen Fa-hui, another DPP legislator, said that if a crime similar to the one that Chi was a victim of occurred in Taiwan, it would be considered a prominent case and dealt with seriously by law enforcement authorities here. Pointing to the mainland authorities' alleged ignoring of Chi's case, Shen urged all Taiwan travelers to China to remain vigilant concerning their personal safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 22.87 points to close at 6,028.75.
The bourse opened at 6,010.71 and fluctuated between 6,028.99 and 5,959.28 during trading. A total of 2.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$74.42 billion (US$2.35 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up at 1.1 percent and foodstuff issues gaining 0.5 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.3 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.1 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent, textile stocks at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 524 to 371, with 123 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 35 points to close at 6,045, with 31,130 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 28 points to finish at 6,040, with 319 contracts traded, while June futures gained 26 points to finish at 6,026, with 55 contracts traded. September futures gained 30 points to finish at 5,920, with 121 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 6,010 for April, 6,012 for May, 6,000 for June, 5,890 for September and 5,897 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

April TE futures moved up 3.7 points to close at 234.6, with 5,770 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 3.15 points to finish at 234.1, with 47 contract transactions. September TE futures moved up 0.25 points to close at 230.4, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.
April TF futures lost 1.6 points to finish at 966, with 3,874 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved down 0.6 points to end at 966.4, with 48 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHINA TRIP DISGRACES ROC DIGNITY: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The recent trip made by an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) delegation to mainland China has disgraced the dignity of the Republic of China at a time when the nation has come under increased threats from Beijing, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.

It is "quite clear" that the politically sensitive activities in which the mission engaged in China have already tainted the ROC's national dignity and appear to show the delegation siding with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) , as the KMT did not clarify a report by China's Xinhua News Agency that claimed the KMT mission visited the "mother homeland" to gain an understanding of its reform-oriented establishments.

At a time when the international community is increasingly wary of Beijing's enactment of its anti-secession law aimed at Taiwan, it is highly inappropriate for any group from Taiwan to indulge in politically charged activities in China, he said, pointing out that there is concern that such behavior might violate relevant government rules, namely the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
The MAC vice chairman made the remarks in reference to the KMT delegation led by Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang that returned to Taiwan that same day after wrapping up a five-day visit to China.

The KMT delegation -- the first of its kind in 56 years since the party retreated to Taiwan in the wake of losing a civil war to the Chinese communists -- visited Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing. It also clinched a 10-point consensus with CCP officials late Wednesday to step up civil exchanges, ranging from cross-Taiwan Strait air links and agricultural issues to labor and academic affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S VISIT DIMINISHES OPPOSITION TO ANTI-SECESSION LAW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's recent visit to China is problematic and claimed that its timing diminishes the strength of Taiwan's opposition to Beijing's enactment of its anti-secession law.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that Chiang's 10-point consensus reached with officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing is also controversial from a legal point of view.

Citing the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Hsieh said that visits to China by Taiwan public functionaries and legislators are strictly regulated by the statute and they are forbidden to sign any form of accord with official Chinese institutions or organizations without authority from the government.

It would be illegal if Chiang's 10-point consensus reached with the Beijing officials were put into black and white, Hsieh said, adding that even if it was not, it is still a debatable case. Chiang is also a KMT legislator-at-large.

According to KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung, who was among Chiang's 27-member entourage that visited Beijing, the consensus is on a wide range of issues, including cross-strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businessmen, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

Hsieh said that any talks between KMT representatives and those of the Chinese Communist Party on their past conflict or on reconciliation are strictly a "party-to-party" matter. "They do not represent 'public affairs,' which is solely the responsibility of the government," Hsieh said.

Meanwhile, Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, noted that Chiang, as a legislator, might have violated the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, in which it is stipulated that no Taiwan citizen is allowed to forge any kind of cooperation with China's political and military organizations without prior authority from the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO HOLD INLINE SKATING CONTEST

TEXT.P: Twenty-two teams from 18 countries will gather in Taipei April 17 to participate in an inline skating competition to be held by the Taipei city government.

"World Inline Cup Taipei 2005," an event organized jointly by the Taipei city government and the Chinese Taipei Sports and Recreation Association to promote inline skating, is the city's first international skating competition. An estimated 10,000 participants from around the globe will take part in either the prize-winning 42 km or 20 km races, or a non-competitive 8 km marathon. Among the participants are Massimiliano Presti and Luca Saggiorato from Italy, the world's No.1 and No. 2 skaters last year.
Taipei city government official Liu Chia-tseng said the city's inline skating population has reached 200,000 and that the sport is gaining popularity nationwide, with an estimated 4 million bladers.
The winner of the 42 km course will be awarded the top prize of US$5,250, while the 20 km course -- open only to Taiwanese citizens -- will offer a first prize of NT$12,000.
Registration to compete will remain open until April 5. For more information, visit www.ctsra.org.tw or download an entry form at www.ctsra.org.tw/english.doc.

DOC.HEADLINE: THSRC TO COMPLETE NT$6 BILLION CAPITAL-INCREASING PLAN IN APRIL

TEXT.P: Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp (THSRC) officials promised Friday that the company will complete this month its delayed plan to increase NT$6 billion (US$190.47 million) in capital.
The plan was originally scheduled to be completed by March 31.
THSRC Vice President of Public Affairs Arthur Chiang explained that the plan was deferred because of a processing delay with some investors.

As a result of the delay, the THSRC is due to pay interest to the bank, consortium with which the company has a contract for a NT$323.3 billion loan, at an annual rate of 0.1 percent payable according to the number of days delayed, Chiang said.
Chiang also said the company is keeping to its schedule to have the high-speed railway start operations in October.
With trial runs being carried out on part of the 345-km track linking Taipei and Kaohsiung since Jan. 26, the trial will be expanded to cover the entire track in late April, he said.
In addition, the speed of the trial runs was increased gradually to 120 kph March 31 and is expected to be further increased to 300 kph in July, he added.
According to the THSRC, the construction of the railway system is 82.1 percent complete. The Taipei-Kaohsiung route will only take about 90 minutes once the system is launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S PLANNED CHINA VISIT HARSHLY CRITICIZED BY WUFI

TEXT.P: A staunch Taiwan independence heavyweight lashed out Friday at the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , arguing that a visit to mainland China planned by its chairman and a 10-point consensus inked between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) will downgrade the status of Taiwan in dealings with China.

Ng Chiau-tong, chairman of the World United Formosans for Independence (WUFI), harshly criticized the KMT, saying that what the party is doing now at a time when Beijing has stepped up its threats against Taiwan with its Anti-Secession Law will only make Taiwan-China disputes a problem of China's internal affairs.

Ng was referring to a just-concluded five-day visit to China by a KMT delegation led by Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang. Chiang's visit is widely seen as a prelude to a planned visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan in June before he steps down from the party's top post in August.

Commenting on the 10-point consensus reached between the KMT delegation and CCP officials last Wednesday in Beijing, Ng claimed that the pact has seriously infringed upon Taiwan's sovereignty and has damaged Taiwan's interests.

It is useless and meaningless to extend more olive branches to China, an enemy of Taiwan, at a time when Beijing has readied itself with the Anti-Secession Law to curb Taiwan through "non-peaceful means," he claimed.
Politicians should have wisdom to deal with politics and must not do things that are harmful to the country's interests, he said.
He also suggested that the government toughen its stance toward China to protect Taiwan business interests there.

The 10-point consensus clinched by the KMT and CCP focuses on private sector exchanges between Taiwan and China, ranging from cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural and financial cooperation to the opening of air links and academic exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT TRADE BICKERING OVER 2008 TAIWAN EXPO

TEXT.P: Legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lambasted the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday over legislation of a statute governing the 2008 Taiwan Expo, saying that a legislative consensus on such an enactment could be reached if the KMT was more cooperative.

Four DPP lawmakers, including Tsai Chi-fang, said that legislative consensus on the enactment of a 2008 Taiwan Expo statute was about to be reached but the absence of the KMT Caucus endorsement prevented it.
Tsai said that the DPP legislators will instigate a protest at the KMT headquarters if the KMT Caucus fails to sign up to the consensus before the end of next week.

Discounting the DPP's challenge, Chen Chieh, a KMT legislative whip, said that the KMT basically supports the notion of Taiwan hosting a world expo in 2008 that the DPP has claimed will create some 60,000 job opportunities. However, Chen said it must be a program that will benefit the development of Taiwan's tourism as well as the economy.

A world exposition like the 2008 Taiwan Expo should serve to raise Taiwan's visibility in the international community and help prop up the country's domestic economy, Chen said, adding that the KMT will remain reserved toward it if the party believes the expo is being used merely as a political tool of the ruling DPP aimed at broadening the DPP's support base for the 2008 presidential election.

Chen described the rationale behind the initial plan of the expo as "fishy, " as the main sponsor of the expo is registered as a non-profit organization, a move he claimed is apparently aimed at evading the regulations of the procurement and budget law.

According to officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the 2008 Taiwan Expo slated to be held in Taoyuan, Tainan and Chiayi from May to September 2008 is expected to attract 5.5 million visitors.

The purpose of the national exposition, to be organized by the ministry, is to make the country a world-class technology hub by attracting visitors from home and abroad and to secure the country's international status as a base for supplying technological products worldwide so that the country can attract foreign investment that will allow the nation's economy to develop, the officials said.

The exposition venue in Taoyuan will be dedicated to high technology, with topics including digitized operations in the home, mobile life, biotechnology and nanotechnology. In Tainan, the event will center around sustainable ecology and environmental protection, while in Chiayi, it will revolve around history and culture, with subjects including the visual arts, performance art and animated film art, they said.
Thus far, the ministry has cultivated a total of 5,500 professionals that will take part in the exposition, they said, adding that it is expected to create 41,000 jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TALKS MEANINGLESS WITHOUT PRIOR DOMESTIC CONSENSUS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian questioned the significance Friday of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) talks with China given the lack of domestic consensus on the issue.

Chen was commenting on a 10-point consensus reached during a Wednesday meeting between KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who wrapped up a five-day visit to China and returned to Taipei Friday, and Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office.
He made the remarks while receiving a delegation from the overseas Chinese community in Osaka, Japan.

The consensus covers a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, protection of Taiwan businessmen in China, Chinese fishermen, and an easing of China's financial market.

"We have our own country and our own government, " the president said, adding that "anyone engaging in consultation and negotiations with others on issues that are sensitive, serious and important has to get permission or authorization from the government."

"If (the KMT) has reached no consensus with the government, and if there is no consensus sought first within Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties, then what is the significance of wishfully promoting a consensus between the KMT and the Communist Party of China?" Chen asked.

He said that cross-strait relation is a fundamental issue on which Taiwan's existence hinges, which he said will not only affect national security, but will also be crucial to the fundamental rights and wellbeing of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

The president stressed that different political parties can have different views and advocacy, but "Taiwan's national interests should have one voice and one voice only -- and that voice should represent the will of the people and should be a common language and common voice in defending the overall interests of Taiwan -- when facing the outside world."
He said that a divided house will not stand and that a cross-strait policy that is in disarray will not endure.
Faced with ever daunting tests and challenges, Taiwan must be even more unified, the president said, adding that only with a unified Taiwan will the country prosper.

The president also said that lowering cross-strait tension, creating reconciliation and fostering an atmosphere of cooperation between the two sides to break the cross-strait stalemate will be a test of the wisdom of the leaders on each side of the strait, as well as of the leaders of the ruling and opposition parties.

He expressed the hope that the ruling and opposition parties will stick to the stance of "Taiwan first, and Taiwan's separate identity" and that they will put aside their differences in an orderly manner to work toward pursuing lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen also expressed gratitude for a series of recent friendly gestures by Japan, including the granting of visa to former President Lee Teng-hui, listing peaceful dialogue to settle cross-strait disputes as the common goal of the United States and Japan, visa-free privileges for Taiwan people during this year's Aichi Expo, Japanese government support for Taiwan into the World Health Organization, and Japan's urging of peaceful settlement of the Taiwan issue in the wake of the recent passage of China's Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY AFFILIATION NOT AN ISSUE WITH PRESIDENTIAL ADVISERS: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Presidential advisers are not chosen because of their party affiliation and "non-green personnel" have never been excluded, a spokesman for the Presidential Office said Friday.
Chen Wen-tzong, director of the Department of Public Affairs of the Presidential Office, was responding to comments made the previous day by Stan Shih, former chairman of the Acer Group.

Shih, who has been acting as a national policy advisor to the president, said he has always maintained a neutral political stance, but as current presidential advisers exclude "non-green personnel," referring to the "green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, if he were to continue to advise the president, people might get the wrong impression. Therefore, Shih said, he hopes President Chen Shui-bian will no longer ask him to serve that post; and if he does, he will have to decline.
Shih currently heads another investment institution.

The spokesman said that the posts of senior presidential adviser and national policy adviser have terms of one year, and that the president reviews and selects new advisors, if necessary, every May 20.

When making these selections, the spokesman said, the president takes a number of factors into consideration, including where a person is from, their ethnicity and their affiliation with civic groups or trade organizations so that the advisor can be as "multifaceted, professional and useful" as possible, the spokesman said.
Judging from the current list of presidential advisers, the president has never excluded "non-green personnel, " adding that the president has "always respected their views," he added.

Chen Chin-chun, a DPP whip in the legislature, said that the Presidential Office cares most about whether advisers have expertise in their own fields, whether they are contributing to Taiwan and is unconcerned about which political party a person favors.

William C. D. Lai, another DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said that Shih is the second victim of Beijing's newly passed Anti-Secession Law, following Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chimei Group.

Hsu, a supporter of President Chen in his first presidential bid in 2000, said on the eve of the 326 March for Democracy and Peace, in which hundreds of thousands of Taiwan people took to the streets to show their displeasure over the Anti-Secession Law, said "Taiwan and the mainland are part of one China," and that he felt more at ease after the law was passed.

Lai said that Shih is an admirable entrepreneur who has contributed a great deal to Taiwan's economic development, but he said that the legislative caucus is concerned about the knock-on effect Beijing's law is having on business people.
He said he was worried that corrupt Chinese officials could use the law as a tool to blackmail or persecute Taiwan business people.
Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the DPP's Department of Culture and Information, said that entrepreneurs have a social responsibility, and they should contribute to the country.
However, Cheng said, the DPP will respect Shih's freedom of choice and will not give the incident a political spin.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 CIVIL CONFERENCE FOR CHILDREN HELD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The 2005 Civil Conference for Children was held in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Friday, with a total of 86 children participating.
Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai also attended the conference and addressed the children, dubbing them "little self-governing mayors."

He promised the children -- selected from elementary schools around the city -- that he will do his utmost to digitize the elementary schools in the city and create a good English-learning environment so that children can communicate with foreigners in English during the World Games slated to be held in the city in 2009.
He also encouraged them to use public transport to reduce air pollution in the city.
Chen promised that he will make the city environmentally friendly by reducing energy consumption and instead use natural power sources such as solar or wind power to operate street lamps.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Lukin Blames All Sides in Chechnya.
The country's ombudsman, Vladimir Lukin, criticized all sides in the Chechen conflict over human rights abuses and bemoaned a lack of press freedom in his annual report published Thursday, but he also surprisingly railed against high gasoline prices and s aid state television was intolerably full of commercials.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Pope in 'Very Grave' Condition After Suffering a Heart Attack.
The Vatican said early Friday that Pope John Paul II had been given last rites, but decided himself not to go to the hospital.
The Wall Street Journal: Probe of AIG Hits On More Potential Problems.
Authorities are taking a deeper look at accounting at American International Group Inc. to examine actions the company may have taken to polish performance measures closely watched by insurance-industry investors, people familiar with the matter say.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST NOT JOIN WHA UNDER PRC-LINKED NAME: MEDICAL EXPERT

TEXT.P: Taiwan must not take part in World Health Assembly (WHA) activities under any name associated with China, even though China has publicly shown willingness to help Taiwan medical experts to play a role in the organization, the leader of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance (FMPA) said Friday.

Alliance president Wu Shu-min was commenting on a goodwill overture from Tang Jiaxuan, a People's Republic of China official, that Beijing is willing to help Taiwanese medical experts have a WHA role.

Wu said he had not yet fully grasped the full meaning of the overture, but as the leader of the FMPA, he would like the World Health Organization (WHO) to formally invite Taiwan to participate as a full member instead of as an observer, as offering observer status would be "too condescending" on the part of the WHO.

He said he would also not accept the name Chinese Taipei -- the name Taiwan uses in order to participate in most international events. Only the name of the Republic of China or Taiwan is acceptable, he said, adding that any other name would be "dwarfing" the country.

What is needed is an official invitation from the WHO extended to Taiwan, said Kao Ming-chien, a National Taiwan University Hospital doctor who is also a former board chairman of the Taiwan Neurological Surgery Association.

Kao said the best scenario is for Taiwan to join the WHO as a "health entity." As the government has spent huge sums of money lobbying Third World countries without achieving much, he suggested that Taipei seize this opportunity to directly negotiate with Beijing over the island's role in the world health community.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TOOL OF CHINESE COMMUNISTS' UNITED FRONT TACTICS: DPP

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials accused the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday of becoming a tool of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) to carry out its united front tactics against Taiwan.
The officials were referring to the just-concluded visit to China by a KMT delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang.

DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan claimed that the trip was plotted by the Chinese communists as part of its united front scheme to divide Taiwan and said the KMT has disgraced itself and Taiwan by dancing to Beijing's tune.

He pointed out that the KMT opposed a party-to-party model for cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations when it was in power and is now making what he called "a preposterous twist" by supporting precisely that form of talks.

The KMT delegation held talks with officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office Wednesday and reached a 10-point consensus on a wide range of issues including cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businessmen, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.
During a meeting with the delegation Thursday, Jia Qinglin, chairman of the People's Political Consultative Conference of China, extended an invitation to KMT Chairman Lien Chan to visit China.

Cheng said that despite the high-profile reception provided to the KMT, China was styling itself as a sovereign that was "admitting the KMT to an audience" in an attempt to reverse an international climate that is extremely unfavorable to Beijing after the enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.
Cheng said the KMT's move has done great harm to Taiwan because it has fallen into a trap set by Beijing to make cross-strait relations an internal affair of China.
Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, urged the KMT to stop pushing for hasty unification between Taiwan and China against the will of the majority people in the nation.
Also, Lai said, the KMT should not have established any agreement with Beijing.

In response to the DPP's criticism, KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh claimed that the visit was aimed at "completing what the government has failed to accomplish" and at "serving the people of Taiwan, " and had nothing to do with the issues of unification and independence.
Chen said it is ridiculous for the DPP to start a smear campaign to paint the KMT as a pro-China party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EVALUATING IMPACT OF CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: MOFA

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Friday that the government will take proper measures concerning cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges after completing its assessment of the impact of China's Anti-Secession Law.
Chen said the government will not push forward any policy abruptly before the assessment is finished or accept any condition put forth by China.

Chen was referring to the 10-point consensus reached between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and officials of China's Taiwan Affairs Office in Beijing on Wednesday on a wide range of issues including cross-strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businessmen, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

According to Chen, the agreement with the KMT after the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan was a "hypocritical trick" by Beijing to try to divide Taiwan.
If China is truly sincere about improving its relations with Taiwan, it should open dialogue with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SAYS ITS 10-POINT DEAL WITH CHINA IS BENEFICIAL FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The 10-point consensus reached between the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) is beneficial for Taiwan, and Taiwan and mainland China should shelve their disputes to create a win-win atmosphere for both sides, KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said Friday.
Cheng made the call after a ranking KMT delegation returned from China to Taiwan earlier the same day after concluding a five-day visit, which took it to Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing.

The 34-member mission, led by KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, forged a 10-point consensus late Wednesday in Beijing with CCP officials to bolster civilian exchanges between Taiwan and China. Chiang's visit was the first of its kind by a ranking KMT official in 56 years since the party retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war in 1949.

Claiming that the trip was fruitful since the 10-point consensus is beneficial to Taiwan and in the national interest, Cheng, however, lamented that the government and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have smeared the trip, calling the response from both "sad, biased and myopic."

She said that the government should feel happy for the beneficial results that the KMT mission obtained in China and she urged President Chen Shui-bian to open his mind and build on this positive development in cross- Taiwan Strait relations.
President Chen's way of thinking can decide if Taiwan and China can enjoy a mutually beneficial relationship, or if the two go to war, she said.

President Chen described the 10-point consensus as " wishful thinking" on the part of the KMT, while the DPP's publicity department director, Cheng Wen-tsan, said that the KMT has turned out to be a tool in the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) propaganda offensive.

The 10-point consensus touches on a wide range of issues, with agricultural exports to China and regular cross-strait charter passenger flights the two most urgent issues for the people on Taiwan, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Wednesday.

Despite harsh criticisms from the independence-leaning camp, two more delegations of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) will head for China later this month for talks on agriculture and air links.

The KMT delegation will discuss Taiwan's farm exports and the opening of regular charter passenger and cargo flights between the two sides, all issues covered in the KMT-CCP 10-point consensus, according to a party official.
The PFP delegation, probably to be headed by Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung, is slated to hold talks with China on agricultural issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LAMBASTES KMT FOR 'PARADOXICAL VALUES' IN APPROACH TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu lambasted the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Friday for what she called the party's "paradoxical values" in its approach to China.

In a vocal criticism of a just-concluded visit to China by a KMT delegation led by one of its vice chairman, P. K. Chiang, Lu said the opposition party had been known for its firm stance against communism, but its current leaders have baffled the world by sending a delegation to visit China, ignoring the 700 Chinese missiles targeting Taiwan.
The party's unexpected about-face from being anti-communist to being pro-communist only underlined the fact that the party has "paradoxical values," Lu said.

In light of the contradictory approaches of the KMT, Lu said the party owes the people an explanation of why it used so much money over the nearly 55 years it was in power to brace for a war with China when now it fawns over the Chinese Communists.

During those years, Lu said, no one could associate with a Chinese Communist without being thrown into prison. But why is it that since the KMT lost power over the country, it has abandoned its cause? Lu asked.
Lu said the KMT should be thankful that it is because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party embraces democracy, which gives the KMT the right to toady up even to the Chinese Communists.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'THREE IN ONE' ELECTIONS WILL NOT BENEFIT ONLY ONE PARTY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that his suggestion of holding three local elections simultaneously is not just for the interest of one party, but for the wellbeing of the people and to save the nation money.

Hsieh made the remarks in an interpellation session in the Legislative Yuan during which he also said that it was not his intention to consult with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the idea to seek their approval or ask them whether it would benefit the party in particular.
The premier also said that electoral reform will not be an easy task and the obtaining of "three-in-one" elections will be a winding path.
Hsieh was referring to holding the elections for city mayors and county magistrates, city and county councilmen, and village and township heads at the same time.

Hsieh's remarks came in the wake of a closed-door talk Thursday with DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang. Su has warned that the move is doomed to fail because it will open the door to massive vote-buying in the absence of complementary measures.

The premier also said that whether to hold the three local elections simultaneously will be decided by the Central Election Commission, and that the announcement of the Executive Yuan is "not a final decision."

Legislator Huang Teh-fu of the opposition Kuomintang said that the Taiwan provincial election committee is in charge of city and county elections, while the village and township elections are overseen by the city and county election committee, neither of which are under the jurisdiction of the Central Election Commission, and the Cabinet's announcement of "three-in-one" elections exceeds its authority.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ACCEPTS INVITATION TO VISIT CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday during a trip to Japan that he will accept an invitation to visit China made by a Chinese Communist Party official.
However, Lien said when he would go would be figured out after he returns to Taiwan.
Lien described the visit of a 34-member KMT delegation headed by party vice chairman P. K. Chiang, which returned to Taiwan from its five-day visit to China Friday, as a "journey of peace."
Jia Qinglin, a member of the China's Central Standing Committee, invited Lien to visit China during his meeting with Chiang in Beijing Thursday.
Lien pointed out that cross-strait relations have been strained for quite a long time, especially in the past five years since President Chen Shui-bian took office in 2000.
He said that he has said repeatedly that he wants to embark on a "journey of peace" to the mainland for the sake of cross-strait peace and stability.

Noting that Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office Wednesday, which covers a wide range of issues including cross-strait transportation, farm products, protection of Taiwan businessmen on the mainland, mainland fishermen and the easing of entry into China's financial market, Lien said that there are many things across the Taiwan Strait that still need to be worked out.
Lien said that some of the things in the 10-point consensus can be quickly carried out or promoted, others will need to be legislated and the KMT intends to act on them duly.
He expressed the hope that when he visits China there will be some substantial progress on these matters.

Regarding the election for the KMT chairmanship, due on July 16, Lien said that the party lost the presidency five years ago because of divisions within the party, and this is why it has to engage in comprehensive reforms.
The election of the chairman will held through a popular vote, and he hopes the election can be held in an open and fair way to boost the party's competitiveness and popularity, Lien said.

He also said that he had exchanged views on matters of mutual concern with several Japanese political figures, and also explained to them the views of the KMT and the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) on ROC-Japan relations and cross-strait relations.

Lien also said that he has no plan to meet with Koh Se-kai, the Republic of China's envoy to Japan on this visit, adding that he and pro-independence Koh are far apart in their views of political issues which has greatly affected their personal relations despite the fact that they were high school and university classmates.

DOC.HEADLINE: APRIL FOOL'S PRANK OF CHINESE ATTACK LANDS STUDENT IN HOT WATER

TEXT.P: It was meant as an April Fool's joke, but a university student's Internet post Friday saying that China had begun a " decapitation strike" against Taiwan didn't make police laugh. The student is being investigated for violating the public order maintenance law.

Officials of the Criminal Investigation Bureau said although the story was intended as a joke, the undergraduate, who posted under the name of a local media organization, was spreading an "unfounded rumor, " which according to the law is subject to a penalty of community service of up to three days or a fine of up to NT$30,000.

According to prosecutors at the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office, the undergraduate is also guilty of impersonating another -- a form of forgery -- and any media organizations or individuals who suffered losses as a result of the post can file a lawsuit and ask for compensation from the student.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO TO CREATE TASK FORCE TO REVITALIZE TAIWAN'S ENTERTAINMENT INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) will recruit professionals in the fields of marketing and venture-capital to form a task force to promote Taiwan's digital audio and visual entertainment industry, the head of the GIO, Pasuya Yao, said Friday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Yao said that Taiwan's entertainment industry, which was in the leading position of the global Chinese community, has been losing ground in recent years, citing statistics that show that the industry's annual output fell to NT$4.4 billion (US$139.6 million) in 2004 from NT$12 billion in 1997.

Noting that the government recently set a target of producing 100 films a year as part of its efforts to promote the domestic entertainment industry, Yao said the GIO will spend millions of new Taiwan dollars this month to recruit professionals and talented persons in relevant sectors, including production, marketing, copyright law and venture-capital, to form a task force whose aim will be to better the local entertainment industry.

The task force will serve as a platform to match human talent with financial resources to revitalize the domestic entertainment industry by exploring markets for films produced in Taiwan, he explained.
Also, Yao went on, the GIO will invite key figures to discuss the global entertainment industry's development trends and to make suggestions on what sort of films Taiwan would be best at producing.
Yao expressed the hope that state-run enterprises will join the effort to revitalize the domestic entertainment industry by investing in domestic films.
He said that he will travel to the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung Saturday to try to persuade the China Steel Corp. to invest in the production of domestic films.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA-BASED BUSINESSMAN FINED BY TAIWAN SAYS HE USES U.S. PASSPORT

TEXT.P: A Shanghai-based businessman who was fined by Taiwan authorities for investing in China said in an e-mail to local journalists Friday that he is a citizen of the United States and therefore not subject to Taiwan's law.

Richard Chang, who is the chief executive officer of the Shanghai-based Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp., said in the e-mail issued from his Shanghai office that he had studied and worked in the United States for many years and has been using an American passport.

Furthermore, Chang said, the hi-tech industry, such as the manufacture of semiconductors, knows no boundaries. "I am glad that I am involved in the building of many semiconductor manufacturing factories in various countries," he said.
Although, he has lived in China since February 2000, Chang said his passion for Taiwan and the United States remains the same.
He vowed to devote himself to his job in Shanghai for the benefit of the shareholders of his company.
Chang was fined NT$5 million (US$159,311) by the Ministry of Economic Affairs the previous day for investing his company in Shanghai in violation of Taiwan's regulations.
The ministry asked Chang to withdraw his investment in China within six months or more fines will be imposed on him until he obeys the order.

In handing down the decision, the ministry said Chang was still considered a legal resident of Taiwan between 2000 and 2002 and is therefore considered to have been living in Taiwan during that time, ergo he is subject to Taiwan's China investment regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF: INT'L PUBLICITY CAMPAIGN READY FOR TAIWAN'S WHA BID

TEXT.P: Taiwan is preparing for an international publicity campaign to drum up support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) , Government Information Office (GIO) chief Pasuya Yao said Friday.

Noting that the international community has shown sympathy for Taiwan in the wake of China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law which permits it to use force against Taiwan, Yao said it is a good opportunity for Taiwan to translate their sympathy into support for Taiwan's efforts to enhance its international profile.
Yao said the publicity campaign will be organized by the National Security Council and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the GIO will do its part according to their instructions.

After the successful March 26 march which was called to show the country's displeasure at the Anti-Secession Law, Yao said the government is waiting to see how China will respond before formulating Taiwan's policies.
However, Yao said, the GIO has ordered the shooting of several television commercials which will be aired on foreign television stations when the time is ripe, Yao said.

These commercials, which feature Taiwan's success in checking severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , and the Chinese military threat against Taiwan, are sure to make a strong case for Taiwan's bid to enter international organizations.

In line with the government's policy of prohibiting political parties and government agencies from running television stations, Yao said the state-owned Taiwan Television Enterprise will be privatalized while state-own Chinese Television System will be converted into a public station which will be merged with Public Television, Hakka Television and Aboriginal Television into a public television group.
The establishment of this public television group to be financed with a government budget should be based on a law which is still being hammered out at the GIO, Yao said.

As to the moving information banners at the bottom of the screen which are used extensively by local television stations to make a pitch for their news about celebrities' sexual scandals and affairs, Yao said he will ask local television executives in a meeting next week to use crawls only to show important government policies or urgent breaking news before he uses the GIO's power given by law to check it.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE-BASED PARK INCREASE

TEXT.P: Sales from the Southern Taiwan Science-based Park amounted to NT$41.57 billion (US$1.32 billion) in the first two months of this year, posting an annual growth of 22.22 percent, according to statistics released Friday by the park's administration.
The tallies show that the optoelectronics industry had the lion's share of the park's total sales during the period between January and February, with NT$28.8 billion or 69.3 percent.

The semiconductor industry is ranked in second place with NT$11.46 billion or 27.58 percent of the total, followed by precision machinery, with NT$770 million; the biotechnology industry, with NT$216 million; computer peripherals, with NT$178 million; and telecommunications, with NT$114 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 2, or the 24th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro-French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER CALLS FOR CHEN-LIEN-SOONG MEETING ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmaker said Saturday that President Chen Shui-bian and the two leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" should meet as soon as possible to forge a national consensus on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that a major obstacle to cross-strait relations lies in divisions in Taiwan's ruling and opposition camps over the issue, PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said he hopes Chen and the two "pan-blue alliance" leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- should meet to forge a consensus on the development of cross-strait ties.

Liu made the remarks after a high-profile KMT delegation signed a 10-point consensus with China in Beijing earlier this week, which has drawn scathing criticism from the Taiwan independence-leaning "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS URGE SPEEDY COMPLETION OF OMBUDSMEN CONSIDERATION

TEXT.P: Two legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Saturday to speedily complete the consideration of Control Yuan nominations.

Legislators Hsieh Hsin-ni and Huang Wei-tze noted that the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has been moribund for over two months after the six-year term of the previous 29 ombudsmen expired January 31.

President Chen Shui-bian nominated a new list for approval by the previous Legislative Yuan late last year, but the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party were dissatisfied with the nominations -- especially that of Clement C.P. Chang, who was nominated for Control Yuan president -- and refused to screen the list.

The two DPP legislators pointed out that the Control Yuan has received 3,496 appeal cases between Feb. 1 and April 1, but no Control Yuan members are available to handle them, undermining the rights of the people.
Also, Control Yuan members are required to monitor national examinations, so their absence will also affect the rights of more than 128,000 participants in various national examinations, they said.
Hsieh expressed the hope that the ruling and the opposition parties can put aside their differences and begin to screen the list seriously.
Huang also said that the legislature will renege upon its constitutional obligations if it refuses to screen the list.

He pointed out that the term of current city and county heads will expire Dec. 20 and according to the political donation law, the aspirants for the city and county chief positions can start to accept political donations only after applying to the Control Yuan to set up a special bank account in which to deposit the donations.
If the members of the Control Yuan cannot be produced in time, it will affect the exercise of government authority and the rights of the hopefuls, he added.
