Also, Yao went on, the GIO will invite key figures to discuss the global entertainment industry's development trends and to make suggestions on what sort of films Taiwan would be best at producing.
Yao expressed the hope that state-run enterprises will join the effort to revitalize the domestic entertainment industry by investing in domestic films.
He said that he will travel to the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung Saturday to try to persuade the China Steel Corp. to invest in the production of domestic films.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HAS NO COMMENT ON INVITATION FOR PARTY CHIEF TO VISIT CHINA

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) declined to comment Saturday on an invitation from Beijing for PFP Chairman James Soong to visit China.

Chen Yunlin, head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said in a media interview a day earlier that People's Political Consultative Conference Chairman Jia Qinglin has extended an invitation to Soong in addition to opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.
The PFP responded in a statement that the party follows a steady, pragmatic and foresighted approach in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait issues and has never scrambled for credit and selfish gains.

A four-point declaration issued by Chinese President Hu Jintao last month and the 10-point agreement reached between Soong and President Chen Shui-bian in February represent a rational and pragmatic voice across the strait, the PFP said.

While Hu has reprised Beijing's policies of "one China" and peaceful unification and its opposition to Taiwan independence, Chen has reiterated his "five-noes" commitment including no independence for Taiwan and no change to the cross-strait status quo during his term.

According to the PFP, a 10-point consensus established between the KMT and the Chinese authorities during a just-concluded visit to Beijing by a delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang has not surpassed the spirit of the two documents or of a cross-strait peace legislation promoted by the PFP.
The party said it is a top priority to enact the law to set up an institutionalized framework for cross-strait peace.
Meanwhile, Chen Chih-pin, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said it is not appropriate for Soong to visit China until the PFP-initiated peace promotion bill is passed.
According to Chen, without the law, any talks held by Soong with the Beijing authorities would have no legal basis and any agreement coming out of the talks would have problems being realized.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Panel Denounces Spy Agencies. More than three years after the Sept.11 attacks, the CIA and other U.S. intelligence agencies remain poorly coordinated, have resisted reform and produce work that is "increasingly irrelevant," a presidential commission concluded in a scathing new report.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
THE NEW YORK TIMES: Weakened Pope Nears Death
The Vatican announced on Friday that Pope John Paul II's breathing had become shallow and some organs had begun to fail.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP DISAPPROVES OF KMT'S PANDERING TO CHINA TO BOOST LEVERAGE

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang expressed his disapproval Saturday of what he described as the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) collaboration with China in an attempt to increase its political leverage at home.
Su said during a trip to central Taichung City that the KMT's "journey of kowtowing" to China has obscured the protest voiced by the people of Taiwan against Beijing's Anti-Secession Law.

He pointed out that KMT Chairman Lien Chan, during his term as premier in 1993, openly dismissed a party-to-party model for cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations as a "downgrading of the country's international status," but he is now following exactly this model.
Su was referring to a just-concluded visit to China by a KMT delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, which reports claim have paved the way for a later trip to China by Lien.

During the visit, the delegation also reached a 10-point consensus with the Beijing authorities on a wide range of issues including cross-strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businessmen, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang pointed out that the talks held by the KMT with the Chinese Communist Party were not authorized by the government and thus do not represent the opinions of the 23 million people in Taiwan.

On the KMT's promise that it will report to the government on the details of its agreement with Beijing, Lee said this would be totally unacceptable because the government has its own timetable for promoting cross-strait exchanges and remains in control of cross-strait issues.
Lee said the KMT's move was tantamount to conceding the cross-strait issue to China, which he said has undermined the national interests of Taiwan.
According to Lee, it is one of Beijing's united front tactics against Taiwan to deny the sovereign status of the Republic of China and the legitimacy of the ROC government.

By supporting party-to-party negotiations with the Chinese communists, the KMT has fallen into a trap set by Beijing to create a false impression that cross-strait relations are an internal affair of China, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS CALL FOR PHASEOUT OF OUTDATED MILITARY SONGS

TEXT.P: Two ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators asked the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Saturday to phase out what they called outdated military songs, particularly those featuring strong Chinese ideology.

DPP legislators Hsueh Ling and Lin Chin-hsing said at a news conference that the singing of pro-China songs in the military has become "ridiculous and absurd" after China enacted its Anti-Secession Law justifying the use of force against Taiwan.
The two lawmakers demanded that the MND delete all those pro-China songs from its officially sanctioned list by July 1.
On March 1, the MND issued a writ to all military personnel to stop singing the song "I Love Chunghua (Chinese)" during evening roll call.

Hsueh and Lin urged the MND to examine all 180 of the songs that the MND requires military personnel to learn during their service period, and to immediately abolish 10 of them, such as "China Will Be Strong" and "The Chinese."
"It is ridiculous for our soldiers to sing those songs as it is actually the enemy that such songs encourage," Lin said.
The move was seen as the latest act by Taiwanese people to show their strong resolve against the Anti-Secession Law after the "one million-man" protest march in Taipei last weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE SECTOR EXPANDS IN TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The service sector generated NT$6.9 trillion (US$219.5 billion) , or 68.6 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) in 2004, beating Singapore's 63 percent, South Korea's 55 percent and China's 34 percent, an economic official said Saturday.

Because of this good performance, Taiwan's economic growth rate was 5.7 percent last year, according to Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, who added that the service sector's expansion has reached the level of mature economies elsewhere in the world.

However, Hu said, despite the expanding revenue in the sector, its employment rate remained at a lower level compared with those in mature economies, and he noted that the service sector's employment rate accounted for 0.85 percent of the GDP in 2004, lower than an average 1.0 percent in economically mature countries.

To accelerate Taiwan's economic growth, the government has mapped out a wide range of strategies to boost development of the service industry, including finance, product distribution, communication and media, medical treatment and health care, manpower training and management, tourism and sport and leisure activities, culture, design, information and environmental protection.

He indicated that the goal for the service sector's annual growth has been set at a level of 6.1 percent during the period between 2004 to 2008, while its GDP ratio is aimed at the level of 71.4 percent by 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA USING 'UNITED FRONT TACTIC' ON TAIWAN'S WHA BID: DPP

TEXT.P: China is using a "united front tactic" on Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) with the intention of making Taiwan part of China against the wishes of local people, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Saturday.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang made the remarks following reports that China might be willing to help Taiwan enter the WHA, the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO), under the title "Taiwan, China."

Noting that the government has been pushing for Taiwan's entry into the WHO under the designation of "Taiwan, " insisting that both sides of Taiwan Strait are two sovereign entities, Lee said the name "Taiwan, China" would be a "united front tactic" of Beijing, to which the Taiwan people will be strongly opposed.

Lo Chih-ming, convener of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) legislative caucus, said that his party will not accept the way China is downgrading the island by helping Taiwan join the WHA under the name "Taiwan, China, " suggesting that the country enter the world organization with the title "health entity."
Claiming that Taiwan does not need such help from China in its WHA bid, Lo suggested that the government continue to solicit support from the international community, including the United States.
Lee Yung-ping, legislative caucus leader of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , declined to comment as the report had not been confirmed.
However, she recommended that the nation use a title that will not cause controversy when joining international organizations.

Noting that "Taiwan, China" would make people believe that Taiwan is only a region of China, Lee suggested the title "Chinese Taipei." Lee said such a title has been used in Taiwan's participation in several international organizations.
Meanwhile, the opposition Kuomintang welcomed China's overture, but opposed China's setting limits to the name by which Taiwan will be referred in the WHA.

KMT legislative caucus leader Chen Chie noted that his party welcomes the overture from China, saying that "both sides of the Taiwan Strait should open their doors for dialogue in pursuit of the welfare of the people on both sides." He added that China should not impose any limits on the name Taiwan should use if it is really willing to create a reconciliatory climate between the two sides.

The KMT claims to the "only political party in Taiwan" that is working to reconcile with China, as its vice chairman P.K. Chiang has just led a big delegation on a five-day visit there, where he met several high-ranking Chinese officials and inked a 10-point consensus with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: INSURER PROMOTES INSURANCE FOR MOTHERS, BABIES

TEXT.P: The fact that more and more women over the age of 30 or 35 are bearing children in Taiwan has prompted local insurers to take advantage of the situation by offering a product for both future mothers and their unborn babies.

Statistics of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics show that in 2003, the number of pregnant women aged over 30 accounted for over 36 percent of all pregnant women in the country, up 10 percent from the level of 10 years ago.
The number of child-bearing women aged over 35 accounted for nearly 10 percent that year, representing almost 5 percent growth over the level of a decade ago, according to the tallies.

To exploit this potential market, ING Life Insurance Company of America Taiwan Branch has recently introduced a special insurance policy for both child-bearing mothers and their unborn babies, an ING Life executive said Saturday.

The insurance covers medical treatment under certain circumstances, for example if the insured baby is found to suffer a genetic disease, the official noted, adding that the "women plus baby" insurance serves both as life and savings insurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAUNCHES TAICHUNG NA ELECTION CAMPAIGN CENTER

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launched its campaign center in Taichung County in central Taiwan Saturday for next month's "mission-oriented" National Assembly elections.

DPP Chairman Su Chen-chang presided over the opening ceremony of the campaign center, located in front of the party's branch headquarters in Taichung County. Nine of the DPP's 156 candidates will run from the Taichung County constituency for the May 14 elections for the mission-oriented National Assembly whose core task will be to approve a draft package of constitutional amendments adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August.

According to the Constitution, amendments can only be carried out by the National Assembly, which will ironically be abolished after holding its scheduled one-month meeting to endorse the legislature-initiated amendment package.
The draft package of constitutional amendments will include:
-- Abolish the National Assembly;
-- Reduce the number of legislators by half to 113;
-- Change the current voting system to a "two vote" system in which voters will cast one ballot for the party and one for the candidate of their choice; and
-- Include the right to referendum in the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REJECTS WHO ACCESSION UNDER 'ONE CHINA' FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh dismissed Saturday a proposal reportedly put forth by Beijing for Taiwan to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) under the name of "Taiwan, China" as no more than a ploy to block Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).
According to the reports, Beijing has offered to help Taiwan take part in the WHA under the condition that the island must use the name "Taiwan, China."

Hsieh pointed out that Taiwan has fought for a long time for its right to join the WHO but said it will not agree to an arrangement to become a part of the People's Republic of China in order to gain WHO membership.
The WHA is the WHO's governing body or decision-making arm.

On reports that KMT Chairman Lien Chan plans to visit China in May to negotiate a peace accord with Beijing, Hsieh pointed out that no-one has the right to establish any agreement with China without the government's authorization.
He urged political parties to stop using cross-Taiwan Strait issues as a means of partisan competition, saying that unity is required in Taiwan for the well-being of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT URGES MORE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui called Saturday for more efforts on the part of both the government and the people to conserve Taiwan's soil and water.

Lee made the appeal while participating in a tree-planting activity organized by a group of his supporters in Nantou County, central Taiwan, which was hard-hit by a devastating earthquake in September 1999.

He noted that although the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has been working on the conservation of the country's soil and water, prohibiting cultivation on one third of the nation's slope lands, this is still far from sufficient.

Stressing that Taiwan's land has been over exploited and seriously damaged in the process of pursuing economic growth during the last several decades, which has resulted in landslides and cave-ins almost every time there is a natural disaster, Lee said it is the time for everybody to take action to protect the natural environment.
Meanwhile, describing Taiwan as an immigrant society, Lee urged the different ethnic groups in the nation to respect each other so that they can prosper.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROMISES AID FOR INDIGENOUS CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh promised Saturday that the government will provide assistance to the nation's indigenous children to help them get a head start in life.

Attending an award ceremony in Taipei, the premier unveiled a government plan to set up kindergartens in every school in which aboriginal children are the majority. He also announced that all classrooms will be equipped with LCD TVs as a means for the children to watch and learn from a newly launched indigenous TV channel.

While awarding a prize to an indigenous child, he said there are many outstanding people in the aboriginal communities and that the government should help deprived indigenous children get a head start and give them a chance to learn skills and foreign languages.
Indigenous children in Taiwan are considered underprivileged as many of them are brought up in remote mountainous areas that lack education resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENACTMENT OF BILL TO AUTHORIZE POWER TO NATIONAL ASSEMBLY URGED

TEXT.P: Presidential Adviser Yeh Chu-lan called Saturday for early legislation of a bill governing the exercise of the power of a soon-to-be-elected mission-oriented National Assembly.

Yeh, who ranks first on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) nomination list for the National Assembly elections, made the remarks during a meeting to promote the DPP's female nominees for the National Assembly.

If the ad hoc National Assembly, whose mission is to approve a package of constitutional amendment proposals passed by the Legislative Yuan last year, convenes without the presence of legislation to regulate its operations, it will be rendered toothless and will be a terrible squandering of the nation's resources, Yeh said.
Touching on some political parties that are having second thoughts about the constitutional amendments, she said it will be a betrayal of their promises to the public if they balk at the reforms.
She also urged the public to vote in support of the DPP, which has been consistent in its ideals of reforms to end constitutional chaos and lead the nation to a normal path.
Meanwhile, a legislative reform action alliance urged Saturday a speedy passage of the bill.
The Organic Laws and Statutes Committee in the legislature will start next Thursday to screen six versions of the bill submitted by various parties.

Lu Hsiu-chu, convener of the alliance composed of academic and civic groups, urged the political parties not to fool the public, not to filibuster the bill out of their own interests, and to continue to promote the constitutional amendments.
Ku Chung-hua, executive director of the Taipei Society, said that if the bill is not adopted, there is a risk of further constitutional crisis.
He expressed the hope of a large turnout for the National Assembly election and that the voters will support those political parties that are in favor of the constitutional amendments.

Huang Chang-lin, chairman of the Awakening Foundation, said that the amendments are far from perfect, but added that the point is not the content, but an opportunity for reforms and that the civic group cares most about the pushing through of the will to reform.

After six constitutional amendments between 1991 and 2000, the National Assembly, its delegates nominated by political parties on the basis of proportional representation, is now a non-standing body with most of its functions having been transferred to the Legislative Yuan.

The ad hoc National Assembly, to be elected May 14, is expected to convene around June 1 for one month. Its mission will be to vote on the constitutional amendments -- including the halving of the 225-seat legislature, an electoral change to a "single seat, two votes" system, the abrogation of the National Assembly itself and the inclusion of the referendum right into the Constitution -- passed by the legislature last August.

Faced with a public outcry for reforms, the ruling DPP, along with the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union, voted for the constitutional amendments with reluctance last August, but after several months, all but two major parties -- the DPP and the KMT -- have changed their minds in the belief that the new electoral system will be detrimental to them.
The minor parties could play a key role in dethroning the fate of the constitutional amendment proposals, according to analysts.

If lawmakers do not agree to begin screening the bill that regulate the operations of the National Assembly next week, the bill will have to wait for a four-month consultation among all parties before it can be put to another vote.
If the bill is put on hold this way, then even if the delegates to the National Assembly are elected, they will be powerless, the analysts have pointed out.

The minor parties could also resort to the raising of the threshold of passing the constitutional amendments. The PFP, the TSU and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union legislative caucus whips have advocated that the threshold be raised from half to three fourths, which would effectively kill the proposed amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC WILL HAVE SAY ON CHINA VISIT: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: An official of the opposition Kuomintang said Saturday that the public will make its own judgment on his just-concluded visit to China, amid scathing criticism by the government and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chiang, who wrapped up what he claimed was a five-day "ice-breaking journey" Friday that took him to Guangzhou, Nanjing and Beijing, made the remarks during an interview with a local TV station.

During his stay in Beijing, Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with Chen Yunlin, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, which covered a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, tourism, journalism, Chinese fishermen, protection of Taiwanese businessmen in China, and the easing of China's financial market. He also met with other high-ranking Beijing officials.

He admitted that "some" of the consensus reached with the communists will be up to the government to carry out or not and he said he will ask the KMT legislative caucus to explain this to the government.
He also said he would be happy to discuss the issue with Premier Frank Hsieh.

Faced with questions that his visit is mere "wishful thinking, " and that it might have violated the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, Chiang disagreed.

Chiang said Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who helped formulate the statute during his tenure as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, told him while greeting him upon his return from Beijing the previous night that there is no concerns about him having violated the law.
Chiang also said that if the court wants to prosecute him for the trip, he will be willing to cooperate.

His visit was for the good of Taiwan, Chiang claimed, adding that the issues raised by the KMT with the Chinese Communist Party have long been included in the suggestions made by the Council for Economic Planning and Development or the Mainland Affairs Council.

Many of the issues have existed for a long time, Chiang went on, saying that he raised them with the communist regime to promote cross-strait trade exchanges, adding his belief that for the Taiwan people, the economy is the most important issue.

With Beijing inviting Lien to visit China and Lien gladly accepting the invitation, Chiang assessed that the timing for such a visit could come between the National Assembly election of May 14 and the KMT chairman election of July 16.
But he said that June 1 could be significant, because the body of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founder of the Republic of China, was relocated from Beijing to bury in Nanjing on that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF EARTH SIMULATOR CENTER TO SPEAK IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Tetsuya Sato, director-general of the Yokohama-based Earth Simulator Center, will give a speech at the National Center for High-Performance Computing (NCHC) in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, NCHC officials said Saturday.

The officials noted that the Earth Simulator Center, funded by the Japanese government, is a super computer designed to provide a "holistic simulation of the entire earth system" that "may enable accurate prediction of the future by modeling present conditions based on data about the past."

The officials added that the center is devoted to research into the greenhouse effect, earthquakes and tsunami, which will help cut the risks from natural disasters and protect the global environment.
Sato will speak on the "Paradigm Shift in Simulation Science and Technology" on April 12, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The Pope of Popes.
He had received the last rites and the Vatican was openly preparing for his passing. But even as the life ebbed from his afflicted body yesterday, Pope John Paul II kept fighting.
As the world prayed for the dying pontiff and cardinals began to fly to Rome to prepare for the succession, the Vatican announced that the Pope had appointed 17 bishops and archbishops and accepted the resignation of six others.
Having declined further hospital treatment, the 84-year-old pontiff lay in his private quarters attended by four doctors, a cardiologist and two nurses. He had suffered heart failure and septic shock, his kidneys were failing and he was struggling to breathe.
Financial Times: Vatican set for Pope's death.
The Vatican was last night preparing hundreds of millions of Catholics around the world for the death of John Paul II, the third longest-serving Pope in history, who was said by cardinals to be "fading serenely". A new era in the Church's 2,000-year history appeared to be dawning after John Paul, who has reigned since 1978, was described in an official Vatican statement as being in a "very serious condition".

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Non-urgent ops off after SGH is hit by superbug.
Singapore General Hospital (SGH) has cancelled all non-urgent surgery for the next two weeks after it was hit by a drug-resistant strain of bacteria.
Fifteen patients have so far tested positive for the drug-resistant vancomycin resistant enterococci (VRE) bacteria and SGH is testing another 933 patients who may have come into contact with the bug.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore General Hospital is hit by VRE.
Singapore General Hospital (SGH) has cancelled all non-urgent surgery from next Monday after it was hit by a drug-resistant strain of bacteria called vancomycin resistant enterococci (VRE).

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Pope suffers heart failure
Pope John Paul II has suffered cardiovascular collapse and is in grave condition, the Vatican said Friday, but it denied a report that the pontiff was in a coma.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Pope suffers heart attack
VATICAN CITY (AFP, Reuters) -- Pope John Paul II is struggling between life and death after suffering a heart attack, the Vatican said yesterday after the pontiff's condition deteriorated dramatically and he received communion for the dying.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: World's faithful unite in prayer for Pope
TEARFUL Roman Catholics across the world, from blue-collar workers in Poland to monks in the Norwegian Arctic and parishioners in the Philippines, prayed for Pope John Paul II amid fading hopes that he would recover.
The Philippine Star: Filipinos in anxious vigil for ailing Pope
Anxious vigils were held across the country yesterday for Pope John Paul II, who has received the last rites after suffering a heart attack.
The Manila Times: Pope close to death
Pope John Paul II hovered close to death Friday after receiving last rites following a devastating heart attack as senior cardinals prepared Catholics around the world for his demise.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN WOMAN HAS 'ROOTS-FINDING' WEDDING IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Central Taiwan, April 2 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: An American couple had their wedding in a Catholic church in Taichung in Central Taiwan Saturday in order to cheer the bride's mother, a Taiwanese who married an American man more than 30 years ago in the same town.

In order to make the wedding a day to remember, the bride, Teresa Krebsbach had to convince her husband Matt Murray, an archaeologist, and a whole bunch of their family members to come to Taiwan, the birthplace of Teresa's mother, Lin Mei-ling and the place where she married her American husband Earl Krebsbach, who died in 1979.

The 61-year-old Lin, who worked in the 1960s in the food and beverage store on the former American air base at Chingchuankang, Taichung, and Krebsbach, an airplane maintenance engineer at the base, became acquainted in 1958 and married in a Catholic church in Taichung City the following year.
Lin and her husband relocated to the United States soon after their wedding, but unfortunately Krebsbach died in 1979, 10 years after their marriage.

Lin raised four children on her own in a land where she knew nobody. She managed to set up a tiny restaurant and in her scant spare time, recalled her beloved husband and their beautiful memories of Taiwan.

Knowing her mother's feelings, Teresa decided to have her wedding in Taiwan, so more than 20 people from both the bride's and groom's sides of the family came to Taiwan March 23 and had a brief tour around northern Taiwan before the wedding.
Saturday's wedding was presided over by a Belgium priest who has lived in Taiwan for more than 30 years in a ceremony that filled Lin's eyes with tears and her heart with fond memories.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN ARTISTS JOIN CULTURAL EXHIBITION IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: Eight artists from Starnberg, Germany, joined a cultural exhibition that opened Saturday in the Taipei County Cultural Center.
The exhibition opened with a performance by mime artist Johannes Goeth. The German artists brought with them 23 artworks to the exhibition, which will run until April 24.
Acting Taipei County Magistrate Lin Hsi-Yao also announced to the artists that Taiwan will hold a German beer festival later this year to further boost bilateral exchanges.
Christa Ackermann, deputy mayor of Starnberg, expressed hope for closer exchanges between Taipei County and her city.

She also presented a set of memorial coins to mark the 100th anniversary of her city to Lin and said that Starnberg's mayor will bring a variety of German beers to the Taipei County beer festival this winter.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL WELFARE GROUPS RAISE FUNDS TO HELP ABUSED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: A fund-raising drive kicked off Saturday at the Taipei 228 Memorial Park to collect money for a private effort to build a nationwide monitoring system targeting families in which there might be abused children.

The "Saving Abused Angels" drive, jointly launched by the Child Welfare League Foundation and the TVBS Caring Taiwan Cultural and Educational Foundation, is aimed at arousing concern among the public over the safety of children, said Lee Tai, a permanent voluntary worker for the TVBS foundation.

Last year, the number of children who died from abuse-related incidents averaged 4.67 per month, Lee said, citing a Child Welfare League survey and adding that these tragedies could have been prevented.
Deputy Taipei Mayor King Fu-tsung, Child Welfare League Chairman Lin Chih-chia, as well as entertainer Jolin Tsai, joined in the publicity drive to call for the public's love for abused kids.
The fund-raising drive will run through June 30, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS LEAVE FOR U.S.

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from the ROC-USA Inter-Parliamentary Amity Association departed Saturday for the United States to exchanges views with their U.S. counterparts on recent developments across the Taiwan Strait.

According to ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong Chai, leader of the group, incidents such as the enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, a massive demonstration in Taiwan against the law and a recent China visit by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) officials are likely to change the cross-strait situation.
Chai said he hopes the visit will help the United States better understand the situation faced by Taiwan.
In addition to members of Congress, the group will also visit Washington officials and major think tanks during the trip, Chai said.

Hou Shui-sheng, another DPP legislator, said the close contact between China and the KMT and the Anti-Secession Law have posed a threat to Taiwan's freedom and democracy and that he hopes the U.S. Congress will continue to support the Taiwan Relations Act to protect Taiwan.
Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Huang Shih-cho said the group will call U.S. attention to the strategic status of Taiwan in the Western Pacific.
It will be in the interests of the United States to help Taiwan join world organizations and sign trade agreements with other countries, Huang said.

DPP Legislator Hsieh Hsin-ni said the group will let the U.S. know the new legislature better and give it an idea of the progress of the NT$480 billion proposed arms procurement package from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO JOIN WHA AS `HEALTH ENTITY': OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official from the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan said Saturday that Taiwan is expected to use the title "Taiwan Health Entity" in its bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) this year as an observer.

The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that the name "Taiwan, China" proposed recently by China to allow the nation to participate in the health organization, carries a downgraded meaning and is unacceptable.
The name by which Taiwan will be referred to in the WHA will require a final decision by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs before being submitted to the WHA.
The official also said Taiwan will seek all possible international support in its quest to join the WHA.
Taiwan applied for WHA observership under the designation of "Taiwan Health Entity" last year, but the application was blocked by China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN LAWMAKERS URGE E.U. TO MAINTAIN ARMS BAN ON CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday it welcomes a statement issued by a group of pro-Taiwan German lawmakers urging the European Union to maintain its ban on arms sales to China.
The German lawmakers, all of whom are members of a pro-Taiwan group in the German Bundestag, issued the joint statement Friday at the conclusion of a visit to Taiwan.
A MOFA official said the ministry appreciates the German legislators' appeal for the European Union to maintain its arms embargo on China.

The joint statement says the signatories hope all E.U. member states will abide by the arms embargo, which was imposed in the wake of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing in which Chinese troops brutally crushed pro-democracy demonstrators.
A lifting of the ban will not be helpful to peaceful development in East Asia, the statement says.

It further says that China's recent enactment of its anti-secession law justifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan threatens the peace not only in the Taiwan Strait but also the entire East Asia region.
Against this backdrop, the statement adds, the resolution passed by the Bundestag Oct. 26, 2004 on keeping the arms embargo against China should be upheld.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG GOVERNMENT HOSTS INTER-CULTURAL FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: A colorful and exotic cultural festival was held Saturday by the Kaohsiung City Bureau of Social Affairs at its service center for children's welfare as part of a celebration to mark Women's/Children's Day, which falls on April 4.

Foreign spouses of local citizens and their families were guests at the festival, in which the organizers prepared various dance and folk performances featuring that cultures and characteristics of the different ethnic groups in the southern Taiwan harbor city, according to the bureau.
Besides the performances, 24 booths were set up at the festival exhibiting a wide range of native and foreign toys and foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER PITCHES FOR EARLY CHEN-LIEN-SOONG MEETING

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party (PFP) lawmaker said Saturday that President Chen Shui-bian and the two leaders of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" should meet as soon as possible to forge a national consensus on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that a major obstacle to cross-strait relations lies in divisions in Taiwan's ruling and opposition camps over the issue, PFP Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said he hopes Chen and the two "pan-blue alliance" leaders -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- should meet to forge a consensus on the development of cross-strait ties.

Liu made the appeal after a high-profile KMT delegation signed a 10-point consensus with China in Beijing earlier this week, which has drawn scathing criticism from the Taiwan independence-leaning "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

In the wake of China's enactment of a law justifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, Liu said integrating domestic opinions on strategies for cross-strait engagements has become an urgent task.

"It is also an unshirkable responsibility for Chen and Lien, the leader of the nation's largest opposition party. Neither the ruling party nor the opposition camp can ignore the public demand for stable and peaceful cross-strait ties," Liu said.

President Chen and PFP Chairman Soong already held a summit meeting in February and reached a 10-point consensus on cross-strait relations and major domestic policy issues. Therefore, Liu said he would not oppose a meeting between Chen and Lien without the participation of Soong.
At this critical juncture, Liu said, Taiwan's ruling and opposition should stop partisan infighting and hammer out a unified stance and strategy to promote constructive cross-strait exchanges.
In his view, Liu said, how to ensure "Taiwan first" and national dignity should be the top concern in boosting cross-strait engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONDEMNS CHINA OVER FORCING 'TAISHANG' TO BACK ANTI-SECESSION LAW

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu condemned China Saturday for pressuring Taiwan businesspeople operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " to voice support for its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Wu issued the denunciation after a Beijing-based broadcasting network reported earlier in the day that six Taiwanese trade associations in the southeastern Chinese province of Fujian opposite Taiwan have issued a joint statement supporting China's anti-secession law that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.

The nation's top China policy planner said the Taiwanese trade associations' move was yet another example of China's use of non-peaceful means against "taishang" following its use of a similar tactic against Hsu Wen-lung, founder of Chi Mei Group, one of Taiwan's largest business conglomerates.
Hsu, who retired from the Chi Mei chairmanship a year ago, published an open letter in a local newspaper last Saturday throwing support behind Beijing's "one China" policy and its anti-secession law.

Hsu's statement came as a surprise and an embarrassment for Taiwan's government because he was one of President Chen Shui-bian's big supporters during Chen's presidential bid in 2000. Hsu's support for Chen made his China business a target of retaliation by Beijing authorities. The publication of Hsu's letter coincided with a massive protest march in downtown Taipei against Beijing's "ill-intentioned" law.

"China's pressuring 'taishang' to issue statements supporting the anti-secession law indicates that the legislation has begun to affect 'taishang,'" Wu said, adding that the new law has not only restricted their freedom of speech and freedom of choice but may even jeopardize their business interests.

Noting that none of Taiwan's government agencies can exercise public authority on China soil, Wu reminded "taishang" to should become more risk-conscious in addition to heeding their own economic benefits in the wake of China's enactment of the anti-secession law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'AUSTRONESIAN AMBASSADOR SHIP' SETS SAIL FOR PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: A 14-member delegation organized by the Kaohsiung City Government left for the northern Philippine island of Batan Saturday aboard a specially designed yacht, chritened "Austronesian Ambassador Ship," for a goodwill visit.

The yacht, which was provided by Liu Ning-sheng, a skilled yachtman who once skippered this craft on a round-the-globe voyage in 2001, left the Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan aimd the blessing of many well-wishers.

Premier Frank Hsieh, acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai, Council for Aboriginal Affairs Chairman Walis Peilin, and a large crowd of city dwellers and aboriginal tribesmen saw the yacht off for the unprecedented voyage across the Bashi Channel to the Batan Island.

The voyage was planned during Hsieh's tenure as Kaohsiung mayor. Hsieh said he hopes the voyage will help boost bilateral cultural exchanges and facilitate Kaohsiung's development as an "ocean capital."
In recent years, Hsieh said, many Batan aborigines have traveled to Kaohsiung to work, helping enhance cultural and artistic diversity in the southern Taiwan port city.

The delegation is headed by Taibang Sasale, chairman of the Kaohsiung City Government's Commission for Native Taiwanese Affairs. The delegation members include physicians and nurses who will offer free medical services during their stay in Batan.
It has been widely believed that Batan residents and Tao tribal people on Taiwan Orchid Island belong to the same ethnic origin.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER KMT LAWMAKER TO RUN FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYORSHIP

TEXT.P: Former opposition Kuomintang Legislator Apollo Chen announced his bid for Kaohsiung mayorship Saturday, saying he will seek the party's nomination for the 2006 election.
Chen said he has made regular trips to the southern port city since ending his tenure as legislator in late January.
"I have been impressed by Kaohsiung citizens' hospitality and their expectations of the city's future development," Chen said, adding that he will set up an office in Kaohsiung the near future.
Chen further said he will relocate his legal residence to Kaohsiung in May to accentuate his determination to run in the next mayoral election in late 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, April 3:
09:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the funeral of PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng's father at Taipei's First Funeral Parlor.
09: 00, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will unveil his policy initiatives for women/children affairs for his bid for Kuomintang chairmanship in Taichung City.
10:00, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan will attend a parent-children garden party at Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall complex in Taipei.
10:00, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will announce his bid for KMT chairmanship at Kainan vocational school in Taipei.
14:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend an eco-friendly exposition in Suao, Ilan County.
16:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will meet with the gymnastic team of Kungcheng Elementary School in Loutung, Ilan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 3, or the 25th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, ROC minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
2000: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng says that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and visiting Liberian President Charles Taylor signed a joint communique Tuesday calling on all nations to resolve international differences through dialogue, negotiations and other peaceful means.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: Two killed, three injured in explosion of underground firecracker plant.
The United Daily News: NTU anthropology professor refuses to abandon prehistorical artefact as ordered by Education Ministry.
The Liberty Times: China is forcing mainland-based Taiwan businessmen to support Anti-Secession Law.
The Taiwan Daily: Pope faces up to death with dignity.
The Central Daily News: "History will assess my trip to China": P. K. Chiang.
The China Post: Pope's condition still 'very serious'
The Taiwan News: Millions join in prayer for dying pope
The Taipei Times: Thousands gather as Pope nears death

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: John Paul Is Near Death;Millions Gather in Prayer.
Pope John Paul II clung to life late Friday as his breathing grew shallow and his heart and kidneys faltered, the Vatican announced, preparing the Roman Catholic Church's 1 billion faithful for the end of the pontiff's 26-year reign.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA addresses IPU today.
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo will address today the 112th Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) General Assembly with more than 1,500 participating lawmakers and their staff from around the globe gathered at the opening ceremonies to be held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Palace giving up on new special session for VAT.
MALACANANG has apparently given up the idea of calling another special session of Congress to rush Senate approval of the expanded value-added tax after coming up empty in the just-concluded special three-day session.
The Philippine Star: GMA: Pope a source of strength.
Pope John Paul II remained a lasting source of strength despite his ailing condition during his last few years, President Arroyo said yesterday as Filipinos trooped to churches and prayed for a miraculous comeback for the pontiff.
The Manila Times: Pope nears the end.
Policemen who thwarted a 1995 attempt by Islamic extremists to assassinate Pope John Paul II in Manila joined fellow Filipinos in praying Saturday for the gravely ill Pontiff, adding that the failed plot enabled them to discover other major terrorist plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MOURNS PASSING OF POPE JOHN PAUL II

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu led the country to express their deep sadness over the death of Pope John Paul II Sunday, saying that the world has lost a great religious leader.
Chen said the Pope's lifetime efforts to seek peace and happiness for all human beings will long be remembered.

The president recalled that in July 2003, his wife, Wu Shu-jen, on behalf of himself and the government and people of the Republic of China, visited the Vatican to congratulate the Pope on the 25th anniversary of his inauguration.
During that visit, the Pope warmly received the ROC's first lady. Most people in Taiwan remember a most touching moment when they shook hands -- each from a wheelchair, Chen said.
Lu lauded the Pope for tirelessly visiting so many places across the world to show his genuine concern about people. The world should continue his selfless devotion to peace, she added.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has asked the ROC Vatican Embassy to forward the ROC's profound condolences. The ministry said the government will send a senior official to attend the Pope's funeral, in addition to having senior officials join a memorial service to be held by the Holy See's Embassy in Taipei.
The Pope's passing away early Sunday (Taipei time) also drew a chorus of sadness and regret from all major political parties as well as church groups in Taiwan.

William C.T. Lai, caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party at the Legislative Yuan, urged everyone to remember the Pope's will to promote peace, reminding those in Europe that while they mourn the great leader's death, they should also do a sensible thing -- not lift the arms embargo on China to maintain peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen Chih-pin, Lai's counterpart in the opposition People First Party, said the government should quickly dispatch a special envoy to express the country's condolences and actively consolidate bilateral relations. The Vatican is Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

The Taiwan Solidarity Union's legislative caucus whip, Lo Chih-ming, said he hopes John Paul II's successor will continue to work for peace and religious freedom for people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Kuomintang (KMT) spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said KMT Chairman Lien Chan expressed his deepest condolences, especially when he remembered how the Pope had held mass while he was in attendance.
Raymond Tai, former ROC envoy to the Holy See, pointed out that since his being elected in 1978, Pope John Paul had always wished that love and peace would prevail on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"Peaceful co-existence and no war between Taiwan and China" was always on the mind of the Pope, whose successor hopefully will uphold the same principle in tackling cross-strait issues, Tai said.

The Chinese Regional Bishops' Conference, based in Taipei, called on believers and non-believers alike to join in paying their respects to the Pope by glorifying his spiritual legacy of peace and love.
Father Chen Kun-chen, secretary-general of the conference, said his group will sponsor a large memorial service in conjunction with the Pope's funeral for the great leader.
In Taichung, central Taiwan, Catholics were showing their sadness at churches Sunday morning. The Taichung diocese will hold a public mass Tuesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: John Paul II Dies at 84.
John Paul II, the voyager pope who helped conquer communism and transformed the papacy with charisma and vigor, died Saturday night after a long battle with Parkinson's disease that became a lesson to the world in humble suffering, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPROVE PRESIDENT'S CONTROL YUAN NOMINEES OR EXPECT CHAOS: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: If the opposition in the Legislative Yuan continues to refuse to act on President Chen Shui-bian's Control Yuan nominees, political chaos will ensue, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus whip William C.T. Lai warned Sunday.

The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has asked President Chen to resubmit his list of nominees and the president has agreed to do so, Lai said, adding that there is no rationale for the legislature to turn down the list this time around.
The list requesting approval of the president's selections will be included in a letter to be delivered to the Legislative Yuan Monday morning, according to the Presidential Office.

However, Lai said, the president did not add or subtract names to the previous list that will be submitted to show that he still has faith in his first selections. The president will respect the Legislative Yuan's decision even if some of the nominees are not affirmed, he added.
The Legislative Yuan is encroaching on the president's nomination power by asking him to replace the names of his nominees even before exercising their right to affirm the individuals, Lai said.

If the president were to consent to changing his selections, it would be tantamount to the Legislative Yuan usurping the president's power to nominate the chiefs of other government agencies, such as the Examination Yuan and the Judiciary Yuan, Lai said. This situation would lead to political chaos, he added.

Lai warned the opposition, mainly the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , that they will face a backlash from the public in the next elections if they keep boycotting the president's nominees.

Meanwhile, the DPP's political ally in the Legislative Yuan, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , warned Sunday that if the opposition continues its boycott of the president's nominees, the TSU will appeal to the Council of Grand Justices to suspend the Control Yuan according to a constitutional interpretation.

Lo Chih-ming, the whip of the TSU caucus at the Legislative Yuan, didn't elaborate on how this could be done, saying only that his party disagrees with the KMT and PFP's position of boycotting the nomination process all together, but that the TSU is not prepared to give all the nominees a rubber stamp of approval.

The KMT and PFP, which held a very small majority in the last Legislative Yuan -- as it does in this new one -- asked the president in the previous legislature to withdraw all his nominees, claiming that none of them lived up to public expectations for Control Yuan members.
The president refused; the result was a Control Yuan that has had no members since Feb. 1 when the terms of the previous Control Yuan members ended.
The opposition in new legislature asked the president to submit a new list of nominees on the grounds that his original list to the previous legislature is invalid in this new legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR MA VOWS TO TAKE BURDEN OF PARTY REFORM IF ELECTED KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor and Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman Ma Ying-jeou got together Sunday with his backers to explain why he is seeking the KMT chairmanship, stressing his determination to carry the burden of party reform.

Ma made the remarks during a half-hour activity held in Taipei, in which party heavyweights, including Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Liluan, Hsinchu County Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin, and legislators John Chang and Hsu Shu-po were also present to lend support.

Ma outlined six major directions for the KMT's future development, calling for broad reform and vision to make the centenarian party capable, young, democratic and clean to help the nation move ahead.

He encouraged supporters to volunteer to serve the party and called on young people to join the party, saying that he will set up a youth and voluntary service group within the party to serve society. Ma also vowed to deal properly with the party's remaining ill-gotten assets and the large number of people on the party's payroll.

He also praised incumbent Chairman Lien Chan's performance in initiating KMT reforms, suggesting an amendment to the party's charter to make Lien an "honorary chairman" after he steps down from the party's top post in August.
The main opposition party has five vice chairmen and the next chairman will be elected through a vote among party members.
Legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng, also a KMT vice chairman, has also begun campaigning for the chairmanship.
Wang was in Taichung City Sunday, where he elaborated on a policy for women and children to seek greater grassroots support.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY WORRIED ABOUT RISE IN CHILD ABUSE, LOW BIRTH RATE

TEXT.P: The rise in child abuse and the falling birth rate in Taiwan are worrying, first lady Wu Shu-jen said Sunday, adding that caring for children should be no problem as long as there is a will to do it well.
Wu made the comments at a garden party for parents and children at the 228 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei. The event was aimed at creating "a new paradise for children."

According to the Ministry of the Interior, there have been over 30,000 cases of domestic violence each year in Taiwan in recent years, of which 6.3 percent were related to child abuse. Charity organizations estimate that there are more than 18,000 child victims each year.
In January, the Taipei-based Child Welfare League Foundation released a report saying that at least 4.13 children are abused to death by adults every month on average in Taiwan.
The first lady said that proper care of children need not be a burden. "It all depends on how you allocate your time, " she said.

Wu cited her own example to respond to some parents' complaints that they are too busy at work to spend much time with their children. She said while she was a lawmaker, she still managed to take some time out for her young ones, even though she was wheelchair-bound.
Another social issue the first lady said she was concerned about is Taiwan's falling birth rate, which last year stood at 1.24 babies per woman -- one of the world's lowest rates.

Couples in France and the United States had an average of 1.9 and 1.2 babies in 2004, while the figures for Sweden and Italy were 1.2 and 1.5, respectively, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior.

Wu said she was especially concerned that so many well educated couples seem to be losing interest in starting a family. She pointed out that even some members of President Chen Shui-bian's staff do not want children.

The development of a nation, to a large degree, depends on the quality of its human resources, she said, adding that she hopes that people will love life, care about kids and cherish what they have, so that Taiwan will have a better society and a brighter future.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T MUST VET NEGOTIATIONS WITH CHINA BEFORE MAINLAND TRIPS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Individuals or political groups must report to the government before and after their visits to mainland China if they intent to hold negotiations there, Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday.

Hsieh said that the government does not disallow visits to China, but he warned of political groups that are hell-bent on being the next to try to cut some deal with China at the expense of Taiwan's national interest. Reporting to the government before and after such visits to China is thus important and a procedural must, he said.

Hsieh's comments came at a time when there has been rampant speculation over the question of whether opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong would accept an invitation to visit China extended by Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office.

A Kuomintang (KMT) delegation, led by Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, returned to Taiwan Friday after concluding a five-day visit to China where they paid tribute to Republic of China founding father and KMT founder Sun Yat-sen and reached a 10-point consensus with ranking Beijing officials to bolster civilian exchanges.
The 10-point consensus touches on a wide range of issues, including agriculture, air links, labor affairs, the protection of Taiwan investors and financial cooperation.

Although the KMT claimed that Chiang's China trip -- the first of its kind in 56 years since the two sides of the Taiwan Strait split in 1949 following a civil war -- was fruitful, it has backfired among pro-independence camps who accuse the main opposition party of selling out Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Soong confirmed a media report that a PFP mission, to be led by Legislator Tsai Sheng-chia, is slated to visit China in the middle of this month for talks on Taiwan's farm exports.

Soong promised that the PFP mission will brief relevant government agencies, such as the Council of Mainland Affairs and the Council of Agriculture, to learn their opinions on Taiwan's agricultural exchanges with China before it departs.

He made it clear that the PFP delegation has no power to represent the government, but added that it will work hard to seek the maximum benefits for Taiwan farmers in the coming talks with Beijing officials.
The mission will also make public the upshot of the trip after it returns to Taiwan so that society can better understand what went on in China, he said.
Commenting on a possible personal visit to China, the PFP chairman said that he will not report to the government if he decides to go.

He said that only the government has the authority and the final say to settle cross- Taiwan Strait issues and he called for mutual respect in bilateral dealings. He said he is ready to play some role between the two sides in the future but pointed out that he is "in no hurry to visit China now."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES TSU, PFP TO SUPPORT CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus whip William C. T. Lai urged the People First Party (PFP) and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Sunday to make good on their promise to support proposed amendments to the Constitution.

Lai said the four proposals -- abolishing the National Assembly, cutting the number of members of the Legislative Yuan by nearly half, changing the electoral system for lawmakers and redefining the existing right in the Constitution to hold nationwide referendums -- were all agree upon in August last year by all parties in the Legislative Yuan, including the PFP and the TSU.
Lai warned the two parties that if they renege on their promise, they face disappointing their constituents and feeling their wrath for flip-flopping.

This is especially true for the TSU, which has always campaigned for the reform of the legislature by trimming the number of its seats, and redefining the people's constitutional right to hold referendums, Lai cautioned.

Simply getting constitutional amendment proposals to be heard at the National Assembly is a rare occurrence since before this can happen, three-fourths of all lawmakers must be present at the legislature to vote on the issue and of these, three-fourths must vote in favor of convening a mission-oriented National Assembly for this purpose, Lai said.
If the TSU backs down from its promise and votes against the proposals at the National Assembly, another chance to amend the Constitution might not be available for many, many years, Lai said.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-Chiang argued that his party will support all proposals except the new electoral system for lawmakers which, he claimed, is designed to eliminate small parties from the Legislative Yuan.
Su said his party was tricked into favoring the change to the electoral system in the legislature, and will not support this in the task-oriented National Assembly.
Su did not explain how his party had been duped.

Su said if the four proposals are to be voted on by the National Assembly one by one, the TSU will vote for all but the new electoral system. However, if they are to be bound together and voted on as a whole, which appears to be likely, he said, the TSU would have no choice but to vote against the package.
Chen Chih-ping, the PFP legislative caucus whip, said his party has had to shift its position because it has perceived a subtle shift since last August by the public.
"We won't hesitate to reverse our position to reflect public opinion. The DPP should mind its own business rather than worry about us changing our minds," Chen said.

The country is gearing up for the election on May 14 of members to a National Assembly that is tasked only to approve the four proposals to amend the Constitution. Among the political parties which have fielded candidates, both the TSU and the PFP have vowed to vote against the proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF INAUGURATES CAMPAIGN CENTER IN KAOHSIUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang inaugurated the party's National Assembly Campaign Center for Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan and made public the party's eight candidates in the country Sunday.

In a brief ceremony, Su put a cordon around the shoulders of the eight candidates as a symbol of the party's mandate and delivered a party flag to DPP County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing as a token authorizing him to manage the party's campaign in Kaohsiung County.
Noting that Yang, as head of the county, enjoys great popularity in Kaohsiung, Su said he hopes that some of it will rub off on the eight DPP candidates to help them win.

He also explained that the only task of the National Assembly to be elected on May 14 is simply to approve or not approve the proposals initiated by the Legislative Yuan last August to amend the Constitution. It is a take it or leave it mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOWERS NATIONAL FLAG TO MOURN POPE'S DEATH

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's national flag will be lowered for two days starting Sunday to mourn the death of Pope John Paul II, as the nation's leaders expressed an outpouring of condolences.
Premier Frank Hsieh said the government will assign an official to attend the Pontiff's funeral. Hsieh said he will not attend since the legislature is still in session.
Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said that Republic of China Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng will represent President Chen Shui-bian at the funeral.
President Chen will appoint a special envoy to attend the inauguration of the next Pope, Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO CONTINUE ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL REFORMS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government will continue to conduct economic and financial reforms to further improve Taiwan's business environment, an official of the country's top economic planning agency said Sunday.

Commenting on a recent survey by the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) that ranked Taiwan as the 18th-best place to do business globally, an advancement of two notches from the previous year's list, Thomas M.F. Yeh, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that this was a form of international recognition of Taiwan's reforms.

Experiencing an economic recession, the government has taken a series of measures to revitalize the country's economy, including expanding public construction and public services, conducting financial reforms and revising out-dated and unsuitable laws and regulations.
He added, however, some structural problems remain to be resolved.

Chen Tain-jy, president of the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that although the EIU annual survey shows the government's economic and financial reforms have produced fruitful results, there still exists room for improvement.
Chen Miao, a deputy researcher of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, suggested that market mechanisms should be respected in conducting financial reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOWS TO HONOR CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS PROMISES

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) will firmly stick to its constitutional amendments promises as part of its efforts to help wipe out political disorder and lay a sound foundation for Taiwan's political development, a party official said Sunday.

Liao Fung-te, director of the KMT's Organization Development Committee, said that the party will never stand back from its promises regarding the amendment of the Republic of China Constitution -- redefining the people's constitutional rights to hold referendums, halving the seats in the Legislative Yuan, guaranteeing gender-equality politics and granting power to the court regarding the impeachment of the president and vice president.

Despite opposition from other parties to some of these constitutional amending proposals that already gained an inter-party consensus in August last year, the KMT will stand firm on its stance in this regard, Liao said, singling out that redefining the public's rights to go to a referendum will be of great significance to Taiwan's democratization.

Liao's remarks came at a time when a mission-oriented National Assembly is slated to be set up in the middle of next month to be exclusively in charge of endorsing the Legislative Yuan's package of constitutional reforms.

The KMT has fielded 160 candidates for the May 14 National Assembly election, many of whom are twenty-something young men and women, a clear indication that the main opposition party is seeking to reform by recruiting new faces in cooperation with political veterans, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The New York Times: Pope Succumbs to Illness Suffered at Length and in Public.
Pope John Paul II died Saturday night, succumbing finally to years of illness endured painfully and publicly, ending an extraordinary, if sometimes polarizing, 26-year reign that remade the papacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIP BY LIEN TO CHINA WOULD BE 'UNSUITABLE': POLL

TEXT.P: Just over half of those responding to a poll released Sunday said it would be "unsuitable" for opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to visit China next month.
Lien was formally invited to visit China after P.K. Chiang, a KMT vice chairman leading a 34-member KMT delegation, came to a 10-point consensus with Chinese leaders in Beijing.

Only 36.7 percent of those polled by the Institute for National Policy Research think it suitable for Lien to make the visit at a time when China's anti-secession law has aroused widespread indignation across Taiwan.
As many as 66.6 percent of the pollees don't believe China is sincere in trying to improve its relations with Taiwan, inspite of its rapprochement with the KMT.
A little over one in five (20.6 percent) agree that the Chiang delegation can represent all people on Taiwan, while two thirds (65.9 percent) say it represents only the KMT.

Are the poeple worried Chiang's negotiations with Beijing, which were not authorized by the government, would damage Taiwan's national interests? Less than half (44.4 percent) say yes, while just over half (50.4 percent) say no.
The survey was conducted March 31-April 2 on people aged between 20 and 69, with 1,072 valid samples.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 4, or the 26th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in a Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: U.S. Ambassador Walter P. McConaughy and his wife leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
1999: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan urges Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.
2000: Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi reiterates that his country's stance of supporting the Republic of China in international forums will never change.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, meets with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong in Taipei to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."
