DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRAISES LATE POPE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian praised the late Pope John Paul II Monday for his legacy of peace and espousal of "peaceful means" to deal with international disputes and social as well as political issues.
Pope John Paul II passed away at the Vatican early Sunday morning, Taipei time.

Chen said that while mourning the great religious leader's death, people from across the Taiwan Strait should also emulate the pope's lifetime efforts of seeking peace and happiness for all human beings, by addressing cross-strait differences in a peaceful manner.

In a formal statement delivered at the Presidential Office on the pope's passing, Chen said that Pope John Paul II always made clear that peace must be built on a foundation of love, justice, truth and liberty -- the "four pillars of peace, " as he called them.
These "four pillars of peace" should also serve in guiding today's efforts to resolve international disputes via diplomacy, Chen added.
"I believe that only when both sides of the Taiwan Strait respect and follow the 'four pillars of peace, ' can peace prevail across the strait," Chen stressed.
He said that with the pope's death, the Catholics of the world have lost their most beloved shepherd, while the world as a whole has lost one of its strongest leaders.

Chen said that as the Vatican's staunchest diplomatic ally, he is representing the Republic of China government as well as the island's 23 million people in expressing Taiwan's deepest condolences for the passing of the pope. The Vatican is Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

Chen recalled that in July 2003, his wife, Wu Shu-jen, on behalf of himself and the ROC government and people, visited the Vatican to congratulate Pope John Paul II on the 25th anniversary of his assuming the papacy. During the visit, Wu met with the pope in person.
"My wife still vividly remembers the meeting, " Chen said, adding that "she told me that the pope's hand was soft and warm and his kindness and sincerity toward people just as unforgettable."
Wu also presented the pope with a letter written by Chen himself in which he expressed his total agreement with the pope's "four pillars of peace."
Chen reiterated that Taiwan is more than willing to play the role of a "loyal guard of international order" and a "staunch supporter of democracy and peace."
"Only when we exercise democracy, peace, freedom and respect, can the people live in a world where there is no violence, no war and no discrimination," Chen stressed.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has asked the ROC Embassy in the Vatican to relay the ROC's deepest condolences. The ministry said the government will send a senior official to attend the pope's funeral, in addition to having senior officials join a memorial service to be held by the Holy See's Embassy in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN SERIOUSLY CONSIDERING INVITATION TO VISIT CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will seriously consider an invitation extended by the Beijing leadership to visit China, but so far, there is no timetable for such a trip, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kong-ping said Monday.

Coordination tasks -- including seeking consensus within the PFP as well as consensus among Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties -- are more urgent and need to be dealt with before Soong makes any decision on a visit to Beijing, Hsieh said.

It has always been Soong's goals as the PFP chairman to sort out a "right direction" for efforts seeking common interests across the Taiwan Strait and to enable the two rival sides to treat each other "like a family," Hsieh said, adding that therefore, Soong has tried his utmost in seeking approaches to resolve the cross-strait differences, without having the slightest consideration of his personal standing.
Soong will visit China only at a "proper" time, with the PFP reaching consensus on this matter with the government and having various "possibilities" worked out, Hsieh stressed.

Meanwhile, five PFP legislators jointly appeared at a press conference Monday to talk about scenarios surrounding Soong's possible visit to China, chorusing that "vision is more important than gesture," and "policy is better than politics."

All five PFP lawmakers said that it is a PFP priority to enact cross-strait peace legislation to set up an institutionalized framework for cross-strait peace. Enactment of the law, however, will be clearly delinked from Soong's China visit plan, they said.

Legislator Lee Yong-ping said that cross-strait affairs, which concern the people's security and welfare, should not be relegated to the level of competition among the political parties in Taiwan. Lee called for parties across Taiwan's political spectrum to forgo their personal biases and instead work concertedly to reach consensus on cross-strait efforts.
Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung said that any form of cross-strait negotiation, including the possible visit to Beijing by Soong, should be conducted under the principles of dignity and reciprocity.
Lawmaker Chou Hsi-wei said that the PFP's cross-strait plans and the recent visit to Beijing by a delegation of its ally party, the Kuomintang, represent efforts to "build bridges and open paths."

"However, it seems that these two parties are now developing some kind of grudge against each other, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is apparently showing jealousy without admitting it," he added.
Chou called for Taiwan's political parties to first reconcile with one another before seeking reconciliation with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO VISIT KIRIBATI IN MAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian revealed Monday his plan to visit the Republic of Kiribati in May and expressed his happiness at being able to visit the country.
Chen made the announcement in a meeting with visiting Kiribati Parliament Speaker Etera Teangana at the Presidential Office.

Chen thanked Kiribati for its support for Taiwan's bid to join international organizations, such as the United Nations and the World Health Organization, and said that Teangana's current visit to Taiwan will help usher in full exchanges between the parliaments of the two countries.
According to Chen, bilateral Taiwan-Kiribati interactions have been frequent since the two countries forged diplomatic ties in November 2003.

Kiribati President Anote Tong visited Taiwan in February 2004, while former Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien paid a visit to Kiribati in January 2004, followed by a visit by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau last July to attend the Kiribati's 25th founding anniversary, he said.

Further exchanges are already on the way, as the two nations have clinched cooperative pacts on agriculture, fishing and sports, he said, adding that the Taiwan government will also provide scholarships for students from Kiribati to pursue higher learning in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS HEALTH INSURANCE FEE WAIVER FOR POOR YOUNG KIDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he takes great pleasure in seeing waiver of national health insurance premiums for children under three years of age from impoverished families starting today in connection with celebrations of Women's/Children's Day.
Chen made the remarks while attending a ceremony marking the inauguration of a special bank account to receive donations for helping disadvantaged children.
Starting on Women's/Children's Day, Chen said, the central government will pay health insurance premiums for children under three from low-income families.

"This new measure will benefit an estimated 24,000 young children from poor families around the country, " Chen said, adding that the premium waiver is expected to help reduce the financial burden for low-income families by an estimated NT$137 million annually.
The government has exempted out-patient and hospitalization fees for all local children under three since 2002.

With a view to offering more aid and welfare services for children from impoverished families, Chen said, the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has decided to open a new bank account to raise funds from individual citizens and private business groups.

Chen said several local news organizations and business groups have thrown their support behind the "Dear Kids Welfare Account" program. The president said he himself will raise funds for this special account in the future.
"I hope the account can raise at least NT$200 million this year," Chen said, adding that he hopes local people can donate funds to help disadvantaged children or kids from impoverished families.
The account was set up at the E. Sun Bank's Taichung branch in central Taiwan. The account number is 0141493012345.
Interior Minister Su Chia-chyuan and many other senior officials were also present at the ceremony marking inauguration of the account as part of the Women's/Children's Day celebrations.

To protect the education rights of pre-school children from low-income families, the government has offered subsidies for pre-schoolers up to the age of five. Chen said he has directed the Interior Ministry and the Education Ministry to study the feasibility of lowering the age to three for receiving similar subsidies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The Pope at peace.
His face serene, his pale hands clutching rosary beads, the body of Pope John Paul II lay in state in the frescoed Sala Clementina of the Vatican's Apostolic Palace yesterday as the world mourned on a scale never seen before.
Outside in St Peter's Square 130,000 people attended a Mass for the repose of the Pope's soul. More than two million pilgrims are expected to descend on Rome this week to pay final homage to the pontiff.
The Pope's passing brought tributes from every continent and from leaders of Islam, Judaism and Buddhism as well as Christianity. Millions attended church services. Scores of countries ordered days of mourning and flew flags at half-mast.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Requiem for 'the Great'; Thousands Attend Outdoor Mass As Rome Braces for Millions.
Pope John Paul II, who in life attracted millions of worshipers and admirers to gatherings around the world, in death received an immense homage Sunday from close to 150,000 pilgrims who gathered for an open-air Requiem in St. Peter's Square, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS TO PROPOSE ESTABLISHMENT OF GENDER EQUALITY AGENCY

TEXT.P: Three female opposition lawmakers announced Monday that they will push for the formation of a special Cabinet-level commission to implement the government's gender equality policy.

Legislators Huan Chao-shun and Huang Min-hui of the Kuomintang and Lee Yong-ping of the People First Party held a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to announce that they will propose an amendment to the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan for the Cabinet to set up an agency in charge of gender equality affairs.

Huang explained that the existing laws and government policy concerning gender equality or women's rights have not been thoroughly carried out because there is no organization within the executive branch to deal with the issue.
Therefore, she urged the Executive Yuan to set up a new commission which enjoys an independent budget and staff to promote gender quality in an inter-ministerial manner.

Lee noted that setting up a special agency to promote gender equality was one of the 2004 presidential election campaign promises made by President Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Vice President Annette Lu.
Representatives of private women's organizations, including the Awakening Foundation and the Modern Women's Foundation, also attended the news conference to lend their support to the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN RE-SUBMITS ORIGINAL LIST OF CONTROL YUAN NAMES TO LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian sent a list of Control Yuan nominees -- the same one that was rejected by the last legislature -- to the new legislature Monday.

The list contained exactly the same 29 names that were on the list submitted to the previous legislature. Among others, the list contained the name of Clement C.P. Chang, a former speaker of the Taipei City Council and one of the reasons that the opposition parties have been opposed to the president's nominations.

In a letter to the Legislative Yuan, President Chen said the terms of office for the members of the third Control Yuan, including its president and vice president, expired on Jan. 30, 2005, but the last legislature failed to act on his Dec. 20, 2004 nominations which he put forward in accordance with the Constitution.
Since a new legislature was sworn in Feb. 1, 2005, the president wrote, "I hereby request that the Legislative Yuan exercise its right to approve the list as soon as possible."
The president did not change the names from the original list to show his respect for the Legislative Yuan and to maintain the Presidential Office's position, a spokesman for the president said.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng was scheduled to call a "consultation conference" later Monday in which ruling and opposition parties were to try to work out a compromise on the issue.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus whip William C.T. Lai said the opposition can veto any of the nominees, but they have no right to refuse to screen the list.
"It's their duty to act on the list, but by refusing to do so, they have caused a hiatus in the operations of the Control Yuan, which is unconstitutional," he asserted.

Li Yung-pin, Lai's counterpart in the opposition People First Party (PFP) , said her caucus had expected the ruling party to show some goodwill before re-sending the nominees list. This, however, has not happened.
Before sending this second list, the Presidential Office could have talked with the opposition and tried to change some of the controversial nominees, Li said.
"Since this has not been the case, the PFP caucus will not approve the list, " she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISED BILL TO SET UP OFFSHORE TRANSPORTATION HUB PASSES 1ST READING

TEXT.P: A legislative committee passed the first reading of a revised draft bill on the establishment of an offshore transportation center.

According to the revised draft bill passed by the Transportation Committee, the operations of an offshore transportation center will expand to free trade zones and the cargoes will not be confined to transshipping, but will also expand to include those to and from China and third places.

Taiwan has three free trade zones, including one at northern Keelung Harbor, which started operations in October 2004, and another at southern Kaohsiung Harbor, which started operations in early January. The third tree trade zone at Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan will start service at the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TRIPS ARE FINE, BUT TOUCH BASE WITH GOV'T FIRST: LEE YUAN-TSEH

TEXT.P: Although visits by political party leaders to mainland China are a good thing to help ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait, it will be much better if they could talk with the government before they do so, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Monday.

Lee made the suggestion while answering questions from lawmakers at a legislative committee focusing on the 10-point consensus reached by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) delegation led by Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang and officials of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) last Wednesday in Beijing.

Admitting that it is good for governments to sit down and talk, Lee, however, pointed out that political parties' inking accords with China without prior government understanding is not acceptable to the ROC government. Such a development is not good for the nation and society, he added.

He said he believes that cross-strait relations will gradually get better in the coming months as President Chen Shui-bian has showed a willingness to reopen talks with China on the basis reached by officials from the two sides in a 1992 meeting in Hong Kong.
Chiang's trip has provoked strong criticisms from the pro-independence camps, including President Chen as well as his ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

They accused the trip of being "highly inappropriate" at a time when Beijing's recent adoption of an Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan has poisoned cross-strait relations and they lashed out at the KMT-CCP 10-point consensus for having "sold out" Taiwan's interests.

The 10-point consensus is aimed at promoting civilian exchanges, covering a broad range of issues in the fields of education, air links and protection of Taiwan business interests as well as fishery, agricultural and financial cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIVE LAWMAKER AGAINST TSU CHAIRMAN'S PLAN TO VISIT YASUKUNI SHRINE

TEXT.P: Aboriginal Legislator May Kao-Chin from the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union protested in strong words Monday against the forthcoming visit to Japan's Yasukuni Shrine by Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang.

Wearing head gear adorned with the Chinese characters for "protest" and historical pictures, Kao-Chin lodged the protest at the headquarters of the TSU, lambasting Su's plan to visit the Japanese temple dedicated to war dead as "selling his soul to the devil for political gain."
Local newspapers reported Monday that Su plans to pay tribute to the nearly 30,000 "patriotic" Taiwanese commemorated at the Yasukuni Shrine who were killed during World War II fighting for Japan.

If they were indeed "patriotic, " Kao-Chin asked which side they supported - - Taiwan or Japan? Japan, Kao-Chin added, killed numerous Taiwanese, including aborigines, before and during its rule of Taiwan.
Kao-Chin likened Su's upcoming visit to the Yasukuni Shrine to the Jews worshipping their Nazi rulers and murderers.
Discounting Kao-Chin's broadside, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said that Su is not going to pay tribute to the Japanese war dead, but to the soldiers who came from Taiwan.

Noting that the people of Taiwan were not only the victims of atrocities committed by the Japanese, they were also victims of Chinese brutality, Chen called for tolerance toward diverse voices and different opinions in society.
Chen asked that Kao-Chin direct her hatred away from Taiwan or Japan and focus it on China.

The Yasukuni Shrine, situated in central Tokyo just outside the moat to the Imperial Palace, is dedicated to about 2.46 million people who have died in Japan's conflicts between 1853 and 1945. Of the total enshrined, 1,068 are convicted war criminals.
Su will be traveling to Japan in the near future, mainly to mark the establishment of a TSU branch in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CRITICIZE OUTDATED BUS REGULATION

TEXT.P: A group of legislators slammed what they called an outdated bus regulation Monday, saying that a height restriction on bus fares is unfair.
The legislators said that according to a current bus regulation, the minimum height to decide for a high school student's ticket or for a children's fare is 140 cm.
According to the height regulation, which has been in place for nearly 40 years, school children are entitled to paying the children's fare, or NT$8 if they are under 140 cm, the legislators said.
If they are taller than 140 cm, they must pay the student fare, or NT$12, the same as that required of a high school or college student.
The problem is, they argued, the average height of sixth graders in Taiwan has now exceeded 140 cm to reach 148 cm.
The outdated height restriction is not only unrealistic but also deprives elementary school pupils of their due privilege, the lawmakers said.

Meanwhile, a survey conducted in the northern county of Taoyuan found that one out of every four first graders in all elementary schools in the county were suffering from myopia, while some 70 percent of them have cavities.
Taoyuan Magistrate Chu Li-lun said that an extra budget will be allocated to improve school facility and health programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 8.82 points to close at 6,019.93.
The bourse opened at 6,013.70 and fluctuated between 6,006.30 and 6,048.37 during trading. A total of 2.94 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.22 billion (US$2.41 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stock moving up the most at 2.0 percent, plastic and chemical shares at 1.1 percent, and foodstuff issues at 0.1 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics issues at 0.4 percent, and textile stock at 0.4 percent. Paper and pulp issues remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 368 to 501, with 139 stocks remaining unchanged. (By Wayne Lee) /

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CELEBRATES CHILDREN'S DAY

TEXT.P: In celebration of Children's Day that falls April 4, the central government began Monday to implement a new measure -- covering national health insurance premiums of children aged under three of low-income families.

Premier Frank Hsieh told a group of pre-school children the good news on his visit to a day care center in Hsichih, Taipei County. He also mentioned that since September, every elementary school in the aboriginal area around the island is obliged to set up a kindergarten to offer an affordable place for less-privileged aboriginal children to study.
Hsieh, who is also an ocarina musician and had an ocarina music album released, played the ceramic instrument to entertain 120 children at the county-run facility.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN FIRST TWO MONTHS REACHES 12.48% OF YEAR'S TARGET

TEXT.P: Major investment projects in Taiwan in the first two months of this year totaled NT$108.186 billion (US$3.43 billion), or 12.48 percent of the targeted investment for this year, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Monday.
Ho made the remarks while presiding over a meeting to promote investment and expand business opportunities. The ministry has targeted a total investment of NT$867 billion this year.

The major investment projects that the ministry are planning to promote this year include the Industrial Development Bureau's whole car design and development project, biotechnology in the medical industry and promoting investment strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU SUGGESTS PFP CHAIRMAN SERVE AS ENVOY FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong should serve as an envoy to lobby world support for Taiwan at a time when cross-Taiwan Strait ties have turned soured after Beijing adopted an Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan in mid-March, a spokesman for the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Monday.
Chen Chien-ming, secretary-general of the pro-independence TSU, made the proposal at a news conference he called at the TSU headquarters.

Suggesting that President Chen Shui-bian appoint Soong as a special envoy to seek backing from the United States, Japan and the rest of the world for Taiwan when the country has come under growing military threats from Beijing, Chen Chien-ming said that Soong should play a bigger role in cross-strait affairs due to a 10-point agreement that he inked with the president in late February.

Since PFP lawmakers have argued that the 10-point consensus reached recently between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Chinese Communist Party does not go beyond the framework of the Chen-Soong agreement, Soong should seize the opportunity and not allow the KMT to steal the limelight, Chen said.
By helping gain international backing for Taiwan, Soong could see his 10-point accord with the president really be implemented and serve the country, he suggested.

He also urged Soong to display greater goodwill by helping push through a special budget bill and a major military procurement bill at the Legislative Yuan before a possible second Chen-Soong meeting.
The president and Soong met on Feb. 14 in a gesture of rapport between the ruling and opposition parties in view of the fragile cross-strait situation.

The two signed the 10-point accord, promising not to change the nation's official title of the Republic of China and not to write a new constitution -- actions viewed by Beijing as moves toward Taiwan independence and ones that could invite "non-peaceful" reactions from Beijing under the conditions set forth in the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON NOMINATIONS FOR CONTROL YUAN BREAK DOWN IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Intra-party negotiations over how to handle President Chen Shui-bian's nominations of Control Yuan members broke down at the Legislative Yuan Monday and its leader announced a new round of talks for Thursday.
Monday's negotiations could not go anywhere because the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) were not satisfied with the president's refusal to name new nominees.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus whip William C.T. Lai said the president has the constitutional right to nominate whomever he likes while the legislature has a duty to screen his nominees.
Lo Chih-ming, Lai's counterpart in the minor opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union, said the controversy should be discussed at a legislative committee, including whether to change some names or not.

The KMT and the PFP expressed regret that the president refused to change any of the names on the nomination list. KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh said if the president remains adamant on this, it would be pointless to screen his old list.
PFP legislative caucus whip Li Yung-pin refused to link this issue to a 10-point consensus her party leader, James Soong, had reached with President Chen.
Failing to bring both sides together, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said this is a political problem that needs a political solution.
He has scheduled a new round of negotiations for April 7, but added that he was not sure if the obstacles can be overcome during this session of the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Akayev Says He'll Resign on Monday.
Kyrgyz President Askar Akayev, who fled his country last month after demonstrators stormed his offices, said in Moscow he would resign Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Church Officials and Italian Leaders Hold Viewing of Pope.
Just 12 hours after Pope John Paul II died Saturday night, the power in the Roman Catholic Church began its shift to his eventual successor.
Wall Street Journal: In Changing World, Church Faces Choice Over Pope's Role.
In his 26 years as pope, John Paul II transformed the papacy like few of his 263 predecessors. His role in aiding the defeat of communism in Eastern Europe, his grueling trips around the world to bless mass audiences and his writings on topics ranging from war and ethics to his own life story granted him a moral authority few other world leaders could match. The cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church face a wrenching choice: Even if they could find someone with similar star power to succeed John Paul II, would he be the right sort of man to lead the church into the third millennium?

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW KINMEN DEFENSE COMMANDER SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Wu Ta-peng was sworn in as the new commander of the Kinmen Defense Command Monday.
Wu, replaced Cha Tai-chuan, who was recently recalled from the frontline island to Taiwan for medical treatment of dizziness.

The changeover ceremony was presided over by ROC Army Commander-in-Chief Chu Kai-sheng, who expressed the hope that the military personnel of the Kinmen Defense Command could become a disciplined and combative force under the leadership of Wu, formerly the commander of the army's eighth regiment.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MINOR EARTHQUAKES JOLT HUALIEN

TEXT.P: Three moderate earthquakes shocked Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Monday, the largest of which measured 3.8 on the Richter scale, according to the Central Weather Bureau's Seismologic Center.
The first quake occurred at 3: 30 p.m. and recorded a magnitude of 3.8. It was centered 6.7 km southwest of a seismic station in Hsincheng, Hualien County, at a depth of 9.5 km beneath the surface.
The temblor had an intensity of three at Hsincheng, two in Hualien City and one in Ilan City, according to the center.

The second earthquake came at 4: 34 p.m. and had a magnitude of 3.7 on the Richter scale with its epicenter 5.7 km southwest of the Hsincheng seismic station at a depth of 10.1 km. It was felt with an intensity of two in Hualien City and surrounding areas.
One minute after the second quake came a third, which measured 3.5 on the Richter scale, with its epicenter located 5.8 km southwest of the Hsincheng seismic station at a depth of 10.5 km.
Seismologic Center Director Kuo Kai-wen said they were a group of moderate shakes and that it was hard to tell which of them was the major one.
There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC CONTINUING WITH OIL EXPLORATION OVERSEAS

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will continue its oil exploration efforts overseas, as its 2005 budget for the task has been secured at the Legislative Yuan, a spokesman for the state-run company said Monday.

The CPC official made the remarks after the company's budgets for exploration on land and offshore, totaling NT$1.14 billion and NT$1.459 billion (US$46.2 million) , respectively, cleared the legislature earlier that same day.

The CPC plans to keep digging for oil in Australia, Ecuador, Indonesia, the United States and Venezuela, the official said, adding that its oil exploration in these countries is estimated to yield some 18.25 million barrels of oil, racking up some US$300 million in profits for the company, he said.

The passage of the budgets have come as good news for the CPC at a time when oil prices are surging again in the international market, he said. Although offshore oil exploration carries risks, he pointed out that it helps the company secure supplies of its own and provides opportunities for greater profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VATICAN TIES STEADFAST: MOFA

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and the Vatican have remained steadfast, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.
Larry Yu-yuan Wang, director of the MOFA's European Affairs Department, made the remarks while attending a news conference hosted by the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus.

During the news conference, KMT legislators Su Chi and Lee Fu-hsiung said the government should do its utmost to cement diplomatic relations with the Vatican after Pope John Paul II died early Sunday Taipei time at the age of 84.

Su, who once served as Mainland Affairs Council chairman, said if the Vatican switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, it could have a domino effect on Taiwan's diplomatic situation.

"Sixteen of the ROC's 25 diplomatic allies are Catholic countries. If the government fails to handle events following the pope's death appropriately, it could have a grave impact on our diplomatic map," Su cautioned.
In response, Wang said, the ROC government has consistently supported the late Pontiff's global charity and peace-promotion activities over the past decades.
"Our relations with the Vatican have been close and steadfast, " Wang said.
He further said dialogue between China and the Vatican has been suspended since 2000 because of China's stubborn resistance to any Vatican involvement in its domestic Catholic church affairs.
For years, China has insisted on its two prerequisites for establishing formal ties with the Vatican -- cutting ties with Taiwan and promising not to get involved in Chinese Catholic church affairs.
In history, Wang said, the Holy See has never taken the initiative to sever its diplomatic relations with any country in the world.
Wang said the ROC government has taken appropriate measures to pay homage to the Pope, including having the national flags flown at half-staff at government buildings since Sunday for two days.

Senior government officials, including President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, have expressed their deep sadness over the death of Pope John Paul II, saying that the world has lost a great religious leader. In addition, President Chen gave a eulogy in praise of the Pontiff Monday.

The MOFA has asked the ROC Vatican Embassy to forward the ROC's profound condolences. The ministry said the government will send a senior official to attend the Pope's funeral, in addition to having senior officials join a memorial service to be held by the Holy See's Embassy in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PAYS TRIBUTE TO JOHN PAUL II

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian went to the Embassy of the Holy See Monday to pay tribute to Pope John Paul II, who died Saturday at the age of 84.
The president was accompanied by Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen.
Vice President Annette Lu and Premier Frank Hsieh also went to the embassy to pay their respects.
The president first bowed three times before a picture of the late pontiff and then talked with Ambrose Madtha, charge d'affaires of the embassy, who invited him to attend the late pontiff's funeral.

The president said that after learning of the pope's death, he asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to express grief on behalf of himself and his wife. He also instructed the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan to fly the national flag at half mast as a mark of respect.

The president expressed his highest regards for the contributions to world peace by the late pope and said he hopes to continue to promote lasting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait in line with the pope's wishes.

He and his wife prayed for the pope April 2, Chen said, recalling that his wife, Wu Shu-jen met the late pontiff in Vatican City in July 2003 during her European visit, and that the scene of the two -- both in wheelchairs -- shaking hands moved him to tears.

Madtha said that the pope has been positive about the efforts of the ROC government and people in pursuing cross-strait peace and he expressed the hope that the close relations between the two sides will be further strengthened.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF WILL NOT RULE OUT VISIT TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Calling trips to China by political parties "a good thing, " Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Monday that he would like to lead his staff on a visit to the Chinese Academy of Sciences for exchanges when the time is ripe.

However, Lee told the Legislative Yuan that it would not serve the interests of the country if agreements between local parties and the Chinese Communist Party are rejected by the government because that parties did not get government approval to forge such agreements.

Lee was asked by lawmakers to comment on the just-concluded trip to China by a delegation from the opposition Kuomintang. The trip, taking place days after a massive protest in Taipei against China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, was criticized by some as cutting the ground from under the feet of the government in its intensifying confrontation with China.

In his view, Lee said, Taiwan's ties with China have been turning for the better in the last several months, especially President Chen Shui-bian's announcement Oct. 10, 2004 that he was willing to talk with China on the basis of the 1992 talks between the two sides.
Although Taiwan and China cannot even agree with each other on what understanding they reached in those talks, Lee said, Chen's announcement showed a converging of positions between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUGGESTS THAT WTO REVIEW VISA FEES FOR EXPORTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has suggested that the World Trade Organization (WTO) review the practice of some countries charging visa fees to exporters, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Monday.
BOFT officials noted that the WTO Doha Round of trade negotiations has made the facilitation of the flow of trade one of the WTO's priority issues.

A WTO trade negotiating team held the fourth meeting in the second half of March, during which Taiwan, the United States, South Korea, the European Union, and Japan submitted 10 written suggestions focusing mostly on how to streamline export and import fees and procedures, the officials said.

They said Taiwan exporters have often complained that some countries charge consular visa fees that are not only expensive but also inconvenient. As many counties have not set up consular or representative offices in Taiwan, the exporters have to send the documents to neighboring countries that do host such offices.

Taiwan representatives said in the meeting that these unreasonable fees increase the cost of international trade, mitigate trade opportunities and cut into the profits of small- and medium-sized enterprises, the officials said.

The BOFT has commissioned the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei to investigate this and other trade hurdles encountered by Taiwan exporters so as to create a more favorable trade environment for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PITCHES FOR CONCERTED EFFORTS TO STAMP OUT CHILD ABUSE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Monday she deplores the increasing prevalence of parents abusing their children in local society.

"Child abuse has become an ever-more serious social issue in Taiwan due in part to a lack of parenting education. It is deplorable that parents fail to love their own children and even maltreat them," Lu said at a roundtable meeting on child abuse problems as part of the Women's and Children's Day celebrations.
Quoting official tallies, Lu said the number of child abuse cases reported in the first half of 2004 marked a 10 percent increase from that reported in the whole of 2003.

"In 1994, 1,638 child abuse cases were reported in 1994 and the number had jumped to 5,349 by 2004. If juvenile abuse was included, the number exceeded 8,000 in 2004, or an average of one child and juvenile abuse case reported every 1.1 hours last year," Lu said.
Worse still, Lu said, 81.06 percent of abusers were parents, while 6.9 percent were baby sitters, 3.67 percent were relatives and 4.33 percent were their parents' live-in lovers.
In her view, Lu said, abusive parents mainly result from their ignorance of parental responsibilities.
"Love for children is the basic parenting principle. It's unthinkable that parents maltreat their own children. Child abuse is an irresponsible way of life," Lu said.

Quoting the results of a series of surveys by children's welfare groups, Lu said marital problems accounted for 20 percent of child abuse cases, 11.6 percent resulted from abusive parents' alcohol or drug abuse, 10.9 percent were related to poverty and 9.8 percent were caused by parents' unemployment.
According to Lu, Taiwan is advanced in terms of children's welfare legislation.

"We enacted the domestic violence prevention law in 1998, the sex crime prevention law in 2002, the family education law and the children and juvenile welfare law in 2003, and the gender equality education law in 2004. It's lamentable that we have so many child abuse cases even after the enactment of all those laws, " Lu said, adding that the government, social workers, scholars and experts should pool their wisdom to work out measures to prevent child abuse.
"We should not only consider how to help abused children but also hammer out measures to prevent those cases from happening, " she added.

The outspoken vice president further said that the local women's movement has focused only on sexual liberation while failing to put equal emphasis on cultivating sexual ethics. Lu said she believes this deficiency is one of the major causes of the significant rise in child abuse in Taiwan in recent years.
"Besides helping abused youngsters, we should from now on devote more efforts to exploring relations between the genders and improving parenting education to prevent child abuse," Lu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERESTS OF NATION, PEOPLE ABOVE THOSE OF INDIVIDUALS, PARTIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that the interests of the nation and the people should be above those of individuals and political parties.
The president made the remarks when he received visiting Kiribati Parliament Speaker Etera Teangana at the Presidential Office.

Chen noted that Taiwan underwent the first peaceful power transfer between parties in 2000. A true democratic country must have parliament and party politics and it is only natural to have arguments and competitions among different parties, he said.
But when faced with the outside world, there can be only national interests, he said.

He also said that Taiwan and Kiribati share the universal values of believing in democracy, freedom, peace and human rights, and that whether a country is great or not has nothing to do with its size and per capita income. Although Taiwan is small, it is on the side of democracy and justice and both it and Kribati are great countries, he added.
Chen, who revealed his plan to visit Kiribati in May earlier in t he day, said bilateral interaction has been frequent since the two countries forged diplomatic ties in November 2003.

Kiribati President Anote Tong visited Taiwan in February 2004, while former Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien paid a visit to Kiribati in January 2004, followed by a visit by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau last July to attend Kiribati's 25th founding anniversary.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHINES AT WORLD PARALYMPIC TABLE TENNIS TOURNAMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 3 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao & Wayne Lee)

TEXT.P: Competing with 18 other countries, Taiwanese men and women athletes have won a total of 11 medals at a world table tennis tournament for the handicapped.

The Chinese Taipei team won five gold, four silver and two bronze medals at the Euro Champ Table Tennis Tournament, a competition organized by the International Paralympic Table Tennis Committee for handicapped athletes March 31-April 1 in Emmen, the Netherlands. Taiwan nabbed two golds and two silvers in both the men's wheelchair team and the women's wheelchair team categories.
In the men's singles, Wu Chen-sheng and Lin Wen-hsin won gold in Class 3 and 4, respectively, while Tsai Ching-ching snatched a bronze in Class 5.
In the women's singles, Tsai Hui-chu won a gold in Class 4/5 and a silver in the Women's Standing Open. Teammate Wei Mei-hui added a silver in Class 4/5 and a bronze in the Women's Standing Open.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO LATE PRESIDENTS' MAUSOLEUMS TO BE TURNED INTO MEMORIAL PARKS

TEXT.P: The interim mausoleums of the late President Chiang Kai-shek and his son and successor Chiang Ching-kuo in Taoyuan County will be converted into memorial parks after their embalmed bodies are interred at a cemetery in Taipei County later this year, a local official said Monday.

Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun said both the Chiang Kai-shek mausoleum at Tzuhu and the Chiang Ching-kuo mausoleum at Touliao have long been the northern Taiwan county's major tourist attractions.

"In addition to bearing great historical significance, the two mausoleums also boast beautiful natural scenery and unique architectural styles, " Chu said, adding that the county government has decided to convert the two mausoleums into memorial parks or libraries after the embalmed bodies of the two late presidents are interred at the Wutzushan military cemetery in Hsichi, Taipei County in July.

The Chiang family sent a letter to the Ministry of National Defense (MND) last year asking it to help with the relocation of the two Chiangs -- who have been embalmed in interim mausoleums in Taoyuan to the Wutzushan military cemetery for permanent interment.

With the consent of President Chen Shui-bian, the MND, the Ministry of the Interior and various other government agencies began to plan for the relocation and burial in line with the state funeral law.

After some twists and turns, the MND commissioned contractors early this year to build tombs for the two late presidents and the graves are scheduled for completion in June. If all goes well, the interment ceremony will be held in July.
The Presidential Office will announce relocation and interment procedures and rituals later in accordance with the state funeral law.

Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the Chinese mainland to the Mao Zedong-led communist party in a bloody civil war. He died in 1975 and his remains were embalmed in a temporary mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan, awaiting a proper burial on the mainland.

Chiang Kai-shek ruled Taiwan with an iron fist, using martial law to suppress democracy. However, some view him as a hero for keeping the island out of reach of the Chinese communists and claim that it was he who fostered Taiwan's freewheeling market economy.

Chiang Ching-kuo is respected for ending martial law in 1987, shortly before his death, thus unleashing the democratic forces that broke his family's vice-grip on power and eventually ended the Kuomintang's half-century of rule over Taiwan.

Chiang Ching-kuo died in 1988 and his remains also lie embalmed in an interim mausoleum at Touliao in Taoyuan. His Russian-born wife died Dec. 15, 2004 and her cremated ashes, which are being kept at Chiang's mausoleum, will be buried along with her husband.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO JOIN GLOBAL CAMPAIGN IN HONOR OF EINSTEIN

TEXT.P: Lights will go on in nine symbolic spots across Taiwan April 18, Eastern Standard Time, as part of a worldwide campaign in memory of the world's greatest physicist, Albert Einstein.
The day marks the 100th anniversary of Einstein's publication of his Theory of Relativity, as well as the 50th anniversary of his death.

According to the Physical Society of the Republic of China, a worldwide lights-on activity to "Let Physics Glorify the World" was initiated by professors Max E. Lippitsch and Sonja Draxler of the Karl-Franzens-Universitat in Austria.
The two professors proposed that all countries light up at the same time to show their support for physics, as well as to symbolize their dedication to the study of basic science.
Taiwan's lights will go on in Taipei 101, the Lu Lin Observatory on Yushan -- Taiwan's highest peak -- and various other symbolic places across the country.

A fund-raising campaign will also be kicked off to collect donations that will be used to help Third World countries promote basic science education, said President Chang Ching-jui of the Physics Society of the ROC.

His society is co-sponsoring the Taiwan activity with the Industrial Technology Research Institute, one that will see lights go on first in Hualien on the east coast, then in Kaohsiung, Tainan, Changhua, Taichung, Hsinchu before reaching Taipei and Yushan. The lighting-up relay will take place between 6: 40 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. on April 19, Taipei time.
An E=MC2 sign will be seen on Taipei 101, the world's tallest building, by what the organizers claim is "arguably the greatest number of people at a single time."
Other Asian countries taking part in the global event include China, Korea, Japan and Malaysia. To date, 44 countries had registered to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES TOTAL US$251.1 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$251.13 billion in March, up US$4.507 billion from the previous month, the Central Bank of China said Monday.
CBC officials attributed the increase mainly to the influx of foreign capital and the revenue from using foreign exchange reserves for investment.
Taiwan maintains the third ranking in terms of foreign exchange reserves, behind only Japan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A German parliamentary group called Monday on Chen Chi-mai, acting mayor of the southern city of Kaohsiung.
The German-Taiwan Parliamentary Group issued a statement advising the European Union to continue its arms embargo against China, for which Chen expressed appreciation.
Chen noted that as many as 1 million Taiwan people took to the streets March 26 to protest against China's recently passed Anti-Secession Law and convey their aspirations for democracy and peace.

Group leader Klaus Rose said that supporting Taiwan is the major work of his group and that as far as he knows, there are a lot of German people who support and sympathize with Taiwan, and that a lot of German media are also concerned about Taiwan.
Rose said the delegation was impressed when it toured Kaohsiung Harbor, the sixth largest container harbor in the world, earlier in the day.
They also visited National Sun Yat-sen University and a new railway station construction project.
The delegation, which arrived in Taiwan March 30, also called on President Chen Shui-bian during their stay. They left Taiwan after their Kaohsiung visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 5 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, April 5:
09: 00, People First Party Chairman James Soong will visit the temporary mausoleum of late President Chiang Kai-shek in Tzuhu, Taoyuan County.

09:00, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan will depart from his party's headquarters for Tzuhu and Touliao, Taoyuan County to visit the temporary mausoleums of late President Chiang Kai-shek and late President Chiang Ching-kuo.
10:20, Representatives of the New Party will visit the temporary mausoleum of late President Chiang Kai-shek in Tzuhu, Taoyuan County.
14: 00, The Taipei Musical Troupe will hold a news conference at the Red Theater in Taipei.
15: 20, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will be interviewed by China Television Co. (CTV) in Nankang, Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN POLICE OFFER ENGLISH HOTLINE FOR VISITORS

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan county government launched a new English help hotline service for foreigners Monday.
By dialing 0911-867110 anytime during the day, information services in English will be provided in a wide range of categories, including travel, search and rescue, and employment.

The hotline, set up by the Taoyuan County Police Department under the instructions of County Magistrate Eric Liluan Chu, is aimed at assisting the 80,000 foreign residents of the northern Taiwan county, the location of the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
While 10,000 check in and out of the airport each day, Taoyuan is also known for accommodating a large number of blue-collar employees from Southeast Asian countries.
Services in other languages will be added in the future, according to Taoyuan County police officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MULLS EXPANSION OF CHANGING RATIO OF STOCK PRICE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The government is considering whether to expand the daily change ratio of stock prices, which is now limited at 7 percent, a government official said Monday.

Lu Tung-ying, vice chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , said that Premier Frank Hsieh instructed related government agencies in a meeting with heads of economic and financial entities to elaborate necessary measures to deal with every possible stock market scenario following the implementation of the ratio change.
Lu said that the FSC is expected to accomplish the preparations by the end of September.
He declined, however, to reveal the exact percentage that the government plans to set to limit the fluctuation of stock prices in a single trading day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU HEAD VISITS YASUKUNI SHRINE IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 4 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A delegation from the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) visited the Yasukuni Shrine in Japan Monday to pay their respects to the Taiwanese and Japanese war dead enshrined there.
TSU Chairman Su Chin-Chiang and his 10-member entourage arrived at the shrine and was greeted by the shrine's abbot, who ushered them into the main hall of the shrine to pay their respects.

Su told journalists accompanying him on the trip that he visited the shrine to show his party's respect for the 28,000 Taiwanese who died as Japanese soldiers during World War II when Taiwan was ruled by Japan as well as Japanese who sacrificed for their country.

Saying that he is the first leader of a Taiwanese political party ever to visit the shrine, Su said he hopes his trip will inspire people around the world to forgive their feuds with one another and work together to create a better future.

The shrine has been at the center of a bitter dispute between Japan and other Asian countries, which take offense at Japanese prime ministers' visits to the shrine because it also enshrines 14 Japanese war criminals of World War II who were executed by the victorious Allies for their crimes.
These Asian states, especially China, consider the visit to be a sign that the country shows no remorse for its war crimes during World War II.
Su expressed sympathy for Japan in the dispute, saying that every country in the world has the freedom to express its respect for soldiers who died for its flag, Japan being no exception.

As head of a party that favors Taiwan independence and denies China's territorial claim over Taiwan, Su showed his disdain for China, saying that country views the shrine with hate. He claimed this hate is not shared by Taiwan or the rest of the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WISHES PFP CHIEF SUCCESSFUL VISIT TO CHINA: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) would wish People First Party Chairman James Soong a successful visit to China and might even ask him to convey a message to Beijing if Soong will consult the opinion of the government and DPP before his departure, a DPP official said Monday.

Dung Li-wen, director of the DPP's Chinese Affairs Department, said, however, that he did not know whether Soong will seek endorsement from the DPP and the government before his trip, in light of Soong's contradictory statements of the last few days.

Dung said that Soong has contradicted his earlier statement that he will built a common front with other political parties before his departure for China by claiming that he will visit China in his private capacity and therefore will not require to inform the government of his trip in advance.
Dung said he doubts whether the PFP chief could visit China as a private person, as this would not be the expectation of either China or the general public in Taiwan.
Since a PFP agricultural delegation is preparing to head for China, Dung said, Soong is probably waiting to see what results from that trip before deciding upon his own visit.

Dung said DPP does not oppose any person or group visiting China, but insists that these trips should be made according to the laws, which is especially important when these Taiwan visitors negotiate with their Chinese hosts on affairs falling within the government's authority, because the "Chinese Communist Party can hurt us more in talks than outside talks."
Under this principle, Dung said, the DPP will not oppose Soong's proposed trip to China as long as he can forge a consensus with the government and other political parties.

Judging from China's persistent attempts to divide the political parties in Taiwan, he predicted that China will reserve its largest charm offense toward Taiwan for KMT Chairman Lien Chan, although it would give Soong the honor of visiting ahead of Lien.
Dung said his party will treat Lien's possible visit to China with the same attitude as it treats that of Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 5, or the 27th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents, is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest" and "Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea who refused to return to the Chinese mainland take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as U.S. chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded U.N. forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years earlier.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders U.S. Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
2000: Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung pays a visit to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party, to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian holds amiable talks with the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, in a landmark encounter at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN CHANCELLOR URGED NOT TO SUPPORT LIFTING OF E.U. ARMS SALES BAN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 4 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The German Green Party on Monday urged German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder not to continue to work for a lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China, pointing to Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law and its human rights problems.

Claudia Roth, chairwoman of the German Green Party, which is part of the German coalition government, said after a meeting with other leaders of the party that China's Anti-Secession Law and its aggressive manner toward Taiwan do not qualify it to request that the E.U. lift its arms sales ban.

Furthermore, lifting the arms embargo against China would send the "wrong message" as China continues to have serious human rights problems, including harming the interests of ethnic minorities and excessive use of the death penalty, Roth said.
Roth added that she believes that German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, also from the Green Party, will advise Schroeder not to support a lifting of the ban.

Emphasizing that the purpose of the E.U.'s China policy is to support democratization in China and to avoid regional dispute, Roth said that a lifting of the arms embargo would not help promote democracy and instead, would only worsen the situation.
Schroeder has reiterated recently that his stance in support of a lifting of the arms sales ban remains unchanged despite opposition from most of the German lawmakers.

It will have a retractable roof, enabling it to be converted into a huge indoor arena for concerts, exhibitions, mass rallies and other events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN SHOULD EXPLAIN CONTROVERSIAL SHRINE VISIT: DPP CAUCUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang should explain the rationale behind his visit to a controversial Japanese Shinto shrine in Tokyo, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus said Tuesday.

William C.T. Lai, a DPP legislative caucus whip, was commenting on Su's visit to the Yasukuni Shrine the previous day. The shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million war dead, including 14 convicted war criminals.

Su is one of a few senior Asian political figures ever to visit the shrine, and his visit immediately drew criticism at home. Aboriginal Legislator May Chin and her supporters even staged a protest at the TSU headquarters in Taipei Monday, accusing Su of dignifying Japan's militarism in the early 20th century and its campaigns against Taiwan's aboriginal people during its colonial rule of the island from 1895 to 1945.

Noting that the people of Taiwan have bitter memories of Japan's militarism during World War II, Lai said Su, as the leader of a major Taiwan political party, should clearly explain to the public the purpose, motivation and target of his visit to the Yasukuni Shrine.

The shrine lists the names of 28,000-plus Taiwanese and 21,000 Korean soldiers, most of whom were forced into military service under Japan's colonial rule. The holy site also lists the names of Japanese civilians who died in fighting.

Visits by Asian leaders to the Shinto shrine in central Tokyo have been extremely rare, but military envoys and attaches from countries in other regions around the world have often paid visits. Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visits to the shrine have tarnished Japan's relations with its neighboring countries, particularly China and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW CREATES VARIABLES OF INSTABILITY: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: China's enactment of an anti-secession law, which authorizes its central military commission to use "non-peaceful" means in dealing with problems in the Taiwan Strait, has expanded Beijing's room to use force against Taiwan, the Republic of China defense minister said Monday.
Defense Minister Lee Jye, who made the comments at a monthly gathering of ministry personnel, also said that the law has brought more variables of instability to peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

Saying that China has tried to mislead the international public and to give itself a legal excuse to use force to resolve the so-called "Taiwan problem" as well as unilaterally change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by enacting the anti-secession law, Lee noted that Beijing also wants to use so-called "legal warfare" and "opinion warfare" as a basis to expand it psychological "war preparedness" in order to achieve its "goal of reunification by force."

Faced with an increasing threat to Taiwan's national security, President Chen Shui-bian has reiterated his "reconciliation, without concession" and "firmness, without confrontation" stance, the minister said, adding that the armed forces, which are responsible for protecting the country and the people, should do their utmost to support the government's policy of pursuing democracy and peace.

Pointing out that only strength can ensure security, peace and hope and that the strength of national development and survival relies on a solid foundation of national defense and security, Lee said that purchasing advanced arms and equipment that can modernize Taiwan's military is part of the process of pursuing peace rather than an arms race with mainland China.

Warning that China's military has more authority and room to attack Taiwan following the enactment of the anti-secession law, Lee said that China will also have a better chance of winning a war against Taiwan if the island postpones purchasing advanced arms and equipment.

He also said that his ministry's arms-procurement project not only considers Taiwan's urgent military needs but also provides Taiwan with a strength of security to develop better cross-strait dialogue and exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMING FOR KMT CHAIRMAN'S CHINA VISIT YET TO BE DETERMINED

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Tuesday he is more than willing to make a "journey of peace" to mainland China, but he added that the timing for his visit has yet to be determined.
Lien made the remarks while visiting the interim mausoleum of the late President Chiang Kai-shek at Tzuhu in Taoyuan County to mark Tomb Sweeping Day and the 30th anniversary of Chiang's death.
In response to a press inquiry about Beijing's invitation to him, Lien said he feels honored to be invited to visit China.

"I would be pleased to visit the mainland on a 'journey of peace, ' but the time has yet to be determined, " Lien said, adding that he has directed his aides to study the most opportune time for him to visit the mainland.

Lien, who just returned to Taipei Monday evening after a vacation in Japan, dismissed as a "joke" the Democratic Progressive Party administration's warning that if he fails to report to the government or obtain the government's approval before departing for a China visit, he could be considered to be breaking Taiwan law.

Lien, a former vice president who lost twice in his bid for the presidency in 2000 and 2004, would not elaborate on the topics he plans to discuss with Beijing leaders during his proposed "journey of peace."
Leading a group of senior KMT officials, Lien also visited the interim mausoleum of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo -- Chiang Kai-shek's son and successor -- at Touliao near Tzuhu Tuesday.
The embalmed bodies of the two late presidents will be interred at the Wutzushan military cemetery in Hsichi, Taipei County later this year.
Taoyuan County Magistrate Chu Li-lun said Monday that the Tzuhu and Touliao mausoleums will be converted into memorial parks after the relocation of the bodies of the two late presidents.
For years, Chu said, the two mausoleums have been major tourist attractions in the northern Taiwan county.

"In addition to bearing great historical significance, the two mausoleums also boast beautiful natural surroundings and unique architectural styles, " Chu said, adding that the county government has decided to convert the two mausoleums into memorial parks or libraries after the interment of the bodies of the two Chiangs.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES LEGISLATURE TO QUICKLY SCREEN CONTROL YUAN NOMINATION LIST

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan should quickly act on the president's nomination list of Control Yuan members for the sake of the public interest, a legislative caucus whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged Tuesday.

William C. T. Lai said the operations of the Control Yuan -- Taiwan's highest watchdog body -- have come to a halt for over two months, with some 3,500 complaints having piled up in that time. He called for a swift screening by the legislature of the name list put forth again by President Chen Shui-bian in order to "save social costs and maintain a good image for the Legislative Yuan."

Inter-party negotiations on the issue broke down Monday after the president submitted the list again to the Legislative Yuan earlier the same day. Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng set a new round of negotiations for Thursday.

The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) refused to screen the list because of dissatisfaction with the fact that the president had not replaced certain controversial figures on the initial list.
The KMT and PFP have made it clear that they will not consent to the list if the president does not change the lineup.
President Chen first submitted the 29-member list to the Legislative Yuan on Dec. 20, 2004 at a time when the term of the third Control Yuan was to expire on Jan. 30, 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFORMATION SERVICES FLAGSHIPS IN THE WORKS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Information services companies are being encouraged to create flagship units with other companies to increase their efficiency through synergy, the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.

Under the so-called "best flagship" project, which is part of the government's efforts to upgrade the manufacturing industry -- a key driving force behind the country's economic development -- local companies in the information services sector are being encouraged to cooperate with other businesses in the fields of manufacturing, distribution, finance, medical treatment and health care, communications, e-commerce, information distribution security, e-commerce, and software creation, IDB officials said.
In the preliminary stage, each flagship enterprise should lead at least three other companies to provide integrated information services or to engage in cooperative development, the officials said.
They added that the IDB will take two years to build up cooperative entities and offer a subsidy of at most NT$30 million (US$949,850) to each applicant during the build-up period.

It is estimated that assisting private businesses to organize 12 service fleets in the information services industry will require about NT$570 million, but the work is expected to build Taiwan into a major global supplier of special information services, the officials said, adding that the project has passed the National Science Council's review and is scheduled to begin in June.
