DOC.HEADLINE: HARMFUL ALGAE APPEARS IN HALF OF TAIWAN'S RESERVOIRS

TEXT.P: A harmful algae that can cause liver damage in humans has appeared in half of Taiwan's 27 reservoirs, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday.
This "green scum" produces the peptide toxin microcystin, which, when ingested in concentration, causes liver damage and can be a major drinking water contaminant.
EPA officials, however, stressed that the algae is only toxic after it dies and the amount of blue-green algae observed in the water so far has been minimal.
"The public has no need to panic over the safety level of the water despite the latest monitoring results," they said.

The officials said that the administration worked with National Taiwan University in February to test for microcystis, commonly known as "reservoir killers, " in reservoirs around Taiwan. Fourteen showed signs of the algae.
Seven small reservoirs in the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu also have microcystis and Feitsui and Hsinshan reservoirs on Taiwan proper have the algae, although the amount is small.

The officials noted that the reservoirs in the outlying islands are confined by their natural environment. Their sizes are small and their accumulated waters are more stagnant, making them susceptible to being contaminated by pollution from farmland and household waste water and rain, which is a prime breeding ground for microcystis.
They advised the public to separate potable water or drink tap water desalinated from the sea.
They said that September will be a critical month since the propagation of the algae will reach its zenith in summer and then begin to die.
The EPA has made plans to monitor the reservoirs in February, May, September and November every year to ensure the safety of the water, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET VALUE CLIMBS TO NT$15 TRILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market had grown to NT$15 trillion ( US$475 billion) by the end of 2004, an increase of 131 percent over the past 10 years, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) of the Executive Yuan.

Total capital accounted for 148.07 percent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) , up from the 1994 share of 101 percent, an indication that the stock market has played an increasingly important role in Taiwan's economy, the DGBAS said.

It said the number of companies listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) and the over-the-counter (OTC) market, as well as their capital, have been increasing as corporations have been growing in size, aided by government deregulation and an ever-transparent flow of information.
By the end of last year, 697 companies were listed on the TAIEX and 466 on the OTC market, the former having a total capital of NT$5.1 trillion and the latter NT$0.6 trillion.

The capitalization on the TAIEX by the end of 2004 was NT$14 trillion, more than double that of a decade earlier. Combined with the OTC market value, Taiwan's stock market had a total value of NT$15.1 trillion, equivalent to 148 percent of its GDP.

The DGBAS said Taiwan's economy has gradually climbed out of the financial depression caused by the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis, registering a yearly growth rate of 5.8 percent in 2000, when stock market turnover reached NT$35 trillion.
But starting in the last quarter of 2000, global high-tech bubbles drove the economy down, dragging Taiwan's stock market turnover down by 40 percent, to NT$20.7 trillion.

Since the beginning of 2004 the economy has turned around, and Taiwan's stock market has fared better too. For example, the average earnings per share (EPS) for the TAIEX and OTC companies reached NT$2.14 and NT$1.54, respectively, the former a six-year high.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST NON-DUES-PAYING KMT MEMBERS CAN VOTE FOR CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Tuesday the dispute over whether or not party members who have not paid their membership dues will be eligible to vote for the party's chairman has been sorted out.

A proposal by the KMT organization and development committee states that KMT members have an obligation to pay membership fees; however, unless they have been disciplined by the party for non-payment of dues, they can still vote even though they have not paid their dues, according to KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng.
"Those who have not been disciplined will be able to vote for party chairman on July 16," Lin said.

Although the party charter stipulates that only those who have paid their membership dues are eligible to vote for the party's chairman, the party will do all it can to contact the people who are behind in their dues and ask them to pay up. If a person does not then pay the dues owing, the party will mete out discipline -- the maximum punishment being the suspension of that person's right to vote on party matters.

KMT spokesman Cheng Li-wen said that the party will ask local chapters to pull out all the stops to get members pay their membership dues, and also work out incentives to get as many party members as possible to pay.
Although the KMT boasts of over one million members, it is believed that fewer than half pay their dues.
Meanwhile, the two KMT vice chairmen vying for the party's top job said Tuesday that they agreed with the compromise proposal to expand the number of members going to the polls.

But Legislator Wu Yu-sheng, a supporter of Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and who originally advocated that only those who have paid their membership dues should be allowed to vote, said that it is still "not fair" to those who have paid their membership dues.
Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao, who backs legislative speaker Wang Jin-pyng, said that both Ma and Wang have agreed that they will try to get as many people as possible to pay their membership dues.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ARMORED AND ARTILLERY UNITS SET UP BY MILITARY POLICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Two new rapid response units -- one armored and one artillery -- were established Monday under the Military Police Command to counter attacks from paratroopers and to deal with terrorist attacks, Military Police Commander Lt. General Shen Shih-chih said Tuesday.
The new units will be housed at the Lungsheng and Chianshih bases in Taipei to beef up defense in the nation's political nerve center.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP AGRICULTURAL DELEGATION PLANS TO VISIT CHINA THIS MONTH

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Tuesday that if a party delegation visits China, it will discuss Taiwan farming groups investing there and the rights of Chinese fishermen working on Taiwan ships.
PFP Legislator Tsai Sheng-chia said that a delegation he is planning to organize will probably leave for China in the middle or latter part of this month.
Once he receives notification from China, Tsai said that he will talk to the government on the fine points of cross-strait farming policy, "mainly to see where the government's bottom line is."

Tsai noted that the government has imposed a great deal of restrictions on farming groups investing in China, and that although the Council of Agriculture has promised to be supportive, the party does not know the real attitude of the government.
In addition, Tsai said that he will communicate with both sides of the Strait on the issue of mainland fishermen, on whom Taiwan fishing vessels rely heavily, to improve their rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FARM EXCHANGES UNCERTAIN DESPITE BEIJING OVERTURE

TEXT.P: Agricultural exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China remain uncertain despite Beijing's offer to broaden contacts and open mainland markets to Taiwan's farm products, industry insiders and experts said Tuesday.

The issue has again become a focal point between the two sides after Beijing came up with the overture at a time when its Anti-Secession Law has poisoned the bilateral relationship. However, experts pointed out that a host of uncertainties remain because Taiwan and China differ in their motives and demands.

China can provide cheap labor, vast land, abundant raw materials and a huge market for Taiwan farmers who are bottlenecked by increased difficulties after the island entered the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Jan. 2002, but they warned of long-term risks, such as technology flight to China and the reshipment of produce back to Taiwan, a situation that might deal a crushing blow to the domestic industry.

Yuan Ming-jen, a consultant at a foundation affiliated with the Mainland Affairs Council to serve mainland-based Taiwan businessmen, opined that it would be much better for Taiwan farmers to set up exploration bases in China with the assistance of the government sector or farmers' associations. This would help give a new lease on life for the domestic industry, he said.

Kung Shih-ming, vice secretary-general of the Cross-Strait Agricultural Association, is optimistic about the prospects for bilateral agricultural cooperation because the two sides complement each other. Exports to China could be a remedy for oversupply at home, he said.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung termed Beijing's promise to offer preferential treatment to Taiwan farm products as just paying lip service since the issue is complex and now is the wrong time with the current cross-strait atmosphere being what it is.
Even if domestic goods are given greater access to the Chinese market, Taiwan's national interests as a whole must take precedence over all other matters, Lee stressed.
COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan also called attention to the issue regarding the reshipment of low-priced produce from China to Taiwan despite its lucrative but volatile market.
Tien Chun-mei, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, said that there is a large gap behind the two sides' motives for promoting agricultural exchanges.

Taiwan is willing to provide technical and managerial assistance to China, while China is more interested in luring investment and trade from Taiwan, she said, adding that the difference has resulted in serious problems such as smuggling.

Chien Lee-hsien, a professor at National Chung Hsing University, pointed out that Beijing has begun using agricultural issues as an approach to deal with Taiwan on the political front. But he pointed out that only concrete measures count despite the fact that an initial opening seems to be in place with a concerted move between the central government in Beijing and local provincial authorities.
If China resorts to using agriculture as a "bargaining chip" to appease farmers in southern Taiwan, cross-strait exchanges in this field will become much more complex in the future, observers said.
In contrast to Taiwan's caution and reserve, China has been very welcome to farm exports from Taiwan and Taiwan farmers settling in China in as much as that would bring in capital and technology.

Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao said on March 14 following Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law that China is willing to open its markets to domestic farm produce, in particular those from southern Taiwan.

Starting from April this year, Beijing's Ministry of Agriculture will provide duty-free treatment to imports of 12 fruits from Taiwan, including mangoes and bell fruit for sale in Beijing and Shanghai. Southern Fujian province is also soon to allow fast customs clearance for Taiwan agricultural imports.

Taking mangoes for example, the two markets can take as much as 2,000 tons of the tropical fruit from Taiwan each year, creating earnings of at least NT$80 million (US$2.6 million) for domestic growers and helping resolve an oversupply in the home market, relevant agricultural agencies estimated.

During a recent China visit by main pposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, Chinese Communist Party officials also promised to draft preferential policies for Taiwan agricultural goods and expressed welcome to Taiwan farmers to settle in five provinces.
Beijing officials said that they hope Taiwan can assist in upgrading agriculture and introduce its food processing, warehousing, transport and distribution know-how in China.

Zhang Juan, a researcher at the Taiwan affairs study center under the Beijing-based Tsinghua University, said Taiwan cultivated tropical fruits and flowers are popular in the vast Chinese market, especially during winter in northern regions where there is a great demand for fruits and vegetable.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES OTHER PARTIES TO HONOR CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM PROMISE

TEXT.P: A senior ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker called on his colleagues from other political parties Tuesday to make good on their campaign promise to pass a constitutional amendment package on political reforms.

Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, pointed out that completing the reforms was a promise shared by all parties during the run-up to last year's legislative elections and that they should not change their mind just because the elections are over.

Lai made the call before the legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Committee is set to start reviewing a bill Thursday governing the exercise of power of the ad hoc National Assembly, which will be elected on May 14 for the sole purpose of considering the constitutional amendment package adopted by the Legislative Yuan with the support of all parties last August.

Items in the package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.

The opposition People First Party (PFP) and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) have recently reversed their support of the reform package and proposed setting a high threshold for the passage of constitutional amendments in the bill.
According to Lai, partisan differences over the content of the bill could stall and kill the constitutional reform.
Inter-party consultations over the bill could take up to four months, leaving the National Assembly delegates powerless after they are elected.

Also, Lai said the PFP's proposals asking for a vote requiring a three-quarter majority for the passage of constitutional amendments and a turnout rate of at least 50 percent for the National Assembly elections are both likely to block the constitutional reform.

Speaking of the issue, Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Policy Committee, said his party believes constitutional amendments should be considered passed if they are endorsed by at least half of the National Assembly delegates.

Chen Chih-pin, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said the PFP insists that a three-quarter threshold be set for the passage of constitutional amendments and that the amendments should be voted on as a package, rather than individually.
Meanwhile, TSU legislative caucus convener Lo Chih-ming said the TSU supports adopting a three-quarter threshold for the passage of constitutional amendments.

Lo said his party is in favor of all of the amendments with the exception of the "single seat, two votes" system and it will have to vote against the package if no individual votes are allowed for the amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN VOWS TO COMMUNICATE WITH PRESIDENT ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong said Tuesday he will communicate with President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Soong made the remarks after heading a group of PFP public office holders to pay tribute to the late President Chiang Kai-shek at his interim mausoleum at Tzuhu in Taoyuan County to mark Tomb-Sweeping Day and the 30th anniversary of Chiang's death.
In reply to a media inquiry about whether he plans to visit China in the near future, Soong said cross-strait relations are very complicated and delicate.
Noting that it takes two to tango, Soong said forging cross-strait rapprochement requires concerted efforts from both sides of the Strait.

While the KMT failed to resolve the cross-strait political dispute during its 55-year rule of Taiwan, Soong said, the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration also has had a hard time achieving a breakthrough to the lingering impasse.

For its part, Soong said, the PFP will promote cross-strait reconciliation with the common well-being of the people on both sides as its ultimate goal. In the process, Soong said, the PFP will see to it that Taiwan's dignity should never be compromised.

"What matters is not which party visits China first. The most important thing lies in the purpose or functions of the visit. What we want is not courteous treatment to be granted by Beijing. What really matters is the Republic of China's national dignity, " Soong said.

While receiving a KMT delegation in Beijing last week, senior Chinese officials publicly invited the two top leaders of Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" -- KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong -- to visit China at times of their convenience.
KMT Chairman Lien has said he is more than willing to visit China, but he added that the timing is still being considered.

Soong said he will communicate with President Chen and Lien in the coming week over cross-strait issues. Nevertheless, Soong stopped short of mentioning whether he would hold face-to-face talks with Chen and Lien over cross-strait topics.

According to media reports, DPP administration officials have expressed the hope that Soong can visit China under the government's authorization. Without the government's prior approval, Soong's China visit would be of a completely private nature just like the KMT delegation's just-concluded visit.

Meanwhile, a DPP official lauded Soong Tuesday for his recent remarks that the government, not any single political party, should play the leading role in formulating cross-strait policy and strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Tory poll surge rattles Labour as battle begins.
The Conservatives have dramatically closed the gap on Labour as Tony Blair launches his attempt to win a third term. A Populus poll for The Times today and three other polls boost Michael Howard as the Prime Minister goes to Buckingham Palace this morning to seek a dissolution of Parliament. All four point to solidifying Tory support.
Financial Times: Mourning for Pope to draw 2m pilgrims.
Up to 2m pilgrims are expected to flood in to Rome this week to pay their last respects to Pope John Paul II, as Vatican officials prepare for a cardinals' conclave that will elect the next man to rule a mighty but deeply divided Roman Catholic Church. About 200 foreign leaders will attend the Pope's funeral, expected to take place at the end of the week. Tributes to his life and work poured in throughout the weekend and today John Paul's body will be transferred to St Peter's Basilica in Rome for public viewing.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA EXPANDS WASTE DISPOSAL REGULATIONS TO 5,000 INSTITUTIONS

TEXT.P: Those in the non-private sector will have to start reporting to the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) this month on how it is dealing with its waste in accordance with current regulations.
The EPA said that some 5,000 companies and institutions subject to the regulations will have to file reports online as to how and where they are disposing of their waste.

EPA officials said the new regulations will include the construction sector, medical institutions, college laboratories, universities and research institutes that produce hazardous waste, photo shops, laundries, the environmental monitoring collection sector, the plating and printing sectors and wholesale markets of agricultural products.

The officials said that the waste produced from the construction sector and medical institutions have often been dumped on roadsides, along riverbeds or on hillsides, which has hampered traffic and polluted the environment.
This is why the EPA has put the construction sector, hospitals, dialysis clinics and smaller clinics on their priority list for regulation, the officials said.

They also said that with the expansion of the regulations and vigorous monitoring, the amount of waste reported grew by 12.2 percent from the previous year to reach 1.52 million tons in 2004. Reporting hazardous waste disposal also showed a marked increase, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO GROUP SEEKS TO BUILD BRAND NAME IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The TECO Group, a conglomerate dealing in a variety of electrical products, will either introduce its own name in China, or buy established international brands to get a toe-hold in the Chinese market, TECO Chairman Theodore M.H. Huang said Tuesday.

Pointing the seriousness the company attaches to this project, Huang said that only two Taiwanese businesses, TECO and the Aurora Group -- a leading provider of office automation equipment in Taiwan -- have constructed large neon ads in Pudong, the commercial area of China's largest city, Shanghai.

However, Huang admitted that it's not easy to build a brand name in an emerging market, adding that the work requires a huge amount of investment and needs time to achieve. Therefore, he noted, he will also seek to take a "short cut, " meaning purchasing a well-known international brand name.

For example, Huang said, by founding TECO-Westinghouse Motor Company after acquiring Westinghouse Motor of the United State in 1995, TECO Group made successful inroads into the Southeast Asian market.

TECO was founded in 1956 as an industrial motor-maker, named TECO Electric and Machinery Co., Ltd. Over the years, it has successfully diversified into a conglomerate with a broad spectrum of business operations in heavy electrics, home appliances, telecommunications equipment, information technology systems, electromechanical components, commercial electronics, stock holdings, and even eateries.

TECO introduced Mos Burger to Taiwan from Japan years ago and has taken a portion of the market share from the dominant fast food businesses in Taiwan, McDonald's, Huang said. He believes the fact that rice hamburgers fit local people's dining habits and better management are the key to Mos Burger's success.

Despite the fact that the TECO group has about 30 subsidiaries and affiliates across Asia, America and Europe, and employs tens of thousands of people, Huang, also a gourmet, said he keeps a close eye on the operations of the Mos Burger chain and is considering expanding to China and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOMB-SWEEPING A HOUSEHOLD AFFAIR FOR RELATIVES OF ZHAO ZIYANG

TEXT.P: Tuesday marks the first Tomb-Sweeping Day since former Chinese Communist Party General Secretary Zhao Ziyang died on Jan. 17, but his family did not have to go to a cemetery to pay their respects as they have kept his ashes at home after disagreeing with Chinese authorities over where to bury him.

Chinese authorities have asked Zhao's family to bury him along with officials at the director-general level -- much lower than what he had been -- at Babao Cemetery, rather than where Chinese party leaders are usually interned.
Zhao's family, saying that that would be "quite inappropriate, " decided to keep his ashes at his Beijing home and "wait for a while" before making a decision.

So on Tuesday, Zhao's kinsmen decorated his study at No. 6 Fuqiang Alley in Beijing with his photo and two couplets that read "We [family members] are proud of you for having promoted democracy and for your conscientiousness; now that you are gone and free, your style will forever be remembered" and "It's our unchanging choice to support your decisions; it's our lifetime honor to be your children."

Since Zhao's house had been closely watched as April 5 approached, many of his friends and relatives came to pay their respects ahead of the holiday celebrated by the Chinese to honor the memories of their departed relatives and to clean their gravesites.

Tian Jiyun, a former deputy chairman of the National People's Congress, was one of the mourners. He left a calligraphy that said: "Three generations of the Tian Jiyun family" before saying good-bye to Zhao's kinsmen.

Zhao's daughter, Wang Yannan, said her family was willing to accept offerings of respect from anyone, but judging from people coming to Fuqiang Alley Tuesday morning, Beijing still was banning the general public from paying tribute to Zhao Ziyang.
So the daughter, Zhao Erjun, Zhao Sijun and other family members performed their own rituals before planting a Chinese magnolia in the garden outside of Zhao's study.
"The white magnolia symbolizes my father's pure personality, so every year, when the flowers begins to bloom, it will be time to remember him," the daughter said.

She said her family has not yet had any further discussion with Chinese officials over where to bury Zhao. "This is an unsettled question that may need to be addressed in the future. Still, we have to wait and see."

Zhao's wife, Liang Boqi, has not been told of her husband's death because the children are worried that the news would upset her too much, given her frail health. She is staying at a seniors facility.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA TO ASSIST DOMESTIC ENTERPRISES IN EXPLORING FOREIGN MARKETS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) will increase efforts to assist domestic enterprises in exploring foreign markets in the near future, TAITRA officials said Saturday.

The surge of the new Taiwan dollar, high price of oil on international markets and the rising prices of materials sold on the international market will have a negative impact on this year's export orders for domestic enterprises, the officials said.

TAITRA will cooperate with the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to find countries with favorable economic incentives for domestic enterprises, including Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania, South Africa and Colombia, the officials said, adding that TAITRA will invite enterprises operating in foreign countries and representative offices of those countries in Taiwan to explain their country's business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGLE-PARENT FAMILIES ON THE RISE: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The ratio of single-parent families to the total number of local households has increased and more mothers now play the role of breadwinner, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Quoting the findings of the DGBAS survey of household income and expenditure in 2003, statisticians said many local mothers are not just homemakers, but rather breadwinners.

According to the DGBAS report, Taiwan had 6.96 million households in 2003, 573,000 of which were single-parent families, or 8.2 percent of the total. The ratio marked a 1.2 percent rise from the 1997 level.
Among single-parent families, 52.8 percent were financially supported by mothers, compared to 47.2 percent supported by fathers.
In contrast, male breadwinners accounted for 78.8 percent of overall local households.
According to the survey, 22.7 percent of the breadwinners in single-parent families were college graduates or higher degree holders, falling 5 percent below the percentage for overall households.
Of the 573,000 single-parent families, 318,000 were financially supported by parents and the remaining 255,000 were supported by children.

Among parent-supported single-parent families, female breadwinners accounted for 72.1 percent, up 3.1 percent from the 1997 level. Meanwhile, 50.2 percent of breadwinners in this type of family had education level below junior high school and their average monthly household income was NT$53,000, falling below the average income of overall local households by NT$15,000.

Meanwhile, 169,000 single-parent families had children under 18 years of age, with 44,000 featuring male breadwinners, roughly same as the 1997 level. By comparison, this category of family with the mother as breadwinner increased 26,000 from the 1997 level. The average monthly household income of this family bracket was only NT$44,000 and children's education spending accounted for 19.4 percent of total income.

Among single-parent families with children as breadwinners, the average monthly household income was NT$54,000. This category of family usually had elderly mothers or fathers and medical bills accounted for 15.8 percent of their total household expenditure.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS SOCIETY OF ROC LOOKING FOR MYSTERIOUS DONOR OF US$750,000

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China is looking for an anonymous philanthropist who has donated the single largest donation -- US$750,000 (NT$23 million) -- to the society.
Reports said the anonymous donor sent a check via UBS AG, Taipei branch recently, with Hau Lung-bin, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society, being the designated recipient.
Hau said that he was on business trip in Hong Kong when his secretary informed him about the check. The check was sent from Taipei with no return address.
Although stunned, Hau said he has always had faith in others, and believes that the donation "must be true, " The bank informed him that the money was deposited into the bank account Monday.

The Red Cross Society has wanted to say thank you to the person with a heart of gold, but the bank said it cannot disclose the identity of the sender out of confidentiality concerns. The Red Cross Society hopes the media will help in locating the sender to thank him or her in person, and to understand what the person wishes the money to be used for.

To protect the privacy of the donor, if he or she insist on not coming forward, the Red Cross wishes to say thank you through the media, the officials said. They also said that donated materials to tsunami victims in South and Southeast Asia are currently sufficient, and if the identity of the benevolent donor remains a mystery, the money will be used to prepare for possible disasters.

They said that since the inception of the society, individual donations have not been big. The two biggest donations from individuals were from a friend of a dead veteran who donated a NT$1 million, and another was also an anonymous person who donated NT$1.2 million, with Hau also being listed as the recipient in the latter case.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pope's Funeral Is Set for Friday.
The body of Pope John Paul II, who died two days ago in his bedroom in the Apostolic Palace In the Vatican,laid upon a red velvet bier, was carried Monday in a solemn procession from the palace and presented to a reverent public in St. Peter's Square. Inside the palace, the cardinals assumed temporary control of the Roman Catholic Church and took an oath of secrecy about their deliberations. They scheduled the pope's funeral for Friday at 10 a.m. and made it clear that the pope would be buried here, according to tradition, rather than in his native Poland, as some had speculated.
Wall Street Journal: Morgan Stanley Plans to Spin Off Discover Card.
Investment bank Morgan Stanley, after a week of internal dissent and heavy criticism from a group of shareholders and eight former executives, said it is looking to spin off its Discover credit- card unit -- a business built by Chief Executive Philip Purcell. The move, an abou t-face by the company, was one of several steps announced late yesterday that signaled an effort to quell the turmoil around Purcell's leadership and performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR INTENDS TO VISIT CHINA AFTER ENDING MAYORAL TERM

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday he does not rule out the possibility of visiting China after concluding his mayoral term in 2006.
Ma divulged his intention while videotaping an interview with Sisy Chen, a TV talk show host, in the afternoon.
Under current regulations, Ma said, he cannot visit China in his capacity as Taipei mayor.
"Therefore, I can't accompany Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on his planned China visit in the near future, " said Ma, who is also a KMT vice chairman.
Ma is currently vying with Legislative Yuan speaker Wang Jin-pyng, another KMT vice chairman, for the opposition party's chairmanship.

"If I manage to win the KMT chairmanship in July, I would be willing to visit China in my capacity as the top KMT leader after ending my mayoral term," Ma said, adding that a prerequisite for his China visit would be that the trip would have to be conducive to Taiwan's development and peace across the Taiwan Strait.

He further said he believes that Lien's overture that Taiwan should refrain from pursuing independence while China should renounce the use of force against Taiwan can serve as the bedrock for a viable framework for peaceful cross-strait engagements.
Touching on the KMT chairmanship race, Ma said that if he wins the election, he will fully cooperate with Wang in running KMT headquarters, including policy formulation and personnel appointments.
Ma also said he will continue to employ incumbent party workers appointed during Lien's chairmanship if he wins the July election.
KMT rank-and-file members are scheduled to elect the party chairman July 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERSONALIZED WEBSITES `NEW HANGOUTS'

TEXT.P: Customizable personal Websites have become the latest popular hangout for Internet surfers, according to a survey by the Taiwan-based portal Youthwant.
Internet portal giants such as Yahoo have begun to offer free upgrades to their online storage services, allowing surfers to create their own personalized websites.

Although creating a Website may not be a novelty for experienced Internet users, last year saw the rise of blogs in Taiwan. Blogging, which has been extremely popular elsewhere in the world for many years, offers interactive features that turns such sites into "virtual lounge bars," the portal claimed.

Blogs are usually a combination of Internet services, including message boards, photo albums and sometimes even a chatroom. Blogs not only allow users to keep journals or diaries online, but those who browse them can also leave comments or questions, creating an interactive environment for both friends and strangers. The anonymous, interactive and boundless characteristics of blogging cater to the needs of those who are too shy to reveal their identities on the Web, as well as those who are bold enough to express themselves in cyberspace,

Nevertheless, what differentiates blogging from the old-fashioned, text-only personal websites is the ability to permit users to complement their sites by adding photos, which, courtesy of the affordability of digital cameras, eventually create uniqueness.
According to the Youthwant survey, 87 percent of Taiwanese students have at least once browsed an online photo album, while 56 percent of them maintain their own.

Yahoo's recent US$40 million purchase of Flickr, a Canada-based online photo sharing service with over 5 million photos stored in its database, shows how promising it sees the market for personalized Websites, even though Yahoo already has a photo album service.
While a growing number of cyberspace lounge bars are being created each day, this popular hangout place is also quietly morphing into a bloody battleground for the dot-com's.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG LABOR GROUP PROTESTS AGAINST BEIJING'S INTERFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 5 (CNA) (By Semy Chen, Lin Yu-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Members of a Hong Kong labor group staged a demonstration in the special administrative region Tuesday to protest against what they called Beijing's manipulation of an upcoming by-election for region's chief executive.

According to the protesters from the Hong Kong and Kowloon Trade Union Council, reports that acting chief executive Donald Tsang has been designated by Beijing as the next leader have discouraged other candidates who were interested in running for the post and have undermined the fairness of the election.

The government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region's plan to request the National People's Congress (NPC) of China to make a legal interpretation concerning the term of the next chief executive also indicates that the by-election is being manipulated by Beijing, the protesters said.
They claimed that the situation could threaten the autonomy of Hong Kong and turn the by-election into a farce.
An electoral college in Hong Kong is set to elect a new chief executive July 10 to fill the position left vacant by Tung Chee Hwa, who resigned last month.

The government of Hong Kong reportedly is planning to request the NPC Wednesday to issue an interpretation on whether the new chief executive will serve out the remainder of Tung's term until 2007 or get another five-year mandate.
However, the majority of people in Hong Kong have demanded that a popular vote be held to elect the chief executive.

According to a vote held among students of the University of Hong Kong between March 30 and April 1, 69 percent of the 2,100 students taking part in the vote are in favor of a general election for chief executive starting from 2007, compared with 24 percent who are against the idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUP TO PROTEST AGAINST TSU HEAD'S VISIT TO JAPANESE SHRINE

TEXT.P: A women's group that has assisted Taiwan women and children forced by the Japanese imperial army into sexual slavery in military brothels during World War II said Tuesday that it will launch a drive to protest against the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), whose chairman concluded a visit the previous day to a controversial Japanese Shinto Shrine honoring Japan's war dead, including many executed war criminals.

The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF) said it plans to launch a letter, telephone, fax and email campaign to the TSU to express their indignation. It will also link up with other social welfare groups to protest against the TSU.
At issue is the pro-Taiwan independence TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang's visit to the Yashukuni Shrine Monday.

Lai Tsai-er, director of the foundation's department of international affairs, noted that the demands by "comfort women" -- as the World War II sex slaves are euphemistically known -- for compensation have fallen on the deaf ears of the Japanese government, and she said she could not understand why the TSU head would want to visit the shrine.
Lai said that Asian countries who have cooperated with the foundation over the years have also inquired why any Taiwanese would want to pay tribute by visiting the shrine.
" I could only explain that this was the action of just a very few people," Lai said.
She said some of the surviving comfort women have also phoned the foundation to complain about the insensitivity of Su's visit.

William C.T. Lai, a legislator from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), earlier Tuesday demanded an explanation from Su for the visit, while Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the opposition Kuomintang said Su should apologize.

Ma noted that whether or not Taiwan people were forced into the Japanese army during the war, Japan was fighting an "unjust war" and pro-unification or pro-Taiwan independence political parties should not visit the shrine.

Su is the first Taiwan political party head to visit the shrine, and his visit immediately sparked criticism at home. Aboriginal Legislator May Chin of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union accused Su of glorifying Japan's militarism in the early 20th century and its bloody and brutal campaign against Taiwan's aboriginal people during the colonial rule of the island from 1895 to 1945. Chin likened Su's visit to Jews worshipping the Nazis.

Su responded by urging people to put aside historical feuds and hatred to pursue peace, adding that his visit was to pay tribute to the 28,000 recruited Taiwanese who died in war and housed in the shrine as well as the Japanese who died for their country.

Visits by Asian leaders to the shrine in central Tokyo have been extremely rare, but military envoys and attaches from countries in other regions around the world have often paid visits. Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visits to the shrine have caused tension with its neighboring counties, particularly China and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS ACTIVIST UNDER HOUSE ARREST IN CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 5 (CNA) (By Chen-yi Liao and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: An AIDS activist friend of the daughter of former Chinese Communist Party General Secretary Zhao Ziyang was detained and put under house arrest Tuesday when he tried to pay his respects to the memory of the deceased Chinese leader.
April 5 is Tomb-Sweeping Day, a holiday for Chinese to honor the memories of their departed relatives and clean their graves.
Hu Jia was arrested "for affecting social order" as he approached Zhao's house in Beijing.

He became a friend of Zhao's daughter Wang Yannan soon after her father's death, when he paid tribute to Zhao -- who died Jan. 17 -- and called for a period of public mourning, for which he was also put under house arrest.
Questioned as to why Hu was arrested, Qin Gang, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry in Beijing, said he knew little about the incident.
Hu also fell foul of the Beijing authorities for disclosing the truth of the situation of AIDS patients in Henan Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG GROUP WANTS REDRESS OF INJUSTICE FOR TIANANMEN VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 5 (CNA) (By Semy Chen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong civic organization petitioned the Chinese government Tuesday to redress the miscarriage of justice in the Tiananmen Massacre of June 4, 1989 and to mourn the democracy activists killed in the bloody crackdown.

Members of the April Fifth Action marched to the liaison office of the People's Republic of China government in Hong Kong to relay their demand to mark Tomb-Sweeping Day, a traditional Chinese festival when Chinese people honor their ancestors.

The protesters had a brief standoff with police after they were blocked from approaching the entrance to the office. Two representatives were later allowed to lay wreaths, read a statement and observe a moment of silent for the massacre victims at the entrance.

Also Tuesday, members of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements in China held a ritual to commemorate those murdered by the communist authorities in the massacre and late Communist Party of China General Secretary Zhao Ziyang, who supported the pro-democracy demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL SPORTING GOODS SHOW TO OPEN APRIL 15

TEXT.P: The 32nd Taipei International Sporting Goods Show will be held April 15-18 at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) reported Tuesday.
The exhibition will bring together a total of 300 exhibitors from Taiwan and abroad, with more than 1,400 booths available, TAITRA officials said.

The first "new product awards" will be presented during the show, and various innovations will be displayed on site to help overseas buyers find the latest products in the shortest period of time, they said.
A conference on the international sporting goods market will also be held alongside the exhibition, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CHAIRMAN PITCHES FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-JAPAN SECURITY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang said Tuesday that Taiwan and Japan should strengthen cooperation in maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait.

Su made the remarks upon his return from a visit to Japan where he attended the inaugural ceremony for the party's chapter in Japan and a meeting of an association composed of Japanese supporters of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's so-called "spiritual leader."

During his visit, Su said he held extensive talks with Japanese parliamentarians, scholars, defense officials and experts on the Taiwan Strait issues in the wake of China's enactment of its so-called anti-secession law that codifies its longtime threat to attack Taiwan.
Su said Japanese politicians and academics have expressed strong concern about the Taiwan Strait security and stability in the face of China's fast military buildup and expansionism.

"My visit was fruitful. We have reached a consensus with many Japanese lawmakers that a Taiwan-Japan security cooperation meeting will be held alternately in Taipei and Tokyo in the future to hammer out common strategies against China," Su said.

Su also defended his visit to a controversial Japanese Shinto shrine in Tokyo Monday, saying that his visit was aimed at paying tribute to the 28,000-plus Taiwanese soldiers who died fighting for the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II when Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule.

Su is one of only a few senior Asian political figures ever to visit the Yasukuni Shrine, which is dedicated to 2.5 million war dead, including some convicted war criminals. His visit immediately drew criticism at home.
Nowadays, Su said, the biggest threat to Taiwan's security mainly comes from China, not Japan and China should be blamed for its militarism.
Su said his visit to the shrine was arranged by the TSU's Japanese chapter chief, not Taiwan's representative office in Tokyo.
Meanwhile, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming claimed that local people need not continue harboring hostility toward Japan because of its past militarism.

"At present, the biggest threat to Taiwan's security comes from China. It's very regrettable that pro-unification people have seldom criticized China's missile threat against us and have instead continued to bash Japan for its historical mistake," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECIAL ENVOY TO POPE'S FUNERAL TO BE DETERMINED SOON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will name a special envoy to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral in the coming one or two days, Presidential Office spokesman Chen Wen-chung said Tuesday.
According to the spokesman, the government is discussing the special envoy issue with the Vatican, which maintains an embassy in Taipei.
"President Chen will make a decision soon, " Chen Wen-chung said, adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is still negotiating the issue with the Holy See.

The Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe. Asked whether President Chen is likely to attend the pontiff's funeral in person, Chen Wen-chung said the government does not rule out any possibilities.

Pope John Paul II died early Sunday (Taipei time) . According to Catholic church regulations, a new pope must be elected from among the 100-plus cardinal bishops around the world in 20 days. By then, President Chen must also name a special envoy to head a delegation to attend the new pope's enthronment ceremony in the Vatican.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI UNVEILS ENERGY CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) unveiled Tuesday its latest energy-saving technology, claiming that it uses up to 40 percent less power.

ITRI Executive Vice President Chu Hsin-sen said the new technology, called "Energy Electronic Technology, " can efficiently manage energy consumption and reduce emissions. Air conditioners using the technology can use 30 percent - 40 percent less energy, which in Taiwan's sub-tropical climate could mean great savings on energy.

The new technology, developed by the nation's leading technology institute, was born in the face of the Kyoto Protocol, an agreement that came into effect in February against global climate change by restricting each country's energy consumption. Taiwan ranks 22nd in the emissions category, accounting for 1 percent of world's total output.

The institute also displayed some applications of the new technology in its Hsinchu headquarters in northern Taiwan, including inverters, system integration, high-efficiency illumination and network monitoring products.
While some households have already begun using some energy-saving appliances, the new technology is anticipated to be adopted extensively in the future, according to Chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN MARINE SETTLES OIL DISCHARGE CASE IN U.S.

TEXT.P: Evergreen Marine Corp. said Tuesday that it has agreed to pay US$25 million to settle a case in relation to illegal oil discharges in U.S. waters and will work with the U.S. government on the execution of an environmental project over a probation period over the next three years.
Evergreen said that the case was caused by the dereliction of duty by a few crewmembers and was not the result of an authorization of the company or its policy.
Some of the 10 crewmembers involved in the case had already quit, while others were being transferred back to company headquarters to receive more training.
Evergreen will strengthen the training for its crewmembers so that they will rigorously follow standard procedure in handling oil discharges, Evergreen said.

At issue was a U.S. government probe March 4, 2001, after the discovery of an oil discharge in the Columbia River in the West Coast U.S. state of Washington. The U.S. Coast Guard traced the spill to Ever Group, a container vessel managed by Evergreen Marine Corp.

The company said that to avoid the squandering of unnecessary manpower and resources on long legal litigation, it began to discuss the matter with the U.S. Justice Department in the first half of 2004 and recently reached a plea agreement.
Evergreen stressed that the case will not have any effect on the normal operation of the company's fleet, its mooring in U.S. harbors, or the cargo the company takes in and out of U.S. harbors.

The company said that global marine environmental protection is crucial and that it will work with port authorities of other nations, introduce a professional auditing system to strengthen vessel regulation, and sail new vessels built according to the "greenship concept."
Evergreen will take delivery of the new vessels starting this September.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES TO HOLD 2ND MEETING WITH PFP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is more than willing to meet with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong again to discuss matters of mutual concern, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng said Tuesday.

Ma made the remarks after Soong said earlier in the day that he will step up communications with Chen and opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan over issues regarding relations across the Taiwan Strait.
To the best of his understanding, Ma said, Chen welcomes the holding of a second meeting with Soong to discuss topics of mutual interest.

Speaking at a news conference, Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's public affairs department, said the Presidential Office will contact the PFP headquarters to flesh out the timing and format for a second such meeting as soon as possible.
Chen and Soong held a rare meeting Feb. 24 during which they reached a 10-point consensus on the development of cross-strait relations and domestic constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 6 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, April 6:
09: 00, The weekly Cabinet meeting will be held at the Executive Yuan.
09: 00, The Legislative Yuan's committees will start their sessions for the day.
09: 00, The opposition Kuomintang will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive International Softball Federation President Don E. Porter at the Presidential Office.
10: 00, The Human Chain Alliance of Taiwan will hold a news conference at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall in Taipei.
11: 00, A news conference following the Cabinet meeting will be held at the Government Information Office.
11: 30, Visiting French Education Ministry officials will hold a news conference at the Central Government Offices Joint Building in Taipei.
14: 30, The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union will hold a news conference at the party's headquarters.
14:30, The Science and Technology Advisory Group of the Executive Yuan will hold a news conference at the Technology Building in Taipei on its bio-medical technology development program.
15: 00, The Nuke-4 Referendum Initiative Association will visit the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's headquarters.
16: 00, The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan will issue reports on commodity prices for March at the DGBAS headquarters.
16: 20, The Banking Department of the Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES SHOULD ABIDE BY LAW: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian convened a major meeting Tuesday in which the participants reached a seven-point conclusion, including that cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should abide by the law.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office and one of the participants in the meeting, said Chen invited officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to the meeting in view of the latest cross-strait political and economic development, including a visit to China by a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the wake of the passage of China's Anti-Secession Law March 14.

KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, during his March 28-April 1 visit, which covered a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, protection of China-based Taiwan businessmen, the rights of Chinese fishermen working on Taiwan fishing vessels, and further easing of China's financial market.

The participants in the meeting concluded that cross-strait affairs are related to the national sovereignty and the exercise of the government's authority. No political parties, groups or individuals have the right to represent the Taiwan people or replace the government's authority.

Cross-strait exchanges should abide by the law and anyone who reaches agreement with foreign governments, the other side of the Taiwan Strait or the envoys they dispatch will be dealt with according to the law by related agencies.

Other conclusions reached by the participants included that the overall interests of the nation and the wellbeing of the people are above the interests of political parties, especially cross-strait contacts, dialogue and consultation, which should require prior consensus among the political parties and the general public for the maximum interests of the nation.
Chen is willing to meet with leaders from the ruling and opposition parties so as to avoid a craze of "China fever" undermining Taiwan's dignity and interests.

The participants pointed out that the biggest difference between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is not about separate rule, but democracy vs. authoritarianism. If Beijing really wants to close the gap between the peoples on both sides, it should not try to lure Taiwan with small favors under its undemocratic system.
As a rising power, Beijing should seriously consider that it should serve as the keeper of international peace and not an intimidator who uses non-peaceful means to sabotage the international order.
Only the 23 million people of Taiwan have the right to decide the fate of the nation and that the Beijing authorities should address and respect the will of the majority of people on Taiwan.

Cross-strait differences should be resolved peacefully through dialogue and that the choice of the Taiwan people under free will should be respected. The Taiwan people adamantly oppose China's legislation of the Anti-Secession Law and its attempts to resolve cross-strait disputes by "undemocratic and non-peaceful means, " they said.
The government will base cross-strait relations on the principle of "reconciliation without flinching and steadfastness instead of confrontation."

Faced with China's persistent denial of Taiwan's sovereignty and its government's attempt to split Taiwan and mislead the international community, the Cabinet should respond immediately in a steadfast and unequivocal manner.

Cross-strait trade policy should base on the principles of "stand ing firmly on Taiwan soil yet reaching out to the world, " and "active opening, effective management, " so as to carry out the ideals of investing in Taiwan first to ensure the country's economic lifeline.
They stressed that the government should not ignore the crucial "effective management" and said the national security and administrative agencies should immediately adjust related trade policy.
On issues related to cross-strait agriculture and service sectors, the government should conduct consultations under the framework of the World Trade Organization, they added.

Those attending the meeting included Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, Presidential Office Director Lin Teh-hsun, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Premier Frank Hsieh, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Lee Ying-yuan, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang, KMT Policy Committee Director Ker Chien-ming, and the DPP caucus whips in the legislature Chao Yung-ching and William C.T. Lai.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TRYING TO PREVENT BEIJING INTERFERING IN TAIWAN POLITICS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian continued trying to prevent Beijing from interfering in Taiwan's politics by convening a major meeting of officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday, a DPP official said.

The meeting was aimed at clarifying the government's position on cross-Taiwan Strait issues in the face of visits to China by domestic political leaders, particularly those of the opposition camp, according to Ker Chien-ming, director of the DPP's policy committee.
Taiwan will descend into anarchy should the government fail to take action in the face of the current situation, he added.

The meeting, which was attended by Vice President Annette Lu, Presidential Office Secretary General Yu Shyi-kun, Deputy Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng, Presidential Office Director Lin Teh-hsun, National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Premier Frank Hsieh, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i, Secretary-General of the Executive Yuan Lee Ying-yuan, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai, Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang, Ker Chien-ming, and the DPP caucus whips in the legislature Chao Yung-ching and William C.T. Lai, reached a seven-point conclusion, including that cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should abide by the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 6, or the 28th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath, which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, whose goal was to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were destroyed during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: U.S. naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing or injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester B. Pearson.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Beijing.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people onboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.
1998 Citicorp merges with Travelers Group Inc., becoming the largest corporation in the world in terms of assets. The new firm is worth more than US$70 billion.
1999: Indonesian President B.J. Habibie assures visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Shih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bien says that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, calls on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and expresses his gratitude for Lee's promotion of increased Taiwan-Tibet exchanges during his term in office.
2004: Lithuanian President Rolandas Paksas is impeached by the Parliament, making him the first European popularly elected president to step down due to impeachment.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them is to betray them."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO COOPERATE WITH ANY INVESTIGATIONS INTO LEGALITY OF CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will fully cooperate with any investigations that the administration may launch into the legality of the recent visit to mainland China by a KMT delegation, KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang said Wednesday.

Chiang, who led the delegation to China March 28-April 1 and reached a 10-point consensus with the Beijing leadership, said that he and the KMT understand the existing Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area and would not violate the law by any means.
He said the Democratic Progressive Party administration has the right to investigate the matter and that the KMT would fully cooperate with any such investigations.
Local newspapers reported Wednesday that law enforcement authorities may take legal action against the KMT for the China visit and could soon start investigations.

President Chen Shui-bian met with officials from the DPP, the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan Tuesday night. The meeting was aimed at clarifying the government's position on cross-Taiwan Strait issues in the face of visits to China by domestic political leaders, particularly those of the opposition camp, according to Ker Chien-ming, director of the DPP's policy committee.
President Chen reportedly said during the meeting that Taiwan will descend into anarchy should the government fail to take action in the face of the current situation.
A seven-point conclusion was reached at the meeting, including that all cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should be in line with the law.
Responding to the conclusions, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said that the KMT welcomes the DPP administration to take legal action against the KMT for the China visit.
Lin called for the DPP not to continue making themselves into "a laughingstock" by questioning the legality of efforts to defend Taiwan and protect the interests of the people.
Meanwhile, Chiang also said that the rationale behind the KMT's mission to China was to seek cross-Taiwan Strait peace, as well as long-term, healthy economic development for Taiwan.

Noting that peace and prosperity are inextricably linked, Chiang said that "Taiwan's economic development hinges on investment, that investment hinges on confidence, and that confidence hinges on cross-strait peace."
As a major opposition party in Taiwan, the KMT is responsible for pushing for peace across the strait so that Taiwan's economy can be revived, Chiang claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD ACTIVELY DRUMS UP SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WHA BID
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 5 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top health official said Tuesday that medical and health experts attending the World Medical Forum understand and support Taiwan's bid for observer status in the World Health Assembly (WHA), the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization.

Hou Sheng-mou, minister of the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan, who is also attending the two-day forum being held in Zurich, Switzerland April 4-6, said the experts also agreed that health is a "fundamental human right" which should be separated from politics.

He said he explained to medical and health professionals and experts from other countries at the meeting that Taiwan's participation in the global health system will not only benefit the people of the island, but also the rest of the world.
Almost all the participants in the forum agreed with Taiwan's WHA bid to be included in the world health body, saying that health should be separated from politics as it is a fundamental human right.

Nevertheless, the DOH head preferred to remain low key on the issue of Taiwan's bid to participate in this year's WHA meeting, which is set to begin May 16 in Geneva, saying that it is for the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to respond to relevant questions.
Asked about China's willingness expressed recently to assist in having Taiwan participate in the WHA's technical affairs, Hou said that he has not received any messages on the matter.

Hou is expected to visit some other European countries after the conclusion of the forum to strengthen exchanges and cooperation with medical institutions in those countries. This is Hou's first visit to Europe since becoming the DOH head.

A total of 150 professionals and experts attended discussions of the forum on the themes of the impact of modern medical technology on medical care services and medical and health insurance systems in various countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: U.S. Will Tighten Passport Rules; Canada, Mexico Borders to Be Affected by 2008.
Millions of Americans will be required to show passports when they reenter the United States from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean by 2008 under new rules announced yesterday by the State and Homeland Security departments, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT SHOULD COOPERATE TO PASS NATIONAL ASSEMBLY STATUTE: KMT

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker said Wednesday the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should cooperate with his party to facilitate passage of a draft statute governing the operations of the mission-oriented National Assembly.

KMT Legislator Lin Hung-che made the appeal after three lesser opposition parties -- the People Fist Party (PFP) , the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) -- called for a second look at the legislature-approved constitutional amendments package to be put up for endorsement by the soon-to-be-elected National Assembly.

According to Lin, the PFP and the TSU intend to push for changing the provision in the Cabinet -proposed draft NA operations statute regarding the number of National Assembly members needed to pass the legislature-approved constitutional amendments package from a simple majority of members to three quarters of the members.
Lin said he believes that the PFP and the TSU want to veto the critical amendment package by setting such a high threshold.

Noting that the package passed by the Legislative Yuan last August is crucial to domestic legislative and political reforms, Lin said the DPP and the KMT, which jointly control more than 70 percent of legislative seats, should cooperate to ensure the passage of the version of the National Assembly statute that requires only a simple majority for the endorsement of the constitutional amendments package.

The package includes halving the number of legislative seats to 113, changing the legislative electoral system to a "single seat, two ballots" system, abolishing the mission-oriented National Assembly, and enshrining the referendum system into the Constitution.

As the "single seat, two ballots" electoral system adopted in the package may hinder the development of small parties, the PFP, the TSU and the NPSU have backpedaled on their previous support for the package.

The legislature is scheduled to screen six versions of the NA operations statute proposed by the government and various political parties Thursday. It remains uncertain whether the draft statute can be included into the legislature's work agenda for the coming week. If the draft statute cannot be enacted in time, the mission-oriented National Assembly to be elected May 14 will be unable to operate.

A total of 300 National Assembly members will be elected in accordance with a proportional system, with voters required to vote for political parties or legally registered groups composed of at least 20 members instead of individual candidates.
