DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO MEET OPPOSITION LEADERS OVER PROBLEMATIC 'CHINA RUSH': AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian would like to meet with leaders of the nation's various political parties for summits on a prospective spate of China visits which may result in harm to Taiwan's dignity and interests, a top presidential aide said Wednesday.

Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun noted that he will start planning for the summit meetings between President Chen and the leaders of the various opposition parties soon after consulting with the president on the precise times and agenda of the meetings.
On who President Chen may meet first, Yu said that the president will remain open on this issue.

President Chen met with officials from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan at his residence Tuesday night. The meeting was aimed at clarifying the government's position on cross-Taiwan Strait issues in the face of visits to China by domestic political leaders, particularly those of the opposition camp.
President Chen reportedly said during the meeting that Taiwan will descend into anarchy should the government fail to take action in the face of the current situation.
A seven-point conclusion was reached at the meeting, including that all cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should be in line with the law.
The conclusions stressed that national interests and the people's welfare should always come before political parties' interests and personal gain.

According to the conclusions, there should be no contact, dialogue or negotiations by Taiwan's political parties with the Chinese authorities without consensus between the ruling and the opposition parties in advance for the sake of safeguarding the interests of the country as well as its people.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang led a KMT delegation to China March 28-April 1 and reached a 10-point consensus with the Beijing leadership, leading to scathing criticism from the Democratic Progressive Party administration and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, a DPP ally.
The DPP administration may even launch investigations into the legality of the recent visit to China by the KMT delegation.
Local newspapers reported Wednesday that law enforcement authorities may take legal action against the KMT for the China visit and could soon start investigations.

It has been widely speculated that the KMT delegation's China visit could set off a wave of visits to China by opposition leaders, including KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN FOREIGN MINISTER OPPOSES LIFTING OF E.U. ARMS SALES BAN
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 5 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer has publicly voiced his stance against German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's China policy by saying in an interview that he opposes a lifting of the European Union's arms sales ban against China.

Fischer, who is a member of the Green Party, which is part of the German coalition government, said in the interview with the German nationwide weekly "Die Zeit" that Schroeder knows that he has his doubts about the matter and his party also has doubts about the E.U. plan to lift the ban. The interview will appear in the weekly's April 6 issue.

Since Schroeder reiterated recently that his stance in support of a lifting of the arms sales ban remains unchanged despite opposition from most of the German lawmakers, the German media and political circles have awaited clarification from Fischer on his stance on the issue.

Almost all the German political parties, including the Green Party, consider that this is not the right time to lift the E.U. ban as Beijing has recently enacted an anti-secession law authorizing the use of force against Taiwan in certain situations.

The Green Party on Monday also urged Schroeder not to continue to work for a lifting of the E.U. arms sales ban, saying that Beijing's anti-secession law and its aggressive manner toward Taiwan do not qualify it to request that the E.U. lift the ban.

Fischer also requested those who support a lifting of the ban to make concessions, saying that those who want to reach a consensus must shorten their distance with those who oppose a lifting of the ban. "Only by doing this, can doubts be removed," he added.

Emphasizing that foreign ministers of the E.U. countries can only lift the ban by a unanimous vote, Fischer said that Beijing's human rights record, regional stability, the E.U. code of conduct for arms exports and U.S. opinions toward a lifting of the ban should be taken into consideration before lifting the ban.

The minister also made an assessment of the Taiwan Strait situation, saying that there had been positive developments, including the inauguration of special cross-strait flights during the Lunar New Year period, prior to Beijing's enactment of the anti-secession law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN UNDER INVESTIGATION OVER 10-POINT DEAL WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: Judicial authorities are investigating whether opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang has violated any laws by reaching a consensus with Beijing authorities during his recent visit to China, Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin said Wednesday.

At a session of the legislature's Judiciary Committee, Shih noted that a person can be charged with treason according to the Criminal Code for agreeing secretly with a foreign government on matters requiring the authorization of the government. Those charged with such a crime could face a maximum penalty of life imprisonment, he added.

According to Shih, the term "agreeing" means coming to terms on substantial items, either verbally or in writing, but he added that this does not include exchanges of views and discussions of some common ideals.

Shih stressed that private individuals or groups, without the government's authorization, are prohibited from forging agreements with foreign governments, and he urged the public to pay attention to this legal restriction.

As far as the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area is concerned, visits to China by private individuals or groups are not in violation of the law as long as the visits do not involve government or political matters, he explained.
The minister said prosecutors will look into Chiang's case to see whether his act constitutes a crime.

Chiang led a KMT delegation to China last week and reached a 10-point consensus with Beijing officials on a wide range of issues including cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese businesspeople, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.

The Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court on Wednesday assigned prosecutor Chu Chia-chi to probe into the case after accepting a treason lawsuit filed by the public against Chiang last Friday.

A group of politicians in Tainan also lodged a lawsuit with the Tainan District Prosecutors' Office last Friday, accusing Chiang of violating the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of tha Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

According to the statute, civic organizations that reach an agreement with China on issues concerning government or political matters without the authorization of government can be fined up to NT$2 million (US$63,492) , and if the offense is considered very serious, a prison sentence of up to five years can be handed down.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREAN DELEGATION SEEKS TRADE EXCHANGES IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A South Korean trade delegation held a procurement-oriented workshop with Taiwanese businesses Wednesday at the Grand Hi-Lai Hotel in Kaohsiung, southern Tawan.

The delegation, headed by Shin Dong Yeol, deputy chairman of the non-profit Korea International Trade Association, is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council, a TAITRA official said Wednesday.

Representatives of Korean businesses talked with their Taiwanese counterparts on a one-to-one basis to unveil their plans to purchase Taiwanese products including semiconductor parts and components, consumer electronics, automobile parts, chemicals, optical products, and health care goods, the official noted.

TAITRA Kaohsiung branch director Wang Chi-ming told the Central News Agency that in an effort to reverse Taiwan's trade deficits with South Korea in recent years, the council has been working to encourage Taiwanese businesses to explore or expand in the South Korean market. The TAITRA invited South Korean traders to visit Kaohsiung in the hopes of boosting the number of businesses in southern Taiwan engaging in trade with South Korea, he added.
The South Korean delegation will also visit the Kaohsiung City Government and the Port of Kaohsiung during their visit in the largest city in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TO LAUNCH NEW DIPLOMATIC ASSAULT TO FURTHER ISOLATE TAIWAN: DPP

TEXT.P: China is set to launch a new wave of schemes on the diplomatic front aimed at stealing away all of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, a source from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus claimed Wednesday.

Beijing may launch the diplomatic assault in September aimed at rounding up all of Taiwan's 25 diplomatic allies and "forcing" them to sever formal relations with Taiwan, said Chen Ching-chun, a DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan.

After all the diplomatic allies forsake Taiwan and Taiwan's international maneuvering chain is smashed, Beijing will be able to force all the United Nations members to recognize the "one China" policy and that Taiwan is part of China, according to Chen.

He quoted President Chen Shui-bian as saying at a meeting the day before that Taiwan is facing unprecedentedly harsh challenges now, with Beijing increasingly tightening its grip on Taiwan in the international diplomatic arena.

Against this backdrop, he said, Taiwan's opposition parties should cooperate with the ruling DPP to help forge cross-strait rapprochement for the benefit of people on both sides of the strait, rather than paying visits to China one after another to win favor from the Beijing authorities.

Chen was referring to the recent visit to China by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang March 28-April 1, during which Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with the Beijing leadership.
Chiang's China visit could open a Pandora's box of more visits to Beijing by opposition leaders, including KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.

At Tuesday's meeting, President Chen and officials from the DPP and the DPP administration agreed that national interests and the people's welfare should always come before political parties' interests and personal gain.

A seven-point conclusion was reached at the meeting, including that all cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should be in line with the law. As a result, the DPP administration might even launch investigations into the legality of the recent visit to China by Chiang and the KMT group.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 6.44 points to close at 6,013.49.
The bourse opened at 6,025.29 and fluctuated between 6,006.81 and 6,046.16. A total of 2.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.49 billion (US$2.01 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up at 0.6 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down at 0.7 percent, textile shares at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent, plastic and chemical shares at 0.2 percent, machinery and electronics issues at 0.2 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 488 to 380, with 150 stocks remaining unchanged.

TAIEX Index futures for May moved down seven points to finish at 6,015, with 177 contracts traded, while June futures lost 13 points to finish at 6,000, with 20 contracts traded.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics and financial stocks, were mixed.
April TE futures moved down 1.1 points to close at 232.4, with 3,163 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 0.85 points to close at 232.55, with 31 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June, September and December.

April TF futures moved up 3.8 points to finish at 962.2, with 5,012 contracts traded. May TF futures gained 5.2 points to end at 963, with 75 contracts traded, while September TF futures moved up five points to close at 960.2, with 1 contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FARM TRADE SHOULD BE CONDUCTED UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK: COA

TEXT.P: Agricultural exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China should be conducted under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) as both sides of the Taiwan Strait are members of the world trade regulatory body, officials from the Council of Agriculture (COA) reiterated Wednesday.

The Cabinet-level COA is not opposed to private agricultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait if the trade or exchanges involve no public authority exercise of power, such as customs tariffs and quarantine, the COA officials said.

If Taiwan farm products heading to China have to pass through customs tariffs and quarantine, the trade should not be conducted without approval by government offices or prior negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait by government-authorized intermediary bodies such as the Straits Exchange Foundation, the officials noted.

President Chen Shui-bian met with officials from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan at his residence Tuesday to discuss Taiwan's situation in light of Beijing's enactment of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.

Chen reportedly said during the meeting that Taiwan is facing unprecedentedly harsh challenges now and that the country will descend into anarchy should the government fail to take action in the face of the current situation, including a recent visit to Beijing by opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang that he made without notifying the administration in advance.
A seven-point conclusion was reached at the meeting, including that all cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges should be in line with the law.
The conclusions stressed that national interests and the people's welfare should always come before political parties' interests and personal gain.
The conclusions also said that cross-strait exchanges should not be allowed to develop unrestrainedly and that such exchanges should be "effectively managed."

The conclusions also indicated that agricultural issues, including bilateral trade, should be regulated and conducted under a WTO framework and that if negotiations are required, they should also be conducted under the WTO framework, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINGERPRINT ID TO BE DECIDED BY LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Whether fingerprints should be carried on new identification cards is an issue to be decided by the Legislative Yuan, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Wednesday.

The Executive Yuan wishes to have the current law requiring fingerprints on the ID cards amended, but the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will require fingerprints to be submitted unless the existing household registration law is revised by the Legislative Yuan before July 1, Su said.
The MOI is scheduled to replace existing ID cards with a new forgery-proof version from July 1 this year, valid until June 30, 2006.

At a meeting held at the Legislative Yuan Home and Nation's Committee Wednesday, a majority of lawmakers who attended the meeting voiced opposition to the option of repealing the existing law requiring fingerprints.

As the current regulations require fingerprints, Su said, the MOI has been preparing the replacement work in line with this principle and has begun formulating rules governing the preservation and storage of the fingerprints.

Hsieh Hsiu-neng, deputy director-general of the National Police Administration, said that he supports the notion of the nation building a nationwide system for the preservation and storage of the fingerprints. Fingerprints on ID cards will be helpful to police in identifying bodies, the homeless and senile persons who become lost, Hsieh added.
To ensure the smooth procedure of the ID card replacements, Su said, the MOI has organized training courses for relevant staff members to be launched from March 31 through April 15.
The new cards will be pale purple and will have 21 forgery-proof features. Unlike the existing identification cards, which have vertical print, the writing on the new ones will be horizontal.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CHIEF OF STAFF DEPARTS FOR SIGHTSEEING TRIP TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff departed for Tokyo Wednesday for a sightseeing trip.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, was accompanied by his wife and former Vice Premier Lin Hsin-i.
Yu kept a low profile and declined to reveal the purpose of his visit prior to his departure.
According to Yu's aides, the visit is mainly a vacation and an opportunity for him to meet with his Japanese friends. He is expected to stay in Japan for a week.

Yu, a former premier, would not comment on pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang's visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in central Tokyo Monday. The Shinto shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million war dead, including several convicted war criminals. Su's visit has drawn criticism in local society, with some people blaming him for dignifying Japan's militarism in the early 20th Century by visiting the shrine.
Yu also refrained from revealing whether Chen will travel to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral in person.
For fear of offending China, Japan has traditionally been reluctant to issue visas to senior Taiwan government officials.
With a view to attracting more foreign visitors to the Aichi Expo, Japan passed regulations in February to waive the visa requirement s for Taiwan tourists between March 11 and Sept. 25.
During the period, Taiwan passport holders can enter Japan without visas for sightseeing purposes for a maximum 90-day stay.
Japanese government officials said they will also consider whether to offer Taiwan citizens permanent visa-free privileges after the Aichi Expo.
Taiwan is Japan's second-largest source of foreign tourists after South Korea.
However, Taiwan's top five officials are still required to apply for a visa if they decide to visit Japan during the world exposition in the central Japanese prefecture of Aichi.

According to a previous report by Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Japan's visa waiver is inapplicable to top five Taiwan officials -- President Chen Shui-bian, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Frank Hsieh, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i and Tan Sun Chen himself.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REVIEW CHINA'S PROGRESS IN MARKET OPENING NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan has interacted with China according to World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations and will review China's progress in honoring its market-opening promises next year, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials said Wednesday.

The officials were responding to a seven-point conclusion on cross-Taiwan Strait relations reached during a high-level meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and representatives of the Cabinet and ruling Democratic Progressive Party a day earlier.
On cross-strait economy and trade, it was concluded that the government must not ignore the crucial "effective management" while adopting an opening policy toward China.

Under these circumstances, national security and administrative agencies will review and adjust cross-strait trade policy, and the government should also conduct consultations with China under the WTO framework on issues related to the cross-strait agriculture and service sectors, according to the conclusion.
The BOFT officials said Taiwan has been involved in multilateral talks with China under the WTO framework and share similar views with China on certain WTO issues.
They said Taiwan welcomes the opening of the Chinese market to Taiwanese agricultural products according to WTO standards.
While China promised to open its service sector during its admission into the WTO, the WTO will conduct a trade policy review of China next April, they noted.
Taiwan will also participate in the review to examine China's progress in opening its market, they added.

Meanwhile, members of Taiwan's financial sector said they will respect the government's decision to adjust its cross-strait policies but expressed the hope that the government will continue a policy of openness in terms of cross-strait economy and trade.
They pointed out the government has allowed the securities and financial service sectors to set up operations in China under the WTO framework.
However, cross-strait financial activities are not as active as expected, mainly because China remains conservative in terms of its financial policy, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROVERSIAL TSU HEAD SAYS HE `FEARS NOTHING'

TEXT.P: The head of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), Su Chin-chiang, whose pilgrimage to Japan's war dead memorial drew strong protests and vehement criticism at home Tuesday and Wednesday, said he has been a soldier and that he "fears nothing."

Opposition Kuomintang and People First Party legislators, as well as aboriginal lawmakers, have loudly criticized Su's visit to the Yakusuni shrine in Tokyo as "deranged" and even ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Cho-shui described the visit as "inappropriate."

At a press conference welcoming 100 new recruits to his party Wednesday, Shu said the TSU has been growing on the strength of the people and Taiwan's identity, and it is proud to be what he claimed is "a mouthpiece for the grassroots people."
Facing a group of protesters and an even larger group of new TSU members, he said: "I have been a soldier. How could I be daunted by protests?"

According to Su, his visit to Tokyo was aimed at strengthening Taiwan's security cooperation with Japan, in sharp contrast to a KMT delegation's visit to Beijing, which Su claimed helped legitimize China's anti-secession law.

His visit to the Yakusuni Shrine, which is dedicated to Japan's 2.5 million war dead and lists the names of 28,000 Taiwanese and 21,000 Korean soldiers, as well the names of many convicted war criminals, has continued to stir up debate across Taiwan.
Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng, speaking as a historian at the Legislative Yuan, said paying respects to the memory of the Taiwanese war dead is, "I feel, something that should be done."

The Taiwanese might not have been recruited to the Pacific War zone and listed in the Yasukuni shrine of their own accord, but still, Tu added, like those killed in the China war zone, they are Taiwan compatriots.

Chen Chin-jun, DPP legislative caucus secretary-general, recommended that the government welcome "bring home" the spirits of the 28,000 Taiwanese war dead so they can rest in peace and the bereaved families can be solaced.

At a press conference, Lee Sheng-feng, secretary-general of the tiny opposition New Party, and three other Taipei-area lawmakers, condemned Su for "honoring the militarist war criminals, " accusing the TSU of inciting a conflict between Chinese nationalism and Taiwanese nationalism with the ulterior motive of dividing Taiwan to save the Taiwan independence movement.
Meanwhile, police have targeted a number of the protesters at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport who pelted Su with eggs upon his return to Taiwan Tuesday.
Police said those who resorted to violence against Su will be prosecuted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, April 6 CNA) The Moscow Times: Kudrin Pessimistic in Fight Against Inflation.
Russia is losing the fight against inflation, Finance Minister Alexei Kudrin said Tuesday, as new figures showed that monthly retail price growth accelerated in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.014 to close at NT$31.571.
A total of US$941 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.685 and slid to a low of NT$31.460 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS REVIEW OF CROSS-STRAIT POLICIES

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh ordered the relevant authorities Wednesday to review and adjust policies concerning "unmanageable" cross-Taiwan Strait activities.

Hsieh told a weekly Cabinet meeting that the review will cover cross-strait charter flights, agricultural products, tourism, the service sector, the information sector, journalistic exchanges and cooperation on crime-fighting, according to Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai.

Hsieh said the government's policy of "positive opening, effective management" toward China remains unchanged and that the government must not ignore "effective management" while continuing to open to China.

A seven-point conclusion on cross-strait relations reached during a high-level meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and representatives of the Cabinet and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) a day earlier will be the government's top guidelines in dealing with cross-strait affairs, Hsieh said.

The premier said the government will react carefully to the various pressures imposed by China on the international community to isolate Taiwan and its tactics to deny Taiwan's sovereignty, divide Taiwan and distort international perception of the cross-strait situation.

He urged political parties and individuals in Taiwan to build up a consciousness of common destiny, prioritize national interests over personal and partisan interests, and stop competing with each other to win China's favor.
He said cross-strait exchanges must abide by existing laws and that the government will act against violators if any irregularities are discovered.
Cho pointed out that the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area defines China as a regime that is hostile to Taiwan.
The government will enforce the law strictly and adopt an effective management mechanism for cross-strait activities, Cho said.
The government's decision to review its cross-strait policies came one month after Beijing enacted its Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan.

A visit to China by a delegation led by opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang last week has also enraged the DPP government, which has accused the KMT of becoming a tool of Beijing's united front tactics against Taiwan.
Judicial authorities are investigating whether Chiang has violated any laws in reaching a 10-point consensus with the Beijing authorities during the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS ROC OFFICIALS NOT TO VISIT YASUKUNI SHRINE IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has demanded that all administration officials refrain from making pilgrimages to a controversial Japanese shrine dedicated to 2.5 million war dead, including several convicted war criminals, an official said Wednesday.
Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai quoted Hsieh as having given the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
Hsieh's directive came after pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Su Chin-chiang's visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in central Tokyo Monday sparked controversy in local society.
The premier was quoted as having said that TSU heavyweights' pilgrimage to the Yasukuni Shrine was a controversial act which none of the administration officials were allowed to follow.
Moreover, Hsieh said, all government officials should also refrain from giving a thumbs-up or encouraging such a controversial act.
Hsieh, a lawyer-turned-politician, further said Su's pilgrimage to the Japanese Shinto shrine was not a legal issue, but rather a political one.
"The crux of the issue was not whether the visit was legal or illegal. It is a political issue that requires individual political parties to make a correct judgment," Hsieh said.

At a time when the government is wholeheartedly pursuing peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, Hsieh said all administration officials should keep in mind the sins of war and all the sufferings it could bring to the people.
"We should staunchly oppose war and all sorts of non-peaceful actions," Hsieh said.

Su is one of only a few senior Asian political figures ever to visit the Yasukuni Shrine. In addition to honoring Japanese war dead and civilians who died in fighting, the shrine also lists the names of 28,000-plus Taiwanese and 21,000 Korean soldiers, most of whom were forced into military service under Japan's colonial rule.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) legislators, as well as aboriginal lawmakers, have criticized Su's visit to the shrine as "deranged" and even ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Cho-shui described the visit as "inappropriate."

Su said Wednesday that his just-concluded visit to Japan was aimed at strengthening Taiwan's security cooperation with Japan, in sharp contrast to a KMT delegation's visit to Beijing, which Su claimed helped legitimize China's Anti-Secession Law. He further claimed that the Yasukuni pilgrimage was to pay tribute to the spirits of Taiwanese soldiers.

Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, speaking as a historian at the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day, said paying respects to the memory of the Taiwanese war dead is, "I feel, something that should be done."

The Taiwanese might not have been recruited to the Pacific War zone and listed in the Yasukuni shrine of their own accord, but still, Tu added, like those killed in the China war zone, they are Taiwan compatriots.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO ATTEND POPE'S FUNERAL AT VATICAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will depart for the Vatican Thursday to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral mass scheduled for Friday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.
MOFA officials said the ministry received the Italian government-issued visa for President Chen at 5 p.m. Wednesday.

According to the officials, Chen and his entourage will travel to Italy via a chartered China Airlines flight. Chen will depart Taipei at 3: 40 p.m. Thursday and arrive in Rome at 5 a.m. April 8. After attending the funeral, Chen will depart for home in the evening the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING IS PLAYING TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN AGAINST TAIWAN: LAWMAKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 5 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of visiting Taiwan lawmakers said here Tuesday that they have urged their U.S. contacts to concern themselves with Chinese infringements on the human rights of Taiwan businessmen operating in China, because they are played against their goverment by China.

The lawmakers, members of the ROC-USA Inter-Parliamentary Amity Association, told Taiwan journalists posted in Washington, D.C., that Beijing is forcing Taiwan businessmen working in China to support its Anti-Secession Law, which is at the center of a bitter dispute between Taiwan and China because it allows China to attack Taiwan as it deems necessary.

Legislator Charles C. Chiang, who is the head of the visiting group, said that Hsu Wen-lung, the founder of Taiwan's Chi Mei Corp., was forced to assert that he supports Beijing's "one China" policy the day before a million people gathered in Taipei March 26 to protest the Anti-Secession Law.

As a firm supporter of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, Hsu was "obviously" compelled by Beijing to speak against his mind because of his group's huge investments in China, Chiang said.

Legislator Chuang He-tsi, also a member of the visiting group, claimed that one of Chi Mei's senior executives was jailed in China and that Hsu had to voice support for Beijing in its dispute with Taipei in the hope that Beijing would treat the executive leniently.
Legislator Lin Chung-mo said that Hsu is only the most prominent victim of Beijing's policy of "bringing Taiwanese businessmen to bear on the Taiwan authorities."
"There are at least 1,000 Taiwan businessmen who have been forced to speak in favor of China in the dispute surrounding the Anti-Secession Law," Lin claimed.
The Chinese authorities scrutinize and find fault with Taiwan businessmen's accounting books to force them to say what they want them to say, according to Lin.
The group arrived in the United States April 2 and will continue its tour of America until April 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TEA DAY' ORGANIZED TO PROMOTE TEA CULTURE

TEXT.P: A government official said Wednesday that a "Tea Day" organized to begin the following day will promote the island's tea culture.

The newly introduced "Tea Day" is part of a campaign organized jointly by the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan and the Taiwan Tea Association to encourage the public to enjoy the healthy, natural drink, which some claim to be Taiwan's national treasure.
The day of the activity was also chosen to echo "World Health Day," which shares the same date, as studies claim that drinking tea can help reduce blood pressure and prolong life.

Aside from the health benefits of drinking tea, a COA official said that tea drinking has evolved into an art and that serving tea has become a subtle way for Taiwanese people to show others care and affection.
Taiwan Tea Association Chairman Wang Rei-kai described tea as an indispensable part of Chinese culture and a national treasure.
According to COA statistics, each year Taiwan produces 20,000 tons of tea on 20,000 hectares of land. Taiwan is known for exporting a large proportion of its tea output, most notably oolong tea.
Even though Taiwan's tea production was affected by the harsh weather conditions this winter, tea prices nevertheless are not expected to rise sharply, according to the council.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: The hidden election.
Labour and the Tories are spending millions of pounds on a hidden high-tech campaign to win over the 800,000 key voters in marginal seats who will settle the general election. The party leaders took to the air on whistle-stop tours yesterday as the date of the election was finally revealed as May 5. Both parties believe that it will be won or lost by a ground-level battle fought away from the television cameras, in which they have been making efforts to identify and contact a relatively small proportion of the electorate.
Financial Times: Blair begins his battle for votes.
Tony Blair on Tuesday launched what is set to be the most keenly contested British general election since 1992, urging Labour to fight for"every vote in every seat"against a resurgent Conservative party. After formally asking the Queen to dissolve parliament and call an election for May 5, the prime minister sought to galvanise his party's many disgruntled supporters by insisting the country faced a"fundamental choice"between competing Labour and Conservative visions on the economy and public services.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Breaking Deadlock, Iraqis Pick President and 2 Other Officials.
Iraq's national assembly Wednesday appointed one one of Saddam Hussein's most tenacious opponents to the office of president, taking asignificant step in forming a new government and breaking a political deadlock nearly 10 weeks after general elections. The assembly voted in Jalal Talabani, a Kurdish leader, as president; Adel Abdul Mahdi, a prominent Shiite Arab politician, as vice president, and Sheik Ghazi al-Yawar, the Sunni Arab president of the interim government, as the other vice president. The three men are expected to take their oaths of office on Thursday and may name a prime minister on the same day, assembly members said.
Wall Street Journal: After 8 Years, Legislation Finally Nears Passage of New New Bankruptcy Law.
After eight years of trying, U.S. Congress next week is expected to pass legislation aimed at a growing problem: Encouraged by mass mailings from the credit-card industry, more and more consumers are taking on more debt than they can handle and ending up in bankruptcy court. The new bankruptcy law, crafted with industry help and backed by President Bush, takes the firm view that this is the borrower's problem, not the industry's. Credit-card companies, banks and t heir allies say the legislation, the biggest change to U.S. bankruptcy law since 1978, is an over due correction to a system that is biased in favor of borrowers and too often protects deadbeats. Opponents condemn the bill will inflict pain on consumers overwhelmed by debt that they can't pay because of health problems or layoffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNG CHEE HWA DID MORE HARM THAN GOOD: HK POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 6 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa was given less than sterling marks for his performance over the last eight years as head of the Special Administrative Region (SAR) by residents in a poll released Wednesday.

Over 1,000 Hong Kong citizens were surveyed by the University of Hong Kong in mid-March on Tung's administrative performance. Forty percent of the respondents said that Tung had done more harm than good in promoting the region's general development. Just 19 percent gave him a higher score, while 30 percent said that Tung's influence had been equally positive and negative on the SAR.
Thirty-one percent believed Tung made a positive contribution to Hong Kong's economy, while 27 percent gave him credit in political affairs, and 18 percent gave him no credit at all.

However, 51 percent blamed Tung for leading Hong Kong into recession, while 25 percent said he had made political mistakes, and 4 percent said the former chief executive performed perfectly during his administration, which began in July 1997 and ended in March 2005.

Tung received 4.6 points out of 10 for his administrative achievements, but 5.4 points for being incapable. The scores reflect that Hong Kong people believe Tung did more harm than good to Hong Kong's development, according to the survey.

Tung's eight years in power were marred by recessions, a deadly SARS epidemic, and accusations he was a puppet of Beijing. His unpopular leadership sparked huge pro-democracy protests in 2003 and 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO STAY AT EXCELSIOR HOTEL DURING VATICAN VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 6 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian will stay at the Excelsior Hotel in downtown Rome during his brief stay at the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral mass scheduled for Friday, diplomatic sources said Wednesday.
The hotel has a long history and boasts convenient transport, the sources said, adding that the hotel is downtown and situated next to the U.S. Embassy.
ROC Vice President Annette Lu and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen also stayed at the hotel during their previous visits to the Vatican -- the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
In Taipei, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced Wednesday that the Italian government has already issued a visa for President Chen to attend the Pope's funeral mass.

According to the officials, Chen and his entourage will travel to Italy via a chartered China Airlines flight. Chen will depart Taipei at 3: 40 p.m. Thursday and arrive in Rome at 5 a.m. April 8. After attending the funeral, Chen will depart for home in the evening the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: SISTER CITY BATON ROUGE MAYOR VISITS TAICHUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: A delegation from Taichung's sister city, Baton Rouge, Louisiana, met Mayor Jason Hu Wednesday as part of a five-day visit in Taiwan to try to drum up investments.
The group, led by Mayor Melvin Holden, expressed the hope during the meeting that the trade and economic cooperation between the two cities will be further strengthened.

The Baton Rouge delegation arrived in Taiwan April 3 and has visited various locations of interest, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Taipei City Government and the Hsinchu Science Park. It is scheduled to depart Taiwan Friday.
Baton Rouge has a population of about 230,000 people and is the capital and second-largest city in Louisiana. Taichung is home to just over a million residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T WANTS COORDINATION FROM ALL PARTIES ON CHINA POLICY : MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The government would like to bring together all political parties to discuss the best way to approach dealings with China, specifically regarding individuals or groups wishing to travel to China on their own without the government's blessing, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Wednesday.

Fielding questions raised by lawmakers at an interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said that President Chen Shui-bian had already proposed in a high-profile meeting with officials from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party a day earlier to hold a meeting of leaders across the political spectrum to discuss the matter.
The proposal, which was listed in a seven-point summary of the meeting, is the best way to reach a national consensus, Wu stressed.

Criticizing a recent visit to China by opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, during which he reached a 10-point consensus with Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, covering a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, protection of China-based Taiwan businessmen, the rights of Chinese fishermen working on Taiwan fishing vessels, and the further easing of China's financial market, Wu said that it hurts Taiwan's interests, particularly at this moment when the government is assessing the impact of China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan.

The 10-point consensus seriously damaged Taiwan's interests because it deprives the government of its authority and its bargaining power in negotiations with Beijing, Wu said. Worse still, he added, it deprives Taiwan of its sovereignty.
The government is not opposed to political parties and individuals visiting China to promote cross-strait exchanges and mutual understanding between the two sides of the Strait, Wu went on.
He said, however, that any matter involving national interests and the public mandate should be authorized by and have the permission from the government.
A national consensus in dealing with cross-strait issues will serve as a guideline for visits to China by political parties and individuals from Taiwan, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS ACROSS POLITICAL SPECTRUM HAIL CHEN'S VATICAN VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's upcoming visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral mass has been met with broad approval from across party boundaries.
Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Su Chi on Wednesday hailed the trip, saying it will be one of Chen's most important overseas trips as president.

Su made the remarks after the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced earlier in the day that the Italian government has already issued a visa for President Chen to attend the Pope's funeral mass.
Noting that 16 of the Republic of China's 25 diplomatic allies are Catholic countries, Su said maintaining good relations with the Vatican should be given priority.

The Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe. Su said if ROC-Vatican ties change drastically, a domino effect could ensue. Should that be the case, he cautioned, Taiwan's diplomatic prospects could be grim.
Su, a convener of the Legislative Yuan's foreign affairs committee, said he is pleased to see President Chen obtain an Italian visa to visit the Vatican.

Nevertheless, Su said local people should refrain from billing it as a major diplomatic breakthrough to avoid provoking China or bringing unnecessary troubles to the Italian government, which maintains diplomatic ties with China.

According to MOFA officials, Chen and his entourage will travel to Italy via a chartered China Airlines flight. Chen will depart Taipei at 3: 40 p.m. Thursday and arrive in Rome at 5 a.m. April 8. After attending the funeral, Chen will depart for home in the evening the same day.
Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said President Chen will represent the 23 million Taiwan people to pay homage to the late Pope.
Hsiao, who concurrently heads the DPP's international affairs department, said President Chen is not expected to touch on any political issues during his brief Vatican visit.

Nevertheless, Hsiao said that the trip will offer Chen a rare opportunity to interact with top leaders from major countries around the world. Therefore, she said, the visit is of great significance both from a political and religious perspective.

Because of China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, top ROC leaders have few opportunities to attend major international events. This will be Chen's first trip to Europe since assuming the presidency in May 2000.

Cheng Wen-tsan, director of the DPP's information and publicity department, said the Vatican symbolizes the values of peace and human rights. In his view, Cheng said Chen's Vatican visit will underscore Taiwan's resolve to deal with relations with China with these universal values as cardinal principles.

DPP legislative caucus whip William C.T. Lai said that the late Pope John Paul II had been a courageous guardian of peace and democracy upheld by Taiwan. As the Vatican has been Taiwan's longtime diplomatic ally, Lai said the DPP caucus fully supports Chen's attendance at the Pontiff's funeral.

Meanwhile, the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union and pro-unification opposition People First Party also threw their support behind Chen's visit to the Vatican, saying they believe the visit will help cement the ROC's diplomatic ties with the Holy See.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP UNDETERRED BY GOVERNMENT DECISION TO DAMPEN 'CHINA FEVER'

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) vowed Wednesday to proceed with their respective plans to arrange for their party leaders to visit China in spite of a government warning such visits might damage Taiwan's dignity and interests.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan's plan to make a "tour of peace" to China won't be shaken by the government's seven-point decision to dampen a rush by opposition figures to go to China, a phenomenon dubbed "China fever," so Lien will begin his visit as scheduled, which is "as soon as possible," KMT spokeswoman Cheng Li-wen said.

PFP Policy Center Director and Legislator Chang Hsien-yao said his party's plans are still on track to send an agricultural mission to China and to arrange for party leader James Soong to visit later.

President Chen Shui-bian called a meeting of top government and ruling party officials Tuesday night, in which they reached a seven-point decision to put the brakes on a series of opposition moves to visit China "to stop 'China fever' from harming Taiwan's dignity and interests."
Cheng said the government should do its part to seek peace across the Taiwan Strait instead of hobbling the opposition's efforts to establish rapprochement.

Chang said his party will proceed with preliminary contacts with Chinese authorities regarding Soong's proposed visit to China. Meanwhile, PFP Legislator Tsay Sheng-jia will lead an agricultural mission to visit China in the near future, Chang added.
The PFP has tried hard to lower the profile of the mission in hopes that talks over "pure" agricultural exchanges between Taiwan and China will bring some good results, Chang noted.

As part of the government's strategy to cool down the current infatuation with opposition party officials traveling to China, the authorities are re-emphasizing the "active opening, effective management" dictum of cross-strait economic and trade exchanges.
As to exchanges in services and farming, the government reiterated the need to negotiate under the framework of the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 7 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, April 7:
09: 00, The Legislative Yuan's committees will start their sessions for the day.
09: 00, The 10th Asia Telecom & Information Exchange forum will open at the Taipei International Convention Center.
10:30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a rally in memory of the 16th anniversary of Cheng Nan-jung's death in Jinsan, Taipei County.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
12: 30, The National Science Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
13: 50, The Taiwan delegation to the 2005 Bologna International Children's Book Fair will hold a news conference at the Government Information Office.
14: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a seminar on the economic justice and the human rights at the National Central Library.
14: 00, The National Policy Foundation will hold a seminar on policies on direct cross-strait charter flight services and amendments to relevant laws at the foundation's headquarters.
15: 40, President Chen Shui-bian will leave for the Vatican via the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
16: 00, A consultation meeting of ruling and opposition parties' legislative caucuses will be held at the Legislative Yuan.
16: 00, The Ministry of Finance will issue reports on customs statistics of exports and imports at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 20, The Financial Examination Department of Taiwan's Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIO-MEDICAL PLAN EXPECTED TO BOOST ECONOMY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A government program emphasizing the country's bio-medical technology development is expected to boost the nation's investments and significantly cut medical expenses, an official announced Wednesday.

The program, to be executed jointly by a number of agencies including the Executive Yuan, the Academia Sinica and the Ministry of Economic Affairs, will eventually cut national health insurance expenses by NT$10 billion (US$316.7 million) and increase investments by NT$40 billion (US$1.27 billion) in the next five years, according to minister without portfolio Lin Feng-ching.
Lin said the plan will concentrate on establishing and improving three major areas: the National Health Information Infrastructure, Taiwan Biobank, and clinical research systems.

He added that Taiwan's high quality clinical research, strong electronics industry, and the national health insurance program give the nation unique advantages in executing the plan over other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET ASKS KMT CHAIRMAN NOT TO MOCK TAIWAN PEOPLE AND THE LAW

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should refrain from mocking the people of Taiwan and the country's laws, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Wednesday.

Cho made the remarks after Lien said the Democratic Progressive Party administration's decision to deal with KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang's recent visit to China in accordance with existing regulations "could make the administration the laughing-stock of the international community."
Cho said all citizens must abide by the law. "It's not nonsense to demand that political figures also abide by the law," Cho added.
As to which laws Chiang might have broken, Cho said the Cabinet is not a judicial agency.

Quoting judicial experts' opinions, Cho said Chiang might have violated Article 113 of the Criminal Code and Section I of Article 5 and Section 1 of Article 33 of the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
According to Article 113 of the Criminal Code, private individuals or groups, without the government's authorization, are banned from forging agreements with foreign governments.

Chiang led a KMT delegation to China last week and reached a 10-point consensus with Beijing officials on a broad range of issues including cross-Taiwan Strait charter flights, agricultural cooperation, protection for China-based Taiwanese business people, tourism, journalistic exchanges and the opening of the Chinese financial market.
Cho said that as some local people have filed lawsuits against Chiang, prosecution authorities will look into the case in line with present regulations.
The Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court on Wednesday assigned prosecutor Chu Chia-chi to the case after accepting a treason lawsuit filed by the public against Chiang last Friday.
A group of politicians in Tainan have also lodged a lawsuit with the Tainan District Prosecutors' Office, accusing Chiang of violating the cross-strait statute.

According to the statute, civic organizations that reach an agreement with China on issues concerning policy issues or political matters without the authorization of the government can be fined up to NT$2 million (US$63,492) , and if the offense is considered very serious, a prison sentence of up to five years can be handed down.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL INCREASE OF CPI UP BY 2.31 PERCENT IN MARCH: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) rose by 2.31 percent in March, while the wholesale price index (WPI) moved up by 1.99 percent, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS officials ascribed the increase in the CPI and WPI mainly to the hike of oil and vegetable prices due to relatively lower temperatures this year.
March's CPI increase of 2.31 percent marks the highest growth rate recorded since last November, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-VATICAN TIES NOT TO CHANGE UNDER NEW POPE: CARDINAL BISHOP
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican, April 6 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and the Vatican will not change after a new Pope in elected, Cardinal Paul S. J. Suan who is based in Taiwan said Wednesday.

Suan, who came to the Vatican in late March for a visit, was responding to an inquiry about whether the Vatican is likely to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China after Pope John Paul II's death and the election of his successor.

Pope John Paul II died Sunday (Taipei time) at the age of 84. According to Catholic regulations, the 183 cardinal bishops around the world will begin the election process for a new pope within 20 days of the death.

Suan, who is the only cardinal bishop in either side of the Taiwan Strait, said unless mainland Chinese people can enjoy full religious freedom, the Vatican is unlikely to forge formal ties with China. At the moment, the 83-year-old cardinal bishop said he sees little possibility of that scenario becoming a reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE REFUSES TO ACT ON ARMS PURCHASE, NOMINEES FOR CONTROL YUAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's request for the Legislative Yuan to affirm his nominees for the Control Yuan and his administration's request for a special budget to buy a package of arms from the United States failed to make it onto the agenda of the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.

Lawmakers from the two main opposition parties in the legislature, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , worked together in the Committee on Rules to vote against putting the two bills on the agenda for this session.

The president's request, contained in a letter, was delivered to the Legislative Yuan on Monday. The 29 nominees were the same ones he had named in December, 2004 and submitted to the previous Legislative Yuan.

The proceeding legislature, also controlled by the opposition, refused to exercise their right to affirm the nominees, claiming that they failed to live up to public expectations for members of the Control Yuan.
Instead, they asked the president to withdraw his list and to come up with a new one. Chen refused and the political stalemate continued until the end of January when the legislature's term expired.

When the new legislature opened in February, the opposition lawmakers still refused to act on the president's request on the grounds it was presented to the proceeding legislature, and was, therefore, no longer valid. It was for this reason that the president re-submitted his request, but refused to replace any of his nominees to the displeasure of the opposition parties in the legislature.

The special budget for the arms purchase has been at the center of another dispute between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the two opposition parties because the KMT and the PFP will not agree to the government's decision to include them in a special budget, which is exempt from the legal cap on government loans.
The government is anxious to get the legislature's green light and wrap up the deal before the U.S. considers withdrawing its offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS GROUPS WORRY ABOUT CHILLING EFFECTS ON EXCHANGES WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: Several business groups aired their concerns Wednesday about the chilling effects on economic exchanges with China caused by a consensus formed between the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and government leaders on ties with China the previous day.

Wang Tiao-chun, secretary-general of the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development, said this consensus is basically putting the brakes on exchanges across the Taiwan Strait and is therefore not conducive to trade with China.

Although the consensus was meant to check the political fever of opposition parties wanting to visit the mainland, Wang said it will dampen local business groups' enthusiasm to promote trade ties with China.

Lo Huai-chia, deputy secretary-general of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association, said when it comes to trade with China, what matters is the normal channels of exchanges, not the pace of development.
"A smooth communication channel can spare businessmen a lot of troubles," Lo said, without elaborating.
"The increasing exchanges between Taiwan and China are facts neither the Taipei authorities nor the Beijing authorities can overlook," he said.
The consensus was worked out by the government and the DPP in an emergency meeting since the leaders of the two major opposition parties have been invited by Beijing to visit the mainland.
In the consensus, the government warned the opposition to follow the law in their associations with those in China or face possible legal repercussions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE SATISFIED WITH PUBLIC FUNCTIONARIES' SERVICES

TEXT.P: Nearly three-fourths of Taiwan people are satisfied with public functionaries' services, according to results of a survey released by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC).

The survey, conducted by the RDEC between March 29 and 30, shows that 74.4 percent of the respondents expressed their satisfaction with the overall service of public functionaries, while 75.4 percent were satisfied with the polite attitude demonstrated by public functionaries in telephone conversations.
The survey, with 1,108 samples available, had a margin of error of 2.9 percent, RDEC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 7, or the 29th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by U.S. aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other locations around Taiwan to begin handling traffic violation cases.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Guofeng as premier and to depose Deng Xiaoping as deputy premier after riots in Beijing.
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: U.S. President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting Communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure against Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a U.S.-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.
1999: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho urges the government to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.
2000: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party announce their decision to drop out of the party because they say that the party has completed its mission.
2001: Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, receives a set of CNA file photos, including one showing he in the arms of his mother along with his father and his elder brother.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."

The Iraqi Parliament picked Kurdish leader Jalal Talabani as the country's new interim president Wednesday, reaching out to the nation's long-repressed Kurdish minority and bringing the country closer to its first democratically elected government in 50 years. (by Mike Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADING INTERNATIONAL WIRE SERVICES REPORT CHEN'S VISIT TO VATICAN

TEXT.P: Three leading international wire services on Wednesday separately reported that President Chen Shui-bian will join other world leaders to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral scheduled to be held in the Vatican Friday.
Associated Press said in a dispatch from Taipei that Chen's upcoming visit to the Vatican will be "an unprecedented visit."
The first ever visit to Europe by a Taiwan head of state is likely to irk rival China, the report said.

"By attending the funeral, Chen will have the rare chance of meeting heads of state and helping raise the international profile of the self-ruled island, " the report said. Beijing is expected to lodge a strong protest against Chen's visit with Italy, it added.

Meanwhile, the Reuters said Chen's visit is "a diplomatic breakthrough" for Taiwan. It also quoted Republic of China foreign ministry spokesman Michel Lu as saying that "Italy agreed to issue a visa to Chen to attend the funeral despite pressure from China."
Agence France-Presse also reported Chen's upcoming visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, saying that the move is sure to anger China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
: The Straits Times : China-Japan ties become more tense.
Simmering tension between China and Japan racheted up a notch yesterday, with the latest row over Japan's new history textbooks sparking a robust response from Tokyo.
The Chinese Foreign Ministry summoned the Japanese ambassador in Beijing to protest against the textbooks, which it says white-wash Tokyo's military past.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The Singapore's National Day Parade this year to hold in five places.
In 9 August, The Singapore's 40th National Day Parade and celebrations will take place simultaneously at five places across the island -- Pandang, Tampines, Yishun, Marina South and Jurong East.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ID CARD LAUNCH PREPARATIONS TO BE BASED ON FINGERPRINT REQUIREMENT

TEXT.P: Preparations for the launch of the new version of the national identification card July 1 will be based on the existing law which requires that citizens be fingerprinted when claiming a new ID card, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan said Thursday.

Su made the remarks while attending a training program held to familiarize related staff with the ID card replacement operations. The remarks came one day after the Executive Yuan passed a revised draft bill to remove the fingerprint requirement in the existing household registration law.

Although the Cabinet has passed the bill, preparations for launching the new ID card will be made based on the fingerprint requirement in case the bill fails to gain Legislative Yuan approval in its current session which ends at the end of May, Su said.
It has been learned that if the bill is not approved, the Interior Ministry will have to purchase around 900 fingerprint scanners at a total cost of NT$500 million (US$15.87 million).

Noting that ID cards should be renewed every 10 years according to the existing regulations, Su said that the launch of a new version of the national ID card has been delayed for 19 years because of the controversy over the fingerprints issue. He said that if issuance of anew card is again delayed this year, this will represent a serious blow to the government's credibility and a violation of the law.
The new cards will be pale purple and have 21 forgery-proof features. Unlike the existing identification cards, which have vertical print, the writing on the new ones will be horizontal.

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Gref Says Economy Needs Siemensr Economic Development and Trade Minister German Gref gave his thumbs up for Siemens' acquisition of a majority stake in Vladimir Potanin's Siloviye Mashiny as he offered assurances to jittery foreign business leaders at a conference Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Cardinals Set Conclave for April 18; John Paul's Will, Called 'Spiritual Testament,' Due to Be Released Today.
Hundreds of thousands more pilgrims descended upon St. Peter's Square on Wednesday for a last chance to view the body of Pope John Paul II, as the College of Cardinals announced that the conclave to select the new leader of the world's 1.1 billion Roman Catholics would hold its first session on April 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THREATENS TO SUE PRESIDENT, PREMIER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers threatened Thursday to sue President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Frank Hsieh over what they called the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's use of the judicial system to serve its own political needs.

The lawmakers made the remarks one day after the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court started an investigation into KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang over his establishing a so-called 10-point consensus with Beijing authorities during his visit to China last week.
According to the Criminal Code, a person can be charged with treason for forging an agreement with a foreign government without the government's authorization.

During a seminar with Ministry of Justice and National Security Bureau officials, KMT legislative caucus whip Chen Chieh said the DPP government must make it clear as to whether China is considered a foreign government, and if it isn't considered a foreign country, then investigating Chiang would be unjustifiable.
Chen said the caucus will not rule out the possibility of suing the president and premier after gathering relevant evidence.
Also, Chen announced that the KMT caucus has from Thursday suspended consultations with the ruling party until the Cabinet makes a positive response regarding Chiang's case.

KMT Legislator Huang Teh-fu pointed out that treason is a crime subject to public prosecution, and he urged prosecutors to initiate a similar investigation into President Chen, who had previously shown a note he claimed was passed on to him from former Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Legislators Su Chi and Lai Shyh-bao, also from the KMT, accused the DPP government of resorting to legal means to achieve political objectives.

Su suggested that the KMT caucus boycott the Cabinet-proposed NT$480 billion (US$15.19 billion) arms procurement package in protest and demand that Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin step down immediately.

Responding to the KMT's criticism, Vice Justice Minister Tang Chin-chuan said that the investigation into Chiang is based on a complaint lodged by the public and that his ministry respects the powers of the prosecutors.

State Public Prosecutor General Wu Ying-chao told the legislature's Judiciary Committee that it will be up to prosecutors to determine whether Chiang's act constitutes a crime after the investigation is completed.
Wu said it is not appropriate for him to comment on the case at this point.
Meanwhile, DPP lawmakers expressed regret over the KMT caucus' decision to suspend consultations with the ruling party.
Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, urged the KMT to stop "acting like children" and hampering the legislative process of a number of important legal and budget bills.

Noting that the KMT has suspended consultations with the ruling party on three occasions in less than two months, Lai said he hopes Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will try to mediate in the dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTIONS ON DISPLAY AT INTERNATIONAL EXHIBITION IN GENEVA
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 6 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Twenty-three inventions from Taiwan are currently on display at the 33rd International Exhibition of Inventions of Gevena 2005 being held at the Palexpo in the Swiss city April 6-10.
About one thousand inventions by more than 700 inventors from 42 countries are on display at the exhibition, considered to be one of the most important of its kind in the world.

According to Chen Chung-Tai, president of the Taiwan Inventors Association, who is heading a Taiwan delegation to participate in the exhibition, inventions by Taiwan nationals are expected to gain fruitful results at this year's exhibition. Taiwan inventions have won various top medals at the event over the past several years.

According to the organizer of the exhibition, 61 percent of the inventions on display this year come from commercial firms or state research institutes, while 31 percent of the inventions come from independent researchers and inventors.
Since many of the visitors to the exhibition are professionals who want to do business, buy licenses or find new products, the event provides participating inventors with huge business opportunities.
According to the organizer, the business volume generated during or after last year's exhibition totalled over US$30 million.
The organizer will announce the award list for this year's best inventions Saturday.

Taiwan External Trade Development Council, which will hold Taipei's first international invention and technology exchange exhibition in Taipei in September this year, also set up a stand at the event to attract foreign inventors to participate in the forthcoming exhibition on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high but closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 41.73 points to close at 5,971.76.
The bourse opened at 6,032.01 and fluctuated between 6,043.1 and 5,971.76 during trading. A total of 3.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.69 billion (US$2.48 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 2.1 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.9 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues and textile stocks both at 1.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.8 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 670 to 221, with 119 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREATER TAIPEI TO BECOME 'MOBILE METROPOLIS' BY 2010: MAYOR MA

TEXT.P: Taipei will become a city of the future by 2010, with "smart buses" relaying their locations to cellphones for people waiting at stops, 2.3 million citizens using the MRT each day and ultimately the merger with Taipei County to create a "mobile metropolis, " Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou told the City Council Thursday.

By that time, wireless fidelity technology will have so matured that many business transactions will be conducted using the technology, as will the city government's services to the public, according to Ma.

In his latest administrative report, the mayor tried to boost the confidence of the city's residents by comparing fast-developing Asian cities, including Taipei, with American and European cities. He pointed to the use of stored value cards for use on buses and subways, for example, as a technological development that is now used in most Asian cities. Also, Taipei's MRT has been renovated into better shape than New York's subway system, the mayor claimed.
"This shows that small cities can beat big cities and small countries can beat big ones as long as they know how to make full use of information technology," he said.

To enhance the city's competitiveness, Ma proposed merging Taipei City and Taipei County. By 2010, the proposed metropolitan area would boast of an MRT system able to carry 2.3 million passengers daily, similar to the capacity that Hong Kong's subways currently handle, meaning that Taipei's MRT will have transformed itself from the Little League to the Majors.

The MRT system will work together with information technology services and " smart buses, " enabling passengers to use their cellphones to see when the next bus will be arriving, according to the report.

Turning to the money available for the city's budget, Ma said the budget for the capital city has been shrinking over the past five consecutive years. He joked that if he had believed in a fortune teller's predictions a long time ago of the city's future financial difficulties, he wouldn't have dared to run for mayor.

In spite of budget constraints, Ma said the city government has pushed ahead with many development projects, including the difficult job of enlarging the sewer system, which is now serving 80 percent of the city's population and, he hopes, will cover 95 percent when his term of office expires at the end of 2006.
