DOC.HEADLINE: PFP MISSION WILL BE CAREFUL DURING CHINA VISIT: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition People First Party (PFP) promised Thursday that a PFP delegation will be careful what it does during its upcoming visit to mainland China.

PFP lawmakers Chen Chih-pin and Lee Yung-pin made the remarks at a news conference at the Legislative Yuan after colleague Tsay Sheng-jia, who will lead the delegation to China next week for negotiations on agricultural exchanges, paid a visit to Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu earlier the same day.

Pointing out that Wu pledged to help private sector exchanges between Taiwan and China, Lee said that the PFP delegation will exercise extreme caution during its China visit and will not do anything that might hurt Taiwan's interests. The PFP only hopes to serve as a bridge for cross-strait interactions, she noted.

Tsai also made it clear that the delegation will not engage in activities that could infringe on the government's power and that it agrees with the MAC on this point. All the PFP wants to do is help Taiwan's farmers, he added.
However, they still called on the MAC to review its position that prohibits any private individuals, groups or political parties from reaching verbal or written agreements with Chinese authorities.

ROC government authorities have recently reiterated that any individuals or groups that sign or reach agreements with China without prior government permission will be dealt with according to Republic of China law.

The government's reiteration of its stance came after a mission by the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) led by Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang to China late March. The group reached a 10-point consensus with Chinese Communist Party officials to bolster civilian exchanges -- a situation viewed by the government as one that might hurt Taiwan's national interests and dignity and open the floodgates to any individuals or parties wanting to ink agreements without government approval.

Meanwhile, PFP Policy Center Director Chang Hsien-yao said that a meeting between PFP Chairman James Soong and President Chen Shui-bian or a meeting between Soong and KMT Chairman Lien Chan is not part of their party's program.

Chang's comments came after news that Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, had contacted the PFP in recent days to arrange a second Chen-Soong meeting. Chen and Soong met on Feb. 24 and made public a 10-point agreement, promising to maintain the national title of the ROC and not to declare Taiwan independence in an effort to ease cross-strait tensions.
As to a prospective visit to China by Soong, Chang said Wednesday that such a visit by Soong is highly possible in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY HOLDS EXERCISE IN PENGHU AGAINST CHINESE INVASION

TEXT.P: The military held a live-fire exercise on the outlying Penghu Islands on Thursday to simulate actions against an invasion by China.
The "Lien Hsin No. 248" joint land, sea and air exercise came one month after China enacted its Anti-Secession Law, which threatens the use of force against Taiwan.

In the drill, combat readiness was practiced under the scenario of unusual military maneuvering along Chinese coasts, with Chinese fighter jets flying across the median of the Taiwan Strait and Chinese frigates approaching Penghu to try to intercept Taiwan's supply ships.
However, operations of the Air Force and Navy were called off because of poor visibility as a result of foggy weather. Artillery live-fire exercises were successful.

Also on Thursday, Penghu County councilors Li Tien-chin and Hsu Yueh-li demanded that the military hold the routine exercise in some other place in the future, saying that the exercises damage Penghu's marine ecology and affect the life of Penghu residents.
Military officials in Penghu said the military had consulted with local residents before the exercise.
The impact of the exercise on local residents should be minimal because the site of the exercise is several hundred meters away from their communities, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DON'T READ TOO MUCH INTO PRESIDENT'S VATICAN TRIP: VP LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged the media Thursday not to over-interpret President Chen Shui-bian's visit to the Vatican for the funeral of Pope John Paul II.
Lu said the Vatican is one of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies and that it is naturally for the president to condole on the death of the Pope, whom she called a great leader.
Chen, who left for Italy Thursday to travel to the Vatican, is the first ROC president to visit Europe.
Local media has dubbed the trip a major diplomatic breakthrough for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1/2 OF U.S. CONGRESSIONAL STAFF THINK U.S. SHOULD DEFEND TAIWAN: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 6 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: About half of the Congressional staff and business leaders in the United States think that the United States should defend Taiwan militarily if China attacks the island, the results of a study on American attitudes toward China showed Wednesday.

Seventy-six percent of U.S. Congressional staff questioned oppose the European Union lifting its arms embargo on China, the results of the first poll of a two-phase study commissioned by a Chinese-American elite group, the Committee of 100, showed.

The study, conducted by the polling firm Zogby International in March, gauged the opinions about China of Congressional staff, including legislative consultants, legislative authorities, aides and press secretaries, as well as business leaders, including enterprise chairmen and CEOs, corporate public relations authorities, department managers and board directors.

When asked, "Should the United States protect Taiwan with its military forces in the event of a cross-Taiwan Strait conflict after Taiwan declares independence? " 52 percent of the Congressional staff queried said that the U.S. should defend Taiwan militarily; only 19 percent said "no, " while 29 percent provide no precise answer.
For the same question, 48 percent of business leaders think the U.S. military should help defend Taiwan; 50 percent think the U.S. military should not, and only 3 percent are undecided.

Meanwhile, 76 percent of the U.S. Congressional staff expressed strong opposition to the European Union's plans to lift its arms embargo on China, compared with a mere 2 percent who said that they absolutely support the E.U. lifting the embargo.

In addition, 49 percent of the Congressional staff and 50 percent of the business leaders surveyed think that the United States should be more active toward the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The same survey also found that Americans think the biggest obstacle to doing business with China is "bureaucratic intervention."
Other major obstacles included cultural and language barriers, poor financial and judicial systems, as well as corruption, in that order, the poll found.
The Committee of 100 is a national, non-partisan organization composed of prominent American citizens of Chinese descent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT BLASTS 'UNAUTHORIZED' TALKS WITH PRC

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Thursday blasted an opposition party's "unauthorized" move to negotiate with Taiwan's arch-rival China, claiming that this amounted to an "open violation of the law."

Chen made the remarks while attending a memorial service at a cemetery in Chinshan, Taipei County, for dissident Cheng Nan-jung, who 16 years ago burned himself to death in a fight for freedom of speech.
He called on the people to beware of a hostile China that is looking negatively at Taiwan people's efforts to seek freedom and democracy.

Only Taiwan's 23 million people have the right to change Taiwan's future, the president asserted, adding that without government authorization or due democratic process, no political parties, groups or individuals can openly violate the law and enter into negotiations or sign any pacts with the Chinese authorities.
"This is the most fundamental principle of a democracy, and also fundamental knowledge that any responsible political party or its leaders must have," Chen said.
Opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang led a delegation to China and reached a 10-point consensus with his Chinese hosts, angering the Chen government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEAVES FOR VATICAN TO ATTEND LATE POPE'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian left for the Vatican Thursday to attend the funeral mass of Pope John Paul II the following day.

The president, who has defined his trip as a "journey of peace and memory," said prior to his departure that he will pay the highest regards to the late pontiff on behalf of the government and the 23 million people on Taiwan, adding that his passing away represents one of the biggest losses to the world.

The president expressed the hope to join world leaders to reflect upon the gracious munificence of the late pontiff, and to cement solid relations between the Republic of China and the Vatican by attending the Pope's funeral.

The president said that the legacy left by Pope John Paul II will encourage people the world over to attach more importance to lasting peace, love and harmony, and that he represents a light to civilization and the progress of freedom.

"As a staunch diplomat and peace partner of the Vatican and a most faithful member of the international democratic society, Taiwan will make every effort to carry out the teachings of the late Pope, " the president said.
He reiterated the determination to pursue lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait, as well as to embark on cross-strait dialogues and reconciliation.
Officials from the Presidential Office said that president's five-member delegation also includes Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, two Catholic fathers and a Muslim representative.

This will be the first time the president will have visited the Vatican, the only country in Europe with which the Republic of China maintains diplomatic ties, and his first official trip to Europe, the officials said.

The visit is only to pay tribute to the late pontiff and after Chen's arrival at the Vatican, he will attend the funeral mass immediately, and will then visit the ROC Embassy to the Holy See beside St. Peter's Square.
The president will return to Taipei Saturday afternoon. His stay in the Vatican will be less than 24 hours, the officials said.
The president will receive preferential treatment as accorded other national leaders, including preferential customs treatment, they added.
Michel Lu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said that President Chen's visit demonstrates the solid and friendly relations between the two countries.
The government hopes that the Vatican will dispatch an ambassador to head its embassy in Taipei, instead of a lower ranking figure, although it will respect the wishes of the Holy See, Lu stressed.

In addition, Lu said that as the late pontiff had attached great importance to religious integration, and was concerned with the Muslim development in the Middle East and the integration of the Catholics and the Muslims, the president's delegation has included a representative from the Muslim community.

President Chen went to the Embassy of the Holy See Monday to pay tribute to the late Pope who died Saturday at the age of 84. The charge d' affaires of the embassy then invited him to attend the late pontiff's funeral.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD REPORT CALLS FOR DIVERSIFICATION OF ENERGY RESOURCES

TEXT.P: The government must take steps to tackle continuously surging oil prices to secure Taiwan's economy, according to a report carried out by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The report proposed that state-run enterprises and the private sector collaborate in setting up cooperative ventures with foreign companies to diversify energy resources in view of a historic high price of crude oil in the world market that breached US$58 per barrel early this week.

Citing statistics compiled by the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the report points out that Taiwan's energy consumption during the 1992-2002 period grew faster than the world average.

The country's demand for coal and petroleum increased by an average of 8.7 percent and 4 percent per year, respectively, during that time, while consumption of liquefied natural gas and electricity rose by 10.1 percent and 66.7 percent, respectively, on an annual basis.

The report suggests that this might be a result of either rapid economic growth or waste and points out that the government's latest projection that puts Taiwan's annual growth for electricity and coal at 2.4 percent and 2.2 percent, and that 2.4 percent for petroleum is still higher than the average expansions posted by the member states of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development over the past 10 years.
The government must evaluate adequate growth rates for power consumption, it says.
As Taiwan's export-oriented economy relies tremendously on imported energy, it calls on the government to address the oil supply issue to minimize the impact of soaring oil prices.

It proposes that the government make policy to allow state-run enterprises, such as Taiwan Power Company and Chinese Petroleum Corp., to seek partnerships with foreign businesses in cooperation with the private sector to diversify investment channels for energy in the international market.
Taiwan's booming financial sector should be a good tool to raise funds for that purpose and help foster related businesses, it adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES FOR NORMALIZATION OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Thursday expressed the hope that Taiwan and China will normalize their relations to make way for perpetual peace across the Taiwan Strait.

The president made the remarks at a memorial event held at the Chin Pao San cemetery in Chinshan township, Taipei County to commemorate the 16th anniversary of the death of Chen Nan-zon, who burned himself to death in 1989 in protest against the former Kuomintang government's suppression of freedom of speech.
President Chen said Chen Nan-zon's devotion to Taiwan's freedom and justice is memorable and that his great spirit and image will stay in the hearts of everyone on the island.

While Taiwan is now a democratic country enjoying absolute freedom of speech, social justice has been realized to an initial extent in Taiwan, and human rights protection has been made a principle policy of the government, the president pointed out.
Although there no longer exists authoritarian rule in Taiwan, its freedom is under threat from China, which has rejected the wishes and efforts of the Taiwan people to pursue democracy, he said.

He said he hopes cross-strait relations can be normalized to facilitate everlasting cross-strait peace, because peace jeopardized by a dictatorship that threatens the use of non-peaceful means is not true peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Schools still failing to teach pupils how to read.
An immediate review of how children are taught to read was demanded yesterday after MPs cast doubt on one of Tony Blair's key reforms. The one in five children who cannot read properly at the age of 11 is "unacceptably high" eight years after the National Literacy Strategy was introduced in primary schools, the Education and Skills Select Committee said.
Financial Times: Blair bid to end Brown rivalry.
Tony Blair on Wednesday dramatically ended long-running speculation that he would try to switch Gordon Brown to another job after polling day, in a move that boosts the party's poll hopes and Mr Brown's own chances of one day succeeding to the premiership. Acting to end months of bitter rivalry with his principal ally in the formation of New Labour, the prime minister said it would be "foolish" to move Mr Brown from the Treasury where he has held sway for the past eight years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR EXPECTED TO CONTINUE PICKING UP IN VALUE: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Despite noticeable fluctuations of the new Taiwan dollar in recent days, the local currency is expected to keep on picking up in value over the long term, analysts said Thursday.
They said that the long-term course for Asian currencies, including the new Taiwan dollar, is to keep on appreciating due to a weaker U.S. dollar and a much anticipated stronger renminbi.

Urging Taiwan companies to quickly hedge against risks of currency exchanges to bring down production costs, experts proposed branding, industry upgrading and market diversification as means of staying competitive.
Only by doing so can domestic companies grow sustainably, they said, adding that it is important to catch up with market trends now.
In the 1980s, Taiwan companies were also troubled by a fast rising local currency, resulting in massive relocations offshore of labor-intensive businesses, they pointed out.

Those remaining in Taiwan took the opportunity to purchase pricey machinery to undergo industrial upgrading -- efforts that saw the country's high-tech sector gain ground in the world market, they went on, adding that the ratio of Taiwan's technology-intensive exports grew from 18.4 percent of its total outbound shipments in 1986 to 43.5 percent in 2004.
Now Taiwan takes pride in value-added goods such as computers and monitors -- a major shift from the sporting shoes and tennis racquets of the past, they noted.

Taking advantage of a rising local currency to achieve sustainable growth, Taiwan companies now should engage in creating their own distinguished brands and edging into new markets, rather than just manufacturing on a contract basis to rack up greater profitability, they suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICIANS URGED TO RESPECT NATIONAL DIGNITY IN PURSUIT OF DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: Several ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers on Thursday urged both government officials and opposition politicians to respect the national dignity in their pursuit of diplomacy with foreign countries.

DPP Legislator Cheng Yun-peng was referring to the visit made by opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang to China last week, in which Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with Beijing authorities, covering issues such as cross-strait transportation, agriculture, protection of Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China, and the opening of China's financial market.
Cheng noted that Chiang's China visit was made without the authorization of the government; besides, the timing was bad.

Given that China just passed the Anti-Secession Law, which will legalize an attack against Taiwan should the island declare formal independence, Cheng said Chiang's visit to the mainland and the consensus he achieved with Beijing on the issues which still lack consensus within the island will be seen as "kowtowing" to China.

Cheng went on that in contrast to President Chen Shui-bian's visit to Rome to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral mass, which he classified as successful diplomacy, Cheng stressed that Chiang's visit to China was unjustifiable and cannot represent all the people of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, DPP Legislator Huang Wei-che said he was glad to see that both the government and opposition politicians were working actively for better ties with other countries. However, he urged them to demonstrate solidity, especially when China has not shown good will toward the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: One Million Wait to View the Pope as Line Is Cut Off.
The streets around St. Peter's Basilica swelled Wednesday with an estimated one million pilgrims, nearly double the barely manageable number of the day before. The surge was so great hat late on Wednesday night Italian officials close d down the line to view the body of Pope John Paul II. Vatican officials said in this city o f three million, one million people had seen the pope's body since it went on public display on Monday. Viewing is to end Thursday evening, and safety officials, concerned with the size of the crowd and recognizing the wait to see the body would exceed 24 hours, sent warnings on the radio and through text messages to cellphones advising people to stay away. Eventually they decided to close the line to newcomers.
Wall Street Journal: Church and State, In Vantican City, A Cardinal Works To Balance Budget.
The late Pope John Paul II earned praise for his role in facing down communism. One of Cardinal Edmund Szoka's contributions to the Roman Catholic Church has been an injection of capitalism. The 77-year-old former archbishop of Detroit is president of the Governatorate of Vatican City, the closest thing this tiny city-state has to a mayor. Two years ago, Cardinal Szoka moved the Vatican's department store out of a glum basement and into the former train station, a spacious, refurbished stone building behind St. Peter's Basilica. Since being assigned to his current post in 2001, he has boosted the Vatican's retailing operations, which now account for 53percent of the city-state's annual budget of about US$190 million. Revenue from the Vatican Museums, including admissions and gift-shop sales, makes up an additional 19 percent, while odds and ends such as the sale of stamps and coins issued by the post office provide the rest. Without that cash, the Vatican wouldn't be able to pay its electricity bill or the salaries of its 1,500 employees, including 63 full-time gardeners.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT IGNORING THE LAW: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker claimed Thursday that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) ignored the government's reminder that the party should pay heed to related laws while visiting China.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP's legislative caucus, made the remarks after the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court began an investigation into KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who recently returned from a visit to China, where he reached a 10-point consensus with the Beijing authorities covering issues such as cross-Taiwan Strait transportation, agricultural cooperation, protection of Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China, and the opening of China's financial market.

The Public Prosecutors' Office took the case Wednesday after accepting a treason lawsuit filed by the public against Chiang for reaching an agreement with a foreign government without the government's authorization.
The KMT's legislative caucus said in retaliation that it will not exclude the possibility of suing President Chen Shui-bian and prime minister Frank Hsieh.
Chao said the KMT should pay more attention to the related laws and listen more to public opinion. He did not make clear which law the KMT was alleged to have broken.

He added that at a time when China has passed the Anti-Secession Law, which legalizes an attack against Taiwan should the island seek formal independence, the politicians from both the government and the opposition should reach consensus within the country before conducting sensitive cross-strait negotiations.

Meanwhile, Legislator Lai Ching-teh, the DPP's legislative caucus whip, criticized the attitude of KMT Chairman Lien Chan toward a seven-point conclusion reached by officials of Chen Shui-bian's administration following Chiang's China visit.

The participants in the meeting convened by Chen concluded that the Republic of China is a sovereign country, that any change to Taiwan's future should be decided by the country's 23 million people, and that any cross-strait affairs involving national sovereignty should not be negotiated by any political parties, groups or individuals without the authorization of the government.
Lai suggested that Lien have a meeting with Chen to better understand the meaning of the conclusion.
Lien, to whom Beijing also extended an invitation, said earlier this week that he would be honored to visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN PROBED FOR TALKS WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: The Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court said Thursday that they have assigned a prosecutor to look into opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's talks with Chinese officials during his high-profile trip to China from March 28 to April 1.

The Prosecutors' Office said the probe was launched after people alleged to them that Chiang's 10-point consensus with Chinese officials constituted the crime of "concluding an accord with a foreign government without government authorization, " which is high treason under the Criminal Code.
An anonymous official in the office said, the case was classified as "ta" category, which includes complaints with little evidence of wrongdoing.

Although the prosecutor was ordered to investigate Chiang two days after President Chen Shui-bian and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) formed a united front to get tough with opposition parties which are scrambling to visit China, the Prosecutors' Office claimed that politics "has no role" in the case.

However, the KMT launched a broadside against Chen and the DPP Thursday, with party lawmakers taking turns to criticize the DPP government for what they claimed was trying to make the law a tool in a political power struggle.

KMT lawmaker Huang Teh-fu said the prosecutors should also probe the president in connection with high treason, since Chen once showcased a written note purporting to be a secret message to him from a senior Chinese official.

Lawmaker Su Chi said Minister of Justice Shih Mao-ling should step down for downgrading his prosecutors into servants of the ruler, and the KMT lawmakers at the legislature should stop considering the government's request for a special budget to buy arms from the United States.
KMT lawmaker Lai Shih-pao said that if P.K. Chiang is guilty, that the KMT, which sent him on the mission, should be guilty too, along with all the Taiwan businessmen operating in China.

KMT lawmaker Chen Chieh pointed out that under the Republic of China Constitution, China is not a foreign country and that the Ministry of Justice is attempting to "stretch" the Criminal Code to cover China.
Vice President Annette Lu claimed that any person who loses a presidential race but attempts to usurp the president's power by concluding treaties with "other countries" should be brought to justice.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO RESTRICTIONS ON AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said Thursday that the government has set no restrictions on Taiwan agricultural exports to China and has made every effort to assist farmers wishing to tap into the China market.

Wu made the remarks while meeting with legislators from the opposition People First Party (PFP) who had come to exchange views with Wu on how to carry out the 10-point conclusion -- including President Chen Shui-bian's reaffirmation of no change to the nation's official title -- reached between the president and PFP Chairman James Soong, and a PFP plan to send an agricultural delegation to China.
Wu welcomed the visit and expressed hope that political parties and the government could have more such discussions to forge consensus and avoid Beijing's "united front" tactics to split the island.

Wu said that Taiwan agricultural exports to China are not smooth mainly because Beijing imposes too high customs tariffs plus complicated customs clearing and quarantine procedures, while there are difficulties in establishing marketing networks.

The above questions will require government planning if they involve the execution of the authority of the government, Wu said, adding that any groups will have to wait for government authorization before conducting negotiations with China.

He reiterated that the government will not oppose or interfere with domestic political parties or civic groups going to China to engage in cross-strait exchanges if they will be helpful to cross-strait understanding and will not undermine national interests.

As the leaders of the two major opposition parties -- Lien Chan of the Kuomintang and PFP Chairman James Soong -- have expressed their intention to visit China, a MAC spokesman also said that considering the sour atmosphere in the wake of China's recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, the MAC is not keen on any party leaders visiting at present.
Meanwhile, a former MAC official urged the government not to rashly export agricultural products to China.

Speaking at a seminar in Taipei on China's agricultural problems, Chiu Tai-san, a former MAC vice chairman, said the government has invested a great deal of money in the improvement of agricultural technology and should not do anything recklessly.

He said that if Taiwan's agricultural products are concentrated too much in one place, it will cause risks and pressure on domestic agricultural development, especially because Beijing often interferes politically with economic issues, compounded by its myriads of agricultural problems and its wavering agricultural policy.

Pointing out that Taiwan farmers often face the problem of imbalanced production and marketing, Chiu said that farmers often fail to take note of market changes, resulting in gluts and shortages alternatively.
Chiu also said that "the intent of China is self-evident" in its active solicitation of Taiwan agricultural associations to visit mainland China.

He said Beijing has to address its failure squarely after years of a "united front" tactics toward Taiwan, and claimed it is now taking a more soft and appeasing approach to try to woo Taiwan people following the anger vented by them in the wake of the passage of the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO INVITE TOKYO MAYOR TO PITCH FOR TOURISM

TEXT.P: Taipei city government sent an invitation letter to Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara Thursday, asking him to serve as the spokesman of a Japanese version of a Taipei tourism magazine.
Government officials noted that Taipei is a major attraction for Japanese tourists and that Japanese tourists are a major target of the tourism publications issued by the city government.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou invited Ishihara to visit Taiwan during a visit he made to Japan last month.

Even though there will be difficulties in arranging the visit because of Ishihara's tight schedule and because of the recent controversy surrounding the head of the pro-Taiwan independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union's visit to a shrine in Tokyo honoring Japan's war dead of World War II, Taipei city government still sent the invitation to him.

The officials said that 70 percent of 5,000 tourism publications issued monthly are supplied to Taiwan missions in Japan, with the remainder distributed to tour operators, which they said exert a certain impact on luring Japanese tourists.
As the itinerary of Ishihara is tight, the tourism publication is expected to ask him to promote Taipei tourism in an interview, the officials said.
Ishihara will be the first political figure to serve as the spokesman of the tourism publication. Previous spokesmen have been mostly from business, literary and cultural circles.
The officials said they chose Ishihara because he has visited Taiwan five times and recently spoke at the launch of a luxurious tourism train organized by the Taiwan Railway Administration.
They said his name will be familiar to quite a number of older Japanese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIBNET SERVES AS WINDOW ON TAIWAN'S RICH, VALUABLE BIODIVERSITY

TEXT.P: A newly completed Internet network known as TaiBNET is poised to serve as a window on Taiwan's ecological system, which is unparalleled in the world and the most invaluable natural asset of the country, a source from Academia Sinica said Thursday.

TaiBNET, the first-phase project of a Web site network introducing Taiwan's rich biodiversity, has been completed by the Academia Sinica Biodiversity Center after three years of painstaking work, said Shao Kuang-chao, director of the Biodiversity Center.

According to Shao, Taiwan is indeed an "Ilha Formosa, " or "beautiful island" as it was named by the first Portuguese colonialists nearly 500 years ago, because it has 2.5 percent of the world's genetic variations even though the island's area is only 0.00025 of the globe, constituting 100 times the average density of species worldwide.
In the seas surrounding Taiwan, the number of species is about one-tenth of the whole world, or 400 times that of the world's average, Shao added.
It is justifiable to say that if there were no Taiwan and the waters surrounding it, the biodiversity jigsaw puzzle of the world would have a piece missing, Shao claimed.

Currently, TaiBNET covers 45,040 species and genetic variations found in Taiwan. Estimated according to the food chain theory of Peter Raven, a distinguished U.S. botanist, the number of Taiwan's plant and animal species should be around 150,000 to 200,000, Shao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE SURPLUS SLIDES IN QI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade surplus plummeted by 85 percent in the first quarter of this year due to declining exports and soaring imports, a source from the Ministry of Finance reported Thursday.

Taiwan exported US$42.85 billion-worth of products and services in the first three months while importing US$42.56 billion-worth of commodities and products, according to Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Finance Ministry's Department of Statistics.
As a result, the country posted a trade surplus of US$290 million in Q1, representing a decline of 85 percent or US$1.66 billion over that posted in Q1 of 2004, Hsu said.

According to Hsu, Taiwan's export trade totaled US$15.78 billion in March, while the country's import trade amounted to US$16.17 billion, up 6.9 percent and 14.9 percent, respectively, over the corresponding month of 2004.
Although both figures were record highs, Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$390 million in March due to rising imports that exceeded exports, Hsu said.
In March, Taiwan's exports of information technology and telecommunications products -- the bulk of the island's export trade -- declined by 25.6 percent over the same month of the previous year.

Hsu attributed the surging imports in March to several factors, including oil imports that skyrocketed 132 percent in March compared with the same month of the previous year as a result of soaring international oil prices, plus imports of civilian aircraft, as well as trains to be used on the Taiwan High-Speed Railway.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE DONATES MONEY TO LOCAL CHARITY GROUP

TEXT.P: The British Chamber of Commerce (BCC) donated NT$699,025 (US$22,190) Thursday to the Ai-Chi Development Center, a charity group that offers shelter to mentally challenged adolescents and children.

Alistair Bulloch, the BCC executive who made the donation on behalf of the organization, said he was glad to do something meaningful for the society at a time when the organization is celebrating its 10th anniversary.
An official of the Ai-Chi Development Center said the donated money will be used to repair the floor of the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TRAVELERS VISITING TAIWAN HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The number of inbound travelers totaled 298,282 in March, a record monthly high and a 24.51 percent growth year-on-year, Tourism Bureau officials said Thursday.
At a meeting presided over by Vice Premier Wu Rong-i on ways to promote tourism, the officials estimated that the number of travelers visiting Taiwan this year is expected to reach 3.25 million.

The officials added that the number of inbound travelers in the first half of 2004 did not meet the original target of 1.4 million due to several factors, such as bird flu and the politically tumultuous situation following the presidential election in March.

However, more and more travelers began to visit Taiwan in the second half of 2004 when those negative factors were eliminated, the officials said, adding that a total of 2.95 million tourists visited the island last year.
Among the nearly 300,000 foreign visitors in March, the number of Japanese travelers exceeded 100,000, representing a 50.61 percent growth over the same month of last year.
Wu instructed the officials to make efforts to persuade tourists visiting the Aichi Expo in Japan to also make a stop here after their Japan visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INTERNATIONAL BANK CREDITS TOTAL US$83.6 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's international bank credits totaled US$83.6 billion as of the end of 2004, an increase of US$10 billion from the previous quarter, Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Thursday.
The increase was due mainly to increased overseas investment and overnight lending to foreign banks, said Sun Chuan-yu, deputy director of the CBC's Banking Examination Department.

CBC data show the United States as being the biggest debtor to Taiwanese banks, followed by Luxembourg, Hong Kong, the United Kingdom, Singapore, the West Indies, Japan, Germany, France and South Korea. These countries account for 76.08 percent of Taiwan's international credit.

Globally, cross-country credits totaled US$15,393.4 billion as of the end of September, 2004. Of the total, Taiwan had a 0.48 percent share. The world's top three creditor countries are Germany, UK and Switzerland in that order, according to the CBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 8 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Friday, April 8:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09: 00, The third Asian Conference of Oral Health Promotion for School Children will open at the Splendor Kaohsiung in the southern city of Kaohsiung.
09: 05, Vice President Annette Lu will address the opening ceremony of an international energy seminar at the Chinese Petroleum Corp. Building in Taipei.
10:00, The Taipei International Electronics Spring Show will open at the Taipei World Trade Center.
10: 30, The Mainland Affairs Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
14: 30, The Taiwan Neurological Society will hold a news conference at the Far Eastern Plaza hotel in Taipei.
15:00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a news conference at the Presidential Office on the Taipei County cultural and artistic exposition.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16: 20, The Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RECOMMENDS WEEKLY AND QUARTERLY CHARTER FLIGHTS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank, the Foundation for National Policy Research, recommended direct weekly passenger charter flights and direct quarterly cargo charter flights between Taiwan and China Thursday as a transitional step toward direct regular flight service across the Taiwan Strait.

Tseng Yung-chuan, the executive director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, said at a seminar called to present the foundation's study that the direct weekly charter flights for passengers, preferably lined up on the four days between Friday and Monday, would cater to the needs of commuters between Taiwan and China.

These flights should link at least the Chinese cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Chengdu, Guangzhou, Shenzhen and Xiamen with the four Taiwan airports of Shungshan, Chiang Kai-shek, Hualien and Hsiaokang in Kaohsiung.

The direct cross-strait cargo flights are more urgent than the passenger flights in terms of Taiwan's economic development, Tseng said, adding that they would be lined up for every quarter so that businessmen can plan their delivery of goods in advance.
Without the direct cargo flights to and from China, Tseng quoted local businessmen as saying, Taiwan is set to see more companies relocating their manufacturing operations from Taiwan to China.

In the initial stage, the cargo flights should cover the Chinese cities of Beijing, Shanghai, Chengdu, Guangzhou, Tienjin, Shenzhen, and Xiamen with Chiang Kai-shek Airport and Hsiaokang Airport, according to the study.

Kao Kung-lien, a former vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said at the seminar that Taiwan's ambition to develop itself into a regional business hub cannot be realized in the absence of direct transportation links with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESPECT POPE'S AUTHORITY

TEXT.P: The Beijing authorities should respect the Pope's authority and improve religious freedom in China instead of expressing discontent over President Chen Shui-bian's trip to the Vatican to attend the funeral of Pope John Paul II, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Commenting on remarks by a Chinese official in Beijing earlier in the day expressing the Beijing authorities' indignation toward the Italian government and the Vatican over allowing Chen to visit, Michel Lu said that Beijing has "nothing to say" in this regard.

The Republic of China is one of the Vatican's diplomatic allies and it is totally rational that the ROC president should attend the funeral to pay his respects to the memory of the late pontiff, he noted.
What the Beijing authorities have done to Catholics in China violates the universal values of freedom, democracy and human rights, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN CALLS ON PREMIER TO EXPLAIN CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who is being probed by prosecutors for concluding an accord with Chinese leaders during a visit to China, called on Premier Frank Hsieh Thursday to explain his trip, but the premier refused to comment on a case under judicial investigation.

Chiang, accompanied by 10 KMT lawmakers, told Hsieh that his alleged 10-point consensus is more a Chinese response to KMT questions than an accord and is aimed at protecting Taiwan businessmen working in China.
The questions and answers were not written down and therefore no record of them exist, Chiang claimed.
Hsieh said only that the ends cannot justify the means and that goodwill could land a person in jail.

Noting that the existing laws restrict public officials from making trips to China, the premier said he anticipated that Chiang would be in for trouble when he departed for China without bothering to notify the government as required by law and reached consensus with Chinese officials, which he said is also prohibited by law.
Hsieh said that even though the KMT has threatened to stonewall his administration's bills at the legislature, there is nothing he can do in the case but let justice take its course.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 8, or the30th day of the second month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign a convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low-interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1958: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as a means of enforcing the nuclear test ban.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the U.S. forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered Mike-class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
1999: NATO continues airstrikes against Yugoslavia while the eastern European country says its 14-month war against ethnic Albanian separatists is over.
2000: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa tells U.S. President Bill Clinton that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life cannot be a true gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CHEN ARRIVES IN ROME FOR POPE'S FUNERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 8 (CNA) (By P.C. Fan and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian arrived in Rome on board a China Airlines charter flight early Friday morning to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral to be held later the same day in the Vatican.

President Chen, heading a Republic of China delegation to the funeral, was greeted upon his arrival at the airport by an Italian protocol official, as well as ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng, ROC Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng and other ROC officials.

Chen and the other members of the delegation, including ROC Foreign Minister Chen Tan-sun, were then led to a VIP room at the airport before receiving a military police escort to the hotel where they will be staying during their visit.
The president will join more than 200 heads of state and dignitaties in paying final respects to the pontiff at the funeral to be held at 10:00 a.m. in Saint Peter's Square.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH SENATE GROUP REGRETS TAIWAN'S EXCLUSION FROM WHO
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 7 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A French Senate group friendly to Taiwan issued a statement Thursday saying it regrets that the island has been excluded from the World Health Organization (WHO) and hopes the World Health Assembly (WHA) can help find a solution when it convenes its annual conference in Geneva next month.
The statement was issued to coincide with World Health Day. It came one day after Republic of China Minister of the Department of Health Ho Sheng-mao called on the French Senate in Paris.
The group, composed of some 45 senators from various political parties, said it regrets that the 23 million people of Taiwan have been excluded from the global disease prevention information system.
In the statement, the group expressed the hope that a solution to this problem could be found during the 58th World Health Assembly, WHO's policy-making body, in Geneva May 16-25.
Noting that the slogan of this year's World Health Day is "make every mother and child count, " the group said every mother and child in Taiwan should also count.

The statement also said that in view of the infectious diseases in Asia, the group hopes that France can make efforts within its foreign policy to support Taiwan's bid to attend technical meetings and activities of the WHO.

Minister Ho's trip to Europe has included visits to Zurich, Paris, Brussels, and Luxembourg. He spoke to the media and think tank officials in Brussels Thursday, stressing that a world health organization is flawed without the participation of Taiwan.
Later Thursday, Ho proceeded to Luxembourg to meet with Luxembourg parliamentarians and the media. He is scheduled to wrap up his European visit Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT TO WORK TO BOOST TAIWAN FRUIT EXPORTS TO CHINA VIA WTO

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) will work to help Taiwan farmers to export more fruit to the Chinese mainland via the World Trade Organization (WTO) mechanism, BOFT officials said Friday.

Despite the facts that both Taiwan and China are WTO members and that Taiwan has been involved in multilateral talks with China under the WTO framework and that the two sides share similar views on certain WTO issues, China has not opened its door wide enough to Taiwan fruit, the BOFT officials said.

According to BOFT tallies, China allows only 12 categories of fruits from Taiwan to be imported. In 2004, China imported only US$1.637 million worth of Taiwan fruit, constituting a mere 1.47 percent of China's total fruit imports for the year.

The BOFT will continue to seek consultations with China under the WTO framework to open the Chinese market wider to Taiwan fruit, including bananas, the officials said. The 12 categories of Taiwan fruit that are currently allowed into China include mangoes, betel nuts and shaddock.

Meanwhile, they pointed out, a number of Taiwan banking institutions have established representative offices in China for more than two years, qualifying them to open branches on the mainland. However, the officials noted, these banks have not been able to further upgrade their operations there due to the lack of a "supervision cooperation memorandum" signed by the governments of the two sides.

Although China promised to open its service sector in its WTO entry protocol, the Beijing authorities have been intentionally difficult toward Taiwan investors, being picky even on the "feasibility study reports" filed by Taiwan businesspeople for investments in China's distribution business, the officials said.

Meanwhile, the BOFT will ask China, during the forthcoming Doha round of bilateral and multilateral talks, to further relax restrictions on building and running hospitals in China, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. AGAINST ANY MOVES TO ALTER MILITARY BALANCE IN TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 7 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A high-ranking U.S. State Department official said Wednesday that the United States does not welcome any efforts that might alter the military balance in the Taiwan Strait.

Nicholas Burns, under secretary for political affairs, made the comments while touching on the European Union's intentions to lift a arms ban on China in a speech he delivered at Chatham House in London. The full text of the speech was released by the State Department Thursday.

Claiming that the United States still seeks to maintain its historic role as the principal guarantor of peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, Burns said that Washington also seeks a peaceful and constructive relationship with China.
"We are China's partner in the Six-Party talks. We have improved our relationship with China," he said.
Nevertheless, the under secretary said that the United States has been dismayed by China's military forces' buildup, particularly its ballistic missile forces across from Taiwan.

He also noted that U.S. President George W. Bush had made it clear during his latest trip in Europe that "due to human rights and regional security concerns, ending the E.U. arms embargo (against China) is a bad idea."

"We will not support the E.U.'s efforts to do so. It would have an impact, as Deputy Secretary Zoellick said recently, on our Trans-Atlantic partnership, particularly if the U.S. Congress were to enact legislation limiting the sale of important U.S. technology to E.U. countries," Burns said.
"Clearly, it is now time for the United states and the European Union to engage in a serious strategic dialogue about our mutual interests in Asia and the Pacific, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SENDS MEDICAL MISSION TO HELP INDONESIAN QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A four-member Taiwan medical mission has traveled to Indonesia to help with post-earthquake relief work, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Friday.
The medical personnel will offer medical services to surviving victims of the powerful magnitude 8.7 earthquake that struck off Indonesia's Sumatra Island March 29, the official said.

According to the official, the temblor resulted in the death or injury of more than 1,000 people, with the remote Indonesian island of Nias bearing the brunt of devastation. Transport and communications in the Nias region remain difficult as the earthquake severely damaged the power system there.

Out of humanitarian concern, the Republic of China government has donated US$50,000 in cash and a large number of body bags to the Indonesian government, the official said, adding that the MOFA has also directed the ROC representative office in Jakarta to purchase US$10,000 worth of rice in Indonesia to help feed the quake survivors.
In addition, the official said the MOFA has cooperated with the Department of Health in organizing the four-member medical mission to Nias and Sibogal in Sumatra to offer post-disaster relief aid.

The March 29 earthquake followed an even-bigger quake that caused the tsunami disaster of Dec. 26, 2004. The death toll in South and Southeast Asian countries, including Indonesia, from the Dec. 26 quake and ensuing tsunamis exceeded 300,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC NOT CONSIDERING POSTPONING NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION

TEXT.P: The head of the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Friday that he will not consider postponing the mission-oriented National Assembly election for the time being.

CEC Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung made the remarks when he was invited by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) to report on the National Assembly election and the proposed "three-in-one" local elections at the end of this year.

TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming suggested that the CEC postpone the National Assembly election for "major incidents, " citing the example of the 1979 legislative elections which were postponed after the United States severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

With the bill governing the operations of the National Assembly still in limbo because of bickering between the ruling and the opposition parties, Lo said that even if the 300 delegates are elected on May 14 as scheduled, the National Assembly will still be a toothless organ, and this could trigger constitutional crisis.

Chang noted that the 1979 legislative elections were postponed by an emergency decree issued by then-President Chiang Ching-kuo. He said that as there is no such emergency decree at present, the CEC will carry out the conclusions reached by the Legislative Yuan last August to hold a National Assembly election on May 14.

A total of 300 delegates are to be elected to the National Assembly, whose mission will be to approve a package of constitutional amendment proposals -- halving the number of seats in the legislature, changing the electoral system to a"single constituency and two votes" system, abrogating the National Assembly, and including the referendum system into the Constitution.
"It is not the jurisdiction of the CEC to suspend or postpone the election, and we are not considering it," Chang said.

The TSU also suggested that the CEC seriously consider postponing the National Assembly election to the end of the year and holding it simultaneously with the city and county head elections to save money and boost the turnout rate, and to avoid a constitutional crisis.

On the proposal to hold mayoral, magistrate, city and county councilor, and village and township chief elections simultaneously to save money, Chang said that the CEC will study the proposal at a meeting next Wednesday.

After reaching a resolution at the upcoming meeting, the CEC will send letters to local election committees as a reference, he said, adding that the views of local election committees will be respected in terms of deciding whether to hold the "three-in-one elections."
Meanwhile, four legislators from across the party spectrum lent their support to the "three-in-one" elections proposal first broached by Premier Frank Hsieh.

Legislator Huang Chien-huei of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that the CEC will convene a meeting April 13 and that it should show its determination to cut costs by holding the elections simultaneously.

Legislator Wu Yu-sheng of the Kuomintang (KMT) said that polls have shown that 58 percent of the people support the "three in-one" elections, and that 56 percent favor merging central and local elections to two times every four years. He said the polls demonstrate the public's desire for election reform.
KMT Legislator Lin Hung-chih and People First Party Legislator Wu Chin-Chi echoed their colleagues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONDEMNS CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: ROC LEGISLATIVE GROUP
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, April 7 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States has condemned China's recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, the head of a Republic of China legislative group visiting the United States said Thursday.

Legislator Chiang Chao-yi of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made the remarks while meeting with Taiwanese expatriates in southern California prior to departing Los Angeles for Taipei Friday.

Chiang noted that during his stay in Washington, D.C., the U.S. government officials, members of Congress and academic figures that he and his delegation met with were unanimous in their condemnation of Beijing's enactment of the law, which authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

The substantive actions the U.S. government has taken include urging the European Union not to lift its arms embargo against China, and concluding an agreement with Japan in an earlier security consultative meeting that peace in the Taiwan Strait is a common strategic objective of the two countries, Chiang said.

Legislator Liu Kuan-ping of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union said that some people in U.S. political circles consider Washington's "one-China policy" as a remnant of the Cold War era. He added that some voices have been calling for new thinking in U.S. policy toward China.

Four other members of the delegation, including DPP Legislators Lin Chung-mo, Ho Shui-sheng and Hsieh Hsin-ni, and Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Huang Shih-chou, also said that they have learned during their visit that the United States has come to understand that China is not a peaceful rising power and that the best defense for Taiwan is its freedom and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF GERMANS OPPOSED TO LIFTING E.U. ARMS SALES BAN ON CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 7 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A nationwide public opinion poll conducted in Germany recently shows that a majority of the German people are opposed to a lifting of the European Union's ban on arms sales to China.

According to the results of the poll announced by the German public television station ARD Thursday, 70 percent of the survey respondents said they oppose a lifting of the ban, while only 23 percent said they support it.
The question of whether the E.U. should lift its ban has become a hot issue in German political circles since China's enactment of its anti-secession law March 14.

Most German lawmakers have said they consider that now is not the right time to lift the ban, and German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer has also expressed opposition to Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's stance in support of a lifting of the ban as the anti-secession authorizes Beijing to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.

Meanwhile, the poll showed that 78 percent of the respondents said they are dissatisfied with the administrative work of the German coalition government, while only 36 percent said they are satisfied.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WON'T OPPOSE PRIVATE CROSS-STRAIT EXHANGES: VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will not oppose or interfere with visits to China by Taiwan political parties or private organizations if the visits are private in nature, conducive to enhancing bilateral understanding and not detrimental to Taiwan's national interests, MAC Vice Chairman Johnnason Liu said Friday.

Cross-strait exchanges that involve government authority must first be approved by the government or government-authorized intermediary bodies such as the Straits Exchange Foundation, Liu added. The MAC is Taiwan's top agency responsible for China policy planning.

Commenting on the planned visits to China by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, Liu said the timing is controversial given Beijing's recent passage of its anti-secession law authorizing the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.

The timing of the visits could mislead the international community concerning the Taiwan people's opinions about that law, Liu said, adding that the administration may discourage Soong and Lien from going to China anytime soon.

Meanwhile, Liu said that the administration has imposed no restrictions on Taiwan's agricultural exports to China. Taiwan farmers have been experiencing difficulty trying to export farm products, including fruit, to the mainland because China's prohibitively high import tariffs, complex and confusing customs and quarantine procedures, and Taiwan businesses' difficulties in opening up distribution channels on the mainland.

Liu said that although both Taiwan and mainland China are World Trade Organization (WTO) members and the two sides should engage in trade exchanges under the WTO framework, the Chinese authorities have been passive in helping Taiwan overcome trade barriers in China.
Even worse, he added, the Chinese authorities have tried to skirt the WTO framework when Taiwan is involved, which he said is obviously motivated by political considerations.

Commenting on the imminent visit to mainland China by a PFP group to exchange views with Chinese authorities and to promote agricultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, another MAC official said that the MAC will not block the visit so long as it is private in nature.

The PFP group, however, must not reach any "consensus" or "conclusions" with the Chinese authorities, must not forge either oral or written agreements, and must not hold a press conference with mainland officials to make any "joint announcement," the MAC official said.

Referring to KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's recent visit to China during which Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with the Beijing authorities, the official said that the PFP must refrain from entering into any form of cooperation with Chinese political or military authorities to "avoid violating Republic of China law."

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MULLING WHETHER TO AMEND STATUTE AMID PROBE INTO VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is mulling over whether to amend a cross-strait statute to counter the government's probe into a KMT vice chairman's recent visit to mainland China and to pave the way for the upcoming visit of the party's chairman to China, a ranking KMT official said Friday.

The official, who preferred to remain anonymous, said that the party is considering whether to revise Article 33 of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area. However, he did not elaborate on the way in which the party would revise the statute.

Article 33 of the statute stipulates that Taiwan people, institutions and groups are prohibited from serving as members of any mainland Chinese institutions or groups without prior government authorization. They are also barred from forging any alliances with mainland citizens, institutions or groups.

The official's revelation came one day after the Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court said it had assigned a prosecutor to look into KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang's talks with Chinese officials during his high-profile trip to China March 28- April 1.

The Prosecutor's Office said the probe was launched after members of the public filed complaints that Chiang's 10-point consensus reached with Chinese officials constituted the crime of "concluding an accord with a foreign government without government authorization,' which is high treason under the Criminal Code.

The KMT official reasoned that as legislators from the KMT and its ally the People First Party (PFP) hold a majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, passing an amendment could be a feasible way to counter the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) "get tough" approach toward the opposition parties.

However, he added that pushing through the amendment would not be of help to Chiang, who is currently under investigation, as the law would not be retroactive. It would only be of help in terms of facilitating a possible meeting between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao during Lien's planned China visit.

The KMT and the PFP have suspended indefinitely their consultations with the DPP to protest against the probe into Chiang's China trip. With tensions between the ruling and the opposition parties high, the review of major issues, such as confirmation of President Chen's Control Yuan member nominees and a statute governing a major arms procurement from the United States, could be delayed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 52.31 points to close at 6,024.07.
The bourse opened at 6,002.35 and fluctuated between 5,997.29 and 6,026.55 during trading. A total of 2.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.00 billion (US$1.96 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with plastic and chemical shares moving down 0.2 percent.

The seven other major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues gaining the most at 1.4 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.2 percent, textile stocks at 1.0 percent, cement stocks at 0.8 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.6 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 579 to 279, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO ACT ON CROSS-STRAIT CONTINGENCIES: JAPANESE NEWSPAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 8 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States will deal with contingencies in the Taiwan Strait in compliance with the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), according to a report in Japan's Sankei Shimbun datelined Washington Friday.

Citing remarks by U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall Shriver during a breakfast meeting Monday with a visiting group of lawmakers from Taiwan, the newspaper reported that Shriver also suggested U.S.-Japan cooperation to counter any contingencies in the strait.

The report quoted Shriver as saying that Beijing sent officials to Washington twice in an attempt to convince the United States before it adopted the Anti-Secession Law March 14, but Washington asked Beijing in turn to rethink its plan to enact the law, according to the report.

According to the report, Shriver voiced grave concern over Taiwan's security to the group of lawmakers led by Chiang Chau-yi of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party and he made it clear that the United States will handle cross-strait incidents in compliance with the terms of TRA.

Shriver also cited peacefully dealing with cross-strait crises as a common strategic objective between the United States and Japan, the report says. However, the U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state failed to outline concrete U.S. measures or the content of its cooperation agreement with Japan in the event of a crisis in the strait, it noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT OF SERTZE ISLET COULD GET OFF GROUND SOON

TEXT.P: Construction of Taipei's second supplementary city hub project will be launched now that a flood prevention and a review of urban development for Sertze Islet, a sandbar between the Tamshui and Keelung rivers, has been completed.

President Chen Shui-bian first broached the idea of developing Sertze Islet during his tenure as Taipei mayor after Typhoon Herb assaulted Taiwan caused serious flooding in Sertze Islet and other areas in 1996.
Chen envisioned Sertze Islet as becoming the second city hub after the Hsinyi region of eastern Taipei.
Incumbent Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has continued to push for the project, which is now subject to the approval of the Urban Planning Committee of the Ministry of the Interior.
According to the project, Sertze Islet will be built up with soil to augment its height to 8.15 meters. It is expected that 14 million cubic meters of soil will be used over a two-year period.
One of the focuses of the development project will be an outbound traffic network, the most conspicuous of which will be a light rail project connecting it with Shihlin and Beitou.

The project also envisions a freeway connecting it with Kuandu and Luchou and the "blue highway" of the Tamshui River to form a comprehensive traffic network and provide Taipei citizens with a place to gain access to the future leisure and playground area.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX
