A total of US$573 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.604 and fluctuated between NT$31.564 and NT$31.625.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP TO OBSERVE 600TH ANNIVERSARY OF CHENG HO'S NAVAL VOYAGES

TEXT.P: A private Taiwan group is organizing a series of activities to observe the 600th anniversary of the naval expeditions led by Ming dynasty mariner and explorer Cheng Ho (Zheng He).

The Taipei-based Chinese Zheng He Society, founded by Liu Tah-tsai, a retired admiral, with former Education Minister Wu Jin as honorary chairman, will host lectures and international symposiums and other activities to mark Cheng Ho's first naval voyage -- aimed at increasing the prestige of the emperor of the Ming dynasty -- in 1405.

According to Pan Huai-tsung, a Taipei city councilor who is also an expert on Cheng Ho, Wu Jin will give a lecture on "Cheng Ho's international status at the present time" at the Taipei City Council Sunday. There will also be discussions open to the audience on the sidelines of the lecture.
In November, a number of retired officers from the British Royal Navy and internationally renowned scholars and academics will visit Taiwan for a symposium exclusively on Cheng Ho.

Meanwhile, the Chinese Zheng He Society will cooperate with the Taipei City Cultural Affairs Bureau in a series of other related activities between April and November to commemorate the mariner, who is ranked by Life magazine as the 14th most important person of the last millennium, according to Pan.

Pan said that Cheng Ho and his fleet occupies an important page in the world's maritime history. With the approach of the 600th anniversary of Cheng Ho's "Western Ocean" naval expeditions, Cheng Ho mania is sweeping the world once again.

The number of Cheng Ho's voyages vary depending on the source, but he traveled at least seven times to the "Western Ocean" with his fleet between 1405 and 1433. The "Western Ocean" refers to Asian and African places Cheng Ho explored, including Southeast Asia, Sumatra, Java, Ceylon, India, Persia, the Persian Gulf, Arabia, the Red Sea as far north as Egypt, and Africa as far south as the Mozambique Channel.
Cheng Ho's fleet comprised 30,000 men and 70 ships at its height. He brought back to China many trophies and envoys from more than 30 kingdoms.

His missions showed impressive demonstrations of organizational ability and technological knowledge but did not lead to significant trade, since Cheng Ho was an admiral and an official, not a merchant.

One popular belief holds that after Cheng Ho's voyages, China turned away from the sea and underwent a period of technological stagnation. This view of history has been used in modern times to support the notion of investment in space exploration.

Other reasons leading to the suspension of China's naval efforts included increasing pressure from resurgent Mongolian tribes from the north, as well as China's governmental finances becoming increasingly constrained, which melted away funding for the naval expeditions.

A recent controversial theory put forward by historian Gavin Menzies suggests that Cheng Ho circumnavigated the globe and discovered America in the 15th century before Ferdinand Magellan and Christopher Columbus.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BLAMES OPPOSITION FOR LOSING TAIWAN'S GROUND TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the situation in which opposition parties are competing with each other to win Beijing's favor has caused Taiwan to lose ground to China.

According to Hsieh during a legislative interpellation session, in "other countries, " any politicians planning to visit China will first inform their own governments to get an idea of what their governments' bottom lines are, and even retired presidents will exchange views with relevant authorities before visiting China.
But this is not the case in Taiwan, where opposition politicians are scrambling to visit China and vying for high-profile receptions from Beijing, Hsieh said.
This kind of vicious partisan struggle has caused the country to lose ground to China, Hsieh said.

Following opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's visit to China last week, KMT Chairman Lien Chan and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong are both planning to visit China soon.
During the trip, Chiang established a so-called 10-point consensus with the Beijing authorities without the government's authorization, which has enraged the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

Prosecutors have started an investigation into Chiang for alleged treason under the Criminal Code, which the DPP claims prohibits any person from reaching an agreement with a foreign government without government authorization.

As to whether the People's Republic of China government is considered a "foreign government, " Hsieh said the legal interpretation and people's perception of this question "might change" according to the evolution of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
At present, the PRC is not considered a foreign government under the ROC Constitution.
Hsieh said it is not appropriate for him to comment further on the case as it is under investigation by judicial authorities.

Hsieh said the Mainland Affairs Council is investigating whether Chiang's act has violated the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which he claimed requires civic groups to obtain government authorization before negotiating with China on government or political matters.
The premier said the government's cross-strait policy will not revert to the "no haste, be patient" stage but the government will enhance "effective management" while continuing exchanges with China.

He urged all political parties to prioritize Taiwan's interests while participating in exchanges with China and to learn a lesson from history about the Chinese communists' tactic of "allying itself with secondary enemies to attack primary enemies."

He pointed out that the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) used to ally itself with other opposition members to attack the KMT when the KMT was the CCP's primary enemy, but these opposition members later became targets of massive purges during the Cultural Revolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's futures market were higher Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 25 points to close at 6,010, with 13,226 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 29 points to finish at 6,012, with 265 contracts traded. June futures gained 21 points to finish at 5,991, with 14 contracts traded, while September futures gained 32 points to finish at 5,884, with 25 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,985 for April, 5,983 for May, 5,970 for June, 5,852 for September and 5,860 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures moved up 1.7 points to finish at 233.3, with 2,467 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 1.5 points to finish at 233.35, with 54 contracts traded. June TE futures moved up 1.8 points to finish at 232.8, with one contract traded, while September TE futures gained 2.3 points to finish at 230.4, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures moved up 1.4 points to finish at 957.4, with 2,614 contracts traded, while May TF futures gained three points to finish at 959.8, with 122 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 1.2 points to finish at 955.2, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA USING ECONOMIC CLOUT TO ISOLATE TAIWAN IN LATIN AMERICA: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 7 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: China has been expanding its economic and political influences in Latin America, partly to isolate Taiwan, which has 12 diplomatic allies in the region, a U.S. official said Thursday.

China has been translating its economic success -- and its search for resources to fuel its economic development -- into greater influence in Latin America and the Caribbean, according to Assistant Secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs Roger F. Noriega.

The U.S. will continue to closely monitor China's outreach to Latin America to ensure that this activity is compatible with the region's "hard-won progress towards representative democracy, " Noriega testified before the House International Relations Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere.
Noriega said China's interest in Latin America is driven by economic and political factors, including the desire to isolate Taiwan politically.

"Rivalry with Taiwan plays into China's courting of Latin American countries," he said. "A key Chinese political objective is to isolate Taiwan, and China will actively court those 12 countries in this Hemisphere that recognize Taiwan" diplomatically."
He noted that Dominica and Grenada recently broke ties with Taiwan in favor of China, while Jamaica has opened an embassy in Beijing.
"In the cases of Dominica and Grenada, Chinese promises of assistance preceded recognition," Noriega said.
China's rapid economic growth has created a dramatic increase in its demand for many raw materials and foodstuffs, said Noriega.
He noted that China is not only importing more raw materials from the Western Hemisphere but is also making significant investments in the region.

Noriega said that China's investment in the region reached US$6.32 billion by 2004, but the Chinese investment remains "well behind" the total U.S. investment in the region of more than US$300 billion.

The assistant secretary questioned whether Chinese investments truly benefit the region, citing low-interest-rate loans requiring work to be done by Chinese companies and investments that focus heavily on extracting raw materials from countries rather than providing jobs and opportunities for workers.

The U.S. has also noticed an increase in military-to-military contacts between China and several Latin American countries. "While these contacts are minimal, we are watching them closely, and seek to ensure that they do not undermine the commitment of Latin American militaries to democracy and civilian control," he said.

"Our policy is built upon a shared commitment to democracy, free markets and economic integration," he said, stressing the strong and growing partnership between the U.S. and the rest of the Western Hemisphere is "the foundation of the region's security, prosperity, and freedom."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN EMPLOYEES EARN LESS THAN NT$400,000

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan employees earn less than NT$400,000 (US$12,700) per year and 91 percent of them and dissatisfied with their pay, according to the results of a poll made public Friday.

Some 26.7 percent of the respondents said that they earn an annual salary of between NT$390,000 and NT$300,000, while 24.8 percent and 22.1 percent claimed that they receive an annual salary less than NT$200,000 and between NT$200,000 and NT$290,000, respectively, according to the results of the survey carried out by the executive search Website www.1111.com.tw.
Only 1.43 percent of Taiwan employees enjoy an annual salary of more than NT$1 million, making a per-capita salary of NT$342,300 per year, the poll shows.

A cross analysis found that employees aged between 31 and 35 get an annual salary of NT$448,100 on average, while those aged between 30 and 26 receive an average of NT$344,100. The 25-21 age group earn an average annual salary of NT$266,800.
Around 82 percent of office employees said that they are not satisfied with their pay, with only 6.6 percent expressing satisfaction with their earnings.
About 91 percent dream of enjoying an annual salary of over NT$1 million, and those already achieving the goal said that it took them 5.09 years to reach that point.

Some 56 percent of the thirty- and twenty-somethings said that creating their own business is the quickest way to rack up NT$1 million in earnings, while more than 60 percent of the employees questioned contended that they would be more likely to earn an annual salary of over NT$1 million working in the information industry and financial insurance sector, according to the survey.
The Website conducted the public opinion poll on the Internet from March 30 to April 7, recovering 1,326 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 2.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Rover finally stalls.
MG Rover's battle for survival dramatically ended last night when the independent car maker called in the receivers, threatening up to 20,000 jobs in the West Midlands. The announcement was made at a brief but tense press conference by Patricia Hewitt, the Trade and Industry Secretary, and Tony Woodley, leader of the Transport and General Workers Union. Ms Hewitt said that the company's board had decided to call in the receivers, adding:"This is a devastating blow to all those involved -- the workers and their families, the company's suppliers and the wider community. Our thoughts are with them."She added that the Government and trade unions would now work with the administrator to try to secure car manufacturing at the company's Longbridge plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: A String of Auctions Get Canceled.
A string of auctions for oil and gas development licenses have been canceled to prevent foreign companies from bidding, an official in the Natural Resources Ministry said. The cancellations appear to constitute a de facto widening of the ban on bids by non-Russian-controlled companies, contradicting recent assurances from Natural Resources Minister Yury Trutnev and other ministers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Longer cover for HDB defects.
New Housing Board flats will come with longer guarantees against defects - five years for leaking ceilings and water seepage through walls, and 10 years for spalling concrete. Up till now, the flats came with only one-year warranties covering all three defects, which have plagued some HDB flat owners in the past. The Lianhe Zaobao: ASSURE 3 for new Housing Board flats. Housing And Development Board ( HDB) will offers.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Air Security Agency Faces Reduced Role; Stone Is Third Chief to Leave.
The Transportation Security Administration, once the flagship agency in the nation's $20 billion effort to protect air travelers, is now targeted for sharp cuts in its high-profile mission. The latest sign came yesterday when the Bush administration asked David M. Stone, the TSA's director, to step down in June, according to aviation and government sources, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP HAILS PRESIDENT'S ATTENDANCE AT POPE'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday she takes great pleasure in seeing President Chen Shui-bian travel to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral as the Republic of China's head of state.
Lu was responding to a press inquiry about her views on Chen's visit to the Vatican while attending a seminar on new energy resources for the new century.

Noting that the ROC has been a long-time ally of the Vatican, Lu said she regrets that previous ROC heads of state have failed to effectively use this connection to break China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan and upgrade Taiwan's international profile.

"I'm more than happy to see our president manage to attend the pope's funeral in the Vatican with dignity," Lu said, adding that she hopes the government will make even more efforts to expand Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers and international presence.
Lu herself once made a formal visit to the Vatican, during which time she was granted an audience with Pope John Paul II.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FORM ALLIANCE TO PROMOTE CULTURAL BILLS

TEXT.P: More than 20 lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties formed an alliance Friday to promote legislation of new laws and amendments to the existing laws regarding cultural and artistic issues.

Premier Frank Hsieh extended his welcome to the founding of the "Alliance for Promoting Culture-Oriented Legislation" at a ceremony marking the event at the Legislative Yuan. He expressed hope that the group will make efforts to push for the passage of cultural bills at the legislature.
Legislator Justin S. Chou of the opposition Kuomintang and Lin Shu-fen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party serve as conveners of the alliance, which comprises 21 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLLEGE STUDENTS LUKEWARM OVER COUNTRY'S SAFETY

TEXT.P: Two-thirds of northern Taiwan's college students would not want to serve in the military to defend the country even if Taiwan was under attack, according to the results of a university survey released Friday.

While military service is mandatory for all Taiwanese men over the age of 18, a survey conducted by the Chinese Culture University's journalism students concluded that 65 percent of college students in northern Taiwan would be unwilling to enlist in military should the nation come under attack from China, Taiwan's most likely enemy.
Just under a month ago, China passed its Anti-Secession Law, giving it a lawful excuse to engage in military action against Taiwan if Beijing decides that Taiwan is pursuing independence.
Taiwanese government officials expressed concern about the survey results.

Liu Teh-hsun, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan, the nation's highest agency dealing with cross-strait matters, said Taiwanese people should seriously ponder the issue for the sake of the Taiwan's future generations.

Liu said the government is doing everything it can to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait, but he urged the public to make contributions should the nation end up in crisis. He added that he personally would be willing and able to defend the country even though he has long been discharged from the military.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MUST ABIDE BY LAWS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that the Legislative Yuan can revise or amend any laws as long as such moves are constitutional, but his government must abide by and execute the existing laws until such time as any amendments are made.

The premier made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan amid reports that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is mulling whether to amend a cross-Taiwan Strait statute to counter a government investigation into a KMT vice chairman's recent visit to China and to pave the way for a visit of KMT Chairman Lien Chan to China.

The Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court said Thursday it had begun to look into P.K. Chiang's high-profile visit to China between March 28 and April 1 after it received complaints that Chiang's 10-point consensus reached with the Chinese authorities was an act "of concluding an accord with a foreign government without government authorization, " which is high treason under the Criminal Code.

KMT Legislator Lu Hsiu-yen asked the premier if he would like to see the amendment of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, mainly Article 33, which stipulates that Taiwan people, institutions and groups are prohibited from serving as members of any Chinese institution or groups without prior government authorization. They are also barred from forging any alliance with Chinese individuals, institutions or groups.
The premier said that he will respect any legislation, revision and amendment of the laws as long as they are constitutional.

He said that many laws need to be reviewed to give them a clearer definition, saying Taiwan is a country ruled by law and that the government acts according to the law and should not be construed as trying to stifle the opposition parties when it invokes the law.
The premier also said that before Chiang's visit to China, the nation's top mainland China policy charter reminded Chiang that he could be breaking the law by making the visit.

Hsieh said that Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , advised Chiang that Article 5 of the cross-strait statute stipulates that unless there is prior authorization from the MAC, there should not be any kind of consultation and signing of agreements.
For this reason, Chiang's 10-point consensus is controversial, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXCHANGES PLEASANTRIES WITH BUSH IN VATICAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian exchanged pleasantries with U.S. President George W. Bush in the Vatican before attending Pope John Paul II's funeral Friday, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu.

According to Lu, Chen arrived at the St. Peter's Square 20 minutes before the pope's funeral began at 4 p.m. (Taipei time). Chen was seated near the front of an area reserved for heads of state from around the world, Lu said.

"While preparing to enter the St. Peter's Square where the funeral took place, Chen had a brief exchange with Bush and former U. S. President Bill Clinton, " Lu said, adding that the content of their chats was not known.

More than 200 presidents, prime ministers and royals from around the world, along with an estimated 4 million other people attended the pope's funeral. Lu said he was unaware of how the Vatican arranged the seating and the nationalities of the two heads of state seated beside Chen.

Bush and Clinton were seated in the seventh and eighth rows, respectively, Lu said, adding that ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and three other members of the Taiwan delegation headed by Chen were seated further back.
Chen arrived at Da Vinci Airport aboard a China airlines charter plane early Friday, making him the first Republic of China president ever to set foot in Europe.

He received courteous treatment befitting his status as the ROC head of state upon his arrival in Rome. A Vatican protocol official, ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng and ROC Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng boarded the plane to welcome Chen.

Italian media and BBC referred to Chen as "Taiwanese president" in their reports, while the ROC national flag and footage featuring Chen visiting the Vatican Embassy in Taipei to pay his respects to the pope earlier this week was also shown on the big screen in St. Peter's Square.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO FUNNEL NT$3 BILLION ANNUALLY INTO ENERGY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Friday that the government will earmark NT$3 billion (US$94.93 million) per annum for an energy research and development fund as part of its effort to make Taiwan nuclear-free.

Addressing a Taipei symposium on energy for the future, Lu noted that the government finalized the "nuclear-free country action plan" in 2003 and is working toward the goal of applying sustainable energy to the industrial sector and the public.
Lu pointed out that Taiwan is a maritime country that has no oil resources of its own, with 97 percent of its energy imported from other countries.
Fortunately, she went on, there is ample sunshine, sea wind and geothermal resources in Taiwan, which make it a perfect environment for developing non-polluting, sustainable energy.

According to Lu, President Chen Shui-bian promised soon after his first inauguration in 2000 that a solar electric system would be installed in the Presidential Office, a promise that was honored one year later.
Lu said developing the environmental protection industry is one of the main objectives of the government's "challenge 2008" national development project.

Also, the government has worked out a plan to establish an "environmental protection incubation center" that will integrate industrial, government, research and academic resources to enhance the standard of Taiwan's environmental protection industry, Lu said.
Although Taiwan is not a signatory of the Kyoto Protocol aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, the island offers full support for the protocol, Lu said.

She said the Cabinet, in reaction to the implementation of the protocol, has set up a task force to promote the use of recycled energy, enhance the efficiency of energy use and phase out industries with high carbon emissions.
In addition, the government will hold a national energy conference in June to discuss in which direction Taiwan should adjust its energy structure, she said.

Meanwhile, asked by the press to comment on reports that China-based Taiwanese businessmen have been coerced to endorse Beijing's Anti-Secession Law, the vice president said there are many other ideal investment environments in other parts of the world and she urged businessmen to reconsider their investment plans.

She said that while Taiwan has achieved democracy and freedom after decades of hard work, it is regrettable that there is still a group of people so desperate to chase the dollar in China that they are willing to place their human rights in constant jeopardy.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO GIVE LECTURES TO PROMOTE 'GREEN PROCUREMENT'

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will give lectures to procurement staff of various government agencies from April 11 to promote the concept of "green procurement," EPA officials said Friday.

According to the officials, green procurement means buying products bearing the environmental protection logo -- a globe wrapped in a leaf. Information related to green procurement is available on the EPA's Web site at http://www.epa.gov.tw.
While green procurement by government agencies saw a 115 percent growth in 2003, the EPA hopes the policy will be carried out even more thoroughly, they said.
More than 700 people have signed up for the lectures, which will be held in the northern, southern and central parts of the island from April 11, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL TAX INCOME IN MARCH GROWS

TEXT.P: The national coffers took in NT$123.6 billion (US$3.9 billion) in tax revenues in March, an increase of NT$6.2 billion, or 5.3 percent, over the year-earlier level, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Friday.

Income tax revenue grew by NT$24.6 billion last month, posting an annual growth rate of 54.5 percent, Hsu Kuo-chung, director-general of the MOF's department of statistics said. He contributed the rise to some companies' presenting year-end bonuses and increasing the wages of their employees.

Meanwhile, the securities-exchange transaction tax turnover in March was NT$6.5 billion, down 50.9 percent over the level of a year ago. The decrease was the result of the fact that the 2004 level was the highest since May 2000, Hsu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES DIFFICULT TO BE HANDLED UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Disputes between Taiwan and mainland China are difficult to deal with under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), government officials said Friday.

Responding to suggestions that the government use the WTO framework to protect Taiwan businessmen's interests in China, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) acknowledged that it is very difficult to use WTO rules to arbitrate issues across the strait that are not economy-related due to the special relationship between the two sides.

They were referring to a recent news report by a radio broadcast network based in Beijing that some Taiwan businessmen's associations based in Fujian Province have issued a joint statement calling for support for Beijing's Anti-Secession Law aimed at Taiwan.
According to the MOEA officials, the news is not an economic matter and is therefore out of the WTO's mandate.

The Council of Mainland Affairs has blasted Beijing for forcing Taiwan businessmen to take side and voice support for its Anti-Secession Law that justifies "non-peaceful means" to counter Taiwan independence.
Meanwhile, Taiwan officials stationed at the WTO said that they are closely monitoring the approaches being adopted by Beijing toward Taiwan businessmen in China.

If hard evidence regarding Chinese violations of the WTO's multilateral trade regulations are found, they will immediately make moves under the WTO framework to seek justice for Taiwan businessmen, the officials said.

They also warned of a "China fever" in view of the various overtures offered by Beijing to Taiwan's farmers, and urged farmers to stay cool and not to harbor "wishful thinking" until such time as Beijing actually implements concrete measures.

Their call came at a time when various political parties in Taiwan are planning to send delegation to China for talks mainly on agricultural exchanges after a mission of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), led by Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, paid a visit to China in late March and reached a 10-point consensus with Chinese Communist Party (CCP) officials.

The 10-point consensus touches on a wide range of issues, such as agriculture, air links, labor affairs, financial cooperation and the protection of Taiwan investors. CCP officials promised to draft preferential policies for agricultural imports from Taiwan and voiced welcome to Taiwan farmers to settle in five provinces.
Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao said on March 14 following Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law that China is willing to open its markets to Taiwan farm produce.

Meanwhile, a legislative mission of the opposition People First Party (PFP) is slated to depart for China next week to hold talks on Taiwan's farm exports. PFP lawmakers have pledged to abide by law of the Republic of China and said that they will not do anything that hurts Taiwan's national interests during its China visit.
A KMT delegation is also expected to travel to China later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: A Huge Throng Gives Waves of Applause to a Beloved Pope.
Applause rang out from a huge crowd this morning at the end of the funeral of John Paul II, the little-known Polish cardinal chosen as pope in 1978. After a Mass that lasted about two-and-a-half hours, his plain cypress coffin marked with a cross and an "M" for the Virgin Mary was brought out from St. Peter's Basilica and placed before an altar in St. Peter's Square. The bells of St. Peter's tolled and 12 pallbearers with white gloves, white ties and tails then carried the coffin on their shoulders back inside for burial, after holding the coffin to face the multitude for a prolonged moment, as the great bell of St. Peter's pealed, and waves of applause swept through the audience.
Wall Street Journal: World Mourns John Paul II At Pope's Funeral in Rome.
Presidents, prime ministers and kings joined pilg rims and prelates in St. Peter's Square on Friday to bid farewell to Pope John Paul II at a funeral service that drew millions to Rome for one of the largest religious gatherings of modern times. At least four million of the faithful filled Vatican City and Rome, and millions more around the world watched broadcasts of the s ervice held in the open at St. Peter's Square.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P: CEP Item 0034 contains some mistakes: The headline should read "PRESIDENT EXCHANGES PLEASANTRIES WITH EX-U.S. PRESIDENTS IN VATICAN" and the second line of the first paragraph "U.S. President George W. Bush" should be changed to "former U.S. Presidents George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton."
A corrected version follows:
PRESIDENT EXCHANGES PLEASANTRIES WITH EX-U.S. PRESIDENTS IN VATICAN

Taipei, April 8 (CNA) ROC President Chen Shui-bian exchanged pleasantries with former U.S. Presidents George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton in the Vatican before attending Pope John Paul II's funeral Friday, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu.

Lu said Chen arrived at the St. Peter's Square 20 minutes before the pope's funeral began at 4 p.m. (Taipei time) . Chen was seated near the front of an area reserved for heads of state from around the world, Lu said.
"While preparing to enter the St. Peter's Square where the funeral took place, Chen had a brief exchange with Bush and Clinton," Lu said, adding that the content of their chats was not known.

More than 200 presidents, prime ministers and royals from around the world, along with an estimated 4 million other people attended the pope's funeral. Lu said he was unaware of how the Vatican arranged the seating and the nationalities of the two heads of state seated beside Chen.

Bush and Clinton were seated in the seventh and eighth rows, respectively, Lu said, adding that ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and three other members of the Taiwan delegation headed by Chen were seated further back.
Chen arrived at Da Vinci Airport aboard a China airlines charter plane early Friday, making him the first Republic of China president ever to set foot in Europe.

He received courteous treatment befitting his status as the ROC head of state upon his arrival in Rome. A Vatican protocol official, ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng and ROC Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng boarded the plane to welcome Chen.

Italian media and BBC referred to Chen as "Taiwanese president" in their reports, while the ROC national flag and footage featuring Chen visiting the Vatican Embassy in Taipei to pay his respects to the pope earlier this week was also shown on the big screen in St. Peter's Square.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW AFFECTS E.U. LIFTING OF CHINA ARMS BAN: MAC

TEXT.P: China's enactment of a law authorizing the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan has derailed progress in the European Union's plan to lift its arms embargo against China, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu was responding to a German media report that quoted senior German officials as saying that the E.U. is unlikely to lift its 16-year-old ban on arms sales to China this year.

According to the report, lifting the arms embargo against China requires the unanimous consent of all 25 E.U. member states. Except for Germany and France, all other E.U. members are skeptical about the aptness of ending the arms ban now.

Because of strong opposition from the United States, the report said, Great Britain, a U.S. ally who will be the E.U.'s presiding country for the second half of 2005, is not expected to handle the arms ban issue. Against this backdrop, the report said, the E.U. will be unable to lift its arms ban against China until 2006.
Asked about his view on the report, Wu said Taiwan, the United States and Japan have all voiced explicit opposition to the E.U.'s plan to end its arms ban against China.
Noting that many E.U. defense technologies have been provided by the United States, Wu said the E.U. cannot ignore the possibility of Washington retaliating against its move.

In addition, Wu said he is convinced that China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan has also discouraged the E.U. from lifting its arms ban because the legislation is widely believed to have had an adverse impact on Asia-Pacific peace and stability.
Commenting on the German media report, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said the ministry would welcome any E.U. decision to maintain its arms ban against China.
Should the report is correct, Lu said, it indicates that the E.U. has paid heed to the grave impact of China's new legislation on Asia-Pacific peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TRIED TO STOP ANTI-SECESSION LAW: U.S. OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The United States tried hard to stop China from adopting its Anti-Secession Law, but failed; therefore, all the United States can do now is urge both sides of the Taiwan Strait to seek all opportunities for dialogue, a ranking U.S. official said Wednesday in Washington.
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Randall G. Schriver made the remarks in a report to the House International Relations Committee.

The report, released Thursday, addressed the recent passage of the Anti-Secession Law by the National People's Congress (NPC) of the People's Republic of China and its impact on cross-strait and U.S.-China relations.

It said that since Dec. 17 last year, when the Chinese began publicly discussing the likelihood that the legislation would be brought to the NPC for consideration, the U.S. has been very clear, "including at the highest levels of the [Bush] administration -- Secretary Rice and former Secretary Powell -- that we believed such legislation would be unhelpful, and a step in the wrong direction.

"Instead, we have counseled taking advantage of warming trends in the cross-strait relationship to further peaceful dialogue that would be in the interests of the people on both sides of the Strait, " Schriver said. U.S. efforts to make this position known to the Chinese, he said, included:

-- In January, former U.S. Deputy Secretary Richard Armitage and then-Deputy National Security Advisor Stephen Hadley met with the director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, Chen Yunlin, who was in Washington to convey China's intentions with regard to the legislation, and expressed the reservations of the U.S.

-- In a February visit to Beijing, National Security Council Senior Director for Asian Affairs Michael Green told senior Chinese leaders that passage of the legislation would undermine cross-strait stability.

-- In a letter to former Chinese Ambassador Yang Jiechi, former Under Secretary for Political Affairs Marc Grossman urged China not to complicate the cross-strait relationship and, rather than proceed with the law, to consider instead ways to resume dialogue with Taiwan.
-- On the eve of the ratification vote by the NPC, the charge d'affaires at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing urged China not to pass the legislation.
-- In their public statements as well, U.S. officials have cautioned against any hardening of positions and urged instead that the two sides look to resume their dialogue.

While Beijing's leaders claim the law simply restates China's long-standing policy, Schriver said the U.S. was "deeply concerned about Article 8 of the legislation, " which states: "If the Taiwan independence secessionist forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China, or that major incidents entailing Taiwan's secession from China should occur, or that possibilities for a peaceful reunification should be exhausted, the state shall employ non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to protect China's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The State Council and the Central Military Commission shall decide on and execute the non-peaceful means and other necessary measures and report to the National People's Congress Standing Committee."

This statement, now codified in law, about a non-peaceful response raises additional questions regarding how China will respond to what it perceives as ongoing efforts in Taiwan to define itself as a separate identity, including steps that fall short of declaring de jure independence, Schriver pointed out.
Given the aggressive military build-up opposite Taiwan -- particularly the deployment of a large number of short-range ballistic missiles -- he said the U.S. has cause for strong concern.

He said passage of the legislation clearly runs counter to current positive trends in cross-strait relations, including the temporary implementation of direct charter passenger flights for the first time since 1949 between Taiwan and China, and the Chinese delegation that traveled to Taiwan for the funeral of former Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
Therefore, he said, upon passage of the legislation and on "our finally having an opportunity to review the actual text passed by the NPC, we were unequivocal in our expression of concern."

In the view of the U.S., the Chinese government clearly had options other than moving this legislation to the NPC for consideration. "But it would seem that a combination of domestic political factors, an approval process too far advanced to allow the leadership to pull it back, and an urgency about the direction a democratic Taiwan would take in the next few years led to the law's passage," he analyzed.

"That's the situation we have to deal with now, despite the very best efforts of the administration and the concerns that have been expressed by members of Congress in resolutions and by the American press," he said.
He concluded that passage of the legislation has undermined, rather than raised, confidence and trust across the strait. "We continue to be concerned about an unhelpful cycle of action and reaction."

The Taiwan public and its authorities have understandably focused on the legislation's provisions for the use of non-peaceful means. Statements by leaders in Taiwan equating the legislation to a unilateral change of the status quo and the March 26 demonstration in Taipei reflect the perception that the law does not serve the interests of the Taiwan people.

Although passage of the Anti-Secession Law has brought a new challenge to U.S. efforts to promote a peaceful resolution to cross-strait differences, he said, "We do not believe it requires a shift in our approach to the issue.

"We remain committed to our longstanding 'one-China' policy, which has helped both sides to prosper and contributes to peace. We are making clear that we do not support Taiwan independence, oppose unilateral changes by either side to the status quo -- particularly with respect to the use of force -- and abide by our commitments under the joint communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act," he said.

Schriver urged both sides to seek all opportunities for dialogue that contribute to a peaceful resolution of cross-strait differences. "We will also continue to make explicit our fundamental opposition to China's acquisition of military capabilities and deployments targeted against Taiwan," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKER ON LOW-PROFILE VISIT TO CHINA FOR AGRICULTURE TALKS

TEXT.P: Legislator Tsay Sheng-jia of the opposition People First Party left Taiwan Friday for a low-profile visit to China where he hopes to open up a new market for Taiwan's agricultural products.

Asked at the airport which cities he will be visiting, Tsay replied that he was going to Hong Kong, but then added he has been invited by China to give a speech on agriculture. His cautiousness reflects an on-going controversy over who should represent Taiwan in talks with China.

He said since Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, the country's farmers have been hard hit by increased imports of foreign agricultural products, yet the government is only concerned that they will be "bought off" if their produce is exported to China.
"It's a sad day when even trade in agricultural products has to be politicized," a disillusioned Tsay said.

He said Taiwan's tea, fruits and other farm products are quite competitive, as they are selling well in Japan, Hong Kong, Canada and other countries. "I don't understand what's wrong with adding China as a market for our farm products," Tsay said.
Tsay said that while in China, he will only speak on Taiwan's agriculture and will not go to Beijing. "Please don't dub me a pro-this or that," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CAUTIOUS OF BEIJING'S ISOLATION PLAN: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will exercise caution over Beijing's recent move to isolate Taiwan carried out in Latin America, an official said Friday.

Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said during an interview that the ROC will keep a close eye on China's recent attempts to isolate the island by trying to lure away its handful of diplomatic allies in Central and South America.

His remarks came following a statement made earlier by United States Assistant Secretary of State for Western Hemisphere Affairs Roger F. Noriega, who noted that China is attempting to extend its diplomatic reach into Latin America by providing countries there with economic, political and military incentives, hoping they will eventually cut diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Beijing's isolation plan has succeeded with several of Taiwan's 12 diplomatic allies in the area, including Dominica and Grenada, which recently severed diplomatic relations with the ROC.
China has been investing heavily in these countries with an estimated US$6.32 billion as of the end of 2004.
Lu said that ROC will try to maintain sound relations with its diplomatic allies by inviting their officials to the island to further discuss economic cooperation plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, April 9:

09: 10, The Institute of International Relations under the National Chengchi University will hold a roundtable meeting on the proposed U.S. arms purchase and national defense at the Howard International House.
10: 30, DuPont Taiwan will issue a survey report on Taiwan people's safety index at the Westin Taipei.
13: 00, The first International PAH Annual Symposium in Taiwan will open at the Agora Garden Taipei.
14: 00, The Association of Taiwan Journalists will hold its 2005 annual congress at the NGO Hall in Taipei.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will return home from his trip to the Vatican via the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
15:30, A meeting of Cabinet members will be held at the Yunhsien Resort Center in Wulai, Taipei County.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD HEALTH DAY 'HANDICAPPED' WITHOUT TAIWAN IN WHA: HEALTH MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 7 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-hsiao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: World Health Day is "handicapped" because of Taiwan's exclusion from the World Health Organization, ROC Health Minister Hou Sheng-mao said in Belgium Thursday.

In a news conference timed to coincide with World Health Day on April 7, Taiwan's health chief said diseases know no political boundaries, and pointed to the fact that every year 1.5 million flights are made to and from Asia, showing that the world is inexorably linked to the region, including Taiwan.
However, Hou said, Taiwan's exclusion from the WHO for political reasons has created a big loophole in this global network and poses a threat to the health of everyone.

Although China claims that Taiwan is a part of its territory, Taiwan is not included in China's health care system and China did not aid Taiwan in 2003 when severe acute respiratory syndrome broke out on the island, Hou said.

Huang Li-teh, a Taiwanese doctor who practices in Switzerland, told the news conference that Taiwan's absence from the WHO makes it impossible for foreign travelers to learn from the WHO Web site what health risks they may encounter, if any, during a trip to Taiwan.
Also, Huang said, foreign medical workers cannot share their Taiwan counterparts' experiences through the WHO Web site.

She disputed the argument that Taiwan is not allowed to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer because it is not a United Nations member, saying that Switzerland had long been a WHA observer before it joined the U.N. in 2002.
Taiwan has tried to join the WHA as an observer since 1997 but has not succeeded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SOURCE TEACHERS FROM INDIANA TO TEACH IN ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 7 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Education (MOE) is working to recruit elementary school teachers in Indiana to help Taiwan's primary schools run English-language courses.

MOE Bureau of International Cultural and Educational Relations Director Chang Chin-cheng, who is now on a visit to the state, is scheduled to sign a memorandum of agreement on the recruitment drive Friday with the supervisor of the Indiana Department of Education, an official of the Cultural Division Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Chicago said Tuesday.
This will be the first U.S. state forging this kind of cooperation with the MOE to help Taiwan's English-language education.

The ministry plans to open English-language courses for students at the third, fourth, fifth and sixth grades in all public elementary schools around Taiwan in the 2005 fall semester as part of the country's globalization efforts, the official said, adding that since last September, his division has been trying to seek qualified English teachers in the U.S.
Under the planned agreement, he said, the Indiana Department of Education will help select well-trained English teachers in the state to teach in Taiwan.

A university graduate, whose mother tongue is English and is certified by the Indiana State Government to teach in elementary schools, is qualified to apply for the position. In the first year of the recruitment program, the MOE wishes to hire 15 English teachers from the U.S., according to the division.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP ANNETTE LU HAILS CHEN'S PRESENCE AT POPE'S FUNERAL A GODSEND

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu hailed as a godsend President Chen Shui-bian's attendance at Pope John Paul II's funeral in the Vatican Friday.
Addressing the opening ceremony of an activity promoting Taipei County's tourism and cultural development, Lu said the death of the pope was sorrowful.
"But God has brought dignity to the people of Taiwan through the pope. For decades, it was the first time that our president could visit Rome in his capacity as our head of state," Lu said.

Commenting on China's refusal to send any envoy to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral in protest of the Vatican's invitation of Chen, Lu said she doesn't think that China is qualified to attend the occasion.

"The pope had preached love and religious freedom throughout his life. China doesn't allow religious freedom and has a poor human rights record. It has even enacted a law codifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan," Lu said.
Chen arrived at Da Vinci Airport aboard a China Airlines charter plane early Friday, making him the first Republic of China president ever to set foot in Europe.

He received courteous treatment befitting his status as the ROC head of state upon his arrival in Rome. A Vatican protocol official, ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng and ROC Representative to Italy Lin Ki-tseng boarded the plane to welcome Chen.

Italian media and BBC referred to Chen as the "Taiwanese president" in their reports, while the ROC national flag and footage featuring Chen visiting the Vatican Embassy in Taipei to pay his respects to the pope earlier this week was also shown on the big screen in St. Peter's Square.
After attending the pope's funeral, Chen is scheduled to make an inspection tour of the ROC Embassy in the Vatican to boost the morale of all embassy staff.
Chen and his entourage, including Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, are scheduled to return to Taipei Saturday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA BACKPEDALS ON STATEMENT THAT TOXIN ALGAE WAS FOUND IN RESERVOIRS

TEXT.P: Apparently contradicting its own statement three days earlier that said that 14 of the islands reservoirs were found to have potentially harmful algae, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Friday said that no toxic algae has been found in any of the island's reservoirs.

The new statement said none of the samples taken from the 37 reservoirs around the island tested positively for the algae. The algae in question can produce the peptide toxin microcystin, which is harmful to people when ingested in concentration.
In the EPA report three days ago, officials said that the algae is only toxic after it dies and the amount of blue-green algae observed in the water so far has been minimal.
They went on to say then that September would be a critical month since the propagation of the algae will reach its zenith in summer and then begin to die.
It is unclear if the new EPA statement Friday was referring to whether no living algae was observed in any reservoir or if no dead algae has yet to be detected.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN AT POPE'S FUNERAL RAISES TAIWAN'S PROFILE: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers across the political spectrum took pride in the high-profile treatment President Chen Shui-bian received in Rome at the funeral of Pope John Paul II Friday.

Lawmaker Chen Chin-jun, who is the secretary for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said he was moved to learn from reports that Chen sat in the first row with other state leaders and that the entire world was watching.

Noting that the trip was hastily-arranged, Chen Chin-jun said that it will be a demanding for the president to fly to and from Rome over only two or three days, adding that "the president has brought the country to the front row of the world; we really appreciate what he has done for the country."

Taiwan Solidarity Union Legislator Lo Chih-ming, who is the party's convener at the Legislative Yuan, said the high-profile treatment President Chen received from the Holy See is evidence of the firm ties between Taiwan and the Holy See.
Lo said the publicity the president has received by his attendance at the pope's funeral has significantly enhanced the country's international profile.
Thanks partly goes to the first lady who visited the Vatican in 2003 to mark the pope's 25th year in office, further cementing the country's ties with the Holy See, Lo said.

An extra feather in Taiwan's cap was Beijing's refusal to send a delegation to the funeral upon learning that President Chen would be in attendance. The ROC rarely wins a political tug of war with China on the international stage, according to Lo.

Lawmaker Chen Chih-pin, the People First Party's convener at the Legislative Yuan, concurred, saying that the Vatican's decision to let President Chen attend the pope's funeral is a sign of the firm relations between the two sides, and the president's trip to Rome has successfully projected the country's image as a peace-loving state onto the international stage.

Kuomintang lawmaker Su Chi said the president's attendance at the funeral was a good thing, but warned against reading too much political significance into it. The trip, he said, is for the president to pay his last respects to the pope, which is a religious event.

The trip is hardly an indication of future ROC-Vatican ties, Su said. That will depend on who will succeed Pope John Paul II and how China will respond to the Vatican's offer to establish diplomatic relations with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE URGED TO SUPPORT 10 NEW MAJOR CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) urged the Legislative Yuan Friday to approve as soon as possible a special budget of NT$137.7 billion (US$43.7 billion) for the 10 new major construction projects for this year.
The implementation of the budget, should it be approved, will make a contribution of 0.87 percentage points to the country's annual economic growth rate, CEPD officials said.
According to an estimate by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Taiwan will enjoy an economic growth of 4.21 percent this year, the officials noted.

Premier Frank Hsieh has, however, set a target of 4.5 percent growth for this year although the country's economy is facing various potential negative factors internationally, including rises in oil prices, an expansion of the U.S. trade deficit and the depreciation of the U.S. dollar. China's efforts to cool down its overheated economy and the recent enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, are another concern they said.

The government has been trying to do more to secure the target set by the premier, including easing restrictions and amending outdated laws while expanding domestic demands by making more public investments.
Also, they added, the government needs the cooperation of the legislature in this regard.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH INSTITUTE INTERESTED IN SETTING UP RESEARCH CENTER IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 7 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Institute Pasteur of France has expressed an interest in setting up a research center in Taiwan and will send representatives to visit Taiwan in two weeks, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Hou Sheng-mou said in the Belgian capital on Thursday.
Hou, who is currently on a visit to Europe, said both sides will work together to develop a dengue fever vaccine.
According to Hou, the institute is a leading organization in the research of infectious diseases, with overseas research centers in Asian countries including South Korea, Vietnam and China.
The institute is interested in expanding its overseas bases and is considering Taiwan as a possible choice, Hou said.
He said the government will conduct further discussions with the institute on this possibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES LENIENCY AND RECONCILIATION AMONG POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, who is in the Vatican for the funeral of Pope John Paul II, called for leniency and reconciliation Friday among political parties at home and between the two sides of Taiwan Straits.

At a dinner hosted by Chen for pro-Taiwan Italian politicians and Taiwan officials posted in Rome, the president said only leniency and reconciliation will pave the way for harmony among different political parties and ethnic groups, and is the cornerstone for peace with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES KMT CHIEF TO ATTEND SUMMIT CALLED BY PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu urged opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan Friday to respond positively to President Chen Shui-bian's call for a summit of political party leaders to work out a consensus on approaches toward dealings with China.

Regarding Lien's planned trip to China, Wu said if political party leaders visit China strictly as private citizens, the MAC won't prohibit them from doing so, even though the MAC feels that now is not the right time to go.

However, Wu quoted newspapers as saying that Lien is expected to sign a peace agreement with China which would be controversial regarding the legality of the pact because Lien does not have the government's authorization.
He urged Lien to meet the president at the summit and work out a common tactics to use when in China.
Wu said if the outcome of Lien's actions do not contradict government policy, the MAC will not take action.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 9, or the first day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
2001: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passes away at the age of 95 at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT AND HONDURAN COUNTERPART MEET AT ROME AIRPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 8 (CNA) (By Tong Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian had a diplomatic rendezvous with his Honduran counterpart, Ricardo Maduro, at Da Vinci Airport in Rome Friday after both of them attended Pope John Paul II's funeral earlier in the day.

Chen held a closed-door meeting with Maduro at a VIP room before they boarded a China Airlines (CAL) charter plane bound for Taiwan. It marked the first time that a CAL charter plane has ever carried two heads of state at the same time.
Maduro, who has been to Taiwan several times, is scheduled to travel from Taiwan to the Japanese island of Okinawa to attend an annual conference of the American Development Bank.

Chen arrived in Rome early Friday to attend the pope's funeral, making him the first incumbent ROC president ever to visit the Vatican since the two countries established formal diplomatic ties in 1942. Chen is also the first serving ROC president ever to set foot in Europe. The Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

Chen joined with 200-plus presidents, prime ministers and royals as well as hundreds of thousands of citizens from around the world to attend the pope's funeral at St. Peter's Square, which started at 10 a.m. Friday.

After the funeral, Chen paid a visit to the ROC Embassy in the Vatican, which is an estate of the Holy See. In addition to looking at the embassy facilities, he gave a brief pep talk to boost the morale of all embassy staff.

Chen then dined with members of a pro-Taiwan group in the Italian parliament, the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, influential Italian politicians, as well as staff members of the ROC Embassy in the Vatican and the ROC Representative Office in Italy.
Addressing the occasion, Chen called for leniency and reconciliation among political parties at home and between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
"Only leniency and reconciliation will pave the way for harmony among the different political parties and ethnic groups, and is the cornerstone for peace with China," Chen said.

Members of Chen's entourage included Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and three religious leaders. After the 19-hour historic visit to the Vatican, Chen and his entourage left Rome for home at 8: 25 p.m. Friday. They are scheduled to land at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 3 p.m. Saturday (Taipei time.)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTORS WIN 23 MEDALS AT INTERNATIONAL INVENTION EXHIBITION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 8 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese inventors taking part in the 33rd International Exhibition of Inventions, New Techniques and Products of Geneva were awarded a total of 23 medals for their entries.

The Taiwanese inventors received a total of 13 gold, seven silver and three bronze medals at the exhibition's award ceremony held Friday night. The five-day exhibition opened April 6 at the Palexpo in the Swiss city.
The brilliant result was all the more outstanding given that all the Taiwanese inventors' entries were the result of their own research without any assistance or subsidies from the government.
A total of 735 inventions from 42 countries are on display at the exhibition, which is considered to be the most important of its kind in the world.
National Lien-Ho University of Taiwan also received a "special contribution" prize from the organizer of the exhibition.
Chen Chung-tai, president of the Taiwan Inventors Association, who is heading a Taiwan delegation to participate in the event, said the result achieved by the Taiwanese inventions was not a surprise.

During the award presentation ceremony, Chen handed out two prizes on behalf of the Taipei mayor for excellent inventions from other countries. The ceremony was presided over by Jean-Luc Vincent, president of the organizing committee of the exhibition.

The exhibition provides participating inventors with huge business opportunities as many of the visitors to the exhibition are professionals who want to do business, buy licenses or find new products.
According to the organizer. the business volume generated during or after last year's exhibition totalled over US$30 million.

Moving to address one its worst drug safty debacles, the Food and Drug Administration announced that dozens of widely used prescription painkillers must carry the government's strongest warning that they posed risk of heart attack and stroke.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Time: Pope is buried
Presidents, prime ministers and rulers from around the world joined hundreds of thousands of pilgrims, prelates and religious leaders Friday in paying a final farewell to Pope John Paul II at a funeral capping the largest religious gathering of the powerful and humble in modern times.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: John Paul laid to rest
VATICAN CITY -- Presidents, prime ministers and kings from around the world joined hundreds of thousands of pilgrims, prelates and religious leaders in paying a final farewell yesterday to Pope John Paul II in one of the largest religious gatherings in the West in modern times.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Filipinos bid John Paul II triumphant farewell
THE CATHOLIC Church's biggest flock in this part of the world yesterday bade Pope John Paul II a "triumphant" farewell as presidents, pilgrims and princes of the Church buried the well-loved Pontiff in the Vatican.
The Philippine Star: GMA: Pope gave moral impetus to EDSA II
President Arroyo paid tribute to Pope John Paul II for providing the moral impetus for the bloodless people power revolt that toppled the administration of her predecessor Joseph Estrada in January 2001.
