DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : The last goodbye.
The poor and the powerful rubbed shoulders to say their last goodbye to Pope John Paul II yesterday as the Vatican staged one of the most momentous funerals in history for the Polish Pontiff.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore contractors win overseas deals worth S$2.5b in 2004: BCA
Singapore contractors won S$2.5 billion worth of overseas contracts last year, the highest record in the past
This figure from the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) is more than double the deals clinched in 2003, and to overcome the golden age before the Asia financial crisis in 1997.
The exceptional performance was driven by strong exports to India, China and the Middle East, said BCA.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER URGES QUICK PASSAGE OF ARMS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien on Saturday urged the Legislative Yuan to pass the bill for a major arms procurement plan quickly.

Tsai said legislators from across the party spectrum should put aside their differences and make the nation's interests a top priority and pass the major arms procurement package for six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries, eight diesel-electric submarines and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States under a special budget.
He made the remarks while attending a seminar during which he cited a poll conducted by the Chinese Culture University to back up his appeal.

The poll found that 65 percent of northern Taiwan college students are unwilling to be enlisted into the military should the nation come under attack from China. Among these respondents, 30.5 percent said that Taiwan couldn't withstand an attack by China, while 25.6 percent said that they would only be cannon fodder if they fought.

Tsai interpreted that two-thirds of the students wouldn't want to fight because they think that Taiwan doesn't have the capability to withstand a Chinese military attack and that resistance would be useless.
To root out such defeatism, Tsai said, Taiwan's military must build up its combat capability to meet the threat from China.

He expressed the hope that legislators could have a rational discussion so as to put the statute for the major arms procurement and its special budget up for review and that the proposal could clear the Legislative Yuan quickly.
If the major arms procurement package can't be passed, then Taiwan will be unable to show to the United States and the international community that it is determined to defend itself, Tsai said.
China would be more than happy to see the arms procurement proposal fail, he added.
However, National Taiwan University professor Chang Ya-chung, speaking on the same occasion, didn't see eye to eye with Tsai on the issue.

Chang said that cross-strait issues are political in nature, and that if political figures can't resolve the problems and only ask young people to go to war, it is only natural that the young people are unwilling to serve in the military.

The legislature has failed to put the statute on the major arms procurement on the Legislative agenda for review since the start of its first session in February because the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party -- which together command a slight majority in the legislature -- do not agree with the government's decision to finance the package in a special budget, which is exempt from the legal cap on government spending.

The statute has been blocked twice since the Cabinet lowered the ceiling price for the procurement package from the original NT$610.8 billion when it was first proposed in mid-2004 to $480 billion (US$15.38 billion) this year because a plan to make the submarines in Taiwan was dropped and because the new Taiwan dollar had appreciated against the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DENIES PARTY CHAIRMAN TO VISIT CHINA MAY 10

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) on Saturday denied that KMT Chairman Lien Chan will visit mainland China on May 10.

The KMT Culture and Information Committee said that the report that Lien will lead three party vice chairmen to visit China and that KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-Chen will visit China soon to arrange for their trip was "unfounded."
Lien's trip to mainland China is still being planned, the committee said.
KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang visited China March 28-April 1, during which Beijing invited Lien to visit and the latter gladly accepted.

Chiang, however, is currently under investigation to see if he violated the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area for reaching a 10-point consensus with Beijing authorities during his visit.

The consensus covered a wide range of issues, including cross-strait transportation, agriculture, the rights of mainland fishermen working in Taiwan fishing ships, protection of mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople, and the further opening of China's financial market.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO THOROUGHLY FULFILL TRA OBLIGATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) is very important, expressing the hope that the United States can thoroughly fulfill its obligations under the act.

A report appeared Friday in the Japanese daily Sankei Shimbun saying that U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Randall Shriver had told a visiting group of Taiwanese legislators in Washington, D.C., Monday that the United States would deal with contingencies in the Taiwan Strait in compliance with the TRA.
The newspaper also reported that the U.S. official proposed U.S.-Japan cooperation to deal with any contingencies in the strait.

In response to media questions raised about the report, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said that Taiwan insists that the cross-strait issue should be resolved peacefully and that it will also make necessary contributions to maintaining peace and stability in the strait.
Taiwan also hopes that neighboring countries can jointly work on regional security, he added.

Nevertheless, the U.S. State Department clarified the report the same day, saying that "U.S. policy has not changed" and "in the case of a Taiwan Strait crisis, the United states would respond in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HOPES VALUES OF LATE POPE WILL INFLUENCE CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: A leading ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Saturday expressed the hope that the values of peace and democracy embraced by the late Pope John Paul II will have apositive influence on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Lai Ching-teh, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said President Chen Shui-bian's attendance at the pope's funeral on behalf of the 23 million people of Taiwan has played up the island's status as an independent, sovereign state.

Lai pointed out that in addition to committing himself to reforming the Catholic Church, the pope also renounced non-peaceful means and spoke out against war on many occasions, including condemning the United States for sending troops to Panama, Grenada and Iraq.
He said Catholicism can be a reference for domestic politics and cross-strait relations and that it is regrettable that China did not send any representative to attend the pope's funeral.
Lai said he hopes China will learn from the pope's love of democracy and peace, which the legislator said are values that can have a positive influence on cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TO CUT CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS BY 500,000 TONS IN FOUR YEARS

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will cut its carbon dioxide emissions by 500,000 tons in four years in reaction to the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol aiming at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, CPC officials said Saturday.

Under the guidance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau, the CPC -- the largest oil supplier in Taiwan and the only one supplying natural gas -- started to survey its greenhouse gas emissions in 2002 and completed a survey report last month.

According to the CPC, the carbon dioxide released by coal is four times that of natural gas in producing one unit of energy, while the carbon dioxide produced by fuel oil is 1.4 times that of natural gas.
With natural gas releasing significantly less carbon dioxide, it is now used in the CPC's refineries in Kaohsiung, Talin and Linyuan, the officials said.
They said the greenhouse gas survey has helped the CPC determine direct and indirect sources of emissions and establish an open and transparent record of greenhouse gases produced by the CPC.
The list will be posted on a Web site in the future, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHOTO OF ROC PRESIDENT IN VATICAN PUBLISHED BY NEW YORK TIMES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 8 (CNA) (By Lillian Liu and Wayne Lee)

TEXT.P: The New York Times on Friday printed a photo showing Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian with senior officials from other countries attending the funeral of the late John Paul II in the Vatican.
Chen's trip to the Vatican was unprecedented as he became the first serving ROC president ever to visit Europe.

The newspaper reported that official delegations from over 100 countries around the world attended the pope's funeral. Among those attending were U.S. President George W. Bush, French President Jacques Chirac and Syrian President Bashar al-Asad.
The Vatican is the only European country with which the ROC maintains formal diplomatic ties.
The New York Times said China did not send a delegation because of the Vatican's ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RETURNS HOME AFTER ATTENDING POPE'S FUNERAL IN VATICAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian returned to Taipei Saturday after concluding his 48-hour "journey of peace and commemoration" that took him to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral.

In addition to joining presidents, prime ministers, royals and pilgrims from around the world in bidding farewell to the pope, Chen also became the first sitting Republic of China president ever to set foot in Europe.

After his history-making visit, Chen had a diplomatic rendezvous with his Honduran counterpart, Ricardo Maduro, at Da Vinci Airport in Rome. Maduro had also traveled from his country to the Vatican to attend the pope funeral.

Chen held a closed-door meeting with Maduro at a VIP room before they boarded a China Airlines (CAL) charter plane bound for Taiwan. It marked the first time that a CAL charter plane has ever carried two heads of state at the same time.

Maduro, who has been to Taiwan several times, will travel from Taiwan to the Japanese island of Okinawa to attend an annual conference of the Central American Bank for Economic Integration later in the day.

Chen arrived in Rome early Friday to attend the pope's funeral, making him the first incumbent ROC president ever to visit the Vatican since the two countries established formal diplomatic ties in 1942. Chen is also the first serving ROC president ever to set foot in Europe. The Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

After the funeral, Chen paid a visit to the ROC Embassy in the Vatican, which is an estate of the Holy See. In addition to looking at the embassy facilities, he gave a brief pep talk to boost the morale of all embassy staff.

Chen then dined with members of a pro-Taiwan group in the Italian parliament, the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, influential Italian politicians, as well as staff members of the ROC Embassy in the Vatican and the ROC Representative Office in Italy.
Addressing the occasion, Chen called for leniency and reconciliation among political parties at home and between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
"Only leniency and reconciliation will pave the way for harmony among the different political parties and ethnic groups, and is the cornerstone for peace with China," Chen said.
Members of Chen's entourage included Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen and three religious leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMANSHIP RACE WON'T SPLINTER PARTY: MA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed Saturday that if he wins the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship election, he will invite Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng -- another contender for the post, to co-lead the party, and that if he loses the election, he will give Wang his full support.
Ma made the remarks while speaking to more than 1,000 supporters at a labor entertainment and education center in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan to drum up support for his bid for the party's top post.
The supporters waved KMT party and ROC national flags and banners in support of Ma, with some of the more enthusiastic supporters cheering Ma from time to time.
Ma stressed that the July 16 election will not be a battle that causes the party to splinter, saying that "it will be a gentlemen's battle."
He also took the opportunity to scathingly criticize the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for its poor handling of the economy and diplomatic affairs.

Taiwan's per capita income is now lower than it was in 2000 when President Chen Shui-bian first came to power, and the unemployment rate has been high during the period of DPP rule, Ma claimed. He added that he wants to galvanize the people's will and be elected party chairman to put the nation back on a proper course.

He also said that he aims to rebuild the pivotal values of the party, oppose Taiwan independence and the "one country, two systems" formula, advocate the signing of a 50-year cross-strait peace agreement, maintain the cross-strait status quo, and show zero tolerance for corrupt "black gold" politics so as to regain the presidency for the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC CONCERNED ABOUT SAFETY AND FUTURE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwanese are most concerned about their safety and worry life in the future will only get worse, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.
The findings of the survey also revealed that many Taiwanese do not know how to protect themselves even though they think they live in a dangerous environment.
The survey was conducted by the Taiwan branch of the U.S.-based DuPont Co. March 25-28.
Nearly 80 percent of the 1,075 respondents said food and traffic safety issues are their greatest concern among the five categories presented to them in the survey on citizens' sense of security.

In the food category, 77.4 percent said disease-infected pork poses the greatest threat to them, while 74.4 percent pointed to residual pesticide on fruits and vegetables, and 73.4 percent mentioned the quality of take-out plastic bags.

In the traffic categories, 85.2 percent mentioned concerns over the possibility of an accident, 81.9 percent pointed to the potential of sexual assault by taxi drivers, and 70.9 percent mentioned long-distance bus operations.

Despite the insecurity revealed by the survey, 40 percent of Taiwanese lack the basic know-how to protect themselves, with 80.7 percent not knowing which bus companies are operating under a legal license, and 64.8 percent saying they jaywalk or run red lights.
Meanwhile, 34.3 percent acknowledged that they do not know how to properly wash off the residual pesticides on food, and 28.4 percent said they do not pay attention to restaurants' sanitation.

The study also indicated that many Taiwanese are pessimistic about the future, with 46.6 percent saying they think their life will get worse in the future, 36.6 percent saying it will remain about the same, and only 6.3 percent saying they hold an optimistic view.

As to who should be responsible for enhancing the public's sense of security, 33.2 percent said the government, 22.6 percent said themselves, 21.3 percent mentioned society, 8.8 percent said the media, and 5.3 percent said companies.
The survey is said to be accurate to within plus or minus three percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAS NO PLAN TO REPLACE EDUCATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that there is no need for Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng to step down over a recent heated verbal exchange with an opposition lawmaker.

A fierce argument broke out between Tu and opposition People First Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua during a legislative session on Thursday after the minister spoke up for Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Shu Chin-chiang's controversial visit to Japan's Yasukuni Shrine honoring Japanese war dead, where the names of 28,000-plus Taiwanese soldiers are also listed.
Opposition legislators have demanded that Tu be replaced over his remarks.
Coming to Tu's defense, Hsieh said that if he were Tu, he would also lose his temper if he were called "shameless" by a legislator.
It would encourage the continuation of such a culture of abuse in the legislature if Tu were to step down over the incident, Hsieh said.
Hsieh said that he will make an evaluation of all his Cabinet members in August in consideration of a possible reshuffle and that the personnel adjustment will not be aimed at Tu.
The premier made the remarks in response to questions from the press while attending an event celebrating the first "international guide dog month" held by the Taiwan Guide Dog Association.
Addressing the event, Hsieh said the trust between humans and dogs marks a relationship of coexistence and reconciliation that transcends biological instinct.
Noting that there are only 11 guide dogs in Taiwan at present, Hsieh said there is still a lot of room for building an environment friendly to challenged citizens.
With the training of new guide dogs lagging behind demand, the government will provide subsidies to guardians of the visually impaired to improve their welfare, he said.

According to the association, Kaohsiung City was the first city in Taiwan to grant the right of way to guide dogs in February last year, giving them the right to enter government agencies and public establishments.
The policy was expanded to other places around Taiwan after the enactment of the Physically and Mentally Challenged Persons Protection Law on June 23, 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE DAILIES REPORT CHEN'S ATTENDANCE AT POPE'S FUNERAL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Major Japanese newspapers gave prominent coverage Saturday to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's attendance at Pope John Paul II's funeral in the Vatican the previous day.

The Asahi Shimbun said in a report carried in its international news section that Chen's presence at the pope's funeral in defiance of China's persistent attempts to isolate Taiwan has attracted much attention. Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo, the ROC's head of state has often been barred from international occasions.

The Taipei-datelined report pointed out that the Vatican is the only European country that maintains formal diplomatic relations with the ROC and that Chen is the first serving ROC president ever to visit the Vatican.
While the Vatican is seeking to forge ties with China, the report said, Chen's presence at the pope's funeral was seen to check such a trend.

According to the report, the Vatican has been working to repair its ties with China since the 1990s. The report said the number of Catholic followers in China, including members of underground churches, exceeds 10 million.

The report also said Vatican officials were divided over whether the Holy See should switch its diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China. Following John Paul II's death, all incumbent Vatican officials will step down. The report said it will up to the new pope to decide how to resolve the dilemma.
The report further said President Chen had expressed his gratitude for the Italian government's granting him courteous treatment befitting his status as the ROC head of state.

The Yomiuri Shimbun daily also carried a dispatch from Taipei saying that Taiwan's government regards Chen's attendance at the pope's funeral, the largest international religious gathering in recent memory, as a diplomatic achievement.
Other national Japanese papers also carried reports about Chen's historic Vatican visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT WILLING TO SUPPORT KMT HEAD'S PLANNED CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that he is wiling to support opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's planned visit to mainland China, but he added that Lien should first have a meeting with him.

President Chen made the remarks at CKS International Airport upon his return from a historic trip to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral. Chen's trip marked the first ever visit to Europe by a serving Republic of China president.
Chen said the administration is willing to engage in frank dialogue with the opposition leaders prior to their planned visits to China.

Amid reports that Lien is keen on accepting an invitation to visit Beijing following KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang's recent high-profiled China visit, the president said that Lien had previously served as premier and as vice president, which he said should make him familiar with national security and the political risks in cross-strait interaction.
"After all, the People's Republic of China is not a country ruled by law, which is an undisputable fact, " Chen added.
Chen asked whether Lien would allow a "normalization of cross-strait relations to be conducted through non-normalized channels" if he were the head of state.

"Can cross-strait dialogue and consultations be conducted rashly, recklessly and willfully without regard for national sovereignty and public authority of the government?" the president further asked.
Chen stressed that he is willing to support Lien's visit to China and that his administration can authorize Lien to discuss certain topics with Chinese President Hu Jintao.

However, he added that Lien should be aware that consensus must first be achieved among the various political parties on issues involving national sovereignty and the government's public authority for the sake of the best interests of the nation.
"What's so difficult for him to talk with the government and with me first?" Chen asked.

The president said that unity is strength, adding that when he and the leaders from more than 150 countries gathered in the Vatican Friday, it was a picture of unity of the international community in response to the late pontiff's call for peace and reconciliation.

Faced with the hostile and obvious threat from the other side of the Taiwan Strait, especially when most of the Taiwan people are demanding that China address their desire for peace and democracy, Chen said, the people might have to endure an irreversible crisis if Taiwan cannot unify and if some opposition parties fall into Beijing's trap in its attempts to cause division within Taiwan.

The president stressed that his administration will follow a "reconciliation without flinching" and "steadfastness without confrontation" policy in the wake of China's recent passage of its Anti-Secession Law which authorizes the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should the island move toward independence.
The majority of the Taiwan people are aspiring for a unified, strong and sovereign Taiwan, and rational and peaceful cross-strait relations, the president said.
As the leader of the nation, Chen said, he supports pragmatic and mutually beneficial exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"Any political leaders can visit China, but if the results of the visits have the potential to undermine national security and the wellbeing of the people, then the administration cannot sit idly by, considering its own duty and its mandate from the people," he added.

The president's words came after prosecutors said earlier this week that they had started to look into KMT Vice Chairman Chiang's visit to China to determine whether his reaching of a 10-point consensus with Beijing violates the stipulations of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PUSH FOR 'FOUR-IN-TWO' ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Saturday said that it will propose combining four local elections into two elections in view of the astronomical time and money spent on elections.

The TSU legislative caucus said that it will formally propose the election change through Lan Chun-chieh, a member of the Central Election Commission (CEC) recommended by the TSU, when the CEC convenes a meeting next Wednesday.

Lo Chih-ming, TSU caucus whip in the legislature, noted that during a national development conference held at the end of 1995, the participants reached consensus on abrogating village and township elections and on cutting the number of local elections.

If local elections are not merged, then the city and county head elections in December will kick off a series of elections for city and county councilors, village and township heads, and borough heads in March, June and August of the following year, respectively, Lo said, adding that this "would be a terrible squandering of national resources."

Premier Frank Hsieh first broached the idea of combining three local elections. The "three-in-one" election proposal refers to the the holding of the elections for city mayors/ county magistrates, city/county councilors, and village/ township heads at the same time.

But as the change could have a profound impact on various political parties and make the rampant vote-buying practices even worse, Hsieh's proposal has created heated discussion. Election workers have also complained that they won't have enough time to prepare for the change and will be prone to committing errors if the plan is implemented.

Lo said that the TSU supports the merging of local elections, but considering the pressure to be placed on the election workers, the party believes that the elections for city mayors/county magistrates and city/county councilors should be merged and be conducted at the end of this year, while the elections for village/township heads and borough heads should be merged and held in mid-2006.
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) both affirmed the "three-in-one" and "four-in-two" election reform proposals.

William C. D. Lai, DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said his party supports both options. However, he added that whether there is sufficient time to implement the reforms and complementary measures needs to be considered.

The DPP will respect the decisions of the Central Election Commission, the Taiwan provincial election committee, and the city and county election committees, which oversee the three local-level elections, Lai added.
Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT's Policy Committee, said his party will support either of the two reform options as long as they save costs and improve efficiency.

Tseng further said that regardless of the option, the Executive Yuan will have the final say, pointing out that the Central Election Commission is not an independent body and must carry out the orders of the Executive Yuan. He also expressed the hope that the Executive Yuan will handle the issue in an impartial manner.

Meanwhile, the opposition People First Party, an ally of the KMT, said that it supports the "two-in-one" option -- namely holding elections for city mayors/ county magistrates and those for city/ county councilors simultaneously -- or the "three-in-one" option. However, he said his party is opposed to the "four-in-two" option as this would require that the tenures of township heads be extended.
The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU)said the fewer number of elections there are, the better, in terms of cutting costs and reducing confrontation.

Chen Jung-chieh, NPSU caucus whip in the legislature, said that the party will support the "four-in-two" elections, adding that if another local election -- for delegates to village and township administrative offices -- is added to make it "five-in-one, " this would be even better.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY OFFICIAL VISITS VICTIMS OF TEMPLE ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: A Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official paid visits Saturday afternoon to the 31 victims still in hospital following an accident at a Nantou temple earlier the same day.

MOI Administrative Vice Minister Lin Chung-seng expressed his condolences during his visits to the injured victims, who were hurt when a wooden stage at a Buddhist gathering at the Lingyen Mountain Temple in the central Taiwan county collapsed Saturday morning. He also instructed the county's Prosecutor's Office to investigate the cause of the accident.
According to witnesses, the temporary wooden stage, said to be designed to hold up to 1,000 people, collapsed after only some 400 people had climbed onto it to have their pictures taken.

More than 180 people were injured and rushed to nearby hospitals. Most of them suffered only minor injuries and were released from hospital after receiving treatment. No one suffered any life-threatening injuries.
Nantou County Magistrate Lin Tsung-nan also visited the injured. He said safety regulations regarding temporary structures should be enacted in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT ASSENT IRRELEVANT TO KMT CHAIRMAN'S PLANNED CHINA TRIP: KMT

TEXT.P: Whether or not the government gives its authorization is irrelevant to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's plan to visit China, KMT officials said Saturday.

They were responding to President Chen Shui-bian's proposal earlier in the day that Lien meet with him before the latter's China visit so that he could authorize Lien to discuss certain issues with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung claimed that KMT members' visits to China are all normal exchanges and that the laws of the Republic of China do not forbid political leaders from visiting China.

According to Chang, Lien, who has served in many important posts in the government in the past, including the vice presidency, will certainly safeguard the ROC and follow the principle of Taiwan first, and his China visit will play up the equal status of Taiwan and China, uphold Taiwan's dignity and promote peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Chang claimed Lien has offered to do something for the country because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has failed to handle cross-strait relations properly.

Expressing doubt about President Chen's sincerity in meeting with Lien, Chang said Chen would not have accused Lien of "doing one thing while in power and doing another while in the opposition" if he were sincere about his invitation.
Tseng Yung-chuan, head of the KMT's Policy Committee, said Chen's proposal indicates that he agrees that Lien's visit to China will help achieve a breakthrough in the cross-strait deadlock.
Therefore, the president should support Lien's plan to visit China for the sake of national interests, Tseng said.
He said that Lien represents the KMT, which is a civic organization, and that it does not matter whether he has the government's authorization or not.

He claimed that only the KMT has the ability to resolve the cross-strait deadlock because the party has followed a consistent policy toward China, saying the KMT was the prime mover behind the launch of special cross-strait Lunar New Year charter flights this year.

According to Tseng, the DPP's failure to handle cross-strait relations properly has led to economic downturn in Taiwan, and the DPP should therefore let the KMT play a major role in cross-strait policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHILDREN CALL FOR A CLEAN PLANET

TEXT.P: Four hundred children from around the country gathered in Taipei Saturday and read aloud statements to express their wishes for a clean, unpolluted Earth.

In the statements, read out in Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka and English, the children from Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung and Kaohsiung said that even though they are kids, they understand that the Earth has been heavily polluted. They also mentioned the issues of the damaged ozone layer and deforestation in urging adults to work towards a clean environment for them.
The event was organized by the Society of Wilderness ahead of "Earth Day" which falls on April 22.
The children claimed that environmental issues are more important than the economy, and that fresh air, clean water and natural resources are necessary to ensure the survival of human beings.
The Society of Wilderness encouraged the public to attend a "Taiwanese Children Love the Earth" activity in Taipei on April 17 and sign a petition for a clean Earth.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR SWISS DAILY CALLS CHEN'S VATICAN VISIT A 'DIPLOMATIC COUP'
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 9 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li, Lo Yuan-shao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Switzerland's most important German-language daily on Saturday billed Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's unprecedented visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral the previous day as "a diplomatic coup."

Because of China's diplomatic embargo, the Neue Zuercher Zeitung daily said, Taiwan has rarely been in the international limelight. With the Italian government's support, the paper said, Chen got a rare opportunity to join presidents, prime ministers and royals from around the world in attending a major world event.
To protest the Vatican's invitation to Chen, Beijing didn't send any representatives to the pope's funeral. The Swiss paper said Beijing's decision handed Taiwan an unexpected diplomatic coup.
Amid reports that the Vatican might switch its diplomatic recognition from Taiwan to China, the paper said, this diplomatic coup has become even more precious to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, major French dailies, including "La Mode" and "La Figaro, " also reported Chen's attendance at the pope's funeral. The French papers described Chen's historic Vatican visit as a modern-day diplomatic miracle. They also predicted that the Vatican's quest for normalizing its ties with China could suffer a setback as a result.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING, OPPOSITION PARTIES SHOULD ENGAGE IN RATIONAL COMMUNICATION: PFP

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) said Saturday that the ruling and opposition parties should respect each other and engage in rational communication when dealing with cross-strait issues.
PFP spokesman Hseih Kung-ping was responding to President Chen Shui-bian's earlier remarks upon his return from a visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral the previous day.

President Chen said that he is willing to endorse opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's planned visit to China, but Chen added that Lien should have frank communication with the government prior to his visit.
Hsieh said that cross-strait relations is the most crucial issue at present and that it should be handled in a rational and pragmatic manner.

Hsieh further said the opposition parties should respect the government when dealing with cross-strait issues and have national interests as their top priority, while the government should also respect the opposition parties. He added that rational communication is paramount.

Hsieh said that it is improper for the government to investigate KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang for reaching a 10-point consensus with Beijing authorities during his recent visit to China, referring to it as using "legal means to solve a political issue."

But he also said that the opposition parties should respect the authority of the government and that any consensus reached between the opposition parties and mainland authorities requires the government's approval before it can be implemented.

The PFP legislative caucus said President Chen's remarks that cross-strait relations cannot be established through non-official channels illustrate his ignorance concerning the frequent exchanges between the private sectors on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chen Chih-ping, PFP caucus whip, said that cross-strait relations are strained but that private exchanges are close and frequent. The private sector could lend a hand where the government is incapable, and this is the intention of the planned visits to China by the heads of the "pan-blue alliance" parties of the PFP and the KMT which he claimed is a "pragmatic" approach.

Meanwhile, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said that President Chen is extending an olive branch to the opposition parties and that they shouldn't act tempestuously like spoiled children.

Chen Chin-chun, DPP caucus whip in the legislature, said that if Lien won't talk with the president and visits China as planned, he will face the problem of representation without prior authorization from the government.
Lien should sit down with the president to try to achieve consensus for the sake of the national interests and the wellbeing of the 23 million people of Taiwan, the DPP legislator added.
The legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, affirmed President Chen's remarks that cross-strait relations will not be established through non-official channels.

Legislator Lo Chih-ming, who is the TSU party whip, said that cross-strait talks are "not the same as hawking goods at a market" and that such talks "should be conducted on the basis of equality and dignity and with the prior authorization of the government."

If the opposition party leaders scramble to go to the mainland without prior government authorization, Lo said, they might fall into China's trap by inadvertently serving Beijing's "one China" scheme and undermining Taiwan's status as a separate and sovereign nation.

Lo also said that his party supports a resumption of the stalled talks between the Straits Exchange Foundation and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- the two semi-official bodies authorized by the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to deal with civilian exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURIST ARRIVALS EXPECTED TO BREAK 3 MILLION MARK: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tourist arrivals are expected to break the 3 million mark this year, a Tourism Bureau official said Saturday.

According to the official, the number of inbound tourists has been increasing steadily since the second half of last year. Tourist arrivals totaled only 1.4 million in the first half of last year due to presidential election disputes and misgivings about a possible avian flu outbreak.
With the domestic political situation stabilizing and the avian flu scare cooling off, the official said, tourist arrivals have gradually regained momentum since the second half of last year.
The number of tourist arrivals reached 2.94 million in 2004, the official said.

Between the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, tourist arrivals totaled 1.61 million. Barring unexpected developments, the official said, this year's tourist arrivals can break the 3 million mark to reach 3.25 million.

Nevertheless, the official acknowledged that if the government wants to realize the goal of attracting 5 million tourists annually by 2008, more activities of international allure should be staged in the coming years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REOPEN MARKET FOR U.S. BEEF PRODUCTS APRIL 16
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 8 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns announced Friday that Taiwan will lift its ban on U.S. boneless beef from animals under 30 months of age effective April 16.

"We are very pleased with this development because it is further significant progress in our efforts to reopen global markets for U.S. beef, " Johanns said, adding that this action demonstrates Taiwan's commitment to trade in beef and beef products based on internationally accepted scientific standards for human and animal health.
Johanns further said the U.S. government's goal is the resumption of normal beef trade throughout the world.

Taiwan banned imports of U.S. beef, live cattle and all related products in December 2003 after the discovery in the U.S. state of Washington of a single BSE case. BSE refers to bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease.
In 2003, the United States exported more than US$76 million worth of beef to Taiwan, with boneless beef products accounted for US$56 million.

Taiwan had been the sixth-largest market for U.S. beef before the import ban was imposed. Australia has since then dominated the Taiwan beef market. Taiwan's Council of Agriculture announced last month that the import ban on live cattle from the United States will remain in place after boneless U.S. beef is allowed to enter the Taiwan market again from April 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABORERS MAY BE IMPORTED FOR MAJOR PUBLIC PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday the government will consider allowing contractors of major public construction projects to import foreign laborers.
Hsieh made the remarks after all Cabinet members held an informal seminar at an amusement park in Wulai on the outskirts of Taipei.

Noting that many major public infrastructure construction projects, including the Peiyi Expressway, have been hindered by labor shortages due to local people's reluctance to take up laborious jobs, Hsieh said the government will review its overall policy on foreign labor imports.
If necessary, Hsieh said, the government will open the door for foreign laborers to take part in major infrastructure construction projects.
"We should endeavor to achieve a balance in labor imports and domestic unemployment issues," Hsieh said.
The informal meeting of all Cabinet members discussed a range of issues in three categories -- economic development, social justice, environmental and community development.

Hsieh said conclusions reached at the seminar will be put into force in the future, including upgrading manpower resources, accelerating research and development, boosting international technological cooperation and sustainable community development.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: A Time for Mourning, but Also for Study and Very Quiet Politics
Pope John Paul II's funeral Mass on Friday began nine days of spiritual mourning, but it also opened a political chapter - the subtle campaigning before the gathering of cardinals in a conclave starting April 18 to elect a successor. In the days before t he conclave begins, it is very likely that the cardinals will begin to conduct quiet research on who they think would make the best leader of the church. Some may even, in the softest of Roman ways, lobby for the job, although any sign of eagerness could have a negative effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 10, or the 2nd day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in-chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

The Manila Times: Italian is top Pope bet.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGED NOT TO FALL PREY TO BEIJING'S 'UNITED FRONT'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will risk falling prey to Beijing's "united front" scheme if he refuses to talk with President Chen Shui-bian and visits China as planned, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) warned Sunday.

Lai Ching-teh said that if Lien goes to China without prior consultations with Chen on cross-Taiwan Strait issues, he will risk compromising Taiwan's sovereignty, while "stealing" the DPP administration's authority.
Lai claimed that if he makes the trip, Lien will be poised to confer upon himself the title of "chief executive of the Taiwan special administration region" under China.
Lai said that as of Sunday, the KMT had not responded favorably Chen, who said a day earlier that he is willing to support Lien's planned visit to China but that he and Lien should meet first.

Chen made the remarks at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon his return from a historic trip to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral. Chen's trip marked the first ever visit to Europe by a serving Republic of China president.
The KMT leadership only reportedly said that a meeting with Chen prior to Lien's China visit would "put a millstone round Lien's neck" and that Lien has decided to make the trip as planned.

Answering his own questions, Lai said Beijing extended an invitation to Lien and promised that Chinese President Hu Jintao will meet him in person because the KMT has "a united front value" to Beijing.

He described the entire KMT as "seeming to be on the verge of total derangement" recently, with Lien obstinately determined to go to China while two other vice chairmen -- Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who he said have both been "kidnapped" by Lien's obstinacy -- dare not spell out their platforms on cross-strait issues in the campaign for the election of the KMT chairmanship.

Lai said that in stark contrast to Chen's recent visit to the Vatican to pay his respects to the late pope, Lien is stubbornly insisting on visiting China, a move that not only defies the opposition of the Taiwan people, but also makes the rest of the world wonder whether there is both a president in Taiwan and a "Taiwan chief executive under Beijing."

He claimed that the DPP caucus supports Lien's planned visit, but it must be made after Lien acquires a consensus with the administration before accepting the Beijing invitation. "Otherwise, Lien will face the problem of representation without prior authorization from the government," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. POISED TO HELP TAIWAN IN CASE OF CHINA INVASION: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The United States will help Taiwan defend an invasion by mainland China should Beijing resort to "non peaceful" means to deal with Taiwan, a lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Sunday.

Chiang Chau-yi made the remarks at a news conference held at the Legislative Yuan upon his return from a visit to the United States, where he took part in the anniversary celebrations of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, visited U. S. officials and met think tank members at the head of a 10-member legislative mission.

Citing testimony by U. S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of States Randall Shriver at a public hearing held April 6 by the International Relations Committee under the House of Representatives, Chiang said that the United States is opposed to changes to the status quo in the Taiwan Strait by either side and that the United States will help Taiwan counter a Chinese invasion.

Shriver was quoted as saying that the United States will respond the same as it did in 1995 and 1996, when it dispatched two aircraft carrier groups to the Taiwan Strait when China conducted live-fire missile test-firing in the strait.

According to Chiang, U.S. officials gave their assurances that the U.S. has not changed its stance in this regard and stressed that neither Taiwan nor China is entitled to alter the cross-strait status quo unilaterally.

U. S. officials are of the view that Beijing's adoption of an Anti-Secession Law March 14, which legislates for the use of "non- peaceful means" to curb Taiwan independence, is an attempt to unilaterally change the cross-strait status quo, he said, adding that Washington is fully aware of the Taiwan people's objections to the law.
The 10-member delegation departed for the United States April 2 and returned to Taiwan in two groups April 9 and 10, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT: PARTY CHAIRMAN'S CHINA TRIP REMAINS ON TRACK

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's proposed trip to China remains on the track and could take place "at any time," KMT spokesman Chang Rung-kung said Sunday.

The spokesman claimed that Lien's trip, to be titled by the KMT "a trip for peace" to underline the KMT's efforts to pursue peace across the Taiwan Strait, will be lined up on the basis of parity between Taiwan and China and will not compromise Taiwan's dignity. He added that the KMT believes government authorization is not necessary for Lien's trip.

As to President Chen Shui-bian's statement the previous day that only if Lien consults with the president before his departure will the president support his trip to China, Chang said his party does not think the president really intends to see Lien. "You don't abuse a person, threaten to bring him to justice and in the same breath ask him to meet you for talks," the spokesman said.

He was referring to a Prosecutor's Office investigation into KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang after his visit to China from March 28 to April 1 and the consensus he is supposed to have reached with Chinese officials during his talks there. Chen has claimed it is illegal for Chiang to have concluded such an accord with China.

The KMT spokesman said he had no idea of reports Sunday that Beijing has asked Lien to visit China before May 20, the first anniversary of Chen's inauguration for a second term, saying that Lien's trip is still being planned and that no date has been fixed.

As the leader of a political party of the Republic of China, Chang claimed, Lien's planned trip is a part of the country's normal exchanges with China and there is no law prohibiting party leaders from visiting China.

As the country's former vice president and premier, Chang said, Lien knows how to serve the interests of the country better than anyone else. Any worry that he might compromise the country's interests during his trip is "groundless," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP OPPOSES HALT TO CHINESE REPORTERS BEING POSTED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) decision to halt the stationing of correspondents in Taiwan by China's Xinhua news agency and People's Daily is not a positive development in Cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges, the opposition People First Party (PFP) said Sunday.

PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said the MAC should reconsider its decision, which flies in the face of Taiwan's long-standing efforts to promote exchanges with China and contradicts President Chen Shui-bian's asserted policy of seeking detente with China.

If local newspapers are correct in their reports that this is an countermeasure against China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, Hsieh said his party believes it will do more harm to Taiwan's image as a democracy than China's access to cover stories about Taiwan.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said Sunday that the decision was taken in light of the dampened atmosphere between Taiwan and China after the enactment of the Anti-Secession Law and the fact that Xinhua and the People's Daily present Taiwan in a biased light in their stories, even though they have correspondents in Taiwan to report the stories first hand.

DOC.HEADLINE: XINHUA, PEOPLE'S DAILY TAIWAN COVERAGE TO BE HALTED: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: The head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Sunday that a program allowing two major Chinese news media organizations to station staff in Taiwan will be halted temporarily in an effort to protect the national dignity and interests of Taiwan.

MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said the MAC decided to halt the press accreditation for China's official Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper because their coverage of Taiwan is not conducive to enhancing understanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Wu said that the purpose of allowing Chinese media organizations to station staff in Taiwan -- a practice that began in 2000 -- was to help the two sides better understand each other.

Unfortunately, Wu said, some Chinese media groups have focused only on the most extreme or radical opinions in Taiwan's political spectrum, which is not helpful to efforts to strengthen cross-strait understanding.

In addition, Wu said, the Chinese authorities have blocked news reports about Taiwan in all media channels, including Websites, another move that does not help Chinese people to gain better understanding of Taiwan society.

Discounting immediate criticism that the halt is an abrogation of freedom of the press, Wu claimed that halting Xinhua and People's Daily reporting in Taiwan and freedom of the press are different but parallel issues, given that both the Beijing mouthpieces have always reported Taiwan from extreme, negative and unfriendly angles.

Meanwhile, Wu noted that the government will not cease media exchanges with China across the board and that other unofficial Chinese news media organizations will still have the opportunity to come to Taiwan to cover news.
Nevertheless, he added, any media, cultural or educational exchanges could be strictly assessed if they are found unhelpful to efforts to cement cross-strait relations.

At least five Chinese media organizations, including Xinhua, People's Daily, China National Radio (CNR), China Central Television (CCTV) and China News Service (CNS) , have stationed journalists in Taiwan since the country first allowed Chinese news media organizations entry to Taiwan Nov. 10, 2000.
All these arrangements have been on a trial basis, with each visit lasting for only two months in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TIMETABLE FOR PFP CHAIRMAN'S CHINA VISIT: PARTY SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: No timetable has been set for People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to visit mainland China and it is "meaningless" for Soong to do so now at a time when Taiwan lacks a national consensus on the issue, PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said Sunday.

Hsieh claimed that Soong will pay a visit to China but pointed out that "there is not a fixed timetable" on the issue. Soong will head for China only when a national consensus is forged on the question of whether political parties should visit China now that Beijing has enacted its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

According to Hsieh, Soong hopes to visit China to help break the ice between the two sides. But it would be pointless for Soong to go if the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) "has not made up its mind whether it is willing to reconcile" with China.

Since Soong met President Chen Shui-bian Feb. 24 and made public a 10-point agreement promising to maintain the national title of the Republic of China and not declare Taiwan independence in a concerted effort to ease tension across the Taiwan Strait, the government has not done anything concrete to serve those ends, Hsieh claimed.

It would be meaningful for the PFP chairman to visit China only if a consensus is reached in Taiwan and if all the parties concerned can manage to work out feasible measures, he said, reiterating that the ruling and opposition camps should respect each other and give national interests precedence when seeking rational and workable resolutions to cross-strait disputes.

The opposition parties should respect the government's authority and mandate, while the government should respect the opposition camp's efforts, he said, adding that it is very important for both sides to exchange views.

Turning to a government plan to take court action to deal with main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang, who the government accuses of hurting Taiwan's interests by reaching a 10-point consensus with Chinese Communist Party officials during a recent visit to China without notifying the Taiwan authorities beforehand, he claimed that it is inappropriate for the government to handle a political issue through legal means.

The government led by the ruling DPP has blamed Chiang for provoking "China fever" among Taiwan's political parties hoping to cut deals with China at the expense of Taiwan's national dignity and interests at a time when the Anti-Secession Law has dealt a heavy blow to cross-strait relations.
Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Lien Chan is also planning to visit China in the near future, although no exact date has been fixed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP OFFICIAL LEAVES FOR CHINA TO PROMOTE AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: An official of the opposition People First Party (PFP) left Taiwan for Fuzhou in the southern Chinese province of Fujian Sunday for a low-profile visit to pave the way for a visit by a PFP delegation that will promote agricultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Huang Pan-kung, director of the PFP Department of Organization, will visit only Fuzhou to conduct preparatory work for the PFP agricultural promotion delegation scheduled to head to China later this week.
PFP officials denied that Huang's visit has anything to do with plans pertaining to PFP Chairman James Soong's much-speculated upon visit to China.

Huang, formerly deputy director of the now-defunct Taiwan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Forestry, has maintained close connections with people in the agricultural and research sectors across the Taiwan Strait and has also kept abreast of the situation and needs in Taiwan's farming circles, according to PFP officials.

His departure for China came on the heels of that of PFP Legislator-at-Large Tsay Sheng-jia, who left Taiwan for China Friday on a trip mainly aimed at opening up a new market for Taiwan's agricultural products.

PFP officials declined to confirm whether Huang will join Tsay in China and both visits have been kept low-profile. Their cautiousness is seen as a reflection of an on-going controversy over who should represent Taiwan in talks with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT DRAWS MIXED REACTIONS OVER BARRING XINHUA REPORTERS

TEXT.P: Local political parties reacted along party lines Sunday to a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) decision to withdraw permission to Beijing's Xinhua news agency and People's Daily to post reporters in Taiwan.

Cheng Wen-Tsan, director of the Communications Department under the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said his party supports the MAC's decision, which he claimed underscores Taiwan's "free rein" in dealing with China.

The decision, which Cheng admitted is a tit-for-tat attempt to chill relations with China in the wake of Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, is "necessary" to reflect the country's anger with Beijing, according to Cheng.

He attempted to downplay the negative impact that the measure will bring about to China's freedom of press, claiming that the move does not infringe on China's freedom of the press because under the communist regime, the media has no press freedom in China.

DPP Legislator William Lai, who is the secretary of the DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, claimed it is "only natural" for the government to strip Xinhua and People's Daily of the right to station correspondents in Taiwan because they "never reflect" Taiwan's mainstream opinions in their stories.

Vice President Annette Lu said in Taichung, central Taiwan, Sunday that the MAC's decision comes too late and claimed that the two Beijing media should have had their right to station reporters in Taiwan suspended March 14 when the Beijing authorities passed its Anti-Secession Law to give itself the right to attack Taiwan.
The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), the DPP's political ally in the Legislative Yuan, lauded the MAC decision.

TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming said the country should not sit on its hands without showing its anger when China displays its hostility toward Taiwan. Chen said all political parties should rally behind the MAC on the issue.

The major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) did not agree with him, however, with KMT spokesman Chang Rung-kung pointing out that instead of forcing China to backtrack from its Anti-Secession Law, the response only underlines that the move is merely a petty attempt to counterattack China.

Noting that the exchanges of correspondents is a percusor to more significant exchanges between Taiwan and China and vital in developing a meaningful relationship with China, Chang said the government is denying itself a valuable chance to do so by excluding the two media organizations from Taiwan.

He predicted that the decision will cast Taiwan in a bad light in the international publicity war between China and Taiwan, and will tarnish Taiwan's image as a democracy that values freedom of the press.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU CALLS FOR STRATEGIC COOPERATION WITH JAPAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), a political ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the Legislative Yuan, called on the government Sunday to strengthen the country's strategic cooperation with Japan to counterbalance China's military buildup.

TSU lawmaker Ho Min-hao said China's military buildup has become a cause of great concern for Japan and the United States, and prompted them to declare earlier this year that the peaceful solution of the Taiwan issue is one of their joint strategic objectives in the region.

Caught between China's intensifying confrontation with Japan and the United States, Ho said, Taiwan's status as a vital link in the island chain off the coast of China is all the more important and therefore could convince Japan to take on the island as a valuable strategic partner.

Ho said TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang exchanged views with Japanese politicians on the possibility of forging closer strategic cooperation between Taipei and Tokyo during his just-concluded trip to Japan.

Meanwhile TSU lawmaker Lo Chih-ming, the party's convener in the Legislative Yuan, said Sunday that the Taiwan Relations Act, which obliges Washington to help Taiwan with its defense, is proof that the United States considers Taiwan an entity separate from China.
Taiwan politicians should realize this and stick to it while dealing with China, Lo said.
He urged the government to deal with local businessmen who invest in China without government approval in the same way it does with political parties that visit China without approval.
He was referring to the government's recent decision to bring to justice any political party and its leaders who visit China in violation of Taiwan's laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OUTPERFORMS SOUTH KOREA IN PPP: CEPD CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Although South Korea has outperformed Taiwan in per-capita gross national product (GNP) , Taiwan is still stronger in PPP (purchasing power parity) than South Korea, according to a government official.

Tu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said over the weekend that the latest figures released by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or 2003 show that Taiwan's PPP is still higher than South Korea's by more than US$6,000.

According to the IMF statistics, Hong Kong enjoyed the highest PPP of US$27,892 among the four Asian Dragons in 2003. Taiwan came second with US$24,558, ahead of Singapore's US$24,552 and South Korea's US$17,900.
The gap in PPP of US$6,658 between Taiwan and South Korea is an indication that Taiwan had a substantially higher income than South Korea, Hu said.
The CEPD chairman added that he believes the figures to be released by the IMF for 2004 will still show that Taiwan has a higher PPP than South Korea, excluding the element of currency exchange rate.
Since the beginning of this year, the South Korean won has appreciated by more than 15 percent against the U.S. dollar, while the new Taiwan dollar only picked up in value by 6 percent.

However, tallies compiled recently by the International Institute for Management Development show that Hong Kong had an average PPP of US$27,743 in 2003, followed by Singapore with US$24,183, Taiwan with US$22,760 and South Korea with US$17,368. Taiwan exceeded South Korea by US$5,392 according to those PPP calculations.
According to figures made public by governments in Asia, Taiwan was bottom of the list in terms of per-capita GNP compared to the three other Asian Dragons in 2004.
Taiwan had an average per-capita income of US$14,032 last year, lagging behind Singapore's US$25,191, Hong Kong's US$23,960 and South Korea's US$14,162.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP TRADITIONAL INDUSTRY INTEGRATE WITH HI-TECH: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government will help traditional industries integrate with the high technology sector to increase the industry's innovation and value-added ability, officials of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

The CEPD has drawn up strategies for the development of high value-added traditional industries and newly emerging service industries to help the traditional industry transform and to create jobs, the officials said.
Premier Frank Hsieh set a target of less than 4 percent for this year's unemployment a day earlier in a Cabinet meeting, they noted.

To achieve this target, the officials went on, the government has implemented various programs, including middle-term and long-term plans for the promotion of employment, programs for diversifying the creation of jobs, programs for upgrading job-seekers' professional abilities and programs for expanding public services.

Also, they added, the CEPD has plans to promote the development of high-value traditional industries by integrating them with the high technology sector, such as the hi-tech textiles, health foods, hi-tech materials and chemicals used in the opto-electronic industry.

Meanwhile, they said, the government will continue to promote the "two-trillion, two stars" program for the development of the semiconductor and opto-electronic industries and accelerating the development of telecommunications and machinery industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD PROMOTE CO-EXISTENCE MECHANISM: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan has encountered a bottleneck in its development and should promote a co-existence mechanism to make a breakthrough, Premier Frank Hsieh said Sunday.

Addressing a gathering of students organized by the World Leader Education Foundation, Hsieh said that Taiwan today needs a new institution and new models for interaction to achieve the goal of co-existence.

The premier told more than 1,000 college students attending the gathering that co-existence is vital in human history because when societies encounter difficulties at a certain stage of their development, there must be some wise people who can find a mechanism to avoid the total destruction of the society. This mechanism, he explained, is co-existence.
Diversity, different historical experiences, languages and ethnicity, Hsieh claimed, are Taiwan's characteristics that make Taiwan's experiences more valuable.
Co-existence will make Taiwan a better society and "a miracle for mankind," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 11, or the third day of the March of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN JOINS BUSH, HU JINTAO IN TIME MAGAZINE'S 100 LIST
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 10 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian joined U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao and 97 others on TIME magazine's annual list of the 100 most influential people in the world, the weekly announced Sunday.

President Chen appeared in the most influential "Leaders and Revolutionaries" category. Others on this list included U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, former U.S. President Bill Clinton and North Korean leader Kim Jong Il.

In the article introducing President Chen, TIME reporter Michael Elliott wrote that Chen, born to a poor family in 1951, "symbolizes Taiwan's transition from Chiang Kai-shek's dictatorship to democracy and from a situation in which political power was dominated by refugees from the mainland to one in which native Taiwanese like himself lead the nation."

The Taiwan Strait is sometimes called the most dangerous place in the world, Elliott said. On one side of the waterway is mainland China, and on the other, the island of Taiwan, where Nationalist forces, led by Chiang, retreated after their defeat by the communists in China's civil war.

Beijing regards Taiwan as a "renegade province" and has said it is willing to use force if necessary to prevent the island's independence, Elliott wrote, adding that the United States, for its part, has pledged to defend Taiwan if the island is attacked without provocation.
Having narrowly won a second four-year term last year after surviving an apparent assassination attempt, Chen, 54, will remain in office until 2008, the report continued.

Beijing can't stand him, Elliott said. China's leaders call him a "splittist" determined to break Taiwan away from the mainland for good. At times, Chen's rhetoric seems excessive, even in Taiwan's boisterous democracy. Voters denied him a victory in legislative elections last December, preferring parties that seek a greater accommodation with China, and since then, Chen has deliberately reached out to Beijing, Elliott said.

Chen' overtures, however, have not been received with obvious rapture; last month China passed a law reiterating its willingness to use force should the island declare formal independence, Elliott reported.

Elliott further wrote that though Chen summoned a million people into the streets on March 26 to protest that law, don't rule out the possibility that he may yet make a deal with Beijing. "I am a maker of history," Chen told TIME, last year.
"If that turns out to be so, let's hope it's because Chen Shui-bian proves to be a force for reconciliation across the Taiwan Strait, not for war over it," Elliott concluded.
This edition of TIME magazine is set to hit newsstands Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ORCHIDS GRACE MOSCOW FLORAL SHOW

TEXT.P: Colorful butterfly orchids from Taiwan received two top awards at the Sakoliki International Flower Show in Moscow, organizers said Sunday.

Joseph Wu and his wife, Peng Hsi-nan, both of whom enjoy fame in the global floral community, overcame many difficulties airlifting 500 pots of butterfly orchids to Moscow for display at the Sakoliki flower trade fair held April 7-10.
It marked the first time that Taiwan has ever participated in the noted international floral trade fair in Russia.

At Sunday's closing ceremony, organizers presented the Best Flower Art Award and the Best Floral Design Award in recognition of the Wus' efforts at promoting orchid cultivation and improving floral technologies. The Republic of China national flag was also flown at the exhibition site in honor of the Wus' achievement.

"It's a great honor for us to receive the awards. We take great pleasure in bringing Taiwan's most beautiful 'angel' to Russia for cultural and artistic exchanges, " Wu said in a Russian television interview after the presentation ceremony.

The Wus' booth attracted a large crowd of visitors, but few of the visitors bought the Taiwan couple's orchids. The Wus said they felt a bit of disappointment about the lukewarm market response. Nevertheless, they said they will not be daunted by the setback and will devote more efforts at studying consumer tastes in the Russian floral market.
In recognition of their professionalism in orchid cultivation, the Wus have been invited to take part in a professional flower show to be held in Moscow April 13-17.
