DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE WANT BREAKTHROUGH IN CROSS-STRAIT STALEMATE: KMT HEAD

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said in an open statement released Monday that addressing the current political stalemate across the Taiwan Strait is the biggest hope of most of the people in Taiwan.

KMT visits to mainland China, including the recent groundbreaking visit to Beijing by a delegation led by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang during which Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with leaders of the Chinese Communist Party, represent party-to-party consultations and efforts that are opening a door that could lead to peace across the strait, Lien said in the statement.
The open statement was read by KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng at the KMT headquarters Monday.

Lien said in the statement that since the consultations are purely party-to-party talks aimed at allowing the two sides to understand each other better, he does not feel that government authorization or approval is required at this current stage.

However, he added, if any cross-strait talks or negotiations involve the exercise of public authority, the KMT will definitely communicate with the government via the proper channels prior to engaging in such talks so as to create an environment conducive to the people's wellbeing.

Lien reiterated that all the "trips of peace" to be conducted by the KMT in the future will be open and transparent. "They will be conducted based on the premise that the Republic of China's national dignity must be upheld, with reciprocity and benefits for people across the strait as the top guiding principle."

He stressed that the KMT has unwaveringly protected the sovereignty of the ROC and the security of Taiwan ever since the ROC was established in 1911, and that the KMT's cross-strait policy which "champions rationality, peace, equality and reciprocity, " has remained unchanged.

At this crucial juncture, when cross-strait relations are unprecedentedly tense, it is the KMT's keen expectation that the Democratic Progressive Party administration will show more openness, generosity and magnanimity to breakthrough the current cross-strait political stalemate to create the opportunity for peace across the Taiwan Strait, Lien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE RENEWS CALL FOR CHEN-LIEN MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian looks forward to meeting with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan prior to Lien's planned visit to China, a Presidential Office official said Monday.

The official, who preferred to remain anonymous, made the remarks after KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said that if Lien does visit China to conduct party-to-party talks with the top Chinese Community Party leader, such a visit doesn't require the government's prior approval or authorization. Lin also questioned Chen's sincerity in promoting domestic inter-party reconciliation.
In response, the official said Chen is sincere in proposing a meeting with Lien prior to Lien's planned China visit.

In a speech delivered at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport last weekend upon his return from a historic visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, Chen said he is willing to support Lien's planned China visit and authorize Lien to talk with Chinese authorities on certain issues so long as Lien meets with him prior to his departure for the mainland.

For the sake of safeguarding the ultimate national interests and forging a domestic consensus on relations across the Taiwan Strait, the Presidential Office official said President Chen hopes Lien can communicate with the government before his China trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT PROCESSING ZONES ATTRACT INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The export processing zones around Taiwan attracted some NT$6.4 billion (US$202.3 million) in new investments and investments for business expansion during the first three months of this year, an official of the Kaohsiung-based Export Processing Zone Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affair said Monday.

The good record was due to several measures initiated by the administration to encourage foreign and local manufacturers to set up or expand their operational lines in the zones, the official indicated, adding they include improving the investment environment, taking efforts to attract foreign and local investment, and seeking sufficient and professional manpower for the zones.
The facilities have been successfully upgraded into capital and technology-intensive industrial zones, he added.
There are now five processing zones around the island, which are located in Kaohsiung and Taichung.

From January to March, nine new investment applications were approved with the value amounting to NT$1.54 billion while the number of expansion investments reached 16 with a total value of NT$4.86 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S EFFORTS UNIVERSALLY RECOGNIZED: AIDE

TEXT.P: Responding to Time magazine's inclusion of Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian in its list of 100 most influential people in the world for this year, an official from the Presidential Office said Monday that President Chen's relentless efforts to serve the country have been universally recognized.

Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of the Presidential Office Department of Public Affairs, said that since Chen took office, he has done all he can to further reforms and seek inter-party reconciliation, while making numerous goodwill overtures toward China to try to secure cross-strait peace and allowing Taiwan to stand tall in the international community with dignity.

Chen Wen-tsung said that President Chen's unwavering efforts to safeguard the country and its people are obvious and recognized at home and abroad, adding that "the president's efforts will continue relentlessly."

Calling the ROC president "the President of Taiwan, " Time grouped Chen Shui-bian Sunday with U.S. President George W. Bush and mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao and 97 others on its annual list of the 100 most influential people in the world.

President Chen appeared in the most influential "Leaders and Revolutionaries" category. Others on this eclectic list include U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, former U.S. President Bill Clinton and North Korean leader Kim Jong Il.

"If that turns out to be so, let's hope it's because Chen Shui-bian proves to be a force for reconciliation across the Taiwan Strait, not for war over it," Elliott concluded.
This edition of Time magazine will go on sale Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP GOVERNMENT CHALLENGED ON CHARTER FLIGHTS, FARM EXPORTS ISSUES

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) official challenged the government Monday on cross-strait issues, including direct charter flight services and Taiwan's farm exports to China, saying that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration should make it clear whether it is committed to these engagements or not.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said Monday that a KMT delegation plans to head to China later this month and will try to move the discussions forward regarding regular cross- strait charter cargo and passenger flights and exports of Taiwan's agricultural products to China.

However, Tseng said that before the delegation contacts Chinese authorities responsible for making public policy, it would be advantageous if the DPP administration would first make clear whether it would be willing to follow up on these contacts in its official capacity. "Otherwise, all of our efforts will be futile, " Tseng argued.

Tseng reiterated that prior to its delegation's departure for China, the KMT will consult with the Mainland Affairs Council -- Taiwan's top China policy planner -- about the government's thinking and intentions on the development of cross-strait relations, including regular direct charter flights and agricultural exports.

Tseng said that the opening of direct cross-strait charter passenger flights during this year's Chinese Lunar New Year holiday was a good example of how the private sector can lend a hand in areas where the government is incapable of getting the job done. He said the KMT acted as a go-between and a "policy-pusher" before the government took over the ensuing tasks to make the holiday cross-strait charter flights a reality.

He called for the DPP administration not to block the opposition parties' efforts in addressing the cross-strait political stalemate and not to act in an obstinate and irrational manner, saying that this is not helpful and only runs counter to Taiwan's mainstream opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TO FEEL THE PINCH IF CHINA BUYS MIRAGE 2000-9CSs: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The ROC Air Force will feel the pinch if China acquires French-made Mirage 2000-9CS jet fighters, the chief of staff at the ROC Air Force General Headquarters said Monday.

Lt. Gen. Peng Sheng-chu made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's defense committee, where opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Yu-fang asked Peng about his views on a media report that said that once the European Union lifts its 16-year-old ban on arms sales to China, China will purchase 210 Mirage 2000-9CSs from France.

As Mirage 2000-9CSs are newer than the Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters that Taiwan acquired in the 1990s, Peng said the Mirage 2000-9CSs are believed to outperform the Mirage 2000-5s in combat capabilities and range.
If China does obtain Mirage 2000-9CSs, Peng admitted that the ROC Air Force will face great pressure.
Taiwan purchased 60 Mirage 2000-5s and two of them have crashed in training flights.

With a view to upgrading air defense capabilities, Peng said, the military has considered procuring a new generation of warplanes after acquiring 150 U.S.-built F-16 jet fighters and 60 Mirage 2000-5s in the 1990s.
Noting that new warplane procurement requires a careful evaluation of a number of complicated elements, Peng said the military is still collecting information and data about the procurement plan.

"We are mulling whether to buy U.S.-made F35s or F-18s or to upgrade our F-16 fleet now in service, " Peng said, adding that the military must also consider whether the United States would sell its most advanced warplanes to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN-LIEN MEETING POSSIBLE IN ADEQUATE ATMOSPHERE: KMT

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) is willing to arrange a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and KMT Chairman Lien Chan in an adequate atmosphere before Lien heads for a visit to mainland China, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said Monday.
Lin made the remarks to reporters at KMT headquarters in Taipei after making public a statement on behalf of Lien on his planned "journey of peace" to China.

Pointing out that the KMT is willing to exchange views with the government on Lien's China visit beforehand if necessary, Lin called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to build a favorable atmosphere first to pave the way and claimed that "the KMT's door is always open wide to such a development."

"If it is necessary, I'm willing to meet with President Chen's secretarial aides first, " Lin said, stressing that "the KMT will not rule out any possibilities of contacts with the government should the political climate at home allow the party to do so."

However, he advised the government to refrain from putting out feelers to the media and made it clear that the KMT has never refused to talk with the Presidential Office regarding the issue. Up to now, he has not received any call from the Presidential Office, Lin noted.

Calling on the government to respect the KMT's goodwill and to support its efforts to help mend Taiwan-mainland ties, he urged the government to turn over the reins to the private sector and allow it to play a role in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs for the sake of Taiwan's overall interests should the government itself be unable to take concrete action.

The purpose of Lien's China visit is to help create a mutually beneficial situation for the two sides of the strait, he said, adding that it will be fully transparent and that Lien will do his utmost to protect national dignity and seek the maximum benefits for the people in Taiwan under the principles of parity, reciprocity and peace in his dealings with the Chinese side.

Lien is slated to travel to China in the near future. KMT spokesma Chang Jung-kung said a day earlier that Lien's China trip could take place at any time, although he said that no exact date has been set.

The government and the ruling DPP have both asked Lien to report to President Chen on his planned trip out of grave concerns that any deals reached by the main opposition KMT in China might damage Taiwan's national dignity and interests.

Traveling at the head of a 34-member delegation, KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang paid a visit to China late last month and reached a 10-point consensus with Chinese Communist Party officials to enhance private sector exchanges.

Chiang's China trip has backfired among pro-Taiwan independence backers who accused the KMT vice chairman of selling Taiwan out. Prosecutors said that they will look into Chiang's China visit to vet whether the 10-point consensus has infringed upon national interests and the government's authority.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU FAVORS GOVERNMENT APPOINTMENT OF VILLAGE/TOWNSHIP HEADS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Monday that it will support the government appointing the heads of villages and townships, instead of holding elections.

Chen Chien-ming, TSU secretary-general, said that the party will propose a revision to the local system law and ask the support of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to implement reforms for the local system.

Chen made the remarks amid media reports that the government is planning to have elections for city mayors/county magistrates and city/county councilmen held simultaneously and that a referendum will also be held on that day to determine whether to abrogate the elections for village/township heads and for elections for delegates to village/township councils.

Chen noted that a national development conference in 1996 reached a consensus on appointing the village/township heads, adding that the DPP has been in office for five years, and has yet to carry out the consensus, adding that if there was already a consensus, why should there still be referendum.
He said that any system should first consider whether it is durable and stable, and should not be an election ploy.

He noted that the Executive Yuan first broached the holding of elections for city mayors/county magistrates, city/county councilors, and village/township heads at the same time, but the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said it was not feasible.
He asked the DPP to provide complimentary measures of its proposal so as not to let the people down.

Meanwhile, the TSU will also kick off a campaign of the rectification of the nation's name and the writing of a new constitution so as to solicit support for the TSU in an election for a mission-oriented National Assembly scheduled for May 14, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW YOUTH CENTER OPENS WITH ROCK-CLIMBING EVENT

TEXT.P: A rock-climbing event on the sidewalk of one of Taipei's busiest streets marked the opening of a new youth center Monday.

Premier Frank Hsieh, joined by Minister of the National Youth Commission under the Executive Yuan Cheng Li-chiun, climbed an artificial wall set up on the sidewalk of Chunghsiao East Road beside the Shandao Temple Station to unveil the new "Youth Hub, " a youth center built to encourage young people to exchange ideas and participate in public affairs.
While the premier appreciated the chanting from the crowd below as he make the summit, he half-jokingly said he prefers not to do something "life-threatening" every time he inaugurates something.

The idea of building the center came from the French Cafe Philo, which is also a place for youth to discuss national events while enjoying coffee, Cheng said, adding that the reason rock-climbing was included in the inauguration ceremony was to encourage young people to think not only horizontally, or extensively, but also vertically, or intensively.
Youth Hub is open to all non-profit youth organizations who make a reservation. It is free to use the facilities, but bringing along coffee is appreciated.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER ASKS FOR MAXIMUM PENALTY FOR COP KILLER

TEXT.P: The two men who attacked two policemen in broad daylight Sunday, killing one of them, will be captured and prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law, Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Monday.
Shih made the remarks at an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

The two policemen, Hung Chung-nan, 30, and Chang Ta-hao, 31, were making their rounds at around 1 p.m in Hsihchih, Taipei County, when they were attacked from behind by two men tailing them. Chang's gun and his 12 rounds of ammunition were taken, while Hung fought to defend his gun. Hung bled to death after being stabbed 15 times and Chang was seriously injured.

According to a surveillance video released Monday, the two men were riding a motorcycle and are around 170 cm, with the driver wearing a dark shirt and trousers, while the man riding pillion was wearing a dark shirt and grey-white trousers. They wore full-face helmets during the attack and then sped off in the direction of Hsihchih.

Saying that this sort of attack was an open challenge to the police force specifically and to social order in general, Shih said a speedy investigation will be conducted and he will ask for the maximum punishment possible by law for the attackers.
He said that the case would likely involve obstructing a police officer and manslaughter at the least. According to Criminal Code regulations, these violations carry a maximum penalty of death.
Vice Minister of the Interior Lin Yung-chien said that the attack was an isolated case and the public should have faith in the ability of the police to keep social order.

Lin said that he is aware that if major crimes go unsolved, the public loses confidence in the police. Should this case remain unsolved for an extended time, Lin said he "would take responsibility." He did not specifically say if this meant that he would step down.
All police are now being told to wear bullet-proof vests while on duty.

Police are asking the public to come forward with any information on the attack and are offering a cash reward of NT$500,000 (US$15,873) for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS URGE TAIWAN TO DO MORE TO PROTECT WHALE SHARKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan must do more to promote the protection of the threatened whale shark, the largest fish in the world, experts from various countries said Monday at a conference in Taipei.

In response to the rapidly decreasing number of whale sharks (Rhiniodon typus) remaining in the wild, National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) and WildAid jointly invited international scholars to join a conference to discuss ways of saving the largest shark, also the largest fish, on earth.

NTOU professor Liu Kuang-ming suggested that tours to sight the whale shark should be organized in Taiwan to help protect the animal. As many countries, including Australia, the Philippines and Belize promote such tours, he added, revenues generated in some of these countries are greater than that generated in catching fish alone.

While the whale shark is protected by many countries and listed in the "threatened species" category by CITES (the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora), Taiwan consumes large quantities of the animal each year.

Known in Taiwan as "tofusa" (Tofu shark), the whale shark can grow up to about 20 meters long and weigh approximately 34 tons, with a life span of almost 100 years. Usually inhabiting shallow coastal waters, it survives by eating small fish and shrimp. It poses no threat to humans. Its tameness is the reason it is often caught and hence the decreasing numbers.

Under regulations by the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan, the quota for catching whale sharks is 65 this year, and Taiwanese fishermen must report to authorities if they have caught any.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG SMUGGLERS ARRESTED AT AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Two Malaysian men trying to leave the country with two packs of drugs were arrested at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taoyuan police officials said Monday.

The two suspects, Wong Kin Hock and Leong Ching Lai, reportedly entered Taiwan April 9 and planned to take a Malaysia Airlines flight to Kuala Lumper Monday morning, before airport security found 14.03 kilograms of the so-called "one-pill-sleep" on them, according to the police.
An investigation is currently underway.

The drug, also known as "red bean" or "K5", is classified by the government as a Class-4 regulated sedative used in clinical trials to deal with anxiety, loss of sleep and muscle contractions. While overdosing may lead to sleepiness, prolonged use of the drug may lead to loss of memory, short attention span, and impaired visual and spatial abilities.
Authorities said the drug was originally abused by the students in Malaysia before the Malaysian government banned it. The drug is now manufactured in Taiwan and exported back to Malaysia.
While it is common to see drugs being smuggled into Taiwan, smuggling narcotics out of the country is rare, according to the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF SHOULD MEET WITH PRESIDENT PRIOR TO CHINA VISIT: DPP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should meet with President Chen Shui-bian prior to his planned visit to China, the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.

"Lien should meet with President Chen before he travels to Beijing to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, " DPP legislative whip William C.T. Lai said, adding that forging a domestic consensus on relations across the Taiwan Strait should precede consultations with the Chinese authorities.
Lai reminded the KMT that cross-strait issues can be resolved only through negotiations between the governments on both sides of the strait.

"As an opposition party, the KMT's dealings with the Chinese Communist Party could lead nowhere," Lai said, pointing out that Chen is the only Taiwan political figure to make Time Magazine's 2005 list of the 100 most influential people in the world along with Chinese President Hu and U.S. President George W. Bush.
"The Time Magazine list indicates that Chen and Hu are the key decisive figures as far as cross-strait issues are concerned, " Lai said.

Quoting the results of a series of recent public opinion polls, Lai said more and more local people have voiced their expectations that a national consensus should be forged before Taiwan begins negotiations with China.
In his view, Lai said, holding an inter-party summit meeting is the best way for the domestic political parties to shape a consensus on the thorny cross-strait issue.
On the speculation that Hu may decline to meet with Lien if Lien meets with Chen first, Lai said he hopes Lien will put national interests above partisan or personal interests.
President Chen expressed a desire last weekend to meet Lien when he spoke to reporters after returning from Pope John Paul II's funeral in the Vatican.
Details of Lien's China trip have yet to be fleshed out but media reports said he is likely to leave after the May 14 National Assembly election.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PROMOTES TAICHI TO POLITICAL LEADERS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged political leaders Monday to do things "the taichi way."

While sharing her thoughts during a press interview Monday after trying the well-known traditional Chinese martial art, she urged political leaders in Taiwan to deal with matters calmly and slowly, just as when practicing taichi.
Lu claimed that doing things in this manner will benefit all Taiwanese people by creating "a nice ambience."
The vice president also dubbed this year "healthy life year," and encouraged the public to work out regularly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OEMS MAKE INROADS INTO INT'L MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading shoemaker Ever Rite Corp., Ltd. and porcelain ornament producer Franz Collection, Inc. are gaining fame in the international market after their brands have become recognized in the international market.

Ever Rite was founded 25 years ago to make footwear as an OEM -- original equipment manufacturer. It is now a major global maker of women's shoes, producing more than 80 million pairs of shoes thus far, according to an Ever Rite executive.

In 2001, the group created the brand "Miss Sofi, " Manager Kuo Yi-chun said Monday, noting that the company has opened a total of 19 booths at department stores and exclusive shops around Taiwan, and two franchise stores in Hong Kong.

Miss Sofi products entered the Japanese market this spring, while the company obtained strong orders for Miss Sofi shoes at a trade fair in Italy in March, marking a good start in the Taipei County-based group's efforts to make inroads into the European market, Kuo indicated.

Meanwhile, the Franz Collection, which has been providing OEM/ODM services since its founding in 1979, won the Guild of Specialist Gift Retailers of Britain's first prize for the best china gift creation May 17 last year with its "Franz" products, according to the company.
The Taipei-based chinaware producer has now nearly 6,000 employees at its 4,000 operational bases and outlets around the globe.

The "Franz" series of ornament-oriented products are now seen in the top-graded shopping centers of the world like the Neiman Marcus in the United States, Harrods in Britain, David Jones in Australia and Lane Crawford in Hong Kong, the company said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CANADA SIGN COOPERATION GUIDELINE ON AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Canada signed an accord Monday to step up cooperation in the innovation and research and development of agriculture technology.

Huang Tze-ping, director-general of the Department of International Affairs of the Council of Agriculture (COA), and Gordon Houlden, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, signed the Guideline for Scientific Cooperation in the field of Agriculture and Agri-food, with COA Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan and Canadian Deputy Minister of Agriculture and Agri-food Leonard Edwards witnessing.

COA officials said that the cooperation guideline will be a milestone for bilateral agricultural cooperation, which they said will help Taiwan upgrade its agricultural technology and competitive edge.
The officials noted that Taiwan signed the guideline for the cooperative program in agriculture cooperation in 1986, and Canada is the second country Taiwan has signed a similar pact with.

They pointed out that both countries will initially establish cooperation on such issues as plant breeders' rights protection, the research and development of health care and medical plants and reprocessing products, herbal plant germ plasm and its research and development, detection methodology of genetically modified crops, academic research and research and development of diagnostic methodology of exotic animals' infectious diseases, elite farm animal exchanges and international marketing.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING LOCAL CURRENCY WILL SLASH TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: A continuously appreciating new Taiwan dollar will deal a blow to the domestic export sector and drag down the country's economic growth, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research reported Monday.

If the local unit keeps on gaining value to the level of 30.07 to the U.S. dollar, Taiwan's export sector will be noticeably affected, slashing the country's economic growth rate from an originally targeted 4.37 percent by the institution to 3.82 percent for 2005, senior researcher Wang Su-wan said in an analysis published in an electronic newspaper run by the think tank for Taiwan businessmen.
According to Wang, the new Taiwan dollar will go on picking up in value against the U.S. dollar in the future, fueled by an influx of hot money from abroad on a weakening greenback.

As the United States is likely to give free rein to its currency over the long term due to its long-standing federal budget deficits and mounting trade gaps, Asian currencies, including the domestic unit, are expected to further appreciate for the foreseeable future, he said.

Citing statistics compiled by the central bank, he reported that the new Taiwan dollar has appreciated nearly 10 percent against the U.S. dollar since the beginning of this year. The 10 percent rise is less than the surges in value posted by the Japanese yen and the South Korean won, but far sharper if compared with mainland China's renminbi, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar.
The new Taiwan dollar first broke the 35 level to the U. S. dollar in July 2004. It closed at 31.56 against the greenback Monday in the Taipei foreign exchange market.
As a result of a continuously rising local unit, price quotations in new Taiwan dollar terms by domestic companies have dropped during the same time, Wang said.

According to tallies compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, export prices measured in new Taiwan dollars posted a negative fall in annual growth in February this year -- the first of its kind since May 2004.

Wang expressed worry that the environment at home is becoming increasingly difficult for companies to survive in the face of surging prices of oil and raw materials, coupled with the impact of a rising local currency on outbound shipments -- the backbone of Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSUMES 7 MILLION TONS OF TEA DRINKS PER YEAR: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A growing trend for health has made tea drinks the mainstream of Taiwan's soft drink consumption, with more than 7 million tons of tea drinks, said to be able to reduce body fat, drunk by consumers in the country every year on average.

According to the latest statistics produced by AC Nielsen, the world's leading provider of market research, information and analysis on consumer products, revenues of NT$15.7 billion (US$497.46 million) was generated in Taiwan's packed tea drink market last year, posing 4.4 percent growth over the previous year.

The record represented the best sales in Taiwan's soft drink market, while carbonated drinks, which used to be star performers, only generating about NT$8 billion for their makers in 2004, the statistics show.

Of the popular tea drinks, packs of the so-called "fat-killer" green tea generated revenues of NT$5.4 billion last year, followed by lemon-favored and juice-added tea drinks, according to the tallies.

Taiwan's tea drink consumption was mainly fanned by Japan's keen interest in catechin, an active compound in green tea that has been proved to be a powerful, water soluble polyphenol and antioxidant, according to local businessmen involved in the soft drink industry.

It is expected that Taiwan's tea drinks market will continue to follow the Japanese fad this year, with green tea beverages that makers claim can "shape the body and kill fat" to be the most popular tea drinks of the year, according to the AC Nielsen analysis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: U.S. Commanders See Possible Cut in Troops in Iraq.
Two years after the fall of Saddam Hussein, the American-led military campaign in Iraq is making enough progress in fighting insurgents and training Iraqi security forces to allow the Pentagon to plan for significant troop reductions by early next year, senior commanders and Pentagon officials say. Attacks on allied forces have dropped to 30 to 40 a day, down from an average daily peak of 140 in the prelude to the Jan. 30 elections but still roughly at the levels of a year ago. Only about half the attacks cause casualties or damage, but on average one or more Americans die in Iraq every day, often from roadside bombs. Thirty-six American troops died there in March, the lowest monthly death toll since 21 died in February 2004.
Wall Street Journal: Democracy Drive by America Meets Reality in Egypt.
The Middle East Partnership Initiative, an office under the State Department announced it was giving about US$1 million in grants to five local democracy groups in Egypt, a key U.S. ally with a notably authoritarian government. The democracy grants have created an uproar in Egypt. A pro-government weekly, Al Osboa, ran a scorching editorial on its front page, calling them "a unique event, an aberrant action and a major sin, " and accusing the groups that accepted them of being pro-Zionist, anti-Egyptian and anti-Arab. Imams at two big mosques branded the recipients servants of the American infidel. A committee of Egypt's parliament opened an investigation of what it saw as U.S. collusion with the grants' beneficiaries, and lawmakers are now weighing proposals to ban future foreign grants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECOND-LARGEST TOURIST SOURCE FOR JAPAN IN 2004
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was Japan's second-largest source of tourists last year, with over 1 million Taiwan people traveling there for sight-seeing, according to the newest statistics released recently by Japanese tourism authorities.
The number of tourists from Taiwan was second only to the 1.58 million from South Korea who visited Japan in 2004.

Japan braced for more than 6.13 million foreign tourist arrivals last year -- the highest level in history and a 17.8 percent growth over the 2003 level, the tallies show, with the number of Taiwan tourists increasing by 37.6 percent year to year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT JOURNALISTIC EXCHANGES STILL ONGOING: GIO

TEXT.P: Correspondent exchanges across the Taiwan Strait will continue despite the Mainland Affairs Council's (MAC's) decision to temporarily ban two Chinese media outlets from posting journalists in Taiwan, a senior official said Monday.

Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao made the remarks after MAC Chairman Joseph Wu announced a day earlier that China's state-run Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper will be banned from sending journalists to Taiwan for the time being because, he said, the two media outlets only air rumors or opinions from the "extreme ends of Taiwan's political spectrum."

Noting that China is not a country that values or upholds freedom of the press, Yao said the two official Chinese media outlets' coverage of Taiwan's news events, including the huge street march in Taipei March 26 against China's anti-secession law, has not helped China understand Taiwan society at all.

In the wake of China's enactment of its anti-secession law codifying the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, Yao said the MAC, the nation's top mainland policy planning agency, should take measures to rein in cross-strait exchanges.
According to Yao, the temporary ban has nothing to do with infringing upon press freedom, as has been claimed by some local critics.
In his view, Yao said, distorted, misleading or smearing Chinese reports about Taiwan are not conducive to cross-strait journalistic exchanges or the promotion of press freedom.
Yao further said the MAC's original aim of allowing Chinese media outlets to post reporters in Taiwan was to promote cross-strait mutual understanding.

However, he went on, the unbalanced reports written by Xinhua and People's Daily correspondents on political affairs in Taiwan have not helped the Chinese public know more about Taiwan. Their reports have not truthfully reflected the mainstream opinions of Taiwan, he added.
Despite the temporary ban on the two media outlets, Yao said the MAC has not banned other Chinese media organizations from sending journalists to Taiwan.

Yao said the GIO is hopeful that Chinese media outlets can truthfully convey the voices of the Taiwan people. If they can uphold this principle, he said, the GIO will be more than willing to assist in promoting cross-strait journalistic exchanges.
"In the long run, cross-strait journalistic exchanges will continue," he added.
As to when the ban on Xinhua and People's Daily correspondents will be lifted, Yao said that will be up to the MAC and national security authorities to decide.

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and People's Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television (CCTV) , China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST ACT CAUTIOUSLY WITH RISING NATIONALISM IN CHINA

TEXT.P: With nationalism on the rise in China, Taiwan should exercise great caution so as not to affect cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the operations of Taiwan businessmen in China, a scholar said Monday.

Professor Liu Pi-jung of Soochow University made the remarks while commenting on a spate of anti-Japanese activities in China, including calls for a boycott of Japanese products and angry protests in front of the Japanese embassy and missions there.
Liu claimed that nationalism started to bud in East Asia "this year," citing Japan, South Korea, China and Taiwan as examples, and saying that there have been clashes among these countries.

"The problem with nationalism is that it is easy to run unchecked after being incited," Liu said, adding that it will be worth watching to see if the spate of anti-Japanese activities, which have already swept over to Guangzhou and Shenzhen from Beijing, will continue to spread.

When the United States mistakenly bombed the Chinese embassy in Belgrade in 1999, Liu noted that while it also caused anti-U.S. feelings, the anger did not last long, mainly because China and the United States are less historically entwined.

But the complicated historical relations between China and Japan have whipped up anti-Japanese activities, Liu said, adding that the protests were the result of long-term territorial disputes, a recent fight over valuable resources in the East China Sea, Japan's bid to serve as a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, and a furor over a recently published Japanese textbook that China believes attempts to whitewash Japanese atrocities against other countries during World War II.
For China, anti-Japan and anti-Taiwan independence are "two political orthodox things, " Liu said, adding that Taiwan should exercise great caution amid such anti-Japanese feelings.

Liu said that a recent visit by the head of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union to a Tokyo shrine dedicated to the Imperial Army dead of World War II might lead the Chinese to link their anti-Japanese sentiment to their anti-Taiwan independence feelings.
If such feelings are incited, it will probably affect the operations of Taiwan businessmen in China, as well as cross-strait exchanges, he cautioned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COULD BE LOSER IN SOURING CHINA-JAPAN TIES: ACADEMIC

TEXT.P: If past experience is any measure, souring China-Japan ties will not make it easier for Taiwan to improve its relations with Japan, an academic specializing in China-Japan ties cautioned Monday.

"On the contrary, it often poses more difficulties for Taiwan to make any advancement in its non-official relationship with Japan, " said Ke Yu-chih, an associate researcher at the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University in Taipei.

This is because Japanese diplomats, who are extremely cautious, worry that their association with Taiwan will worsen their country's already strained ties with China, and prefer to shelf their dealings with Taiwan when they are in trouble with China, Ke explained.
But she didn't rule out the possibility for breakthroughs on specific issues between Taipei and Tokyo amid tensions between Japan and China.
In Ke's view, the recent anti-Japan protests in many Chinese cities will make a dent in bilateral trade over the short term, but its long term impact, if any, is currently unclear.

The Japan-bashing atmosphere prevailing on the mainland is a sign that the China-Japan friendship that culminated in a 1998 visit to Japan by former Chinese President Jiang Zemin is on the rocks, Ke said.

She attributed the recent anti-Japan protests to the great deal of strife between the two countries, such as Chinese anger over the way Japan has played down in new middle school history text books Japan's aggression against China during World War II, the territorial dispute in the Chinese East Sea, and China's worry about Japan's closer defense alliance with the United States, to name a few.

The demonstrations, of course, will cloud economic cooperation between the two countries, and bilateral talks on a free trade pact between Tokyo and Beijing, which was expected to begin this year is set to be shelved, Ke went on.

Although the possibility is slim for the two countries to improve their political ties in the short term, the possibility that they will sever ties because of the current troubles is even less in light of close economic ties between them, Ke said.

Noting that China is Japan's largest trading partner, with bilateral trade of US$168 billion, or 14.6 percent of China's total international trade last year, Ke said a severance of diplomatic ties would be a disaster for both Japan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE ACADEMICS SUGGEST WAYS TO GIVE TAIWAN ROLE IN U.N.
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chinese academics suggested ways to give Taiwan a role in the United Nations if Taiwan were to acknowledge Beijing's "one China" principle, according to members of a visiting group from the Taipei-based Foundation on International & Cross-Strait Studies.

An anonymous member of the group told CNA that some Chinese academics they met here Monday suggested that as long as there is an understanding between Taiwan and China that they will eventually unite someday, China's delegation to the United Nations should use a name and be made up of members agreed upon by both Taiwan and China.

But before Taiwan and China work out a way to assemble a delegation and a name for this delegation, China's seat at the United Nation should be represented by the People's Republic of China, said the sources.
The academics also said Taiwan could send its own delegations to international bodies other than the United Nations, according to the Taipei foundation member.
The Taiwan delegates quoted their Chinese contacts as saying that although the suggestions were only personal opinions, they are in line with China's Anti-Secession Law.

The sources said their contacts come from the Chinese Academy of Social Science in Shanghai, which is a think tank for the Chinese leadership with ideas that are usually more liberal than those of their Beijing colleagues.

The six-member Taiwan group led by Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Foundation for International and Cross-Strait Studies, has already visited Beijing and will fly on to Xiamen before returning to Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC TO DISCUSS '3 IN 1' ELECTION POSSIBILITY

TEXT.P: A discussion about the possible merging of three local-level elections into one will be held by the Central Election Commission (CEC) in Taipei April 13, officials said Monday.

CEC Vice Secretary-General Deng Tian-yo said the plan, to be carried out under the initiative by Premier Frank Hsieh, will see county magistrate and mayoral elections, city and county councillor elections and village and township head elections held at the end of the year, combined into one balloting day to save taxpayers significant amounts of money.
The CEC will invite its members, along with members of the Taiwan Provincial Election Commission, to attend the discussion session to decide whether executing such a plan will be possible, said Deng.
During the session, the participants will also examine the list of candidates running for election to the mission-oriented National Assembly.
If the proposal is supported, the CEC will notify the Taiwan Provincial Election Commission to carry it out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST STAND AGAINST BEIJING'S TACTICS: EX-PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan should stand its ground with China, even though Beijing is trying to use its clout with Taiwan businessmen operating in China to affect Taiwan government policy, former Premier Vincent Siew said Monday.
Siew made the remarks while speaking in Tainan, southern Taiwan, on new strategies for Taiwan's economic development.

He pointed out that the promotion of Taiwan as an Asia and Pacific operations hub is still the right direction, adding that Taiwan should make good use of its superb geographic position to become a linchpin of the region.
On the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Siew said they are very important to the country's economic development and that the China market should not be ignored.
However, he added that upgrading the competitiveness of Taiwan will rely on more effective integration and planning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-JAPANESE PROTESTS MAY AFFECT YEAR-END `ASEAN PLUS 3' SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April 11 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Recent anti-Japanese protests in China and South Korea could affect the atmosphere at the "ASEAN plus three" -- the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations plus China, Japan and South Korea -- when it convenes a summit at the end of this year, a scholar in China said Monday.

Yang Jian of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences said that a spate of anti-Japanese activities, including a call for boycotting Japanese products and protests in front of the Japanese embassy and missions, because of a furor over a recently published Japanese textbook might affect the atmosphere at the summit.
But he said that the anti-Japanese protests have not hindered the research work of the 13 countries prior to the East Asian summit.
He said that to promote the integration of ASEAN plus three, the research work has not stopped as a result of the strained relations between Tokyo, Beijing and Seoul.
Related research such as proposals on Asian currencies and bonds will be submitted at the summit, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE, FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN GROWS BY 10 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese and foreign investment approved in 2004 grew by more than 10 percent from the previous year, the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Monday.

Commission officials said that 1,149 investment proposals by overseas Chinese and foreigners were approved in 2004, totaling US$3.95 billion, which represents a growth of 6.59 percent in number of proposals and a 10.55 percent increase in monetary value from the year-earlier level.
The officials said that the government will continue to organize delegations to Europe, the United States, and Japan this year to solicit further investment.
The government will also sponsor an international business conference September 22, with nanotechnology and its industry applications as its theme.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO LIFT NEWS BLACKOUT ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The government's decision to temporarily ban two Chinese media outlets from posting journalists in Taiwan has nothing to do with restrictions on freedom of the press, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng said Monday.

According to Huang, the decision to ban China's state-run Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper from sending correspondents to Taiwan for the time being is part of the government's efforts to "effectively manage" exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Noting that "active opening, effective management" remains the government's fundamental cross-strait policy, Huang said the temporary ban was adopted in tune with this guideline.
"The temporary ban is part of our efforts to maintain the order of cross-strait journalistic exchanges and has nothing to do with freedom of the press," Huang explained.

He said it is China that has spared no efforts to suppress freedom of the press. In addition to blacking out reports about Taiwan, he said, China has suppressed reform-minded Chinese newspapers, concealed recent farmers' riots in Sichuan Province, and ordered the closure of Peking University's and Tsinghua University's BBS Websites.

If China can meet the standards outlined by the International Press Association for press freedom, such as free access to media information, free transmission of news information, free publication of newspapers and free expression of opinions, Huang said, a barrier-free environment for cross-strait journalistic exchanges can be realized immediately.

Before such a day comes, Huang said he hopes the Chinese authorities will at least lift its blackout against the online Internet editions of Taiwan's two major newspapers -- China Times and the United Daily News.
Meanwhile, Huang said, the government will not waver on its resolve to promote constructive cross-strait journalistic exchanges.
Despite the temporary ban on the two media outlets, Huang said the government has not banned other Chinese media organizations from sending journalists to Taiwan.
Moreover, he said, the MAC is studying the feasibility of allowing reform-minded Chinese media outlets to post journalists in Taiwan.
"We'll announce the evaluation results when the time is ripe," he added.

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and People's Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television (CCTV) , China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO PROMOTE FINANCIAL MARKET INTEGRATION

TEXT.P: A government plan to speed up integration among Taiwan's financial institutions will continue to be promoted, officials said Monday.
During a presentation, Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng said that the financial markets are to be integrated through mergers of banks, stock companies and insurance firms.
Kong was attending a conference to brief ruling Democratic Progressive Party representatives on the domestic financial market situation and the government's integration plans.

To encourage institutions to integrate, the government has begun a plan to allow Taiwan-based banks with a market share of over 10 percent in the country to get early approval to set up overseas branches and purchase foreign banks. These banks will also be automatically allowed to move their branches to other locations, according to the reports made during the presentation.
Kong said Taiwan's financial market still has room for integration as none of the 14 domestic financial holding companies have a market share of more than 10 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN VISIT SYMBOLIZES WORLD RECOGNITION OF TAIWAN: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday his historic visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral last week symbolized the world's recognition of Taiwan's long-term efforts at pursuing democracy, human rights, peace and justice.
Chen made the remarks while receiving a group of model children from impoverished families.

Describing his attendance at the pope's funeral as being of profound significance, Chen said that "our long-time efforts in pursuing these universal values are also our best gifts to commemorate the pope, " adding that he is grateful for the courteous treatment accorded to him and his entourage by the Holy See and the Italian government during the whirlwind 19-hour visit to the Vatican -- Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
Chen also took the opportunity to reaffirm the government's determination to promote children's welfare services, particularly assistance to those from impoverished families.
Chen said the Children's Bureau under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has set up a "Dear Kids" welfare bank account to receive donations from the private sector to help disadvantaged children.
Chen said he will raise funds for the account and that the MOI expects to raise NT$200 million this year alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 12 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, April 12:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
10: 30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
11: 00, New Guatemalan Ambassador to Taiwan Ricardo Putzeys Uriguen will present his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office.
11: 30, Vice President Annette Lu will meet her Salvadoran counterpart Ana Vilma de Escobar at the Presidential Office.
12: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will host a luncheon party at the Presidential Office for her Salvadoran counterpart Ana Vilma de Escobar.
13: 30, The ruling Democratic Progressive Party will hold its weekly Central Standing Committee meeting at the party's headquarters.
13: 30, A news conference on an education cooperation program between the Ministry of Education and Intel will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
14:30, Vice President Annette Lu will plant the national tree of El Salvador at the "Latin Park" near the Presidential Office.
16: 00, The Banking Bureau under the Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
16: 00, The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
16:00, The Department of Navigation and Aviation of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the Hualien Harbor Bureau will hold a joint news conference at the MOTC headquarters.
16: 20, The Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China will hold a news conference at the bank's headquarters.
16: 30, The Directorate General of Customs will hold a news conference at the Ministry of Finance.
16:30, Ambassador of the Dominican Republic Victor Manuel Sanchez Pena will visit Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou at Taipei City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF LAUDS PRESIDENT'S INCLUSION IN TIME'S 2005 TOP 100

TEXT.P: The fact that President Chen Shui-bian made it onto Time magazine's 2005 top 100 list is further evidence of his achievements in leading the country onto the world stage, Government Information Office (GIO) Minister Pasuya Wen-chih Yao said Monday.
He claimed that some local media erroneously translated Time's English citation of Chen as "the president who has led Taiwan to the brink of war."

As a matter of fact, Yao said, China, which enacted a law to give itself the right to attack Taiwan in defiance of worldwide opposition, should be responsible for the crisis of war that looms large across the Taiwan Strait.

On the other hand, Chen who refuses to compromise on Taiwan's sovereignty despite his full understanding that the international situation is not favorable for the country's diplomacy, has spared no efforts to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Describing Chen a leader with a good grasp of public opinion, Yao said the president knows the importance of stability across the strait and has reiterated many times his determination to improve ties with China.

He cited as proof the president's promises, made in his 2000 inaugural address, to refrain from moving Taiwan toward independence, and his declaration in 2004 that his administration is willing to advance ties with China on the basis of the two sides' 1992 talks.
"All these prove that the president is a pragmatic leader with the determination to improve ties with China," the GIO chief said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT TO BE URGED AGAINST LIFTING ARMS EMBARGO ON CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 11 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-hsiao & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The international relations committee of the European Parliament is expected to recommend Tuesday in Strasbourg against the lifting of an arms embargo against China, according to news reports in Paris.
The European Parliament opened in Strasbourg Monday and Elmar Brok, the German chairman of the international relations committee, is slated to give a briefing on the embargo.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO WAIVE FORMALITIES IN MEETING WITH KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will consult with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan in lining up a meeting between them over Lien's planned trip to China, an aide to the president said Monday.
Huang Chih-fang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said his office will cut corners on formalities in working out details about the meeting with Lien's aides.

He made the comment after KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng noted that Lien has not ruled out the possibility of meeting with the president, who has said he will support Lien's visit to China as long as the opposition leader exchanges views with him before he goes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 12, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. AMBASSADOR TO U.N. NOMINEE SUPPORTS TAIWAN'S WHA BID
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A ranking U.S. State Department official, who has been nominated for the post of U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said Monday that he supports Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly, the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization, as an observer.

John Bolton, the incumbent under secretary of state for arms control and international security, voiced his support for Taiwan's bid while attending a U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on his nomination.
Bolton has said before that Taiwan meets the requirements of statehood to join the United Nations.

In his confirmation hearing to become under secretary of state in 2001, Bolton had also said that he felt the admission of Taiwan to the United Nations would be consistent with the United States' one-China policy.

In response to questions raised by Sen. Lincoln Chafee (R-R.I.) at the hearing, Bolton said that the comments he had made on Taiwan represented his opinion as a private citizen and that he does not "back away" from his remarks.
However, he also said that he would accept and follow U.S. President George W. Bush's stance on cross-Taiwan Strait policy.

"President Bush has expressed his view on the relationship between Taiwan and China. He's made it clear that the administration supports Taiwan as an observer in the World Health Organization but that he doesn't go beyond that. And I accept that, " Bolton said.
"I know what the president's policy, and I'm prepared to follow it," he added.
Bolton was nominated last month by President Bush for the post of U.S. representative to the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGED TO SPEAK FOR HUMAN RIGHTS DURING CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should speak for those whose basic human rights or religious freedom have been oppressed by the Chinese government during his planned China visit, a ruling party legislative whip said Tuesday.

Chen Ching-jun, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus, said at a news conference that 50.5 percent of the respondents in a just-released public opinion poll voiced opposition to Lien's planned trip to China to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, compared to 36.7 percent who gave a thumbs-up to Lien's travel plan.

"The poll results indicate that more than half of the Taiwan people don't support Lien's planned China visit, " Chen said, adding that if Lien insists on his travel plan in defiance of mainstream public opinion, he should be courageous enough to ask the top Chinese leaders to stop human rights abuse and cease suppression of Falun Gong and Catholic followers.
Speaking on the same occasion, William C.T. Lai, also a DPP legislative whip, said he hopes Lien can meet with President Chen Shui-bian before traveling to China to meet with the Chinese leader.

"Forging a national consensus on relations across the Taiwan Strait should precede negotiations with China. We hope Lien can make a positive response to the president's call for an inter-party summit to shape a domestic consensus before his China trip for the sake of safeguarding the ultimate national interest," Lai added.

In a speech delivered at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport last weekend upon his return from a historic visit to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, Chen said he is willing to support Lien's planned China visit and authorize Lien to talk with Chinese authorities on certain issues so long as Lien meets with him prior to his departure for the mainland.
Lien issued a publis statement Monday saying that his mainland visit doesn't require the govenrment's authorization because he is now a private citizen and will visit China as KMT chairman.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Wages Lagging Behind Prices. For the first time in 14 years,the American workforce has in effect gotten an across-the- board pay cut. The growth in wages in 2004 and the first two months of this year trailed inflation, compounding the squeeze from higher housing, energy and other costs. The result is that people are finding themselves falling behind.

Philippine National Police chief, Director General Arturo Lomibao said, terrorist groups appear to have adopted a pattern of mounting a major attack every six months, the country's top cop warned Monday.
