DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WHO BID SHOULD NOT BE AFFECTED BY CHINA: U.S. SENATOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's admission into the World Health Organization (WHO) would be "very helpful" for global health, and China's "paranoia" about the matter should not affect Taiwan's bid to join the body, U.S. Sen. George Allen said Monday.
Allen made the comments during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on John Bolton's nomination for the post of U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

Bolton, the incumbent undersecretary of state for arms control and international security, said while responding to questions raised by the senator that he supports the Bush administration's position in support of Taiwan becoming an observer in the WHO.

Allen also voiced his support for Taiwan's bid during the hearing. "I'd be personally happy if they were a member, but if we can have them as an observer, they certainly ought to be involved. Especially with the SARS epidemic, they can be very, very helpful, " he said.
"And the fact that China is so paranoid about it should not be of any consequence when we're concerned about world health," the senator added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG WILLING TO QUIT KMT CHAIRMANSHIP RACE IF LIEN SEEKS 2ND TERM

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that he is willing to quit the Kuomintang (KMT) chairmanship race if incumbent KMT Chairman Lien Chan decides to seek a second term.
Wang, who is one of the KMT's five vice chairmen, said that he will immediately pull out of the race should Lien announce his decision to seek a second term in the post through a vote in the party.

Wang said, however, that he will continue with his campaign for the party's top post as scheduled despite an endorsement launched by various city and county council speakers and deputy speakers of KMT affiliation calling on Lien to take part in the party's election for chairmanship on July 16.
If Lien really seeks a second term, it will help assuage grave public concern over the party's future, Wang pointed out.

He also brushed aside speculation that the race between himself and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou for the party chairmanship could cause a split in the KMT, saying that it will be a "gentlemen's race" and that both he and Ma will do their best to gain greater public support for the party.
Yunlin County Council Speaker Chen Ching-hsiu, who initiated the endorsement, urged Lien to seek a second term to unite the party.

To avoid a split in the KMT and to secure victory in December's city and county chief elections as well as to better the KMT's chances in the 2008 presidential election, Lien should continue serving as the party's head, Chen said in the statement.
KMT spokeswoman Cheng Lee-wen said that the party headquarters will maintain neutrality in the vote for the next chairman and that the election will be held in compliance with the party's rules.
Commenting on the grass-roots support for Lien to remain as chairman, Cheng said that it is entirely up to Lien whether or not to enter the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER CALLS FOR FINGERPRINT REQUIREMENT TO REMAIN IN PLACE

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Tuesday urged the Legislative Yuan not to review an amendment to the household registration law, saying that the requirement for citizens to be fingerprinted when claiming a new identification card should remain in place.

DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang made the remarks amid public concerns about social order after two policemen were attacked from behind in broad daylight while patrolling the streets in Hsihchih, Taipei County. One of the police officers was killed and the other seriously injured in the attack.
Under the current law, citizens will be required to be fingerprinted when claiming the new version of the ID card which is set to be launched July 1.
The Executive Yuan recently proposed a package of revisions to the household registration law to remove the fingerprint requirement due to pressure from human rights organizations.
Tsai stressed the importance of establishing a national fingerprint data bank, saying that it would save costs and resources in police work to track down criminals.

"Human rights cannot be used as a pretext for not setting up such a data bank, " Tsai said, adding that effective use of current technology to secure personal information could prevent any potential human rights abuses.
"It is regrettable that the Executive Yuan wants to revise the law to remove the fingerprint requirement when social order is getting worse," Tsai said.
While asking the Legislative Yuan to shelve the draft revision package put forward by the Executive Yuan, Tsai said that it would be better if the Executive Yuan itself withdrew the bill.

Meanwhile, William C.T. Lai, DPP party whip in the legislature, called for a national conference on social order to be held to invite experts to discuss and review ways to improve social order, including revising laws, improving police forces and their equipment, and promoting relevant education and the importance of family.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO HUNT DOWN COP KILLERS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Tuesday expressed his regret over the recent attack by two assailants on two police officers in which one of the officers was killed and the other seriously injured.
Hsieh made the remarks while answering lawmakers' questions in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan. He pledged to make full efforts in hunting down the two assailants.

Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the opposition People First Party accused Hsieh of contributing to the police force's failure to capture the assailants in the hours after the crime, claiming that many police officers had been assigned to protecting the premier who was taking part in a public activity nearby at the time. Lin's charge was later denied by Taipei city police authorities.

The two policemen, Hung Chung-nan, 30, and Chang Ta-hao, 31, were stabbed from behind by two men while on patrol in Hsihchih, Taipei County Sunday. Chang's gun and 12 rounds of ammunition were taken, while Hung fought to defend his weapon. Hung bled to death after being stabbed 15 times, and Chang was wounded badly.

According to a surveillance video released Monday, the two assailants, both of whom are about 170 cm tall, were wearing full-face motorcycle helmets at the time of the attack. They sped of on motorcycle after the attack.
At the time of the attack, the premier was in Nankang, a Taipei City district located next to Hsihchih township.

Hsieh said he believes that no Taipei County police officers were summoned to protect him during his visit to the district. Nevertheless, he said he will seek the relevant authorities' confirmation in the matter. He stressed that as premier of the country, he is responsible for maintaining social order.

The premier said he will ask relevant law enforcement units to carry out a general review of social order problems every three months, noting that he is confident that the assailants in Sunday's attack will soon be captured by police.

Police are asking the public to come forward with any information in the cop killing case and are offering a cash reward of NT$500,000 (US$15,873) for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the suspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 14.47 points to close at 5,993.89.
The bourse opened at 5,974.71 and fluctuated between 5,995.93 and 5,955.24 during trading. A total of 1.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$43.59 billion (US$1.38 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving up the most at 0.4 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 0.3 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.2 percent.

Four other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 471 to 357, with 184 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE-DAY ANTI-TERRORISM DRILL TO BEGIN WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh will lead all Cabinet members to take part in a three-day anti-terrorism drill starting Wednesday.

The drill will be held at Hengshan command post, a tightly guarded command center in Tachih on the outskirts of Taipei, officials from a counter-terrorism action office under the Executive Yuan revealed Tuesday.
Officials said the drill will consist of a computer simulation on the scenario of Taiwan being attacked by terrorists.
Premier Hsieh said in an interpellation at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that the Presidential Office will announce if President Chen Shui-bian will attend the anti-terrorism drill.

Speaking on the same occasion, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye said that the anti-terrorism drill will be conducted by the Executive Yuan, with Premier Hsieh as the convener, in the first half of the year, while the annual military drill -- the "Hankuang" exercises -- will be held later this year, which will also include an anti-decapitation strike drill.
Asked whether "Hankuang" live-fire maneuvers will raise cross-strait tensions, Hsieh said the annual drills are needed and everyone should take them in stride.

Decapitation strategies short-circuit command and control systems, wipe out nationwide nerve centers and leave the opponent hopelessly immobilized. Many military observers say the mainland is very likely to use this strategy to invade Taiwan by seizing the island's center of power, the capital, and its top leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. SEES DIFFICULTIES IN LIFTING ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA: MOFA

TEXT.P: The European Union (E. U.) has seen growing difficulties regarding a proposed lifting of its arms embargo against mainland China following Beijing's enactment of the Anti- Secession Law against Taiwan, an official from Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday.

Larry Yu-yuan Wang, director-general of the MOFA's European Affairs Department, said that the E.U. feels that it is more difficult to make the move in the wake of the March 14 enactment of the law which authorizes the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should the island move toward formal independence.
Citing public response in Britain to Beijing's enactment of the law, Wang pointed out that the E. U. has changed its original stance of aiming to lift the ban in the second half of this year.

As Britain will assume the E.U.'s rotating presidency in the second half of 2005, observers see a number of uncertainties standing in the way of the E.U. lifting the ban due to Britain's close links with the United States, Wang said, adding that the MOFA's outposts will continue to closely monitor developments.

Wang's comments came one day after a Hong Kong media report that China will purchase 210 Mirage 2000-9CS fighters from France after the E. U. lifts its ban on weapons exports to China. The ban was imposed in the aftermath of the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tianamen Square in June 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPSU OPPOSED TO CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENT

TEXT.P: The Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NPSU) said Tuesday that a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last year will be detrimental to small parties.
NPSU Chairwoman Chang Po-ya made the remarks when she introduced her party's aspirants for the May 14 election of the mission-oriented National Assembly and solicited public support for them.
Chang noted that the NPSU was the only political party that was opposed to a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan during an extraordinary meeting last August.

A total of 300 delegates to the ad hoc National Assembly will be elected on May 14, whose mission will be to approve a package of constitutional amendments passed by the legislature -- including cutting the 225-seat Legislative Yuan by almost half, changing the election system to a "single seat, two votes" formula from the present "multi-seat" one, abolishing the National Assembly and redefining the right to hold a referendum which is in the ROC Constitution.

Chang said that the proposed new election system will squeeze out the small parties that represent the voice of the underprivileged and minority groups, which she said is not favorable to the pluralistic, democratic development of the nation.

Among the NPSU aspirants, the second generation political figures are most noticeable, including Yen Kuang-heng, son of Legislator Yen Chin-piao; Chen Hsiu-pao, daughter of Legislator Chen Chin-ting; and Shih Nai-yuan, son of former Hsinchu Mayor Shih Hsin-chung.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 10 points to close at 5,990, with 14,469 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 10 points to finish at 5,995, with 810 contracts traded, while June futures gained one point to finish at 5,975, with 69 contracts traded.
September futures lost one point to finish at 5,854, with 607 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 14 points to close at 5,843, with 21 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,980 for April, 5,985 for May, 5,974 for June, 5,855 for September and 5,857 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures moved up 0.9 points to close at 233.2, with 1,797 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained 1.15 points to finish at 233.25, with 89 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 0.7 points to close at 232.75, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

April TF futures gained 2.2 points to finish at 955.2, with 2,385 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved up 2.8 points to end at 955.4, with 406 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down 2.4 points to finish at 954.2, with one contract transaction, while December TF futures gained three points to end at 953.8, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS REVIEW OF SOCIAL ORDER EVERY 3 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Tuesday ordered a review of social order every three months following several criminal cases that have seriously affected the public's faith in social order.

Hsieh, while responding to interpellations made by opposition Kuomintang Legislator Alex Fai, noted that he had instructed police authorities to review social order every three months and asked them to present some "fruitful results" in the near future.

Hsieh, who has set cracking down on fraud and intimidation his priority job in improving social order while assuming the premiership in February, made the promise with infamous kidnapper Chang Hsih-ming still at large and two men who attacked two police - leaving on dead - yet to be caught.
Noting that several accomplices of Chang have been apprehended, Hsieh expressed regret over the attack on the policemen.
Stressing that the assault on the police officers was a unique case, the premier said he has faith that the two will be captured soon.
Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan also promised to address social order.

The premier noted that although several ministers of the interior have stepped down due to the deteriorating social order, social problems still loom. Hsieh stressed that resolving this problem does not rely on promises but on substantial action.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONTINUES PUSHING FOR HD DVD FORMAT

TEXT.P: In a DVD conference in which representatives from various countries discussed a wide range of DVD-related issues at Taipei's Grand Formosa Regent Hotel Tuesday, Taiwan's top technological research institute openly promoted the HD DVD format to be the main format on behalf of Taiwanese firms.

Representatives of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) as well as from over 21 domestic and international firms attended the conference. The ITRI vowed to promote the High Definition DVD (HD DVD) format, which Taiwan supports, to be the mainstream in a global format battle that feature HD DVD and the Blu-ray DVD.
Topics including progress, authorization and marketing strategies of new DVD formats were also brought up during the ITRI-held meeting.

Deputy Director of ITRI's Opto-Electronics & Systems Laboratories Huang Teh-rei said ITRI's participation in developing the HD DVD format shows Taiwan's aspiration to get on the ground floor of the international information industry.
Twenty-one firms from around the globe also displayed their latest DVD-related products at the conference, including HD DVD discs and optical drives.

Huang said that ITRI hopes successful global adoption of the HD disc format will benefit Taiwanese optical disc manufacturers by reducing significant amounts of royalties paid to Toshiba and NEC, whose HD DVD competes with Blu-ray discs developed by Sony and Panasonic.

Supporters of the HD DVD format claims that it can hold up to 25 gigabytes of information, while the Blu-ray discs can store up to 50 gigabytes. Current DVD discs have only about 5-10 gigabytes of capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS CALL FOR EFFECTIVE STEPS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC ORDER

TEXT.P: The government should take immediate steps to improve public order after a spate of outrageous criminal cases were reported in recent days, a group of opposition People First Party (PFP) legislators said Tuesday.

The PFP lawmakers, including Lee Hung-chun, Chang Hsien-yao and Wu Ching-che, suggested at a news conference that the National Police Administration, the Coast Guard Administration, the National Fire Administration and the proposed Immigration Administration be integrated into a single agency under the direct jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan to upgrade crime-fighting efficiency.
At present, the National Police Administration is under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of the Interior.

Lee said that after two policemen were assaulted in broad daylight while patrolling the streets in Hsihchih, Taipei County Sunday, the government should call a national crime-fighting conference immediately to hammer out effective measures to reduce crimes and better protect the safety of police officers. In the Sunday assault, one of the police officers was killed and the other seriously injured.
Quoting official tallies, Lee said 1,659 police officers were either killed or injured between 2002 and 2004, accounting for 2.5 percent of the nation's total police force.
"The ratio ranks among the world's highest, indicating that our public order has worsened steadily, " Lee said, adding that the government should pay more heed to the situation.

In addition to upgrading the National Police Administration and purchasing advanced crime-fighting equipment, Lee suggested that the government set up a NT$3 billion police fund to care for injured police officers and their families as well as bereaved families of policemen killed in the line of duty.

"By setting up the fund, we'll be able to offer better welfare services to policemen who were injured on duty or the families of police officers killed on duty," Lee said, adding that the measure is also expected to help boost the morale of all police personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN VICE PRESIDENT VISITS CHUNGHWA TELECOM

TEXT.P: Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma Albanez de Escobar visited Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. Tuesday, with the two sides agreeing to set up cooperative joint ventures to explore business opportunities.
Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Ho Cheng-tan warmly received De Escobar and company officials gave her a briefing on the company's operations.

According to Ho following his meeting with the distinguished guest from El Salvador, the Salvadoran government has concrete plans to promote its telecommunications sector, including building an information highway and becoming an electricity and telecommunications hub in Central and South America.

Chunghwa Telecom is very willing to help in developing an e-government and fostering skilled professionals in the field for that country -- one of the Republic of China's staunch diplomatic allies in Central America, Ho said, adding that by sharing its development experience with El Salvador, the company can reach further and seek fresh business and investment opportunities abroad.
Chunghwa Telecom is Taiwan's largest provider of telecommunications services.
Traveling at the head of a 12-member delegation, De Escobar is currently on a visit to Taiwan at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO ACT ACCORDING TO LAW ON CITY SUMMIT MEETING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Tuesday that if Taiwan city mayors apply to attend the fifth Asia-Pacific Cities Summit (APCS), which will be held in October in Chongqing, Sichuan, this October, the MAC will deal with the applications according to the law.

Reports quoted Chongqing Mayor Wang Hongju as saying to visiting Hong Kong media representatives Monday that he had sent invitation letters to eight Taiwan mayors to attend the summit meeting Oct. 11-14, but he wouldn't divulge the names of the mayors, saying that they include mayors of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Wang stressed that as long as they are members of the APCS, his city will send invitation letters, irrespective of the political backgrounds of the mayors, adding that the meeting will be mainly to discuss issues of mutual concern of the mayors.

Asked whether acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai of the DPP was invited, Wang only said that it is not appropriate to reveal which ones accepted invitation and which ones refused to come, but the names will definitely be made public later.
MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said that the MAC has yet to verify the news and has no further information.

But he said that if mayors in Taiwan receive similar invitations, and apply with the MAC, it will deal with the matter according to law -- mainly the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, and regulations governing civil servants and people in special posts entering the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SHOULD NOMINATE NCC MEMBERS: GIO HEAD

TEXT.P: The head of the Government Information Office (GIO) said Tuesday that he hopes members of a proposed National Communications Commission (NCC) will be nominated by the premier, and not be nominated in proportion to the seats of various political parties in the Legislative Yuan.
Pasuya Yao made the remarks when he attended a seminar sponsored by legislators keen on the legislation of technology bills in the Legislative Yuan.

Yao said that he is willing to serve as the last chief of the GIO, but the premise will be the draft organic law of the NCC and the draft organic law of the Executive Yuan will pass the legislature soon.

The opposition parties' version of the draft organic law of the NCC stipulates that the members of the proposed commission will be produced in the same way as the members of the Central Election Commission (CEC), which should be produced through nominations in proportion to the seats of the political parties in the legislature.

Yao noted that the CEC is a political organ, and the members will have to take political factors into consideration, but the NCC will be a professional body, and its members should be nominated by the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTDTV SEEKS TAIWAN'S SUPPORT FOR RIGHT TO BROADCAST INTO CHINA

TEXT.P: A representative of the U.S.-based Chinese-language New Tang Dynasty Television (NTDTV) station called on the people of Taiwan on Tuesday to support the company's fight for freedom of communication, which the representative claimed has been jeopardized because of China's suppression.

Liu Ying-chuan made the appeal ahead of the scheduled termination on April 15 of a contract between NTDTV and European satellite operator Eutelsat. NTDTV claims that Eutelsat has refused to renew the contract under pressure from China.
According to Liu, NTDTV has since March 2004 leased an Asian satellite channel from Eutelsat to broadcast uncensored programs into China.

Liu said Beijing is unhappy with NTDTV's reporting on Chinese persecution of dissidents and religious groups and has tempted Eutelsat to end its contract with NTDTV in exchange for a deal to broadcast the 2008 Olympic Games.

Liu argued that Chinese suppression of freedom of the media and information will lead to internal conflicts in China and pose a threat to the overseas Chinese community and the international community.

With the United States being a major client of Eutelsat, she asked the Taiwan people to write to U.S. President George W. Bush or support a NTDTV signature campaign to push Eutelsat to change its decision.
Beijing has denounced NTDTV -- whose staff include a number of Falun Gong practitioners -- as a mouthpiece for the cult that has been outlawed by China.

Chang Chin-hua, a professor of journalism at National Taiwan University, who is also a leading member of the Falun Gong organization in Taiwan, said while Taiwan's decision to temporarily ban China's state-run Xinhua news agency and People's Daily from posting reporters on the island has raised widespread discussions on media freedom, the people of Taiwan seldom pay attention to suppression of media freedom in China.
Chang said the NTDTV incident is a typical case of suppression of media freedom and she urged the Taiwan people to support NTDTV's cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: WAYWARD KIDS GET OLYMPIC LESSON

TEXT.P: An Olympic gold medalist in taekwondo who had a sorted youth, shared her experiences of overcoming frustration and finding a way toward a better path of life to 50 kids at a reformatory school in a seminar Tuesday.

Chen Shih-hsin, 27, was invited by the Taichung District Court to meet the juvenile delinquents, helping them learn to see the world with the right view of life and values, and assist them to walk out the shadow of their lives.

Chen said that she was wild as a youngster, noting she ran away from home and stayed away three years. During those years, she worked as a betel nut vendor, and also once sold goods as a vendor on the street; and thank God, she did not make mistakes large enough for her to be sent to a reformatory school, Chen recalled.

The star athlete told the kids that she decided to resume taekwondo lessons that she had started at the age of five, after discovering that all her wayward ways had done her no good. By that time, she began to learn how to cherish her life and establish a good career as a taekwondo athlete, Chen said.

In the meeting with the youngsters now at a crossroads, the Olympic medal-winner encouraged them to find out who they are and what they can do, and not to be afraid of experiencing frustration and failures while facing life's challenges.
Chen won the women's under 49kg taekwondo gold medal at the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, Taiwan's first Olympic gold medal.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAIRMAN LIEN REMAINS FIRM ON STEPPING DOWN IN AUGUST: KMT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan remains firm in his decision to step down from the party's top post in August, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said Tuesday.

Lin's remarks came after an endorsement, launched by various city and county council speakers and deputy speakers calling on Lien to continue serving as KMT head by taking part in a party election for the next chairman set for July 16, was made public earlier the same day by the local media.
The endorsement, initiated by Yunlin County Council Speaker Chen Ching-hsiu, urged Lien to seek a second term through a vote in the party for the sake of the party's unity and future.
According to Lin, Lien is very grateful for the warm support from the public. But he added that Lien "remains unchanged for the time being on his decision to quit the post."

The endorsement came at a time when the competition between Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou for the KMT chairmanship is becoming fiercer and fiercer, with both kicking off campaigning to seek greater backing from party members.
After learning the news about the endorsement, Wang said earlier the same day that he is willing to quit the race if Lien decides to seek re-election.
Ma, however, was reluctant to give a clear response to the news, saying only that he could not answer a hypothetic question.
Ma and Wang are two of the KMT's five vice chairmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: STORM IN A SOUP CUP NOTHING TO GET STEAMED ABOUT SAYS MOFA TO ALLIES

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and its African allies have not been affected by a recent episode involving decorative designs on soup cups used at a luncheon in honor of their envoys stationed in Taipei, an official said Tuesday.
"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has apologized for the incident, which has not affected our interactions and existing relations with our African allies," said MOFA spokesman Michel Lu.

According to media reports, ambassadors of the ROC's African allies, including Swaziland, Malawi, Chad, Senegal and Sao Tome and Principe, were annoyed by cartoon motifs on bouillon cups used at a luncheon in their honor during their inspection tour of the Penchou Industrial Park in the southern county of Kaohsiung April 7.

The decorative designs featured a person playing with animals, including a lion, a jellyfish, a starfish and a giraffe. Although the person looked Oriental, the cup was printed with "African Natives."
The ambassadors reportedly felt humiliated by the design. They were especially irritated by the jellyfish decoration because jellyfish is a pun for " men with no guts," media reports said.

Commenting on the reports, Lu said the African envoys indeed reacted unhappily upon seeing the motifs on the soup cups. But after talking things out, Lu said they accepted the explanations given by officials of the Kaohsiung County Government's information department.
According to Lu, the luncheon was arranged by the county government's media officials.
"The table settings were used naturally and they didn't have any ill intentions. They thought the decorative designs were interesting and lovely," Lu said.
The foreign envoys later accepted MOFA's apology and completed their schedule, Lu said, adding that the episode didn't affect the ROC's relations with its African allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY WATCHING DEVELOPMENT OF VATICAN-CHINA TIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is closely watching the possible development of relations between the Vatican and China, an official said Tuesday.

Larry Wang, director-general of the ministry's Department of European Affairs, pointed out that it has been a long-standing policy of the Holy See to try to enhance its relations with Beijing in order to protect religious freedom and Catholics in China.
While this policy will continue regardless of who will be the next pope, the ministry will keep a close watch on the situation, Wang said.

According to Wang, the arrangement of President Chen Shui-bian's trip to the Vatican for the funeral of late Pope John Paul II last week involved a lot of difficulties because of the limited time available.
However, the Holy See was friendly to Taipei and respected Taiwan's decisions in the process, he said.
The Vatican is the only European country that maintains diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INVITES GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIWAN IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday extended an invitation to Guatemalan President Oscar Berger to visit Taiwan in August.
Chen made the invitation while receiving new Guatemalan Ambassador Ricardo Putzeys Uriguen, who presented his credentials to Chen the same day.

Chen invited Berger to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) in August. The DPU, initiated by Vice President Annette Lu, aims to promote democracy, peace and prosperity among Pacific nations.
Expressing his welcome to Putzeys to Taiwan, Chen noted that the Republic of China and Guatemala have maintained diplomatic ties for more than 70 years.

"The cordial ties between the two countries rely on their shared values in liberty, democracy and human rights, " Chen said, adding that although the two nations are geographically far apart, the hearts of their people are closely linked as they have common expectations in many aspects, such as maintaining regional peace and stability.

The president expressed gratitude to Berger for his long-term support to Taiwan's bid to join international organizations, especially the World Trade Organization (WTO) . Taiwan joined the WTO in 2002, making it the 144th member.
Expressing Taiwan's hope to contribute to the world community, Chen said the island is now working hard to enter the World Health Organization (WHO), and still needs the support from Guatemala.

While hailing Berger's brilliant leadership in governing Guatemala, Chen also made known the ROC government's hope to make contributions to the Central American country's infrastructure, such as highway construction projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO COMMEMORATE EINSTEIN IN GLOBAL CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Ahead of the 100th anniversary of the publication of Albert Einstein's special theory of relativity, the Ministry of Education (MOE) has invited the public to participate in a global "Physics Enlightens the World" activity April 19 in memory of the great physicist.

The worldwide event, initiated jointly by two Austrian professors, Max E. Lippitsch and Sonja Draxler of the Karl-Frenzens Universitat, will see 44 countries across the globe "light up" the same time. Taiwan will also "light up" in symbolic locations including at the Taipei 101 April 19 at 7 p.m. local time.

The education ministry said the public has a variety of ways to participate in the campaign. People can log onto the Internet to "light up" online, or send a short message with their cellular phones to "light up" Taiwan's light on a world map.

Taiwan will begin the activity at 6: 40 p.m. in Hualien, then relay it to Kaohsiung's National Science and Technology Museum, followed by Tainan City at a canal, the Tainan County Government plaza, the Great Buddha Sculpture in Bagua Mountain in Changhua County, Taichung National Museum of Natural Science, Hsinchu Synchronized Radioactivity Center, Taipei 101, and the Yushan Lu-lin Observatory.
A series of other activities will also be held in locations across Taiwan. Log onto http: //419.com.tw for more information about the campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT DISCUSSION ON PRODUCE EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Tuesday urged China to hold ameeting with Taiwan to discuss details of exporting Taiwan's agricultural products into the mainland in order to uphold Taiwanese farmers' rights.

During a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said the government does not restrict agricultural products to be exported to China. However, he added, Taiwanese farmers' rights cannot be assured if the government's participation in cross-strait trade and exports is not visible.

He made the remarks in response to an opposition Kuomintang legislator who said he hopes the government will help Taiwanese farmers make inroads into China's produce market, particularly as Taiwan has a surplus of agricultural products this year.

The premier in principle agreed with the idea, but stressed that a meeting between Taiwan and China should be organized to ensure the rights of Taiwanese farmers before going into the details, and that government powers should be present in dealing with cross-strait trade issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES MEDIA THAT HELPS CROSS-STRAIT UNDERSTANDING CAN COME

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that his Cabinet hopes that the media figures in Hong Kong and China who understand and can help cross-strait issues can come to Taiwan.

Hsieh made the remarks in the wake of a decision by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Sunday that China's state-run Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper will be banned from sending journalists to Taiwan for the time being in an effort to protect national dignity and the interests of Taiwan.

The MAC said the coverage of Taiwan by Xinhua and People's Daily is not conducive to enhancing understanding of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, adding that some Chinese media groups have focused only on the most extreme or radical opinions in Taiwan's political spectrum.

Refuting criticism by Legislator Lin Yu-feng of the opposition People First Party who described the government's reason for suspending the two ousted Chinese news media organizations as lame and that it would only undermine journalistic freedoms and Taiwan's image, Hsieh said he hopes that others will not mistakenly think that the temporary ban will be an interruption of cross-strait journalist exchanges or a regression of journalistic freedom.

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and the Peoples' Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television, China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFSHORE BANKING UNITS ASSETS HIT US$69.22 BILLION AT END OF 2004

TEXT.P: The assets of offshore banking units (OBUs) totaled US$69.22 billion as of the end of 2004, although capital coming from Asia dropped while the capital from America increased to 20 percent, the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

According to the DGBAS report on the situation of OBUs operations, as of the end of 2004, 70 banks in Taiwan were engaged in OBUs operations. Among them, 42 are domestic banks and 28 are foreign banks.
The assets of OBUs operations in 2004 totaled US$69.22 billion, with the annual increase rate over the past five years averaging 10.9 percent.
The source of capital came mainly from deposits of financial institutions, accounting for 61.7 percent at the end of 2004.

In terms of the sources of capital, Asia had been a major source over the past years, accounting for more than 70 percent, but the ratio has slipped since 2001. The ratio dropped to 64 percent in 2004, compared with the ratio of America and Europe, which had increased to 20 percent and 11 percent, respectively.
In terms of capital destinations, Asia has been the major destination over the years, accounting for 67 percent at the end of 2004, followed by America at 20 percent, and Europe at 10 percent.
There has been an upward trend in Asia over the years, while a downward trend for America, DGBAS officials added.

OBU is a financial institution carrying out offshore trades. Offshore banking has been regarded as an alternative to opening up a local market to foreign banks. In effect, offshore banking enables an institution to engage in banking and foreign exchange activities free of the regulations of the host country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO PROMOTE AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION WITH CHINA IF TIES IMPROVE

TEXT.P: The government will negotiate an agricultural cooperation deal with Beijing to allow China to learn from Taiwan's agriculture experience if cross-Taiwan Strait relations improve, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said Tuesday.
You said that problems with China's farmers, farming villages and agricultural sector in general have become a factor that is likely to lead to widespread social unrest in China.
While the income of farmers, which number 900 million, lags far behind that of urban residents in China, up to 26 million Chinese farmers are living in absolute poverty, You pointed out.
You said the government has never restricted exports of Taiwan's agricultural products to China but it has to make careful consideration before allowing the export of agricultural technology.
According to You, although local farmers will increase their profits in the short run by exporting agricultural products to China, securing their long-term interests requires comprehensive planning.

Calling the public's attention to the political motives behind China's policies, You urged political parties and civic groups interested in cross-Taiwan Strait affairs not to be deceived by Beijing's united front tactics against Taiwan.

You claimed that by welcoming Taiwanese agricultural products into the Chinese market and Taiwanese agricultural investment in China, Beijing is trying to win the favor of Taiwanese farmers and agricultural groups in an attempt to absorb Taiwan's agricultural technology and resources.

By doing so, Beijing is also trying to create a false impression that cross-strait exchanges continue to flourish despite the recent enactment of its aggressive Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, which has invited widespread condemnation from the international community, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Parties warned against inflaming race tension.
Britain's race relations chief today warns political leaders that they risk inflaming ugly tensions in the general election. The atmosphere is sour, fractious and brittle, Trevor Phillips, the chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality, has told The Times. His comments came as a prospective Conservative candidate admitted last night that he had doctored photographs in his campaign literature to emphasise his party's tough stance on immmigration.
Financial Times: Four MG Rover directors offered assets valued at Â£49m on Monday to help keep the carmaker viable.
The move by the so-called "Phoenix Four", the men who own MG Rover's parent - Phoenix Venture Holdings - appears intended to counteract criticism of their conduct in making themselves multi-millionaires after buying MG Rover for Â£10 in 2000. The move came as administrators struggled to reopen talks vital to its survival with Shanghai Automotive Industries Corporation. A Phoenix representative said: "They want to help out as much as they can."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Yukos Trial Ends With Applause.

In an impassioned and at times emotional appeal, Mikhail Khodorkovsky on Monday closed his defense with a 39-minute address to the court that left his relatives, lawyers and even reporters applauding and some supporters wiping away tears.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Nominee to U.N. Defends Record at Senate Panel.
In his confirmation hearing, John R. Bolton, rebutting attacks from Democrats on his fitness to serve as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, pledged Monday to bring about a "close partnership" with the organization and denied ever trying to get any one dismissed for disagreeing with him on intelligence matters. Senator Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, a Republican who had questioned Bolton's qualifications and investigated his record during the hearing, said after the morning session that he was generally satisfied with Bolton's answers and that he was still "inclined" to vote to approve him, a step that would probably send the nomination to the Senate even if all the Democrats voted no.
Wall Street Journal: Famine Relief, In Battling Hunger, A New Advance: Peanut-Butter Paste.
Plumpy'nut, a new product made of sweet, enriched peanut-butter paste, is helping transform the treatment of malnutrition in chidldren in famine relief. Each packet, the size of a small juice pouch, weighs less than 100 grams but packs 500 calories. After several weeks on a diet of Plumpy'nut -- brought to the refugee camp in Krinding near Darfur by Save the Children, a U.S. aid organization -- children suffering hunger were able to stand and walk again.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI POSTPONES PLAN TO INVITE TOKYO GOVERNOR TO PITCH FOR TOURISM

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government decided Tuesday to postpone a plan to invite Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara to serve as the spokesman of a Taipei travel journal's Japanese edition following disputes concerning Japan, a city official said.

The plan was formed in March when Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou visited Tokyo and invited Ishihara to tout Taipei tourism, the official said, noting that the city government has been preparing for the matter since Ma's return from Japan.

However, right before the mailing of an official invitation to Ishihara, two incidents concerning Japan's wartime actions sparked anti-Japanese sentiment in Taiwan and China, the official said, referring to a controversial visit by opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Su Chin-chiang to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo April 2 and Japan's decision April 5 to approve a history textbook which China says glosses over Japanese atrocities committed during World War II.
The Tokyo shrine is dedicated to Japan's war dead and includes the names of more than 28,000 Taiwanese soldiers who fought for the Japanese.

In light of the political controversy, Taipei decided to delay the invitation and asked two French artists to take over the post of tourism spokesmen for the next quarterly issue of the magazine, the city official said.

Taipei is a major attraction for Japanese tourists who are a major target for tourism publications issued by the city government and officials are seeking popular entertainers from Taiwan who live in Japan to serve as spokespeople for the following quarter's edition, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH PLANS TO OFFER 'LORENZO'S OIL' TO 3 ALD BROTHERS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will offer a nutrient called "Lorenzo's Oil" to three local boys suffering from a rare degenerative disease who are now receiving treatment in the United States if U.S. physicians think that the nutrient will be helpful to them, an official said Tuesday.

Lin Hsiu-chuan, director of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) , was responding to media reports that the father of the three brothers, all of whom suffer from adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) had complained in a news conference held in the United States about Taiwan's reluctance to continue offering the nutrient to his sons for free.

According to media reports, American physicians said at the news briefing that the three brothers need to be treated with Lorenzo's Oil, which is said to be able to slow the deterioration of the rare genetic disease, although its effects have yet to be scientifically verified and remain speculative.
Lin said the BHP has sent a letter to the three brothers' American doctor asking for his affirmation that the three boys need the nutrient.
"Once we receive the affirmation, we'll offer the Lorenzo's Oil to the three brothers," Lin said.

Taiwan imports Lorenzo's Oil from the United States and according to media reports, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration sets stringent conditions for obtain prescriptions for it. Only those who are under seven years of age and have not yet shown ALD symptoms can secure a prescription from a designated physician in the state of Maryland, according to the reports.
The father of the three boys, Chang Ming-hui, wrote to National Taiwan University Hospital earlier this month asking for a free three-month supply of Lorenzo's Oil.

According to Taiwan's national health insurance regulations, the three brothers are not entitled to free supplies of the nutrient because they went abroad for medical treatment without the endorsement of any local medical institution.
The three ALD-afflicted brothers left for Minnesota in January this year in the company of their parents to receive treatment for their rare disorder.
Local people donated a staggering NT$72 million (US$2.25 million) in just a few days after their father, a Kaohsiung city government staff member, appealed for financial help on the Internet.

ALD is a rare genetic disorder in which the fatty myelin "insulation" around the nerves breaks down. The disease was brought to public attention largely thanks to the 1992 film "Lorenzo's Oil, " which was based on the true story of an American couple's search for a cure for their ALD-afflicted son.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR SEEKS REGIONAL ECONOMIC BOOST

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai demanded during a conference that the government drum up regional investment in an attempt to boost the economy in the southern Taiwan city, officials said Tuesday.
He will also lead a delegation in June to several countries, including Japan and South Korea, to solicit investment and promote Taiwan's tourism industry.

At the first economic development forum held by the Kaohsiung city government Tuesday, scholars and experts from various fields discussed possible ways to revive Kaohsiung's economy after Chen repeatedly expressed his desire to create a friendly business environment in the city since taking over as acting mayor Feb. 1 when former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh was promoted to the premier.

A plan to establish three "commercial parks" in Kaohsiung is currently underway, after the city government proposed setting up a logistics management park, a software technology park and an airfreight park, Chen said.

Kaohsiung is also one of the first cities in Taiwan to successfully attract private investment from other regions of the country, said Chen, adding that he also asked the city's administration to lure more investment into Kaohsiung as part of the economic revival plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO PUT FORTH VERSION OF PEACE PROMOTION BILL

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that the Cabinet will put forth its version of a peace promotion bill as soon as possible to correspond to one proposed by the opposition People First Party (PFP).

Hsieh told lawmakers during a legislative interpellation session that the government had originally planned to set up the Committee for Cross-Strait Peace and Development first before enacting a law governing the committee.
The legislature's Home and Nations Committee is scheduled to start reviewing the bill Wednesday.

According to a draft law unveiled by the PFP, a special cross-strait peace consultation committee would be established under the law that would be able to negotiate with the Beijing authorities without the president's authorization.

Any cross-strait peace agreement signed by the committee and approved by the Legislative Yuan would become effective after being put to a public referendum, and any resolution and legislation proposed by the committee and endorsed by the legislature would be binding for government agencies, according to the draft.
However, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator criticized the PFP-proposed bill as unconstitutional a day earlier and suggested that it be put off.

This triggered strong retaliation from the PFP, which joined forces with the opposition Kuomintang to bar more than 20 DPP-proposed bills from being included on the legislature's agenda during Tuesday's procedures committee meeting.
Lee Yung-ping, a whip of the PFP legislative caucus, said the PFP will continue to boycott bills proposed by the DPP if the DPP continues to call the PFP bill unconstitutional.

Ker Chien-ming, head of the DPP's Policy Committee, said his party has never opposed the cross-strait peace promotion bill and he urged the PFP not to "damage the harmonious atmosphere" of the legislature because of this case.
Ker said the DPP will consult with the PFP to ensure that the content of the bill is in conformity with the national interest and the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO CONDUCT FIRST-EVER ANTI-TERRORISM DRILL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet will conduct its first-ever anti-terrorism drill starting Wednesday after more than three months of preparations, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Tuesday.
The three-day drill has been planned in line with United Nations resolutions passed in 2001 and 2004 that require all countries to fight against terrorism, Cho said.

Noting that the drill has been organized by the Cabinet's anti-terrorism action control office, Cho said it has nothing to do with any military exercises or anti-decapitation strike drill, a reference to a strategy in which Taipei would be attacked by enemy forces in order to cut the leadership off from the rest of the country.

"The exercise is mainly designed to test various administrative agencies' abilities to cope with violent terrorist attack, biological attack, chemical attack, radioactive attack and sabotage to information and communication systems, " Cho explained, adding that the ultimate goal of the drill is to establish standard operating procedures and beef up the government's crisis management capacity.
Although Taiwan is not a U.N. member, Cho said, it must still respond to the U.N.'s call to counter terrorism.
Cho said Premier Frank Hsieh will lead the Cabinet in conducting the anti-terrorism drill at the Tachi joint training center in suburban Taipei.
As the drill has nothing to do with military exercises, Cho said President Chen Shui-bian and national security officials will not take part.
Cho said the Cabinet will brief the press on the procedures and results of the drill once it is completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TUNG BLOSSOM FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The 2005 Tung Blossom Festival will kick off Saturday with a fun-filled ceremony at the West Lake Resort in the northern Taiwan county of Miaoli, a Hakka stronghold, the Council of Hakka Affairs (CHA) announced Tuesday.

This is the fourth consecutive year that the Cabinet-level council has organized a tung blossom festival to boost tourism and cultural development in Taiwan's major Hakka communities, particularly those in northern parts of the country.
Acting CHA Chairman Lee Yung-teh joined with representatives of major Hakka communities from around Taiwan in staging a special ritual in Taipei Tuesday to promote the program.

Addressing the ceremony, Lee said tourist groups from New Zealand, Australia and various European countries will travel to Taiwan to appreciate the tung flower season and take part in various cultural activities to be staged during the month-long festival.
Meanwhile, he went on, May Day, a local pop group, has been invited to help promote the festival. The group will sing Hakka songs at the festival's opening ceremony.

In 2004, Lee said, the Tung Blossom Festival attracted 2.7 million visitors and generated NT$500 million in business revenues. This time around, he said, the festival promises to be bigger and better than ever, with more than 600 cultural events to be held in 32 Hakka communities in Hsinchu, Taoyuan, Miaoli, Taichung, Nantou and Taipei counties. This year's festival will last through May 15.

Referring to the choice of tung flowers as the focus of the festival, former CHA Chairwoman Yeh chu-lan said that as tung trees are common in northern Taiwan Hakka communities, the council has "adopted" the tung blossom as a symbol of Hakka culture.

The trees, (aluerites fordii hemi, common name paulownia), used to be an important source of income for the Hakka, Yeh said, adding that through the festival, the CHA hopes that the trees will once again bring prosperity to Hakka communities.

With a view to cashing in on the thriving demand for wooden furniture materials for export to Japan, farmers in the Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli areas started planting wutung trees (firmiana simplex, common name Chinese parasol) in the 1960s. But the difficulty of growing these trees later forced many farmers to switch to planting tung trees, which are much easier to take care of. Both trees originate in the Yangtze River area of China.
After Japanese customers discovered it was the wrong kind of wood and stopped purchasing from local suppliers, the tung oil trees were left unfelled.
Three decades later, the trees are flourishing, with their profuse spring blossoms making them a major tourist attraction in the Taoyuan-Hsinchu-Miaoli area.

The trees can still be used for carving, furniture and wood pulp. The oil extracted from the seeds used to be used as a key ingredient for varnish and it remains important for Hakka people, who produce hand-made umbrellas made of oiled paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: While many see China's Anti-Secession Law as a step back for cross-strait commercial relations, an official from the Council for Economic Planning and Development claimed otherwise Tuesday.

"Cross-strait trade is not a zero-sum game, " said Yeh Ming-feng, the council's vice chairman. "Taiwan and China both have their unique (economic) advantages and political situations will not affect either side much," he claimed.

Yeh's remarks came following a warning by the Eurochambers that Taiwan will lose its competitiveness if it continues to impose import restrictions on some 2,400 products from China. These items, however, are allowed to be imported into the country if they are from other WTO member countries.

While some feel that China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan will pose a potential threat for foreign investors wishing to enter Taiwan's market, Yeh described China's rising nationalism as a great opportunity for Taiwan to attract foreign investment.
A recent protest in China against Japan's reluctance to face its World War II history will turn the eyes of foreign investors, particularly the Japanese, to Taiwan, he claimed.

"Japanese enterprises are known to be very careful and often have difficulty adapting to China's corporate culture. After the protest, it is likely that they might re-examine their China investment plans and begin to deal with the Taiwanese," Yeh speculated.
He said that Taiwan's well-developed business environment also provides an incentive for those who are hesitating to invest in China.
Taiwan has been pushing to be a regional financial center in East Asia for years.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP SETS UP A 'LATIN GARDEN' NEAR PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu set up a "Latin Garden" near the Presidential Office Tuesday and planted the national tree of El Salvador -- a maquilishuat -- to welcome a visit by Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma Albanez de Escobar.

Heading a 14-member delegation, including Minister of Agriculture and Livestock Mario Salaveria, and Vice Minister of Foreign Relations Margarita Escobar, Albanez de Escobar, the first woman vice president of El Salvador, arrived in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit.

Lu said Albanez de Escobar's visit is to conduct detailed discussions with Taiwan for the planned establishment of a "Taiwan Park" in El Salvador that aims to lure Taiwan enterprises and is designed to globalize Taiwanese companies' business operations abroad.
Albanez de Escobar's trip is also a response to Lu's March visit to the Central American country to further strengthen bilateral ties.
Lu said that after further talks, she believes that the "Taiwan Park" is not a dream but a viable plan.

In addition to planting the national tree of El Salvador as a witness to 70 years of the Republic of China-El Salvador ties, Lu said national trees of more Central and South American countries will be planted to signify the friendship between Taiwan and its Latin American allies.
During her visit, Albanez de Escobar will also meet President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, as well as other high-ranking government officials.

The Salvadoran delegation will visit several economic and cultural establishments, including the National Palace Museum, the Keelung Harbor Bureau and the Taipei World Trade Center, before leaving Taipei April 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILLING TO MEET WITH KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday he would take pleasure in paying a visit to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan if such as visit can help boost inter-party reconciliation and passage of major bills in the legislature.

Hsieh made the remarks during a Legislative Yuan interpellation session where opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chen Chao-jung asked Hsieh whether he is will to meet with Lien to ease a protracted standoff between the ruling and opposition camps and whether all party leaders should report their China travel plans.
Under current regulations, Hsieh said, the government doesn't ban any individual person to visit China.

"But if Lien intends to sign a so-called "peace accord" with Chinese authorities during his planned China visit as reported by the news media, then he must report such a plan to relevant government agencies prior to his departure for the mainland," Hsieh stressed.

As the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP controls a slim majority in the legislature, Hsieh said he would be willing to meet with Lien to boost inter-party reconciliation and facilitate passage of a number of important bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO PARTICIPATE IN APCS MEETING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the city will send a representative to attend the 2005 Asia Pacific Cities Summit (APCS) to be held in China in October.
However, Ma added that he was still not sure whether he can attend personally, as "Taiwan has been very busy recently."

Taipei city government officials have confirmed that Ma received an invitation from Chongqing City, Sichuan Province -- the host of this year's APCS scheduled for Oct. 11-14. According to Ma, more than ten Taiwan cities are members of APCS.

Noting that the APCS meeting is an international activity, Ma said he is permitted to attend the meeting in accordance with the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also taken the initiative in urging the invited mayors to participate, Ma said.
He added that he has participated in two earlier APCS meetings, one in Seattle and the other in Brisbane.

Recalling that he tried hard to win this year's sponsorship of the APCS meeting when he attended the Brisbane summit four years ago, Ma expressed regret that the then-organizer of the meeting gave the 2005 sponsorship to Chongqing City without public discussion.
Ma said the Taipei city government will continue its efforts to win the sponsorship of a future APCS meeting.

Meanwhile, Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party also confirmed that same day that the Kaohsiung city government has also received an invitation to the summit, but said he had not yet decided whether to attend.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING DIRECT CROSS-STRAIT NAVIGATION LINKS ROC POLICY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reiterated Tuesday that opening direct cross-Taiwan Strait navigation links is a policy of the government but that its implementation needs consultation between the two sides of the strait.

Fielding questions raised by lawmakers at an interpellation session of the Legislative Yuan, Hsieh said that a statute governing the establishment of free trade harbor zones approved by the legislature has provided a primary framework for cross-strait shipping.

Also, the premier said, Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan, which has been authorized to handle transshipments between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait through its offshore transshipment center, should be allowed to expand its services for the cross-strait transport links.
He noted, however, that it is up to the Beijing authorities in this regard because the opening of the direct cross-strait navigation links should be discussed by the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 13, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
2001: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrives in the Republic of China at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP TAIWAN NEGOTIATOR WITH CHINA LAID TO REST IN PINGTUNG COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, April 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Koo Cheng-fu, the late top Taiwan negotiator with mainland China who died in early January, was laid to rest in a cemetery on a scenic farm in southern Taiwan Wednesday.

Koo -- who held a historic ice-breaking meeting with Beijing's chief negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, in Singapore in April 1993 and concluded four agreements with him, marking an end to nearly half a century of no contact between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- died of renal failure in a Taipei hospital Jan. 3 at the age of 88.
Koo's coffin was moved Tuesday from Taipei to the Fukuangshan Monastery in Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, where Buddhist master Hsing Yun presided over a Zen funeral to commemorate the late Koo.
In his memorial prayer, Rev. Hsing Yun lauded Koo as having lit up the world and done everything in his power to benefit the people.

Koo, a business tycoon who also had a talent for writing poetry and singing Peking opera, was appointed in March 1991 by the Republic of China government to be the chairman of the quasi-official intermediary body, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Although Koo's family had tried to keep the burial ceremony low-profile, a long funeral procession of about 100 vehicles, including several tourist buses, produced a rare scene in the serene Kaoshu rural township in Pingtung County Wednesday.
According to Koo's family, a memorial museum similar to the Koo Museum located in Lukang, Changhua County will be built next to the cemetery where Koo is buried.

The farm on which the cemetery is located was reportedly part of a 3,000-hectare tract that Koo's father, Koo Hsien-jung, bought when Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule some 60 years ago. At that time, Koo Hsien-jung was a successful businessman and a "coordinator" between the Japanese and the Chinese from both Taiwan and mainland China.
According to Koo's family, Koo was still worrying about the tension between Taiwan and mainland China even in his final days after a long battle with kidney illness.

Although the diplomatic tug-of-war between the two sides of the strait continued unabated after the historic 1993 Koo-Wang talks in Singapore, Koo visited the mainland in October 1998 and met with then Chinese President Jiang Zemin as well as Wang, helping improve ties between Taiwan and the mainland.

In addition to being a successful businessman, Koo also served as head of the Chinese National Federation of Industries and of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, contributing greatly to Taiwan's economic development.

A senior adviser to both former President Lee Teng-hui and incumbent President Chen Shui-bian, Koo was also Taiwan's top envoy, taking part in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's informal leadership summits on behalf of the president from 1995 to 1997.

Koo's passing was termed by some local political observers as tantamount to the symbolic death of cross-strait relations, given that the two sides had been at a complete political impasse since July 1999 after then ROC President Lee Teng-hui described the cross-strait relationship as "state-to-state" in nature.
Condolences for Koo's passing came not only from around Taiwan and mainland China, but also from the United States and Japan, where Koo had had prominent business and political connections.
