DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO LET MORE CHINA, H.K. MEDIA ORGANIZATIONS POST STAFF IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Wednesday that the MAC will allow more independent-thinking mainland Chinese and Hong Kong media organizations to post journalists in Taiwan so that the Chinese people can get a more accurate picture of current events in Taiwan.

Wu was responding to remarks earlier in the day by Lee Weiyi, a spokesman of the Taiwan Affairs Office of Beijing's State Council, that Taiwan has no justifiable reason for withdrawing permission for two mainland Chinese state-run media organizations to post journalists in Taiwan. Lee said the decision will affect cross-strait journalistic exchanges and undermine the rights of Chinese news media and journalists.

The MAC on Sunday temporarily banned the Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily newspaper from posting journalists in Taiwan, claiming that their coverage of Taiwan has not been conducive to enhancing understanding between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Wu said that cross-strait journalistic exchanges are extremely unbalanced, noting that the Taiwan people can have access to mainland China news and information, while mainland Chinese people don't have access to accurate information about Taiwan.

Wu noted that the Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily have focused on the most extreme or radical opinions in covering Taiwan's political scene, which he said has distorted the picture of Taiwan's actual situation.
He said that there are still three mainland Chinese media organizations -- China Central Television, China News Agency and China National Radio -- that have journalists posted in Taiwan.
He said the MAC will allow more other news organizations from China and Hong Kong to post journalistic staff in Taiwan in order to provide a more accurate picture of Taiwan to the Chinese people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY'S ROLE IS TO DEFEND ROC AGAINST EXTERNAL THREATS: HUO

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of National Defense Huo Shou-yeh said Wednesday that, as stated in the Republic of China Constitution, the armed forces' mission is to defend the nation's security.

Huo made the remarks in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, during which opposition Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung asked whether the ROC military would fight for Taiwan independence.

Huo said that the ROC armed forces have always maintained their combat readiness for any possible military threats from beyond Taiwan's borders, adding that the armed forces firmly abide by the principle of getting no involvement in non-military affairs, such as politics.

The issue of Taiwan independence is an internal political issue that should be solved by political means, he said, adding that the ROC military's obligation is to defend Taiwan against any external threats regardless of the reasons behind those threats.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES TAIWAN BUSINESSES TO INVEST IN EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged local business groups Wednesday to invest more in El Salvador which she said has the potential to become a Latin American regional operations hub.

Lu made the appeal while accompanying visiting Salvadoran Vice President Ana Vilma Albanez de Escobar on a tour of UPS Corp.'s Pacific transshipment center at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway.

Both Lu and Albanez de Escobar said they were impressed by the UPS transshipment center's convenient and efficient air freight delivery operations. They also expressed the common hope that the air cargo volume between Taiwan and El Salvador will increase in the future.

Lu further said she came to a deep understanding during her visit to El Salvador last month that the Central American country stands a good chance of becoming a regional business hub in Central and South America because of its strategic geographic position and economic development potential. Hopefully, Lu added, more local companies can launch investment projects in El Salvador.
Later in the day, Lu accompanied Albanez de Escobar on visits to an air cargo transshipment park and an industrial park in Taoyuan County, where Lu once served as magistrate.
Heading a 14-member delegation, Albanez de Escobar, the first female vice president of El Salvador, arrived in Taipei Monday for a five-day visit.
To welcome Albanez de Escobar's visit, Lu planted a maquilishuat -- El Salvador's national tree -- in a "Latin Garden" near the Presidential Office Tuesday.

Lu said on the occasion that Albanez de Escobar's visit is aimed at discussing an ambitious cooperative plan to build a "Taiwan Park" in El Salvador to lure investment by Taiwan enterprises and ethnic Salvadoran businesspeople residing in the United States.
With concerted efforts from both sides, Lu said she believes that the "Taiwan Park" project is not be a pipe dream, but rather a viable plan.

In addition to planting the maquilishuat to mark the 70 years of ROC-Salvadoran ties, Lu said the national trees of more Central and South American countries will also be planted in the new "Latin Garden" to signify the friendship between Taiwan and its Latin American allies.
During her visit, Albanez de Escobar will also meet President Chen Shui-bian and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, as well as other high-ranking officials.

In addition, the delegation will visit several economic and cultural establishments, including the National Palace Museum, the Keelung Harbor Bureau and the Taipei World Trade Center, before leaving Taipei April 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAGISTRATE TO VISIT GERMANY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing is set to leave for Germany on Wednesday for a 10-day architectural fact-finding tour.

Yang will be accompanied by Tseng Tzu-feng, a professor of urban development and architecture at National University of Kaohsiung; Lu Yu-yi and Wang Li-jen, architectural consultants to the Kaohsiung County Government; Lin Hsi-chun, chief of the government's tourism bureau; Wu Li-hsueh, chief of the government's social affairs bureau; and Wu Hsu-feng, chief of the government's cultural bureau.
The group is scheduled to depart from Kaohsiung International Airport at 5 p.m. for Frankfurt via Hong Kong.
They will visit the Center for Art and Media in Karlsruhe on April 14 and solar factories in Freiburg on April 15.
On April 16, they will visit the cable railway in Schauinsland, as well as the Clock Museum and the Schwarzwald Museum.
On the following day, they will head to Tubingen to inspect the ecological building methods there and a project to remodel old military barracks, as well as visit German architect Joachim Eble.
The group is scheduled to inspect the sustainable city planning and green transportation project in Stuttgart on April 18.

During the next two days, they will visit the university town of Ulm and German urban planner and landscape architect Peter Latz, as well as visit the National Garden Festival Germany in Munich and inspect the city's urban planning projects.
The group is scheduled to return to Taiwan on April 22.

Kaohsiung County Government officials said they hope to learn from Germany's experience to aid them in planning a university town in Yenchao township and a park at the old site of the Weiwu military barrack.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOTEL ROOM RATES AVERAGE NT$2,913 PER NIGHT IN 2004

TEXT.P: The average rate for a hotel room in Taiwan last year stood at NT$2,913 (US$92.77) per night, marking an increase of 5.4 percent over the year-earlier level, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Wednesday.

After compiling its own tallies with statistics from the Central Bank of China and the Tourism Bureau, the DGBAS reported that Republic of China citizens made 7.781 million trips abroad in 2004, while Taiwan received 2.95 million person-visits from foreign countries.

These two figures marked an increase of 31.4 percent and 31.2 percent, respectively, over those posted in 2003, when the numbers of both outbound and inbound tourists were relatively low due to an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), DGBAS officials said.

As of the end of 2004, there were a total of 20,407 rooms in hotels ranging from international five-star hotels to low-end hotels in Taiwan, with the average rate standing at NT$2,913 per night. Occupancy rates hit 65.6 percent for 2004, up 9.2 percentage points over the previous year, the officials noted.

With the numbers of both outbound and inbound tourists rising remarkably, Taiwan citizens' overall travel expenditures totaled NT$8.17 billion (US$260.19 million) in 2004, compared with revenue of NT$4.04 billion (US$128.66 million) generated from visits to Taiwan by foreign nationals.
These figures represented an increase of 26.1 percent and 35.7 percent, respectively, over those posted in 2003, the DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK EXCHANGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.19 points to close at 5,998.08.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with textile stocks moving down at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.4 percent, and construction issues at 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REP CALLS FOR NORMALIZATION OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES IN WTO
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The relations between Taiwan and China in the World Trade Organization (WTO) must be normalized before cross-Taiwan Strait trade relations can be rationalized, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO Yen Ching-chang said Wednesday.
Yen made the remarks in response to a position paper released by the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) on Taiwan's progress in observing WTO obligations.
In the paper, the ECCT again criticized Taiwan for failing to relax its import restrictions on Chinese products and warned that the situation will bring down the island's competitiveness.

The ECCT pointed out that Taiwan has banned the import of more than 2,400 Chinese products on the grounds that they might jeopardize national security and the domestic industrial sector, which the group says is in violation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade of 1994.
Yen said the problem is mutual and that it is unfair to demand Taiwan to take measures unilaterally.
While there is room for Taiwan to improve its import restrictions on Chinese products, China has also maintained some unreasonable trade measures toward Taiwan, Yen noted.

However, it seems impossible for Taiwan and China to sit down for talks to try to resolve the problem because their relations in the WTO have not been normalized, with China's mission to the WTO even refusing to exchange correspondence with Taiwan's mission, according to Yen.

DOC.HEADLINE: POPULAR PFP LAWMAKER RETURN TO KMT FOLD TO BOOST CHANCE IN ELECTION

TEXT.P: A popular People First Party (PFP) legislator who had defected from the Kuomintang (KMT) in 2000 said Wednesday that he has returned to the fold of the KMT.

PFP Legislator Chou Hsi-wei said he will take part in the KMT primary and represent the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party to run for Taipei County magistrate in the year-end election.
Chou, said that the "pan-blue alliance" will have to integrate if it wants to win the Taipei County magistrate election, one of the most hotly contested constituencies.
Chou stressed that a divided "pan-blue alliance" is doomed to fail, and this is his reason to rejoin the KMT.
The PFP splintered off from the KMT with James Soong as its leader.

He said that being the likely candidate for the magistrate race if he were to stay in the PFP, this would only result in problems for the "pan-blue alliance"; therefore, it is best for the alliance if he returns to run under the banner of the KMT.
Chou said that PFP Chairman Soong was aware of his decision and told him he understood. Chou added that he respects and accepts the PFP's decision to suspend his membership.
Chou said that from now on he will join the KMT caucus in the legislature and that even if he loses the KMT primary, he will remain in the KMT.

The parties of the "pan-blue alliance" are one family, Chou said, and any candidate-hopefuls in the alliance should accept the rules, and as such, he will abide by the result of the primary which will determine whether he stands for the party in the election.

Noting that the PFP has yet to create a nomination mechanism, and that if the two parties have no common way to achieve this, he does not want to be the "next Wang Chien-hsien" because of the late integration of the two parties.
The KMT endorsed the New Party's Wang at the eleventh hour for the Taipei County election in late 1996, and Wang lost by a small margin to Su Tseng-chang of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
The KMT confirmed Wednesday that Chou has rejoined the party and was welcome.

Liao Feng-teh, director of the KMT Organization and Development Committee, said the KMT embraces Chou with open arms, although Chou still has to take part in the KMT primary before he can represent the party to run for Taipei County magistrate.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng also welcomed Chou, who added that he was not aware of any other persons from the PFP interested in joining the KMT for the year-end elections.

Hung Hsiu-chu, a popular KMT legislator who has thrown her hat in the ring for Taipei County magistrate, said she welcomed Chou to return to the fold of the KMT, noting that the KMT and its splinter party are like brothers and they need solidarity.

But Hung questioned the timing of Chou's return at a sensitive time ahead of the primary, which she said might give rise to doubts if he really wants to embrace the KMT or if he has more personal interests in mind.
Hung said that the primary should be held in an open and transparent manner so that everyone can give full support to the primary result without having any doubts.

Legislator Lee Yung-ping, caucus whip of the PFP in the Legislative Yuan, said Wednesday the attitude of the PFP and the KMT jointly recommending a candidate to run in local elections remains unchanged.

PFP Legislator Chang Hsien-yao said that whether there will be KMT-PFP cooperation in the Taipei County magistrate election will have to wait for a meeting between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman Soong.
Chang said that the PFP is willing to support Chou under any circumstances as long as it helps the "integration of the 'pan-blue alliance.'"

He stressed that Chou's case will not trigger a massive defection of PFP legislators to the KMT, adding that factional integration and the situation of each candidate varies from city to city and county to county, and any PFP member who wants to vie for inclusion in the year-end elections with dual party membership will have to get approval from the central committees of the two parties.
With Chou's announcement to rejoin the KMT, another PFP legislator said that he will now solicit the PFP's endorsement to enter the Taipei County magistrate race.

Legislator Lee Hung-chun, who comes from a political family and holds a Ph.D. in engineering, said that the grassroots of the KMT and the PFP had previously asked him and his elder brother, Lee Hung-yuan, former Director of the Water Resources Department of Taiwan Provincial Government, to be a part of the elections.

With Chou's active participation, Lee said he had originally wanted to help Chou win, but now that the situation has changed, he wants to join the race to contribute his professionalism in construction works to Taipei County.

Another PFP legislator, Liu Wen-hsiung, who has announced his bid to run for Keelung mayor, said that he felt sad that the KMT is still trying to lure back former party members, adding that the PFP "should act in concert and not have individuals defecting."

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS URGED TO WORK WITH POLICE TO BETTER SOCIAL ORDER

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Wednesday that with major criminal cases remaining unsolved, he has asked chief prosecutors of the district prosecutor's offices around the island to work with police to effectively clear the docket.
In addition, he has also asked State Public Prosecutor-General Wu Ying-chao to convene a major conference on social order.

Shih's remarks came in the wake of attacks on two policemen in broad daylight Sunday, leaving one dead and another seriously injured, and a kidnapping case involving a notorious wanted man. Both cases are unsolved.
Shih said that the manpower of some local prosecutor's offices is limited, and they are often burdened with matters involving public prosecution.
For this reason, the prosecutors must work and coordinate well with police to safeguard social order, Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO RETURN TO TALK WITH CHINA BASED ON 1992 FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to return to the negotiating table and talk with Chinese negotiators using the "1992 meeting" as a basis as described by President Chen Shui-bian in his 2004 second-term inaugural address, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.
Lai Ching-teh said that the DPP does not oppose any private cross-strait exchanges, such as those dealing with journalism or agriculture.

However, Lai noted, dealings that involve the exercise of public authority, such as customs tariffs and quarantine, necessitate the ruling parties from both sides to send their officials to "sit and talk" before the results of any such exchanges can be implemented.
Lai called for the Beijing leadership to show genuine goodwill toward Taiwan instead of playing a two-handed game in its "united front" scheme.

Lai was speaking in response to remarks made earlier Wednesday by Li Weiyi, spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, who said that China will actively push for closer media exchanges across the Strait, expand imports of Taiwan's farm products and will welcome delegates from Taiwan's agriculture sector who wish to go to China for talks on sales.

Li also said that China welcomes representatives of Taiwan political parties and private organizations to come to China for talks who recognize the "1992 consensus" -- a consensus reached by Taiwan and Chinese negotiators in a meeting held in Hong Kong in 1992, at which both sides agreed orally that there is only one China and both sides can have their own interpretation of that "one China" -- and those who are firmly opposed to Taiwan independence.

Commenting on Li's remarks, Lai said that there was no "1992 consensus" since it was a mythical term invented by officials from the former Kuomintang (KMT) administration in charge of China policy and that the KMT had never reached any consensus with Chinese officials in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNDS AVAILABLE FOR TAIWAN INVESTORS IN ROC'S ALLIES

TEXT.P: About NT$26.23 million (US$832,000) from a Ministry of Foreign Affairs' budget will be made available as incentives to Taiwanese who invest in the ROC's allies, two legislative committees decided Wednesday.

The amount was half of a NT$52.67 million budget requested by the foreign ministry to encourage local businessmen to venture into the markets of the nation's allies. The budget had been frozen by the legislature, which asked the ministry to use it only after giving notice to the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Sharon Asks U.S. to Pressure Iran to Give Up Its Nuclear Program.
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel urged President Bush to step up pressure on Iran to give up all elements of its nuclear program, according to senior American and Israeli officials. Sharon said Israeli intelligence showed Iran, though he gave no indication that Israel was preparing to act alone to attack Iranian nuclear facilities, a prospect that Vice President Dick Cheney raised publicly three months ago. American officials said the evidence Sharon presented, including aerial photographs of sites in Iran, was neither startling nor new to Bush. But they said the prime minister was clearly pressuring Bush not to allow the European negotiations with Iran to drag on.
Wall Street Journal: New Relations, China's Growth Places Strains On a Family's Ties.
For thousands of years, Chinese have made the family paramount, with generations often living together, and younger members deferring to their elders. Fathers were the head of the household. But opportunities born of China's move to a market-based economy over the past two dozen years are creating new wealth, new hierarchies and new strains. The scramble to keep up with neighbors, or one's own relatives, is testing family ties, contributing to a rise in social problems. Some 1.6 million couples divorced in China last year, a 21 percent jump over the year before, according to China's Ministry of Civil Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHEN-SOONG PRONOUNCEMENT' REASONABLE FOR CROSS-STRAIT DEALINGS: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu suggested Wednesday that legislators from across Taiwan's political spectrum refer to the 10-point agreement that President Chen Shui-bian reached with opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong in February as a reference when trying to enact a "cross-strait peace promotion law."

It is believed that if the lawmakers use the statement of agreed-upon points released by Chen and Soong on Feb. 24 -- in which the two said that the Republic of China is a sovereign state and that President Chen will not seek to change the status quo between Taiwan and China during his term -- as the spirit and guiding principles of a draft "cross-strait peace promotion law, " the legislators will gain the greatest possible support from all the people of the country, Wu noted.

Wu said that so far, the PFP version of a cross-strait peace promotion draft law and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) version of an "anti-annexation law" is not suitable enough to win the support of the government since both versions have their shortcomings.

For example, he said, the PFP included President Chen's "five noes" commitment, including not to change the status quo between Taiwan and China, and the "1992 consensus" as part of the draft "cross-strait peace promotion law, " points that could spark ceaseless arguments in Taiwan's political circles.

Wu said that the "1992 consensus" is basically a myth as none of the current governments across the Taiwan Strait has referred it as any kind of "consensus" in terms of development of cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS LOCAL GOVERNMENT CHIEFS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC ORDER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh demanded that local government chiefs on Wednesday enforce government authority effectively to improve public order, saying the shortage of police officers should not be an excuse for the worsening situation.
Hsieh issued the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting in the wake of two high-profile criminal cases.

Hsieh said it was a major challenge to governmental authority that two policemen were assaulted in broad daylight in Hsichih, Taipei County over the weekend, adding that the case must be resolved as soon as possible.

Speaking of a similar case occurring in Keelung on Tuesday, Hsieh said authorities concerned should review if there is any loophole in the current bail system because the criminal in this case had been arrested on five occasions in three months before this but was never kept in detention.
Also, Hsieh said police must track down notorious gunman Chang Hsi-ming to restore public confidence in Taiwan's law and order.

The premier noted that he has ordered the Ministry of the Interior to establish a set of criteria to evaluate the performance of each locality in fighting crime every three months to push local government chiefs and police authorities to shoulder their share of the responsibility.

Although the National Police Agency plans to recruit 1,315 people to join the police force this year, the number will not be enough to meet the demand in light of the fact that a similar number of policemen quit every year, he said.

However, he added, the shortage of police is no excuse for worsening public order because it will made a great difference if local government chiefs and police authorities consider improving public order their top priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AGRICULTURAL PREFERENCE TO TAIWAN INSINCERE: TAIWAN FARMER

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese representative from the agricultural sector revealed Wednesday that Beijing's promise to offer preferential tariffs to Taiwan agricultural exports is a lot of hot air.

The representative made the remarks at an exhibition of Taiwan fruits in Beijing organized jointly by the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, the Hong-Kong based Chinese Commercial and Industrial Coordination Society, and Taiwan Provincial Fruit Trade Association.
Several high-ranking Chinese officials also attended the exhibition, including He Shizhong, a division chief of Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council.

He said that Chinese authorities are considering several measures to facilitate Taiwan agricultural exports to China, including offering more convenient customs clearance and quarantine procedures, and urged Taiwan to send civic groups to negotiate with their counterparts in China.
"Once the negotiations are completed, China will work out a preferential plan for the export of Taiwan fruits to the Chinese market," He said.

Tsai Chang-lung, president of the Taiwan Provincial Fruit Trade Association, noted that fruit exports from Southeast Asian countries to China are enjoying tariff-free preference in accordance with an economic cooperation agreement between China and Southeast Asian countries.
Tsai urged China to quickly offer tariff-free preference and more convenient customs clearance procedures for Taiwan fruit farmers to show its good will.
However, He noted that several government agencies are studying this question, and he cannot give a timetable on when to offer this preference.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, giving up NT$0.028 to close at NT$31.540.
A total of US$710 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.568 and slid to a low of NT$31.524 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S COMMENTS ON 'SEVEN-POINT CONCLUSION' UNACCEPTABLE: MAC

TEXT.P: China's comments on Taiwan's "seven-point conclusion" on engagements across the Taiwan Strait in the wake of Beijing's enactment of its anti-secession law are "unacceptable, " a senior Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Wednesday.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung made the remarks after Li Weiyi, a spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said in Beijing earlier in the day that Taiwan's latest "seven-point conclusion" on cross-strait exchanges marked a retreat in Taiwan's commitment to boosting bilateral ties.

The "seven-point conclusion" referred to the outcome announced at the end of a high-level meeting chaired by President Chen Shui-bian April 5 following a high-profile visit to China by opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang, who signed a so-called "10-point consensus" with Chinese authorities during his stay in Beijing.

The "seven-point conclusion" accentuated the Democratic Progressive Party administration's determination to "effectively manage" cross-strait exchanges, including stressing that all cross-strait interchanges should abide by the law and that anyone who reaches an agreement with foreign governments, the other side of the Taiwan Strait or the envoys they dispatch will be dealt with according to the law by related agencies.

Speaking at a news briefing in Beijing Wednesday, Li claimed that the "seven-point conclusion" tightens restrictions on cross-strait trade and cultural exchanges. "Turning the clock back violates the interests of Taiwan compatriots," he added.
In response, MAC Vice Chairman You said Li's comments were "unacceptable," but he didn't elaborate.

During the Beijing news conference, Li also said private industry associations on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are welcome to exchange views on the much-expected opening of direct cross-strait charter cargo flights.
Responding to a media inquiry about his opinions on Li's overture, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu said he sees no sincerity in Li's call for talks by private industry associations.

Wu said Taiwan is willing to negotiate issues regarding the opening of direct cross-strait charter cargo flights, but he added that at the moment, the government's top priority is to evaluate the impact of China's recent enactment of its anti-secession law codifying the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan.
"We must wait and see whether Taiwan's dignity and interests would be affected by that legislation before we re-start any contacts with China," Wu said.
According to Wu, China has forced a noted Taiwan business tycoon to issue a public statement endorsing its cherished "one China" policy and its anti-secession law.

"We must wait to see whether China will take any other steps to restrict the speech of freedom of Taiwan business people with interests in China or to force them to sign any documents, " Wu said, adding that he is not sure at the moment how long the "observation and evaluation" period will last.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITIES OF TAIWAN, U.S. TO EXCHANGE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: National Chiao Tung University and the University of Illinois signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cooperation between the two schools Tuesday.

Peter Wu, dean of Chiao Tung University's College of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and Richard Balhut, head of University of Illinois' Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, signed the MOU on behalf of the two schools.
Under the MOU, 19 Chiao Tung University students will go to the University of Illinois, making it a rare case of student exchanges in such numbers with a single university.

Balhut said that he hopes all his department's students can have the experience of learning through international exchanges, adding that his university has cooperated with universities in Japan and South Korea and that it has chosen Chiao Tung as a cooperation partner in Taiwan.
Wu noted that the University of Illinois ranks fifth in U.S. colleges of engineering, and it is a rare opportunity for his college to have exchanges with the prestigious university.

He said Chiao Tung hopes to attract 10 students from the University of Illinois to come to Taiwan next spring, and that the students will not only be able to study courses at his college, but will be able to select courses at other colleges if approved.
Chiao Tung will also solicit the chance to have the students to get training in Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which is a showcase of Taiwan's high-tech sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EARNS US$201 MILLION FROM MARCH'S FOREIGN TRADE

TEXT.P: Foreign exchange reserves earned from Taiwan's exports reached US$20.48 billion in March, while those spent on imports totaled US$20.28 billion, both the second-highest monthly figures ever, according to statistics from Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC).

CBC officials noted that the foreign exchange reserves earned from exports and those spent on imports in March represented a growth of 21.4 percent and 22.9 percent, respectively, over the same month of last year, leaving a surplus of US$201 million.

In the aggregate, foreign exchange reserves earned from the island's exports from January to March totaled US$51.74 billion, while those spent on imports reached US$49.53 billion, representing a growth of 10 percent and 17.9 percent, respectively, over the same period of 2004, leaving a surplus of US$2.21 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY LEADERS SHOULD GET PRIOR AUTHORIZATION TO TALK WITH CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: Political party leaders should get prior authorization from the government before they talk with China on political issues, the nation's top China policy planner said Wednesday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Lee Ching-an, a legislator of the opposition People First Party, asked Wu if the MAC would find it acceptable if opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan visits China without government authorization and reaches an agreement with China that it withdraws its missiles targeting Taiwan.
"This would create internal problems, " he said, adding that KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's visit to China was a highly political exchange that should have required national consensus.

Chiang reached a 10-point consensus with Beijing during his high-profile March 28-April 1 visit, covering a wide range of issues, including cross-Taiwan Strait transportation, agriculture, tourism, protection of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China and further easing of China's financial market.
If party leaders engage in highly political issues without a national consensus and prior authorization from the government, this would be "unthinkable" in any other democratic country, Wu said.
He said that Taiwan has its own Constitution and laws that should be honored, adding that anything that involves government authority should follow the Constitution and abide by the rule of the law.

If China wants to extend an olive branch by withdrawing the missiles targeting Taiwan, it does not need to wait for a visit by Lien, he pointed out. Also, Beijing should destroy the missiles instead of just conducting the pointless exercise of withdrawing the highly mobile and easily deployed weapons, he added.
As Lien has claimed his China visit needs no endorsement from the government, Legislator Lai Shyh-bao suggested that Wu call on Lien privately.
However, Wu said that consultations between the ruling and opposition parties should be conducted by leaders of the respective camps rather than by the MAC.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY BILL PASSES PRELIMINARY REVIEW AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A bill governing the operations of the ad hoc National Assembly passed a preliminary review at the Legislative Yuan on Wednesday.

However, it remains uncertain whether the bill will finish its legislative process before the National Assembly convenes as inter-party differences over several crucial articles of the bill still await consultations for a resolution.
Delegates of the National Assembly are scheduled to be elected on May 14 for the sole purpose of considering a constitutional amendment package adopted by the legislature last August.

According to the draft passed by the legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Committee, the National Assembly will convene in 10 days after the outcome of election is confirmed, with the session to run no more than one month.

Copies of the proposed constitutional amendments will be delivered to the National Assembly members in three days after the election outcome is confirmed, and a representative of the Legislative Yuan will be asked to report the main purposes of the amendments at the National Assembly session, the draft stated.
Disputed articles, including one concerning the threshold for the passage of constitutional amendments, were set aside for further inter-party consultations.

While the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and opposition Kuomintang believe that constitutional amendments should be considered passed if they are endorsed by at least half of the National Assembly delegates, the opposition People First Party and Taiwan Solidarity Union insist that a three-quarter threshold be set.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MEMBERS A NON-EVENT FOR PUBLIC: POLL

TEXT.P: Even though the mission-oriented National Assembly election is coming up in just one month, more than half of the people of Taiwan do not know the exact date it will be held, according to the results of a poll released Wednesday.

The survey showed that many people are lukewarm about the May 14 election, which will choose members for the National Assembly. About 51 percent said they do not know when the election will be held, while 81.6 percent said they do not know each political party's stance in amending the Republic of China Constitution.
From the poll's results, analysts doubted that the result of the election will accurately reflect the opinions of those who choose to vote. Only 65 percent answered yes as to whether they will vote.
The survey was conducted by a private think tank, Taiwan Advocates, April 8-10 and received 1,081 valid replies from eligible voters.
The National Assembly is to decide whether to endorse a constitutional amendment package, which was passed by the Legislative Yuan last year.

The package consists of four amendment items: abolishment of the National Assembly; a close to 50 percent reduction in the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan; changing the existing legislative election to a "single-seat, two votes" system, and detailing the nature of holding referendums as laid out in the Constitution.

Regarding cutting the size of the legislature, 45.8 percent support the amendment, with 30.1 percent saying it should be cut by just 25 percent. Just over 14 percent think the number of seats should remain the same.
As to the change in the voting system, 33.5 percent think it will only benefit major political parties.
About 82 percent think the elected National Assembly members should endorse each amendment item individually, rather than in a package.
Approximately 68 percent said they hope additional polls of citizens will be conducted to decide whether the public supports National Assembly members' decisions on endorsing the package.
The poll had a margin of error of 2.98 percent with a confidence level of 95 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA UNQUALIFIED TO CRITICIZE TAIWAN OVER JOURNALIST BAN: CABINET

TEXT.P: China is not qualified to criticize Taiwan's decision to temporarily ban two Chinese media outlets from posting journalists in Taiwan due to their constantly biased reports about local news events, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Wednesday.

Cho made the remarks after a spokesman for China's Taiwan Affairs Office claimed at a news briefing in Beijing earlier in the day that Taiwan's ban on the Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper marked a gross interference with freedom of the press.

"As China itself doesn't respect the freedom of the press, it is not qualified to use the term 'gross interference' to criticize Taiwan's handling of the case. We have consistently protected freedom of the press, and the temporary ban on correspondents from the two state-run Chinese media outlets has nothing to do with freedom of the press, " Cho said.
Cho further pointed out that Taiwan has not imposed an across-the-board ban on all Chinese media outlets.

"We have only suspended the permission for the two named media outlets to post journalists in Taiwan for the time being because they have continuously published unfriendly, biased, distorted or outrageous reports about Taiwan, " Cho said, adding that he hopes the measure will inspire Chinese media organizations to improve the quality of their news reporting and their journalists.
Cho reiterated that the ban doesn't have anything to do with freedom of press and would by no means affect Taiwan's respects for journalists.
"In the meantime, we hope Chinese journalists can learn to respect the government and people of Taiwan," Cho added.

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and People's Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television (CCTV) , China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them out each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EYEING BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES IN BANGLADESH

TEXT.P: The state-funded Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is eyeing potential business opportunities in Bangladesh and is preparing to encourage local businesses to invest there, a TAITRA official stationed in Kaohsiung said Wednesday.

With a population of more than 140 million, Bangladesh enjoys an abundant labor force, while its consumption market is seen as having potential for expansion, the official said, noting that investment opportunities exist in most of the South Asian country's business fields such as textiles, mobile phones, leather products, bikes, shoes, foodstuffs, plastics, machinery and electricity.

Bangladesh is also the world's eighth-largest exporter of ready-made garments, while every year it imports a large quantity of textiles to supply the ready-to-wear production lines in the Karnaphuli export processing zone in Chittagong, the nation's largest port, according to TAITRA.
Taiwanese textile businesses could forge cooperative alliances with Bangladesh manufacturers to expand their overseas operations, the official suggested.

To assist local businesses to explore the South Asian market, TAITRA has invited several organizations, including the Taiwan Textile Federation, the Taiwan Development and Trust Corp., the Taiwan Garment Industry Association, the Taiwan Footwear Manufacturers' Association and the Tainan city government to hold an investment workshop for local businesses slated for April 15 at Tainan City Hall.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK PRO-DEMOCRACY ACTIVISTS DEMAND DIRECT VOTE ON CHIEF EXECUTIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 13 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong issued a declaration Wednesday demanding a direct vote to elect the special administrative region's chief executive and Legislative Council.

The declaration was issued by a group of more than 50 organizations dedicated to the promotion of Hong Kong's democracy, at a time when the National People's Congress (NPC) of China is to make a legal interpretation on the term of Hong Kong's next chief executive.
Former Chief Executive Tung Chee Hwa resigned in March due to his low popularity.

The declaration notes that although the Tung's resignation truly reflects the opinions of the Hong Kong people, they are more concerned about whether there will be a direct vote to elect their future leaders instead of intervention by their Chinese rulers in Beijing.
"A popular vote to elect Hong Kong's chief executive and Legislative Council is an important way to resolve the special administrative region's political problems," the declaration says.
In addition, the declaration also demands more cooperation between the executive and legislative branches and the establishment of partisan politics in Hong Kong.
The pro-democracy activists expressed hope that the elections for choosing a chief executive and a Legislative Council in 2007 and 2008, respectively, can move in this direction.
They also suggested that the by-election to choose a new chief executive to replace Tung should be transparent and fair and that there should be more candidates allowed to compete in this post.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. ARMY MOVE A RESPONSE TO CROSS-STRAIT TENSIONS: LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: A move by the United States Army to transfer a branch of its command headquarters from the United States to Japan is to deal with any contingency across the Taiwan Strait and on the Korea peninsula, two legislators said Wednesday.

According to reports, the United States has confirmed that it will transfer a branch of its command headquarters from a Washington base to its Zama military camp in Japan's Kanagawa Prefecture just 40 km southwest of Tokyo.
Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lee Wen-chung described the move as necessary to uphold both U.S. and Japanese interests in the region.
He added that Taiwan should take immediate action to counter any threats from China and he urged the public to support the government's weapons procurement plan.
Opposition People First Party Legislator Ku Chung-lian agreed with Lee's remarks, but claimed that the reason for the U.S. move is because North Korea poses a more imminent threat than China.

Ku claimed that cross-strait tension has "abated" and that Taiwan should not act "excessively" to avoid upsetting China. He also said he opposes the weapons procurement plan because "the weapons for sale by the United States are too outdated to boost the nation's defense forces and will cost too much for the country's future taxpayers."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'HAN KUANG' DRILL TO PRACTICE STRATEGIES AGAINST DECAPITATION STRIKE

TEXT.P: The upcoming "Han Kuang 21" series of military exercises will test the armed forces' combat prowess against unlimited warfare tactics and decapitation strikes, according to a Ministry of National Defense (MND) report released Wednesday.
The MND report, which was prepared for the reference of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee, said the annual series of exercises comprise two parts -- simulated war games and live-fire drills.

The computerized war simulations will be conducted at the combined services operation command center, the combined services training center and various tactical command centers. The simulated war games will take place between late April and May.

The weeklong war simulations will hone various combat strategies and tactics, including anti-blockade strategies, airborne defense control, naval forces' air defense and maritime control tactics, as well as cyber-defense operations. The war games will be conducted eight hours a day during the week-long maneuvering period.

The live-fire drills are scheduled for June through August to verify combat strategies and tactics hammered out during the computerized war games. These maneuvers will include strategies to cope with surprise attacks on a major local oil depot and undersea cables.

The live-fire exercises will also practice counter strategies against unlimited warfare methods such as shockwave bombing, infiltration, abduction, hijacking, computer virus attacks and decapitation strikes.

Decapitation strategies short-circuit command and control systems, wipe out nationwide nerve centers and leave the opponent hopelessly immobilized. Many military observers say China is very likely to use this strategy in an invasion of Taiwan by seizing the nation's center of power -- the capital -- along with its top leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENTS TO BE HELD TO PRESERVE NATION'S CULTURAL ASSETS

TEXT.P: Officials from public and private organizations gathered in Taipei Wednesday to stress the importance of preserving the nation's cultural assets ahead of International Cultural Property Day April 18.

A series of events will also begin in the southern county of Tainan April 16 to mark the two-month cultural festival in which some 109 activities will be held in 18 counties around Taiwan, according to the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA).

Officials from the CCA, which is one of the organizers of the festival and responsible for directing and guiding the flow of culture in the nation, said Taiwan does not hold back from protecting its cultural assets even though it is not a member of the United Nations.
Taiwan has also amended its regulations on preserving the nation's artifacts to show its resolve in safeguarding the country's treasures, the officials said.
The officials said they expect this year's events will also make Taiwan's role in the international community more noticeable.
Those who are interested in obtaining more information can log onto www.ncrpcp.gov.tw or call 06-2224911-1204.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN PURCHASE DELEGATION VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A purchase delegation from South Korea is visiting Taiwan in search of trade opportunities, officials from the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) said Wednesday.
The delegation, headed by Korea Importers Association (KOIMA), is in Taiwan at the invitation of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and TAITRA.

According to the officials, KOIMA is the largest importers' association in South Korea, with nearly 10,000 member companies, and the delegation plans to purchase items including construction materials, computer peripherals, chemical products, frozen food, vegetables and fruit, automobile components, machinery and electronic parts during its stay in Taiwan.
Under the coordination of TAITRA, the delegation will conduct 73 trade consultations with 47 local companies, with trade transactions expected to reach more than US$2 million.

Ou Chia-juei, deputy director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) , noted that Taiwan's trade deficit with South Korea totaled US$6.27 billion last year and that it reached US$1.91 billion in the first quarter of this year alone.
"If the trade imbalance continues, Taiwan's trade deficit with South Korea may reach US$8 billion this year," Ou added.

Since last year, BOFT has set South Korea as a target market and is helping Taiwan companies to develop there by inviting 277 domestic firms to set up an association to strengthen trade exchanges with their Korean counterparts.
BOFT officials said that this year, they will continue inviting Korea trade delegations to purchase Taiwan products and find agents here for their products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE FREE TRADE HARBOR ZONE PROJECTS GAIN PRELIMINARY APPROVAL

TEXT.P: Taipei Harbor and the Taoyuan air cargo park near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport are expected to become free trade harbor zones in the near future, Executive Yuan officials said Wednesday.

A free trade harbor zone coordination committee under the Executive Yuan gave preliminary approval for the two projects Wednesday and the plans are expected to be formally passed at a committee meeting to be presided over by Vice Premier Wu Rong-i April 28.
Taipei Harbor and the Taoyuan air cargo park will become Taiwan's fourth and fifth free trade harbor zones following the establishment of the Keelung, Kaohsiung and Taichung harbor zones.

The planned Taipei Harbor Free Trade Zone, which will cover an area of 79 hectares and will focus on global logistic services, is expected to create an anual production of NT$23.3 billion (US$739 million) and 1,300 jobs once completed, while the Taoyuan air cargo park is expected to offer 25,000 jobs and create an annual production value of NT$800 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: '319' INVESTIGATORS RETURN FROM U.S. TRIP TO CONSULT FORENSIC EXPERT

TEXT.P: Three members of a special law enforcement team investigating the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu on the eve of the 2004 presidential election have concluded a visit to the United States to consult a world-renowned forensic expert about the case, a spokeswoman said Wednesday.

Kuo Chen-ni, a chief prosecutor at the Tainan Prosecutors' Office in southern Taiwan who concurrently serves as spokeswoman for the investigative team, said that Dr. Henry Lee, a Chinese-American forensic scientist who has assisted in forensic investigations of the shooting, has offered counseling for further probes into the case, particularly the cause of the death of the alleged shooter.

Kuo and two other team members -- Cheng Hsiao-kuei, the Criminal Investigation Bureau's forensic department chief, and Wang Sen-jung, a prosecutor -- departed for the United States April 6 and returned home Tuesday.

According to Kuo, the team informed the U.S. authorities about their travel plan prior to their departure. Kuo said their main purposes was to seek Lee's counsel about certain problems regarding the investigations.

Lee was quoted as having told the trio that all the data collected by the team so far is not sufficient to conclude that Chen Yi-hsiung, a former chairman of the Tainan City Wrestling Association, committed suicide 10 days after he allegedly shot and slightly wounded Chen and Lu March 19 last year.

"Dr. Lee asked us to further investigate the cause of Chen's death. In terms of data and information available at the moment, it remains unclear whether Chen killed himself or was murdered or fell into the sea accidentally," Kuo said.
Based on evidence collected by the team, Kuo said Lee thought that the shootings were most likely carried out by the same gun.
As investigations are still ongoing, Kuo would not reveal further details about Lee's counseling.

After nearly a year of grueling investigations of numerous clues, the investigative team announced a breakthrough early last month by identifying Chen Yi-hsiung as the shooter in the apparent assassination attempt.

President Chen and Lu were slightly wounded when two homemade bullets grazed them as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in Tainan. After the Chen-Lu ticket narrowly won re-election the following day, the sole challenging ticket of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong accused the president of having staged the shooting to win sympathy votes and filed two lawsuits to challenge the election result. The shooting is believed to have gravely aggravated hostility between the ruling and opposition camps.
Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, was found dead in Anping harbor in the southern city of Tainan March 29 last year -- 10 days after the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA RISING BUT NO THREAT TO U.S.: EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: China is rising, with increasing clout in Asia, but it is plagued by domestic and foreign problems and will not be a threat to the United States in the long term, a U.S. expert on Asian affairs said here Wednesday.

Robert G. Sutter from Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., said at a seminar sponsored by the Atlantic Council of the U.S. that China is nothing but another Soviet Union or Japan, two countries whose strength peaked in the 1970's and 1980's, respectively, but fizzled out simultaneously by the turn of the century.

Furthermore, China for the time being is busy with its domestic affairs rather than expanding its clout among Asian states and it has feet of clay -- none of its neighbors trust it and all of them view its rise with misgiving, Sutter said.

Perceiving neighboring states' misgiving about its emergence, Sutter said China is going out of its way to emphasize that it is a peace-loving state, has no intention of dominating the region and has carefully avoided challenging the United States position in Asia.

China's influence in Asia, if any, is minimal, Sutter claimed, adding that China has historical complexity with Russia, although its presence in Central Asia is eclipsed by Russia and the United States. It has a fundamental conflict of interest with India that has not been sorted out by its efforts to reach out to New Delhi.

China might be considered a big power by its neighbors in Southeast Asia, which rely heavily on it for their economic development. However, China's influence in the area is limited because these states are wary of China's emergence and their cooperation with the United States to fight terrorism has diluted China's influence, according to Sutter.
Sutter further made the claim that China "has no influence over Taiwan" and has turned to the United States for help, as it has done with Japan.
Facing the emergence of China, Sutter said, the United States is trying to contain China's influence while engaging with Beijing.

Sutter said Washington offers to cooperate with China, but at the same time it demonstrates to China it has the power and determination to stop war. This, coupled with President George Bush's reputation as a leader who will punish his enemies, have effectively deterred Beijing from embarking upon military adventures in Asia, he said.
At the same seminar, Banning Garrett from the Atlantic Council of the United States said China's rise is more an opportunity than a crisis for the world.

For the industrialized countries, Garrett said, China is a huge potential market they cannot ignore. For China, the industrialized countries have the technology it needs to develop its economy, and these mutual beneficial relationships make war between them almost impossible, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S BIDS TO JOIN INTERNATIONAL GROUPS DEPENDS ON ITS OWN EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to seek to join international organizations through its own efforts, a government spokesman said Wednesday.
Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said that Taiwan's aim is to assume its responsibility as a member of the international community and to avoid becoming a loophole in international groupings.
"Our own efforts are the most important support on which our bid relies," he stressed.
Cho made the remarks when commenting on reports that Beijing is willing to help Taiwan participate in World Health Organization (WHO) activities.
Beijing's move shows that what it has done to block Taiwan's participation in the WHO is unreasonable and irrational, he said.
Cho said he did not feel Beijing's goodwill toward Taiwan in offering assistance to Taiwan's WHO bid, especially after it enacted the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS REBUT CHINESE CRITICISM

TEXT.P: Government officials shot back at criticism by Chinese officials about Taiwan's decision to withdraw permission for two Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan and to restrict opposition parties' associations with China.
You Ying-lung, a spokesman for the Mainland Affairs Council, said Beijing can easily improve its ties with Taiwan by dealing with government rather than wooing the opposition parties.
He accused Beijing of trying to split Taiwan by repeatedly inviting opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to visit China.
The MAC spokesman also urged political parties to realize Beijing's attempts and avoid playing into its hands to the detriment of Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Government Information Office Vice Minister Yi Rung-tsung said Taiwan withdrew its permission for the state-run Xinhua news agency and People's Daily to station reporters in Taipei because they never cover Taiwan's stories without political bias.

Handing out a list of Taiwan-related stories carried in the People's Daily in March, Yi told a news conference that the newspaper has misused its privilege of posting reporters in Taiwan, as has Xinhua.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE ANTI-SECESSION LAW BACKFIRES: US STATE DEPARTMENT OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chinese enactment of its Anti-Secession Law has backfired on the Chinese government, an official from the State Department said Thursday.

Under Secretary for Political Affairs R. Nicholas Burns, told the Congress's Committee on Armed Services and Committee on International Relations that the Anti-Secession Law is very much against the spirit of what should promptly be the relationship across the Taiwan Straits, and that's the peaceful means of resolving disputes, not the threat of force or the use of force.

Burns said the law had the impact of creating some doubt within the European Union (EU) about whether or not the embargo of arms sales to China should be lifted, and added US argument that the embargo should be maintained.

Burns said the EU has now taken the time to consider the larger implications of lifting the embargo, and the US State Department doesn't belief that the EU is close to a decision to lifting the embargo.

Burns said the US response to the Anti-Secession Law is vigorous and very clear, and the Chinese government is aware of US interest in seeing that the disputes across the Taiwan Straits are handled only in a peaceful manner, and therefore there is no need at this point to take any punitive action in the economic realm to express US unhappiness with the Anti-Secession Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 16, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO TAKE ACTION BEFORE E.U. ARMS SALES BAN CAN BE LIFTED
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 15 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Y.S. Lo)

TEXT.P: Luxembourg Foreign Minister Jean Asselborn said Friday that China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law has complicated the debate among European Union member states on whether or not to lift the E.U. arms sales embargo on China.

The minister also said since the foreign ministers of 25 E.U. nations failed to reach a consensus on lifting the ban at an informal meeting held in Brussels, the E.U. hopes Beijing will take this as a sign that it needs to take concrete steps before the ban can be lifted.

Pointing to Article 8 of the Anti-Secession Law, that states, in part: "If the Taiwan independence secessionist forces should act under any name or by any means to cause the fact of Taiwan's secession from China, or that major incidents entailing Taiwan's secession from China should occur, or that possibilities for a peaceful reunification should be exhausted, the state shall employ non-peaceful means and other necessary measures to protect China's sovereignty and territorial integrity, " Asselborn said that this has made the E.U. discussion on lifting the ban more complicated.
Luxembourg currently holds the seat of the E.U.'s rotating presidency until the end of June this year and all E.U. members have expressed the hope that China can find a solution to problem.

"Now, it's not up to the rotating presidency, the European Commission nor each member state to make a decision on lifting the ban. China should also take concrete actions, " the minister said, adding that the E.U. hopes the Beijing government will release those who are still in jail due to their participation in the 1989 democratic demonstrations in Tiananmen Square and to sign the U.N. Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
The minister further said that if China signs the U.N. covenant and puts it into practice, it will help toward having the arms sales ban lifted.

According to Asselborn, during the meeting, the foreign ministers also expressed the hope that their countries can further strengthen economic and political relations with China, but said that they would also pass on to China the message of E.U. values, such as human rights and the peaceful settlement of disputes.

Meanwhile, German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer said after the meeting that China can make an important contribution to a consensus that might be reached by the E.U. member states on lifting the ban, pointing to its ratification of the U.N. human rights covenant and its efforts to reduce tensions in the Taiwan Strait.
Criticizing the Anti-Secession Law that poses a threat to Taiwan, Fischer said that the law is a "backward step of a non-constructive nature."
Fischer, a member of the German Greens, which is a ruling coalition partner of German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's Social Democratic Party, is keenly opposed to lifting the ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
