The Japan Times: Change constitution: Japan's Lower House report
a Lower House panel submitted a final report Friday to Speaker Yohei Kono, stressing the need to amend the Constitution's war- renouning Article 9 and to allow a female to ascend the Chrysanthemum Throne.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : MM Lee on casino: Can Singapore afford to say no?
In the strongest indication yet that Monday's answer will be yes, Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew posed this question to Singaporeans: Can the country afford to say no to a casino?
So, the Government had little desire to draw in tourist attractions such as Fumula-One racing, for example. And in the 1970s, when entrepreneur Run Run Show asked about building a casino, the answer was a flat no.
But the world has changed, said Mr Lee. Today, Singaporeans travel and can go to casinos elsewhere. Whether they want a casino or not, the fact is that one will pop up in a neighbouring.
Mr Lee shared these observations last night at the Citibank Legacies of Leadership speaker series, where he was the keynote speaker.
The Lianhe Zaobao: MM Lee: We have more trouble if we don't have casinos.
Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew's comments come ahead of Monday's parliamentary sitting, when the Government will announce its decision on a casino. It comes after a year-long debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT COULD BREAK LAWS FOR SIGNING 'PEACE ACCORD' WITH CHINA: MAC

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) may violate the country's laws if it signs a "peace accord" with China without the government's authorization, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said Saturday.

Wu was commenting on reports that KMT Chairman Lien Chan, during his upcoming visit to China, might sign a peace accord with Chinese President Hu Jintao -- who is also general-secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) -- to officially end the KMT-CPC civil war that lasted around two decades on China before the KMT fled to Taiwan in 1949.

Wu said the government will not interfere in any forms of lawful social exchanges between the KMT and CPC but the KMT could violate certain laws if it is involved without the government's authorization in activities concerning government or political affairs.

Wu stressed that such restrictions are not unique to Taiwan, saying it is also unlawful in countries such as the United States and France for any individuals or civic groups to negotiate with a foreign government without their governments' permission.

According to Wu, as the CPC is the ruling party of the People's Republic of China, which controls political and military powers, the signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait peace accord should be a government-to-government matter.
Noting that Taiwan is a democratic country that deals with political affairs according to the rules of democracy, Wu urged all politicians and political groups in Taiwan to abide by these rules.

Prosecutors have launched an investigation into KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang for alleged treason after he reached a so-called 10-point consensus with Beijing authorities during his visit to China last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO REPORT TO NATION ON CHINA TRIP PRIOR TO VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Saturday that he will report to the nation before making his "journey of peace" to mainland China
Lien said that KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng is currently arranging for his mainland visit, and after the plan is fleshed out, he will report to the nation.

Speaking at a meeting of KMT party elders, he also tried to deflect criticism of the visit as one by "pro-communists" by Vice President Annette Lu, saying that he had lived in Taiwan for more than six decades without even once visiting China.
In contrast, Lu visited the mainland for more than 20 days over a decade ago, prompting Lien to ask, "Is it fair to say that she can go, but that my visit is 'pro-communist?'"

He also said that the KMT under the late party chairman and President Chiang Chin-kuo allowed local residents to visit their families on the mainland, terminated martial law, lifted the ban on political parties, allowed more media to operate and moved the country firmly along the path of democracy.

"Should any cross-strait contacts be considered pro-communist? " Lien asked, citing the Koo-Wang talks in 1993 as an example. The talks took place in Singapore between the late Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's former top negotiator with the mainland and former chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and his Beijing counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

The Koo-Wang talks marked the first high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after a hiatus of more than five decades. The talks began a number of exchanges and dialogues between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the next few years before relations stalled after former President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" statement on cross-strait ties in 1999.
Lien questioned Lu's way of thinking and vision, saying that he was worried about "Taiwan's future if the island continues to move along in such a closed-door mindset."
Meanwhile, Lien said that he hoped that the fierce race for the chairmanship of the KMT would not overshadow the important election of members for the mission-oriented National Assembly.
Lien said that the election of the delegates to the ad hoc National Assembly will be crucial to the promotion of constitutional amendments.

He said the KMT has nominated 160 candidates to vie for National Assembly seats. The delegates' mission is to pass a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last August, which include reducing the number of legislators in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan by almost half, changing the electoral system from "multi-seat" to "single seat and two votes, " and the abolition of the National Assembly.
Lien said that the party has long advocated these amendments as a step toward realizing legislative and central government reforms.

He reaffirmed his earlier statement at the party's central standing committee that every party member should focus on the National Assembly election, adding that the upcoming election for KMT chairman is not the most important issue now; most important is the election for National Assembly members.
The election for KMT chairman will be held on July 16, and National Assembly members will be elected May 14.

"Every party member, especially candidates for party chairman, should keep this in mind, " he said, referring to two of the party's vice chairmen -- Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng -- who are vying for the party's top post.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Stocks Hit New Low for 2005; IBM's Earnings, Reports on Economy Prompt Major Sell-Off.
Stocks plunged to new lows for the year on Friday as investors reacted fearfully to a poor earnings report from IBM and to fresh data suggesting the economy is softening and that consumers, long the bulwark of U.S. economic growth, are beginning to lose confidence, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP WISHES EVERYONE CAN HAVE A HEALTHY LIFE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu on Saturday urged the public to show more concern and do more to create a healthy society and healthier earth.
Lu made the remarks at a learning camp held in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, aimed at training teachers to promote a healthy society.
Lu said that a group of some 1,200 "rangers" will be formed in May to safeguard the forests and mountains of Taiwan.

Among these "rangers, " 600 will be serving their alternative military service, while the remaining will be aboriginal people, Lu said, adding that they will also be dedicated to preventing landslides which occur frequently in Taiwan following earthquakes and typhoons.

In addition to natural disasters, Lu said there are other kinds of disasters that Taiwan must be aware of, such as China trying to lure Taiwan investors to the mainland as an "economic landslide, " in which she said Taiwanese investors will collapse when China suddenly changes its investment policy.

Lu described the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) as currently fawning over China as being in contrast to its previous anti-communism policy, calling it a "political landslide." Lu was referring to the visits of several high-ranking KMT officials to China, including one of its vice chairmen, P.K. Chiang, who reached a 10-point consensus with Chinese authorities on a wide variety of issues, such as agricultural cooperation, cross-Taiwan Strait transport, and the opening of China's financial markets.

Chiang's visit came under criticism by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and has been discussed at length on the island, with many saying that the KMT has no right to reach agreements with Beijing, in which the government's authority is involved.
Lu also criticized the deterioration of social order and lamented that there is too much gossip on television news and newspapers, classifying them as "social landslide."
The vice president also talked about suicide and abortion problems, suggesting that there should be better policies to allow people to live a happier life.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISIT TO CHINA 15 YEARS AGO REQUIRED NO REPORT: VICE PRESIDENT LU

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that the only time she visited mainland China was in 1990 when she was a private citizen who did not hold any public office and therefore didn't need to report to anyone about the visit.
Lu was responding to a spokesman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) while she was in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, addressing a training camp sponsored by the Taiwan Public Health Association.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung revealed earlier in the day that Lu traveled to the mainland for a 26-day visit 15 years ago without reporting to the then KMT-administration. Chang spoke after government criticism about a planned visit by KMT Chairman Lien Chan to China.
Lu wondered how Chang found out about her trip to the mainland, speculating that Beijing passed the information to him.
The vice president took the chance to remind the public that everything you say or do on a visit to China can be recorded, and that you don't know when or how the information will be used.
Lu said that she went to the mainland before taking part in legislative elections in 1991, knowing that it would be inconvenient for her to make such a visit after holding public office.
She stressed that there was no law regulating citizens visiting mainland China then. Besides, Lu said she didn't do anything that she couldn't tell others.

She claimed that China supplied the information of her mainland visit to the KMT, which is tantamount to telling the people that Beijing can use whatever information it has against people, and she would like to remind Lien about this on his upcoming visit to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TRYING TO SET UP LIEN-CHEN PHONE CALL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian attaches great importance to Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's upcoming visit to China and would like to talk to the opposition leader on the phone to express his concern about the visit, according to the Presidential Office Saturday.
Media reports have said that Lien will soon make a visit to China and will meet with Chinese leaders during the visit.

Pointing out that Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun already contacted KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng Friday to pass on the president's sincere message to Lien, the Presidential Office said that Lin was also asked to help make arrangements for a phone conversation between the two political leaders.

The two secretaries-general did not reach any concrete conclusions about the issue and the presidential office has not yet received any response from KMT headquarters, it said, adding that it will continue speaking with the KMT.

Saying that Yu would very much like to meet with Lin, the Presidential Office noted that it also hopes that a talk over the phone can be arranged for Chen and Lien to exchange their views on relevant matters before the latter's visit to China.

It also expressed the hope that Lien will participate in an inter-party leaders meeting pushed by the president to seek consensus between ruling and opposition political parties on issues regarding their cooperation about the nation's development and well-being of the Taiwan people.

Meanwhile, Chen Wen-Chung, director of the presidential office's public affairs department, said Friday night that the presidential office would actively make arrangements for a phone conversation between the president and Lien if the KMT head wishes to talk to the president.
He made the remarks after KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said the same day that Lien does not exclude the possibility of talking to the president by phone.
According to Chang, the KMT general-secretary contacted Yu Friday and proposed to meet with him prior to proceeding to the the phone conversation arrangements between the president and Lien.
Chang said that Lin thinks that his meeting with Yu would facilitate the Chen-Lien talk.

Nevertheless, Lin said Saturday that he prefers to meet with Yu after he returns from the mainland after next week's visit since it would be better for them to discuss things after his consultations with his Chinese counterparts on matters regarding Lien's trip.
Touching on the future phone call between the president and Lien, Lin said, "The president has this expectation and we won't disappoint him."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTA TO HOLD URBAN DEVELOPMENT CONFERENCE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Sixteen experts from various European countries will gather in Taipei April 18 to join a four-day conference to discuss urban development issues, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said Saturday.

The 16 invited guests will consist of scholars, along with serving and retired officials from France, England, Spain, Germany, Poland and the Netherlands. The conference is being organized by the non-profit "International Network for Urban Development" (INTA), MOI Construction and Planning Agency Director Chen Kuang-hsiung said.

Chen said those at the conference will discuss policy changes in urban renewal, which is one focus of the Republic of China government's administration. He added that Taiwan's eagerness to amend existing regulations and policies regarding urban development is the reason for hosting the conference.
Chen said he expects more offshore investments will be brought into the country by amending policies and creating a better commercial environment.
While many international bodies refuse Taiwan's participation, the INTA is one of a handful that allowed Taiwan to join under the name of the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REJECTS CHINA'S OFFER FOR DPP TO VISIT CHINA FOR FARM TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu rejected China's invitation for ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) members to visit China to discuss issues concerning sales of Taiwanese agricultural products to China.

Wu said the government will only consider this invitation if Beijing respects Taiwan as a democratic and pluralistic society and promises not to use any non-peaceful means to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait differences.

After the enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan, the people of Taiwan hope China will do something to promote cross-strait peace and democracy, instead of trying to divide Taiwan or offering some "small favors" to try to please the Taiwan people, he said.

In an interview with China's state-run Xinhua News Agency late Friday, Chen Yunlin, director of Beijing's Taiwan Affairs Office, said Beijing welcomes the DPP to lead members of Taiwan's agricultural sector to China to discuss issues concerning sales of Taiwanese agricultural products to China.
Chen said China has maintained no contact with the DPP because the DPP has stuck to its pro-independence platform.
However, he added that Beijing will differentiate average DPP members from a small majority of pro-independence hardliners and welcomes these DPP members to visit China in a proper capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN DEPARTS FOR SINGAPORE VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan departed for Singapore Saturday for an unannounced visit.

Lien kept a low profile, with the duration and itinerary of his Singapore visit remaining unknown. He was accompanied by only two party officials -- KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang and Ting Yuan-chao, the director of Lien's office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES GOVERNMENT TO FORBID KMT CHAIRMAN FROM VISITING CHINA

TEXT.P: An official of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the government on Saturday to forbid opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan from visiting China, saying Lien's reported plan to sign a "peace accord" with Beijing is "obviously unlawful."

According to TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming, a peace accord should be an agreement between governments, and the KMT, which is no longer in power in Taiwan, is not qualified to seal such a document with the Communist Party of China (CPC) , which represents the government of the People's Republic of China.
Chen claimed that the KMT will obviously violate the country's laws if it negotiates and seals a "peace accord" without the government's authorization with China.
Also, as a former vice president of the Republic of China, Lien is not suitable to act as a negotiator with Beijing unless he obtains the government's authorization beforehand, Chen said.
He urged the Democratic Progressive Party government to exercise its authority and restrict Lien from going to China.

Local media reports said that Lien plans to visit China in late April and might sign a "peace accord" with Chinese President and CPC General-Secretary Hu Jintao to officially end the KMT-CPC civil war that lasted around two decades on China before the KMT fled to Taiwan in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN URGED TO REQUEST THAT CHINA CHANGE ITS POLITICAL SYSTEM
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 15 (CNA) (By C.S. Chu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A former leader in the 1989 democratic demonstrations in Tiananmen Square on Friday suggested that Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan ask Beijing to change its political system and to practice democracy if the KMT head decides to visit mainland China in the near future.

Wang Dan, who is currently studying in the United States, made the suggestion while delivering a speech on " The Road to Democracy for China and the Taiwan Experience" at an overseas Chinese cultural and educational center in the city.
Media reports have said that Lien will soon make a visit to China.

There is a big difference between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wang said, adding that Taiwan has become a democratic society, while mainland China is still under the rule of a totalitarian regime.
"Cross-Taiwan Strait relations cannot have durable peace and stability if such differences remain unchanged," he said.

Without talking about issues regarding China's political democratization and only touching on matters relating to the sales of Taiwan agricultural products to the mainland or the interests of mainland-based Taiwanese business people would harm the nature and character of the island, Wang further said.

Wang also expressed the hope that Lien will not avoid raising democracy issues during his visit to the mainland since the 23 million people of Taiwan would very much like to see China change its political system.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER WON'T ACCOMPANY LIEN ON CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday he has politely turned down an invitation to accompany Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on his visit to China.
Wang made the remarks during his visit to the eastern county of Hualien, where he was trying to gain support for his bid to win KMT chairmanship in an intra-party election scheduled for July 16.

As the Republic of China's legislative speaker, Wang said he has set "four prerequisites" for his future China trip -- national demand, popular consent, endorsement by a legislative resolution, parity and dignity.
Wang, also a KMT vice chairman, revealed that Lien had invited him to join a KMT delegation, to be led by Lien, to China in the near future.

Because of the "four prerequisites" premise, Wang said he has no intention of accompanying Lien on the much discussed China trip. Moreover, Wang said he feels that now is not an opportune time to visit China. He did not elaborate on this point.
Asked whether Lien would meet with President Chen Shui-bian prior to his departure for a China trip, Wang said Friday's intra-party discussions didn't reach a positive decision on the issue.

"Participants to yesterday's meeting only decided to authorize KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng to inform President Chen's chief of staff, Yu Shyi-kun, of the exact time for Lien's China trip and the topics to be addressed during the visit, " Wang said, adding that to the best of his understanding, it remains uncertain whether there will be a Chen-Lien meeting prior Lien's departure to China.

While the race for the KMT chairmanship between Wang and another KMT vice chairman, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, has continued to gain momentum, some KMT party elders have been urging Lien to continue in the top party post. Wang commented that so long as Lien is willing to stay, he will throw his full support behind Lien.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ISSUE CONCERNS GERMAN MEDIA
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 15 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: China's passage of its Anti-Secession Law and the European Union's (EU) plan to lift its arms embargo against China has put Taiwan in the spotlight of the German media, with a major broadcasting company producing a special radio program about Taiwan Friday.

Several Taiwanese politicians and scholars were interviewed in Taipei by a Bayerischen Rundfunks journalist for the program, titled "Taiwan -- the Republic of China, " to discuss their opinions on the issues.

In the program, broadcast on Friday evening, Legislator Lin Cho-shui of Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party told the German audience that Taiwan, like any other country in the world, is independent with its own government and Constitution.
Lin criticized China's Anti-Secession Law, which depicts Taiwan as an unsolved problem in a civil war, arguing that the interpretation of Taiwan as part of China is nothing but nonsense.

Meanwhile, Legislator Shuai Hua-ming of the opposition Kuomintang expressed concerns over the EU's plan to lift its arms embargo against China. He explained that China's military budget has grown annually, and the EU's planned move could lead to unrest in Asia. Meanwhile, Taiwan will face the reinforced threat of China's annexation.

Vice Chairman Huang Wei-feng of the Mainland Affairs Council told the German media that Taiwan dreams to be recognized and respected as a country that can take part in any international activities without being boycotted by China.

When questioned about recent disputes generated by Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law, which allows the use of "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan under certain circumstances, the official said Taiwan will do all it can to settle any disputes in a peaceful manner.

Professor Tsai Wei of the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University said that he hopes Taiwan can cooperate with the United States and other strong powers in the international community to push for changes in China's economic, political and social fields.
However, the scholar admitted Taiwan must first improve its efforts to promote economic and political democratization, and then seek support and acknowledgment from the international community.
The program will be rebroadcast on Bayern 2 Radio on April 18 at 6: 30 p.m local time.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPOSIT BALANCE AT CHUNGHWA POST HITS 10-YEAR HIGH: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The deposit balance of Chunghwa Post's banking service hit a 10-year high of NT$3.49 trillion (US$110.09 billion) as of the end of February this year, according to the latest report released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure represented a rise of 7.2 percent from that of the same period last year and accounted for 15 percent of the combined deposit balance of major financial institutions, the report said.
As of the end of February, a total of 30.14 million savings accounts had been opened at Chunghwa Post, up 1.6 percent year-on-year.

Of these accounts, passbook savings accounted for 22.51 million, with a deposit balance of NT$1.36 trillion, while fixed deposits accounted for 3.59 million, with a deposit balance of NT$2.12 trillion.
Meanwhile, the combined deposit balance of major financial institutions registered NT$23.39 trillion as of the end of February, 45.4 percent of which are fixed deposits.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT HELD TO CELEBRATE 'WATER FESTIVAL' IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Adults and children celebrated the "Songkran Festival" at the Sungshan elementary school in Taipei Saturday as water was splashed and squirted into the air to symbolize washing away bad luck.

Officials, city councillors and new immigrants were among those who got soaked during a water fight to celebrate the festival, which originated in Thailand. Water trucks joined the celebration by shooting streams of water into the air. Food stands provided the crowd with a place to take a breather while kids and adults, in raincoats or not, enjoyed the festival held by the Taipei City Government on Saturday.

The "Songkran Festival, " also known as the "Water Festival, " is part of Thailand's three-day traditional new year celebration beginning April 13. During the festival, Thai people show their respect to their elders by pouring scented water onto their hands, before the elders wish the youngsters good luck and prosperity in return.

Since many countries including Thailand and Cambodia celebrate the festival every year, officials invited new immigrants from Southeast Asian countries to the event and described it as "a meaningful activity."

DOC.HEADLINE: NOW IS THE WRONG TIME FOR DPP COUNTY CHIEFS TO VISIT CHINA: DPP

TEXT.P: It is not an opportune moment for ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) county chiefs and mayors to visit China now, and the party should not and will not negotiate with China on behalf of the government, a DPP official said Saturday.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin made the remarks in response to media reports that Beijing has invited DPP members to send a delegation to China for talks regarding cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural exchanges, and extended an invitation to several DPP county chiefs and mayors to attend the 2005 Asia Pacific Cities Summit (APCS) to be held in China in October.
Yen noted that the DPP has adopted an open attitude toward any party official's China visit, if such visits are conducted without preconditions and operated on an equal footing with China.
He went on that according to the laws of the nation, county chiefs and mayors should obtain the central government's approval before their China visits.

However, Yen thought it was not an opportune time for any DPP county chiefs and mayors to visit China following the recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law by Beijing, which legalizes an attack on Taiwan should the island seek formal independence.

Turning to cross-strait agricultural exchanges, Yen stressed that the DPP should not and will not replace the government to negotiate with China for any issues that involve the exercise of government authority.

"Neither should other political parties [negotiate with China about such issues], "Yen added. Yen was believed to be referring to the recent visit to China by one of the opposition Kuomintang's vice chairmen, P.K. Chiang, who reached a 10-point consensus with Chinese authorities on a wide variety of issues, including agricultural cooperation, cross-strait transport, and the opening of China's financial markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS SAY LIEN'S TRYING TO SKIRT CRIMINAL CODE A BAD IDEA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan would most likely still be breaking the law if he seeks to circumvent the Criminal Code by signing an agreement with China using the cover of a "party-to-party" model, ranking officials of the Executive Yuan said Saturday.

The officials made the remarks amid reports that Lien will visit China at the end of April and that Chinese President Hu Jintao will meet with Lien in his concurrent capacity as the Chinese Communist Party's secretary-general.

Lien and Hu could sign an agreement to terminate the civil war between the KMT and the CCP, and both could also touch on a framework for cross-strait peace, a non-military zone and a "peace zone, " the reports said.

The officials said that they expect the agreement regarding the termination of the civil war to be crafted by the KMT using a "party-to-party" model to try to evade Article 113 of the Criminal Code which stipulates that "for those matters that require prior government approval, if a person without such approval signs an accord with a foreign government or with those dispatched by a foreign government, he or she is subject to life imprisonment or imprisonment of no less than seven years."

They reminded Lien that China is a communist country and its constitution stipulates clearly that the Chinese Communist Party is paramount and the line between the party and the government is indistinguishable.

"China is not a democratic country, " they said; therefore, whether it is peace talks or an agreement between the KMT and the CCP, odds are that the law will be violated and the KMT should seriously rethink the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CONTINUE HELPING AFRICAN ALLY'S HEALTH CARE: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue helping Sao Tome and Principe's efforts in the prevention of malaria, and will also invite the African country's health care personnel to Taiwan for training, officials of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

Sao Tome and Principe Health Minister Alberto Manuel dos Santo, heading a group of health officials, accompanied by his country's ambassador to the Republic of China, Ladislau Quaresma Frederico d'Almeida, are currently on a visit to Taiwan. They visited the Taipei County Health Bureau and the county's Banchiao Health Center Friday.
The Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe is faced with a number of health care difficulties, with malaria topping its list of diseases other than AIDS and tuberculosis.
A visiting Sao Tome official said that his country hopes Taiwan could help train its personnel in public health affairs.
Sao Tome is one of the over two dozen countries in the world that maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Director-General Chang Wu-hsiu of the DOH Bureau of International Cooperation indicated that the Center for Disease Control has been promoting a counter-malaria project in Sao Tome for more than a year, adding that there have been encouraging preliminary results.
The DOH will continue to dispatch health missions to the African country, Chang noted, adding that his department will also provide training programs for Sao Tome public health workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT INSISTS '1992 CONSENSUS' NONEXISTENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Saturday rejected a claim by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) that representatives of Taiwan and China reached a consensus on the "one China" issue in their talks held in Hong Kong in 1992.

Chen made the comment while addressing a meeting of the Rotary International Taiwan's Taipei region, backing up his point with a biography of late Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu -- who acted as Taipei's chief negotiator with Beijing.

Chen said Koo's biography notes that the so-called "1992 consensus" is a term coined by former Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi in April 2000, less than one month before Chen's first inauguration.
The term has since been used by China to support its "one China" principle, Chen pointed out.

The KMT, which remained in power in Taiwan until May 2000, claims that Taipei and Beijing agreed during the 1992 talks to allow either side to interpret the meaning of "one China" freely, with Taipei insisting that the "one China" referred to "the Republic of China" and Beijing insisting that it meant "the People's Republic of China."

Citing Koo's opinions, Chen said no conclusion was reached between the two sides on the "one China" issue in the 1992 talks, although Beijing accepted Taipei's proposal that both sides maintained different interpretations of "one China."

However, Beijing is now claiming that the two sides both agreed on the principle of "one China" in 1992, which according to Beijing means "one country, two systems, " a model that will downgrade the status of Taiwan to a local government like Hong Kong, Chen said.

The president criticized the Anti-Secession Law enacted by China last month as trying to provide a legal basis for its attempt to invade Taiwan and as a violation of the principles of peace, justice and civilization.
The legislation has seriously hurt the feelings of the Taiwanese people and pulled cross-Taiwan Strait relations back to a deadlock of confrontation, he said.
He urged Beijing leaders not to miscalculate the cross-strait situation, especially the mainstream public opinion in Taiwan.

Chen said he believes the principle of peace and mutual respect are the only feasible approaches leading to the resolution of cross-strait differences and that the two sides should jointly create a favorable climate for cross-strait peace and reconciliation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCP DISARMING TAIWAN-TARGETED MISSILES AN OPEN QUESTION: KMT

TEXT.P: It is uncertain whether opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will urge China to dismantle its missiles targeting Taiwan during his planned visit to the mainland, a party official said Saturday.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung made the remarks in response to questions from journalists on whether Lien will touch on this issue during his planned meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who is also the general-secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).

Concerning the reports that Lien might sign an agreement with Hu to end the so called "KMT-CCP civil war" which lasted several decades on the mainland before the KMT retreated to Taiwan in 1949, Chang said he had no idea about this.

Noting that the KMT has long promoted benign interactions between the two sides of Taiwan Strait, Chang said when Lien visits China, he will insist on upholding the country's dignity and maintaining an equal footing with China while promoting cross-strait peace.
"His visit will help promote the welfare of the people of Taiwan," Chang claimed.
Chang stressed that Lien's upcoming China visit will focus on the concept and framework of peace, and many topics can be discussed.
Asked whether Lien will touch on the issue of China's dismantling hundreds of missiles targeting Taiwan, Chang said, "It depends on the situation at that moment."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SUICIDE PREVENTION ACT' COULD HELP REDUCE NUMBER OF DEATHS: CHARITY

TEXT.P: Passing a law to help prevent suicide could reduce the number of people in Taiwan who take their own lives, a representative of a non-profit organization said Saturday.
The Shepherd Love Association petitioned legislators to immediately pass the act by holding a two-day signature drive in Kaohsiung Saturday.

Wu Mei-li, the association's CEO, said while the ROC government has made suicide prevention one of its top priorities by setting up help centers and keeping hotlines open, suicide has ranked ninth since 2002 as the cause of death in Taiwan.
"Laws regarding suicide prevention need to be enacted," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STONE MONKEYS EXHIBITION OPENS IN CHIAYI CITY

TEXT.P: A stone sculpture exhibition organized by the Chiayi Stone Sculpture Association opened at a cultural park in Chiayi City, southern Taiwan, Saturday.

During an opening ceremony for the event, which was presided over by Chiayi Mayor Chen Li-chen, the group presented a stone monkey sculpture to the city-owned park as a gift, while in return it received the city government's promise to provide outdoor space for artistic creations, according to city officials.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen said that the southern Taiwan city has been dedicated to the art of stone sculpture, especially monkey-shaped sculptures, for more than 60 years, and the association played a key role in promoting the city's cultural development.

She indicated that the city government is now working to build a stone sculpture park as part of the city's efforts to develop a culture industry with local characters, noting that construction of the planned park is expected to be finished by the end of this year.
The city will also initiate a yearly "stone monkey festival" as part of efforts to boost tourism, Chen added.
Chiayi is passed through by the Pachang River, one of major rivers in Taiwan, which produces abundant high-quality stones perfect for sculpting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PARTY CAN TALK WITH CHINA ON SOVEREIGNTY-RELATED MATTERS: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that no individual political party can accomplish matters related to national sovereignty when talking with China, urging opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to talk with him first prior to a planned visit to the mainland.
President Chen made the remarks while attending an activity organized by the Rotar International Taiwan's Taipei region.
The president said that he supported Lien's visit to China and could authorize him to talk with Chinese leader Hu Jintao on something.

But on matters related to the government's authority, there should be prior consensus between the ruling and the opposition parties in the best interests of the nation and the people, the president said.

Beijing's cherished "one China" formula is in fact "one country, two systems, " which is an attempt to Hong Kongnize and localize Taiwan, Chen said, adding that this is an issue that will involve a gross change of national sovereignty.
The president said that whether Lien wants to talk about a cross-strait peace accord or an agreement to formally end the civil war all involve matters of national sovereignty.
"If one political party can unilaterally decide on matters related to national sovereignty, it is turning a blind eye to the government's authority,' he said.

Any cross-strait consensus or agreement reached with China will be rendered void and meaningless without the participation and authorization of the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the president said.

Also, any attempt or gimmick that seeks to denigrate or splinter Taiwan will not bridge the distance between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but will allow both sides to drift further apart, he said.

The president pointed out that the number of China's missiles targeting Taiwan increases by 120 every year. With the total number of missiles now reaching 725, the president said that it is meaningless to say how many could be removed to show goodwill, saying that Beijing should instead remove and destroy them all.
Noting that the KMT and the Communist Party of China held discussions regarding peace in 1945 before the KMT lost the mainland, the president asked if the KMT was prepared to lose Taiwan too.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN'S VISIT TO BRING MORE CERTAINTY TO TAIWAN STRAIT: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday expressed the hope that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's planned visit to mainland China will "bring more certainty to the Taiwan Strait."
Ma, who concurrently serves as a KMT vice chairman, made the remarks as an aside at a group wedding ceremony for 72 couples.

Reports said that Lien could embark on his visit to China at the end of this month and sign a "peace accord" with the Communist Party of China and touch on issues related to non-military zones or "peace zones."

DOC.HEADLINE: CULTURAL FESTIVAL BEGINS IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: Ahead of International Cultural Property Day that falls on April 18, Taiwan will assist its diplomatic allies not only economically, but also culturally, an official of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) announced Saturday.

CCA Chairman Chen Chih-nan made the comments in the southern city of Tainan during an opening ceremony to mark the commencement of a two-month cultural festival while officials and several guests from other countries watched. A series of events will begin in 18 counties around Taiwan to stress the importance of preserving the nation's cultural assets.
The ceremony was chosen to be held in Tainan because the city is full of Taiwan's historical relics and artifacts.

Chen said in addition to commercial exchanges, Taiwan will engage in cultural and social exchanges with its diplomatic allies. Taiwan will donate US$700,000 to Guatemala in a plan to help the country restore its artifacts, he said.

"Only advanced nations are willing to preserve cultural artifacts," Chen said. "Taiwan hopes the festival will teach the public their significance and help Taiwan become one of the countries known for its culture," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: End of the road as Rover rescue collapses.
About 5,000 car workers in the West Midlands were left jobless last night after the complete collapse of MG Rover as the last hopes of a deal with a Chinese partner disappeared.
They will receive redundancy notices this weekend and will be told within a week about their chances of a job in other industries. It is the biggest single loss of jobs for five years. The huge Longbridge plant in Birmingham will now be mothballed with the 400-acre site probably being redeveloped.
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, trying to soften the blow both to the area and to their election campaign, rushed to Birmingham to announce a Â£150 million support package for retraining, redundancy pay and helping Rover's suppliers.
Financial Times: Â£150m to aid Rover workers.
The final collapse of MG Rover brutally intruded on Labour's election campaign on Friday, after the Chinese ended any lingering hope of a rescue deal for the stricken carmaker.
Tony Blair and Gordon Brown abandoned their campaign schedules to rush to the West Midlands. Their second emergency visit to Birmingham in eight days came after the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation sounded Rover's death knell by confirming unequivocally it would not buy the company as a going concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Change to the Clean Air Act Is Built Into New Energy Bill
A brief provision in the energy bill that was approved by a U.S. House committee this week, if it becomes law, would make one of the most significant changes to the Clean Air Act in 15 years, allowing communities whose air pollution comes from hundreds of miles away to delay meeting national air quality standards until their offending neighbors clean up their own air. Under the new provision, the "downwind" states would not be required to meet clean air standards until the "upwind" states that were contributing to the problem had done so. Currently, states can get more time but only if they agree to added cleanup measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER URGES CAUTION IN INVESTING IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i on Saturday urged Taiwan businessmen wanting to invest in the mainland to be cautious, saying that risks there are still high.
Wu made the remarks while delivering a speech to over 100 business representatives in Taichung, central Taiwan.
On the economic development of Taiwan, Wu noted that Taiwan's unemployment rate currently stands at around 4 percent, which should be good when compared with other industrialized countries.

Taiwan's economic growth was 5.7 percent last year, compared with the average growth of 4 percent of the world. Taiwan's economic growth this year is expected to reach 4.2 percent, which will also be better than the average 3 percent globally.

On Taiwan businessmen flocking to invest in the mainland, Wu said that they may be impressed by the development in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, but fail to notice that elsewhere in China, development is still retarded.

Taiwan businessmen must not be fooled by the glamorous facade of China, Wu said, adding that China's economy has kept on growing while the development of the political front has been stalled, saying that this is bound to conflict.
Wu reminded Taiwan businessmen not just to look to cheap labor and land when considering investing in China, saying that they should diversify investments to reduce risk.
China often says how much money Taiwan businessmen have earned from the mainland, but it fails to mention how much foreign exchange reserves they have earned for China, Wu said.
The economic development of the mainland owes much to the capital and equipment introduced by Taiwan businessmen, he added.
Wu also pointed to the outstanding high-tech industry in Taiwan, saying that 20 Taiwan high-tech products hold the No. 1 global market share.

But he also said that with high-tech industry firmly established in Taiwan, the government has to reconsider whether to provide tax incentives to the industry, adding that social justice must also be factored in.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-CHINA 'PEACE ACCORD' HARMFUL TO TAIWAN: DPP

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will seriously damage the national interests of Taiwan and create international misunderstandings if it is to sign a "peace accord" with China, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin said Saturday.

Yen was referring to an upcoming visit to China by KMT Chairman Lien Chan, during which Lien reportedly might seal a "peace accord" with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to officially end the KMT-CPC civil war that lasted around two decades on China before the KMT fled to Taiwan in 1949.

Yen warned that Lien's trip -- expected to take place less than two months after China enacted its Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan -- is very inappropriate because it will be tantamount to an endorsement of the aggressive legislation.
To create a false impression of peace by signing a "peace accord" with Beijing at this point will reduce the Taiwan issue to an internal affair of China, he said.

In particular, it will feed Beijing's bid to eliminate the government of Republic of China and downgrade Taiwan to become a locality under the People's Republic of China if the "peace accord" is to be signed for the purpose of ending the "civil war, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPORTS GAMES FOR JUNIOR AND SENIOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS BEGINS

TEXT.P: The 2005 Sports Games for junior and senior high school students began on Saturday, with President Chen Shui-bian addressing the inauguration ceremony held at the county stadium in Chiayi, southern Taiwan.
Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng, and chairman of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports Chen Chuan-show were also present at the ceremony.
The competition, that will last until April 21, drew the participation of some 12,000 athletes around the island.
Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen urged the athletes to show courage and confidence in pursuit of their dreams.

Chen Shih-hsin, the taekwondo gold medallist at the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, and Chen Yi-an, a gold medallist at a taekwondo demonstration competition at 1988 Olympics in Seoul, brought the torches to the stadium, catching much of the attention of the public.
A pop music concert will be held later the night to usher in the Games, in which a total of 16 sporting events will be held.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN ON LECTURE TOUR OF SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan departed for Singapore Saturday for a brief visit at the invitation of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy.
Lien kept a low profile on his Singapore visit, accompanied by a small entourage whose members included KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang and Ting Yuan-chao, the director of Lien's office.
KMT headquarters issued a news release after Lien's departure, which said the main purpose of Lien's Singapore tour was to deliver a speech at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy.

The school at the National University of Singapore was founded by Singapore's Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew to provide training to enable students and practitioners a multi-disciplinary approach to the development and implementation of policy alternatives.

According to KMT sources, the Lee Kuan Yew School has invited Lien and Chiang to give lectures and attend a seminar with the school's faculty members and students because both of them used to hold a number of important government posts during the KMT's 55-year rule of Taiwan.
The sources said Lien and his small entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei Sunday evening.

Asked whether Lien's itinerary includes meetings with any political figures, the sources said Lien has many old friends in Singapore. "It would be natural if Lien meets with them during his trip," a KMT official said.
Commenting on Lien's Singapore trip, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said the ministry respects domestic political party leaders' overseas visits.

As Lien's Singapore visit came amid reports about his plan to make a historic journey to China, local observers were concerned about the possibility of Lien discussing his China travel plan with Singaporean officials.
Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT's policy coordination department, said Lien's Singapore trip is not expected to have anything to do with his China travel plan.

Chen Ching-jun, legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said the ruling party respects Lien's freedom of travel. But he urged Lien to keep in mind national dignity and parity if he touches on topics regarding relations across the Taiwan Strait during his visit.
According to Chen, Lee Kuan Yew has tried hard to serve as a go-between in cross-strait engagements in recent years.

"If Lien talks about his planned China trip with Lee or other Singaporean officials during his visit, he should take into account national dignity. He should not claim that his party's stance represents mainstream Taiwan public opinion. He should abide by constitutional provisions and national consensus while addressing cross-strait topics," Chen urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN TO ATTEND WTO MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 16 (CNA) (By Chih-hsiang Lu and Wayne Lee)

TEXT.P: A group of officials and business representatives from Taiwan will jointly attend a 10-year anniversary meeting held by the World Trade Organization in its headquarters in Geneva beginning April 20 to discuss trade-related issues, officials said Saturday.
This will mark the first time Taiwanese businessmen will have attended a WTO-held meeting since Taiwan joined the international trade regulatory body three years ago.
Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and representatives of the Importers and Exporters Association are among those who will fly to Switzerland.

While Japanese and South Korean businessmen are known for their participation at WTO conferences, Taiwanese businessmen have been reluctant to take part in the global trade body, said Yen Ching-chang, the nation's ambassador to the WTO in Geneva.
"Businesses should not exclude themselves from participating in international trade talks," he said.

The conference will see the discussion of various trade-related topics, including economy and growth, challenges facing the current WTO systems, and agriculture. Australia, the U.S., the E.U. and several other countries have sent envoys to Switzerland to attend the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMMONIUM SULPHATE EXPORT TO BE SUBJECT TO CONTROL

TEXT.P: In light of an increasing demand by Taiwan farmers for locally produced ammonium sulphate, the Council of Agriculture decided Saturday that export of the fertilizer will be subject to government control for one month from April 18.
Official approval to export the fertilizer will be required during this period, a COA official said.

Taiwan has been hit by a series of cold fronts since the beginning of spring, which caused damage to part of the island's rice paddies, the official said, noting that the move to replant has led to a rise in demand for the chemical fertilizer.

To meet the demand, the council initiated the export control, and will implement the measure in coordination with relevant authorities until May 17, the official explained. During the period, ammonium sulphate exports will only be allowed after local demand is met.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES CHINA TO LIFT NEWS BLACKOUT AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: China should ease its news blackout against Taiwan to promote constructive journalistic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, the nation's top mainland policy planner said Saturday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the call at a seminar on Taiwan-Macau relations and cross-strait ties.
Wu said the MAC is mulling ways to help mainland Chinese people obtain accurate information about Taiwan to forge mutual understanding and trust.

In the wake of its decision to temporarily ban China's state-controlled Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily newspaper from posting correspondents in Taiwan, Wu said, the MAC is now trying to invite more independent-thinking mainland media outlets to organize delegations to visit Taiwan and even post reporters in Taiwan.
If all goes smoothly, Wu said, some of those media outlets will send delegations to visit Taiwan in the near future to conduct news coverage on specific themes.

Wu further said the MAC is studying whether Hong Kong media outlets can freely distribute their publications in China. Should that be the case, Wu said, the MAC, will consider cooperating with Hong Kong media outlets so that Taiwan-related information can be accurately conveyed to mainland Chinese readers.

Noting that the ban on Xinhua and People's Daily are temporary in nature, Wu said the MAC will decide whether to lift the ban in terms of China's response to Taiwan's call for constructive cross-strait journalistic exchanges.

"We'll watch whether China would allow mainland media outlets that the MAC is inviting to organize delegations to Taiwan or post journalists in Taiwan as well as whether China would ease its blackout against Taiwan news outlets Internet online versions, " Wu said, adding that if Beijing can make positive response to Taiwan's call, the MAC could allow Xinhua and People's Daily to post reporters in Taiwan again.

Wu reiterated that the ban has nothing to do with suppression of the freedom of press, saying that the named mainland news outlets' reports had been distorted, misleading and unhelpful to boost cross-strait mutual understanding.

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and People's Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television (CCTV) , China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them out each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2005 TUNG BLOSSOM FESTIVAL KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The 2005 Tung Blossom Festival kicked off Saturday with a fun-filled ceremony at the West Lake Resort in the northern Taiwan county of Miaoli, a Hakka stronghold.

Lee Yung-teh, acting chairman of the Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) , joined with Yeh Chu-lan, a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, other senior officials and representatives of major Hakka communities from around Taiwan in staging a special worship ritual at the resort in Miaoli's Sanyi township.
More than 1,000 Hakka cultural event will be staged in 50 Hakka townships in northern and central Taiwan during the festival which will last through May 15.

In addition to arranging 21 "pathways" for appreciating white tung blossoms, the CHA has also invited 108 Hakka cultural and performing troupes to present musical, theatric and dancing performances during the festival. Poem recitals and folk crafts demonstrations will also be staged to attract tourists.

This is the fourth consecutive year that the Cabinet-level Hakka council has organized a tung blossom festival to boost tourism and cultural development in Taiwan's major Hakka communities, particularly those in northern parts of the country.

Tourist groups from New Zealand, Australia and various European countries will travel to Taiwan to appreciate the tung flower season and take part in various cultural activities to be staged during the month-long festival.

In 2004, Lee said, the Tung Blossom Festival attracted 2.7 million visitors and generated NT$3 billion in business revenues. This time around, he said, the festival promises to be bigger and better than ever.

Referring to the choice of tung flowers as the focus of the festival, Lee said that as tung trees are common in northern Taiwan Hakka communities, the council has "adopted" the tung blossom as a symbol of Hakka culture.

The trees, (aluerites fordii hemi, common name paulownia), used to be an important source of income for the Hakka, Lee said, adding that through the festival, the CHA hopes that the trees will once again bring prosperity to Hakka communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. SUPPORT CRITICAL TO TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: The European Union's support will be critical to Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the World Health Organization's (WHO's) governing body -- as an observer, the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.
Speaking at a seminar on Taiwan's WHO bid, Chang Wu-hsiu, director of the DOH's international cooperation department, said many countries have become supportive of Taiwan's goal.

Taiwan has campaigned for joining the WHA as an observer since 1997. Because of China's boycott, Taiwan has not made it so far. But last year, the United States and Japan publicly voiced support Taiwan's WHA observership. Hereafter, Chang said, the E.U.'s attitude will be crucial in determining the fate of Taiwan's WHA bid.
Accompanied by Chang, DOH Minister Hou Sheng-mao visited several European countries, including Switzerland, France, Belgium and Luxembourg, to seek their support for Taiwan's cause.

"We mainly met with media outlets, think tanks and parliamentarians during our visits to lobby their support. It remains to be seen whether they can influence their governments to throw support behind our WHO bid," Chang said.

From the perspective of epidemic control, Chang said, Taiwan is eligible to join the WHO-crafted health care mechanism. Otherwise, he said the global epidemic control system will be incomplete and flawed.
Chang said the DOH has been actively promote "medical diplomacy" in recent years to forge friendship with other countries through medical services and cooperation.

"The DOH has stepped up efforts to cultivate personnel for medical diplomacy. We hope to seek the support of more than 30 countries with no diplomatic ties with Taiwan to support our WHO bid through medical cooperation," Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, April 17:

construction contract at the Aboriginal Cultural Village in

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 17, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
2001: The Taipei Bank is chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: Anti-Japan demonstrations continue raging in the mainland despite Japanese protest.
The United Daily News: Lien Chan visits Singapore to exchange views with Lee Kuan Yew over Taiwan issue.
The Liberty Times: Chinese mob attack Taiwanese factory in Chaotsou.
The Taiwan Daily: President: Taiwan will suffer because of Lien's talk with PRC.
The Central Daily News: Lien visits Singapore to exchange views with Lee Kuan Yew, Lee Hsien Loong over Taiwan issue.
The China Post: Chen warns Lien against signing treaty.
The Taiwan News: Planned Lien-PRC pact deemed illegal by DPP
The Taipei Times: Government cautious over China invite.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Cardinals in final pre-conclave meet
VATICAN CITY (AFP) -- Roman Catholic cardinals met yesterday for the 12th and last time before the secret conclave in which 115 of them will elect a successor to the late Pope John Paul II.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: BIR to Church: You're next CHURCH leaders, including priests and ministers, and religious organizations will not be spared in the government campaign against tax cheats.
The Philippine Star: GMA wants VAT law passed by Apr. 30
President Arroyo said yesterday she expects to sign into law a value-added tax (VAT) bill "with a higher rate and wider scope" by April 30.
The Manila Times: Palace absolves Roces
MALACAnANG sees no need to have Susan Roces investigated because there was nothing seditious about her tirade against the Arroyo administration.

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: More pro- tests erupt in China. Windows broken at Japanese Consulate, restaurants in Shanghai
Protesters threw stones and broke windows at Japan's Consulate and Japanese restaurants in Shanghai as tens of thousands of people defied government warnings and staged demonstrations Saturday.
