DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Fear of Slump Batters Wall St.
Stock prices suffered their hardest fall in more than two years--with the Dow Jones industrials plunging more than 190 points--as evidence mounted that the U.S. economy's once- robust growth is slowing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Pediatric Vaccine Stockpile at Risk; Makers Hesitate to Supply Government.
Just three years after the largest and most serious shortage of childhood vaccines in two decades, the federal government's stockpile of childhood vaccines, designed as a buffer against shortages, is nearly empty -- and without immediate prospects of being filled, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT PART OF CHINA: VP LU
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Philippines, April 17 (CNA) (By Emerson T. Lim & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is not a part of China, and United Nations' Resolution 2758 of 1971 didn't say that Taiwan is apart of China, Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said in an interview published by the Philippine Star newspaper Sunday.

In the interview, conducted by the paper's publisher Maximo Soliven in Taiwan on Thursday, Lu said it is unfair to force Taiwan to unite with China, because Taiwan has been an independent country for many many years.

Likening Taiwan to a cat and China to a lion in the Taiwan-China dispute, Lu said that pushing the cat to the lion would inevitably result in the cat being eaten by the lion. "This is the law of the jungle, not the law of human society," she added.
In order to maintain peace in the world, Lu said, "predatory animals should be confined to their cages while small and tame animals should be allowed to roam free."
"Now that the lion is waking up, the world should help tame the lion" to ensure peace and stability in Asia, she continued.

Lu disputed China's claim as brazen lie that the U.N. Resolution 2758 acknowledges that Taiwan is a part of China. She said the resolution only granted mainland China the U.N. seat held by the ROC and recognized the People's Republic of China as the sole legitimate representative of China.
At the end of the interview, Lu urged the world to "Let Taiwan be Taiwan," adding that "we are not a part of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CANCELING CHINA TOURS IN SWARMS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 17 (CNA) (By Amy Huang & S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The ongoing anti-Japanese protests in China have been scaring off Japanese tourists in large numbers, with major Japanese tour agents reporting a steep rise in cancellations in recent days.
According to a survey by the Yomiuri Shimbun daily, a tourist agency in the Tokyo area that had arranged China tours for 2,300 people in April received 100 cancellations between April 11-13 alone.
JTB Tourist Agency, also located in the capital area, received 240 tour cancellations between April 11-14, according to Yomiuri.
Other tourist agencies around Tokyo have received numerous calls from customers regarding concerns about travel safety in China.
Japanese airlines have also been affected by concerns over the riots. All Nippon Airways, which offers 118 flights to nine Chinese cities a week, has received 1,300 cancellations for April 1-16.
The trend has raised concerns among Japanese travel agencies and airlines of a sharp drop-off in business as the peak summer season for travel to China approaches.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDE DENIES KMT CHAIRMAN MEETING BEIJING OFFICIALS IN SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 17 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The top aide to Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Saturday denied rumors that Lien has met with mainland Chinese officials for talks during his current brief visit in Singapore.

Ting Yuan-chao, director of Lien's office, denied rumors late Saturday that Lien met with Beijing officials during a dinner the same day hosted by Singapore's Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew in honor of Lien. Rumors had been circulating that Lien have talked with Chinese officials during the dinner about matters pertaining to his forthcoming visit to China.
Lien delivered a speech at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy Sunday morning. As described by Ting, the speech was closed to the media.

The KMT head arrived in Singapore Saturday for a brief visit at the invitation of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy. Lien, accompanied by a small entourage whose members include KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang. has kept a low profile during his visit.

On President Chen Shui-bian's renewed calls in Taipei Saturday for the KMT leader to meet with him before embarking on the China trip, Lien said Sunday that he "has no particular opinions on this concern."

"Everything is being arranged, and I have no particular opinions about President Chen's remarks, " Lien told reporters when he stepped out of the Lee Kuan Yew School after delivering the closed-door speech.
President Chen Shui-bian reportedly said Saturday that "no individual political party can accomplish matters related to national sovereignty when talking with China."

Noting that the KMT and the Communist Party of China held discussions regarding peace in 1945 before the KMT lost the mainland, Chen asked if the KMT was prepared to lose Taiwan too. He urged Lien to talk with him prior to his planned visit to the mainland.

According to those who attended Lien's closed-door speech, the KMT head mostly spoke about the situation and prospects regarding cross-Taiwan Strait relations, the huge gap between Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties in perspectives on cross-strait issues, as well as problems Lien himself faces on related matters.
The Lee Kuan Yew School at the National University of Singapore was founded by Lee to train students in multi-disciplinary approaches to the development and implementation of policy alternatives.
Lien and his small entourage are reportedly scheduled to return to Taipei Sunday evening.
Commenting on Lien's Singapore trip, Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Michel Lu said Saturday that the ministry respects domestic political party leaders' overseas visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMING OF KMT HEAD'S PLANNED CHINA VISIT POOR: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's planned China visit reportedly set for the end of this month comes too closely on the heels of Beijing's enactment of its anti-secession law against Taiwan, ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Sunday.
The timing of the visit could lead the international community to mistakenly conclude that Taiwan's opposition politicians have acquiesced to the law, Su said.
Noting that the poorly-timed visit could also be used as a "bargaining chip" by Beijing in its schemes regarding cross-strait relations, Su said the visit is definitely inappropriate.
Su warned that Taiwan has laws and regulations preventing opposition leaders from forging with Chinese authorities accords that involve matters which fall into the government's sphere of authority.
Su said the opposition leader should avoid engaging in matters that could undermine Taiwan's position and should avoid being fooled by Beijing's tricks that could cause Taiwan to disintigrate.
When asked by reporters whether he himself has any plans to visit China, Su responded that "now is not the time to talk about this matter."

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG REPORTERS DETAINED IN CHINA WHILE COVERING PROTESTS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 17 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Three Hong Kong journalists were detained Sunday in Shenyang City, northeast China, while covering anti-Japanese protests, Hong Kong media reported.
The reports said three photographers from Hong Kong's TVB, ATV and Cable TV were detained when they were shooting anti-Japanese protests in Shenyang, Liaoning Province.
The arrests took place at 9: 00 a.m. local time. Public Security agents said the three were detained because they had not obtained a permit for covering the event.
The three Hong Kong reporters were released at noon, after being questioned for three hours, the reports said.
Anti-Japanese protests were spreading Sunday in China, with the provinces of Guangdong and Guangxi in the south, Liaoning in the northeast, and Sichuan in central China reporting such events.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR URGES PRESIDENT TO BE OPEN TO KMT HEAD'S CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian should be open-minded regarding opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's planned mainland China visit as the visit could help usher in peace in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday.

Ma made the comments while answering questions from reporters during a visit to eastern Ilan County regarding Chen's remarks a day earlier that "Lien's China visit will enable the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) to bring Taiwan into its fold."

Stressing that an "opposition party has no power to sell Taiwan out, " Ma said that President Chen should wish Lien success during his China visit and help him complete the task that could bring peace to Taiwan.
The Taipei mayor added that he will also consider visiting China, if such a visit is determined to be beneficial to Taiwan, should he win the election for the KMT chairmanship in July.
Meanwhile, a KMT lawmaker said that Lien's upcoming visit to China has gained strong support among the public.
Chen Chieh, a caucus whip of the main opposition KMT at the Legislative Yuan, said that the public is supportive of Lien's "journey of peace" to help break the ice in cross-strait relations.

Stressing that Lien's China visit is aimed at seeking the maximum benefits for the people in Taiwan, Chen Chieh claimed that he has strong confidence that the popular backing for Lien's visit will be reflected in the mission-oriented National Assembly election set for May 14.

He called on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its political ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, to be cognizant of the KMT's efforts to build peace for Taiwan and urged the DPP to bravely face up to the development for the sake of Taiwan's stability and prosperity.

The government should give its blessing to the KMT for its peace-forging efforts because the Taiwan people hope that the opposition camp can help the government achieve something that is beyond its own reach, he pointed out.
Lien is scheduled to visit China in late April or early May, during which he will make stops in Xian, Shanghai, Nanjing and Beijing.
The KMT chairman is slated to meet with the CCP Secretary-General Hu Jintao, who is also the Chinese president, marking the first contact between the KMT and the CCP in 70 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO MAINTAIN PERSPECTIVE ON CHINA DISPUTES

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged the government Sunday to maintain its perspective on the issue of China amid the fiery disputes between the government and the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) over KMT Chairman Lien Chan's planned China visit.

Lawmaker Lo Chih-ming, the convener of TSU caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said that his party is worried that the government could lose its focus on domestic issues and the economy, which he called the lifeline of Taiwan, in embroiling itself in the disputes with the KMT.

Noting that Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong are both scrambling to visit China, Lo said the government has played into the hands of the two opposition parties by trying to line up meetings between the president and the chairmen before their trips, rather than trying to stop them according to the law.
In order to lure Lien and Soong into consulting with the president, Lo said the government even hinted that it may ask them to negotiate with China on some issues on behalf of the country.

Taiwan will lose its sovereignty by authorizing opposition leaders to talk with China, the TSU lawmaker warned, noting that Beijing insists that there is only one China, that the People's Republic of China is its sole legitimate government, and that Taiwan is a part of its territory.
Lo said China's recent enactment of the anti-secession law against Taiwan has driven home to the world Beijing's hostility towards Taiwan and has inaugurated a new chapter in Taiwan's diplomacy.

Instead of taking advantage of the opportunity to initiate diplomatic offenses, Lo said, the government has squandered the chance by arguing bitterly with the KMT over whether Lien should or should not visit China.
He urged the government to cool off the China fever among the opposition parties and turn its attention to domestic issues and the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP CONDEMNS CHINESE OFFICIALS FOR NOT PREVENTING LOOTING

TEXT.P: A legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) condemned Chinese authorities Sunday for not preventing protestors from looting a factory of a Taiwanese-financed company in Guangdong Province a day earlier.

Legislator William Lai said that the factory operated by B.B. Battery Co., currently the third largest producer of dry batteries in the world, was surrounded by thousands of protestors Friday and looted the following day as public security officers stood by without intervening or trying to defuse the situation.

The protestors had gathered at the B.B. Battery factory in/near Chaozhou City to protest what they claimed was damage to local fishermen's livelihood caused by waste water discharged by the Taiwanese battery maker into surrounding waters.

According to Lai, sources from the Taiwan Business Association in Guangdong quoted B.B. Battery management as stating Saturday that the company's waste water discharge system was built in accordance with official standards set by the Chaozhou Environmental Protection Bureau and that waste water discharged by the company has been within the allowable limits.
The management denied that waste water from the company was the real culprit and demanded that the local government and residents produce evidence to back up their accusations.
B.B. Battery reported damage and losses of 10 million renminbi (US$1.25 million) resulting from the looting.

Condemning Guangdong authorities and police for their "negligence, " Lai said that Beijing's newly enacted anti-secession law targeting Taiwan has not only provided China with a legal excuse to use non-peaceful means against Taiwan, it has also provided a convenient tool for corrupt Chinese authorities to blackmail Taiwan businesspeople maintaining business operations in China.

Nowadays, Lai claimed, mainland Chinese authorities have become even more fearless or unbridled in their schemes against mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople in light of an increasingly divided Taiwan resulting from in-fighting triggered by the opposition parties.

Pointing a finger at opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who is reportedly going to China at the end of this month for a "groundbreaking" visit, Lai urged the KMT to realize the nature of the Chinese communists and what kind of country China is.
Lai urged Lien to "stop and watch" how the Chinese authorities are treating the mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople before he embarks on his so-called "journey of peace."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S Q1 TRADE SURPLUS DOWN SHARPLY FROM 2004 LEVEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$290 million for the first quarter of this year, marking a sharp decline of 85 percent from the year-earlier figure, according tallies compiled by Taiwan customs authorities.

The tallies show that Taiwan exports and imports totaled US$42.85 billion and US$42.56 billion, respectively, in the January-March period, giving the country a trade surplus of US$290 million -- down by US$1.66 billion from the 2004 level.

Officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , the Bureau of Foreign Trade and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council unanimously pointed to surging prices of crude oil and raw materials as the root cause for the trade surplus decline, which they said was most pronounced for March.

Rising prices for oil, energy and raw materials helped Taiwan record larger trade deficits with Australia, Indonesia, Kuwait, Malaysia and Saudi Arabia for the first quarter, the officials said, noting that Taiwan's trade deficit with Saudi Arabia for March grew by 28.2 percent year to year.

Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said she is optimistic that Taiwan's trade deficits with these countries will gradually narrow, with the global oil price dropping to about US$50 a barrel for the time being.

According to Ho, Taiwan's export sector remains competitive despite the trade surplus decline for the first quarter resulting from increased imports. Taiwan exports still registered growth of 7.8 percent in value, she noted, attributing the increase to higher prices of export goods.

Citing MOEA statistics, Ho reported that the index in Taiwan export product price rose by an average of 9 percent last year, ahead of South Korea's 7 percent. She claimed this is an indication that Taiwan has improved in making value-added products.
Taiwan also posted trade deficits of US$7.93 billion and US$1.91 billion with Japan and South Korea, respectively, for the first quarter, up by 13.8 percent and 31.9 percent over the 2004 levels.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said that it is worth noting that South Korea has increasingly become a "second Japan" for Taiwan in international trade, given that South Korea has exported many daily consumption products to Taiwan in recent years, such as petrochemical goods and mobile phones, as well as key parts and components and machinery equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-JAPANESE PROTESTS ERUPT AGAIN IN SEVERAL CHINESE CITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing/Hong Kong, April 17 (CNA) (By Chen-yi Liao, Mandy Wong/S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Anti-Japanese protests erupted again Sunday as Japan's foreign minister arrived in Beijing, with protesters in many Chinese cities clashing with police.

Witnesses said over 1,000 protesters marched toward Japan's consulate general in Shenyang, northeast China Sunday morning, with some 60 of them breaking through a police cordon and throwing rocks and bricks, and shouting "Go back to Japan!"

The attackers clashed with police, but tensions were reduced as some people yelled "Chinese don't beat Chinese." No arrests were reported, except for several Hong Kong and Japanese media workers who were taken away for questioning and then later released.
Japanese officials based in Beijing said some cars parked inside the Shenyang consular were damaged by the attackers.

Earlier reports said thousands of people, mostly college and university students, were dispersed as they gathered at a shopping mall in Shenyang. Those who were not daunted then marched to Japan's consulate general, where they put up anti-Japanese banners and called on the public to boycott Japanese products.
In southern China, thousands of protesters shouted "Boycott Japanese products" slogans in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province as anti-Japanese protests took place there for the third Sunday in a row.

Holding banners condemning Japan's glossing over of its wartime atrocities in newly published history textbooks, the protesters waved Chinese flags and sang their national anthem as they marched toward Shennan Road, where Japanese-invested department stores were targeted.

Police were seen making way for the protesters while also containing them to "designated areas" for the march. At one point, marchers threw objects at Japanese stores, destroying Japanese signs and trying to demolish advertisements for Japanese products, narrowly escaping clashes with the police.

Anti-riot police with shields and batons were guarding two big Japanese department stores, each two or three meters away from the other to stop protesters from swarming into the stores, whose names were covered for fear of inciting Chinese anger.
Still, the heavy police force failed to prevent windows at a Japanese noodle house from being smashed, witnesses said.

In Guangzhou, capital of Guangdong Province, more than a dozen protesters were chased away by police when they were trying to set up anti-Japanese placards. Police also put up barricades around the city gymnasium and checked people's identity documents to discourage them from gathering.
The police actions apparently did not stop some 10,000 people from marching in the streets shouting anti-Japanese slogans.
In Zhuhai and Dongguan, two other Guangdong cities, protesters, totalling about 1,500 in each city, were seen shouting slogans such as "Boycott Japanese products."
In Dongguan, a Japanese-invested factory was surrounded by over 1,000 protesters, who damaged the factory's doors and windows.
Similar anti-Japanese protests were also reported Sunday in Nanning, Guangxi Province, Chengdu, Sichuan Province, and Shanghai.
In Hong Kong, Japan's Consul General Takanori Kitamura said he is not worried about local protesters as he believes Hong Kong is a multi-cultural society where reason prevails.
Kitamura said he believes the Hong Kong protest will take place peacefully and incidents of attacking Japanese consular offices will not happen in Hong Kong, as they had in China.
Organizers said between 5,000 and 8,000 people will march in Hong Kong streets in protest against Japan later Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA LIKELY TO LAUNCH 3-PRONGED OFFENSIVE AGAINST TAIWAN: NEW BOOK

TEXT.P: China is likely to launch offensives against Taiwan on the propaganda, psychological and legal fronts this year in its attempt to force Taiwan to surrender, according to a new book released Sunday.

The book, titled "An Assessment of Taiwan's Security and Strategy, " warned that the three-pronged offensive is to stop U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, by encouraging some forces in Taiwan to oppose them, and to plant spies in Taiwan.

To deal with the three-pronged offensive, the book recommended the establishment of a rapid-reaction force to address a possible Chinese sneak attack on the island, the enhancement of Taiwan's overall monitoring and early warning systems to give the country more time to respond to abrupt attacks, the improvement of the capability for information warfare, and the expansion of semi-military cooperation with Japan and the United States.

Lawmaker Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said at a ceremony marking the launch of the book that China will invade Taiwan only if the island declares independence, or when Beijing believes it is able to take over Taiwan before other countries can come to the island's defense.
He echoed the book's recommendation for the establishment of special warfare forces capable of defending the capital for at least two weeks to provide time for foreign military assistance to arrive.

The book, published by the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation, a private non-partisan research organization, was compiled by a team led by Ting Yu-chou, former secretary-general of the National Security Council, and Chang Jung-feng, former deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Arms Equipment Plundered in 2003 Is Surfacing in Iraq.
Equipment plundered from dozens of sites in Saddam Hussein's vast complex for manufacturing weapons is beginning to surface in open markets in Iraq's major cities and at border crossings. Looters stormed the sites two years ago when Hussein's government fell, and the fate of much of the equipment has remained a mytery. But on a recent day near the Iranian border, resting in in great chunks on a weedy lot in front of an Iraqi Iraqi Border Patrol warehouse, were pieces of machine tools, some weighing as much as a car, that investigators say formed the heart of a factory that made artillery shells near Baghdad. Military equipment, including parts for obscure armaments used by Hussein's army, is also turning up in Baghdad and Mosul in the north, they say.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD STAY CLEAR OF SIN0-JAPANESE FRAY: EX-SECURITY OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Taiwan should stay clear of the ongoing strife between China and Japan, a group of former security officials said unanimously Sunday.
Ting Yu-chou, a former secretary-general of the National Security Council, said Taiwan is in no position to take sides in the dispute, not to mention not having the capability to interfere.

Anti-Japanese demonstrations have taken place in several cities around China in recent days, sparked by Japan's bid for a permanent U.N. Security Council seat and the recent publication of new Japanese history textbook that glosses over Japan's wartime atrocities.

The former national security chief said that the gathering of some 100,000 protestors in Shanghai over the weekend should represent the climax of the anti-Japanese rallies which he predicted will begin to subside in the days ahead.
Taiwan, which maintains close economic ties with both Japan and China, hopes that the strife will be settled peacefully and that conflict will be avoided, Ting continued.

Ting made the comments in answering questions from journalists at a ceremony marking the launch of a new book on Taiwan's security, titled "An Assessment of Taiwan's Security and Strategy," compiled by a team led by himself and published by the Cross-Strait Interflow Prospect Foundation.
Ting's opinion was shared by two other ex-security officials attending the ceremony. The officials were former National Security Council advisers Lin Cheng-yi and Lai Hsing-yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR PEACEFUL EXCHANGES ACROSS STRAIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan called for peaceful exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in a speech he delivered Sunday at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy in Singapore, according to a news release issued by the KMT headquarters.

Peace and security in the Taiwan Strait area is an issue of common concern to all people around the world, while the pursuit of a better quality of life and living environment is a common aspiration of the people on both sides of the strait, Lien stressed.

Referring to the KMT position on the cross-strait issue, Lien said that his party is opposed to Taiwan independence, to "one country on each side of the Taiwan Strait" rhetoric, and to the "one country, two systems" formula initiated by Beijing.
"I'm opposed to everything that jeopardizes the cross-strait peace," the main opposition party leader emphasized.
He also criticized the government led by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for Taiwan's poor economic performance, which he attributed to the DPP's populist leadership.

Taiwan's economic success during the period of KMT rule of more than 50 years was achieved by a universal education system, correct policies, efficient government leadership, and the people's hard work, Lien claimed.
The KMT head is on a brief visit to Singapore at the invitation of the Lee Kuan Yew School. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT POISED TO HELP TAIWAN COMPANIES BOOST EXPORTS

TEXT.P: In view of the sharp year-on-year slide in Taiwan's trade surplus witnessed in the first quarter of this year, the government is poised to help Taiwan companies increase their exports through market exploration and the inking of free trade agreements (FTAs) with friendly countries.

Chen Ruey-long, vice minister of economic affairs, said that exploring new markets is very important to help domestic companies boost exports at a time when the global economy is widely forecast to cool off and when the country's Q1 trade surplus contracted by 85 percent over the year-earlier level.

Although the trade surplus decline was in large part due to a sharp increase in imports, Chen said that the time has come for the government to thoroughly examine Taiwan's export outlets and help Taiwan firms edge into new markets as a means of increasing outbound shipments.

In cooperation with the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has set its sights on Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, India, Japan, Russia, South Korea, Thailand and Vietnam, where it hopes to help seize a large market share for Taiwan products, Chen said.
A task force has also been set up in the hopes of helping curb Taiwan's mounting trade deficits with Japan and South Korea, he noted.

Acknowledging that Taiwan's dwindling export sector may be partly due to Taiwan companies' massive relocation overseas, the vice minister said that the MOEA has swung into full gear in moving to sign FTAs with friendly countries, such as those in Central and South America.
If Taiwan companies are good at market deployment across the world, they will still be strong in foreign markets despite the fact that their exports from Taiwan fall, Chen said.

TAITRA Secretary-General Chao Yung-chuan said that the TAITRA, Taiwan's leading non-profit trade promotion body, is planning to open 10 footholds offshore to help encourage domestic businesses to boost exports through investment abroad via a more comprehensive and effective network.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN HAS YET TO EXPLAIN WHAT HE'S UP TO IN CHINA: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The president is pleased to see opposition leader Lien Chan make a successful visit to China but Lien has yet to explain to the people on Taiwan what he's up to while there, a presidential spokesman said Sunday.

Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's planned visit to China has become Taiwan's top political story, with Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who's eyeing Lien's post, joining the fray by saying the ruling camp should be happy to see Lien possibly bringing peace back to Taiwan.

An opposition party leader cannot possibly sell out Taiwan, something only the ruling party is capable of, because opposition parties do not have any public authority -- what they have is only "a mouth," Ma said.

If Lien can bring home a chance for peace across the Taiwan Strait, President Chen Shui-bian of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party should feel happy about continuing the work by realizing the chance, and should not have accused the KMT of possibly losing Taiwan again, Ma added.

Chen Wen-tsung, director-general of the Department of Public Affairs at the Presidential Office, countered Ma by stressing that President Chen Shui-bian indeed would like to see Lien succeed in making the visit and has publicly suggested talking with Lien over the phone before he embarks on the trip, scheduled for later this month or early next.

At the same time, Chen Wen-tsung pointed out, the president also repeated the government's position that anything involving public authority or national sovereignty must have government authorization. "This is the president's responsibility to all the people as head of government," he emphasized.
As the leader of the country, the president is responsible for guarding national sovereignty, maintaining Taiwan's security and protecting people's well-being, said the spokesman.

In light of this, Lien should explain to the people on Taiwan what subjects he's going to discuss with Chinese leaders in Beijing, but as of now, "we only know from media reports that he may be talking about a peace treaty between the two sides of the strait or an armistice between the KMT and the Chinese Communist Party," Chen said.

Therefore, he said, President Chen's willingness to make a telephone call to Lien to discuss these serious national issues is a clear indication of the president's sense of responsibility as the national leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO CRACK DOWN ON NARCOTRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh issued a three-point instruction Sunday to the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) in the crackdown of narcotrafficking and pledged to establish a drug-free society in Taiwan.

Inspecting the operation of the CGA Central Coastal Patrol Office in Chingshui, Taichung County, Hsieh said that the government has designated the period between 2005 and 2008 as the "Years of Combating Narcotrafficking" to show his administration's determination in this regard.

The premier praised the CGA for the role it played recently in the crackdown on various international major narcotrafficking cases and a drug manufacturing plant in the central Taiwan county of Nantou.

He furthered that to cut the drug supply source, to crack down on all drug-related crimes and to integrate sea and land drug-combating forces are the three main guidlines for the government's efforts in this field.

Noting that the government has mobilized all relevant agencies to cooperate in fighting against narcotrafficking and rehabilitating drug-adicts, Hsieh urged the CGA to be an effective protector of Taiwan's coastal area.

But the arrival of an elected government this month will take the partnership in new directions that the Americans may find difficult to control.

The Japan Times: China refuses to apologize for anti-Japan violence
China refused Sunday to apologize for three weekends of sometimes violent ant- Japan demonstrations that damaged the Japanese Embassy and a consulate, in protests over Japan's wartime histroy and campaign for a permanent U.N. Security Council seat.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING BETWEEN KMT HEAD AND SINGAPOREAN LEADERS CONFIRMED
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 18 (CNA) (By S.J. Kan and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A press secretary for Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong confirmed Monday that the prime minister and his father, Minister Mentor Lee Kwan Yew, met with Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Sunday.

The two Lees met with Lien at a luncheon after the latter delivered a speech at the Lee Kwan Yew School of Public Policy in the city-state, the secretary said, adding that it was "a meeting among old friends."

Media reports have said that Lien might discuss an "eventual peace plan" between Taiwan and China in an expected meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his visit to China at the end of this month.

But Lien declined to touch on the details of his upcoming visit to China while responding to questions raised by the Central News Agency before delivering his speech at the school, saying that he was only invited by the school to give a speech.

Talking about his speech, Lien said that he would only exchange views with scholars listening to his speech on matters regarding the Asian and international situation, without specifically mentioning cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Nevertheless, Scott Fritzen, an assistant professor at the school, who was on hand for speech, said that in the speech, Lien talked a lot about cross-strait relations as well as differences among the Taiwan political parties on issues relating to cross-strait problems and difficulties he has encountered.
The KMT head, who arrived in Singapore Saturday, returned to Taiwan Sunday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH OPPOSITION 'PAN BLUE' LEADERS PREPARING TO VISIT CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is likely to visit China in the near future at the invitation of Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao, a PFP legislative whip said Monday.

Lee Yong-ping quoted a Xinhua News Agency report as indicating that Chen Yunlin, head of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, had been authorized by Hu, who is also concurrently mainland Chinese president, to publicly announce an invitation to Soong for a visit to the mainland.
"Chairman Soong has been welcomed to lead a PFP delegation to visit China," Chen was quoted as saying.
On this development, Lee said that as an opposition leader in Taiwan, Soong has always advocated rational and peaceful means to resolve cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

The PFP legislative caucus welcomes the invitation extended by the top CPC official, Lee said. It is believed that Soong will accept the invitation and visit Beijing at the most opportune time, launching an "ice-breaking" trip for cross-strait relations, she added.
According to a PFP official who wished to remain anonymous, Soong will probably visit China in early May.
Meanwhile, Lin Fong-cheng, secretary-general of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , departed Taipei for Beijing Monday to line up the much-anticipated visit to China by KMT Chairman Lien Chan.

KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung, who was accompanying Lin, said prior to departure that they will meet with officials from the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council for talks on the dates and agenda of Lien's forthcoming visit to China.

The KMT and the PFP -- a KMT splinter party -- formed the "pan-blue alliance" several years ago. The Lien-Soong ticket challenged President Chen Shui-bian in the 2004 presidential election, losing by a razor-thin margin.

The Lianhe Zaobao: Vacation paradise is a national project with or without casinos: said Minister Lee Boon Yang.

He said Singaporeans must support the decision by Government, because the vacation paradise project is a national project with or without casinos.

VATICAN CITY (Reuters) -- Roman Catholic Cardinals begin a conclave today to elect a successor to Pope John Paul II. The winner will be the 265th pontiff in history.

ADMINISTRATION Senator Joker Arroyo cautioned the government against imposing taxes on the commercial operations of the Catholic Church and other religious groups, saying it risked facing a backlash if it failed to justify the plan.
The Philippine Star: JDV confident bicam can pass VAT bill in 10-12 days
Speaker Jose de Venecia is optimistic that senators and congressmen in the bicameral conference committee can agree on a final version of the value-added tax (VAT) bill after 10 to 12 days of constant negotiations.
