VATICAN CITY: Cardinals destroyed Pope John Paul II's Fisherman's Ring and lead seal to formally end his reign, and the Vatican expressed confidence that unprecedented precautions would keep the name of the new pope secret until it is announced to the world from a balcony overlooking Saint Peter's Square.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REITERATES STANCE ON OPPOSITION LEADERS' CHINA VISITS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh reiterated the government's stance Monday on opposition political heavyweights' China travel plans, saying that if their visits touch on issues involving the exercise of public authority, they should obtain prior government authorization

Hsieh made the statement after opposition Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng departed for Beijing earlier in the day to flesh out KMT Chairman Lien Chan's planned China visit and a senior Beijing official extended a public invitation on behalf of Chinese Communist Party General Secretary Hu Jintao to another Taiwan opposition leader, People First Party Chairman James Soong, to visit China.
Hsieh, a lawyer-turned politician, said opposition political heavyweights' China visits can be addressed from three perspectives -- legality, political ethics and personal freedom.

From the legal perspective, Hsieh said, opposition leaders must furnish the government with a prior report or obtain the government's prior authorization if their China visits will touch on issues involving the exercise of public authority. Otherwise, he added, they may break existing laws, and any agreement they reach would be invalid.

From the political ethics perspective, Hsieh went on, it's up to the opposition heavyweights themselves to decide whether they will inform President Chen Shui-bian or relevant government authorities prior to their departure for China.
If opposition leaders' China visits are purely for sightseeing and don't touch on any policy issues, Hsieh said, then the government fully respects their freedom of travel.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Cardinals Gather for Conclave to Select Pope; Balloting to Be Guided By Rules Old and New.
Sequestered behind Vatican City's medieval walls, 115 Roman Catholic cardinals from 52 countries begin Monday to choose a successor to Pope John Paul II in a secret conclave that will follow elaborate rules both written and unwritten, ancient and new, spiritual and political, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG DELEGATION STUDYING STUTTGART'S GREEN CITY PROJECT

TEXT.P: A delegation headed by Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing visited Stuttgart on Sunday to inspect the southern German city's urban planning and greening project, county officials said Monday.

Stuttgart, which used to be an overcrowded, overdeveloped industrial city, has undergone a major transformation in recent years under a municipal government "greening" plan to make the city into a European commercial and industrial center with a high-quality living environment to attract people to live, work and invest.

Yang praised the German city for its greening efforts, saying during the one-day visit that Kaohsiung County can learn from it in planning a university town in Yenchao township and an urban park at the old site of the Weiwu military barracks, according to the officials.

Yang and his delegation left Taiwan April 13 for a 10-day urban and architectural fact-finding tour in Germany. Before arriving in Stuttgart, the group visited Karlsruhe, Freiburg and Tuebingen in western and southern Germany.
They will head to the university town of Ulm and the largest city in southern Germany, Munich, before returning to Taiwan April 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WHIP REMINDS KMT HEAD NOT TO BREAK TAIWAN LAW DURING CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong should achieve consensus at home before departing on their planned China visits, a legislative whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Monday.
William Lai said that as developments unfold, it seems that a visit by KMT Chairman Lien to China, at the invitation of Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao, will indeed occur.

Lai reminded Lien to make sure that he does not break Taiwan law during his visit, pointing to the 5th Provision in the Additional Articles of the ROC Constitution, which stipulates that no political party through its actions should endanger the existence of the Republic of China.

KMT Chairman Lien is set to visit China later this month. The visit will make Lien the first KMT chairman to set foot on mainland Chinese soil since the KMT withdrew to Taiwan more than five decades ago.
PFP Chairman Soong will likely visit Beijing in early May, also at the invitation of CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao, according to PFP sources.

Meanwhile, Legislator Chen Chin-jun, another DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, called for both Lien and Soong to give their forthcoming China visits a second thought, saying that their China visits should absolutely not infringe on the interests of the Taiwan people or the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU ASK PFP CHAIRMAN TO GET GOV'T AUTHORIZATION BEFORE CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) suggested Monday that People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong hold a second meeting with President Chen Shui-bian to get government authorization before he visits mainland China.
Lo Chih-ming, a whip of the TSU at the Legislative Yuan, said the move would enable Soong to "start talks with the Chinese side with government authorization on behalf of Taiwan's 23 million people."

The TSU is opposed to visits by political party leaders to China without government authorization because such visits, although made in the visitors' private capacities, will erode Taiwan's sovereignty and indirectly hinder the president's legal status as head of state, he claimed.

Chen and Soong met on Feb. 24 and clinched a 10-point agreement pledging to maintain the national title of the Republic of China and not to declare Taiwan independence, in a concerted move to mitigate tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

TSU Legislator Ho Min-hao called on political party leaders to think twice before they prepare to go to China and urged the government to deal with any visits that undermine the country's sovereignty and interests.

The TSU lawmakers' comments came after China's Xinhua News Agency reported earlier the same day that Hu Jintao, general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) who is also the Chinese president, issued a formal invitation to Soong to visit.
According to a ranking PFP official, Soong accepted the invitation and will most likely go to China in early May.
Meanwhile, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is also slated to pay a visit to China in late April or early May.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng left for China earlier Monday to arrange for Lien's upcoming visit. Lien is scheduled to visit Xian, Shanghai, Nanjing and Beijing and meet Hu -- a historic first between the leaders of the two parties in more than 60 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Duma Gives Its Vote to Big Parties.

The State Duma on Friday gave its approval in the crucial second reading to legislation that would transform the lower house by ending the election of independent deputies and making it even more difficult for smaller parties to claim seats. The vote was 335 to 96.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG'S STATUS AS NEGOTIATOR IN CHINA UNCLEAR FOR NOW: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: It is unclear whether People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will seek or be granted government approval to negotiate with Chinese President Hu Jintao ahead of his proposed trip, a local scholar said Monday.

Noting that Soong formally accepted an invitation from Hu, who is also general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, to visit China, Huang Chieh-cheng, director of the Graduate Institute of American Studies at Tamkang University, said how the government perceives Soong's China visit and how it will affect the relationships among Taiwan's major political parties are two things that merit close observation.

Lien Chan, chairman of the ROC's largest opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT) , has also been invited to visit China. KMT Secretary- General Lin Fong-cheng left for Beijing Monday to finalize Lien's schedule.

While Lien has refused to consult with President Chen Shui-bian prior to traveling to China, Soong very likely will do more than just talk with the president over the phone about his upcoming visit, which is expected to take place in early May, Huang said.
What subjects Soong will raise with his Chinese hosts, and whether President Chen will authorize him to discuss them in the name of the ROC government, are issues that remain open, Huang added.

Furthermore, what will happen to the "pan-blue alliance," of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party, and whether relations between the PFP and Chen's Democratic Progressive Party will undergo a substantive change, are also worth watching, he said.

He emphasized that what is certain is that Beijing has extended its hands into Taiwan politics. Beijing is playing the Asian style of chess called "go, " not the traditional Chinese style called "hsiangchi, " against Taiwan, so it must respond with caution, he said.
Many consider "go" a game requiring more strategy in close quarters and one that can be lost by a single poorly executed move.

Huang noted that currently Beijing is adopting a multi-pronged strategy toward Taiwan, characterized by "initiative, flexibility and a clearly defined line in the sand, " targeting Taiwan's opposition party leaders, business people and farmers, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER TAIWAN MOVES TO NEW HOME IN TAIPEI 101 BUILDING

TEXT.P: The Bayer Group's Taiwan affiliate moved its Taipei headquarters to the Taipei 101 Financial Building Monday, becoming the first transcontinental company stationed at the modern skyscraper.
A grand ceremony was carried out to mark their move, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou being the guest of honor.

During the ceremony, Ma said he believes more and more businesses and international enterprises will follow Bayer's step, setting up their operational bases in the Taipei 101 building, a new landmark in Taiwan.
According to Bayer Greater China CEO Elmar Stachels, the new home fits Bayer's characters of seeking high-tech and innovation.
Taiwan is one of Bayer's key markets in Asia, and it employs more than 300 people on the island while achieving sales of over NT$13 billion (US$410 million), according to Bayer Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES END LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 173.21 points to close at 5,715.16.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 5,809.76 and hit a low of 5,679.35 during trading. A total of 3.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$72.66 billion (US$2.28 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 6 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 4.5 percent, foodstuff issues at 4.2 percent, banking and financial shares at 3.3 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 3 percent, textile stocks at 2.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.7 percent and plastics and chemicals shares at 1.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 884 to 61, with 66 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'HAN KUANG 21' MILITARY DRILLS BEGIN WITH COMPUTER SIMULATIONS

TEXT.P: The computer simulation part of the "Han Kuang 21" military exercise began in various tactical command centers around the country Monday, a spokesman for the military said Monday.

The five-day computerized war simulations are aimed at honing various combat strategies and tactics, including anti-blockade strategies, airborne defense control, naval forces' air defense and maritime control tactics, as well as cyber-defense operations.

The simulated war games will be conducted at the combined services operation command center, the combined services training center and various tactical command centers simultaneously, and is being coordinated by a simulated Hengshan Strategic Command System, the spokesman said.
The simulated war games will be conducted eight hours a day during the five-day maneuvering period.

Live-fire drills -- another part of the "Han Kuang 21" annual series of drills devoted to testing the armed forces' combat prowess -- are scheduled for June through August to verify combat strategies and tactics hammered out during the computerized war games. These maneuvers will include strategies to cope with surprise attacks on a major local oil depot and undersea cables, according to the spokesman.

The live-fire exercises will also practice counter-strategies against warfare methods such as carpet bombing, infiltrations, abductions, hijackings, computer virus attacks and decapitation strikes, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LIKELY TO VISIT CHINA IN EARLY MAY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 18 (CNA) (By Lo Kim-fai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan will most likely visit Beijing in early May, a KMT legislator and member of the KMT Central Standing Committee said Monday.
Wu Den-yih made the remarks while attending a cross-strait forum in Hong Kong sponsored by a federation of Taiwan business associations in the Asia-Pacific region.
Wu said that Lien hopes to upgrade cross-strait exchanges on agriculture and trade though his visit to contribute to cross-strait and regional peace.
Wu also said that the chances that Lien and James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , will visit Beijing together are slim.
A PFP official said earlier in Taipei that Soong would accept an invitation from Chinese President Hu Jintao to visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR REMAINS UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar remained unchanged against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday to close at NT$31.699.
A total of US$732 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$31.699 and fluctuated between NT$31.680 and NT$31.760.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April lost 185 points to close at 5,707, with 30,992 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved down 185 points to finish at 5,700, with 15,172 contracts traded, while June futures lost 189 points to finish at 5,680, with 148 contracts traded.
September futures lost 200 points to finish at 5,560, with 229 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 218 points to close at 5,536, with seven contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,892 for April, 5,885 for May, 5,869 for June, 5,760 for September and 5,754 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

April TE futures moved down 7.45 points to close at 223.05, with 4,490 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost eight points to finish at 221.8, with 3,416 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 8.3 points to close at 221.6, with 15 contracts traded, while September TE futures moved down 8.85 points to close at 220.1, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December.

April TF futures lost 38.6 points to finish at 886.4, with 7,525 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved down 34.8 points to end at 890, with 3,622 contracts traded. June TF futures moved down 36 points to finish at 890, with 17 contract transactions, while September TF futures lost 42.8 points to end at 883.2, with nine contracts traded. December TF futures lost 41.8 points to close at 881.8, with three contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN URGES OPPOSITION PARTIES TO REFRAIN FROM 'CHINA RUSH'

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang urged opposition political heavyweights Monday to refrain from scrambling to visit China.

Su made the call after opposition Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng departed for Beijing earlier in the day to organize KMT Chairman Lien Chan's planned China visit and a senior Beijing official extended a public invitation on behalf of Chinese Communist Party General Secretary Hu Jintao to another Taiwan opposition leader, People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, to visit China.

In his view, Su said top leaders of domestic political parties should not scramble to visit China for partisan interests and should instead give top priority to national interests and the common wellbeing of all the people of Taiwan.
If opposition leaders insist on visiting China, Su said, they should respect the nation's law and keep in mind that a national consensus is needed to address any issue involving popular interests.

Asked whether a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and PFP Chairman Soong is needed before Soong's departure for China, Su said it's not suitable for him to make any comment on this question before Soong's decision becomes clear.
As a ruling party, Su said, the DPP is more than willing to engage and communicate with all other domestic political parties.
After the Feb. 24 Chen-Soong meeting, Su said, the DPP and the PFP have been on friendly terms.

During their first meeting in February, Chen and Soong reached a 10-point consensus on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait and domestic constitutional reforms, including that the nation's name -- the Republic of China -- will not be subject to any changes in constitutional reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD BE ABLE TO SUBMIT STRONG PROPOSAL IN APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan should develop its ability to establish agenda at major events like the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to boost its influence, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i said Monday.
Wu made the remarks while attending an APEC operations seminar sponsored by the Chinese Taipei APEC Study Center.

Wu noted that APEC and the World Trade Organizations are two international organizations that Taiwan participates in, and that the APEC leaders' meeting is the only venue where Taiwan can get together with such a grouping of world leaders and officials.
He said that no publicity drive will be more effective to demonstrate Taiwan's sovereignty than Taiwan leaders mingling with other leaders and discussing matters with them.

But he said that the agenda of the APEC meeting has been affected by the changing international political and economic situation, and Taiwan has to keep abreast of the latest APEC developments and work out way that Taiwan can increase its presence.

He noted that Taiwan proposed the creation of an APEC Digital Opportunity Center (ADOC) at the 11th APEC Economic Leaders' meeting in Bangkok in 2003 to bridge the digital divide in APEC member economies. The proposal was welcomed by participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACCELERATES EFFORTS TO HELP COMBAT AIDS IN MALAWI

TEXT.P: Taiwan is hosting a three-day international academic workshop on HIV/AIDS prevention in the capital city of Malawi, a long-standing Republic of China diplomatic ally in southeast Africa, the Department of Health (DOH) reported Monday.
The international AIDS workshop in Lilongwe is part of Taiwan's accelerated efforts to help combat AIDS in Malawi, which has one of the highest HIV infection rates in the world.

According to a United Nations report, HIV/AIDS causes 50,000 to 70,000 deaths each year. The disease has created some 500,000 orphans in Malawi since the first case was noted in 1984, and the number of orphans is increasing by nearly 60,000 on a year-on-year basis.

Taiwan began to funnel funds, resources and manpower into Malawi in 1998 to help arrest the spread of HIV/AIDS. Over the years, Taiwan medical missions have traveled to the country and built the Central HIV/AIDS Hospital in Malawi's northern city of Mzuzu.

As of January this year, the Central Hospital -- so far the only AIDS hospital in Malawi offering all diagnoses and treatments for free -- has treated over 1,200 AIDS patients and an average of 200 new cases have been referred to the hospital in recent months, DOH officials reported.

At the outpatient section of the Central Hospital, the Taiwan medical service team is combining technology and medication. The patient's treatment history as well as medication archive is recorded and managed electronically after his or her fingerprint has been keyed in during the patient's first visit to the hospital, according to DOH officials.

The story of Taiwan's medical teams operating in Malawi - jointly authored by team leader Yu-Kuang Liao-liang and DOH ambassador in Africa, Chen Chih-cheng -- is scheduled to be published soon in the Lancet, an influential British medical journal, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR BRUSHES ASIDE SPECULATION OVER KMT CHIEF'S PEACE PACT

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will do his best to forge a consensus on building peace across the Taiwan Strait during his upcoming visit to mainland China, but will not ink any peace accords with the Chinese side, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.

Ma said that he strongly believes that Lien will not sign any peace agreements with Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao during his upcoming China visit, since doing so would first need government approval and the opposition camp can only play the role of "pioneer."

Stressing that Lien's visit is aimed at maintaining peace between Taiwan and China, Ma said that Lien will speak for the people on Taiwan while seeking to help lay a foundation for cross-strait peace.
The Taipei mayor is one of the five vice chairmen of the main opposition KMT.

Lien's planned China visit, in late April or early May, will mark the first KMT-CPC contact in more than 60 years. The KMT chairman is slated to meet Hu in Beijing, in addition to making stops in Nanjing, Xian and Shanghai.

Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lashed out strongly at Lien's China trip as an apparent attempt to challenge the nation's law and undermine Taiwan's sovereignty by seeking to ink a peace pact with China without government approval.

Lo Chih-ming, a TSU whip at the Legislative Yuan, questioned whether Lien thinks that now is an appropriate time to visit China when it still deploys more than 700 missiles targeting Taiwan and has adopted an Anti-Secession Law to deal with Taiwan using "non-peaceful means."

Lo asked Lien to first return the preferential subsidies and stop receiving the special security privilege granted by the government to him due to his status as a former vice president before he travels to China. He also demanded the government strictly handle Lien's China visit in accordance with the nation's laws.
TSU lawmaker Ho Min-hao urged Lien not to make the trip to China to avoid becoming a "culprit of Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONGERS' APPROVAL RATING OF CHINA DOWN MARGINALLY: SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 18 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong people are slightly less approving of the Chinese central government now than they were six months ago, according to a survey released by the Chinese University of Hong Kong Monday.

More than 800 Hong Kongers were surveyed in early April. Forty-eight percent said they are satisfied with the Chinese government's performance in Hong Kong, two percentage points down from a similar survey last October.
Nearly 20 percent are not satisfied with the Chinese government's performance in Hong Kong.

The survey also found that the approval rating of Hong Konger of Chinese leaders increased, with 75 percent of them saying they are satisfied with Premier Wen Jiabao, followed by 64 percent who said they are satisfied with President Hu Jintao.
The survey also found that 47 percent trust in the Chinese central government, nearly twice who said they don't trust the government. The result was identical to that of last yeast's survey.
In addition, 30 percent said that the "one country, two systems" model is being carried out in Hong Kong, 6 percentage points higher than last October.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC USING SOONG VISIT TO ALTER CROSS-STRAIT ATMOSPHERE: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Beijing is inviting James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, to visit partly to induce a change in the cross-Taiwan Strait atmosphere soured by China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, a China analyst said Monday.
Professor Byron Weng of National Chi Nan University also sees the Chinese move as an attempt to lure those in Taiwan favoring unification with China into cooperating with the Chinese regime.

Beijing is finalizing a schedule for Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to visit China. Since Soong had expressed interest in visiting, it would be reasonable for Chinese President Hu Jintao to invite Soong, too, Weng said.

Although Soong had earlier reached a 10-point consensus with President Chen Shui-bian, it would be "hardly imaginable" that Hu is trying to use the Soong visit to convey some kind of message to Chen, Weng said.

He noted that Chinese leaders have explicitly laid out the conditions for meeting with Chen: he must accept Beijing's "one China" principle, and his Democratic Progressive Party must give up its pro-independence platform.
If Beijing indeed is trying to make an overture to Chen, then Soong would just be "a tool, " which he is quite unlikely to allow himself to be, the scholar said.
On the other hand, Chen could not possibly ask Soong to speak for him while meeting with Hu. Soong at best can act as a certain "channel of contact," Weng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO ASK CHINA TO REMOVE MISSILES: LAWMAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 18 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will ask Chinese authorities during his upcoming visit to China to remove its missiles aimed at Taiwan, a lawmaker from Taiwan's opposition party said in Hong Kong Monday.
Legislator Wu Den-yih, who is also a member of the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee, made the remarks after attending a forum on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
To the best of his understanding, Wu said Lien will bring up four main topics during his China trip, tentatively scheduled for early May.

First of all, Wu said, Lien will ask mainland authorities to eliminate barriers to cross-strait cultural and commercial exchanges, such as exempting or reducing import tariffs on agricultural and industrial goods from Taiwan.
Second, Wu said, Lien will urge China not to block Taiwan's entry to the World Health Organization (WHO).

"For the sake of epidemic prevention, Taiwan must be included in the WHO-led global health care system. If China continues to block Taiwan's WHO bid, it will draw a backlash from the Taiwan people and hinder the development of cross-strait rapprochement," Wu said.
Third, Wu said, Lien will push China to relocate the hundreds of ballistic missiles deployed in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian that target Taiwan.

"If China indeed wants to make peace with Taiwan, it should relocate or dismantle its missiles aimed at Taiwan. Otherwise, the people of Taiwan will have ill feelings and doubts about Beijing's sincerity, " Wu said.
Moreover, Wu went on, Lien will ask mainland authorities to allow mainland citizens to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan to promote civilian exchanges and mutual understanding.

Wu said he is cautiously optimistic about the outcome of Lien's forthcoming China trip. Lien will be the first KMT chairman to visit the mainland since the party, which had ruled all of China before retreating to Taiwan in 1949 after loosing a bloody civil to the Communist Party of China.
Wu further said the KMT is willing to do whatever is conducive to Taiwan people's well-being and cross-strait peace.
Wu delivered a speech on new developments in cross-strait relations at the seminar, sponsored by a federation of Taiwan business associations in the Asia-Pacific region.

Addressing hundreds of Hong Kong scholars, experts and business executives presen at the seminar, Wu said Hong Kong should strengthen exchanges with Taiwan to maintain its pivotal role in cross-strait engagements.
Wu also said he believes that Taiwan, Hong Kong and Shanghai can strengthen cooperation in transshipment, trade, industrial investment and tourist development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE OPERA TROUPE INVITED TO PERFORM FOR THAI ROYALS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, April 18 (CNA) (By Wu Hsie-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ming Hwa Yuan Taiwanese Opera troupe is scheduled to perform in Bangkok April 23-24 to celebrate the 55th anniversary of the marriage of King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit of Thailand, and the 50th birthday of Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorne.

At the invitation of the Thai government, the Taiwanese folk art performing group, founded in 1929, will present its most popular play, "The Living Buddha Chikung" to the royal family of Thailand, according to Ming Hwa Yuan.

The award-winning play, premiered in 1983, features Buddhist truths, principles and practices. It is perfect for the play to be performed in the Buddhist country of Thailand, the head of the renowned Taiwanese troupe, Chen Sheng-fu, said Monday.
The Thai people will celebrate their king and queen's 55th anniversary of marriage April 28, after Princess Sirindhorne celebrates her 50th birthday April 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIALS ARRIVE IN BEIJING TO PAVE WAY FOR CHAIRMAN'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 18 (CNA) (By Liao Chen-yi & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two executives of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) arrived in Beijing Monday to talk with the authorities there on a proposed visit to China by party Chairman Lien Chan.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng and spokesman Chang Jung-kung kept a low profile upon their arrival. Lin only told reporters that they respect the host's arrangements for their trip to Beijing.

Asked about Beijing's earlier invitation to James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, the KMT's political ally, to visit China, Lin said the KMT is happy to see any activities that benefit peaceful exchanges between Taiwan and China.
No high-ranking China officials were present at the Beijing airport to greet the KMT officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC OPTS FOR AVOIDING INFLATION AMID SLOWING ECONOMY: PUNDITS

TEXT.P: The central bank will opt for easing inflationary pressure as its top priority amid a slowing domestic economy that has been reflected in a sharp slide in Taiwan's trade surplus for the first quarter of this year, economists said Monday.

Citibank Taiwan Vice President Cheng Cheng-mount said that the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) will choose to stem rising domestic consumer product prices as its chief task by gradually raising key interest rates, even though the economy has shown signs of cooling.

Cheng made the forecast on the grounds that Taiwan's economy is still growing at a moderate pace and that the CBC's main mission is to maintain stable consumer product prices rather than stimulating economic growth.

Pointing out that the large decrease in trade surplus should be just a short-term phenomenon owing to increased imports of machinery equipment and construction materials and rising prices for oil, energy and raw materials, the economist said Taiwan will not suffer a trade deficit over the long term thanks to its relatively high savings rate.

However, he claimed that inflationary pressure is under control in Taiwan and predicted that the CBC, following in the footsteps of the U.S. Federal Reserve, will increase key interest rates by a one-eighth percentage point by the end of June.
A government official echoed Cheng's view by making it clear that the prime mission of the central bank is to stabilize consumer product prices despite the fact that Taiwan's economy has slowed.

Singling out the sharp decline in the Q1 trade surplus -- down by 85 percent at US$290 million compared to the previous year's level -- he also contended that the CBC will make the rate hikes in late June.

Wu Chung-shu, an economic researcher at Academia Sinica, called on the government not to overreact to the trade surplus shrinkage, as booming imports are an indication that domestic demand and investment have not subsided.
He said he also expects the CBC to lift interest rates in a piecemeal fashion so as to reduce the gap with the U.S. levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CASH REWARD RAISED FOR TIP-OFFS ON FORGERY

TEXT.P: The reward for information leading to the arrest or indictment of forgers has been raised to NT$500,000 (US$15,776) from NT$200,000 (US$ 6,310) , according to the Intellectual Property Office under the Ministry of the Economic Affairs.
The office urged informants to use a toll-free hotline, 080-001-6597, or send their information to the office's e-mail address: yell@tiop.gov.tw.
An official from the office said that Web sites are replacing tradition shops and vendors as the most popular places for selling forged products.

The official said his co-workers at the Intellectual Property Office are working with their overseas counterparts to crack down on overseas-based Web sites that offered to sell fake products in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MEN BUSTED FOR FORGING MICROSOFT AUTHENTICITY LABELS

TEXT.P: Four men were arrested Monday for producing fake Microsoft certificates of authentIcity.
Computers with these fake authenticity stickers were first found in Australia last July, and Australian police tracked the maker down to Taiwan.
Acting on a tip-off from Australian officials, local police raided a workshop in Sungshan, Taipei City on Monday.
Four people were arrested along with 33 sheets of a wide variety of fake certificates for Windows 98, Windows XP and other software.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA, JAPAN NOT BUDGING ON APOLOGIES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 18 (CNA) (By Chen-yi Liao and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Chinese and Japanese officials refused to budge Monday on their respective demands that the other side apologize first before actions can be taken to improve their frozen ties.

Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing and his Japanese counterpart Nobutaka Machimura failed to break the ice as each asked the other to apologize for a series of incidents leading to their hurriedly arranged meeting in Beijing Sunday.

Hatsuhisa Takashima, spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry, told reporters Sunday that violence in recent anti-Japanese demonstrations has affected exchanges between the two countries and Machimura demanded that the Chinese government stop similar things from happening again.

Japan demanded that China apologize for allowing protesters to vandalize Japanese diplomatic missions and businesses during three consecutive weekends of demonstrations in several cities across China.

Only when China promises to beef up security measures for Japanese diplomats and civilians in China can bilateral relations return to normal and friendship between the two peoples be promoted, Takashima said.

On Monday, Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Wu Dawei said Japan should apologize first for whitewashing its wartime atrocities in history textbooks and for paying respects to war criminals at the Yasukuni shrine before China will apologize for the anti-Japanese protests.

Wu was lukewarm toward Japan's proposal for a summit meeting between Japan's prime minister and China's president in Indonesia during a conference of Asian and African leaders later this month, saying only that "the Japanese have made such a request and we will consider it."

When Li met with Machimura Sunday, he told his guest: "The Chinese government has never done anything for which it has to apologize to the Japanese people, " adding that the main problem "is that the Japanese government has done a series of things that have hurt the feelings of the Chinese people."
Li cited "the Taiwan issue, " referring to a recent policy declaration by Japan that gave the impression it would join the United States in defending the country in case of an attack by China.

Machimura pressed Li on what he described as "violence toward embassy activities and also toward Japanese people in China." He repeated demands for an official apology, compensation for damages and better security around Japanese institutions.
Machimura said Japan's policies on Taiwan have not changed and emphasized that his government had already expressed "remorse, regret and apology" several times for its wartime past.

"We are not opposed to demonstrations, even if the demonstrations are anti-Japanese demonstrations, because we highly appreciate freedom of expression... as long as it remains peaceful, " Takashima said.

The frosty to-and-fros between the two countries, particularly when Li and Machimura refused to shake hands with each other, have led Hong Kong media to conclude that bilateral relations have plunged to an all-time low since the establishment of diplomatic ties in 1972.

Shi Yinhong, a professor of international relations at the Renmin University of China, told Hong Kong's Apple Daily that the two governments will not easily change their positions with regard to such issues as Taiwan, territorial disputes in the East China Sea, history textbooks, and civilian protests.

In the short term, Shi said there will be a lot of twists and turns before Chinese-Japanese relations will return to normal. However, he claimed that the Chinese government has the will and determination to stop bilateral ties from worsening.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CIVIC GROUPS PROTEST AGAINST JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 18 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A dozen Hong Kong civic groups went to the Japanese, United States and ROC missions in Hong Kong to protest against Japan's newly published textbook, which they feel is an attempt to paper over its atrocities during World War II.
Around 30 representatives from civic groups submitted petitions to the consulate generals of Japan and the United States as well as the ROC's mission in Hong Kong.

In addition to the textbook, they also protested against Japan's occupation of the Tiaoyutai Islands cluster in the East China Sea, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visit of a Tokyo shrine dedicated to Japanese war dead, as well as Japan's bid for permanent membership on the United Nation's Security Council.
A group of Hong Kong college students also went to the Japanese consulate general in Hong Kong to protest.
The students carried with them more than 2,000 signatures from Hong Kong citizens to underscore their appeal.
Monday's protest came on the heels of a massive anti-Japanese demonstration of more than 10,000 people in Hong Kong Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: As Stocks Slide, Investors Hope for Positive Earnings Reports.
After last week's market plunge - when America's three main stock gauges fell more than 3 percent - Wall Street and unusually nervous individual investors are looking to the flood of earnings reports this week to see how optimistic corporate America is in its outlook for the economy. But early earnings warnings from companies like General Motors and Ford have already discouraged investors, and I.B.M.'s surprise earnings shortfall last week was one reason that stocks dropped so sharply. And while earnings growth for the quarter is expected to be respectable, that growth is likely to be well below the pace of last year.
Wall Street Journal: New Bush Strategy on Aid Face Test in Madagasca; U.S. Lets African Nat ion Pick Ways to Use $110 Million.
When the Bush administratio invited Madagascar a year ago to apply for aid under a new U.S. program, government officials here came up with a wish list of traditional development projects: a new hospital, more school spending, aid to rice farmers. Madagascar President Marc Ravalomanana will be in Washington today to attend the signing of a US$110 million, four-year aid package. It's the first grant ever under Bush's Millennium Challenge Account program -- and a test of whether the U.S. has found a better way of delivering assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP, KMT CHAIRMEN'S VISITS TO CHINA DIFFERENT: DPP

TEXT.P: A visit by opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to China will be different from that of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Monday.
DPP Secretary General Lee Yi-yang was responding to news that the PFP had accepted an invitation from Chinese Communist Party Secretary General Hu Jintao for Soong to visit China.

Lee said that in the wake of Beijing's adoption of an anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, which has resulted in world condemnation as well as Taiwan people taking to the streets, "the timing is not right for opposition leaders to scramble to visit China."

But he said Soong's visit will be different from Lien's in that Soong will be going with a 10-point consensus, including no change of the official name of the nation and no change to the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, reached with President Chen Shui-bian during a meeting Feb. 24.
Lee claimed that the consensus has national consensus and is one on which the DPP and PFP share the most common ground.
He pointed out that Chen hopes to invite party leaders to a meeting but that Lien has adamantly refused and has not sought national consensus.

Furthermore, he said, Lien will be going on behalf of the KMT, which accepts a so-called "1992 consensus" which, according to Lee, means that there is but one China of which China is a part -- Beijing's interpretation of the consensus.

In contrast, Lee said the 10-point consensus has no "92 consensus" but instead points out the sovereign, independent status of the Republic of China, which is starkly different from the KMT's interpretation of the "92 consensus," he said.
Lee expressed worry Lien's visit to China will be detrimental to Taiwan's sovereignty.
Meanwhile, a DPP legislator said Lien's talks in China should not encroach upon government authority.
William Lai, DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, was responding to remarks earlier in the day by KMT Legislator Wu Den-yih at a Hong Kong seminar.

Wu said that during Lien's trip in early May, he will talk with Beijing on a wide range of issues, including Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization, China's missiles targeting Taiwan and opening Taiwan to tourists from China, as well as the removal of barriers to cross-strait cultural exchanges and trade.
All these issues involve government authority and require national consensus, Lai said, pointing out that two-time presidential election loser Lien has no right to act on the nation's behalf.
"Lien should not seek his own legacy in history and fall into China's trap," Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES MADE NT$8.7 BILLION PROFITS IN Q1

TEXT.P: The seven state-run enterprises under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) had accumulated combined profits of NT$8.7 billion (US$254.63 million) in the first three months of this year, according to statistics issued Monday by the MOEA.
All seven companies made profits except for the Taiwan Power Company and the Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC).
Among the profit-makers, Chinese Petroleum Corp. led the pack with pre-tax profits of NT$8.02 billion (US$253.05 million), which is 62.76 percent of the whole-year profit forecast.

Following far behind was the Tang Eng Iron Works Co., Ltd. which posted pre-tax profits of NT$529 million, or 75.57 percent of its target profit for the whole year, and Taiwan Water Supply Corp., with NT$269 million, Taiwan Sugar Corp., with NT$154 million, and China Shipbuilding Corp., with NT$101 million.

For Taiwan Sugar Corp. and Taiwan Water Supply Corp., their performances are quite remarkable in light of the fact that they used to be loss-makers. Taipower post a loss of NT$77 million because of the sharp rise of international oil prices, but this took place in January and the company has seen profits since February because of the smaller-than-expected rise in the price of coal.
The AIDC, which recorded a profit in the previous year, has seen its finances worsening this year with losses of NT$250 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO REQUIRE MARKING OF FOODS THAT COULD CAUSE ALLERGIC REACTION

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will require processed foods to be marked with warnings if they contain ingredients that could cause allergic reactions, in a new measure that could be implemented by the end of the year at the earliest.

It is generally believed that milk, eggs, nuts and seafood are most likely to cause allergic reactions, but to find out which foods are the most likely sources of allergic reactions for Taiwan people in particular, Taipei Veterans General Hospital has begun a survey on food allergies and will turn the results over to the DOH for reference.

The hospital will distribute 30,000 questionnaires to residents in Taipei, Taichung, Kaohsiung, Hualien and Penghu counties to compile information on the most common food allergies among Taiwan people.

DOH officials said that after compiling the results, they will take stock of approaches used in the European Union, the United States and Japan to mark processed food packaging with warnings over possible allergic reactions from certain ingredients.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OPEN TO 2ND MEETING WITH PFP CHAIRMAN: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is open to a proposal that he meet a second time with opposition People First Party (PFP) James Soong prior to Soong's visit to China, a Presidential Office spokesman said Monday.

Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's public affairs department, made the remarks after a senior Beijing official extended a public invitation to Soong on behalf of Chinese President Hu Jintao earlier in the day.

"The Presidential Office's stance on visits to China by opposition political leaders is crystal clear. We have no particular opinion about party-to-party exchanges across the Taiwan Strait if no public policy issues are involved in those engagements, " said Chen Wen-chung.

However, he added that if opposition political leaders want to sign accords with China on issues involving national sovereignty or the exercise of public authority, they must obtain the government's prior authorization. "Only by so doing can we safeguard our national interests and the common well-being of our people, " he stressed.
According to Chen Wen-chung, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun talked with PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng earlier that day.
Chin was quoted as having told Yu that Soong will mention the 10-point consensus reached during a Feb. 24 Chen-Soong meeting in his talks with Hu.

Noting that the 10-point consensus embodies the bedrock of the government's cross-strait policy, Chen Wen-chung said that if Soong upholds the 10-point consensus, his talks with Hu will not go beyond the government's basic policy line.

As to whether a second Chen-Soong meeting can be held prior to Soong's China trip, planned for the first half of May, Chen Wen-chung said that so long as Soong thinks it is necessary, the Presidential Office will be more than willing to line up such a rendezvous.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said he hopes Soong can meet with the president before departing for China.
Moreover, the nation's top mainland policy planner said he hopes Soong will abide by the law and give top priority to national interests during his trip.
China's official Xinhua news agency said Monday that Hu had invited Soong to lead a PFP delegation to China. Hu issued the invitation in his capacity as Communist Party chief.
The invitation came as another opposition leader, Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, prepared to embark on what the KMT is calling a "journey of peace" to China in late April or early May.

The KMT and the PFP, known locally as the "pan-blue alliance, " both favor eventual unification with a democratic China, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) insists that Taiwan's future -- independence or unification -- should be decided by the country's 23 million people.
Earlier Monday, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng left for Beijing to flesh out details of Lien's planned trip with China's Taiwan Affairs Office.
The DPP administration has expressed concerns about the flurry of exchanges between opposition parties and China, urging delegations to consult the government before going.

The desire by opposition parties to wrest control of cross-strait relations from the DPP administration has given Beijing an opportunity to further its divide-and-conquer strategy by courting Chen's opponents and weakening his hand, analysts said.
"Beijing's strategy towards Taiwan is to divide the various groups and use a carrot and stick method to deal with each, " said Andy Chang, a China watcher at Tamkang University.
"The aim is to cause division and confrontation within Taiwan, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WRITER COMPARES CHINA'S SELECTIVE MEMORY WITH THAT OF JAPAN

TEXT.P: As China's anti-Japanese protests generated widespread attention, an American columnist questioned Monday China's own "selective memory" on major historical events and found it unable to stand the test of its own requirements for the Japanese.
Writing for the Washington Post, Fred Hiatt suggested China do the same thing it demanded of Japan: "Face up to history squarely."
He reminded readers that in Japan, issues of war guilt or innocence, and of proper historiography, are debated endlessly and openly in Japanese newspapers, magazines and universities.

Some Japanese demonstrate against politicians who refuse to go to the Yasukuni Shrine -- where Japan's war dead, including some who were executed as war criminals, are honored -- while other Japanese demonstrate against politicians who do go, he said.

Compare this to the situation in China, where there is only one acceptable version of history, at least at any given time; history often changes, but only when the Communist Party decides to change it, he pointed out.

For example, he said, according to a report by Howard W. French carried in the New York Times last December, many textbooks do not mention that anyone died in the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. One 1998 text notes only that "the Central Committee took action in time and restored calm." Anyone who challenges the official fiction is subject to harsh punishment, including beatings, house arrest or imprisonment.

And if the 300,000 victims of the Nanjing Massacre are slighted in some Japanese textbooks, what of the 30 million Chinese who died in famines created by Mao Zedong's lunatic Great Leap Forward between 1958 and 1962? No mention in Chinese texts, according to Hiatt.
He further pointed out that as the Times found in its review of textbooks, Chinese children do not learn of their nation's invasion of Tibet (1950) or aggression against Vietnam (1979).

"Facing up to history squarely" isn't easy for any country. Americans do not agree on how to remember the Confederacy. Russia cannot yet admit to Soviet depredations in the Baltic republics and Japan often sees itself purely as a victim of World War II, he said.

But in countries that permit open debate, historical interpretations can be constantly challenged, revised and maybe brought closer to the truth. In dictatorships that use history as one more tool to maintain power, there is no such hope, Hiatt said.

China's communists used to find it useful to vilify Russia in their history texts. These days, for reasons of China's aspirations to lead Asia, Japan makes a more convenient villain. Next year might be America's turn. The reasons may be complex, but none of them has much to do with facing history squarely, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MAKES PITCH FOR ETHNIC SYMBIOSIS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh, who is known for advocating "political symbiosis" of different parties, made another pitch for "ethnic symbiosis" of different ethnic groups Monday.
After visiting the 228 Memorial Hall in Taipei, Hsieh said the different ethnic groups in Taiwan should learn to live together by understanding each others' historical backgrounds.

Political symbiosis is already difficult enough, but the symbiosis of various ethnic groups, which he described as a kind of "hetero-symbiosis" because of the different backgrounds of various ethnic groups, is even more difficult, he said.
He urged each group to feel empathy with each other, starting from learning and accepting the island's history, of which the 228 incident is a vital part.
Only by coming to terms with history, the premier said, will the people of Taiwan be able to stop their inter-ethnic fighting and face up to the future together.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI STEPS UP PREPARATIONS FOR ID CARD REPLACEMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has stepped up preparations for new identification (ID) card replacements in order to minimize inconvenience for local citizens, Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan said Monday.
The ministry is scheduled to replace existing ID cards with a new forgery-proof version from July 1 this year. The entire process is scheduled to be carried out by June 30, 2006.
Su said the ministry will arrange for local photo studios to offer photography services at household registration offices. He added that the service charge will not exceed NT$150 per person.

Moreover, the minister went on, the government will cover the photo costs for people from low-income families. Home delivery services will be offered for those suffering from serious disease or those who are otherwise incapacitated, he added.
Su said the MOI is negotiating with local photo studio associations to prevent their members from rigging market prices during the ID card renewal period.

"We'll also craft a detailed service mechanism to ensure that local people can receive their ID cards within 30 minutes of having their mug shots taken at the household registration offices, " Su said.
To ensure smooth proceeding of the ID card replacements, Su said, the MOI has organized training courses for relevant staff members.
Starting June 1, local household registration offices will notify people to submit one photo to be used on the new cards.
The photo must be clear and in color, must be taken without the subject wearing a hat or sunglasses and must have been taken within the last six months.
The name and identification card number of the person in the photo, as well as the date when the photo was taken, must be written on the back of the photo.
People must pick up their new identification cards in person, while a home delivery service will be provided for disabled persons.
The new cards will be pale purple and will have 21 forgery-proof features. Unlike the existing identification cards, which have vertical print, the writing on the new ones will be horizontal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO ALLOW TWO CHINA MEDIA TO RETURN IF BEIJING REFORMS PRESS

TEXT.P: As long as China displays a determination to pursue press reforms, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) will allow two banned major news media to station reporters in Taiwan, MAC official said Monday.
The officials' remarks came after Reporters Without Borders expressed concern about a temporary ban on Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily from posting journalists in the country.

The officials said the government temporarily banned the two media outlets because they had no respect for journalistic professionalism. China can no longer use its government mouthpiece to distort news reporting from Taiwan, and the damage in the wake of Beijing's passage of an anti-secession law March 14 will also not be artificially widened, they claimed.

The officials said that as long as Beijing demonstrates its sincerity and determination to pursue press reforms, removes its blockade of the Internet versions of Taiwan's United Daily News and China Times, and does not deter its newspapers from sending journalists to Taiwan, the MAC is willing to reconsider permitting Xinhua and People's Daily to post staff to Taiwan.
In addition, the MAC is planning to invite two other Chinese newspapers -- Guangdong's Nan Fang daily and Shanghai's Diyi Caijing daily -- to post staff in Taiwan.
The MAC has inquired about their willingness to post reporters in Taiwan "so that they can experience first hand Taiwan's respect for press freedom and its professionalism."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS MORE EFFORTS AT WOOING JAPANESE TOURISTS, INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh directed relevant government agencies Monday to step up efforts to attract Japanese tourism and investment in Taiwan, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said Monday.
William C.T. Lai, a DPP legislative whip, quoted Hsieh as having issued the directive during a dinner with DPP legislators and senior government officials.

According to Lai, Hsieh said that with the intensifying strife between China and Japan over their feud regarding history, more Japanese citizens have chosen to visit Taiwan rather than China in recent months.

In the past three months, Hsieh said, the number of incoming Japanese tourists has increased by 50 percent from the same period of last year. Against this backdrop, Hsieh said he hopes the Government Information Office, as well as the tourism and investment promotion authorities, can redouble their efforts to court prospective Japanese tourists and investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BRITAIN BUSINESS COUNCIL MEETING TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Seventh Joint Meeting of the Taiwan-Britain Business Council will open Tuesday in Taipei.

The British delegation to the meeting will be headed by Stephen Brown, chief executive of UK Trade and Investment which is the British government's organization for promoting trade and investment overseas and also inward investment into Britain, according to anews release issued by the British Trade and Cultural Office in Taiwan.
The meeting will be divided into three panel discussions centered on bio-pharmaceuticals, telecommunications and information technology and the infrastructure construction, respectively.
The meeting is aimed at maintaining contact between Taiwan and British enterprises and exploring opportunities for bilateral cooperation, the meeting organizers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESS GROUP PANS GOVERNMENT FOR EVICTING CHINESE REPORTERS

TEXT.P: A local press group took issue Monday with the government's decision to evict correspondents posted to Taiwan by Beijing's Xinhua news agency and People's Daily, describing the move as "unnecessary."
The Association of Taiwan Journalists said in a statement that the measures has stained Taiwan's hard-earned reputation as a free democracy.

Noting that press freedom is unknown in China, the association said it is naive for Taiwan to expect Chinese correspondents assigned by its state-run media to Taiwan to cover stories about Taiwan impartially.

On the other hand, the statement said, if China believes Taiwan's decision is atravesty of press freedom, than Beijing should practice what it preaches by giving Taiwan correspondents posted to China a free rein in covering stories in China rather than corralling them with restrictions.

The Mainland Affairs Council announced April 10 that it was rescinding a permit for Xinhua and People's Daily to post reporters to Taiwan on the grounds they had misused their privileges by turning out misleading reports about Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 19, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro-democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan-zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LABS COMPLETE DESTRUCTION OF SAMPLES CONTAINING H2N2 VIRUS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 18 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) announced Monday that all 18 countries, including Taiwan, that had received proficiency testing samples containing the H2N2 influenza virus have completed the process of destroying the samples.

According to the WHO, samples containing the influenza A/H2N2 virus were inadvertently distributed by the College of American Pathologists (CAP) , a private U.S. company, to a total of 3,747 laboratories in the 18 countries, and an international effort has been underway to ensure the destruction of these samples. The virus was found to be similar to H2N2 viruses that circulated in humans in 1957-58 at the beginning of the so-called Asian influenza pandemic.
The WHO also said that the destruction of the samples in the United States is still ongoing and is expected to be completed in the near future.
A total of 15 laboratories in Taiwan were reported to have received proficiency test samples containing the dangerous virus. All 15 labs have completed the destruction of their samples.

The other 17 countries and areas that have destroyed their samples are Bermuda, Belgium, Brazil, Chile, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Italy, Japan, Lebanon, Mexico, South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, xxxx, xxxxx, xxxxx.

Pointing out that there have been no reports of H2N2 infections in laboratory workers associated with the distribution of the H2N2 viruses from the CAP, the WHO said that "the likelihood of laboratory-acquired influenza infection is considered low when proper biosafety precautions are followed, " and that "the risk for the general population is also considered low."

However, apart from recommending that all samples be destroyed, the WHO also suggested that "biosafety procedures be reviewed for use on influenza viruses that have not circulated recently in humans and against which the majority of the population would have no protective immunity."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC RECOGNITION OF ROC EXTREMELY SIGNIFICANT: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is the common asset of the 23 million people in Taiwan, and the People's Republic of China's recognition of this nation is extremely important to cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday.

Pointing out that Beijing's doing so would have a profound and far-reaching influence on bilateral ties, Wang called on the Taiwan people to treasure this nation, adding that this is his long-term stance regarding the ROC-PRC relationship.

Wang's comments came after a media report that Jia Qinglin, chairman of the National Committee under the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, mentioned the ROC as Taiwan's official title during a meeting with visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang on March 31 in Beijing.

It was the first time that a ranking Communist Party of China (CPC) official mentioned Taiwan by using its official designation amid along-standing hostility between the two sides of the strait, which has recently escalated following Beijing's enactment in mid-March of its Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan.

The legislative speaker also called on the government to provide adequate information regarding the PRC to opposition KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong before they go to China for visits, claiming that this would be ideal in helping them make greater efforts for Taiwan.

Wang said he strongly believes that both Lien and Soong will do their best to seek the maximum benefits for Taiwan based on the overall interests and security for the country during their respective visits to the PRC.
Lien is slated to depart for the PRC in late April or May, while Soong will most likely go there in early May, both at the invitation of CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT JUST SPRINGBOARD FOR CHINESE MARKET: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that Taiwan should not denigrate itself as just a "window" or "springboard" to the vast Chinese market.
With its abundant manpower, manufacturing technology and rich foreign exchange reserves, Taiwan has great potential to become an Asia-Pacific economic and trade hub and stronghold, Chen said.

"Therefore, crafting a Taiwan-centered industrial development blueprint has been the government's top guiding principle in formulating economic policy, " Chen said while inspecting an air cargo transshipment park near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE URGED TO HEED INCREASING SINO-JAPANESE TENSIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 18 (CNA) (By Y.L. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A leading German newspaper on Monday urged European countries to pay proper heed to the increasing tensions between China and Japan and not to sell weapons to China.

In an editorial Monday on the current dispute between the two Asian countries, the "Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung" newspaper said that the Beijing leaders' criticism of Japan for failing to undertake soul-searching for its wartime atrocities represents China's attempt to demonstrate its strength as a rising power.

As many people consider the apologies made by Japanese leaders for their country's wartime atrocities as not being sincere, Beijing feels certain no neighboring countries will support Japan in the Sino-Japanese dispute, according to the editorial.

Although the attitude of those Asian countries which had been occupied by Japan during World War II is understandable, the European Union's silence regarding the current dispute is "unacceptable, " the editorial said.
"Is it really possible that Berlin, Paris and London are preparing to strengthen China and sacrifice their old ally Japan?" it asked.

Regardless of how Japan treats its own history, the country definitely has no intentions of attacking its neighbors, the editorial said, adding that China, on the other hand, despite all its talk of peaceful development, has never given up the option of the use of force against Taiwan.
Therefore, the newspaper urged the European countries to pay attention to the increasing tensions between China and Japan and not to encourage China by selling arms to it.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: 35,000 new jobs and huge gains to economy.
THE answer is two, not one. Singapore is saying yes to two integrated resorts with casinos that will reap $5 billion in investments, 35,000 new jobs and a $1.5 billion boost to the economy annually.
Making the much-awaited announcement in Parliament yesterday, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong spelt out these huge gains and also assured critics of steps taken to minimise social harm.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Singapore say yes to two integrated resorts with casinos.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has said Singapore will have two integrated resorts with casinos after nationwide big debate in past 13 months.
One will be built at Marina Bayfront and the other on Sentosa island.
With the two integrated resorts, Singapore will attract investments in the order of S$4 billion to S$7 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
