The Washington Post: DeLay Issues Broad Denial Of Ethics Violations.
House Majority Leader Tom DeLay (R-Tex.), in his first detailed written response after weeks of questions about his dealings with lobbyists and handling of ethics matters, issued a broad denial that he violated any law or House rule in accepting trips abroad, and he implored supporters back home to accept his version of what he called "the real story," the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CAUTIONS LOCAL FARMERS AGAINST RASHLY MAKING INROADS INTO CHINA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Tuesday cautioned local farmers against rashly making inroads into mainland China.
COA Vice Chairman Tai Cheng-yao's warning came after recent reports that Chinese authorities promised to give tariff-free treatment to Taiwan's agriculture products.

Tai questioned whether this is part of China' "united front" tactics to try to obtain Taiwan's superior agricultural technology. In addition, the preferential treatment could be suspended at any time as the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not signed an agreement, he added.

Tai was speaking at a meeting convened by the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) legislative caucus, which is studying the feasibility of Taiwan agricultural products making inroads into China under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Tai expressed doubts about China's claimed intention of taking care of Taiwan farmers, saying that Taiwan leads most other nations in agricultural technology. He said that if China obtains Taiwan's superior agricultural technology after contracting Taiwan farmers to work in special zones opened for them on the mainland, then Beijing might "turn from opening to controlling."

Bureau of Foreign Trade Director General Huang Chih-peng said on the same occasion that the chances of China giving preferential treatment to Taiwan's agricultural products is minimal. He noted that in line with the rules of the WTO, of which both Taiwan and China are members, other member nation's have the right to request the same treatment if China gives tariff-free treatment to Taiwan's agricultural products.

Huang noted that Taiwan's agricultural products are highly competitive and that exports to the global market have grown since the island's WTO entry in January 2002 while exports to China have decreased in the same period. He said this illustrates that China has set up steep non-tariff barriers.

"Those who are considering making inroads into the mainland market had better be on guard, " he said, adding that "if they decide to make inroads into China, they had better do so through legal channels to cut the risks to a minimum."

Fu Don-cheng, director of the Department of Economic Affairs of the Mainland Affairs Council, expressed concerns that Beijing may attempt a "political solution" to bypass the rules of the WTO to give Taiwan agricultural products preferential treatment by claiming the issue is an "internal affair." He said that in this scenario, Taiwan's dignity would suffer and its sovereignty would be undermined.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE EXPECTED TO DISCUSS CHINESE ARMS SALES BAN WITH NATO MINISTERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department said Monday that Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is expected to discuss issues regarding the European Union's arms sales ban on China with NATO foreign ministers at a meeting of the organization to be held later this week.

State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said at a media briefing that Rice had a brief discussion earlier in the day with the Belgian foreign minister about lifting the E.U. arms sales embargo against China.

"Our position hasn't changed. We believe it's the wrong decision, both for the message it sends and for the potentially strategic implications for us, " he said while touching on the stance of the U.S. toward the European attempt to lift the ban.
Rice is scheduled to leave Tuesday for Russia and Lithuania to attend the NATO foreign ministers meeting.

Although the E.U. arms embargo is not a topic of the NATO meetings themselves, Boucher said that since the topic is frequently discussed by the secretary with her European counterparts, he would expect it to come up in her conversations at the upcoming NATO meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO JOIN WORLD IN COMMEMORATION OF SPECIAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY

TEXT.P: To coordinate a worldwide campaign in memory of the world's greatest physicist, Albert Einstein, the Kaohsiung-based National Science and Technology Museum (NSTM) invited the public to join in a "1,000 People Lighting Up Einstein" activity slated for Tuesday evening.

According to the organizer, some 1,000 college students, teachers and professors will gather at the museum square, with all of them wearing Einstein masks and holding flashlights. Their lights together will create the equation E = mc2 -- following the start of Taiwan's nationwide lights-on campaign in Hualien on the east coast.

The activity will then be relayed to Tainan City at a canal, the Tainan County Government plaza, the Great Buddha Sculpture on Bagua Mountain in Changhua County, the Taichung National Museum of Natural Science, the Hsinchu Synchronized Radioactivity Center, Taipei 101 and the Lu-lin Observatory on Yushan -- the highest peak of Taiwan.

According to the Physics Society of the Republic of China, the worldwide Einstein commemorative activity, named "Let Physics Glorify the World," was initiated by Austrian professors Max E. Lippitsch and Sonja Draxler to mark the 100th anniversary of Einstein's publication of the special theory of relativity and the 50th anniversary of his death, both falling on April 18.

By encouraging countries around the world to turn on their lights at the same time on the special day, the scholars hope that the move will arouse the world's attention to physics and support the study of the science.

Some 44 countries, including Japan and South Korea, have answered their call to take part in the "lights-on" activity. At the same time, a fund-raising campaign is to be kicked off to collect donations to help Third World countries promote basic science education.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education has said that the public has a variety of ways to participate in the global campaign. People can log onto the Internet to "light up" online, or send a short message with their cellular phones to "light up" Taiwan's light on a world map.
A series of other activities will also be held in locations across Taiwan. Log onto http: //419.com.tw for more information about the campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL ANNOUNCE LIEN'S PRC ITINERARY WEDNESDAY: AIDE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 19 (CNA) (By C. Y. Liao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: After lengthy discussions with ranking Communist Party of China (CPC) officials, visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said Tuesday that the itinerary of Chairman Lien Chan's upcoming visit to the People's Republic of China will be announced Wednesday.

The KMT will make the announcement at the weekly meeting of its policy-making Central Standing Committee, Lin said, adding that the Beijing-based Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council will also give an explanation publicly on the same day now that Lien's PRC itinerary has been fixed.
Lin said that his talks with Taiwan Affairs Office Director Chen Yunlin took eight hours in an effort to ensure a safe, smooth and pleasant trip for Lien and relevant personnel and reporters.

Reiterating that Lien will do his utmost to protect Taiwan's dignity, seek benefits for the people on Taiwan and make peace in the Taiwan Strait when he meets CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing, Lin revealed that the two men will discuss a broad range of issues, which may also include the "one China" question.

The KMT will staunchly safeguard the interests of the Republic of China that it founded 95 years ago, he stressed, but denied speculation that the KMT is preparing to sign a truce agreement with the CPC.

He also said that "everyone" is welcome to join forces to build peace and create benefits for the people on both sides, referring to the latest development that Hu also extended an invitation to People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to visit.

The KMT official arrived in Beijing a day earlier to arrange a visit for Lien to the PRC, where he will make stops in Nanjing, Shanghai, Xian and Beijing. Lien is slated to meet the CPC No. 1 leader Hu in Beijing, marking an unprecedented KMT-CPC encounter in more than 60 years amid long-standing hostility between the two political parties.
Meanwhile, more than 100 reporters with Taiwan's media organizations have applied to cover news of Lien's visit in the PRC, according to the KMT.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR 'CODE OF CONDUCT' AMID OPPOSITION VISITS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has drafted a "code of conduct" for all political parties as the leaders of two major opposition parties are preparing to visit China, trips that some fear might cause damage to Taiwan.
The DPP's "basic code of conduct" is contained in a resolution calling for "three noes and three yeses" when dealing with China.

Chairman Lien Chan of the largest opposition party, the Kuomintang, and Chairman James Soong of the second-largest opposition party, the People First Party, have been invited to visit China. The visits are scheduled for later this month and early next month.
The first no in the DPP proposal is: "We are firmly opposed to the 'one China' condition, in the form of the so-called '1992 consensus,' for party leaders to visit China."

The second no: "Without government authorization, we are firmly opposed to any negotiations over cross-Taiwan Strait affairs that might involve national sovereignty or the exercise of public authority."

The third no: "We are firmly opposed to any Chinese government move aimed at stripping Taiwan's national status and denying Taiwan's national government so that Taiwan's government would appear like a local or regional government."

On the other hand, the DPP strongly advocates the following three points on which an absolute majority of the people on Taiwan agree. First, the Republic of China is an independent country whose sovereignty is shared by its 23 million people, and they alone have the right to change its status.
Second, the Chinese government's attempt to resort to the use of force against Taiwan must be vehemently condemned and cross-strait disputes must be resolved with peaceful means.

Third, the people on Taiwan strongly oppose China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law which authorizes Beijing to use "non-peaceful means" to settle disputes with Taiwan; and Taiwan citizens' rights to participate in international activities must not be suppressed.
The DPP resolution says it is time that all sectors of Taiwan society stood firmly together in the face of Chinese hegemony.

"Different parties may have different positions and views inside Taiwan, but all political parties should be unanimous in their determination to maintain our free and democratic way of life, to ascertain the ROC's sovereignty, and to safeguard the right of the 23 million people to decide on their own future," it says.
The resolution was passed by the DPP Central Executive Committee Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-VATICAN TIES REMAIN SOLID: ROC FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and the Vatican will remain steadfast after the election of a new pope, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.
Lu was responding to concerns whether ROC-Vatican ties could be affected following the election of a successor to the late Pope John Paul II, who died earlier this month at the age of 84.

Over the past 20-plus years, Lu said, China has on the one hand sought to normalize its relations with the Vatican but has continued to suppress religious freedoms and arrest Catholic clergymen and followers on the other.

Noting that religious freedoms and the well-being of all Catholic followers around the world are the top concerns of the Vatican, Lu said diplomatic ties or politics are just the means, not the end, for the Holy See.

If China fails to respect religious freedoms or allow its people to enjoy the freedom of assembly, Lu said, it would be very difficult for the Vatican to forge diplomatic ties with China anytime soon.

In the foreseeable future, Lu went on, China is not expected to adjust its policy and attitude toward human rights and religious freedoms. Against this backdrop, Lu said he doesn't think that the Vatican will forge diplomatic ties after a new pope is designated.

Moreover, Lu said the Vatican has consistently been satisfied with Taiwan's contributions to international humanitarian aid. Over the years, Lu said, Taiwan has established a steadfast, peaceful and merciful partnership with the Vatican.
In its long history, Lu said, the Vatican has never taken the initiative to sever diplomatic ties with any other country.

The world is waiting for 115 cardinals to elect a new pope. The cardinals headed into their first full day of voting for a new pope Tuesday after an inaugural ballot failed to find a successor Monday.
Asked who will serve as Taiwan's top envoy to attend the new pope's inauguration, Lu said it's up to the Presidential Office to decide.

President Chen Shui-bian personally attended Pope John Paul II's funeral in the Vatican April 8, making him the first serving ROC head of state ever to set foot in Europe. Because of China's diplomatic embargo, the Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO RESUBMIT BILL GOVERNING ASSETS OF POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that it will again try to put a bill governing the assets of political parties on the Legislative Yuan's agenda.

William Lai, DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks as the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) failed to attract bidders for its sale of land used by the National Development Institute (NDI), the party's school to nurture the nation's leaders.

Noting that the KMT has repeatedly said that it will engage in reforms, Lai said the attempted sale of the NDI shows that it is impossible for the KMT to return its ill-gotten party assets voluntarily.

The DPP earlier tried to put a bill governing the assets of political parties on the legislative agenda, but failed because the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), command a slight majority in the 225-seat legislature.
Lai expressed the hope that the PFP will support the DPP this time and stand on the side of justice.

Noting that the KMT closed the door on consultations earlier this month in displeasure over judicial authorities' investigation of KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang's China visit -- in which he reached a 10-point consensus with Beijing, Lai said that draft statutes concerning the 2008 Taiwan Expo, a major arms procurement, the amendment to the organic law of the Executive Yuan, and confirmation of members of the Control Yuan nominated by President Chen Shui-bian have been stalled in the legislature.
"The KMT is selling its party assets on one hand, and is traveling to China to cooperate with the Communist Party of China on the other," which is "unacceptable" to the DPP caucus, Lai said.

DPP Legislator Hsu Kuo-yung also said that the KMT had seized the land occupied by the NDI by forcing people to sell their land cheaply. Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who concurrently serves as one of the party's vice Chairman, also worked with the KMT to rezone the NDI land to try to benefit the KMT, Hsu claimed.
In response, Chen Chieh, KMT legislative caucus whip, said that it is "regrettable" that the DPP is proposing to include the bill on the agenda again.

Chen Chieh said that the DPP's move is to try to whip up confrontation between the ruling and the opposition parties, which he said proves that the DPP government's advocacy of "reconciliation and co-existence" is false and insincere.
The NDI is located in the Wenshan district, Taipei, with 28 land lots totaling 78,541 square meters. The KMT has said that it will sell the property.
Though the KMT has not revealed its asking price, according to the published value of the land, it should be worth more than NT$5.2 billion (US$185.07 million).

Lin Yung-jui, vice chairman of the KMT's Administration and Management Committee, who presided over the bidding, said that three potential buyers showed up Tuesday. But as no one submitted an offer, the party will solicit bidding again later.
A potential bidder also said that as the urban planning project of the NDI has yet to be finalized, the risks are big, adding that he was only looking without seriously considering submitting a bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION MUST NOT GO IT ALONE IN CHINA: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: Opposition leaders should talk with the government and seek domestic consensus on major issues before visiting China so that they will not be used as a tool by Beijing in its united front tactics against Taiwan, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said Tuesday.
Huang was referring to plans by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to visit China in late April and early May, respectively.
Huang said the different attitudes adopted by the two parties in dealing with their planned China trips will affect the public's perception of them.
According to Huang, the Presidential Office has encountered much difficulty while trying to communicate with Lien over his trip because the KMT does not pay heed to the government at all.

On the other hand, the Presidential Office has maintained close contact with the PFP after President Chen Shui-bian and Soong established a 10-point agreement during their last meeting on Feb. 24, Huang noted.

Huang pointed out that the PFP informed the Presidential Office soon after receiving an invitation from Beijing for Soong to visit China, which he said shows that the PFP is sincere and friendly toward the government.

He said the Presidential Office agrees with the PFP that Soong's China trip should help bring about dialogue between the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and believes that Soong will pass on the opinions of the Taiwanese people to Beijing.
However, he denied Soong is visiting China as a special envoy of the president.
He said the Presidential Office has not discussed with the PFP arrangements for a second meeting between Chen and Soong but will leave the possibility open.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR INVITED TO ATTEND TWO REGIONAL CONFERENCES IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said on Tuesday that he may not be able to attend the 2005 Asia Pacific Cities Summit slated for Oct. 12 in Chongqing, western China, but that he will send a representative in his stead if he cannot attend.

Ma made the comments after a city administrative meeting. He said that he has also been invited to join in the CityNet Congress 2005, to be held in Hanoi, Vietnam, Oct. 11-15, and that he is unsure which he should go to.

CityNet, also called the Regional Network of Local Authorities for the Management of Human Settlements, is a network of local authorities that promotes sustainable urban improvement initiatives in the Asia-Pacific region.
Taipei joined CityNet as a member last November.

Ma, who is running for the chairmanship of the opposition Kuomintang, also said that if he wins the race and China subsequently invites him to visit, he will not go unless the trip would benefit Taiwan.

Eight Taiwan mayors, including Ma, were invited to attend the Asia Pacific Cities Summit in Chongqing. The summit was established in 1996 to foster city partnerships and to facilitate the exchange of ideas, knowledge and experiences between local governments, technical experts and businesses within the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Labour stretches its lead as Tories grumble.
Labour is heading for another big majority in the face of a faltering Conservative challenge, a new poll suggested last night amid the first serious sniping from the sidelines at the conduct of Michael Howard's election campaign.
A Populus poll for The Times, taken over the weekend, suggests that Labour has strengthened its support since the election was called a fortnight ago, while the Tories have slipped.
Financial Times: Setback for Howard on tax.
Michael Howard is failing to convince voters that the Conservatives are a low tax party which would spend public money more effectively than Labour, according to a new poll for the Financial Times.
As prominent Tories pile pressure on Mr Howard to step up his hitherto modest commitment to cut taxes in the next parliament, the poll by MORI shows nearly seven out of 10 people believe a Conservative government would increase taxes about three times more than the number who think it would reduce them.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 33.19 points to close at 5,748.35.
The bourse opened at 5,736.97 and fluctuated between 5,773.32 and 5,726.96 during trading. A total of 2.54 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$57.73 billion (US$1.82 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by plastics and chemicals shares at 0.6 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.5 percent, cement stocks at 0.4 percent, construction issues at 0.3 percent.
Two other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down at 0.6 percent and foodstuff issues losing 0.3 percent.
Textile stocks remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 567 to 267, with 173 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD SHOW SINCERITY IN LEGISLATURE BEFORE PRC TRIP: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Visits by opposition leaders to the People's Republic of China (PRC) are acceptable, but their lawmakers should first cooperate with the ruling party to have important bills clear the legislature, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday.

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) legislators Kuo Su-chun and Liu Cheng-hung, who criticized the government's poor handling of KMT Chairman Lien Chan's upcoming visit to the PRC by threatening to take court action against the main opposition party.

Denying the KMT lawmakers' accusation, Hsieh claimed that it will be very hard for the public to buy their story that Lien's PRC visit is to seek benefits for the people in Taiwan if the KMT lawmakers do not work on pushing through bills at the Legislative Yuan, such as the 2008 Taiwan exposition bill, a new five-year fiscal year budget bill and a national health insurance reform bill.

In addition to visiting the PRC, the KMT should engage in screening bills at the Legislative Yuan for the benefit of the Taiwan people, he said, stressing that political figures should be very watchful with their words and deeds and always act in compliance with the law to avoid becoming a bad example for society.
Although Lien's PRC trip is well-intentioned, he warned that a good thing might also be in violation of the law if it lacks a legal process required by law.

The premier reiterated that Lien must report his PRC visit to the government before he goes there and that the KMT chairman must not ink any agreements with the Communist Party of China without government authorization, emphasizing that whatever accords Lien signs involving government authority in the PRC will be invalid.

It would be unnecessary for the government to exist should the opposition camp, which controls more than half of the seats in the Legislative Yuan, not act according to the law or amends the law first, he opined, noting that it is the basic principle of a nation ruled by law.
The premier said he welcomes Lien to approach the Mainland Affairs Council to make a report on his PRC trip or talk about getting government authorization before he goes there.

Turning to a planned visit by People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong also to the PRC, he said that Soong's trip marks a noticeable difference from Lien's case because Soong will notify the government and acquire its approval beforehand.
Meanwhile, Lien is set to depart for the PRC in late April or early May. The exact date will be made public by the KMT Wednesday, KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said.
The PFP has confirmed that Soong will make his trip in early May.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: World Bank: Russians Poorer Than Brazilians

Russia grew slightly wealthier, beating Romania but falling just short of Brazil, according to the World Bank's new World Economic Indicators annual report. Gross per capita income rose by $480 to $2,610 in 2003 -- the last year for which comparative statistics were available -- propelling Russia into 97th place. Last
year, the country ranked 99th among 208 countries and territories, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.126 to close at NT$31.573.
A total of US$800 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.699 and hit a low of NT$31.565.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April gained 47 points to close at 5,754, with 14,912 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved up 35 points to finish at 5,735, with 16,108 contracts traded, while June futures gained 43 points to finish at 5,723, with 202 contracts traded.
September futures gained 48 points to finish at 5,608, with 109 contracts traded, while December futures moved up 66 points to close at 5,608, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,707 for April, 5,700 for May, 5,680 for June, 5,560 for September and 5,542 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

April TE futures moved up 2.2 points to close at 225.25, with 3,796 contracts traded, while May TE futures gained two points to finish at 223.8, with 4,849 contract transactions. June TE futures moved up 2.3 points to close at 223.5, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and December.

April TF futures gained 18.6 points to finish at 905, with 6,931 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures moved up 9.6 points to end at 899.6, with 6,066 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up 11 points to finish at 901, with one contract transaction, while September TF futures gained 7.8 points to end at 891, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN INTERNATIONAL STAMP EXHIBITION TO KICK OFF IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The organizers of the upcoming "18th Asian International Stamp Exhibition -- Taipei 2005" unveiled the show's logo and mascot at a news conference held Monday at the Chunghwa Post Office building in Taipei.

The stamp exhibition, to be held from August 19-24 at the Taipei World Trade Center, is expected to attract 100,000 visitors, Chunghwa Post General Manager Huang Shui-cheng said, noting that the event will be combined with Taiwan's tourism promotion drive.
The indigenous Formosan black bear was chosen in a public competition to serve as the show's mascot, while Taipei 101 -- the tallest building in the world -- was chosen to represent the event.
Huang said that around 300 foreign stamp authorities, collectors and traders have registered to take part in the exhibition in which a total of 150 booths will display stamps from around the world.

Meanwhile, the Tourism Bureau and China Airlines will set up tourist information centers at the venue to coordinate a planned display of stamps concerning travel and tourism, according to the organizers.
The exhibition is aimed at luring more overseas tourists to Taiwan, Huang explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU WANTS POLITICIANS FORBIDDEN FROM VISITING CHINA

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Tuesday they are planning to ask the legislature to pass a resolution forbidding politicians from visiting China without the government's authorization until Beijing renounces its threat to invade Taiwan.
The proposal will be put forth next Tuesday ahead of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's planned trips to China.

It will be raised in accordance with the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, which stipulates that the Legislative Yuan can adopt a resolution restricting Taiwan people from going to China during a certain period of time in the event of "a major unexpected circumstance undermining the primary interests of Taiwan or a situation jeopardizing cross-strait interaction," they said.
Such a ban can only be put into force once it is proclaimed by the Executive Yuan, the law states.

According to TSU Legislator Huang Shih-cho, the enactment of China's Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan should Beijing deem the country to be moving toward independence has seriously impacted the security of Taiwan and the Asia-Pacific region, which matches the definition of "a major unexpected circumstance."
Lien's and Soong's visits to China disregarding the situation have seriously impaired the security and dignity of Taiwan, Huang said.
The TSU also strongly opposes Soong's plan to discuss with Chinese President Hu Jintao a 10-point agreement reached between Soong and President Chen Shui-bian.

Lo Chih-ming, convener of the TSU's legislative caucus, claimed that the move will be tantamount to recognizing the existence of the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" issue, which he said will trap Taiwan in the "one China framework" set up by Beijing.
Lo said Soong must be prohibited from discussing the 10-point agreement with Beijing without the government's authorization and without a domestic consensus on the issue.
He proposed that the government hold a referendum at the end of this year to consult the people on whether they would agree to negotiating with China under Beijing's "one China framework."

As part of his Feb. 24 10-point agreement with Soong, Chen reaffirmed his "five-noes" commitment that he will not declare independence for Taiwan, will not change the official name of the country, will not include the "state-to-state" concept on cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the Constitution, will not promote a referendum to change the cross-strait status quo and will not abolish the Guidelines for National Unification and the National Unification Council.
The TSU has accused Chen of betraying the Taiwanese identity by forging his agreement with Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPENSATION-DEMANDING CHINESE LOSE LAWSUIT IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: Tokyo's high court upheld Tuesday a district court decision that war victims cannot demand compensation from a country even if that country is guilty, in a ruling against a lawsuit lodged by 10 Chinese citizens against Japan.

It is beyond doubt that the Japanese army experimented on live humans and committed the Nanjing Massacre during World War II. However, according to international law, individual victims do not have a right to demand compensation from the war-launching country, Judge Masato Kadoguchi said in his ruling.

Tokyo's district court in 1999 turned down the demand on the same grounds, while recognizing the complainants' suffering. It also acknowledged as "historical fact" that Japan's long-time occupation of China caused severe harm to the Chinese.

Japan occupied Manchuria in northeast China in 1931 and launched all-out attacks on other parts of China in 1937. It surrendered in 1945 after being defeated by the Allied forces, ending World War II.

Some of the 10 Chinese are survivors of the atrocities perpetrated by the infamous Unit 731 of the Japanese army, which used living humans as guinea pigs in weapons experiments, while the others are family members of those killed in the 1937 Nanjing Massacre or Japanese air raids.
In their lawsuit, they demanded a total of 100 million yen in compensation from the Japanese government. Seeing the suit defeated in the second trial, they said they will appeal against the ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN DEPARTS FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China policy planner departed for Tokyo Tuesday for a six-day visit aimed at helping Japanese politicians and scholars better understand the state of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu said prior to his departure that he will deliver a speech at Waseda University Wednesday on the cross-strait situation in the wake of China's recent enactment of its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, as well as Taiwan's present policy toward China.

According to Wu, Japanese political and academic communities are very concerned about the developments in cross-strait relations and Taiwan's China policy following the anti-secession legislation, which codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.
Wu said he will take advantage of his visit to brief Japanese academics and political figures on cross-strait developments and Taiwan's policy guidelines.
In addition, he said he will meet with friends in Japanese political circles to exchange views on topics of mutual interest. Wu is scheduled to return to Taipei Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. GROUP OBSERVING COMPUTERIZED WARGAMES

TEXT.P: An American military adviser group is observing a computer simulation that is part of Taiwan's annual "Han Kuang 21" military exercise, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday.

The remarks by DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung, a member of the defense committee in the Legislative Yuan and an expert in Taiwan military affairs, came after Japan's NHK TV channel reported that Dennis Blair, former head of the U.S. Pacific Command, is leading a delegation of around 20 military officers that is observing the computerized wargames that started Monday.

NHK commented that this was the first time that the U.S. Defense Department has openly said it has sent military personnel to Taiwan, which the TV channel claimed "strongly indicates" that it wants to counterbalance China.
Lee said that this is not the first time that the U.S. Pacific Command has sent a military adviser group to monitor the computerized wargames.
But with the continued expansion of China's military might, he claimed, military cooperation between Taiwan and the United States will become even closer.
He noted that in the past, the U.S. adviser group would only observe some of the wargames, but this year they will observe throughout the five-day period of the games.

The five-day computerized war simulations are armed at honing various combat strategies and tactics, including anti-blockade strategies, airborne defense control, naval forces' air defense and maritime control tactics, as well as cyber-defense operations.

Live-fire drills -- another part of the "Han Kuang 21" annual series of drills devoted to testing the armed forces' combat prowess -- are scheduled for June through August to verify combat strategies and tactics hammered out during the computerized wargames. These maneuvers will include strategies to cope with blitz attacks on a major local oil depot and undersea cables.
The live-fire exercises will also practice counter-strategies against warfare methods such as carpet bombing, infiltrations, abductions, hijackings, computer virus attacks and decapitation strikes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES TO OFFER CHEAP TAIPEI-SINGAPORE FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines announced Tuesday a special offer of economy class tickets between Taipei and Singapore for no more than NT$NT$3,000 (US$95).

Airline officials said that those interested in the special offer can order the tickets via the Internet from noon April 20 until noon April 30 and should depart between May 1 and May 31, returning between May 2 and June 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: CELIA INFANT FORMULA RECALLED AS PRECAUTION AGAINST CONTAMINATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan has recalled from stores all powered infant formula made by the French manufacturer Celia even though Celia says the particular product suspected of being tainted was not imported into Taiwan, the Department of Health said Tuesday.

Chen Lu-hung, director of the health department's Bureau of Food Sanitation, made the remarks after receiving a letter from the French Institute in Taipei, which represents French interests in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, that some infant formulas produced by Celia were found to have been contaminated by salmonella, but that the product was only sold in France and Italy, not in Taiwan.

The formula in question was all produced before March 22 and the health department is checking if any of the contaminated formula was in fact imported into Taiwan and whether the date is before or after March 22.
Formula made after that date has been found to be safe for consumption.
Thirty-five infants in Europe experienced diarrhea after ingesting the formula in March, but none were seriously ill.
Chen said that infant formula for under one-year-olds has been taken off the shelves, and that sales for over one- year-olds is being stopped and recall efforts will be complete by week's end.
Meanwhile, Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he will monitor the situation.

Hsieh was responding to Legislator Liu Cheng-hung of the opposition Kuomintang who questioned the way the health department has been handling the matter, saying that it notified the importers to withdraw the products last week, but only told consumers of the problem later.
A local agent of the French infant formula stressed that most of the product has been examined and proved to be uncontaminated, and that the recall is only a precautionary measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ON REPORT ABOUT U.S. OFFICERS OBSERVING WAR SIMULATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) declined to comment Tuesday on a Japanese media report that a delegation from the U.S. Pacific Command has arrived in Taipei to observe Taiwan's "Han Kuang 21" series of military exercises.

Japan's public television channel NHK reported earlier that day that former U.S. Pacific Command Commander-in-Chief Adm. Dennis Blair is heading a 20-member delegation that is observing Taiwan's ongoing computerized war simulations.
In response to press inquiries about the NHK report, MND officials said it is the ministry's established policy to refrain from commenting on such reports.
The annual Han Kuang series of exercises comprise two parts -- computer war games and live-fire drills.

The five-day computer war simulations kicked off Monday, including a simulation of a Chinese missile and air attack on Taiwan and a simulation of a naval invasion and air attack in the Taiwan Strait, MND sources said.

According to the sources, the computer war games this year will continue to focus on joint operations and discovering the military's shortcomings and deficiencies. The findings will have an impact on the military's future arms procurement plans, the sources said.

Meanwhile, the sources went on, a U.S.-developed joint theater-level simulation system (JTLS) is being used in the Han Kuang 21 war simulations. The system uses computer images that resemble a live-fire maneuver.

The JTLS is capable of remotely linking up to the nation's top military command, the sources said, adding that the military personnel participating in the computer war-game exercises need no longer gather at the maximum-security Hengshan Command in suburban Taipei.

The war simulations will hone various combat strategies and tactics, including anti-blockade strategies, airborne defense control, naval forces' air defense and maritime control tactics, as well as cyber-defense operations.

The live-fire drills are scheduled for June through August to verify combat strategies and tactics hammered out during the computer war-game exercises. These maneuvers will include strategies to cope with surprise attacks on a major local oil depot and undersea cables, as well as counter strategies against unlimited and asymmetric warfare methods such as carpet bombing, infiltrations, abductions, hijackings, computer virus attacks and decapitation strikes.

Decapitation strategies short-circuit command and control systems, wipe out nationwide nerve centers and leave the opponent hopelessly immobilized. Many military observers say China is very likely to use this strategy in an invasion of Taiwan by seizing the nation's center of power -- the capital -- along with its top leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO PROTECT MORE AGED TREES

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government updated a statute Tuesday so that more aged trees will be protected and individuals incurring loss of land for the sake of protecting trees will get compensation.
The city's Tree Protection Statute was altered to cover more aged trees eligible for city protection in an amendment that will be sent to the city council for approval.
Under the revision, trees that are 100 years old or more, those with a trunk circumference of 4.7 meters or diameter of 1.5 meters will be included in the "First Class" category.
Trees aged 50 years or older, measuring 2.5 meters in circumference or 0.8 meters in diameter will be listed in the "Second Class" category.

Both classes are eligible for city protection. Even if the protected trees are on private land, owners can apply for technical assistance if the trees are sick, damaged by natural disasters, or in other emergencies. The city will send advisers to help rescue or rehabilitate the trees and owners will be subsidized for such efforts.
The statute also bans any construction that might hinder the growth of a protected tree within the area 1.5 times that of the tree's largest radius on the ground.
A First Class tree found on public land must remain where it is. If the tree is on private land, the owner can request city assistance in relocating and rehabilitating it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT JUST SPRINGBOARD FOR CHINESE MARKET: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that Taiwan should not denigrate itself as just a "window" or "springboard" to the vast Chinese market.
With its abundant manpower, manufacturing technology and rich foreign exchange reserves, Taiwan has great potential to become an Asia-Pacific economic and trade hub and stronghold, Chen said.
Therefore, he said, crafting a Taiwan-centered industrial development blueprint has been the government's top guiding principle in formulating economic policy.
Chen made the remarks while inspecting the Far Glory Air Cargo Park near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County, some 40 km south of Taipei.

In the face of ever-growing global competition, Chen said, vitality and innovation are critical to Taiwan's competitiveness. While some people claim that Taiwan should accelerate integration with the Chinese market and serve as a "window" or "springboard" for other countries to make inroads into the Chinese market, Chen said he disagrees strongly with such views.

"We should not look down upon ourselves as just someone else's 'stepping-stone' or 'springboard.' We should not draw up our future national development policy based on such a near-sighted view. Taiwan is absolutely not an isolated island or part of China's remote hinterland. With our quality work force, technological know how and bountiful foreign exchange reserves, we can be an Asia-Pacific business hub and economic powerhouse, " Chen said, adding that his administration has worked out Taiwan-centered development strategies.
Chen also urged relevant government agencies to make concerted efforts to ensure that the Far Glory Air Cargo Park project can be completed in five years. (Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CAUTIONS AGAINST INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan businessmen working in China who have reported risk to their security and turned to the Taiwan-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) for help is steadily increasing, according to statistics released by the SEF Tuesday.

SEF officials said the number peaked at 124 in 2004, which represents an increase of 15.88 percent over the previous year and brought the total number of Taiwan businessmen who have asked the SEF for help with personal security problems to 755.

The SEF said in a statement accompanying the statistics that the figures are just the tip of the iceberg because, it claimed, there are "countless unreported cases" in which Taiwan businessmen have been kidnapped, murdered, or robbed in China.
The statement said the SEF is worried that Taiwan businessmen in China, estimated at around 1 million, have become sitting ducks for criminals in China.
Personal security cases accounted for 57.67 percent of all problems that Taiwan businessmen have asked the SEF for help with since 1990 when the SEF was founded.
The statement said the SEF is usually the last resort for Taiwan businessmen trying to solve disputes and that they turn to the SEF only after they have exhausted all other avenues.

As China is a country without an independent judiciary and without a transparent policy-making process, the SEF warned that doing business there is fraught with risks and that Taiwan businessmen should think carefully before venturing into that market.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHIEF CAN DISCUSS AGREEMENT WITH CHINA: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's plan to discuss with Beijing his 10-point agreement with President Chen Shui-bian will not involve any legal problems, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun claimed Tuesday.
According to Yu, the concepts covered by the 10-point agreement are all established government policies.

As part of his Feb. 24 agreement with Soong, Chen reaffirmed his "five noes" commitment, including no declaration of formal independence for Taiwan, no change to the official name of the country and no change to the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo during his term.

Soong, who is to visit China next month soon after a similar trip by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan set for late April, is expected to raise the Chen-Soong agreement for discussion during his meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
Beijing officials said they welcome visits by Taiwanese politicians who support the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" issue and who oppose Taiwan independence.

James Huang, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said it is fair to say that the 10-point agreement represents Chen's standpoints because he has repeated on many occasions the concepts included in the agreement.
However, Huang stressed that this does not mean that Soong is holding talks with Beijing on behalf of the president.
As to the "1992 consensus, " Huang insisted there was never any consensus between Taipei and Beijing on the principle of "one China" during their talks in Hong Kong in 1992 as Beijing has claimed.

Lee Yi-yang, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, urged Soong to confine his talks with Beijing to the 10-point agreement and refrain from recognizing the disputed "1992 consensus."
Meanwhile, PFP Policy Research Center Director Chang Hsien-yao said Soong will visit China in his capacity as chairman of the PFP rather than as a special envoy of the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITINERARY OF KMT CHIEF'S CHINA TRIP TO BE DISCLOSED WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The itinerary of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's trip to China will be disclosed simultaneously in Taipei and Beijing early Wednesday, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Tuesday.

Lin, who had just returned from a trip to Beijing to line up Lien's tour, said the itinerary has been worked out by him and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, and will be disclosed after being approved by Lien.
The KMT chairman's chief of staff said Lien's tour will culminate in a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, which he claimed will be helpful for the peace across the Taiwan Strait.

Speaking in Taiwanese, Lin said Lien's trip is intended to calm down the tension between Taiwan and China with the purposes of helping Taiwan people live in peace, sell their goods to China and improve their lives by making more money.
Local news reports have said the Lien's trip will take him to Xian, Shanghai, Nanjing and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: In Secret, Cardinals Begin Their Balloting to Choose a Pope
Black smoke pirouetted Monday from a chimney ove r the Sistine Chapel, signaling that the cardinals electing the 265th pope had taken a first inconclusive vote two and a half hours after locking themselves in their tradition-laden conclave since 1978, when John P aul II was elected.
Wall Street Journal: Islam's Global Gains Pressure Catholics to Rethink Strategy
For more than 40 years, the Roman Catholic Church has embraced a seductive theory: By extending an olive branch, Christianity could lay to rest its 1,400-year history of conflict with Islam. The church created a new curial office dedicated to fostering a robust dialogue with Islam, as well as other world religions, with the goal of achieving mutual understanding and peace. It welcomed the building of mosques in Europe and spoke out against religious discrimination of Muslims. Now, as Catholic cardinals meet in the Vatican to choose the next pope, there is a growing feeling that these efforts to reach out to Islam have backfired. While some Muslims have embraced the call for dialogue, many Catholics now fret that the conciliatory approach has tied the church's hands, preventing it from keeping up with Islam's rapid growth, particularly in parts of the world once dominated by Catholicism. Some critics also believe the softer stance should be more contingent on a reciprocal tolerance of Catholics in the Muslim world.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 20 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, April 20:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 20, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li-jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Secret Papal Voting Begins. A leading contender to head the Roman Catholic Church demanded a rigid defense of its traditional moral teachings Monday as he and 114 fellow cardinals convened to elect a successor to Pope John Paul II. Their first session ended at dusk after an inconclusive first ballot.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAILS ELECTION OF NEW POPE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday hailed the smooth election of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger of Germany as the new pope.

"We congratulate the Vatican on the election of Pope Benedict XVI, " the DPP said in a press statement, adding that it believes the universal values of religious freedom, democracy and human rights advocated by the Vatican will prevail around the world.
Noting that Taiwan and the Vatican have enjoyed a longstanding friendship and shared values, the DPP said it hopes bilateral relations will be further strengthened and expanded under the new papacy.
Because of China's diplomatic embargo, the Vatican is Taiwan's only only diplomatic ally in Europe.
With unusual speed and little surprise, 115 cardinals in red robes elected Ratzinger, 78, as the Holy See's 265th pontiff Tuesday.

Pope Benedict XVI, succeeding John Paul II, asked the world to pray for him and his papacy in his first appearance on the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica following his election. John Paul died earlier this month at the age of 84.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO EMBARK ON HISTORIC VISIT TO CHINA APRIL 26

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to embark on a historic visit to China April 26, making him the first KMT chairman to set foot on the Chinese mainland in more than five decades, KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said Wednesday.

Labeling Lien's forthcoming visit to China as a "journey of peace, " Lin said that Lien is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing April 29, marking the first rendezvous between the heads of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in nearly 60 years. Hu also serves as the general secretary of the CPC.

Lien and his entourage, including his wife and four children, are first scheduled to visit Nanjing April 27, where Lien will pay homage at the mausoleum of the late Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founder of the KMT and the Republic of China, the first democratic country in Asia, according to Lin.
He also is scheduled to meet with the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference Chairman Jia Qinglin in Beijing April 28 for a talk.
Lien will deliver a speech at Beijing University on the morning of April 29 prior to the meeting with Hu Jintao, Lin said.

Lien, who spent several of his formative years in the northwest Chinese city of Xian, is scheduled to head to Xian April 30, where he will pay a visit to an elementary school he attended before the age of 9 and pay homage at the tomb of his grandmother.
The KMT chairman is scheduled to fly to Shanghai May 1, where he will meet with the leaders of mainland-based Taiwan businesspeople and deliver a speech May 2.
Lien and his group are scheduled to return to Taiwan May 3, according to Lin.

Lin, who returned Tuesday from a visit to Beijing to line up Lien's tour, said Lien's itinerary has been worked out by himself and Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China 's State Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SENDS CONGRATULATIONS TO NEW POPE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's warm congratulations to Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger on being elected the new pope Tuesday are on their way to the Vatican, the Presidential Office announced Wednesday.
President Chen's felicitations will be conveyed by the Republic of China Embassy in the Holy See Wednesday to Pope Benedict XVI, who succeeds Pope John Paul II who passed away April 3.
Cardinals in red robes elected Ratzinger as the new head of the Catholic Church Tuesday, making him the first German pope in nearly a thousand years.

President Chen, who attended the late Pope John Paul II's funeral in person at the Vatican April 8, will decide later members of Taiwan's official delegation to the new pope's enthronement ceremony after the ROC diplomatic personnel in the Vatican consult with the Catholic Church authorities on related affairs, according to officials from the Presidential Office.
The Vatican is the only country in Europe that maintains formal diplomatic relations with the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES PRESIDENT TO CONVENE SUMMIT MEETING OF POLITICAL PARTIES

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Wednesday urged President Chen Shui-bian to convene a summit meeting of the various political parties by April 25 so as to narrow their differences over China and forge a consensus.

Lo Chih-ming, TSU caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks amid reports that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will depart for a visit to China next Tuesday and that People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will travel there soon afterwards.
Lo pointed out that the leaders of the opposition parties "scrambling to visit China" risks undermining the government's stance and the national interests.
If they go, they should have the endorsement of the public, and the political party summit will provide a forum to forge a national consensus and public trust, Lo added.
He urged President Chen to convene a party summit meeting which he said will enable the ruling and the opposition parties to express to President Chen their stances on cross-strait relations.

KMT Chairman Lien, who Lo claimed has so far been unwilling to report to the government about his upcoming mainland trip, can also take the opportunity of listening to the will of the people expressed through various parties taking part in the summit meeting.

TSU Chairman Su Chin-chiang said that the upcoming China visits by Lien and Soong are aimed at "getting even" for their losing the last presidential election in 2004, adding that if the KMT and the PFP really want to cooperate with mainland China, then they might as well merge with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WILL HAVE TO TALK WITH TAIWAN'S ELECTED LEADERS: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chinese leaders will ultimately have to talk with popularly elected leaders in Taiwan if they want their engagements with Taiwan's opposition figures to be productive, a U.S. State Department official said Tuesday.

Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall G. Schriver, who will leave his job at the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs next month, made the remarks while meeting with Taiwan journalists posted in Washington, D.C.

Commenting on reports about Beijing's invitations to Taiwan's two opposition heavyweights -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- to visit China, Schriver said dialogue is better than no dialogue at all.
"As we've said on the record before, our view is that on the margins, dialogue is better than no dialogue at all, and we think talking is better than not talking," Schriver pointed out.
Nevertheless, Schriver added that ultimately how these trips will be viewed will depend on a number of variables.

"Will this diplomacy be a mechanism for moving forward? Subsequently, will it contribute eventually to dialogue broader across the political spectrum in Taiwan? Or will it be limited to just reaching out to the opposition in the tensely divisive mood internally in Taiwan's domestic politics? We just don't know yet, " Schriver said.
"So we are watching this carefully. And genuinely, on the margins, we think, dialogue is better than no dialogue. And we'll see how this plays in Taiwan," he added..
Ultimately, Schriver continued, "for this to be productive for all parties, the leaders in Beijing will ultimately have to talk to elected leaders in Taiwan and the government that's in power."
As to the controversy surrounding KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's recent visit to China, Schriver said he would not comment on Taiwan's internal politics and legal matters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BLAMES LEGISLATURE FOR FAILURE TO PASS ANY LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh blamed the opposition-controlled legislature on Wednesday for failing to pass any legislative or budget bills in the nearly three months since his inauguration.

Hsieh said during a weekly Cabinet meeting that this is a problem that the public should pay attention to, given that the Legislative Yuan can be this slow when there has not been any conflict between the legislative and administrative branches.
Hsieh pointed out that urgent bills on the waiting list include a special statute governing the Taiwan Expo 2008, which he called an event much anticipated by both the government and private sectors.

With the project having been put forth for nearly three years, Hsieh urged the legislature to pass the bill soon because a lot of things have yet to be done with only three years left before the event is set to be held.
Hsieh said the government hopes the exhibition will succeed and bring a lot of business opportunities to Taiwan.

Agreeing with Hsieh, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators said the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party should apologize to the 23 million people in Taiwan for repeatedly blocking Cabinet-proposed bills from being included on the legislature's agenda.
According to DPP legislative caucus convener Chao Yung-ching, his caucus has sought consultations with the opposition on many occasions but has consistently been rejected.
However, PFP legislative caucus convener Chen Chih-pin denied that the opposition has blocked Cabinet-proposed legislation or budgets, saying the PFP has been very friendly toward Hsieh.
Chen claimed that it is very normal that no legislation or budgets have been passed so far since the legislature has spent most of its time interpellating the premier over the past months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Steadfast Beliefs in a Tumultuous World.
In his words and actions, Pope Benedict XVI has shown a determination to hold fast to the moral certainties that have guided him from the horrors of Nazi Germany through the tumult of the 1960s -- even though these beliefs appear to be falling out of public favor across Europe and much of the developed world, the paper said.

Manila Bulletin: Conclave fails to elect Pope
VATICAN CITY (Reuters) -- Roman Catholic cardinals failed anew to choose a new pope in two more votes yesterday at their secret Vatican conclave after last Monday's first vote.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: BIR told: Probe religious leaders Velarde, Villanueva
RELIGIOUS leaders, including Mike Velarde of the El Shaddai charismatic group and Eddie Villanueva of the Jesus is Lord Movement, should be investigated by the Bureau of Internal Revenue if the government is to show teeth in its campaign against tax evaders.
The Philippine Star: Bicam adopts single VAT rate
The congressional bicameral conference committee finally reached an agreement yesterday to adopt a single value-added tax (VAT) rate, effectively scrapping the multi-tier proposal endorsed by the House of Representatives.
The Manila Times: Gray smoke, bells confuse faithful
VATICAN CITY: It was another false alarm -- but for more than a minute Tuesday, thousands of pilgrims in Saint Peter's Square thought the world had a new pope and ran toward the basilica hoping to be the first to catch a glimpse of him.
