DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: U.S. threatens UNSC action on Pyongyang
Hard on the heels of the apparent shutdown of a nuclear reactor in North korea, the White House said Monday it would consider taking Pyongyang to the U.N. Security Council for possible sanction if the Stalinist state refuses to return to six-party talks on its nuclear program.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : MM: It's time to remake Singapore.
The man behind Singapore's clean, safe, efficient and chewing gum-free reputation yesterday deemed these virtues no longer sufficient. Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew called for the country to remake itself culturally.
Joining in the casino debate, Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew called for the country to remake itself culturally. Become a fun and fascinating place, he declared, a city that orchestras and pop divas will not miss on their world tours. Embrace high as well as pop culture.
The Lianhe Zaobao: The integrated resorts with casinos can make the downtown to glow the new light.
The decision to say yes to integrated resorts with casinos by Singapore Government will remake the downtown shining again, said Minister Mentor Lee Kuan Yew.
MM Lee joined the casino debate in Parliament yesterday and described the beautiful landscape of the city in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN HOPES FOR OPEN TALKS WITH CHINA'S LEADER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Wednesday that he will exchange views with Chinese President Hu Jintao openly during his visit to China in the hope of bringing peace for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lien made the remarks while attending a regular meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee.
Hu invited Lien to visit China in his capacity as Chinese Communist Party general secretary.
Lien said that his visit to China next week will mark the first meeting between the leader of the KMT and the Communist Party of China since the KMT fled to Taiwan 56 years ago.
Lien said that "56 years is not a short time. There might be some sadness, but there is also solemn significance" of his upcoming visit.

On cross-strait issues, Lien said that the "agenda doesn't have to be big or grand, " adding that "as long as both sides can rationally exchange views based on peace, goodwill and sincerity," he is confident that both sides can explore some issues under the ideals of "equal footing and a win-win situation."
Noting that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have differences, but Lien said that seeking common ground and trying to enlarge this common ground will be what both sides will be striving for.
He also expressed the hope that his trip will lay a favorable foundation for cross-strait exchanges.

Lien, who will depart for China next Tuesday, said he will first go to Nanjing to pay his respects to Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the founding father of the Republic of China who helped found the first republic in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Rice Calls the Kremlin's Grip 'Very Worrying'.
U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on Tuesday called the Kremlin's tight grip on power and the media "very worrying" and urged President Vladimir Putin not to cling on to power beyond his current term. Rice made some of the sharpest U.S. criticism to date of the Kremlin's record on democracy at the start of a visit to Moscow.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened higher but closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, losing 55.34 points to close at 5,693.01.
The bourse opened at 5,799.85 and fluctuated between 5,799.85 and 5,683.00 during trading. A total of 2.78 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.72 billion (US$2.01 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares edging up 0.1 percent and construction stocks moving up 0.6 percent.

All other six categories posted losses, with plastics and chemical shares down 0.9 percent, machinery and electronics shares down 1.5 percent, cement stocks down 0.4 percent, foodstuff stocks down 1.2 percent, textiles down 0.3 percent, and paper stocks down 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 732 to 137, with 138 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDEPENDENCE GROUP ACCUSES KMT, PFP OF HARMING TAIWAN'S INTERESTS

TEXT.P: The leader of a pro-independence group accused opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong Wednesday of seriously damaging the interests of Taiwan over their planned visits to China.

Taiwan Society North Chairman Wu Shu-min noted that China triggered widespread disapproval from the international community following the enactment of its Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, but claimed that the China trip by KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang last month undermined Taiwan's efforts to win international support.
The upcoming China trips by Lien and Soong will further damage the national interests of Taiwan, according to Wu.
Wu said Beijing should start official talks with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government if it truly intends to show its goodwill toward Taiwan.

Wu expressed his opposition to Soong's plan to discuss with Beijing his Feb. 24 10-point consensus with President Chen Shui-bian, pointing out that Soong is not qualified to represent the government or people of Taiwan.

The agreement, in which Chen reaffirmed his "five noes" commitment including no independence for Taiwan and no change to the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo during his term, has enraged pro-independence hardliners on the island, who have accused the DPP of betraying the Taiwanese identity.

Wu urged the government to specify its stand toward visits to China by opposition leaders and threatened to have his supporters "besiege the KMT headquarters" if Lien does anything detrimental to Taiwan during his China trip.
Lien is set to visit China between April 26 and May 3, while Soong is expected to go there in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: RATIONAL DISCUSSION NEEDED ON HEALTH INSURANCE SYSTEM: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that the government will listen carefully to the views of medical professionals and the public on the national health insurance program and give them serious thought.

The premier's remarks came before a march by tens of thousands doctors later of the day to protest against shrinking reimbursement from the Bureau of National Health Insurance that they claimed threatens their survival.

Hsieh said that the government attaches great importance to pluralism in society and for this reason, will take into consideration the voice of the general public and the medical professionals, with equal concern for their rights and interests.
But in the end, there should be rational discussion, as the national health insurance program involves pluralistic values and multilateral interests.
He stressed that the government has to consider the best interests of everyone and the quality of medical care, as well as the care of the underprivileged.
The underprivileged should get prioritized medical care so as to help create a more just society and lessen the gap between rich and poor.

On the cash-strapped finances of the national health insurance program, Lien said that the government has adopted some emergency measures, although these will not address the root of the problem, which is still controversial because of the diversity of views on the subject.

The government's temporary remedial measures include a slight adjustment of premiums and an increase in government spending of NT$11 billion (US$349.2 million), which should be of some help to the floundering national health insurance program, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT REINING IN PFP HEAD WITH SOVEREIGNTY BOTTOM LINE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is right to use People First Party Chairman James Soong to discredit Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan but that does not mean giving Soong a "blank check" when he visits China, political analysts said Wednesday.
According to the analysts, the DPP has adopted a six-point "code of conduct" to restrict Soong's mandate in negotiating with China.

The government and DPP have been trying to discredit Lien while authorizing Soong to talk to the Chinese leadership on the basis of a 10-point consensus he reached recently with President Chen Shui-bian.

If the ruling camp does not come up with a firm position on the imminent visits to China by the two opposition leaders, its statements will be regarded as political mud-slinging and its actions may be seen as proof that it is panicking, the analysts said.

For this reason, the DPP has adopted its six-point "code of conduct" for political parties dealing with China, the first point being adamant opposition to Beijing's "one China" principle in the form of the so-called "1992 consensus," they added.
The code of conduct also affirms the Republic of China's sovereignty enjoyed by the 23 million people of Taiwan, who alone have a right to change the ROC's status and decide on its future.

The code of conduct largely agrees with the 10-point consensus reached between Soong and Chen, and so will have the effect of reining in Soong, as he will be urged to recognize the idea that the consensus reached in the 1992 negotiations in Hong Kong does exist.
But that does not mean China is the sole legitimate party to paraphrase the 1992 talks. Taiwan -- in this case Soong -- can offer its version of the story too, the analysts pointed out.
They said that if China insists on its version of "one China" as a precondition for Taiwan politicians to negotiate cross-strait affairs, the government will not accept.

In short, the government and the DPP are using the Chen-Soong consensus and the "code of conduct" as a line in the sand over which Soong should not step when he visits China early next month, the analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DIPS ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dipped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, giving up NT$0.060 to close at NT$31.513.
A total of US$954 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$31.573 and hit a low of NT$31.460 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGED TO RELAY TAIWAN MAINSTREAM OPINION TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should voice Taiwan's mainstream public opinion to Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao when he visits Beijing, a veteran China expert said Wednesday.

Chang Wu-ueh, a professor at the Institute of China Studies at Tamkang University, urged Lien to do this as Beijing has publicly declared that "it is willing to discuss with Lien a broad range of issues of major interest and concern to the people on both sides (of the Taiwan Strait)."

Claiming that Beijing lacks an adequate understanding of a democratic Taiwan, Chang said Lien should also express concern over China's democratization to Hu and help him get a clear idea of Taiwan's democratization.

According to Chang, the KMT chairman should tell Hu that most of the people of Taiwan are in favor of maintaining the status quo across the Taiwan Strait to secure peaceful development on the two sides. In addition, Lien should urge Beijing to recognize the existence of the Republic of China, he said.

Doing so would not be meddling in China's internal affairs, rather it would be aimed at helping forge mutual understanding, he said, adding that a majority of the people on both sides hope fervently for a more open society based on freedom and democracy.
Cross-strait relations would develop in a more positive direction if both sides uphold the same values, he said.

Now that the KMT has designated Lien's visit to China as a "party-to-party" encounter with the CPC, Lien should act as an opposition leader, he said, calling on Lien to refrain from discussing sensitive issues or inking pacts with Hu involving government authority.
Democracy is Taiwan's asset in its dealings with China and the issue of how to turn party-to-party contacts into an asset for cross-strait exchanges will be a task for the government, he said.

The KMT announced earlier in the day that Lien will depart for China April 26 and return May 3, marking an unprecedented meeting between the top leaders of the two rival political parties since the KMT retreated to Taiwan from mainland China in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SHOULD STRESS CROSS-STRAIT DIFFERENCES IN '1992 CONSENSUS'

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should emphasize the differences between Taiwan and China over the meaning of "one China" when discussing with Beijing a consensus supposedly agreed upon by both sides during talks held in 1992 in Hong Kong, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday.

Ma, who also serves as a vice chairman of the KMT, made the suggestion during a weekly meeting of the party's Central Standing Committee. Lien is set to visit China from April 26-May 3, during which he is expected to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao.

According to Ma, the "1992 consensus" refers to an agreement allowing Taipei and Beijing to interpret the meaning of "one China" differently, with Taipei insisting the "one China" means "the Republic of China" and Beijing maintaining it means "the People's Republic of China."
The KMT should focus on this spirit when discussing the issue with Beijing, Ma said.
Beijing has claimed that the so-called "1992 consensus" means that both sides agreed to the principle of "one China."

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party has refused to recognize the existence of the "1992 consensus, " which is said by the KMT to have been established when it was ruling Taiwan, on the grounds that doing so would trap Taiwan in Beijing's "one China" policy.

Ma proposed that Lien address the concepts of freedom, democracy, human rights and rule of law in a scheduled speech at Peking University, which Ma called a good opportunity for Lien to exchange dialogue with the Chinese people.
Also, Ma said, Lien should address issues concerning Taiwan's international participation.
As an opposition party, the KMT should not try to dominate cross-strait talks and should allow the involvement of the government, Ma added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for April lost 53 points to close at 5,701, with 12,443 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for May moved down 56 points to finish at 5,679, with 31,733 contracts traded, while June futures lost 47 points to finish at 5,676, with 83 contracts traded.
September futures lost 76 points to finish at 5,532, with 354 contracts traded, while December futures moved down 73 points to close at 5,535, with 15 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,754 for April, 5,735 for May, 5,723 for June, 5,608 for September and 5,608 for December.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

April TE futures moved down 3.35 points to close at 221.90, with 1,821 contracts traded, while May TE futures lost 3.35 points to finish at 220.45, with 4,797 contract transactions. June TE futures moved down 3.9 points to close at 219.6, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

April TF futures remained unchanged at 905, with 3,180 contracts changing hands, while May TF futures surged 3.4 points to end at 903, with 5,766 contracts traded. June TF futures moved up two points to finish at 900, with seven contract transactions, while September TF futures increased 3 points to end at 899, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HEAD APOLOGIZES OVER HANDLING OF INFANT FORMULA INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The head of the Department of Health (DOH) apologized Wednesday over the way the department handled the issue of suspected tainted infant formula produced by French manufacturer Celia that caused a scare among local consumers.
DOH Minister Ho Sheng-mao offered the apology during a Cabinet meeting for not informing the public about Celia's products in a timely manner.

Some of Celia's infant formula products were found to have been contaminated by salmonella bacteria. Thirty-five infants in Europe experienced diarrhea after ingesting the formula in March, but none were seriously ill.

The DOH asked the importer to take the formula in question off the shelves last week, but only later informed consumers, although the importer had been inundated by phone calls from worried consumers about the safety of the product.
Ho apologized to the public for the department's handling of the matter and said the staff responsible will be disciplined.

He admitted that the DOH first learned about the contaminated infant formula from the World Health Organization in March, but failed to keep abreast of all the information available, which caused panic among local consumers.
Secondly, the DOH failed to make the public its top priority and failed to establish a partnership relationship with the Consumers' Foundation.
Lastly, Ho said, the DOH's crisis-handling mechanism should be strengthened.

Wu Rong-i, chairman of a consumer protection committee at the Executive Yuan, said that after examination, the committee has found none of the suspect infant formula on the shelves of Taiwan stores, which he said also matched the findings of the DOH, suggesting that none of the tainted formula has been introduced into Taiwan.
Wu also said that the DOH should have considered the feelings of consumers in handling such matters and should have avoided causing misunderstanding and uneasiness because of incomplete information.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAFFIC VOLUME AT TAIWAN'S INTERNATIONAL AIRPORTS HITS NEW RECORD

TEXT.P: The number of inbound and outbound passengers via Taiwan's two international airports hit a new record of 24.21 million in 2004, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported Wednesday.

Passenger volume at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport dropped to 19.09 million people in 2003 from 24.01 million in 2002 because of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndromes (SARS).
With the SARS shadow fading away last year, passenger volume at both airports rebounded to set a new record.
A total of 31 carriers operate flight services via the two airports, six domestic and 25 foreign owned.
The six Taiwan carriers transported a total of 14.06 million inbound and outbound passengers last year, with an average occupancy rate of 74.3 percent, also a record high.
In comparison, the 25 foreign carriers carried 10.15 million passengers for an average occupancy rate of 69.6 percent.

China Airlines -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- topped the list in terms of passenger volume at CKS Airport, carrying 6.8 million passengers in 2004, followed by EVA Airways, with 4.86 million. Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways was next with 3.19 million, followed by Japan Asia Airways, with 1.52 million.

China Airlines was also the No. 1 carrier in terms of passenger volume at Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan, carrying 760,000 passengers, followed by Dragon Air, with 490,000 passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES POLITICIANS TO ABIDE BY LAW WHEN VISITING CHINA

TEXT.P: Political party leaders should abide by laws during trips to China and should set a good example for the general public, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said Wednesday.

You said the MAC does not like seeing political leaders visiting China in the wake of Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law that permits it to attack Taiwan, but if they insist on making the trip, they should at least comply with the law when doing so.

You made the remarks after the opposition Kuomintang announced earlier that day that its chairman, Lien Chan, will embark on a trip April 26 that will culminate in a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing.
Meanwhile, James Soong, the chairman of the opposition People First Party, has also accepted an invitation from Hu to visit China in early May.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA HEAD TO RESIGN

TEXT.P: Environmental Protection Administer Chang Jun-en said Wednesday that Premier Frank Hsieh has approved his resignation, which will take effect next Monday.
Chang announced his resignation after presiding over a regular meeting of the Environmental Protection Administration, saying that he tendered his oral resignation to Hsieh that afternoon.

Asked about his abrupt resignation from the post, Chang only said that it has been four years since he was transferred from his teaching post at National Cheng Kung University to the EPA. He then started crying.

Premier Frank Hsieh retained most of the members of the Cabinet from former Premier Yu Shyi-kun when he assumed office in February, but according to reports, the Cabinet will undergo major reshuffle later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNA ASSOCIATION WORKING TO REDUCE TUNA FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is taking measures to reduce the number of tuna fishing boats to comply with international conservation efforts, Taiwan Tuna Association President Wang Shun-lung said Wednesday.

During a meeting of the association held in the port city, Wang pointed out that international fisheries organizations have expressed deep concern over the issue and have pressed the United Nations to impose sanctions on countries that refuse to comply.
According to Wang, the association has worked out a plan to reduce the number of tuna fishing boats, which now amounts to more than 600, after coordination with members of the tuna industry.
Wang noted that the tuna industry is a very competitive international industry.

On the problems faced by Taiwan's tuna industry, Wang said Taiwan is overly reliant on the Japanese market while lacking in fishery resources, and he claimed that the tuna quotas enjoyed by Taiwan are insufficient.
Under these circumstances, he said, reducing the number of tuna boats is a necessary measure that Taiwan must take until new markets are developed.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPROVED INVESTMENT IN CHINA DECLINES IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Approved investment by Taiwan businessmen in China in the first quarter showed a decline in terms of the number of investment projects and the total monetary value, according to the latest tallies released by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs Wednesday.

The figures show that the number of approved investment projects was 289 in the first three months, down 47.83 percent from the same period of last year, while the total investment amount approved was US$1.27 billion, down 6.57 percent from last year.

Commission officials said that the cooling down of the investment fever could be related to China's policy of cooling down its overheated economy, the aftermath of its recent enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, and complaints by Taiwan businessmen in private about having their tax-paying checked and their factories inspected.

The electric and electronic manufacturing sector topped the Taiwan investment projects in China, accounting for 40 percent of the total, followed by the chemical manufacturing sector (10 percent), and the basic metal manufacturing sector (9.64 percent).
The investment projects were focused in Jiangsu, Guangdong and Zhejiang provinces, with investment projects in the three provinces accounting for 86.31 percent of the total.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGES ASIAN NEIGHBORS TO HELP CHINA DEMOCRATIZE

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to create an environment conducive to peaceful dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and other countries in East Asia should encourage China to seek peace and democracy, Taiwan's top China policymaker said Wednesday.
Joseph Wu, chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks in a speech delivered to the faculty and students of Waseda University in Tokyo.
Taiwan's China policy goals are "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation and permanent peace," he said.

However, these goals now look elusive as China's Anti-Secession Law has severely damaged cross-strait relations, he said. Still, he emphasized that Taiwan will never stop seeking peaceful dialogue with China and will always work at maintaining peace and stability in East Asia.

The main problem with China's Anti-Secession Law lies in its attempt to change the status quo -- trying to restrain Taiwan's democratic development with vague provisions which authorize the use of "non-peaceful means" to achieve its political goals.
This is the reason why Japan, Europe, the United States and other democracies have frowned on the law, not to mention Taiwan residents who have taken to the streets in loud protest, he said.
He further pointed out that China's military build-up is threatening not just Taiwan, but other Asian countries as well.

As a matter of fact, he said, the biggest conflict between Taiwan and China is not military, but diplomatic. "China has spared no efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international community, trying to stifle Taiwan's economic activities, even in the NGO (non-governmental organization) area."
Now Taiwan is closely watching what China will do following its enactment of the much-hated Anti-Secession Law, Wu said.
Nevertheless, there is room for improved relations. "We are expecting China to negotiate with us over substantive issues such as direct charter passenger flights," he added.
If progress can be made in this area, both sides can step onto the road toward cooperation, instead of being bogged down by the current impasse, Wu said.

He promised that Taiwan will work hard in that direction, because only when both sides engage in sincere cooperation can they realistically begin political discussions that hopefully will lead to permanent peace.

In addition to direct charter passenger flights, he cited other areas of potential cooperation, including charter cargo flights, currency exchange, an investment guarantee pact, a financial monitoring mechanism, avoidance of double taxation, judicial agreement on protecting Taiwan businessmen in China, repatriation of Chinese stowaways, and jointly combating cross-strait crime.

Given Taiwan's democratic system and peace-loving people, he said the government will not reject any proposal for a permanent solution to cross-strait disputes as long as his 23 million fellow citizens assent.
Wu flew into Japan Tuesday for a visit during which he will also exchange views with Japanese leaders on Taiwan's China policy and Taiwan-Japan ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Benedict XVI, 78, Was John Paul II's Strict Defender of the Faith.
Roman Catholic cardinals reached to the church's conservative wing on Tuesday and chose as the 265th pope Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, a seasoned and hard-line German theologian who served as John Paul II's defender of the faith. The unusually brief conclave seemed to suggest that Cardinal Ratzinger was a popular choice inside the college of 115 cardinals who elected him as a man who shared - if at times went beyond - John Paul's conservative theology and seemed ready to take over the job after serving beside him for more than two decades.
Wall Street Journal: In Choosing Pope, Church Stakes Future on Its Base.
The election as pope of Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, a 78-year-old German theologian who once jokingly referred to his reputation as the Vatican's "grand inquisitor, " signals the Roman Catholic Church will march, not tiptoe, down the traditionalist path blazed by the late John Paul II. In his two-decade career as John Paul's unyielding enforcer of church doctrine, Cardinal Ratzinger, now Pope Benedict XVI, has combated what he views as the chief adversaries of God and the church: secularism and moral relativism. Many leading Catholics yesterday viewed the choice of Benedict as a decision by the cardinals to stake the future of Catholicism on its base -- its teachings about God and Jesus, and its most-committed believers. That is what many within the church feel is most urgently needed: a pope who wants to reassert Catholic identity.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIFFERENCES ASIDE, GOV'T WILL TREAT OPPOSITION TRIPS WITH EVEN HAND

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will handle the trips to China by the heads of the two main opposition parties with an even hand, but the tenor of the Kuomintang (KMT) in its dealings with the government has been " disrespectful, " Cho Jung-tai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

As both the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) have announced that their chairmen will separately visit China, Cho said the Executive Yuan will deal with both trips according to the law, which applies to everyone who goes to China from Taiwan.

Under this principle, Cho said, anyone who intends to conclude any agreement with China on matters falling within the government's jurisdiction should get the government's authorization or consent beforehand.

The Executive Yuan, however, has received opposite responses from the two parties on the issue, with the KMT refusing to contact the administration before its chairman leaves for China; whereas the PFP head has been more accommodating in revealing the party's plans to the government.
Cho said the KMT's reluctance to comply with the government's request is quite disrespectful.

Traveling to China does not entail any legal constraints imposed by the government, Cho said, but it is necessary that any political party or individual who has the intention to act as if it were a representative of the Republic of China to get approval for any actions that may be deemed to undermine the integrity of the administration and the sovereignty of the nation.
The KMT's response reflects the party's carefree attitude toward the authorities, he added.
On the other hand, Cho said, PFP Chairman James Soong has promised to convey to China the 10-point consensus reached by President Chen Shui-bian and himself on Feb. 24.

Calling the 10-point consensus a concise and comprehensive reflection of the president's attitude toward China, Cho said Beijing leaders can easily understand the president's opinions through their talks with Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOPES TO SEE REAL PROGRESS IN TAIWAN'S WHO BID: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States looks forward to seeing incremental progress in Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) , Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall G. Schriver said Tuesday.
Schriver, who will leave his job at the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs next month, made the remarks while meeting with Taiwan journalists stationed in Washington, D.C.
Asked whether Beijing has shown any softening of its aversion to Taiwan's WHO bid, Schriver said Chinese authorities have not indicated that they have a new position on the issue.

"We continue to work on it. We have not only approached Beijing on this issue, but also worked with countries we regard as friends and the like-minded. So we'll see if we can achieve our ultimate objective, which is observership for Taiwan in the WHO, and see if we can make incremental progress in that direction," Schriver said.
Taiwan has sought to attend the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's decision-making body -- as an observer since 1997. Due to Beijing's obstruction, Taiwan has yet to realize its goal.
At last year's vote, the United States and Japan gave "yes" votes, but China still managed to use its diplomatic clout to block the bid.

Asked whether Taiwan would ask for a vote at this year's World Health Assembly scheduled for May in Geneva, Schriver said the United States and Taiwan have discussed a range of options to be adopted this year, including a vote.

"The vote, we did that last year. We know the outcome. If our friends in Taiwan want to pursue that again, they know they can count on our support. But we are interested really not so much in a symbolic move of any kind. We want to see real progress towards meaningful participation for Taiwan in the WHO," Schriver said.
"[An] example would be, if not observership, then Taiwan's ability to participate in the work of the WHO, contribute to the WHO in ways without any obstacles from Beijing," he explained.
As to whether the European Union has shown support for Taiwan's WHA observership, Schriver said: "The E.U. is part of our consultations, but you'd better ask the E.U. on their position."

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVILIAN EXCHANGES MUST COME FIRST IN CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The time is not yet ripe for Taiwan and mainland China to conduct political negotiations and it is better for the two sides to hold talks on civilian exchanges to break the present impasse across the Taiwan Strait, a political analyst said Wednesday.

Juan Ming, a senior advisor at the Taiwan Research Institute, called on Lien Chan, head of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), to hold talks on bolstering private-sector interactions when Lien visits China April 26 to May 3 as a means of helping break the ice between the two sides of the strait.

It is not feasible for Lien to discuss political issues regarding a peace accord or China's removal of its more than 700 missiles targeting Taiwan at this juncture, he contended, suggesting that Lien start two-way talks focusing on coordinated crime-fighting, direct transportation and trade links and economic issues with Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao.
He reminded the KMT chairman not to be used as a tool in Beijing's propaganda machine at a time when Beijing has passed its Anti-Secession Law legislating "non-peaceful means" to deal with Taiwan.

He also urged People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong, who will also visit China in early May, to convey the opinions of the people of Taiwan to CPC leaders that they will never accept Beijing's Anti-Secession Law or give in to its military threats against Taiwan.

Juan, however, did not think that Soong would end up being Beijing's stooge since the CPC approved of the 10-point agreement signed Feb. 24 by Soong and President Chen Shui-bian that promises to maintain the cross-strait status quo.

The anticipated Lien-Hu meeting will be the first tete-a-tete between the top leaders of the KMT and the CPC since 1949, when the KMT retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese Communists on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED NOT TO CHEAT WORLD COMMUNITY ABOUT TAWAIN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: The 23 million people of Taiwan are eligible to take part in the World Health Organization (WHO) in a "direct, separate, complete and immediate" manner, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.

If China is sincerely concerned about Taiwan people's health rights, the ministry said, it should not block Taiwan's bid to join the annual World Health Assembly -- the WHO's governing body -- as an observer any more.
China should also refrain from making hypocritical statements to cheat the world community over its concern about Taiwan's WHO participation, the ministry said in a news release.

The ministry was responding to recent remarks by Li Weiyi, a spokesman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, that China is concerned about Taiwan people's health rights and has come up with four basic principles regarding Taiwan's WHO participation. Li claimed that Taiwan has so far not made any response to China's proposals and he added that Beijing is willing to discuss with the WHO Secretariat to work out a "special arrangement" for Taiwan's to participate.
The ministry said Chinese authorities have never clearly fleshed out its so-called "four basic principles."

Probably, the ministry said, the "four basic principles" referred to statements made by China's deputy health minister at the 2004 World Health Assembly in Geneva. According to the statements, only Taiwan's medical and health-care personnel would be allowed to take part in the WHO's technical activities. Moreover, China would treat Taiwan as a local government under its jurisdiction.
The ministry said Beijing's such principles are absolutely unacceptable to Taiwan.

Stressing that interaction between Taiwan and the WHO should be based on reciprocity, the ministry said such interaction should not be denigrated as technological exchanges between Taiwan's medical personnel and the WHO.

The ministry pointed out that Taiwan's jurisdiction covers 1.5 million sorties of flights over its flight information zone, 220,000 sorties of takeoffs and landings at its international airports with a combined traffic volume of more than 21 million passengers, and more than 50,000 inbound and outbound cargo ships.

Given such heavy international traffic volume, the ministry said, Taiwan should be included into the world health and disease control system. Without Taiwan's participation, the ministry said, the WHO-initiated global health system will be flawed and handicapped.

Noting that the soon-to-be-completed International Health Regulations are aimed at regulating epidemic control and public health affairs amid ever-growing international interactions, the ministry said the WHO should admit Taiwan into its fold to realize its noble goal of "health for all."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXTENDS CONGRATULATIONS TO NEW POPE

TEXT.P: Taiwan has extended its congratulations to former Germany Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger on his election as the new leader of the Catholic Church, and looks forward to working together with him and the Holy See to promote bilateral ties, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement Wednesday.

The statement said, the ministry has asked its embassy in Vatican City to convey to former Cardinal Ratzinger, who chose the name Pope Benedict XVI, the congratulations from President Chen Shui-bian, Premier Frank Hsieh and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen.

Calling the new pope a worthy successor of the late Pope John Paul II, the statement said the new pope is sure to carry on John Paul II's cause for promoting peace, justice, human dignity and freedom of religion around the world.
As a peace-loving democracy, the statement said, the Republic of China will continue to support the Holy See's religious and charitable activities and work to continue maintain bilateral ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20,000 TAIWAN MEDICAL WORKERS GO TO STREETS

TEXT.P: Over 20,000 medical professionals from around the island gathered in downtown Taipei Wednesday afternoon to stage a noisy protest against a government decision to impose a limit on health care finances, a measure they claim threatens their survival.

Many well-known doctors, hospital executives and fellow workers in the health care industry were petitioning the government and the legislature to rescind the decision to limit the total reimbursement, demanding a more "reasonable" reform of the health care system.

Organizers said the number of participants broke the 20,000-mark because as many as 70 percent of clinics shut down, and even family members of the health providers joined in the march, affecting up to 200,000 patients.

The protesters' loud cries apparently reached the ears of Premier Frank Hsieh, who promised to take into account the views of medical professionals as well as the general public as to what to do about the cash-strapped national health insurance program.

Minister of Health Hou Sheng-mou said it was sad to see some of his former colleagues taking to the streets over an issue that can be solved through robust dialogue. "The government's door to negotiation is always wide open," he said.

Jao Yung-ching, convener of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus, called on the medical workers to be patient and wait for the government to come up with a comprehensive reform proposal.

The Taiwan Health-care Reform Foundation did not quite agree with the protesters, saying individual hospitals and clinics must open their books for public review so that people will know whether they are really poor or just hypochondriacs.

Besides opening up their accounting books, all hospitals must also have their quality of service examined and meet the same standards, so real solutions can be found to ease the financial crisis of the health care system, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 21 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, April 21:
09:00, The Legislative Yuan will start its session for the day.
09:00, A seminar on trade and investment in India will be held at the Taipei International Convention Center.
10: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend a news conference at the National Taiwan University Alumni Hall on combating pornographic Web sites.
10:00, The Democratic Action Alliance will stage a protest at the Central Election Commission.
11: 00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.
12: 30, The National Science Council will hold a news conference at the council's headquarters.
14: 15, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
15: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive winners of this year's medical contribution awards at the Presidential Office.
16:30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a news conference at the ministry's headquarters.
17: 00, The Financial Supervisory Commission will hold a news conference at the commission's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO IMPACT ON TAIWAN AGRICULTURE SMALLER THAN EXPECTED: COA

TEXT.P: The impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) has been smaller than expected, proof that the government has adequately handled the thorny issue to date, Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung said Wednesday.

Lee made the remarks in a speech delivered at a seminar held jointly by the COA and National Chung Hsing University in northern Hsinchu County. More than 140 representatives from the government and the academic sector took part.

According to Lee, the COA has been doing all it can to advocate a competitive, high-quality and eco-friendly agriculture sector in recent years to help Taiwan farmers sell more in the global market after the country joined the WTO in Jan. 2002.

Noting that the core function of the COA is to protect and boost interests of local farmers and fishermen, Lee reported that the government increased the COA's budget to NT$122 billion (US$3.87 billion) for 2005 in order to better take care of these people.

Statistics made public April 18 by the COA's Fisheries Administration show that the average wholesale price of marine products in the domestic market was NT$53 per kilogram last year, a slight increase of 0.2 percent over the 2002 level.
Both the inbound and outbound shipments of fishery goods decreased in volume but grew in value in 2004 compared to the previous year's levels, according to the same tallies.

Last year, 114,155 metric tons of marine delicacies worth US$311.2 million were imported to Taiwan, down by 1.3 percent and up by 2 percent compared to the 2003 figure, respectively. Frozen tuna and crustacea were the mainstays.
Meanwhile, 531,572 metric tons of seafood valued at US$1.463 billion were exported, off by 6.6 percent and up by 12.2 percent year to year, respectively.

According to Fisheries Administration officials, Taiwan's fishery industry has come under fiercer foreign competition after the country entered the WTO. To help it grow sustainably, the administration has been actively exploring markets offshore for domestic fishermen and encouraging the public to eat more seafood, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN TO RESHUFFLE CABINET: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that he has no plans to reshuffle his Cabinet for the moment.

Fielding questions raised by reporters on the resignation of Environmental Protection Administrator Chang Jun-en, Hsieh said that Chang decided to leave his current post because the four-year transfer period from his teaching post at National Cheng Kung University expired.
There will be no other change of members of his Cabinet, he said.
The premier also categorically denied speculation that there will be a large reshuffle of the Cabinet in August.

Chang announced his resignation earlier the same day after presiding over a regular meeting of the Environmental Protection Administration, saying that he had told the premier verbally of his intention to resign.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APPRECIATES U.S. SUPPORT FOR ITS WHO BID

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health officials and medical workers took heart Wednesday upon hearing of a United States official's public support for the country's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA).

Chang Wu-hsiou, the director for the International Cooperation Bureau under the Department of Health said he appreciates U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary Randall Schriver's Tuesday statement in Washington that his department has approached Beijing and is working with friendly countries to help Taiwan participate in the WHA.

Noting that this is the second time in one week that Schriver has voiced U.S. support for Taiwan on the issue, Chang said he is optimistic about the prospect of Taiwan's eventually participation in the WHO.

In addition to counting on friendly states' support, Chang said, the Department of Health is trying to enhance the country's international presence by generously providing medical aid to countries in need, such as Indonesia, Thailand and the Maldives after these countries were ravaged by tsunamis on Dec. 26 last year.
The more actively Taiwan joins international rescue operations, the easier it will be for Taiwan to win support for its WHA bid, Chang said.

Dr. Deng Jou-fang, the president of the Taiwan International Medical Alliance, which has campaigned for Taiwan's involvement in international bodies for years, said Washington's support will boost Taiwan's WHA attempts on the international stage and will facilitate Taiwan's efforts to woo the support of European Union member states.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AND EUROPEAN STRATEGIC DIALOGUE ON ASIA TO BEGIN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The United States is to have a strategic dialogue with the European Union and Europe about Asia, U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Tuesday.

Rice told journalists on a flight from Washington, D.C., to Moscow for a visit that the dialogue is a very positive development as Asia is probably facing more changes than any other region, and the dialogue will help the two sides of the Atlantic Ocean to sort out their differences in approaches to the region.
Notably among these changes is the rise of China and the democratizing trend in Southeast Asia, Rice said.

Citing the conflicting views between the United States and Europe on whether the EU should lift its arms embargo on China, Rice said it stems from the two sides' different understanding of the security environment in Asia, and hopefully it can be removed through strategic dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 21, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUE HELPFUL TO REDUCING TENSIONS: WHITE HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 20 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Wednesday that the United States believes dialogue between Taiwan and China would help resolve cross-strait issues and reduce the tensions.

The spokesman made the remarks in response to a question raised at a media briefing regarding an invitation extended by Chinese President Hu Jintao to Taiwan's leading opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien China for a "party-to-party summit" to be held next week in Beijing.
Saying that he has not heard about that specific invitation, McClellan, however, said that "we believe cross-strait dialogue is important to resolving the issues and reducing tensions."

Asked whether it would be in the United States' interest if Hu and Lien took steps towards a final resolution of the Taiwan issue and whether Washington would encourage such steps, the spokesman declined to give a reply, only saying that the question is "pretty speculative" at this point.
