DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: A New Pope: Benedict XVI. Joseph Ratzinger, a renowned theologian and hard-line enforcer of Catholic Church doctrine for the last two decades, was chosen Tuesday to succeed his friend and close ally Pope John Paul . Ratzinger,78, became Pope Benedict XVI, the 265th leader of the world's largest and most powerful Christian institution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PROMOTES 'READING 300' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for support for a "reading" promotion project launched by the Ministry of Education (MOE) to help disadvantaged children or those residing in remote areas enjoy the pleasure of books and reading.
Noting that books can offer knowledge and inspiration for young children, Chen said he hopes local parents can accompany their children in exploring the "wonderful world of reading."
Chen made the appeal in an article appearing in the latest edition of an online weekly that bears his nickname, "A-bian."

The president recalled that he took the initiative last June to help school children in remote regions discover the joys of reading. In line with his directive, Chen said, the MOE has since launched a "Reading 300" campaign aimed at recruiting volunteers to guide school children at 30 selected elementary schools in remote mountainous regions over three years to read books.

To the best of his understanding, Chen said, conscripts performing alternative service, retired school principals and teachers, housewives, college volunteers, and social group members have joined the project to accompany and guide disadvantaged children in exploring the pleasures of reading.

With the advent of the April 23 World Book Day, designated by UNESCO, Chen said the MOE will sponsor a "Book Is the Best Gift" campaign Friday to promote reading. The activity will include inviting 40 school children from remote regions to listen to stories at a Taipei bookstore and presenting awards to volunteer mothers who have devoted their leisure time to assisting disadvantaged school children in reading.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Polyclinics to close at night.
Polyclinics have decided their night clinics should call it a day, four years after they were started.
Night sessions have already been wound up at five polyclinics, and the two which still run them will stop next month, in Toa Payoh and Jurong.
Each sees about 140 patients a night at their 7pm to 9pm clinics.
The Lianhe Zaobao: SM Goh: Singapore has to change when the Middle East are inventing themselves in a big and bold way.
Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong yesterday lent his support to the integrated resorts with casinos and called Singaporeans to have faith in the Government's judgment and in their own strength.
Mr Goh mentioned Dubai and Qatar. Both places, which he visited recently, had hold plans to draw more tourists and grow their economies.
Dubai, already the aviation hub of the Middle East, is erecting the world's tallest building and largest shopping mall. Qatar is creating a man-made island four times the size Marina Center. They were not reinventing themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Church enters new era
VATICAN CITY (AFP) -- The Roman Catholic Church entered a new era yesterday after cardinals picked German conservative Joseph Ratzinger to guide its 1.1 billion followers, drawing praise around the world but also criticism from many quarters.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Stop paying nuke plant debt, SC justice urges gov't
Supreme Court Associate Justice Reynato Puno has urged the government to consider stopping payments for loans that the late strongman Ferdinand Marcos borrowed to build the mothballed Bataan Nuclear Power Plant.
The Philippine Star: GMA says Benedict XVI a 'continuing beacon' to faithful
President Arroyo led the nation in hailing the election of German Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger as Pope Benedict XVI, calling his appointment a "continuing beacon" for the country's faithful.
The Manila Times: Praise, skepticism greet new Pontiff
VATICAN CITY: Pope Benedict XVI pledged Wednesday to work to unify all Christians, reach out to other religions and continue implementing the Second Vatican Council as he outlined his goals and made clear his pontificate would follow closely the trajectory of his predecessor, Pope John Paul II.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Bush Picks Envoy to Iraq.
President Bush said he would appoint his United Nations envoy,John D. Negroponte,ambassador to Iraq after the formal end of U.S. military occupation on June 30,tapping a hardened career diplomat and troubleshooter to oversee the deep U.S. role in the country. (Lu-sheng Chu)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGED TO RAISE DEMOCRATIZATION ISSUES IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A Chinese dissident living in the United States recently issued a public letter, urging Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to raise questions regarding China's democratization while meeting with Beijing leaders during his upcoming visit to mainland China.
Lien will visit mainland China next week at the invitation of Chinese Communist Party Secretary General and Chinese President Hu Jintao.

According to a Voice of America report, Wang Dan, a former leader in the 1989 democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, said in the letter that he and other Chinese dissidents abroad would like to see any ideas and actions that would help reduce cross-Taiwan Strait tensions and promote democratic development on both sides of the strait.

The key problem in the cross-strait relationship is the different systems on the two sides, Wang said, stressing that the lack of democracy on the mainland is the main factor that has prevented the two sides from reuniting.
Wang said that if mainland China cannot democratize, then "the KMT's unification idea will remain unrealistic."

Since the KMT has an opportunity to hold face-to-face talks with the Chinese Communist Party, it has the responsibility to let the Beijing leaders realize the Taiwan people's hope to see democratization on the mainland, he added.
"I hope that Lien will not avoid raising the issue, otherwise, his visit to the mainland will be meaningless," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPPOSITION LEADERS' CHINA VISITS 'POSITIVE STEPS': OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department looks favorably on Taiwan opposition leaders' upcoming visits to China, deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said Wednesday.

Ereli made the remarks at a routine news briefing when asked about the State Department's views on the forthcoming visits to China by two Taiwan opposition heavyweights -- Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.
Generally speaking, Ereli said, the United States believes that dialogue is the best way to reduce tensions across the Taiwan Strait.
"We look favorably on and welcome steps in that direction. Recent travels to China by Taiwanese individuals are positive steps, " Ereli said.
Asked whether such visits could complicate cross-strait relations, Ereli said he wouldn't get into the politics of it because the politics of it is not the issue for the United States.
"The issue for us is people on both sides of the strait taking steps to come to understandings that are acceptable to both sides and that work to reduce tensions," Ereli added.

Chinese President Hu Jintao has invited Lien and Soong to visit China in his capacity as general secretary of the Communist Party of China. Lien is scheduled to depart Taipei April 26 for what he calls an eight-day "journey of peace" to the Chinese mainland. Soong is scheduled to travel to China in the first half of May.

U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall G. Schriver said Tuesday that Chinese leaders will ultimately have to talk with popularly elected leaders in Taiwan if they want their engagements with Taiwan's opposition figures to be productive.
"As we've said on the record before, our view is that on the margins, dialogue is better than no dialogue at all, and we think talking is better than not talking," Schriver pointed out.
Nevertheless, Schriver added that ultimately how these trips will be viewed will depend on a number of variables.

"Will this diplomacy be a mechanism for moving forward? Subsequently, will it contribute eventually to dialogue broader across the political spectrum in Taiwan? Or will it be limited to just reaching out to the opposition in the tensely divisive mood internally in Taiwan's domestic politics? We just don't know yet, " Schriver said.
"So we are watching this carefully. And genuinely, on the margins, we think, dialogue is better than no dialogue. And we'll see how this plays in Taiwan," he added..
Ultimately, Schriver continued, "for this to be productive for all parties, the leaders in Beijing will ultimately have to talk to elected leaders in Taiwan and the government that's in power."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Passenger Lists Sought For Flights Over U.S.
The U.S. government plans to force foreign airlines flying over American soil to turn over the names of passengers on board or check the names against U.S. government watch lists in an effort to prevent terrorists from entering U.S. airspace, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER QUITS TAIPEI COUNTY MAGISTRATE RACE TO SUPPORT COLLEAGUE

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) announced Thursday that he will withdraw from the KMT primary for the Taipei County magistrate election to throw his weight behind another strong contender.

KMT Legislator Lee Chia-chin made the announcement at a press conference jointly held by himself and Chou Hsi-wei, a legislator of the opposition People First Party (PFP) who recently returned to the KMT fold to boost his chances of winning the year-end election.
Lee noted that the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP has lost the Taipei County magistrate election the last four times, which he attributed mainly to the divisions within the alliance.

He said that he has had frequent contact with the "pan-blue's" grass-roots supporters recently and has learned that their biggest aspiration is to see the alliance win the Taipei County magistrate election.
After careful thought, Lee said, he has decided to withdraw from the race to "make the first move toward the solidarity of the 'pan-blue alliance.'"

Lee expressed his appreciation for his supporters, but said with emotion that "the battle has been fought" and that he hopes his withdrawal will contribute to the solidarity of the "pan-blue alliance."

He also lauded Chou as a talented person, saying that the two of them had developed a close relationship during the 2004 presidential election race when the KMT and PFP fielded a joint ticket and he was the KMT whip and Chou was the PFP whip.
Chou's election as magistrate would benefit Taipei County, Lee claimed, adding that he has promised to serve as Chou's campaign manager.
For his part, Chou said that Lee took the initiative to call him about withdrawing from the race due to concerns that bickering in the KMT primary might lead to divisions in the "pan-blue alliance."

Chou also said that Lee supports him because Lee thinks he has a better chance of winning the Taipei County magistrate. Noting that Lee had prepared for the election for quite some time, Chou said he admires Lee's courage for quitting the race now.

Meanwhile, another KMT aspirant for the Taipei County magistrate post, Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, said she is "perplexed" by Lee's abrupt announcement of withdrawal. Nevertheless, she added that she will continue to run in the race with a "spirit of sportsmanship."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGED TO REMOVE BAN ON XINHUA, PEOPLE'S DAILY REPORTERS

TEXT.P: Several opposition legislators on Thursday urged the government to reinstate permission for two Chinese news organizations to station staff in Taiwan.

Kuomintang Legislators Wu Ying-yi, Ker Chun-hsiuang and Chang Shou-wen, as well as Non-Partisan Solidarity Union Legislator Chang Li-shan made the appeal in the wake of Mainland Affairs Council's (MAC's) decision earlier this month to suspend permission for the state-run Xinhua news agency and the People's Daily newspaper from posting staff in Taiwan.

In making its decision, the MAC pointed to what it called the two organizations' focus on covering the most extreme elements in Taiwan's politics, which it said has not contributed to cross-strait understanding.
The legislators said in a press conference that press freedom is a universal value championed by President Chen Shui-bian and a value which "should not be compromised for any reason."

Hung Hsi-ming, president of the Taipei-based Chinese Senior Reporter Association, said the association regrets the MAC's decision, adding that the ban has hurt cross-strait journalistic exchanges and resulted in controversy in the international community.

The legislators echoed Hung's words, claiming that the MAC has been "backpedalling" in its approach to China, which they claimed has made the council a "laughing stock" in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU ASKS LIEN, SOONG TO RAISE 'FIVE NOES' WHILE MEETING WITH HU

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) raised a "five noes" proposal Thursday, asking two opposition leaders who will soon pay visits to mainland China separately not to forget to protect the interests of the people on Taiwan.

TSU legislative whip Lo Chih-ming urged Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to let Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao know how the people of Taiwan feel when the two meet Hu, also the Chinese president, in Beijing.

Reminding Lien and Soong that their social status and fame came from public support in Taiwan, Lo said that the two men should spell out the "five noes" to Hu: the people of Taiwan denounce Beijing's military threats, do not agree with its diplomatic blockade of Taiwan, do not accept its Anti-Secession Law, cannot accept its concept of the disputed "1992 consensus" and cannot condone its more than 700 missiles targeting Taiwan.

Although President Chen Shui-bian and Soong signed Feb. 24 a 10-point agreement promising to maintain the cross-Taiwan Strait status quo, Lo claimed that the Chen-Soong accord failed to help consolidate and forge a consensus in Taiwan society regarding Taiwan-China relations.

Asking Soong not to kowtow to Beijing regarding the 10-point Chen-Soong accord, TSU lawmakers wanted Soong to sign a pledge to vow that he will not recognize the "1992 consensus" before he leaves for China in early May.
Meanwhile, Lien has decided to visit China April 26 to May 3, a move that is expected to end the long-standing hostility between the KMT and the CPC that has existed over the last 70 years.

The TSU and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party form the pro-independence "pan green camp, " while the "pan blue alliance" of the KMT, the PFP and the New Party back maintaining the cross-strait status quo prior to eventual unification with a democratic China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION HEATS UP

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) held a draw Thursday to assign numerical designations to each of the various political parties and groups participating in the May 14 National Assembly election.
Seizing the opportunity to drum up support, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates chanted the slogan "everybody go, constitutional reform go go go" after the party drew No. 8.

DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang and senior presidential adviser Yeh Chu-lan, who tops the party's candidate list, presented a carnation garland to each DPP candidate and handed out carnations to onlookers to play up the party's campaign theme, namely "Carnation Constitutional Reform."

Not to be outdone, candidates of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, led by Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming, brought along the party's mascot -- an ant -- and promoted their bid to draft a new constitution and change the official name of the country.

Meanwhile, the Democratic Action Alliance staged a demonstration at the scene to express their opposition to what they called a "harebrained constitutional reform" and ask for a public debate on the issue.
The 300 seats for the ad hoc National Assembly will be allotted to the various parties and groups based on the proportion of votes they each garner in the upcoming election.

The mission of the National Assembly will be to consider a constitutional amendment package adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August. Items in the package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.

Also on Thursday, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan reaffirmed his party's support for the proposed amendments while presiding over the inauguration of a campaign mission for the election.

Lien insisted that amending the Constitution is the only way to achieve constitutional reform, saying the KMT opposes any attempts by any pro-independence groups to abolish the Constitution to create a new one.

In an effort to boost the voter turnout rate in the election, the CEC will hold a "lucky draw" for people who go to the polls. The top prize will be NT$1 million (US$31,556) in cash, while notebook computers will be given to three second prize winners. Other prizes up for grabs include five digital cameras, eight mobile phones, 10 translation machines and 15 MP3 players.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-SECESSION LAW NEARLY UNIVERSALLY CONDEMNED: EX-ROC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 20 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The international community is generally opposed to China's Anti-Secession Law, believing that it is not only a threat to Taiwan, but has also impacted regional peace, Liu Shih-feng, Republic of China visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution, a U.S. think tank, said Wednesday.

Liu, a former secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, made the remarks at a seminar on "Relations Across the Taiwan Strait: The Anti-Secession Law and Its Aftermath, " which was sponsored by the University of California at Los Angeles and the Asia Society's branch in southern California.

Liu said that since China's passage of the law, which codifies the use of force against Taiwan should it move formally to independence, the United States, Japan and Australia have expressed strong opposition to the legislation. Other countries in Asia and the European Union also disagree with the law, Liu added.

She cited the example of the EU, saying that some EU members who had originally wanted to lift the EU arms embargo against China have decided to delay taking such a move after Beijing's passage of the law and the strong opposition from the United States.

Liu also told participating U.S. scholars about a massive march in Taiwan on March 26, in which hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets to express their displeasure over the law, and the Legislative Yuan also passed a resolution to oppose it.

Beijing's defense budget increasing at a double-digit rate in recent years is a clear indication that the threat to Taiwan is growing, Liu said. In addition, Beijing has always adopted two-pronged tactics, using the rivalry between the ruling and the opposition parties to drive a wedge within the island.

Liu cited as an example how Beijing has recently overlooked the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to talk directly with opposition parties, which is an attempt to force President Chen Shui-bian to come to terms with its cherished "one China" principle.
She said that opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan has been opposed to President Chen for years, and has not recognized the ruling position of President Chen and the DPP.

For this reason, when Lien goes to China next Tuesday for a visit at the invitation of Chinese leaders, he will only "represent himself, " adding that his words and deeds will not stand for Taiwan or the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REGULATE PRODUCTS CONTAINING TRICLOSAN

TEXT.P: A draft bill on a national standard of products containing triclosan will be unveiled in August and put into practice next February, the Consumers Protection Committee under the Executive Yuan announced Thursday.

The announcement came after research in the United Stats showed that antibacterial chemical triclosan, which has been widely used in toothpastes, deodorants, liquid hand soap and detergents, could combine with additional chlorine in tap water and increase the risks of cancer after long-term use.

To put consumers at ease, the committee has invited the Department of Health (DOH), and the Bureau of Standards, Meteorology and Inspection under the Ministry of the Economic Affairs (MOEA) to meet and come to a consensus.

The DOH will provide professional views on the safety level of triclosan by the end of May. The MOEA will then work out a draft bill on a national standard of products containing triclosan by the end of July.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Rice Conveys Criticism and Praise.
U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on Wednesday mixed criticism of the Kremlin's record on democracy with praise for Russia's commitment to the war on terrorism and on nuclear nonproliferation on the second day of her visit to Moscow. Rice started her day by giving interviews to NTV television and Ekho Moskvy radio before meeting with President Vladimir Putin in the Kremlin and giving an upbeat assessment of U.S.-Russian cooperation on security and other issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFLUENCE OF DUST, SAND STORM OVER TAIWAN DIMINISHES

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Thursday revised Taiwan's air quality outlook after the influence of a dust and sand storm diminished.

The EPA issued an alert on worsening air quality on April 19 in the wake of the invasion of pollutants from a dust and sand storm occurring a day earlier in Mongolia and China's Inner Mongolia region, with air quality expected to remain unhealthful all over Taiwan until April 22.

However, EPA forecasters said thanks to Wednesday's rain showers, the influence of the dust and sand storm has spared most parts of the island with the exception of northern Taiwan as of Thursday and is expected to dissolve completely later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were generally higher on Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May moved up nine points to close at 5,688, with 44,013 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June rose four points to finish at 5,680, with 196 contract transactions, while September futures gained 13 points to close at 5,545, with 226 contracts traded.
December futures moved up 26 points to finish at 5,559, with six contracts traded, while March futures dropped 243 points to close at 5,552, with only one contract traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,679 for May, 5,676 for June, 5,532 for September, 5,533 for December, and 5,795 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.
May TE futures increased 0.35 points to close at 220.8, with 6,221 contract transactions, while June TE futures lost 0.2 points to finish at 220, with 16 contracts traded.
September TE futures dropped 1.65 points to finish at 218.9, with one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures moved up 12 points to close at 915, with 9,462 contract transactions, while June TF futures rose 14.2 points to finish at 915.6, with 26 contracts changing hands.
September TF futures rose 8.4 points to close at 907.4, with 16 contracts traded, while December TF futures rose 6.4 points to close at 910, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN SHOULD MEET WITH PRESIDENT PRIOR TO CHINA VISIT: POLL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should meet with President Chen Shui-bian prior to his departure for a historic visit to China, according to a majority of respondents to a recent survey, said pollsters Thursday.

The survey of 1,117 adults was conducted April 11-12 to explore local people's opinions about the latest developments in the situation across the Taiwan Strait. The findings will be presented to Cabinet members for reference in policy formulation.

According to the poll results, 58.8 percent said they thought that Lien should meet with President Chen prior to his China visit and discuss themes of his agenda; only 19.1 percent said they were opposed to such a proposal.

A cross analysis of the survey findings showed that even among the "pan-blue alliance" supporters, proponents of the proposal outnumbered opponents, 49.7 percent to 34.6 percent; the ratio even reached 59.2 percent among those without party affiliations or preferences. The "pan-blue alliance," referring to the KMT and its two splinter groups -- the People First Party and the New Party, advocates a more conciliatory approach toward China and wants Taiwan's eventual unification with a democratic China.

Among the 740 respondents who said they were aware of KMT Vice Chairman P. K. Chiang's March 28 to April 1 visit to China without prior consultations with the government and his signing of a 10-point consensus with Beijing authorities, 59.7 percent said they felt that Chiang's moves were inappropriate, compared to 21.9 percent who supported Chiang.
Meanwhile, 46.2 percent said they supported prosecution authorities' probes into Chiang's moves to determine whether they broke any existing laws, but 36.1 percent disagreed with any judicial probes.

Lien, heading a large KMT delegation, is scheduled to depart for what he bills as a "journey of peace" to China April 26. He will be the first KMT chairman ever to visit China since the party, which once ruled all of China, retreated to Taiwan after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese Communists in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 28.98 points to close at 5,721.99.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 5,565.41 and hit a high of 5,725.48 during trading. A total of 2.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.63 billion (US$2.01 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 3.7 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 1.3 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.
Three other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 0.6 percent, textile stocks at 0.2 percent and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 526 to 320, with 161 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV PLATFORM PRESENTATION FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION SET FOR MAY 7

TEXT.P: A televised platform presentation of 12 political parties and groups participating in the May 14 National Assembly election will be held on May 7, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Thursday.
CEC officials also said that there will be only one TV platform presentation, and there will be no public debates.
THe CEC held a draw to assign numerical designations to each of the political parties and groups participating in the election earlier of the day.
The 300 seats for the mission-oriented National Assembly will be allocated to the various parties and groups based on the proportion of votes they each garner in the upcoming election.

The mission of the ad hoc National Assembly will be to consider a constitutional amendment package adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August. The items in the package include cutting the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113, changing the electoral system from the current "multiple seats" to a "single seat, two votes" system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL COUNCIL OF NURSES' 2005 CONGRESS TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The 23rd Quadrennial Congress 2005 of the International Council of Nurses (ICN) will be held in Taipei May 22-27, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Chiang Kuo-chiang, vice chairman of MOFA'S NGO Affairs Committee, said the ministry will offer assistance to the Taiwan Nurses Association, the organizer of the event, to facilitate the holding of the conference, in which some 3,000 nursing experts from more than 120 countries will attend.

Chiang noted that as the ICN and World Health Organization have maintained cooperative ties, the holding of ICN's 23rd Quadrennial Congress in Taipei signifies the recognition by the world community of the contributions of Taiwan's medical care system.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Secret loans bolster Â£16m Tory election campaign.
The Electoral Commission announced an investigation last night into the principle of parties using secret multimillion-pound loans from rich benefactors to bankroll election campaigns. The commission acted after learning from The Times that a number of Â£1 million-plus loans have been secured by Tory treasurers to bolster the party's Â£ 16 million fighting fund.
Financial Times: CBI warns Labour on plans to raise taxes.
Labour's plans to increase rates on business could seriously undermine companies' confidence in the government, the CBI has suggested. The intervention by the employers' body reflects mounting concern that the corporate sector may bear the brunt of tax rises in the next parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HAS 'CERTAIN RESPONSIBILITIES' TO HELP TAIWAN'S DEFENSE: RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said in a recent interview with CNN in Moscow that the United States has certain responsibilities under the Taiwan Relations Act to help Taiwan defend itself if it is attacked.
Rice gave the interview with Jill Dougherty of CNN during her visit in Moscow Wednesday.
In the interview, Dougherty asked Rice whether the United States has expressed some concern about Russia's arms sales to China.
In response, Rice said the United States is certainly concerned about any efforts or any policies that lead to increased Chinese military capabilities in the Asia-Pacific region.
"Taiwan is obviously an issue here, because the United States has certain responsibilities under the Taiwan Relations Act to help Taiwan defend itself if it's attacked, " Rice said.
She further said the U.S. government has talked to the Russians about this.

"We've talked especially about the need to recognize the balance of power issues, the balance of forces issues in the Asia-Pacific region. And I might just note that Russia itself, of course, is a Pacific power and should have similar concerns about what could happen to the military balance in the region if Chinese military modernization continues apace," she added.
Russia is China's key weapons supplier.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP MISSION TO GO TO CHINA SATURDAY TO ARRANGE CHAIRMAN'S VISIT

TEXT.P: A People First Party (PFP) mission led by Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng is expected to leave for mainland China this coming Saturday to arrange for a visit by party chairman James Soong, a key party official said Thursday.

Chang Hsien-yao, director of the PFP's Policy Center, who is currently in Beijing to exchange views with Communist Party of China (CPC) officials regarding Soong's planned visit slated for early May, told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview that he fully sensed the CPC's goodwill and sincerity and added that the PFP group should be able to go to China Saturday.
The CPC has expressed the hope to get a better understanding of Soong's viewpoints on Taiwan-China relations, he said.

PFP spokesman Hsieh Kung-ping said a day earlier that the PFP has never deviated from its stance regarding the cross-Taiwan Strait relationship that advocates "no war, no Taiwan independence and maintaining the status quo of the Republic of China."
According to PFP officials, Soong will not act as an envoy for President Chen Shui-bian or relay any messages from Chen when he meets CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing.
Soong is likely to discuss practical issues regarding agriculture, security and direct trade, transport and postal links with CPC officials, they said.

Apart from Soong, main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will also travel to China April 26 through May 3 for a what the KMT terms a "journey of peace, " during which he will make stops in Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai.

Lien's anticipated meeting with Hu, who is also the Chinese president, on April 29 is set to be a historic and prominent contact between the two rival political parties since 1949, when the KMT troops were defeated by the Chinese Communists on the mainland and retreated to Taiwan.
The upcoming China visits by Lien and Soong, both at the invitation of Hu, comes at a time when cross-strait ties are at their lowest level in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAPES CULTIVATED UNDER POWER-SAVING LIGHTS SAVE MONEY FOR GROWERS

TEXT.P: Grapes that will grow in commercial quantities in greenhouses under artificial power-saving lights have been successfully developed by the Taichung District Agricultural Improvement Station, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Thursday.

Technology used in the indoor cultivation of grapes, developed by the COA' s Taichung station and claimed to be the first of its kind in the world, has enabled Taiwan grape growers to produce the delicious fruit almost all year round, as opposed to only one harvest a year as in most other countries, COA Taichung station researchers said.

In addition to using fluorescent, power-saving lights at the greenhouses, the COA researchers have also adopted other botanical technologies, including tree-by-tree pruning and germination, to adjust and shorten the grape trees' production period.

According to the researchers, production of grapes from greenhouses where no artificial lighting was provided averages about 600 to 700 kilograms from each quarter acre of land, but the production can be increased to 800 to 1,000 kilograms if additional lights are used.
Until recently, many grape growers, mostly in central Taiwan, have still been using mercury lamps during winter in their grape greenhouses, which use a great deal of electricity.

However, according to the researchers, using fluorescent or power-saving lights can cut costs significantly -- by 30 percent to 50 percent -- consequently helping lower the growers' production overhead.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER ASKS LIEN TO CLARIFY HIS AMBIGUOUS STATUS BEFORE TRIP

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator challenged opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Thursday to specify if he is visiting China as a civilian or as a retired vice president.
According to Chen Chao-lung, Lien had previously said that as a civilian, it was unnecessary for him to report to the government on his China trip.
Chen argued that if what Lien said is true, he should not be allowed the escort of armed security officers during the trip.

Lien is set to visit China from April 26 to May 3, during which he is expected to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao. Beijing reportedly has agreed to allow Lien to bring with him a team of armed security officers.

Hsu Li-meng, executive director of the National Security Bureau's special service center, said the center provides security protection for retired presidents and vice presidents and that there have been past precedents for the retired leaders to visit foreign countries under the escort of security officers.
As a privilege for the retired leaders, the destination countries have permitted these security officers to bring along their guns, according to Hsu.
In this case, Lien's security officers have to file an application with the Ministry of the Interior for permission because they are going to China, Hsu noted.
If the application is approved by the ministry, it will mark the first time security officers from Taiwan have been allowed to visit China, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.028 to close at NT$31.541.
A total of US$900 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$31.513 and fluctuated between NT$31.440 and NT$31.541.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN CO-DEVELOP X-RAY FABRY-PEROT RESONATOR

TEXT.P: National Tsing Hua University announced Thursday that it has worked with National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center and Japanese synchrotron radiation facility Spring-8 to develop a X-ray Fabry-Perot resonator.
S. L. Chang, dean of the College of Science of Tsing Hua University, who presided over the research program, said that the development will be a landmark in related research in Taiwan.

Chang said that the results of the research will be published May 13 in the journal "Physical Review Letter, " and that U.S. Physics Society is considering reporting it in "Physics Today, " "Physical Review Focus," and related physics magazines.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND ROUND TAIWAN-GUATEMALA FTA TALKS TO BEGIN ON APRIL 25

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Guatemala are to convene their second round of negotiations concerning the signing of the free trade agreement (FTA) April 25-29 in Guatemala, officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

According to MOEA officials, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will head Taiwan's negotiation team, and both sides are expected to reach a consensus on most of the topics at this round of talks.

MOEA officials noted that representatives will be divided into several divisions, including market access, service industry and investments, regulations and procedures, as well as cooperation for further discussions.

The two sides are expected to focus on topics that were not agreed upon at the previous round of talks, including national treatment, rule of origin, dispute settlements, safeguard measures, service industry and investments.
Other topics, including tariff cuts on agricultural and industrial products, and the negative list for the opening of the service industry, will also be discussed at the meeting.

MOEA statistics show that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Panama totaled US$269.36 million last year, a growth of 112 percent over the previous year, following the signing of the FTA between the two countries in January 2004.
The officials expressed the hope that Taiwan and Guatemala can complete soon their FTA talks to further strengthen bilateral economic and trade ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN TO TELEPHONE PRESIDENT CHEN APRIL 25 ON CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will be receiving a phone call from opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan April 25 for talks on cross-strait relations, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung announced Thursday.

The Lien-Chen telephone conversation, scheduled to be held exactly beginning at 4:10 p.m. next Monday, is apparently a response from the KMT leadership to President Chen, who has repeatedly called for Lien to meet him or at least call him before the latter embarks on a historic trip to China, slated for April 26.

Lien will be the first KMT chairman to set foot on Chinese soil in more than five decades since the KMT lost a civil war to the Communist Party of China and withdrew to Taiwan in 1949. He is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing April 29.

According to Chang, the schedule of the forthcoming telephone conversation has been arranged after Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun exchanged views with KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng earlier Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAKE CREDIT CARD NUMBERS FALL TO FOUR-YEAR LOW: VISA

TEXT.P: The number of fake VISA credit cards in Taiwan plunged to a four-year low of 0.04 percent in December 2004, from a high of 0.34 percent at the end of 2000, according to a recent report by VISA International Service Association.
According to a VISA executive, the number of counterfeit VISA cards in Taiwan decreased sharply in the past four years, making Taiwan the best example in clamping down on card forgery.

Taiwan's fake card rate still stood at 0.34 percent at the end of 2000, triple the average in the Asia-Pacific region, while the value of losses incurred from transactions with doctored cards also slid by 83 percent, the VISA executive noted, praising Taiwan for outshining other countries in the region by making the most outstanding progress in countering forged cards.

He said that VISA will continue cooperating with Taiwan's card-issuing banks and the police to further step up smart card payment security in stores and wipe out counterfeiting, despite the fact that the Taiwan credit card market is quite mature and strong in terms of risk management.

To achieve the goal, VISA has started to introduce EMV VISA cards around the world, with the number of multi-application, multi-purpose chip cards having reached 3 million in Taiwan as of the end of 2004, a rise from around 1 million in the middle of that year, a VISA Taiwan executive said.

For the time being, nearly all VISA member banks in Taiwan have had their franchise stores install reading machines certificated by VISA and based on EMV specifications to secure a safer payment environment, VISA statistics show.
VISA forecast that the number of transactions made with EMV VISA cards in Taiwan will grow to 5 million per month in 2005, well up from the current monthly level of 2 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGED TO DESCRIBE TAIWAN AS INDEPENDENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should clearly state to Chinese leaders that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are independent of each other during his upcoming visit to China, the nation's top China policy charter said Thursday.

The statement, issued in a news release by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , was in response to Lien's remarks the previous day that he will use the phrase "separate rule" to describe the present status between the two sides of the strait.

The MAC noted that China's recently enacted Anti-Secession Law clearly states that Taiwan is part of China and that Taiwan can enjoy a high degree of autonomy under the "one country, two systems" formula.

Lien also said Feb. 17, 2000 when he was vice president that the "special state-to-state" cross-strait relations conform with the de jure "separate rule, independent" reality of both sides of the strait, the MAC said.
If Lien advocates only "separate rule" during his April 26-May 3 visit to China, he will fall into Beijing's cherished "one China" trap, according to the MAC.

If Lien does not clearly state that the Republic of China is an sovereign, independent state and that its sovereignty belongs to the 23 million people of the country, and that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are under separate rule and independent of each other, then "it will undermine the national sovereignty of the Republic of China," the statement said.

The MAC said that since President Chen Shui-bian first assumed the presidency in 2000, he has promoted cross-strait relations under the principles of peace and development, and his stance has always been insistence on a sovereign, independent ROC.

The MAC stressed that the Taiwan people want cross-strait peace with dignity and that they strongly oppose China's use of the Anti-Secession Law as an excuse to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan.
It expressed the hope that any political figures visiting China will express unequivocally to the Chinese leadership the mainstream public opinion in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT CONTACT KEY TO CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff urged China Thursday to open government-to-government contact across the Taiwan Strait to boost bilateral exchanges.
Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, made the call ahead of visits to China by two opposition leaders at the invitation of Chinese President Hu Jintao.

At the beginning of this year, Yu said, the two sides had friendly engagements, including the opening of non-stop cross-strait charter flights during the Chinese New Year holiday and the arrival of three Chinese officials to attend the funeral of the late Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
However, Yu said, the amicable atmosphere faded after China's enactment of its anti-secession law that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.
Since the enactment of that legislation, cross-strait relations have been stalled, Yu said, adding that Taiwan does not like this retreat or setback in cross-strait engagements.
If China has goodwill and sincerity, Yu said, it should immediately start government-to-government consultations.

"Government-to-government contact is the right way for cross-strait engagements and only by so doing can cross-strait exchanges, peace, reciprocity and cooperation make headway for mutual benefits," Yu said, adding that official cross-strait engagements are the core of regional and international concerns about the developments in the Taiwan Strait.

If China insists on ignoring Taiwan's ruling party while engaging its opposition parties, Yu said, this will not only cause divisions in local society but will also draw different opinions from the international community.

For instance, U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall G. Schriver said Tuesday that the Chinese leadership will ultimately have to talk with popularly elected leaders in Taiwan if they want their engagements with Taiwan's opposition figures to be productive.

Hu has invited opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong to visit China, separately, in his capacity as general secretary of the Communist Party of China. Lien, a former vice president of the Republic of China, is scheduled to depart for what he bills as a "journey of peace" to China April 26, while Soong plans to visit China in the first half of May.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL GROUPS TO PROVIDE FREE SERVICES IN DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan medical groups are scheduled to depart for the Dominican Republic Friday to provide week-long free medical services to people in the Central American ally of the Republic of China.

Some 20 doctors, nurses and pharmacists with the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps and the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation of Taiwan are scheduled to stay at the Taiwan Hospital -- the first medical institution that the Republic of China government built for the Dominican people -- located in a rural township some 4 hours from capital Santo Domingo, said Liu Chi-hsiang, chairman of the Taiwan Roots Medical Peace Corps.
During their stay, the two groups will treat some 50 patients with harelips as well as burn victims, said Liu, who visited the country last August with another Taiwan Roots mission.

The two groups are making the trip at the invitation of ROC Ambassador to the Dominican Republic John Feng, who was largely instrumental in making possible the establishment of the Taiwan Hospital, which became operational April 1.
According to officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Dominican Republic relies almost entirely on imports for its medication needs and medical care standards are generally low nationwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Pope May Color Debate in U.S. Over 'Life' Issues Like Abortion.
The election of an unstintingly conservative pope could inject a powerful new force into the intense conflicts in American politics over abortion and other social issues, which put many Catholic elected officials at odds with their church. Pope Benedict XVI ascends to power at a tumultuous time for his church in American politics: Catholic voters, long overwhelmingly Democratic, have become a critical swing vote. Republicans have become increasingly successful at winning the support of more traditional Catholics by appealing to what President Bush calls the "culture of life" issues, including abortion, euthanasia and research on embryonic stem cells. Bush carried 56 percent of the white Catholic vote in 2004, up from 51 percent in 2000 - a formidable part of his conservative coalition.
Wall Street Journal: Cram Sessions, For High Schoolers, Summer Is High Time to Polish Resumes.
Getting into America's elite colleges has neverbe en tougher, and now, in addition to grades and test scores, essays, recommendations and class rank, there's this for teens and their parents to worry about: summer. "Summers are import ant, big time, " says Lloyd Peterson, vice president of College Coach LLC, which charges $3,499 for its college-counseling services. "The more prestigious the school, the more important the summers are." A record 16.7 million students are expected to enroll in college next fall, 1.2 million more than five years ago. The U.S. education department expects up to 18.8 million enrollees eight years from now. At the same time, ambitious high-school students are loading up on advanced-placement classes and taking prep courses to boost their scores on college-admissions tests, heightening the competition. With the glut of high-scoring applicants, colleges are paying closer attention to factors such as community service, artistic talent, leadership -- and summers. "There's more demand than we can accommodate at the selective institutions. What do you do? You need some tie-breakers, " says Barmak Nassirian of the American Association of Collegiate Registrars and Admissions Officers, a Washington, D.C., trade group.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS IN MARCH REACH RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers reached a record high of US$20.89 billion in March, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday.
MOEA officials attributed the growth mainly to the stable economic recovery in Europe, the United States and several Asian countries.
Cumulatively, the value of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers in the first quarter totalled US$55.51 billion, a growth of 20.13 percent over the same period of last year.
In March, the value of export orders received from Hong Kong -- one of the major outlets for Taiwan products -- reached US$5.07 billion, also a record high.

Among the export items, electronic products registered a US$610 million growth in March on a year-on-year basis, while the transport equipment increased by US$540 million, thanks to several big orders received by China Shipbuilding Corp.
MOEA officials estimated that export orders received in the second quarter will also enjoy double-digit growth over the same period of last year.

Meanwhile, the results of a recent survey show that 27.26 percent of the manufacturers polled believed that export orders will increase in April, while 23.26 percent thought orders will decrease, with 49.48 percent believing that export prospects will remain the same.

Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, noted that China's plan to cool off its economy and its just promulgated Anti-Secession Law, as well as the prosperity of the American market, will be the factors affecting Taiwan's exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ISSUE SHOULD BE SOLVED BY FOUR COUNTRIES: EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui accused two opposition leaders who are set to visit China of "trying to connive with China to sell out Taiwan" Thursday, arguing that the Taiwan issue should be solved by the United States, Japan, China and Taiwan rather than by talks between Chinese leaders and the two opposition figures.

Flanked by groups of pro-independence activists, Lee told a news conference that the planned trips to China by Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong and their expected meetings with Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing are wrong in regard of time, place and form.

Lee, who served as president and KMT chairman concurrently between 1988 and 2000, claimed that the Taiwan issue is an international issue and its solution depends on international talks involving Taiwan, China, United States and Japan and in a place other than Beijing -- preferably the United States.
Talks in Beijing about the Taiwan issue, such as the ones to take place between Lien and Hu and Soong and Hu, will only result in Taiwan's annexation by China, Lee claimed without elaborating.

Furthermore, the timing of the trips, slated for late this month and early next month, respectively, is especially inappropriate in light of China's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law March 14 that provides the legal basis for use of force against Taiwan.

Their visits will send the wrong message to the world that Taiwan people who rallied in Taipei March 26 to protest against the Anti-Secession Law do not really care about the Chinese threat, according to Lee.
He added that any talks with China should be conducted by the government rather than political parties.
He claimed that Lien and Soong are ignoring the country's dignity and people's interests, and risking national security, and called on President Chen Shui-bian to stop them.

Noting that the government is investigating KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang for reaching a consensus with Chinese officials during a visit he made to Beijing in March, Lee urged the government to serve justice rapidly in Chiang's case, which will deter other politicians from following suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SHOULD PROTEST AGAINST CHINA'S ANTI-SECESSION LAW: ANALYST

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan should bring to the attention of Chinese President Hu Jintao the concerns of the Taiwan people, particularly the deleterious effects that the Anti-Secession Law created, a leading Taiwan think tank members said Thursday.

Lai Yi-chung, the director of Taiwan Thinktank's International Department said Lien should take the chance to protest against China's Anti-Secession Law and its practice of forcing Taiwan businessmen operating in China to rally behind Beijing in its dispute with Taipei.
Also, Lai said, Lien should explain to his Taiwan compatriots his stance on Beijing's "one China" principle before he heads for China on May 26.

No one will oppose what the KMT claims to be Lien's "journey for peace, " Lai said, but Lien owes his people an explanation about his view of Taiwan-China relations and dispel any doubts about his tour.

He dismissed Lien's trip as only a political attempt by the KMT to bring itself back into the center of the political arena after being sidelined by the reconciliation of People First Party Chairman James Soong and President Chen Shui-bian.

However, Lien's attempts were foiled in this regard because Hu Jintao followed his invitation to Lien with a similar invitation to Soong, whose trip is sure to outshine that of Lien's because he will convey to Beijing leaders a 10-point consensus he reached with President Chen during a Feb. 24 meeting, Lai went on.
Compared with Soong's planned trip, Lien's tour of China will be much less significant, Lai claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT'S OPINIONS UNDERSTOOD: PRESIDENTIAL AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has heard former President Lee Teng-hui's comments on the forthcoming visits to China by two opposition leaders and will heed Lee's opinions in the same way he respects all the diverse opinions from every sector of the country, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Noting that Taiwan is a free democracy where the people enjoy freedom of speech, Yu said that as the head of state and a "balancer of diverse voices, " Chen has listened to Lee with sincerity.

When asked by reporters whether there will be a meeting between Chen and Lee in the near future, Yu said that Chen and Lee used to maintain "smooth" channels of communication, but added that he had no idea whether the two will meet again soon.

Lee fired a broadside Thursday at opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- who are scheduled to embark on visits to China April 26 and early May, respectively -- calling them "traitors to Taiwan."
Lee urged Chen to regulate Lien and Soong squarely by exercising governmental authority.
The former president also called for "four-nation talks" -- among leaders from the Untied States, Japan, China and Taiwan -- to help solve the Taiwan issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER TO BE ROC ENVOY TO NEW POPE'S INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan will head an official delegation to attend Pope Benedict XVI's inauguration mass at the Vatican Sunday, Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
"President Chen Shui-bian has named Su to head the delegation to offer felicitations to the new pope on behalf of our country and the president himself," Yu told a news conference.
In addition to Su, the delegation members will also include Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Ou-Yang Jui-hsiung and Republic of China Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng.
Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo, the Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
Chen traveled to the Vatican earlier this month to attend the late Pope John Paul II's April 8 funeral, making him the first serving ROC head of state to set foot in Europe.

Due to Chen's busy schedule, Yu said, the president cannot travel to the Vatican to attend the inauguration ceremony. He is scheduled to visit two of the ROC's South Pacific allies -- the Marshall Islands and Kiribati -- later this month.
As the Ministry of the Interior is in charge of religious affairs, Yu said, Chen decided to name Su to head the ROC delegation to the inauguration.
Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, 78, was elected new pope Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION INDEX TO SHOW SLIGHT GROWTH IN Q2

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials estimated Thursday that Taiwan's manufacturing production will show slight growth in the second quarter following a decrease recorded in the first quarter.

MOEA statistics show that the industrial production index stood at 130.38 in March, a drop of 0.78 percent over the same month of last year, while the manufacturing production index was 134.40, a decrease of 0.77 percent on a year-to-year basis.

Cumulatively, the industrial production index in the first three months stood at 119.58, a decrease of 0.62 percent over the same period of last year, while the manufacturing production registered a negative annual drop of 1.19 percent.

Chang Yaw-tzong, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department, noted that the decrease in March manufacturing production was mainly because of the less-than-expected global economic prospects, especially in the United States, Japan and Europe.

He also predicted that Taiwan's foreign trade will be slightly affected in the second quarter as the United Nations and several organizations have readjusted downward global economic growth for this year, and international oil prices and the U.S. dollar are unstable amid increasing interest rates around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GIVES CONDITIONAL GREENLIGHT TO KMT HEAD'S CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will support opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China on two conditions, Presidential Chief of Staff Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.

Yu said he contacted KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng earlier in the day to tell him that Chen will support Lien's trip if he can meet two conditions -- if he can engage with China, "pragmatically, for mutual benefit and on an equal-footing " and "for the purpose of serving and defending the supreme interest of the people and nation."
Yu said the president would like to see Lien before his trip, but would settle for a phone call because of Lien's tight schedule before his April 26 departure.

Chen, who once claimed that opposition party leaders' proposed talks with China's are illegal, asked Lien to consult his opinion before embarking on his tour in exchange for the president's support for the visit. Lien has so far not bothered to take advantage of the offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA HAS BETTER INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT THAN CHINA: INDIAN OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: With a 100-year history in terms of its private corporate development, India is a better destination than China for Taiwanese investment, an Indian official based in Taiwan claimed Thursday.

Addressing a Taipei seminar on investment and trade in India, India-Taipei Association Director-General Vijay Gokhale noted that India has a vast potential market with a middle-class population of 150 million that is expected to grow to 300 million by 2009.
Compared with China, India enjoys more advantages because the policies of the Indian government are stable and its direction is clear, Gokhale said.

While the two major political parties in India both agree that economic openness is the only path for the country, the trade openness policy has remained unchanged since its implementation in 1993, Gokhale pointed out.
In addition, he went on, the industrial sectors of Taiwan and India complement each other. For example, Taiwan is a major supplier of machinery in the world and can meet India's demands, he said.
According to Gokhale, the soaring international oil prices and the rise of the Indian currency have not impacted the country's imports and exports.
India has signed a free trade agreement (FTA) with Thailand and is currently holding FTA talks with Singapore and China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB CHIEF VOWS TO FIND MORE EVIDENCE FOR '319' SHOOTING

TEXT.P: The special law enforcement team investigating the shooting of President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the 2004 presidential election is still striving to secure more evidence to substantiate its claim that a man found dead was the shooter, a senior official said Thursday.
Hou You-yi, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB), made the remarks after attending a meeting of the special investigative team at the Tainan City Police Bureau in southern Taiwan.
Noting that investigative work has approached the final stage, Hou said the special team has not been daunted by criticism about its identification last month of Chen Yi-hsiung as the shooter.
Hou said the team has been working in the right direction. "We have been tracing the suspect by pinpointing the source of the two homemade bullets found at the crime scene," he said.

Because Chen Yi-hsiung is dead, many people have said the team's claim is not convincing. However, Hou claimed it is a fact. He said the team has continued to work hard to find more evidence to prove its claim and clarify suspicious points.
Chen Yi-hsiung, 63, was found dead in Anping harbor in the southern city of Tainan March 29 last year -- 10 days after the shooting.

President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu were slightly wounded when two homemade bullets grazed them as they campaigned in an open-topped jeep in Tainan March 19, 2004. After the Chen-Lu ticket narrowly won re-election the following day, the sole challenging ticket of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong accused the president of having staged the shooting to win sympathy votes and filed two lawsuits to challenge the election result. The shooting is believed to have gravely aggravated hostility between the ruling and opposition camps.
After nearly a year of grueling investigations, the investigative team announced a breakthrough early last month by identifying Chen Yi-hsiung as the shooter in the apparent assassination attempt.

Three investigative team members traveled to the United States early this month to seek renowned Chinese-American forensic expert Dr. Henry Lee's counsel about certain problems regarding the investigations.

Lee was quoted as having told the trio that they should further investigate the cause of Chen Yi-hsiung's death because the data collected by the team so far is not sufficient to conclude that Chen Yi-hsiung, a former chairman of the Tainan City Wrestling Association, committed suicide 10 days after he allegedly shot and slightly wounded Chen and Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS' PLANNED CHINA TRIPS CRITICIZED

TEXT.P: Some 100 pro-Taiwan independence groups issued a joint statement Thursday criticizing opposition leaders' planned visits to China for trying to connive with China to sell out the nation.

Taiwan Society North Chairman Wu Shu-min read the statement at a news conference jointly called by former President Lee Teng-hui and the 100 groups formed by pro-independence activists on the planned visits to China by Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.
Lien is scheduled to leave April 26 for an eight-day visit, while Soong plans to travel in early May.
Neither Lien nor Soong are entitled to represent either the people or the government of Taiwan in talks with the Chinese authorities because they are not in power, the statement notes.
Also, it goes on, any statement or move that puts Taiwan under the "one-China" principle is abandoning its sovereignty and is not acceptable to the people of Taiwan.

It is inappropriate for any political leaders to hold talks with the Chinese authorities at the moment, as Beijing enacted its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan not long ago, the statement adds, explaining that holding talks with Beijing now will mislead the international community into believing that the people of Taiwan have accepted the law that authorizes the Chinese authorities to use non-peaceful means in dealing with Taiwan.

The statement also urges the government to exercise its authority and deal with Lien's visit and to look into KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's recent visit to China to ascertain whether there has been a possible violation of the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER REBUTS EX-PRESIDENT'S CALL FOR TALKS ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui should not expect the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to do what even the government cannot do, KMT lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao said Thursday.

Lai, who is the deputy secretary of the KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks in response to Lee's call earlier in the day that the issue between Taiwan and China should be settled in an international conference involving the two parties, the United States and Japan rather than through talks between Taiwan's opposition leaders and Chinese president Hu Jintao.
Lee's call was intended to stop KMT Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong from visiting China to talk with the Chinese leadership.
Lai said Lee should practice what he preached during his presidency from 1988 to 2000, adding that if he could not do it, he should not expect the KMT, which is only an opposition party, to do it.

The KMT lawmaker said Beijing always claims that the Taiwan issue is an internal affair and resists any efforts to discuss the question in an international context and he pointed out that there is no indication that it has changed its position.

Saying that Lee resorted to secret contacts with China through emissaries during his term as president, Lai said Lien's proposed engagement with the Chinese leadership under the public eye will be much better.
Meanwhile, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), embraced Lee's call.

DPP lawmaker William Lai, the DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, said his caucus supports Lee's call, especially his claims that Lien's and Soong's trips are wrong with regard to their timing, place and form.

But he disagreed with Lee's criticism of the government that it is failing in its duty by not stopping Lien and Soong from making the trips, arguing that the law does not give government the power to prevent crimes that have not yet been committed.

Lawmaker Mark M. H. Ho of the opposition TSU, which considers Lee as its "spiritual leader, " echoed Lee's call for an international conference, claiming that it is the only way to solve Taiwan's disputes with China once and for all.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 22, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo-huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."
