DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT DIALOGUE BEST WAY TO SOLVE CROSS-STRAIT PROBLEMS: STATE DEP'T
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. State Department press officer said Thursday that the United States considers that direct dialogue is the best way to solve problems between Taiwan and China.

Deputy spokesman Adam Ereli made the remarks at a press briefing in response to questions regarding former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's suggestion that the United States would be a better place to hold a cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue.
Lee said the same day that cross-strait problems should be resolved with the international community taking part since such problems are issues related to world peace.
Saying that he is not aware whether the suggestion is being actively considered in the United States, Ereli, however, reiterated Washington's stance of pushing for direct cross-strait dialogue.

"I think certainly the United States, by its public stance and in its dealings with officials on both sides of the strait, has made it clear that we believe that direct dialogue between them is the best way to resolve the tensions, and that obviously we'd welcome steps by both sides that contribute to that end," he said.

The deputy spokesman also said that he does not think that the people of Taiwan and China need to look to the United States to solve their problems as "it resides first and foremost in the will and commitment of the people directly concerned."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON FRENCH SUPPORT FOR ANTI-SECESSION LAW: U.S. STATE DEP'T
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Thursday declined to comment on the French government's stance on China's Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan, saying only that Washington's position on the law is clear and won't be affected by France.

According to wire service reports, French Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin made a statement at a joint press conference held with his Chinese counterpart, Wen Chapao, during his current visit to Beijing that Paris does not oppose the Anti-Secession Law and that the law is completely consistent with the French position.

In response to media questions touching on Raffarin's remarks at a routine briefing, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said that he does not have any comment on what the French position is on the Anti-Secession Law since he had not seen those reports about France throwing its support behind the law.

Pointing out that he can only talk about the United States' stance on the law, Ereli said that Washington has made its position clear and that the French stance on the law "certainly does not affect our position."

Asked whether the French stance on the law contradicts the U.S. position, he said: "People don't agree with everything that we've said. I'm not saying that it's the case here, because again I don't know. I can't speak for the French government."

According to a Agence France-Presse report from the U.S. capital Thursday, a State Department official reiterated the same day Washington's opposition to the Anti-Secession Law after France voiced its support for the legislation.

The official said on condition of anonymity that "France has the right to its position....Our view is the Anti-Secession Law is not helpful. If France has a different view, then it is France's business," according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC TO PROMOTE R&D DESPITE LOWER THAN EXPECTED BUDGET INCREASE

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) said Friday that it will continue to promote research and development despite the fact that the growth in the government's high-technology budget has been lower than expected.

NSC officials noted that President Chen Shui-bian in his re-election campaign in 2004 had envisioned increasing the R&D budget to 3 percent of gross domestic product by 2006, which would mean annual growth of 15 percent in the government's high-tech budget over the next two years.
However, the officials noted, the budget increase for 2005 was only 4.85 percent, far lower than the targeted 15 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOVE THE EARTH, CHERISH TAIWAN: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian exhorted the country Friday to "save a little more and waste a little less" in order to live up to the resolution to "love the Earth and cherish Taiwan."

Addressing the opening ceremony of the 2nd NGO National Environmental Policy Forum -- an event marking International Earth Day -- Chen called on his fellow compatriots to be more environmentally conscious so that people now and future generations can live in a better place.

Chen said that 2004 was an "environmentally turbulent year, " culminating with the Dec. 26 tsunami tragedy that claimed some 200,000 lives in South and Southeast Asia and caused extensive damage to the environment.

He noted that although Taiwan is not a signatory to the U.N.-initiated Kyoto Protocol, which came into force Feb. 16 this year, Taiwan will have to face the realities and global demands for greenhouse gas emission reduction.

It is hoped that by squarely implementing measures under new laws, including a statute governing recycled energy development and the greenhouse gas emission control law, Taiwan's industrial development will continue to flourish while the environment is not compromised.

On arguments and controversies surrounding the building of new nuclear power plants, cross-mountain highways and big steel-refinery plants, Chen said that the outdated "development leads the economy" view should be cast off and replaced with a new "support development with conservation" concept.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR TO ASK DEPUTY TO REGISTER HIM FOR PARTY'S PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday that he will ask his deputy to register on his behalf for the party's primary for the Taichung mayoral election as he will be busy attending an important meeting in the United States.

Hu, who made known his intention to seek another term long ago, said earlier that he would register for the primary on the first day of registration. All KMT aspirants for Taichung mayorship are required to register for the party primary between April 28 and May 2.

However, Hu said Friday that he has to travel to the United States for a major meeting during that time, noting that he has been invited by Bill Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corp., to attend the Government Leaders' Forum in Washington, D.C. April 26-27.
Hu said that attending the forum is a rare opportunity, adding that if he does attend it, he won't be able to return to Taiwan in time to register on the first day.

Hu had originally planned to register himself when he returns home May 2, but his campaign team strongly advised him against this. Hu said he respects the views of his team and will therefore ask Vice Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi to register on his behalf.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO DISTRIBUTE COPIES OF TWO BOOKS DURING CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will bring with him two books and a notebook when he travels to mainland China next week for a historic visit, a KMT spokesman said Friday.

Chang Jung-kung said that in addition to meeting with political figures on the mainland and exchanging gifts, Lien has prepared copies of two books, with one written by Lien's grandfather Lien Heng on the general history of Taiwan, and the other, titled "Hope Comes With Change, " written by Lien himself, to distribute to them.

The KMT has also prepared a notebook on Lien's visit on the mainland so that the mainland Chinese people will understand more about what Lien and the KMT advocates. Lien will also distribute copies of the notebooks as well as copies of his book when he speaks to student at Peking University April 29.

Lien will visit Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai during his China trip April 26-May 3. He is expected to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao April 29, marking the first meeting between leaders of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) since the KMT fled the mainland in 1949. Hu concurrently serves as the general secretary of the CPC.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. STANCE ON RUSSIA, E.U. ARMS SALES ISSUES CONSISTENT: STATE DEP'T
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The United States has had a consistent stance on issues relating to Russian arms sales to China and on a possible lifting of the European Union's arms embargo against China, the U.S. State Department said Thursday.
Media reports have said that during Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's recent visit to Russia, she asked Russia not to sell arms to China because this might undermine stability in the region.
Asked whether Rice's request represents a new policy of the United States, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said "No" at a press briefing the same day.
It is a "long-stated U.S. policy, " he said, adding that he thinks it's also "consistent with our position with respect to the E.U. arms embargo."
"As we've articulated before, we don't want to see a militarization that adversely affects the security balance currently in the region," he added.
Rice expressed Wednesday in Moscow Washington's concerns over any actions or policies that might increase Chinese military strength in the Asia-Pacific region.

Saying that according to the Taiwan Relations Act, the United States has a responsibility to help Taiwan defend itself if it comes under attack, the secretary said that the United States has discussed with Russia on issues regarding its arms sales to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES LIEN PHONE CALL TO PRESIDENT CHEN PRIOR TO CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed welcome Friday to the promise that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will telephone President Chen Shui-bian before Lien embarks on his China visit slated for April 26.

Both the Democratic Progressive Party administration and the KMT authorities have confirmed that Lien will telephone Chen at 4:10 p.m. next Monday to inform the president about his forthcoming visit to China, which will mark the first time that a KMT chairman sets foot on mainland Chinese soil in more than five decades.

MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung welcomed the scheduled Lien-Chen telephone conversation, saying that Lien will demonstrate the courtesy and responsibility of an opposition political party leader when making the phone call to President Chen.
It is believed that Lien's China visit will be smoother and more rewarding if the opposition leader communicates with the administration beforehand, You noted.

You said that it is a democratic norm that political parties compete among themselves, although he added that the national interests should be put ahead of party gains. He said this competition is to the benefit of the country only when the opposition parties bear the nation's dignity and the people's wellbeing in mind and cooperates with the government, You added.

He said that after China enacted its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan, the Republic of China government was forced to rearrange its priorities regarding its cross-strait policies in consideration of national security and the people's interests.

You renewed calls for Beijing officials to return to the negotiating table with their Taiwan counterparts, saying that if China intends to recognize cross-strait political reality and reduce hostility toward Taiwan, it must resume official talks with Taiwan's authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATROL OF EAST CHINA SEA COMPLIES WITH LAW: COAST GUARD

TEXT.P: The dispatch of two vessels to patrol the Republic of China's exclusive economic zones in the East China Sea is in compliance with the domestic law, a Coast Guard Administration (CGA) official said Friday.

CGA Deputy Director Yu Chien-su was responding to a media report that the CGA urgently dispatched the "Ho Hsing" and "Mo Hsing" patrol ships to disputed waters in the East China Sea Thursday to affirm the ROC's sovereignty over the region.

According to the media report, Japan and China have had disputes over oil exploration in the East China Sea, and parts of the disputed oil fields are located in Taiwan's 200-nautical-mile exclusive economic zones. In addition to asserting the nation's sovereignty claim, the report said, the CGA patrol ships have also been directed to look into the two neighboring countries' actions in the region.

Yu would not explain whether the dispatch of the two patrol ships was aimed at asserting the ROC's sovereignty. Instead, he said the CGA has regularly sent patrol ships to keep guard in waters off Taiwan's northern and southern coasts in accordance with the law.

Noting that the CGA is obligated to police the nation's territorial seas and exclusive economic zones, Yu said the CGA has sent patrol ships twice a month to police waters north and south of Taiwan. The latest patrol "is not the first of its kind," he added.

In 2004, the Ministry of the Interior published a list of CGA patrol routes in the nation's exclusive economic zones, including waters 200 nautical miles north of its territorial sea base lines surrounding the islet of Pengjia.

Chen Li-tung, dean of National Taiwan Ocean University's graduate school of maritime law, said he supports the CGA's dispatch of patrol ships to the East China Sea to protect the nation's legitimate rights. He also urged the government to adopt more active steps to assert the ROC's exclusive rights in its economic zones.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : PM Lee rallies Singaporeans.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong believes that most Singaporeans support the decision to have two integrated resorts with casinos as a way to grow the economy and create jobs.
They know the Government did so after careful thought and with a clear conscience.
The Lianhe Zaobao: PM Lee: The decision on integrated resorts concerns with casinos the interest of S'pore in next 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU OPPOSES PRESIDENT'S TALKS WITH KMT CHAIRMAN OVER CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) objected Friday to President Chen Shui-bian's plan to hold talks over the telephone with opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan over Lien's upcoming visit to China.
The TSU urged Chen not to endorse the trips by Lien and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, or to lean toward the "one China" principle espoused by Beijing.
Lien is expected to telephone Chen Monday to report on the purpose and details of his China trip, set for April 26 to May 3. Soong will visit China in May.
According to Lai Hsin-yuan, a whip of the TSU legislative caucus, Chen and Lien should communicate face to face under media scrutiny because cross-Taiwan Strait policy is a disputed issue.
Lai accused Chen and Lien of not taking the matter seriously by allowing such discussion to take place over the phone.
Lai also asked the president to clarify if his talks with Lien mean that he supports the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" issue that Lien is planning to discuss in Beijing.
Chen had previously insisted that there was never any consensus between Taipei and Beijing on the issue during talks held in Hong Kong in 1992 during the rule of the former KMT government.

Lai accused Chen of being inconsistent in terms of his cross-strait policy, claiming that Chen has been swaying over the past five years between his "five noes" commitment and the "one country on each side" concept and between endorsing the campaign to change the official name of the country and denying it.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRIVERS URGED NOT TO OCCUPY PARKING SPACES FOR DISABLED

TEXT.P: A civic group urged drivers Friday to respect the rights of the physically disabled by not occupying parking spaces designated for them.

The Free Universe Education Foundation said government-designated parking spaces for the disabled are already far from sufficient, but able-bodied drivers often encroach into their spaces partly because fines are so insignificant.

People who do not have a permit are fined only NT$1,200 (less than US$40) if they park in spaces reserved for the disabled, while fines plus towing fees for parking alongside a red-lined no-parking curb total more than NT$2,000.

Tang Feng-cheng, chairman of the foundation's organizing committee, quoted the Taipei city government as saying that as of the end of March, it had issued nearly 26,000 parking permits for the disabled, while the city has only 1,800 disabled parking spaces.

Director Hsueh Cheng-tai of the city's Bureau of Social Affairs said he supports a proposal to raise the fines. However, he said he preferred to use "moral persuasion" to advise drivers not to infringe upon the rights of the disabled.
City Councilman Li Keng Kui-fang urged the government to crack down on violators and she called on the public to respect the rights of the disabled.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LAW BARRING OPPOSITION LEADERS FROM VISITING CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday there is no law prohibiting opposition leaders from visiting China.

Hsieh was responding to Legislator Cheng Chao-ming of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during an interpellation session in which Cheng asked the government to prohibit opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong from visiting China.
The premier said that the law only prohibits military personnel and specific kinds of people from making such visits.

The law does not bar anyone from visiting China for tourism or tombsweeping, he said, referring to Lien's plan to sweep his grandmother's tomb during a visit to Xian, one of the stops on his April 26-May 3 visit.

He also said that Lien's talks as a party leader on exchanges with the Communist Party of China (CPC) may not involve the exercise of government authority, but claimed that it is "normal" in other countries to first report to the government and the president prior to such visits.
On whether a telephone conversation between Lien and President Chen Shui-bian prior to his China visit can be construed as reporting to the government will hinge on the content of the talks, he said.

The premier was responding to questions by DPP Legislator Chen Chao-lung on whether Lien's scheduled phone call to Chen is considered reporting to the government, and on whether Lien's visit to China comes at an appropriate time.

Hsieh said that if Lien and Chen quarrel over the phone, it will not be considered a report, but added that if Lien mentions his trip, the government will give him leeway, saying that the phone call will at least show respect to the existence of the president and the government.
On former President Lee Teng-hui's criticism of the China visits by Lien and Soong as wrong in terms of timing and venue, Hsieh said that the timing is indeed inappropriate.
But as Taiwan is a country governed by law, the government still cannot prohibit them from going, he said.

He noted that hundreds of thousands of Taiwan people took to the streets March 26 to show their displeasure over China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which has translated into pressure for Beijing.
Because of the pressure, China wants to extend an olive branch to Taiwan, which is why it is welcoming visits by the opposition.
He said that Lien's invitation to China is not because Beijing welcomes him but because it refuses to talk to the Taiwan government.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Thew Washington Post: Powell Playing Quiet Role in Bolton Battle; GOP Senators Sought Views on Nominee.
Former secretary of state Colin L. Powell is emerging as a behind-the-scenes player in the battle over John R. Bolton's nomination as ambassador to the United Nations, privately telling at least two key Republican lawmakers that Bolton is a smart but very problematic government official, according to Republican sources, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWANS IMPORTED FROM HUNGARY DESTROYED: COA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Friday that a batch of swans imported from Hungary has been destroyed and there is no possibility that any disease they might have been carrying has leaked into Taiwan's poultry.
Officials from COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine said that a domestic trader imported 30 swans from Hungary, which were put into quarantine in Keelung Jan. 28.
Five of the swans died between Feb. 8 and March 12. The dead swans were autopsied and incinerated, the officials said.

They said that the remaining 25 swans were found to have in their systems the antibodies for the highly contagious Newcastle disease, goose parvovirus infection and avian influenza during three tests during the extended quarantine period.
Although the viruses themselves were not detected, the bureau decided to destroy the swans March 14 for safety reasons, they added.
They said the killed swans were put into sealed containers after disinfection and taken to the COA's Animal Health Research Institute in Tamsui for incineration.
All the swans underwent complete autopsy and examination, and there is no questions of them having ever left the quarantine station, they stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA `UNINHABITABLE FOR MANKIND': MAC

TEXT.P: China has become one of the world's most uninhabitable countries and the people of Taiwan must guard against all kinds of risks when traveling there, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung said Friday.
You issued the call at a news conference when reminding people from Taiwan to be extremely cautious if traveling to China for business, pleasure or settlement.

Citing a report made public by the Development Program affiliated to the United Nations, You said that 16 of the world's 20 most uninhabitable cities were in China in 2004 as a result of poor performance in public order, environmental protection, religious freedom and human rights.

The MAC vice chairman further pointed out that studies carried out by Taiwan experts show that acid rain falls in one-third of China's territory, while problems related to counterfeit drugs, garbage and drinking water are so rampant they are claimed to kill thousands of people per year.

More than 60 percent or even 80 percent of China's 10 million deaf-mute population are victims of counterfeit drugs, while as many as 300 million people have difficulty getting potable water, he said, adding that only 50 percent of the garbage is handled in China's cities.
All these problems have led to a serious deterioration in overall living environments in Chinese cities, making "China one of the world's most uninhabitable countries," he claimed.
In addition, he went on, religious freedom is also strictly limited in China under pretext of national security.

Since China initiated its reform drive in the early 1990s, more than 2.7 million people have been arrested without conviction. Some 400,000 people have been sent to labor camps, around 200,000 have gone missing and tens of thousands have been abused to the point of brain damage or death, he said.

According to an assessment on social order carried out by a Chinese research unit, only five or seven out of China's 132 cities meet its safety requirements and standards, the MAC vice chairman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Moscow Times: Reports: UES Set to Sell Ren-TV.
Control of Ren-TV, the last relatively independent television channel, will change hands next month in a deal that could further limit press freedoms, Kommersant and Vedomosti reported Thursday. A Ren-TV spokeswoman confirmed that electricity monopoly Unified Energy Systems was in talks to sell its 70 percent stake in the channel to state-controlled Evrofinance Mosnarbank and broadcasting company RTL Group, owned by Germany's Bertelsmann AG.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were slightly higher Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for May grew 37 points to close at 5,725, with 28,450 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June rose 31 points to finish at 5,711, with 197 contract transactions, while September futures gained 45 points to close at 5,590, with 56 contracts traded.
December futures moved up 26 points to finish at 5,576, with 36 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 35 points to close at 5,585, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,688 for May, 5,680 for June, 5,545 for September, 5,550 for December and 5,550 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were all higher.
May TE futures increased 1.75 points to close at 222.55, with 6,131 contract transactions, while June TE futures grew 1.7 points to finish at 221.7, with 16 contracts traded.
September TE futures rose 3.65 points to finish at 221.95, with two contracts traded, while December TE futures moved up 2.45 points to close at 223.45, with five contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March.
May TF futures moved up 3.2 points to close at 918.2, with 5,864 contract transactions, while June TF futures rose 3.4 points to finish at 919, with 10 contracts changing hands.
September TF futures grew 7.6 points to close at 915, with eight contracts traded, while December TF futures rose 13.2 points to close at 917.8, with eight contracts traded.
No transactions were reported for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved down against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.038 to close at NT$31.503.
A total of US$632 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$31.541 and fluctuated between NT$31.480 and NT$31.610 during the trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER HALF OF HONG KONG YOUTH SEE JAPAN IN NEGATIVE LIGHT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 22 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: More than half of Hong Kong youth said their feelings about Japan have become more negative in the wake of recent tension between China and Japan, according to the results of a survey released Friday.
The survey was conducted recently among 507 youths aged 15-34 by a Hong Kong youth association.

The results show that over 90 percent of those polled could not accept Japan's newly published history textbook that downplays its wartime atrocities during World War II, while over 80 percent said they could not accept Japan's invasion over the disputed Tiaoyutai islands, which lie northeast of Taiwan and are jointly claimed by China, Japan and Taiwan.

Meanwhile, about a dozen representatives of pro-Taiwan civic groups marched to the Japanese consulate in Hong Kong to protest against the newly published textbooks and visits by Japanese parliamentarians to a shrine near Tokyo that honors Japan's war dead, including executed Class A war criminals.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAISHANG' IS EXTENSION OF TAIWAN'S POWER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen operating in China and elsewhere around the world -- better known as "taishang" -- represent an extension of the power of Taiwan, President Chen Shui-bian said Friday.
Taishang's growth and expansion overseas, including China, also mark the accumulation of Taiwan's economic and trade strength, according to Chen.

He noted that people should bear in mind that if there was no Taiwan, there would be no Taishang. Stressing that Taiwan is the home and the mother of Taishang, Chen claimed that the world looks up to Taishang because they have a strong back-up in Taiwan. He claimed that if Taishang lose Taiwan, they will not only lose reliance and back-up, they will even miss their positions in the world.
The president made the remarks when he was addressing a groundbreaking ceremony in Tainan County to mark the beginning of the development of an LCD television and optoelectronic industrial park.

The park, part of the Southern Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park, will be an industrial processing zone housing TFT-LCD manufacturers and processors of related up-stream and down-stream industries.
Construction is scheduled to kick off next month with a preliminary development budget of NT$15 billion (US$476 million).

Chen noted that production of the Southern Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park was around NT$1.58 billion in the first year of the park's operations in 1999. The output grew remarkably to NT$259.4 billion by 2004, he added.
Despite its brisk growth, Chen said, the Southern Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park has been unable to secure land to accommodate support or satellite industries for the park.

The development of the LCD television and optoelectronic industrial park will be a new, sounder design in Taiwan's high-technology industrial development, with principal and supporting industries being housed in the same location, Chen noted.

Output of the TFT-LCD processing industry -- one of the three "trillion-class" industries in Taiwan -- is expected to reach NT$1.37 trillion in 2006, Chen said, adding that Taiwan's TFT-LCD production commanded 42.02 percent of the entire world market in 2004, about the same level as that produced by South Korea, the world leader in the TFT-LCD industry.

Due to severe competition, Taiwan's TFT-LCD makers have had no choice but to diversify into production bases worldwide, including China, to help reduce production overheads. This is also an unavoidable challenge that Taiwan's TFT-LCD industry faces, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT'S CHINA VISIT CAN BEAR GOOD RESULTS: EX-PREMIER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 22 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai/S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation was quoted as saying Friday that opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China will hopefully produce good results.

Vincent Siew, who was attending an Asia Summit in Boao, southern China, was quoted by Hong Kong media as saying that an exchange of visits between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will bear good results if both sides show sincerity, pragmatism and reason while remaining cool-headed.
A former vice chairman of the KMT, Taiwan's largest opposition party, Siew said his foundation has worked hard to reduce tension and promote understanding between Taiwan and China.
Occasions like the Boao Summit, which draws participants from both sides of the strait, can help increase trade and investment between Taiwan and China, he was quoted as adding.
Siew, who had been Taiwan's premier, said such exchanges will increase in the future, contributing to greater peace and stability in the strait.

The Boao Summit, scheduled for April 22-24, claims not to shun "sensitive" topics. According to the conference program, a panel will discuss "Asia's New Role -- Focusing on Northeast Asia" on the final day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 25.1 points to close at 5,747.09.
The bourse opened at 5,777.49 and fluctuated between 5,799.73 and 5,741.49 during trading. A total of 2.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.45 billion (US$2.04 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 0.8 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares, textile stocks and machinery and electronics shares all at 0.5 percent and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Construction issues lost ground at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 474 to 348, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH AIT CHIEF OVER CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: The unofficial U.S. envoy in Taiwan has paid a visit to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to exchange views on Lien's upcoming journey to China, KMT spokesman Chang Jung-kung said Friday.

"Douglas Paal, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , met with Lien a few days ago to exchange views on Lien's April 26-May 3 visit to China, " Chang said at a news conference held at the KMT's headquarters.
According to Chang, Lien briefed Paal on the KMT's basic stance on handling cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

"We have explained to the United States that peace is the bedrock of our fundamental stance on cross-strait relations. We don't support Taiwan independence and our advocacy of increased cross-strait exchanges conforms with the U.S. stance," Chang said.

He claimed that the United States attaches great importance to Lien's forthcoming China visit. In addition to the Lien-Paal meeting, Chang said, other AIT officials have also met with KMT cadres to boost mutual understanding.

Since KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's March 28-April 1 China visit, Chang said, the U.S. authorities have on two public occasions and one private occasion affirmed that any dialogue is better than no dialogue at all as far as cross-strait relations are concerned.

Chang said the KMT is fully aware of the U.S. expectations for official cross-strait dialogue. But before official contact across the Taiwan Strait can take place, Chang said, opposition Taiwan politicians' dialogue with the Chinese authorities are helpful to maintaining peace and stability in the region.

"While in China, Lien will certainly defend Taiwan's dignity, promote cross-strait peace and aver parity in bilateral engagements," Chang said, adding he is convinced that Lien will receive recognition both at home and in the international community for his historic visit.
As to whether Paal presented any demands in the course of his talks with Lien, Chang said the United States is unlikely to demand anything from the KMT since the party is not in power.

Chang further said the KMT's China policy is enshrined in its official documents and that Lien and all other KMT officials accompanying him on the visit will abide by the law and will not usurp the government's power.

Lien, heading a large delegation of KMT officials and journalists, will depart next Tuesday for what he bills a "journey of peace" to China that will take him to four cities -- Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai.

Lien, who was the Republic of China premier from February 1993 through February 1998 and vice president from May 1996 to May 2000, will be the first KMT chairman to visit China since the party, which once ruled all of China, fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese communists.
Lien, who lost two presidential bids in 2000 and 2004, is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who is also general secretary of the Communist Party of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS DIVIDED ON OPPOSITION LEADERS' CHINA VISITS

TEXT.P: Legislators from across the political spectrum are still divided on the upcoming visits to China by the leaders of the nation's two major opposition parties.

Lien Chan, chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), and James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) , are expected to visit China later this month and early next month, respectively, at the invitation of Chinese President Hu Jintao, who is also secretary-general of the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Chung-mo claimed that Lien and Soong will just be taken by China as puppets used to manipulate Taiwan's politics. "People should not overestimate Lien and Soong's ability in political manipulation, as Beijing will also despise their fawning attitudes," Lin claimed.

DPP Legislator Kao Chien-chih noted that many people fear that the visits might undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and that if they really want to promote peace across the Taiwan Strait, they should ask the Chinese authorities to dismantle their missiles targeting Taiwan.
Legislator Tzen Tsan-teng, also from the DPP, criticized the KMT for straying from its previous anti-communist policy.
In contrast, KMT Legislator Kun Wen-chi hailed Lien's visit, describing it as a move to create dialogue and promote peace, which the United States also wants to see.

KMT lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao said Lien will not damage Taiwan's interests as some people fear, because he is not in power. He said the visits will lead to less tense cross-strait ties, which will be beneficial for the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY TO LAUNCH 'PUBLIC TRIAL' ON TIAOYUTAIS SOVEREIGNTY ISSUE

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming said Friday that his party will initiate a "public trial" by "all the people of Taiwan" May 15 should the administration fail to respond to controversy surrounding the sovereignty issue of the Tiaoyutai island group before that time.

Yok said at a press conference that the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government has made no effort to protect the Republic of China's sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais in the first place, while former President Lee Teng-hui has claimed that the Tiaoyutais, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan, are part of Japanese territory.

Noting that Lee slammed opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong a day earlier for their planned visits to China and accused them of "colluding with China to sell Taiwan, " Yok claimed that Lee was "colluding with Japan to sell Taiwan."

Arguing that the Tiaoyutais are part of Republic of China territory, Yok said that if the DPP government continues to condone Lee's nonsense and makes no response to the controversy regarding the Tiaoyutais sovereignty issue, the New Party will initiate a "public trial" May 15, supposedly to "let the Taiwan people decide" who is "colluding with Japan to sell Taiwan."

New Party Legislator Joanna Lei said that the Chun Xiao oil and gas field -- China's southernmost offshore oil and gas field in the East China Sea, only 4 km from the median line with Japanese territory and currently the heart of an ongoing Chinese-Japanese dispute -- is located within the ROC's 200-nautical-mile economic zone and is also part of the Tiaoyutai reef area.

The DPP government, however, has not uttered a word on Japan's recent sovereignty claims over the Chun Xiao oil and gas field, giving away mammoth interests equal to NT$8 million (US$254,000) for each of Taiwan's citizen for nothing, Lei said.

Lei claimed that the Tiaoyutai island group is part of ROC territory, saying that the Ilan county government in northeastern Taiwan formally registered the uninhabited Tiaoyutai island group as territory under ROC jurisdiction last April in accordance with a Ministry of the Interior plan and priced the Tiaoyutai land at NT$100 per square meter.

Since the Chun Xiao oil and gas field is located within the Tiaoyutai area and within the ROC's 200-nautical-mile economic zone, the DPP government should move to claim it and protect the nation's interests, Lei said.
The Tiaoyutai, located between Taiwan and Okinawa, are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.
China ceded the island group to Japan in 1895 at a time when the last Chinese imperial dynasty, the Qing, was in sharp decline and losing territory to aggressive foreign powers.

After World War II, the islands were put under U.S. control, at which time the ROC government demanded their return. In 1972, however, the United States returned the islands to the Japanese government -- a decision that governments and patriotic groups on both sides of the Taiwan Strait continue to protest.

The Ilan County Land Administration Office incorporated the Tiaoyutai islets under the jurisdiction of the Toucheng township government in the northeastern county of Ilan in February 2004 to signify the ROC's sovereignty claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES TO PASS THREE PRIORITIZED BILLS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday that three bills for which his Cabinet most needs bipartisan support are a revised bill on the organic law of the Executive Yuan, a draft bill for the 2008 Taiwan Expo and a statute governing major arms procurements.
Hsieh made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

Legislator Tsai Chia-fu of the opposition Kuomintang asked whether there are scenic spots to attract tourists when Kaohsiung sponsors the World Games in 2009, noting that promoting Taiwan's economy will also promote tourism.

Hsieh said the government's policy is to have each city and county promote one international activity, with Chiayi County focusing Alishan while Nantou County will focus on Sun Moon Lake, adding that the policy has borne fruit, with the number of Japanese tourists coming to Taiwan reaching 800,000 recently.
The premier also said it is necessary for Taiwan to commission a public relations company to lobby for Taiwan in the U.S. Congress.

Hsieh was responding to questions by Legislator Fu Kun-chi of the opposition People First Party who cited reports that Taiwan spent US$1.08 million over two years to commission Cassidy & Associates to lobby the U.S. Congress and asked if the money spent was worth it.

The premier said it is necessary to pay a PR company to lobby in the U.S. Congress, noting that the policies set by Congress have global influence. He added that the Minister of Foreign Affairs decides upon which PR company to commission and how much money to spend.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME WORLD'S LARGEST DISPLAY PANEL SUPPLIER: CHI MEI

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to become the world's largest supplier of display panels in 2005 after the 5.5 and 6.0 generation lines enter mass production, Chi Mei Optoelectronics (CMO) Chairman Frank Liao said in southern Tainan County Friday.

Addressing a ground-breaking ceremony for an industrial zone designated for the liquid-crystal display (LCD) television industry in the Southern Taiwan Science Park, Liao noted that the production value of Taiwan's display panels is now far ahead of that of Japan.

Liao said the LCD television and thin-film transistor liquid-crystal display (TFT-LCD) technologies are very valuable to Taiwan's economic development and that the industrial zone will help integrate the country's optoelectronics industry.

According to the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the production value of Taiwan's flat panel display industry amounted to NT$715 billion (US$22.69 billion) in 2004, up 71 percent from the previous year.
The production value of display panels accounted for NT$545 billion, while parts and components accounted for NT$170 billion.
The bureau has predicted that the production value of the flat panel display industry will climb further to NT$950 billion this year.

Tainan Magistrate Su Huan-chih, who was also present at the ceremony, pointed out that the idea of establishing the industrial zone was first put forth by CMO founder Shi Wen-long in January 2004 and is now being followed by leading South Korean manufacturers such as LG and Samsung.
Su said he believes the project will boost the international competitiveness of the Southern Taiwan Science Park.
The industrial zone will cover an area of 247 hectares and cost NT$15 billion, according to the Tainan county government.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS TO 4.15%: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped to 4.15 percent in March, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Friday.
The rate marked a 0.13 percent decline from the February level and a 0.3 percent fall from the year-earlier level, DGBAS officials said.
According to DGBAS tallies, 428,000 people were out of work in March, with an average unemployment period of 30 weeks.
Meanwhile, the same tallies show that the average unemployment rate for the first three months of this year stood at 4.16 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CALLS FOR CALM OVER PARTY CHIEF'S CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: The spokesman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) called Friday for peace and calm among pro-independence supporters over KMT Chairman Lien Chan's visit to mainland China, saying that every citizen in a democratic society is free to voice his or her opinion, but in a peaceful way.

Chang Jong-kung made the remarks at the KMT headquarters in Taipei after the Human Chain Alliance of Taiwan said earlier the same day that they will mobilize supporters to see Lien off at Chiang Kai- shek International Airport next Tuesday or even "intercept" Lien on the highway to the airport to express their opposition to his China visit.

Stressing that Lien's visit is to help build peace between Taiwan and China, Chang said that everyone in Taiwan is entitled to enjoy the harvest as it will represent major progress in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

KMT officials and supporters will also see Lien off at CKS International Airport April 26, he said, adding that most of the people in Taiwan praying for cross-strait peace will be happy to see Lien embark on the trip that will end May 3.

Commenting on a telephone call slated to be made by Lien to President Chen Shui-bian Monday afternoon ahead of his departure, Chang said he believes that the conversation will touch on cross-strait affairs. "I believe that Chairman Lien will give a good explanation of his China visit to the president, " he added.

The government and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party have both insisted that Lien notify Chen before he departs for China out of grave concern that Lien's talks with Communist Party of China officials, including General Secretary Hu Jintao, who is also the Chinese president, will infringe upon the government's authority and erode Taiwan's interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF'S CHINA TRIP WILL NOT HELP ECONOMIC EXCHANGES: ANALYST

TEXT.P: Although the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) leader's planned China visit is not a bad thing, it will not help promote economic and trade exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, a professor claimed Friday.

Lin Hsiang-kai, a professor at National Taiwan University, said that negotiations concerning cross-strait economic and trade exchanges should be conducted with dignity and on an equal footing and that without the authorization of the government, even if the opposition parties reach consensus with China, it will be just an "opinion from the civil sector."

Citing the example of KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang's visit to China in March, during which the Chinese government promised to sign an agreement to further protect the interests of Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China, Lin said the issue concerning the huge interests of Taiwanese businessmen in China should be negotiated on a government-to-government basis.

During Chiang's China trip, he reached a 10-point consensus with Beijing on a wide variety of issues, including cross-strait transport, agricultural cooperation and the opening of China's financial market.

Lin added that China's recently promulgated Anti-Secession Law will be detrimental to cross-strait economic and trade exchanges and that a single visit by a KMT official will not bring about a breakthrough on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: LCD TV PRODUCTION VALUE TO INCREASE BY NT$200 BILLION

TEXT.P: The annual production value of the liquid-crystal display (LCD) television industry will be increased by NT$200 billion (US$6.34 billion) after an industrial zone designated for the industry is completed in Tainan, southern Taiwan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday.
The industrial zone, which broke ground Friday in the Southern Taiwan Park, covers 247 hectares with a development budget of NT$14 billion and will be opened to manufacturers by the end of May.

The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the MOEA noted that Taiwan has produced around 1.8 million LCD units last year and that after the establishment of the industrial zone, the annual production value is expected to increase by more than NT$200 billion, creating 30,000 jobs.

IDB officials said that 1.95 million digital TV (DTV) and LCD TVs were produced last year with a production value of around US$54.4 billion, up 320 percent and 212 percent, respectively, from the previous year.
It is expected that the number of DTVs and LCD TVs will reach 3.6 million units with a production value of US$83.2 billion this year.

The officials also said that the production value of the flat panel display industry showed remarkable growth last year, reaching NT$715 billion. But as 90 percent of the investment on equipment has to rely on imports, many manufacturers have to delay their next-generation plant expansion projects when the price for flat panel displays is down.
This will affect Taiwan's competitive edge, they said, adding that the IDB has listed the raising of the self-sufficiency rate for equipment as a top priority.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CHINESE ENTERING TAIWAN LEGALLY FOR UNLAWFUL PURPOSES: MOI

TEXT.P: Although a government crackdown has effectively reduced the number of illegal Chinese immigrants, the number of Chinese residents entering Taiwan through lawful means for illicit purposes is increasing, Vice Interior Minister Lin Yung-chien said Friday.

Lin told a group of opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union lawmakers that the problem of illegal Chinese immigrants has improved significantly after the Cabinet set up a special task force to crack down on illegal immigrants.
According to Lin, the number of illegal Chinese immigrants arrested by the police dropped to some 1,800 people in 2004 from some 3,500 the previous year.

However, the number of Chinese residents who entered Taiwan under the pretext of getting married or staying with relatives so as to engage in prostitution or illegal employment is getting higher and higher every year, Lin said.
He said the problem poses a threat to Taiwan's public order and he pledged that the Ministry of the Interior will impose stricter controls on the entry of Chinese residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER'S, TAIPEI MAYOR'S ASSETS INCREASE MODESTLY

TEXT.P: The family assets of both Premier Frank Hsieh and Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou have increased modestly over the past year, according to assets disclosure reports released by the watchdog Control Yuan Friday.
Assets disclosure reports filed by Hsieh and Ma with the Control Yuan last December showed that their overall family assets didn't change significantly last year as compared with their 2003 reports.

According to Hsieh's report, he had NT$9.97 million in bank deposits, marking an increase of more than NT$700,000 from the figure reported in 2003. In addition, Hsieh had a deposit of US$51,800 in his foreign currency account plus a total stock holding of 46,000 shares.
In comparison, Ma had NT$61.95 million in bank deposits, up NT$3.14 million from a year ago. His stock holdings remained unchanged, while his wife's increased slightly.

Meanwhile, Minister of Finance Lin Chuan had NT$12 million in bank deposits plus U.S. dollar-denominated deposits worth about NT$1.29 million. In addition, lin had a number of stock holdings, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., Nan Ya Plastics Corp. and China Steel Corp.

According to the Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law, the president, vice president, premier, political appointees, paid advisers to the president, elected officials and representatives are required to file family assets disclosure reports with the control Yuan annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT GOING ALL-OUT TO HELP HIGH SPEED RAIL RUN: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The still-under-construction high speed rail (HSR) system along the west coast of Taiwan marks the country's first major build-operate-transfer (BOT) project for infrastructure development, must not be allowed to fail and its operation should be launched as planned, Premier Frank Hsieh said Friday.

All relevant ministries and government units have been asked to make all-out efforts to help complete the project, he said, noting that even if the HSR system is not built perfectly, the government will be obliged to buy it back at a price of over NT$300 billion (US$9.5 billion) under the terms of the BOT contract.

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions regarding the project, which is scheduled for completion at the end of October, from lawmaker Chang Hwa-kuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

He pointed out that Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chou Liang-li has been assigned to coordinate efforts from different fields to resolve technical problems of the HSR system, which is a hybrid of Japanese and European systems.

At the present stage, the bullet train's test runs have reached 120 kph, the premier said, adding that he hopes the test runs can be speeded up to above 200 kph by June or July and that the Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) will carry out its promise of starting regular service by the end of October as originally scheduled.
The THSRC has completed most of the 345-km project, which connects Taipei in the north with Kaohsiung in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: A mother, a victim...another crime statistic.
As law and order moved to centre stage in the election campaign yesterday and politicians cherry-picked statistics, the reality lay in intensive care in a South London hospital. Abigail Witchalls, a young mother of 26, was critically ill last night after she was stabbed in the neck in front of her 21-month old son as they enjoyed a quiet walk in the spring sunshine. Ms Witchalls, a part-time English language teacher, was on her way back to her in-laws' home in the prosperous Surrey village of Little Bookham, pushing her son, Joseph, in a buggy. She was approached by a man demanding money. When she refused he stabbed her in the neck and fled.
Financial Times: Cadbury chief slams investor groups for lack of openness.
Simmering tensions between British companies and their shareholders burst into the open on Thursday when the chairman of Cadbury Schweppes launched a broad attack on the investment community. John Sunderland, also president of the CBI, in a speech accused banks, institutional shareholders and hedge funds of lacking the openness they demanded of listed companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Backs His U.N. Nominee, but Powell Warns of Volatility.
U.S. President Bush on Thursday issued a storng new defense of John R. Bolton, his nominee as ambassador to the United Nations. But associates of Colin L. Powell, the former secretary of state, said Powell, in private telephone conversations, had made clear his concerns about Mr. Bolton on several fronts, including his harsh treatment of subordinates.
Wall Street Journal: Facing Vioxx Trials, Merck Prepares to Fight Each Case.
As Merck faces Vioxx liability that some analysts have estimated could top US$20 billion, it says it is committed to fighting every case against it with a legal war chest of US$675 million. Vioxx was withdrawn from the market last Sept. 30. after a study suggested it doubled the risk of heart attack in those taking the drug for more than 18 months. In the lawsuits, Merck is now combing patients' pasts for evidence that their unhealthy habits, not the drug, caused heart problems. And its lawyers have won some important procedural victories, driving up the costs for plaintiffs' lawyers. Merck still faces a daunting task in winning over juries. Plaintiff lawyers plan to stress how multiple studies suggested Vioxx was a problem years before the withdrawal. Many experts who raised questions have said Merck tried to squash their views. At one point, the Food and Drug Administration sent a warning letter telling Merck to stop making unsupported claims about Vioxx's cardiovascular safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WHO BID TO MAKE REAL PROGRESS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to take part in the World Health Organization (WHO) is expected to make real progress this year, a senior official said Friday.

According to the official, WHO member states are working on revisions to the International Health Regulations (IHR) which would facilitate Taiwan's participation in the world health promotion and epidemic control body.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the revised IHR will adopt a "universally applicable" principle to allow for Taiwan's participation in WHO activities.

Once the proposed amendments are passed, the official said, the IHR will stipulate that its provisions will be applicable to all humans to protect them from being infected with internationally communicable diseases.

The official said the IHR revisions are mainly aimed at admitting Taiwan into the WHO because WHO officials have come to understand the global disease control and health care system cannot afford to exclude Taiwan any longer.

The WHO is expected to pass the proposed IHR revision package at the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the WHO's decision-making arm -- to be held in Geneva in May. The official said the government has kept close contacts with the United States and other pro-Taiwan countries over the issue.

Taiwan has sought to join the WHA as an observer since 1997. Due to China's boycott, Taiwan's bid has made little progress. At last year's WHA, a vote was held on Taiwan's bid. The United States and Japan gave "yes" votes last year, but China still managed to use its diplomatic clout to block the bid.
This time around, the official said, the government has decided to adjust its strategy after consultations with the United States and other allies.
"We'll give the top priority to actually taking part in WHO activities as our initial goal, " the official said. But he didn't elaborate.
Earlier this week, U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Randall G. Schriver said the United States looks forward to seeing real progress in Taiwan's WHO bid this year.

"We continue to work on it. We have not only approached Beijing on this issue, but also worked with countries we regard as friends and the like-minded. So we'll see if we can achieve our ultimate objective, which is observership for Taiwan in the WHO, and see if we can make incremental progress in that direction, " Schriver told a group of Taiwan reporters stationed in Washington, D.C.

Asked whether Taiwan would ask for a vote at this year's World Health Assembly scheduled for May in Geneva, Schriver said the United States and Taiwan have discussed a range of options to be adopted this year, including a vote.

"The vote, we did that last year. We know the outcome. If our friends in Taiwan want to pursue that again, they know they can count on our support. But we are interested really not so much in a symbolic move of any kind. We want to see real progress towards meaningful participation for Taiwan in the WHO," Schriver said.
"[An] example would be, if not observership, then Taiwan's ability to participate in the work of the WHO, contribute to the WHO in ways without any obstacles from Beijing," he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISIT TO CHINA IS A BETRAYAL OF TAIWAN, SAYS PRES. ADVISOR

TEXT.P: Senior Presidential Advisor Peng Ming-min said Friday that the upcoming visits to China by two opposition leaders are a " betrayal of Taiwan" as such visits could derail a government bill to buy weapons from the United States (U.S.).
Peng said James Soong of the People First Party (PFP) reached a 10-point consensus with President Chen Shui-bian, agreeing to support the government in passing major bills at the Legislative Yuan.

However, he pointed out, the president's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the PFP have not been able to put such major legislative items as the arms purchase bill, or Control Yuan members' list to committee screening, much less pass them. Peng attributed this to Soong's failure to honor his words.

The president gained only a nominal score -- having Soong calling him "Mr. President, " but lost heavily as Soong has done nothing to fulfill his promise for legislative cooperation with the DPP, according to Peng.
The president now looks as if he is "being strangled by his 10-point consensus with Soong," and he has been scorned by supporters of Taiwan independence, Peng said.
Now Soong and his Kuomintang counterpart Lien Chan are to visit China, Peng is worried that the chances of passing the arms purchase bill will become even slimmer.

Turning to the visits to China, which have been the subject of much discussion, he said the two opposition leaders are trying to play Taiwan politics using the "China card" with a view to discrediting President Chen.
While the rest of the world is giving a thumbs-down to China's Anti-Secession Law, China is able to use the two visits to tell the world that Taiwan is "not that angry" at the law, he said.

He accused Lien and Soong of disregarding Taiwan's national interests by making the visits, as they will be seen as evidence of a division inside Taiwan and will help to relieve China from world-wide pressure, Peng said.
Therefore, he added, the visits can be clarified as a betrayal of Taiwan which he believes will not produce any concrete results.

Former President Lee Teng-hui has alleged that both Lien and Soong "are working with the Chinese Communists to betray Taiwan." However, Peng stated that it is still too early to come to this conclusion as the opposition leaders have not yet landed in China.
Peng supports Lee's proposal for four-party talks to solve the Taiwan Strait issue which would involve Taiwan, China, Japan and the U.S. but noted the U.S. would not be interested in such a proposal.

The U.S. has always advocated that cross-strait disputes should be settled by direct and peaceful dialogue between Beijing and Taipei, Peng said, adding he does not see any likelihood of the U.S. changing its position and intervening.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN CONTINUES SUPPORTING TAIWAN'S WHA BID

TEXT.P: The spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry reiterated his government's support Friday for Taiwan to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer.
Hatsuhisa Takashima told foreign press that if neighboring countries also agree, Japan welcomes Taiwan's bid to become a WHA observer.
Last year, Japan welcomed Taiwan's attempt to join the world health body as an observer if "all parties concerned" also endorsed it, and Japan has made its position clear at the WHA conference.
Hatsuhisa Takashima was asked Friday if Japan would continue to support Taiwan, he said yes, adding Japan expects neighboring countries to agree with Japan over this matter.
Last month, a Taiwan presidential advisor, Wu Shu-min, visited Japan at the head of a delegation, lobbying for Japan's early public statement this year on this issue.
Such a statement from Japan could make other countries follow suit, Wu said, urging all democracies to continue to support Taiwan in its WHA bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DROPS IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 4.15 percent in March, a decrease of 0.13 percentage points compared to February, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure represented an unemployed workforce of some 428,000 people, a decrease of 13,000 from February, according to the statistics.

March's unemployment rate also dropped 0.30 percentage points from last year's level. This figure was lower than Hong Kong's 6.1 percent and Japan's 4.7 percent, but higher than Singapore's 3.7 percent and South Korea's 3.5 percent.
The unemployment rate in the first quarter reached 4.16 percent, a decrease of 0.37 percentage points compared to the same period last year.
In March, the number of employed people stood at 9.87 million, an increase of 3,000 from February, and a growth of 162,000 compared with March 2004.
DGBAS statistics also showed that the number of people employed in the first quarter reached 9.88 million, a growth of 185,000 people over the same period of last year.

In comparison with March 2004, the number of people employed in the industrial and service sectors showed an increase of 124,000 and 100,000, respectively. However, the number of people employed in agricultural sector decreased by 62,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP ASKS GOVERNMENT TO SUBSIDIZE HYBRID CARS

TEXT.P: A local environmental protection group called on the government Friday to subsidize the cost of hybrid cars to encourage people to replace their traditional automobiles with the environment-friendly vehicles.

According to Environmental Quality Protection Foundation Secretary-General Liu Ming-lung, hybrid cars, which are powered alternately by electric and gasoline, can save gasoline consumption by nearly 50 percent and reduce emissions by more than 90 percent.
However, the vehicles are not popular in Taiwan mainly because of their high prices, Liu said.
Liu pointed out that the battery systems used in the hybrid cars are very expensive and that government subsidies are required even in foreign countries to encourage consumers to buy the vehicles.
Without such subsidies, the prices of hybrid cars in Taiwan are almost double that of foreign countries, Liu noted.
For example, Liu continued, a Prius hybrid car manufactured by Toyota sells NT$1.3 million (US$41,269) in Taiwan, when it costs less than NT$700,000 overseas.

Liu proposed that the government follow the tax deduction measures adopted by the United States, Japan and European Union and cut the commodity tax of hybrid cars by 50 percent, which he said will save consumers at least NT$100,000 per car.
The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) should also provide subsidies to bus operators for the purchase of hybrid buses, he added.

In response to the issue, EPA officials said providing subsidies and incentives for the purchase of hybrid vehicles is a policy the EPA will follow but that the EPA still needs to coordinate with other agencies to work out details, for example the subsidy amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU INDUSTRIAL PARK'S EXPORT HIT US$15 BILLION IN 2004: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan generated a revenue of NT$495.8 billion (US$15.7 billion) from exports in 2004, and the figure accounted for 8.5 percent of Taiwan's total exports that year, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

As of the end of last year the industrial park, which was established in 1980, housed a total of 384 companies and statistics showed that the amount of investments poured into the facility reached about NT$1.5 trillion.

Most of the companies are in the business of integrated circuits, computers and their peripherals, opto-electronics, communications, precision machinery, and biotechnology, according to the tallies, which also indicated that the number of workers in the park has been increasing since 2002.

Some 113,000 persons were employed in the Hsinchu industrial park last year, 10 percent of whom worked at research departments. Over a half of the researchers were in the integrated circuit industry. The DGBAS said that as a result of growing economic recovery in the worldwide markets, the science-based industrial park received an operational turnover of NT$1.1 trillion last year, posing a growth of 26.6 percent from the level of the previous year.

Meanwhile, the companies in both the Hsinchu industrial park and the Southern Taiwan Science-based Industrial Park in Tainan County spent NT$50.4 billion totally in research programs in 2003, a number accounting for 5 percent of the companies combined turnovers, higher than the average 1.2 percent of local manufacturers outside the parks, according to the DGBAS

Thanks to efforts to develop new products, the number of patented items in the industrial parks has increased. In 2003 it was recorded at 3,026 items, and has increased to 12.6 percent over the level of a year ago, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP URGES OPPOSITION LEADERS TO DEFEND ROC'S DIGNITY ON CHINA VISITS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu urged two opposition leaders Friday to deliver on their promises to protect the Republic of China (ROC) during their upcoming visits to the People's Republic of China (PRC).
Lu made the call while attending a seminar on social justice, happiness and human rights.

The outspoken vice president said both Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong have on numerous occasions vowed to defend the ROC's national dignity and sovereignty.

"Now is the time for them to substantiate their pledge," Lu said, adding that Lien and Soong should ask the Chinese authorities to play the ROC's national anthem and hoist the ROC's national flag to welcome their arrival in Beijing for talks with PRC President Hu Jintao.

Moreover, Lu said, all Taiwanese people hate the Chinese military threat. "We hope the two opposition leaders can ask Hu on behalf of the 23 million Taiwanese people to dismantle and destroy China's hundreds of ballistic missiles which are pointed at Taiwan," Lu said.
In addition, Lu said, major countries around the world have condemned China's enactment of its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.
"Lien and Soong should ask Hu during their talks to phase out or revise the ill-intentioned legislation that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan," Lu said.
If Lien and Soong really do bring up these demands during their stay in China, Lu said, the people of Taiwan will give them a warm welcome when they conclude their visits and return to Taipei.
Hu invited Lien and Soong to visit China, separately, in his capacity as general secretary of the Communist Party of China.

Lien, heading a large delegation of KMT officials and journalists, will depart next Tuesday for what he bills a "journey of peace" to China that will take him to four cities -- Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai.

Lien, who was the ROC's premier from February 1993 through February 1998 and vice president from May 1996 to May 2000, will be the first KMT chairman to visit China since the party, which once ruled all of China, fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese communists.
Lien, who lost two presidential bids in 2000 and 2004, is scheduled to meet with PRC President Hu in Beijing April 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TASK FORCE TO VISIT BEIJING TO ARRANGE CHAIRMAN'S CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: A task force of the opposition People First Party (PFP) is scheduled to leave for Beijing on Sunday to establish an itinerary for the party chairman's visit to China, according to the PFP's news release on Friday.

The news release announced that the task force, to be headed by party Secretary General Chin Chin-sheng, is assigned to discuss James Soong's proposed China trip with officials in Beijing. It noted that the PFP will conduct its talks with the mainland side with sincerity, respect and pragmatism.
The PFP stated that it will publicize the details of Soong's visit on both sides of the Taiwan Strait simultaneously, once the task force has reached an agreement with Chinese officials.
