DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO MOBILIZE SUPPORTERS TO 'BID FAREWELL' TO KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) urged its supporters or like-minded people to rally at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport next Tuesday when opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will head for China for a visit.
TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming told a news conference that the rally is aimed at reminding Lien not to kowtow to China's demands during his April 26 - May 3 China visit.

Chen also reiterated the TSU's "five noes" policy toward cross-Taiwan Strait engagements -- no Chinese invasion of Taiwan, no Chinese diplomatic blockade against Taiwan, no Chinese missile threat against Taiwan, abolishment of China's anti-secession law and non-existence of the "1992 consensus" on "one China."
Claiming that the "five noes" are Taiwan's mainstream public opinion, Chen urged Lien to convey them to Chiense President Hu Jintao during their scheduled meeting in Beijing April 29.
Meanwhile, the National Security Bureau (NSC) called an inter-department meeting Friday to discuss effective measures to maintain order and security at CKS Airport on Lien's departure day.

Officials from the NSC, the Aviation Police Bureau and other relevant agencies attended the meeting. More than 1,000 police officers will be mobilized to prevent Lien's supporters and opponents from squabbling or fighting at the airport complex.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATIN AMERICAN COUNTRIES TO SEND STUDENTS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A delegation of the Latin American Consortium for Integrated Services (LACIS) will visit Taiwan in May to investigate the viability of sending students from their countries to learn about Taiwan's advanced information technology.

The LACIS, formed by Latin American universities and research organizations with the help of Taiwan and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) , is aimed at accelerating the development of the information industry and nanotechnology in Latin American countries.

The Latin American high-tech consortium admires Taiwan's advanced information technology, and has always been interested in forming cooperative ties with the island, according to Professor Wu Chung-yu of the National Chiao Tung University.
Under the arrangement of Wu, who is also an IEEE executive, a delegation from LACIS, to be headed by Professor Pedro Julian of Argentina, will come to Taiwan on May 27 to conduct a four-day visit.

During their stay here, the LACIS delegation will visit the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Education and Academia Sinica to explore the possibility of sending some 1,000 or 2,000 university students each year to study in Taiwan.

The LACIS delegation will also seek the exchange of visits among high-ranking government officials in charge of education in Taiwan and Latin American countries to further strengthen the substantial ties and academic exchanges between the two sides.
Wu noted that the standard of Latin American students is good, and therefore many Taiwanese universities are happy to attract them to study here.
He revealed that the National Chiao Tung University has been interested in receiving foreign students, and he hoped that other schools will also join the program.
If everything goes smoothly, Wu added, Latin American students could pursue advanced courses here from the start of early next year.

Wu went on that if Latin American students can stay in Taiwan to work for the island's high-tech industries after finishing their studies here, it will boost Taiwan's high-tech development, and will also strengthen the academic, business and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Latin American countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORSENING SITUATION IN CHINA HINDERS TAIWAN'S WILLINGNESS TO INVEST

TEXT.P: A worsening political and economic climate in mainland China has hindered Taiwanese businesses' willingness to invest, according to some Taiwanese businessmen based in China.

Chang Wu-chun, secretary-general of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Shanto City, southern Guangdong Province, said that the recent changes in China's political and economic stance has affected the willingness of Taiwan business people to invest in China more than Beijing's March 14 enactment of the Anti-Secession Law.

Chang claims that it will take approximately six months to gauge the impact of the law on Taiwanese companies. He also stated that the pace of Taiwanese investment in the Zhujiang Delta area has slowed down.

The falling status of Taiwanese businessmen may be another reason behind the decrease in investment in China by Taiwan, Chang said. He noted that local Chinese governments and officials now have a cooler attitude towards Taiwanese companies and show little interest in their operations -- a marked difference to their warm attitude in the past.

Meanwhile, the newest statistics compiled by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) showed that Taiwan' s China-bound investment in the first quarter of this year declined both in project numbers and value.

The government approved a total of 289 China-bound investment projects worth US$1.207 billion in the Q1, down by 47.83 percent and 6.57 percent, respectively, compared to the previous year's levels. There were 169 projects each valued at less than US$200,000.

Around 40 percent of the Q1 capital funneled into China by Taiwanese businesses went to the electronics and electrical manufacturing sector, ahead of 10 percent to the chemical manufacturing sector and 9.4 percent to the basic metal processing sector. Jiansu, Guangdong and Zhejiang provinces absorbed 86.3 percent of the overall capital.

Commission officials ascribed the decrease to China's drive to turn down its economic heating, its Anti-Secession Law against Taiwan as well as intentional tax-investigation moves by local Chinese authorities.

According to Commission officials, the frequency of tax-investigation and the number of blockades, and intrusions into factories run by Taiwanese businessmen by local mobster's increased after Beijing adopted the Anti-Secession Law. Taiwanese investors pointed out that they now face greater political and economic risks in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 23, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES US$1 M. TO GLOBAL FUND TO FIGHT 3 DEVASTATING DISEASES
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 22 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Friday donated US$1 million to the Geneva-based Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria as promised to express its concern for global health.

The island's former minister of the Department of Health under the Executive Yuan, Chen Chien-jen, made a commitment during last year's annual meeting of the World Health Assembly (WHA), the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) , to donate US$1 million to the fund.

The donation, which was made in the name of "Health Authorities of Taiwan, "represents the improvement in relations between the island and the fund over the past three years. The island was only able to use the designation "the People of Taiwan" when it made its first donation to the fund in 2002 through a representative of the organization in the United States.

On behalf of the fund, former U.S. Health and Human Services secretary and chairman of the Global Fund, Tommy Thompson, received a check from Shen Lyushun, director of the Taipei Economic and Culture Office in Geneva.

Expressing his gratitude for Taiwan's concrete contribution and assistance to the fund, Thompson, a longstanding supporter of Taiwan's bid to join the WHA, said that he hopes the island can provide relatively more support to the fund and the world health community in the future, implying that the island's economic strength give it the ability to do better in this regard.
He also said that he will continue to help Taiwan in pursuing its goal of joining the WHO.

In response, Shen said that besides making the donation to the fund, Taiwan has also provided various countries around the world with medical and health assistance through bilateral and multilateral channels, stressing that active participation in the global health system and making a better contribution to the system have always been objectives of the island.

The Global Fund was created to dramatically increase the resources for the fight against three of the world's most devastating diseases as well as to direct those resources to the areas in greatest need.

In close cooperation with the WHO and the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS(UNAIDS) , the Global Fund has also played an important role in AIDS prevention around the world. It is also the main financial resource of the "3X5" AIDS-Prevention Programme.
So far, the fund has attracted more than US$6 billion in contributions from governments, institutions and individuals around the world. It hopes to raise US$21 billion in 2007.

It has been learned that staff of the Global Fund are well aware of the difficulties that Taiwan has encountered in its bid to join the international health community and would like to strengthen cooperation relations with the island as well as attract more donations from the country.
The Global Fund elected the same day Dr. Carol Jacobs, chairman of the National Commission for HIV/AIDS of Barbados, as the new chairman of the board of the fund.

JAKARTA -- President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday urged Asian and African leaders here to forge a common solution to stabilizing prices of crude oil in the world market and ease the burdens on oil-importing countries.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Higher power rates approved
CONSUMERS can expect higher electricity bills next month as the Energy Regulatory Commission yesterday announced it had approved an additional 5.56 centavos per kilowatt-hour (kWh) increase in the rates charged by the National Power Corp., the state-owned power generator.
The Philippine Star: Napocor gets 42% rate hike
The Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) approved yesterday a 42 percent increase in the average power rate of the National Power Corp. (Napocor), rejecting the state-run firm's request for a steeper increase to help ease its huge debt burden.
The Manila Times: Napocor granted smaller rate hike
The National Power Corp. (Napocor) has been allowed to raise its rate by an average of P0.0556 a kilowatt-hour (kWh) effective this month, and consumers are expected to feel the impact of the increase by June.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Koizumi issues rare war apology

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL PEOPLE URGED TO EAT MORE FISH PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: An official from the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Saturday urged local people to eat more fish products to improve health and reduce the nation's medical burden.
Hsien Wen-ta, director of COA's Fisheries Administration, made the appeal in a symposium on the country's marine policy held at National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

Noting that the fishing industry has played an important role in the economic development of many countries, Hsieh said Taiwan's fishing industry has also contributed significantly to the island's economic development, supporting the livelihood of many fishermen and providing a good source of protein to the people.

At a time when Taiwan has become an aging society, Hsieh urged the public to eat more fish products like the people of Japan and northern European countries do. Hsieh added that the fact that people of these countries are healthier and have longer life spans is absolutely related to their preference for fish products.
Stressing that Taiwan's fishing industry must be run without harming the island's ecosystem, Hsieh urged the public to monitor the industry while showing support for it.

Referring to the petitions from fishermen and fishery operators for less stringent regulations, bigger tax cuts and the introduction of more mainland Chinese fishermen, Hsieh said the government will undertake a thorough evaluation during which it will take sustainable development of the fishing industry and overall social costs into consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DISCUSSION YET ON CANDIDATE FOR TAIPEI MAYORAL RACE: DPP

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) official said Saturday that the party has yet to discuss who will represent the party in the 2006 Taipei mayoral election.

The official was responding to a local media report saying that President Chen Shui-bian met with Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan in March to discuss the possibility of nominating him to run for Taipei mayor.

According to DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan, the party is currently busy dealing with the May 14 National Assembly election and the year-end local elections and has not started to discuss matters concerning the Taipei mayoral election, which is still nearly two years away.
Cheng said the DPP has never given up on the idea of regaining the mayoralty from the Kuomintang and that it will definitely not be absent from the next election.

An unnamed DPP official said the party needs to find a candidate who is able to attract "pan-blue" voters in order to win the election, given the fact that "pan-blue" supporters outnumber "pan-green" supporters in the capital city.

Although Su displayed excellent performance in his former post as Pingtung magistrate and in dealing with last year's opposition-led demonstrations during his term as interior minister, he needs to work harder to improve the country's public order in his current position before joining the Taipei mayoral election, the official said.

Meanwhile, former Council for Hakka Affairs Chairman Luo Wen-jia, who is vying for the DPP's nomination for the year-end Taipei magistrate election, said that Su is a good candidate for Taipei mayor but that it is still too early to talk about the subject.
Luo said that changes are taking place in Taiwan's political scene faster than anyone can imagine and that no one can predict what will happen next in the Taipei mayoral campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PROVINCE OF ALBERTA PROMOTES TOURISM IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The tourism bureau of the Canadian province of Alberta has set up a branch office in Taiwan in an effort to attract more Taiwanese tourists to visit the province.
The bureau considers Taiwan a potentially lucrative source of tourists to the province and hopes to promote high-quality Canadian tourist attractions to people on the island.
Statistics show that a total of 12,900 Taiwan nationals visited Canada during the January-March period of this year, marking a 20 percent increase of the year-earlier level.

Yang Chun-yu, representative of the branch office, said she is confident about boosting that number substantially, noting that the province of Alberta has many wonderful natural attractions, including three world-class national parks and five UNESCO-designated natural heritage sites that are worth being introduced to the Taiwan people.

Yang said the office will first set up a Chinese-language Web site to make it easier for local people to get tourism information on Alberta. She added that her office will also cooperate with local travel agencies to offer high-quality tours for group-travelers.
Alberta is one of Canada's most dynamic provinces and has one of the strongest economies in North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VISITS 'SELF-STRENGTHENING' YOUTH AT HER HOME

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian paid a visit Saturday to a Hualien middle school student recently cited as a young "self-strengthening" heroine for her courage demonstrated in the face of adversity.
Chen visited Yu Ya-meng at her home in Hualien County, eastern Taiwan to "help her realize a dream of youth."

The middle school student was one of eight youths, ranging in age from 12-16, decorated with a "self-strengthening" award by the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) March 27 in recognition of their vitality and endurance in the face of challenges and hardships that their counterparts from normal families could never imagine. She is also a beneficiary of the non-profit organization's aid program for children from impoverished homes.

Last year, Yu won an education award from the president because of her excellent academic performance. While receiving the award, she pledged that she would buy an air conditioner for her grandparents in the future after she earned her first pay check from work. However, Yu didn't have to wait long to fulfill her promise as President Chen brought an air-conditioner with him on his visit to Yu's family.

Chen said that he was also born into a poor family which he said could not even afford a television set. Recalling that he had spent his first student scholarship on a TV set, the president said he understands Yu's dream and ambition to help her family live well.
Chen encouraged Yu to maintain her efforts to achieve her dreams, as he had done in his youth.
In return, Yu presented Chen with a stone tea pot as a gift. She said that she hopes the stone pot can work like "Aladdin's magic lamp" by bestowing on Chen strength to protect Taiwan.

Yu, a student of Hua Jen Middle School in the township of Chian, expressed her wish to pursue higher education and said someday she will serve in the military. For now, Yu said, all she can do is study hard to achieve her goal.

The TFCF -- a Taiwan version of the U.S. Christian Children's Fund (CCF) -- has been lauded by Chen as "a driving force enabling the government to strenuously and undauntedly work to administer the country" for the unconditional care it provides for disadvantaged children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU PROPOSES 'LOVE TAIWAN' TEST FOR KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) lawmakers on Saturday put forth a series of questions to test opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan according to what they call the "love Taiwan index" ahead of his planned visit to China.
TSU Legislators Huang Shih-cho and Tseng Tsan-teng said the test is designed to evaluate whether Lien is fit to make the trip, scheduled for April 26 to May 3.

In the test, Lien is asked to answer what the relations between Taiwan and China are, whether he will ask Chinese President Hu Jintao to promote democratization in China, whether he will rebuke China for enacting the Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of force against Taiwan, and whether he will fight for Taiwan's sovereignty and its right to participate in the international community.

Huang and Tseng said they fear Lien will damage the national interests of Taiwan because Lien has refused to report to the Democratic Progressive Party government before the trip and has consistently confronted the government.
They called it a "disgrace" for Lien to accept Beijing's invitation to visit under the condition of recognizing the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER BELIEVES KMT CHAIRMAN WILL ABIDE BY LAW DURING CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that he believes opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will abide by Taiwan law during his upcoming trip to China.

Calling Lien a well-educated intellectual, Hsieh said Lien should be able to differentiate between what is lawful and what is unlawful and should be aware that signing an agreement with China requires the government's authorization.

Previous reports suggested that Lien might sign a peace accord with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to officially end the KMT-CPC civil war that lasted around two decades in China before the KMT fled to Taiwan. The KMT has denied the reports.

On the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union's plan to stage a demonstration against Lien's China trip, Hsieh said the expression of different opinions through lawful means is acceptable in a pluralistic society.
Hsieh urged the people to remain rational toward Lien's China trip and avoid resorting to violence during the demonstration, saying that doing otherwise would undermine the spirit of democracy.

On a local media report that Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan might represent the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to run in the 2006 Taipei mayoral election, Hsieh said that he has not heard anything about it and that it is still premature to discuss the subject.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAZAAR HELD TO RAISE FUNDS FOR BATTLE AGAINST CANCER

TEXT.P: The state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. and the private Hope Society for Cancer Treatment jointly held a bazaar Saturday to raise funds for the battle against cancer.
The only items for sale were indigenous Taiwan butterfly orchids because of their resilience, according to the bazaar organizers.

A Taisugar official said that the company hopes cancer patients can be as resilient as the flowers in battling their disease. The Taiwan butterfly orchid produces blossoms in December that usually last until spring, surviving through the cold winter months, he said.

Several popular entertainers, including singer Terry Lin, joined in the event to help raise funds. Lin auctioned off the bazaar's first orchid, which received a top bid of NT$6,666 (US$212). He also sang at the bazaar to cheer up cancer patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINAL LAWMAKER CALLS FOR JAPANESE ATONEMENT FOR WARTIME CRIMES

TEXT.P: Japan should take concrete steps, instead of just offering empty rhetoric, to atone for its World War II atrocities, an aboriginal lawmaker said Saturday.
Legislator May Chin of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union made the call a day after Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi apologized for his country's World War II aggression in Asia.

Addressing a summit of Asian and African leaders in Jakarta, Indonesia Friday, Koizumi acknowledged that imperial Japan's occupation of much of East Asia "caused tremendous damage and suffering for the people of many countries."

"Japan squarely faces these facts of history in a spirit of humility, " Koizumi told representatives of dozens of nations assembled to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the first Asia-Africa conference.
Commenting on Koizumi's remarks, Chin said at a news conference that the Japanese prime minister's expression of "deep remorse" was not enough to make amends for its wartime atrocities.

"Actions speak louder than words, " Chin said, adding that Japanese leaders should kneel while apologizing to show their sincere repentance and offer financial compensation for Taiwanese "comfort women" who were forced into prostitution to serve Japanese soldiers during World War II and bereaved families of a number of aboriginal tribesmen who were forced to join the war in the 1940s when Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule.
Chin pointed out that Koizumi's remarks didn't go beyond what former Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama said in 1995 in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II.
Over the past decade, Chin said, the Japanese government has only offered rhetorical apologies while doing little to make amends for its past mistakes.
Worse still, Chin said, the Japanese government has approved history textbooks compiled by rightist scholars that whitewash or even distort Japan's militarist past and wartime atrocities.
Chin said she will lead 60 representatives of Taiwanese aboriginal citizens who died during World War II to Japan June 13 to stage a protest at the controversial Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo.

The Shinto shrine is dedicated to 2.5 million Japanese war dead, including convicted war criminals. It also lists the names of 28,000-plus Taiwanese and 21,000 Korean soldiers, most of whom were forced into military service under Japan's colonial rule.
"We'll ask the Japanese government to withdraw the tablets bearing the names of our aboriginal cousins and compensate their bereaved families," Chin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COMPUTING, NETWORKING BUSINESS LEADERS TO VISIT U.S.

TEXT.P: A delegation of local computing and networking business leaders, to be headed by Minister Without Portfolio Lin Ferng-Ching, will pay a visit to the United States from April 27 to May 8 at the arrangement of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), according to an AIT news release Saturday.

The news release said that the mission is being organized by the the U.S. liaison office's commercial section to familiarize qualified Taiwan companies with U.S. technology and expertise, seek suitable products or technologies to distribute or represent in Taiwan, help participants better understand new IT technology trends and applications, and facilitate strategic alliances, business partnerships and joint venture activities in Taiwan.

The delegation will represent a cross-section of Taiwan's technology sector, including prominent decision-makers from public organizations, quasi-governmental organizations and private-sector technology firms, while private sector participants will include industry leaders in the areas of software and information services/solutions, telecom services, systems integration, network services, E-Business, and IT manufacturing, the AIT said.

The institute indicated that Taiwan is a leading producer of an impressive array of information technology products, and many of Taiwan's key IT players are shifting resources to "ubiquitous" computing applications and services and are seeking relevant U.S. suppliers and technology partners.

The delegation will visit U.S. high-tech firms leading the development of "IT Everywhere" technology and related applications, such as Microsoft, Intel, Yahoo, EDS, Cisco, Texas Instruments; small and medium high-tech companies; as well as leading academic R&D institutions and professional associations active in the IT arena, according to the AIT news release.

It also said that the delegation is scheduled to depart Taiwan April 27 for San Jose, California. After visiting Silicon Valley, the group will visit Dallas, Texas, and then Washington, D.C., before returning to Taipei.

The National Information and Communication Initiative Committee of the Executive Yuan, the Information Service Industry Association, and the Institute for Information Industry Market Intelligence Center are all supporting this mission, the news release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ARRIVES IN ROME TO ATTEND NEW POPE'S INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: An official Republic of China delegation, headed by Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, arrived in Rome Saturday to attend Pope Benedict XVI's inauguration mass scheduled for Sunday.

Su and other delegation members were greeted by a Vatican protocol official, ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tou Chou-seng and ROC Representative to Italy Lin Chi-cheng upon their arrival at Da Vinci Airport.
In addition to Su, other delegation members include Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Ou-Yang Jui-hsiung and Ambassador Tou.
Because of Beijing's diplomatic embargo, the Vatican is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
President Chen Shui-bian traveled to the Vatican earlier this month to attend the late Pope John Paul II's April 8 funeral, making him the first serving ROC head of state to set foot in Europe.
As the interior minister is in charge of religious affairs, President Chen decided to name Su to head the ROC delegation to the new pope's inauguration.
Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger of Germany, 78, was elected the new pope Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO BOOST EXPORTS TO SUSTAIN ECONOMIC GROWTH: CIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to speed up its export growth in order to sustain the momentum of the country's economic development, analysts at the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) said Saturday.

Taiwan posted a trade surplus of just US$290 million in the first quarter of this year, with trade deficits registered for January and March. The figure was US$1.66 billion lower than the year-earlier figure.

Exports rose 7.8 percent year-on-year to US$42.84 billion during the three months to the end of March, marking the first time a growth rate of less than 10 percent has been recorded since the final quarter of 2003.
Meanwhile, imports amounted to US$42.55 billion, up 12.6 percent over the year-earlier figure.

Data provided by customs authorities indicates that the import of transport vehicles saw the highest growth, at 60 percent, with the import of trains for the high-speed railway system contributing most to that growth.
CIER analysts predicted that the import growth rate is likely to slow down after the demand for high-speed trains is met.

However, they said it will be unfavorable to Taiwan's economic growth if the government does not try to enhance export growth, especially when export orders are declining while the new Taiwan dollar continues to rise against the U.S. dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Four Top Officers Cleared by Army in Prison Abuses
A high-level investigation of the U.S. Army has cleared four of the five top Army officers overseeing prison policies and operations in Iraq of responsibility for the abuse of detainees there, Congressional and administration officials said Friday. The findings, which provoked outrage from some civil rights groups and Democratic aides, came nearly a year after shocking photographs of American military police officers stacking naked Iraqi prisoners in a human pyramid and of other abuses first telecast nationally. So far, only a small number of soldiers, mostly from the enlisted ranks have faced courts-martial for their actions at Abu Ghraib and elsewhere. Dozens of others have faced administrative discipline for abusing captives at other detention sites and battlefield interrogation stations across Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 129,000 CRIMINAL CASES REPORTED IN Q1: NPA

TEXT.P: A total of 129,017 criminal cases were reported in the first quarter of 2005, up 14,008 cases, or 12.18 percent, from the same period last year, according to tallies released by the National Police Agency (NPA) Saturday.
The crime resolution rate stood at 63.11 percent, which was 0.96 percentage points higher than the year-earlier figure, NPA statistics showed.
Among the various categories of crime, drug abuse, computer crime and theft registered the most significant rise.
A total of 12,622 drug abuse cases were reported in the three months to the end of March, for a year-on-year increase of 5,017 cases.
Computer crime accounted for 5,571 cases, up 4,128 cases, or 88.67 percent, from last year.
Meanwhile, theft cases totalled 75,158, marking an increase of 3,324 cases over last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE MND NOT TO COMPROMISE ON LAFAYETTE COMMISSION CASE

TEXT.P: Two lawmakers familiar with military affairs urged the Ministry of National Defense (MND) Saturday to defend national interests in negotiating the Lafayette frigate kickback case with French authorities.

Legislators Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and Lin Yu-fang of the opposition People First Party made the call after the French daily Le Monde reported Friday that the French government has named a former finance ministry official to negotiate with Taiwan over compensation for a Lafayette frigate commission scandal.

According to the report, the French government hopes to resolve the case through negotiations instead of a court verdict. And if the international arbitrary court handling the case rules that France must compensate Taiwan for illegal kickbacks in the Lafayette frigate deal, the report said, France is hopeful that a fugitive Taiwan arms broker can be made to pay part of the amount.

Taiwan purchased six Lafayette-class frigates built by French defense contractor Thomson-CSF for US$2.8 billion in 1991. The contract signed between the ROC Navy and the French firm clearly stipulated that no kickbacks were allowed in the deal.

However, allegations about kickbacks over the deal emerged after the death of Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng, head of the navy's arms acquisition office, whose body was found floating in the sea off the east coast of Taiwan in late 1993.

It has been alleged that Yin was murdered to prevent him from blowing the whistle on rampant corruption in the military -- including the Lafayette deal. Kickbacks involved in the Lafayette deal allegedly reached an estimated US$500 million.

The ROC Navy has filed an appeal with an international commercial arbitrary court in France in August 2001 to seek compensation from French authorities. Moreover, the Navy asked for an additional US$99 million in damages to its reputation.
Commenting on the latest French media report, the two legislators said it is understandable that France would seek to consult with Taiwan over the Lafayette kickback issue.

Lee and Lin further said they believe that the court ruling would very likely be unfavorable to France. They urged the MND and other relevant government agencies to start preparations for possible negotiations with France over the kickback issue.
The two lawmakers also said the MND should stand firm on its stance and defend national interests in future negotiations.

As to whether the MND should agree to the reported French proposal that Andrew Wang, an arms broker who fled Taiwan in 1993 and has been wanted since September 2000 for suspected involvement in the alleged Lafayette kickback scandal and the subsequent murder of Navy Captain Yin, be made to pay part of the compensation, the two lawmakers said it should depend evidence presented by France. According to the contract, France alone is liable to pay the compensation.

A Swiss federal court has ruled that Taiwan, France and the Principality of Liechtenstein should be given access to Swiss legal files, particularly documents regarding the Andrew Wang family's bank accounts in Switzerland, to facilitate investigations into the alleged Lafayette kickback scandal.

Swiss judicial authorities have frozen Wang's Swiss bank accounts, which contain some US$600 million in suspected slush funds used as kickbacks from the Lafayette frigate deal, according to previous press report.
Wang and his son, Wang Chia-hsing, might also have bank accounts with deposits totaling US$100 million in Liechtenstein and the British-administered Cayman Islands in the Caribbean Sea.
Since Aug. 1, 2000, an ROC special investigative team has been probing arms procurement scandals allegedly connected with the death of Navy Captain Yin under suspicious circumstances.
No major breakthrough has been achieved because key suspect Wang, who is believed to be deeply involved in the Lafayette kickback scandal, remains at large, reportedly residing in London.
The investigation team has not yet discovered any hard evidence of alleged Lafayette kickbacks paid to Taiwan officials.
To speed up the investigations, the team has recently recruited several prosecutors versed in financial and banking affairs to assist in tracking the money trail.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LAUDS SUCCESS OF CLA'S JOB CREATION PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Saturday lauded a multiple job creation program initiated by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) for successfully helping more than 50,000 people land jobs since it's implementation four years ago.
Hsieh made the remarks while addressing the opening of an exhibition to demonstrate the results of the job creation program at the Red Playhouse square in Taipei's bustling Simending district.

The premier said the program is part of the government's efforts to take care of Taiwan's aboriginal people, who make up roughly 2 percent of the island's overall population. He noted that some 15 percent of the people who have found employment through the program are aboriginal.

CLA Minister Chen Chu, speaking on the same occasion, explained that the program was launched mainly with the aim of helping middle-aged and elderly citizens as well as aboriginal people find employment. With the cooperation of more than 1,000 private organizations around the island, the council has helped many unemployed people find work in their hometowns, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SOFTENS TONE ON OPPOSITION LEADERS' CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he would offer his blessing for the two opposition leaders' forthcoming visits to China if they faithfully abide by the domestic law throughout their trips.
Chen was quoted as having made the remarks while lecturing at the Ketagalan Institutem, which was founded by Chen to nurture a new generation of leaders for public service.

Under the present law, Chen said the government cannot ban the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong -- from traveling to China.

"They are leaders of civic groups. None of our existing laws prohibit them from visiting China. So long as they abide by law during their visits, we can offer our blessing, " Chen said, adding that they might be able to offer the government first-hand information after they exchange views with senior Chinese officials.

Probably, Chen said, their China visits could offer inspiration or guide for future development of relations across the Taiwan Strait. Chen further said he has never opposed the two "pan-blue" leaders' China visits. "What I wants to stress is that during their visits, they should refrain from touching on anything involving national sovereignty or public authority without prior government authorization, " Chen said, adding that he is pleased to see that KMT officials have repeatedly stressed in recent days that Lien would not sign any agreements during his China visit.
Lien is scheduled to talk with Chen over phone Monday about his China visit.
Chen said it will mark the first time in more than four years that Lien is willing to talk with him.

"I appreciate his decision. The phone call will mark the first step for constructive interaction and reconciliation between the ruling and opposition parties after all these years of standoff and confrontation. We should welcome and recognize this move," Chen said, adding he will not insist that Lien address him as "president" during their scheduled phone conversation.

For many years, Chen said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have no direct contact and have to rely on indirect channels or media reports to know the other side's views on many issues. The two opposition leaders' China visits can offer opportunities for direct dialogue with top Chinese leaders and thus provide first-hand information for government reference in policy formulation, he added.

Lien, a former ROC premier and vice president, is scheduled to depart Taipei April 26 for what he bills a"peace of journey" to China. He will be the first KMT chairman ever to set foot in china since the party, which one ruled all of China, retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese communist. He will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao April 29.

Lien lost his presidential bids in 2000 and 2004. He has been unwilling to address Chen as president since losing the 2004 presidential election by a slim margin. He filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory. The two lawsuits have both been rejected by the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S CHIEF OF STAFF TO VISIT U.S.

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff will visit the United States in mid-May to meet with U.S. officials, scholars and media executives, government sources said Saturday.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun is scheduled to depart for New York May 15, the sources said.

Yu made a low-profile visit to Japan earlier this month. His upcoming U.S. visit has caused attention as it will come after China's enactment of its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan and two opposition leaders' visits to China.
According to media reports, Yu will meet with U.S. officials from the State Department, the Pentagon and the National Security Council during his visit.

In an interview with CNA, Yu kept a low profile on his May visit, saying that he will mainly attend his son's graduation ceremony and meet with some friends. Yu's son has completed his master's program from Columbia University and a graduation ceremony is scheduled for May 18. Besides New York, Yu's U.S. itinerary will also include a stop in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. ARMS BAN LIFTING TO IMPAIR TAIWAN'S HUMAN RIGHTS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Saturday that if the European Union lifts its ban on arms sales to China, it would hurt Taiwan's freedom and human rights.
Such a move would also be a stark irony to E.U. countries which have been known for their advocacy of freedom, democracy and human rights.

Hsieh made the remarks in a videotaped speech delivered to more than 300 members of the International Society for Human Rights (ISHR) , who were gathering in Germany for the non-government organization's annual congress. The society is headquartered in Frankfurt, Germany.

Noting that China's recently enacted anti-secession law codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan, Hsieh said if the E.U. lifts its arms embargo against China would be tantamount to endorsing such an ill-intentioned legislation.
It's immoral to force a liberal, democratic Taiwan to unify an undemocratic China, Hsieh said, adding that the E.U. should refrain from throwing weight behind China by lifting its arms ban.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 24 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, April 24:
09: 30, A "Taiwan for WHO" forum will be held at the Taiwan International House (No. 125, Fl. 14, Nanjing East Rd. Sec. 2, Taipei).
11: 10, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a Lions Club meeting in Hsinchu County.
11: 20, Premier Frank Hsieh will inspect a Tachia River dredging project in Taichung County in central Taiwan.
16:00, Premier Frank Hsieh will attend the inaugural ceremony for Kukuan Park in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Top Army Officers Are Cleared in Abuse Cases; One General Will Likely Get Reprimand Over Abu Ghraib.
An Army inspector general's report has cleared senior Army officers of wrongdoing in the abuse of military prisoners in Iraq and elsewhere, the paper quoted government officials familiar with the findings as saying yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 24, or the 16th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches its first satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while on its way to Mt. Ali in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: West and East Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
2001: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicks off in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. BEEF BACK ON THE MENU IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: U.S. beef is back on the menu in Taiwan after being banned for a year-and-a-half because of the discovery of a single case of mad cow disease in Washington State.

A 2,170 kilogram shipment of U.S. beef in 166 cartons arrived at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Sunday morning, and quarantine officials from the Council of Agriculture (COA) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs took random samples for testing. Results of the examinations are expected in two weeks.
Importers are eager to fill the backlog of orders for the meat from local restaurants and supermarkets.
The Department of Health (DOH) announced in late March that Taiwan will conditionally reopen its market to U.S. boneless beef from cattle under 30 months of age beginning April 16.

Meat from U.S. cattle under 30 months old, clear of bones, offal and specific risk materials, including brain, trigeminal ganglia, dorsal root ganglia and spinal marrow, and with certificates issued by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) , can now be imported into Taiwan. Ground beef is not included in the opening list, bureau officials added.

The DOH Bureau of Food Safety, meanwhile, has asked the USDA to provide Taiwan with a list of the names of legal, contracted U.S. slaughterhouses to be used as a reference to compare with the sources of the newly imported beef.
COA officials said last month that an import ban on live cattle from the United States will remain in place in line with regulations set forth by the World Animal Health Organization.

Taiwan suspended beef imports from the United States in December 2003 due to safety concerns over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), also known as mad cow disease, after the discovery of a single case of mad cow disease on a ranch in the U.S. state of Washington.

Taiwan health and agriculture officials have traveled to the U.S. to conduct on-site inspections of the implementation of U.S. safeguards against mad cow disease and have recently completed the necessary reviews for resuming the beef trade.

Taiwan purchased US$325 million worth of U.S. beef and beef products in 2003 and was the sixth-largest importer of U.S. beef before Taiwan imposed the ban in December 2003. Since then, Australian beef has replaced U. S. beef in the Taiwan market.

More than 40 countries, including Japan, the largest importer, banned U.S. beef in the aftermath of the mad cow disease scare, seriously affecting the U.S. beef export trade, which is worth at least US$3.8 billion a year. Big names in the beef export trade, including Tyson Foods, Inc. and Cargill, Inc., have exerted great pressure on the USDA for an early resumption of exports to these countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD NOT CAVE IN TO NAME GAME FOR WHO BID: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan should join the World Health Organization (WHO) under its own name rather than "Taiwan, China, " which would downgrade it into a part of China's territory, the head of a private think tank said Sunday.

At a seminar organized by the Taiwan New Century Foundation on ways of participating in the WHO, the foundation's president, Chen Lung-chu, said the prospects for Taiwan's WHO bid this year are better than in the past because China, which has gone out of its way to shut Taiwan out of any international group, might soften its attitude somewhat to try to quell the international flap that has ensued after its enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which legalizes China's use of force against Taiwan.

Taiwan, however, should not accept any name that suggests it is a part of China for membership in the WHO; rather, it should insist on a name that reflects its status as an independent country separate from China, Chen said.

The first choice for Taiwan, of course, would be to join as a full member. Since that is impossible as only U.N. members can enjoy this states, the next choice is to participate in the organization as an observer under the name of the Republic of China, Chen said.
"Taiwan, China," which indicates that Taiwan is a part of China, is not a viable option, Chen added.
Citing the WHO's promise during the 2005 World Health Day on April 7 to make every mother and child count, Chen said the promise will never be delivered with Taiwan excluded from the WHO.
Taiwan will try for the ninth time in a row to have its observership bid in the World Health Assembly (WHA) put on the WHA agenda for discussion at its annual conference on May 16 in Geneva.
For the ROC to join the WHA as an observer, a majority in the assembly must support such a motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO TAKE NEW TACK ON WHO ENTRY STRATEGY: MOFA OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan will use a two-pronged approach this year to try to get Taiwan's bid to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA) as an observer on the agenda for discussion, a senior official with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Sunday.

Liao Tung-chou, head of a World Heath Organization (WHO) task force under the foreign ministry, said at a colloquium that Taiwan will continue to seek to join the WHA -- the WHO's decision-making arm -- as an observer this year, while seeking to participate in operations of the International Health Regulations (IHR).

Still based on a "health entity" concept, Taiwan will continue to push for WHA observer status this year, the ninth consecutive year since 1997, with international support also expecting to increase, Liao said.

Due to China's recalcitrance, Taiwan's bids have largely gone nowhere. At last year's Assembly, the United States and Japan voted in favor of putting the issue on the agenda, but China and its satellites kept the motion off the agenda.
This time around, Liao said, the government has decided to adjust its strategy after consultations with the United States and other allies.
"We'll give top priority to actually taking part in WHO activities in a two-pronged approach as our initial goal," Liao said.
Taiwan will use the influence of the United States and Japan's "yes" votes last year to encourage the European Union's to follow suit this year, Liao noted.
Taiwan will also seek support from its diplomatic allies as well as pro- Taiwan countries to have revisions to the IHR articles passed by the WHA, he added.
The revised IHR will adopt a "universally applicable" principle to allow for Taiwan's participation in WHO activities.

Once the proposed amendments are passed, Liao said, the IHR will stipulate that its provisions will be applicable to all humans to protect them from being infected with internationally communicable diseases.
The WHO is expected to pass the proposed IHR revision package at the annual World Health Assembly (WHA) in Geneva on May 16.
