A calm, deliberate Zacarias Mousasoui pleaded guilty to conspiring with Al Qaeda operatives who were involved in the Sept.11 terrorist plot. But he defiantly vowed to "fight every inch" of the way against being put to death because, he said, he actually was recruited for a separate assault: flying a large plane into the White House.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP MISSION HEADS FOR BEIJING TO ARRANGE FOR CHAIRMAN'S VISIT

TEXT.P: An eight-member delegation of the People First Party (PFP) left for Beijing Sunday via Hong Kong to arrange for a visit by party Chairman James Soong to mainland China planned for early next month.

PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng, who led the group, said that Soong will not represent the government or any other individual when he visits China and talks with Communist Party of China (CPC) officials, including CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao, who is also the Chinese president.

Soong will make the visit in his capacity as PFP chairman and will talk with Hu based on the 10-point accord that Soong inked with President Chen Shui-bian Feb. 24 to seek common ground and build peace across the Taiwan Strait, Chin said, adding that the PFP very much hopes to help in pushing for government-to-government dialogue between Taiwan and China and make great contributions in cross-strait peace.

Brushing aside the controversial "1992 consensus" and the disputed "one China" question, he said that the PFP respects the president's stance in this field as everyone has his or her own interpretation. But he claimed that the public is quite aware of the outcome of the 1992 meeting attended by Taiwan and Chinese officials in Hong Kong.

He added that the 10-point Chen- Soong accord will form part of the government's China policy in the future since 90 percent of the people in Taiwan approved of the agreement that pledges to maintain the cross-strait status quo and rules out Taiwan independence during President Chen's tenure.
The PFP mission is slated to return to Taiwan next Wednesday.

The PFP is Taiwan's second-largest opposition party, which comprises the pro-unification "pan blue alliance" with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the New Party countering the pro-independence "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan is also scheduled to leave for China next Tuesday for a visit through May 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN GIVES TENTATIVE SUPPORT TO 'THREE-IN-ONE ELECTION'

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supports a proposal to hold three local government elections simultaneously by the end of this year, but complementary measures should be in place to ensure that everything goes smoothly, party Chairman Su Tseng-chang said Sunday.

One day after President Chen Shui-bian threw his weight behind the Executive Yuan's plan to hold the elections of the chiefs and councilors of counties and cities, and the chiefs of townships near the end of the year on the same day, the DPP chairman, who initially opposed the idea in a rare conflict between the DPP government and the party, softened his attitude by saying that the plan would need to be carefully thought out to avoid chaos.

Citing warnings by Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin that holding the three elections at the same time would give corrupt politicians a good chance to rig the elections, Su said it would be an enormous task for election and law enforcement officials to prevent fraud.
"Complementary measures should be in place to ensure that the president's plan of reforming the country's electoral system does not go awry." Su argued.

Su, who will be responsible for the party's performance in various elections, had criticized the "three-in-one election" as a political ploy to ensure the defeat of the DPP in the local elections when Premier Frank Hsieh unveiled it on March 30. The premier had said that the move was to shave costs incurred from holding separate elections.

Su dismissed as nonsense speculation that the president's decision to support the premier in the dispute was an indication of the president's personal preference for Hsieh over Su as Chen's possible successor.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CARPET FOR LIEN A SMOKE SCREEN FOR UNITED FRONT: DISSIDENT

TEXT.P: The red carpet treatment that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will receive in Beijing will be nothing more than window dressing by the Chinese Communists as a united front against Taiwan, democracy activist Wang Dan said Saturday.

Wang, a former leader of the pro-democracy demonstration that was crushed by the Chinese military in Tiananmen Square in 1989, who now lives in the United States, said that another reason that China will be falling over itself to embrace the KMT delegation is to curry favor with Washington, which has long advocated that cross-Taiwan Strait issues be resolved peacefully or via dialogues.

In a speech delivered to a group of overseas Chinese in Los Angeles, Wang suggested that Lien, who is scheduled to embark on his self-styled "journey of peace" to China April 26, should make it clear to Chinese President Hu Jintao that change must come to the China's political regime, including democratization and freedom of speech. Lien must also speak on behalf of Taiwan to protect the island's long-term interests, he said.

Wang, a Harvard University doctoral candidate who is currently on a research project on the West Coast, said that even if the KMT chairman signs an agreement with his Beijing hosts, it would be "just rubbish, " given the true colors of the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Noting that every written accord that the KMT and the CPC reached in the past ended up in the trash can of history, Wang, a history major at Beijing University before the 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre, said that the Chinese Communists are untrustworthy and not interested in matters that only benefit others.
Wang, the founder of the Chinese Constitutional Reform Association in the United States, has visited Taiwan many times since he first set foot on the island on March 18, 1999.
He was in Taipei in January 2003 to launch his two new books written in Chinese -- one a collection of poems and the other a work of prose -- both published by Taipei's Locus Publishing Co.
He was in Taipei again in July 2003 for six weeks at the invitation of the Taipei City Government as an artist-in-residence.
Wang was jailed in July 1989 for his part in the pro-democracy demonstration and was released in February 1993. He was arrested again in October 1996 and sentenced to a further 11-year prison term.
In April 1998, he was released on parole on medical grounds and permitted to travel to the United States for treatment -- a move that effectively sent him into exile.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACING DOWNWARD PRESSURE IN H2 ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: If China continues to macro-manage its economy and the global economy keeps slowing down, Taiwan's economic growth in the second half of this year is expected to be adjusted downward, economists said Sunday.

The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research on April 14 lowered its 2005 estimate of Taiwan's economic growth rate from 4.37 percent to 4.05 percent, and the government's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics also adjusted its forecast down to 4.21 percent.
Foreign banks in Taiwan have set their forecasts of Taiwan's 2005 economic growth at between 4.0 percent and 4.5 percent.

On Taiwan's economy, Cheng Chen-mao, an economist at Citibank, said that second quarter growth may be even lower than the first quarter, though many have predicted it will improve in the second half. Two factors must be taken into account for this, Cheng said: to what extent China macro-manages its economy, and how strongly the U.S. economy recovers.
A third factor affecting Taiwan's Q3 and Q4 performance will be how strongly Taiwan's electronics industry recovers, Cheng added.

He said Taiwan's foreign trade surplus has shrunk mainly because its electronics industry has not recovered well, idling a large portion of production facilities. Therefore, he said, increases in orders for and prices of Taiwan's electronics products will be a key indicator of Taiwan's economic performance in the second half of the year.

China has been an important market for Taiwan, absorbing Taiwan's electronics output in step with the world market. Over the past few years, however, Taiwan has increased steel, petrochemical and other exports to China. If China keeps implementing its macro-management policy, Taiwan's export businesses will definitely be affected, Cheng said.

Citibank has forecast that China's economy will grow 8.5 percent this year, but the Chinese government recently announced that the growth rate for the first quarter was 9.5 percent. Therefore, Cheng said, China will likely take further steps to cool down its economy.
An economist with Taiwan's Standard Chartered, Li Chang-tai, agreed that the Chinese and U.S. economic situations will affect Taiwan's performance in the second half of 2005.

As the two major economies are doing quite well, as is Taiwan's domestic demand, and the government is seeking to boost the economy, Standard Chartered Taiwan remains optimistic about the island's growth in the second half, Li said.

Li attributed the poor first quarter trade surplus -- a mere US$290 million -- to slow export growth of semiconductors and rising oil prices that brought up the total value of imports and slowed down export businesses.
At the same time, he pointed out, strong domestic demand and real estate investments have been buttressing Taiwan's economic development.
He warned that oil price fluctuations and the island's growing dependence on the Chinese market are "risk factors" that Taiwan must face.

Professor Chu Hao-min of National Chengchi University in Taipei said as the global economy has been slowing, import demand in such major markets as Europe and the U.S. -- Taiwan's major export markets -- has naturally affected Taiwan's export performance.
"If not for the Chinese market, Taiwan would have long ago suffered a trade deficit," Chu said.
He further pointed out that Taiwan's current account surplus has been shrinking, capital outflows have exceeded inflows, and the international balance of payments is feared to worsen.

But this may also signal an increase in the import of production machinery and equipment, which would mean a boom in investment. "That would be a good thing for the long-term growth of the economy, " he said.
Chu did not agree with Standard Chartered's upbeat view on Taiwan's real estate market, saying housing prices in Taiwan are approaching their ceiling.

What will have a critical effect on Taiwan's second-half economic performance is business investments, domestic consumption and the government's measures to stimulate the economy, in addition to the Chinese and U.S. economies, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE MILLION CARD-CARRYING CHINESE COMMUNISTS HAVE BEEN 'REBORN'

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 people joined a rally Sunday in downtown Taipei to celebrate the "important milestone of one million members having quit the Communist Party of China."

Li Ching-mei, organizer of the rally on Ketagalan Boulevard, said that the "quit the CPC" campaign is unstoppable, and the one million who have quit have been "reborn." Li hoped even more CPC members will quit.

The campaign, sponsored by The Epoch Times newspaper, attracted support from more than 150 civilian groups all around the world, including Hong Kong, New York, Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane, Li said.
People in other cities in North America, Europe, and Japan also participated in the "quit the CPC" campaign.
During the past 24 hours, some 20,000 people have participated in rallies or marches, including 10,000 from around Taiwan, according to the organizer.
As of Sunday, according to The Epoch Times, more than 1.06 million people have signed up via the Internet to give up their membership in the Communist Party of China and its affiliated organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN MUST REJECT 'ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE WHILE IN CHINA: DPP WHIP

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not condone Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien's actions if he intends to yield to Beijing's "one China" principle in talks with Communist Party of China (CPC) officials, DPP lawmaker William Lai said Sunday.

Lai, a DPP caucus whip at the Legislative Yuan, said that the DPP would give its blessing to Lien only when it is fully confident that the KMT chairman will not do anything that might infringe upon the government's authority in talks with CPC officials during his visit to mainland China from April 26 to May 3.
If Lien does something that is in violation of the Republic of China's laws during his trip, the government must deal with him strictly by the book, he said.

Although President Chen Shui-bian said the previous day that he would give Lien his blessing if the KMT head promises to observe Taiwan's laws and denounces Beijing's "one China" principle when talking with CPC officials, Lai claimed that the president has never changed his position on this point and that he was trying to do his best to remind Lien never to hurt Taiwan's interests during his China visit.
In the face of Beijing's united front tactics, Taiwan's opposition and ruling camps should unite and not be fractured, he urged.
He also called for calm among pro-independence supporters who have threatened to intercept Lien on his way to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport before his departure for China Tuesday.

Pointing out that everyone in a democratic society is free to express his or her own viewpoint, Lai, however, said that the DPP hopes to see no conflict and called for law and order as the main principle for people to follow.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR ADVOCATES CROSS-STRAIT 'CONFEDERATION OF STATES'

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou advocated a "confederation of states" concept Sunday that was spearheaded by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan in 2004 as a "more realistic" solution to cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Noting that "many people favor the confederation idea, " Ma, concurrently a KMT vice chairman, said that one of Lien's goals in his forthcoming visit to China is to stress to the Beijing leadership the fact that Taiwan and China are two independent political entities under separate governmental systems.

In his book published prior to the 2004 presidential election, Lien said that "on the possible ways of future integration between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a confederation system is an idea worthy of consideration, inasmuch as it can maintain the momentum of both sides moving toward the direction of unification."

Ma noted, however, that Lien's "confederation system" concept may not be acceptable to the sitting Beijing leadership at present since this system is a "commonwealth" system under which Taiwan and China are two separate states with their own sovereignty.
Even so, he said, it would not be an obstacle barring the KMT chairman from seeking to meet with Beijing leadership to end the long political impasse across the Strait.

Ma said that although the two sides do not recognize each other, private cross-strait exchanges have been so frequent and has been close to a level surpassing the one that the two Germanys enjoyed before they were unified.

He said the two rival sides should first seek to defuse tensions and military threats before they can talk about cooperation, followed by the signing of a peace agreement and economic cooperation and development accords.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU GIVES QUALIFIED BLESSING TO KMT CHIEF'S TRIP TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu followed President Chen Shui-bian's lead in giving her blessing Sunday to Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's proposed trip to China, but was reserved about the impact of Lien's visit.

Speaking in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan on the sidelines of a conference of a local Lion's Club, Lu said that any act within the law will be protected; those that are not will be punished, adding that she hopes Lien succeeds in his trip, which is not prohibited by law.
The vice president, who is known as an outspoken critic of China, said it is difficult to predict whether Lien's trip will be helpful or harmful to the country.

She cast into doubt Lien's claims that his trip will promote peace between Taiwan and the mainland, asking, "Can anyone believe that one person's single trip to Beijing can bring peace across the Taiwan Strait, especially in light of the KMT's past unsuccessful dealings with the Communist Party of China?"

Lien's trip, set for April 26, a month-and-a-half after China's enactment of a law to provide it with a legal basis to use force against Taiwan, will inevitably cause Taiwan's forces to relax their guard and will cause soldiers to question the wisdom of confronting China, Lu claimed.
The vice president said she hopes Lien does not compromise the country's sovereignty, dignity, and that he will respect the Republic of China's Constitution and its leaders.

Citing the fact that Lien addresses her as "Miss Lu" and President Chen Shui-bian as "Mr. Chen, " the vice president said: "He is setting himself up to be the butt of international jokes by continuing to address us in this way."
Lien, who lost to Chen in the 2004 presidential race by a slim margin, has never admitted defeat. Instead, he filed two lawsuits to have the election overturned. Both cases were thrown out of court.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION ATTENDS POPE BENEDICT XVI'S INAUGURATION
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, April 24 (CNA) (By Tony Fang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A delegation from Taiwan attended the inauguration of Pope Benedict XVI along with 36 heads of state and 140 delegations from around the world on Sunday.
The Taiwan delegation, led by Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan arrived at St. Peter's Square where the inaugural mass was to be held at 9:30 a.m.

The climax of the two-hour mass is the pope receiving the symbol of papacy, a fisherman's ring, a gold signet ring showing St. Peter in a boat fishing, and a white wool scarf decorated with five black crosses known as the pallium.
At the end of the ceremony, the pope walked around the square to greet the dignities and attendees, including 400,000 to 500,000 faithful from around the world.
Notably among them were about 100,000 faithful from the pope's native Germany, including his brother Rev. George Ratzinger from Regensburg, Germany.
For safety, Italian police imposed a ban on air and ground traffic within a radius of eight kilometers around the square from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S CHINA TRIP IS FOR CROSS-STRAIT PARTY EXCHANGES: KMT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's trip to China is a matter of cross-Taiwan Strait party exchanges and does not need government authorization, a KMT official said Sunday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, director of the KMT Central Policy Committee, said that Lien's planned China trip is an open and transparent activity of cross-strait party exchanges and has nothing to do with government authority.
Lien will visit China in his capacity as KMT chairman and he will be promoting cross-strait exchanges and peace as well as protecting the interests of the Taiwan people, Tseng argued.
Referring to opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong's planned visit to China in early May, Tseng said that it is not contradictory to Lien.
The KMT is receptive to any efforts that are aimed at furthering the interests of the people of Taiwan and promoting cross-strait peace, Tseng affirmed.
Lien is scheduled to leave for China April 26 to start an eight-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR TO GO ON RISING SLIGHTLY AGAINST U.S. UNIT

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar is likely to go on rising slightly against the U. S. dollar this week on renewed speculation that mainland China is set to allow its renminbi to freely float against the greenback in a narrow band, banking experts said Sunday.

But experts predicted that the local currency will only fluctuate marginally in a narrow range between 31.40 and 31.55 against the U.S. unit due to weak momentum because of a slowed influx of foreign capital due to a sliding stock market.
The new Taiwan dollar ended at 31.503 against the U.S. dollar last Friday on the Taipei foreign exchange, up by NT$0.196 compared to the week-earlier level.

A fresh market anticipation for an appreciation of the renminbi will still prop up Asian currencies in a piecemeal fashion, which bankers said will not be as strong as in the first quarter of this year.

Their analysis came after Zhou Xiaochuan, central bank governor of China, said Saturday that there were no serious political or technical obstacles to the reform of the rigid peg of the renminbi to the U.S. dollar. But Zhou did not spell out any exact time on the move, saying only that a timetable for any changes was still under review.

Cheng Cheng-mount, Citibank Taiwan vice president, forecast that the local currency will not markedly pick up in value until the end of the year, which is traditionally the peak season for many businesses.

Although the New Taiwan dollar's strong appreciation in the first half sparked grave concern in the export sector, Cheng said that the U. S. economy and the effects of China's drive to stem its economic overheating, rather than the currency exchange rate, will have greater leverage on Taiwan's economy in the second half.

Hsu Chang-tai, an economist with the Standard Chartered Bank in Taipei, opined that the U. S. dollar's depreciation may have come to an end after an adjustment period of more than two years in terms of value against other major currencies.

As the U. S. dollar is gradually stabilizing, Taiwan's central bank will also make the local currency stay little changed to secure Taiwan's competitive edge, Hsu said, pointing out that the currency exchange rate will thus not be a major element affecting Taiwan's economy in this year's second half.

Hsu expected the renminbi to be freely exchanged within a narrow band between 3 percent and 5 percent against the greenback this year. There will be a small effect to help push up the new Taiwan dollar over the short term, but its overall impact will not be conspicuous, he contended, forecasting that the local currency will move between a range of 31.3 to 31.8 for the rest of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE CONCERNED ABOUT CHINA VISITS BY LIEN, SOONG

TEXT.P: European countries are concerned about the aftermaths of visits to China by leaders of Taiwan's two opposition parties, a ranking Republic of China official told German media.

Kau Ying-mao, vice foreign minister who is visiting Europe, said European officials and academics have questioned the timing and motivations of visiting China by Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong.

He said the European elite wondered if all parties concerned in Taiwan have reached a consensus on the two's China visits, saying they will monitor how Taiwan's government is going to handle the issue.

Talking about European response to China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, Kau said European officials have privately expressed their puzzle as to why China has repeatedly emphasized its interest in increasing exchanges with Taiwan and yet at the same time authorizing the use of force against Taiwan.

The European officials unanimously agreed that China's Anti-Secession Law is a challenge to peace in Asia-Pacific, and so it is highly probable that Europe will put off a decision to lift arms embargo against China, according to Kau.
Kau was leading a delegation exchanging views with German officials, researchers and politicians. He left Berlin Sunday for Brussels, where he will continue his visit to Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Medicare Change Will Limit Access to Claim.
A new federal policy of the United States will make it significantly more difficult for Medicare beneficiaries to obtain hearings in person before a judge when the government denies their claims for home care, nursing home services, prescription drugs and other treatments. Under the new policy, Medicare official s said, most hearings will be held with videoconference equipment or by telephone. A beneficiary who wants to appear in person before a judge must show that "special or extraordinary circumstances exist, " the rules say. The policy chan ge comes as Bush administration officials are predicting an increase in the volume of cases, with the creation of a Medicare drug benefit expected to generate large numbers of claims and appeals. But in a recent study, the Government Accountability Office, an investigative arm of Congress, questioned the heavy reliance on videoconferences, saying that "beneficiaries are often uncomfortable using videoconference facilities and prefer to have their cases heard face to face."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY PRESENTS PRESIDENT CHEN'S LETTER TO NEW POPE
DOC.DATELINE: Vatican City, April 24 (CNA) (By Tony Fang/S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Newly inaugurated Pope Benedict XVI received heads of state and special envoys, including the Republic of China's Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan, who handed him a letter from ROC President Chen Shui-bian Sunday.
In his hand-written letter, the president expressed the Republic of China's highest regards and warmest congratulations to the Pope.

In addition, Su handed to the Pope a copy of the latest issue of Time magazine, which has a special report on the world's 100 most influential figures. Both Benedict XVI and Chen are on the list. Coincidentally, their names are printed on the same page.
The special gift from Taiwan drew a smile from the Pope. Cardinals standing by also responded with hearty smiles.
The Pope shook hands with each of the heads of state and special envoys from 140 countries extending their felicitations to him at the St. Peter's.
On Monday, he will greet representatives from other religions and Catholics from his home country Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 25, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRYING TO ISOLATE CHEN BY WOOING HIS FOES: NEWSWEEK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 24 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian has turned the People's Republic of China's anti-secession law to his political advantage, and Beijing is now attempting to isolate the Taiwan leader by wooing his political foes, according to a report to appear in Newsweek magazine's May 2 edition.

"China wants Taiwan back, but doesn't quite know how to make it happen, " the report, entitled "Taiwan Bitter Friends", says, adding that cross-strait tensions seemed to be easing earlier this year until China's enactment of a tough anti-secession law in March authorizing the use of force against the island to prevent a permanent break between the two sides.

Touching on issues regarding opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's upcoming meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao and Beijing's invitation extended to the leader of Taiwan's other major opposition party, People First Party Chairman James Soong, for a visit to the mainland, the report says that "Beijing is even tempting the island's fruit farmers -- largely pro-independence supporters with scrumptious trade terms for their produce."
"It's a stick-and-carrot strategy, " the report quotes Emile Sheng, a political science professor at Soochow University in Taipei, as saying.

"Not all Taiwanese are impressed by Beijing's overtures. Despite Lien's talk of achieving 'peace for both sides of the Taiwan Strait,' any negotiations need Chen's blessing, his party still holds more sway with Taiwanese voters than the KMT," the report says.
"Lacking any real power, Lien's bid for a cross-strait breakthrough may turn into another cross-strait breakdown, " it also says.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPINIONS MIXED IN TAIWAN ON KMT CHAIRMAN'S CHINA VISIT: POLL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's upcoming China visit has drawn mixed reactions from the people in Taiwan, according to the results of a public opinion poll released Monday.

In the poll, conducted on randomly selected adults around the island April 21-23 by Focus Survey Research at the commission of the Taiwan Thinktank, 45 percent of the respondents said they approve of KMT Chairman Lien Chan meeting with the Beijing leadership during his visit in China, while 42 percent said they disapprove. Lien's visit will mark the first by a KMT chairman to the mainland in more than five decades.

A total of 71 percent of the respondents said it would be "inappropriate" for Lien to reach any consensus or enter any kind of agreement with Beijing without the authorization of President Chen Shui-bian, according to the Taiwan Thinktank.

Some 64 percent of the respondents said they think Lien does not have the authority to represent the people of Taiwan, the Taiwan Thinktank reported. Even some 40 percent of supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition KMT and the People First Party (PFP) had the same opinion, the pollsters said.

On the question of whether Lien and PFP Chairman James Soong, who is also scheduled to visit China in early May at the invitation of mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao, should meet with President Chen prior to their visits to China for talks, 66 percent said Lien and Soong should call on President Chen beforehand, compared with 24 percent who said "it's not necessary," the poll found.

About 54 percent of the respondents said they approve of Soong talking with the Beijing leadership about the 10-point consensus on cross-strait relations that he reached with President Chen recently, compared with 30 percent who disapprove.
Meanwhile, the poll found that 50 percent of the respondents think the communist Chinese regime is now more hostile toward Taiwan than a year ago, while only 20 percent think the opposite is true.
A total of 39 percent think that cross-Taiwan Strait relations will turn for the worse over the coming year, while 31 percent think the opposite will occur.

Commenting on the poll findings, Chen Ming-tong, a professor at National Taiwan University and former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that Beijing's anti-secession law targeting Taiwan has turned cross-strait relations sour and that the Taiwan general public is now more pessimistic about the prospects regarding the development of cross-strait relations.

Hung Yu-hung, chairman of the private think-tank Taipei Society, said that the results of the poll reveal two significant points, namely that the people of Taiwan identify strongly with their country regardless of their political affilition, and that they have a highly-developed sense of democracy and political reasoning.
A total of 1,075 valid samples were collected in the survey which is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 2.99 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO ISSUE NEWS RELEASE AFTER CHEN-LIEN CALL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will talk by telephone Monday at 4: 10 p.m. ahead of Lien's trip to China the next day, and the Presidential Office will issue a news release shortly after the call, a spokesman said.

Chen Wen-tsung, director of the Public Affairs Department under the Presidential Office, said Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun had talked with KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng by phone earlier in the day about the way to handle the news release after the Chen- Lien phone conversation this afternoon.

In line with Presidential Office custom, Chen Wen-tsung said, the Chen-Lien phone conversation will be recorded. Nevertheless, he said the Presidential Office will not publicize the contents of the call. Instead, he said, the Presidential Office will issue a news release outlining what was said.
Chen Wen-tsung said only Lien knows what the nature of the discussion will be and that the Presidential Office will respect the KMT's decision if it wishes to make public the transcript of the call.

Chen Wen-tsung said President Chen's conversations with guests from home and abroad are always recorded and put into the government archives. The practice has been in place since the KMT administration, which lasted for more than five decades until May 2000.

Lien, a former ROC premier and vice president, is scheduled to depart from Taipei April 26 for what he calls a "journey of peace" to China. He will be the first KMT chairman to set foot in China since the party, which one ruled all of China, retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese Communists. He will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao April 29.

Lien lost his presidential bids in 2000 and 2004. He has been unwilling to address Chen as president since losing the 2004 presidential election by a slim margin. He filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory. The two lawsuits have both been rejected by the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES MEMBERS NOT TO STAGE PROTEST AGAINST KMT HEAD'S CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: As pro-independence groups prepare to stage a demonstration at Chiang Kai-shek Airport against opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China April 26, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman urged party members Monday not to mobilize and not to break the law.

Everyone in a democratic society enjoys the right to express their opinions, but they are not allowed to break the law, Su Tseng-chang said, urging DPP members not to oppose Lien's China trip in a violent manner.

Su made the call while campaigning in Miaoli for party candidates in the mission-oriented National Assembly election to be held May 14. He reiterated that now is a bad time for such visits to Beijing after millions of Taiwanese people took to the streets to protest against China's passage of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan in early April.
However, he added that opposing Lien's China visit is one thing, while mobilizing to oppose the trip is something different, saying it is not necessary for DPP party members to mobilize.

DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan noted that the party will not mobilize to oppose Lien's China trip and that it is banning its members from taking part in similar rallies in the name of the DPP. The party will monitor Lien's conduct and remarks during his stay in China according to the "three noes and three yeses" principle in dealing with China, he said.

Meanwhile, TSU Secretary-General Chen Chien-ming on Monday urged those who intend to take part in the protest rally at CKS Airport prior to Lien's departure to Beijing Tuesday not to bring along objects, such as eggs, that could easily lead to conflicts.
Chen made the remarks at a news conference to explain the planned gathering. He asked those who will participate in the rally to allow the rally to proceed in a "peaceful and rational manner."

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN AND SOONG WELCOMED TO CHINA WITH OPEN ARMS: M'LAND POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly all of the respondents in a recent survey in mainland China said that the visits by the chairmen of the two largest opposition parties in Taiwan will be welcomed.
Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will go to China on April 26 and James Soong, the head of the People First Party (PFP), a splinter group of the KMT, will make a similar trip in early May.
The Social Survey Institute of China interviewed 1,000 people with phone in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Nanjing, Xian, Fuzhou, Wuhan, Xining, Zhengzhou, and Shenyang.

The results, quoted by Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po newspaper Monday, showed that 69 percent of respondents think the visits mean cross-strait relations are "coming out of winter and entering into spring, " with 96 percent saying that the two men are welcome to visit China.

Those polled in China were optimistic about future relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, with 71 percent saying Lien and Soong's discussions with Chinese leaders will "broaden" the channel of dialogue between China and Taiwan.

Seventy-six percent said the two visits will have a crucial effect on the economic development in China and Taiwan as both sides will strengthen economic cooperation, something that is needed for their "joint development."

The results of the Chinese survey were in stark contrast with a Taiwan Thinktank survey that showed that 42 percent of those polled in Taiwan did not support the two opposition leaders' visits to China, while 45 percent approved.
