DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD HOPES CHINA VISIT WILL HELP CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Monday that he hopes his upcoming visit to China will help push cross-Taiwan Strait relations forward to a new era of peace.
Lien also said that his visit is mainly aimed at reflecting the Taiwan people's expectations, stressing that he will discuss a variety of topics with his Chinese hosts during the visit.
The chairman made the remarks at a news conference held by the KMT.

Lien, at the head of a KMT delegation consisting of three vice chairmen as well as ranking officials and members of party think thanks, is scheduled to leave Tuesday for Nanking, the first leg of his eight-day tour in China.

Seeing his visit as an opportunity to free both sides of the Strait from their history, Lien said that he hopes that the two sides can work together and help each other move forward to a peaceful future and adopt practical measures to jointly create an interactive relationship.

The chairman said he hopes to better his understandings of China's huge changes in the fields of politics and economic development, as well as to hold talks with Chinese leaders on issues relating to cross-strait peace, economic and cultural exchanges, and the wellbeing of the Taiwan people.
Noting that he will not restrain himself from discussing any topic with Chinese leaders, Lien, however, said that he neither represents the government nor is authorized to negotiate with China.

The KMT head will reportedly urge Taiwan and China to abandon their policy of independence and the use of force, respectively. Lien is also expected to push for the signing of a 50-year cross-strait peace agreement and to establish "three communications" between the two sides to expand cross-strait economic and trade exchanges.

He also said that promoting cross-strait peace has been his own and his party's longstanding policy and stance that has never changed, and that during the visit, he will try to better understand Beijing government's ideas to create a promising future and a win-win situation for both sides of the Strait.

As he considers his meeting with Hu a significant matter, the chairman revealed that the KMT's efforts in promoting peace in the Taiwan Strait have been affirmed publicly by the United States and by leaders of various countries in Asia and Europe in private.

Asked whether he will discuss issues regarding human rights and democracy during his meeting with Hu or in his speech to be delivered at Beijing University, Lien said that he will not forget the importance of human rights and democracy since these issues are with universal values. However, he emphasized that "how to promote a peaceful future is the most important cross-strait issue."

As to questions regarding whether he will request that China dismantle missiles targeting Taiwan and sign a peace agreement with Taiwan, the KMT head declined to give a reply, saying only that he has not met with Hu yet.

Talking about People First Party Chairman James Soong's visit to China next week, Lien said that he would like to see leaders of other political parties engage in dialogue with China, noting that the PFP's mainland policy is similar to that of the KMT's and that visits of other political parties to the mainland can strengthen mutual understanding and harmony between the two sides of the Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSULT PRESIDENT BEFORE GOING TO CHINA, SAYS LEE YUAN-TSEH

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Monday that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong should consult with President Chen Shui-bian or the Democratic Progressive Party administration prior to their visits to China.

Lien and Soong must consult the government before they embark on their China visits, the head of Taiwan's top research institute said, adding that only after the country has a consensus on this matter will the two opposition leaders' visits have any meaning or benefit for the people.

Lien, a former ROC premier and vice president, is scheduled to depart Taipei Tuesday for what he calls a "journey of peace" to China. He will be the first KMT chairman to set foot on Chinese soil since the party, which once ruled all of China, retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Chinese Communists. He will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing this Friday.
Soong is scheduled to head to China May 5. He is also visiting China at the invitation of Hu.
Soong was formerly a Taiwan provincial governor and a KMT secretary-general. He also ran on the loosing ticket with Lien in the 2004 presidential election.

The Academia Sinica president said that he has no idea what Lien and Soong might be thinking about regarding their "historic" China visits, but since President Chen has said that he would offer his blessing for the two opposition leaders' forthcoming visits to China if they faithfully abide by domestic laws throughout their trips, Lien and Soong should fully exchange their opinions with the president beforehand.

President Chen said recently that their China visits could possibly offer inspiration or be a guide for the future development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, adding that he has never opposed the two "pan-blue" leaders' China visits. "What I wants to stress is that during their visits, they should refrain from touching on anything involving national sovereignty or public authority without prior government authorization," the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRONESIAN-SPEAKING PEOPLE ORIGINATED FROM TAIWAN: AUSSIE PROF.
DOC.DATELINE: Taitung, eastern Taiwan, April 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Austronesian-speaking people across the Asia-Pacific region originated from Taiwan, an Australian academic said Monday.

Prof. Peter Bellwood, director of the School of Archaeology and Anthropology of Australian National University, said that it was archaeologically proven that ancestors of today's Austronesian-speaking people, numbering about 300 million, migrated from Taiwan to Pacific Rim areas.

Bellwood said he backed up this theory after he completed archaeological fieldwork recently in Batan Island in the northernmost part of the Philippines, and the Yer Bac prehistoric site in northern Vietnam, where, he said, he found pieces of penannular jade rings and earthenware that were related to the people who lived in prehistoric Taiwan.

In a speech delivered at the National Museum of Prehistory in Taitung, Bellwood said that jade was not produced in most of the Austronesian-speaking areas except for Taiwan and the pieces of penannular jade rings found in both Batan and Yer Bac were similar to those found in Hualien, eastern Taiwan.
In addition, he said, the earthenware unearthed in the Philippines is similar in pattern to the pieces unearthed in Hualien or Taitung, eastern Taiwan, which date back 4,700 to 3,500 years.

According to Bellwood, the Austronesian-speaking people began to emigrate downward from the north to the Philippines about 4,000 years ago, gradually to Vietnam and the Polynesian islands. Across the more than 2,000 kilometer migratory travels, Taiwan and Austronesian countries might have maintained interactions for as long as 3,000 years, he added.

Discounting Bellwood's theory, some local academics who listened to the speech argued that Bellwood's evidence, only pieces of jade rings and pottery, was "too weak, " saying that those relics were not necessarily the things that Austronesian-speaking people of the past used. The relics could be brought to those areas by traders in later years, they said.
The academics said Bellwood should prove his theory with more evidence.

On a related note, a theory developed in Australia and New Zealand in recent years has it that from genetics and linguistics points of view, Taiwan is the place where the Austronesian-language people originated from.

Professor Geoffrey Chambers of Victoria University in Wellington believes that Maori people and other Polynesian peoples of the Pacific "island-hopped" from Taiwan through the Philippines and Indonesia to West Polynesia. From there, he said, they traveled to the islands of East Polynesia and then southwest, eventually settling in New Zealand.

Taiwan's indigenous people as a whole are believed to belong to the Austronesian-language group, which probably underwent the widest physical dispersion of a single language family prior to the European colonial expansion following Columbus, from the island of Madagascar off the east coast of Africa all the way to the tiny, isolated Easter Island (Rapa Nui) and extending to Taiwan, Vietnam, Northern Australia, New Zealand and most of the Melanesian and Polynesian islands.

Taiwan's indigenous people -- the native groups that predate all other ethnic groups in Taiwan -- could have originated either from the southern part of China or from a vast Austronesian-language region.

Taiwan's aborigines are considered the northernmost Austronesian people. Among them, the government currently divides them into 12 major mountain tribes and 10 Pingpu groups. While elements of the languages and cultures of the 10 mountainous races have been maintained, most of the native languages of the Pingpu people have died out and no traces remain.
Among the mountainous aborigines, the Saisiat and the Atayal are believed to have migrated to Taiwan some 3,000 years ago.

Anthropologists have no idea what exactly happened, or when, to cause some of Taiwan's earliest natives to die out or disappear, but efforts to seek traces of the original natives' existence via anthropological, linguistic and historical studies have been continuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER LOWERS ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE FORECAST TO 4.41 PERCENT FOR 2005

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) Monday lowered its growth forecast for Taiwan's economy in 2005 to 4.41 percent, due to a less-than-vibrant foreign trade sector and a slowing global economy.

TIER acting President David Hong said that Taiwan's gross domestic product this year will grow less than last year's 5.71 percent but hailed an annual expansion of more than 4 percent a sound performance for a nearly mature economy like that of Taiwan.

Hong predicted that the domestic economy will begin to gain greater momentum in the second quarter and will peak in the fourth quarter. TIER economic growth rate forecasts for each quarter are 4.09 percent, 4.19 percent, 4.63 percent and 4.71 percent in that order, he reported.

Taiwan will enjoy a trade surplus of US$13.1 billion for the whole of this year, up from the 2004 level of US$6.1 billion thanks to an export sector that is estimated to increase by 9.09 percent this year -- almost twice the growth forecast for the import sector of 5.29 percent.

The growth rate in private sector investment will drop to 8.09 percent in 2005 due to sliding domestic demand, while private sector consumption will rise by 2.87 percent as a result of rising consumer product prices at home and surging oil prices in the world market, according to Hong.

The TIER also predicted that the new Taiwan dollar will average NT$30.73 against the U.S. dollar for the whole of 2005, an upward adjustment from an earlier forecast of NT$31.65 that represents an appreciation of NT$2.84 over the 2004 average.

The new Taiwan dollar will still face pressure to appreciate this year on a firm anticipation that mainland China will allow its renminbi to be traded flexibly amid repeatedly strong requests from the United States and the European Union, TIER researchers said.

They opined that it is unlikely that the U.S. dollar will go up in value over the short term if the United States fails to make noticeable improvements in its long-standing deficits in federal budgets and foreign trade.

As the U.S. Federal Reserve is expected to continue raising key interest rates in the near future, Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) will follow in the footsteps of the U.S., although at a slower pace, to reduce the gap in interest rate levels between the two countries, they said.

They pointed out that the CBC will adopt a neutral policy to stabilize consumer product prices while gradually picking up interest rates to help rational allocations of assets to secure a sound financial market over the long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 11.22 points to close at 5,758.31.
The bourse opened at 5,853.24 and fluctuated between 5,771.38 and 5,727.42 during trading. A total of 1.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$40.75 billion (US$1.3 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.2 percent, followed by construction issues and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.8 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.7 percent, cement stocks at 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues at 0.1 percent.
Both banking and financial shares and machinery and electronics stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 455 to 390, with 162 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THINKTANK TO HOLD THREE DEBATES ON CONSTITUTIONAL REFORMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Thinktank, a private policy research institute, will hold three debates on amending the Republic of China Constitution ahead of the May 14 election of representatives to the National Assembly, which in theory is to approve the amendments.
Taiwan Thinktank plans to hold the debates on April 28, May 6 and May 9 and will invite public television to broadcast the debates live, a Taiwan Thinktank official said Monday.

Recent polls have shown that most people are not even aware that the National Assembly will be convened or when the vote for representatives is. Given that the results of the assembly will affect the nation, the think tank decided to organize the debates to inform the public.

The two parties supporting the constitutional reform, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang, and those parties opposing the reform, including the People First Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union, will have their representatives take part in the TV debates, according to Taiwan Thinktank.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May gained three points to close at 5,728, with 13,763 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June remained unchanged at 5,711, with 105 contracts traded, while September futures lost three points to finish at 5,587, with 125 contracts traded. December futures lost 60 points to finish at 5,532, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,725 for May, 5,711 for June, 5,590 for September, 5,592 for December and 5,630 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
May TE futures moved down 0.55 points to close at 222, with 2,360 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 0.7 points to finish at 221, with 13 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for September, December and March.

May TF futures gained 0.8 points to finish at 919, with 2,854 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved down 1.4 points to end at 917.6, with 25 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 1.6 points to finish at 914.6, with 16 contract transaction, while December TF futures lost 0.8 points to end at 917, with seven contracts traded. March TF futures moved down 16.8 points to close at 921, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar slid against the new Taiwan dollar on Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, giving up NT$0.129 to close at NT$31.374.
A total of US$647 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$31.503 and was traded between NT$31.356 and NT$31.586.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPECTS BREAKTHROUGH IN TAIWAN'S BIOTECH INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The completion of the Chunan section of the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) symbolizes the arrival of a new era for Taiwan's biotechnology research and development, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.
Chen also expressed the hope that the completion of the facility will mark a watershed in Taiwan's and even the world's biotech industry.
The president made the remarks while addressing the 10th anniversary celebration of the foundation of NHRI and the dedication ceremony of its Chunan section in Miaoli County.
Chen said he felt very happy to be able to participate in what he called "an important moment in the history of Taiwan's life science development."

According to Chen, as major countries around the world are competing with each other for the leading position in terms of life science, nanotechnology and information and communications technology, Taiwan must continue to innovate, develop and ensure sufficient talent is available in order to win this global competition.

Meanwhile, NHRI President Wu Cheng-wen said he expects the institutes to become the locomotive of Taiwan's biotechnology, a fortress of national health and a center of global medical and health research.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT CHINA MAY 5-12

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong is scheduled to visit China May 5-12, party sources said Monday.
A PFP working group, headed by PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng, is currently in Beijing to flesh out Soong's China visit with Chinese officials.
According to information from Beijing, PFP sources said, Soong will first visit Xian in northwestern China and Beijing will be the last stop of his mainland trip.

The sources said Chin's mission met with mainland officials, including Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, from Sunday evening through 4 a.m. Monday to work out Soong's itinerary.

Both sides have tentatively agreed that Soong's China visit will be defined as an engagement between the PFP and the Communist Party of China (CPC) with the aim of promoting and improving development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and maintaining cross-strait peace, the sources said.

Soong will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who concurrently serves as CPC general secretary, during his stay in Beijing, the sources said, adding that the exact date and agenda for their meeting have yet to be worked out.

Meanwhile, Soong will deliver a speech at Tsinghua University. His itinerary will also include visits to his hometown in Hunan province's Hsiangtan City, Nanjing and Shanghai where he will meet with Taiwan business people operating in China.
PFP officials said Chin's mission is scheduled to return to Taipei April 27.
The officials further said Soong will be visiting China in his capacity as PFP chairman, not as someone else's special envoy.

The PFP is a splinter group of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) . Both parties support a more conciliatory policy toward China than the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and favor eventual cross-strait unification.

Stressing that Soong's upcoming China visit will mark an historic rendezvous between the PFP and CPC leaderships, PFP officials said, Soong will take advantage of his visit to help break through the lingering cross-strait impasse.
Soong's China visit will come on the heels of KMT Chairman Lien Chan's April 26 to May 3 journey to China.
Soong served as Taiwan provincial governor from 1993 to 1998. The Taiwan Provincial Government has since been marginalized as part of the government's political reform.

Soong also once served as KMT secretary-general. He ran as an independent in the 2000 presidential election, but lost to DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian by a narrow margin. Shortly afterwards, he founded the PFP. He served as KMT Chairman Lien's running mate in the 2004 presidential election, but the Lien-Soong ticket lost to the DPP ticket of Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: CCF/TAIWAN OPENS OPERATIONAL CENTER IN THE PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Fund for Children and Families, a Taiwan version of the U.S. Christian Children's Fund (CCF) and thus known as CCF/Taiwan, has recently set up an operational center in Mindanao, the Philippines, to help impoverished children there, an organization official said Monday.

CCF/Taiwan is the largest child and family welfare organization in Taiwan and has helped over 100,000 local children living in impoverished families to grow up into self-reliant citizens under its sponsorship programs. It is at present sponsoring more than 27,000 needy local youths.

CCF/Taiwan Executive Director Chen Pang-hung said that as Taiwan has prospered economically, the number of sponsors contributing to the fund has risen to the extent that the charity can now branch out into other poverty-stricken nations.

Besides sponsorship programs, the CCF/Taiwan center in Mindanao will also assist women in the families being sponsored by the center to receive vocational training, while it is also planning to set up a day care center for kids as part of its efforts to help improve the quality of life of these families, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DIVORCE RATE GROWS BY NEARLY FOUR-FOLD IN 12 YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's divorce rate grew by nearly four fold in 12 years, according to the latest statistics released by the government Monday.

The tallies compiled by the Population Administration Department under the Ministry of the Interior show that in 1983, 160,288 couples married and 17,528 couples divorced, with the marriage number sliding to 131,453 and the number of divorces rising sharply to 62,796 in 2004.
The 2004 divorce number reflects a 3.6-fold growth over the 1983 figure, the same tallies show.

There were 55,460 divorced men in Taiwan in 1983, accounting for 1.1 percent of the country's total male population in that year, but the number of divorced men had surged by nearly five-fold to 224,934 last year, representing 5 percent of Taiwan's males.
Meanwhile, the divorce number among Taiwan's women increased from 63,526 in 1983 to 391,090 in 2004, with the percentage rising from 1.3 percent to 6.2 percent, the statistics show.

At the same time, Taiwan's men and women are marrying older, with the average marrying age for men and women advancing to 30.7 and 26.8 years at present, largely up from 28.2 and 24.6 years in 1983, respectively.

Taiwan's birth rate also dropped to a record law of 1.24 per couple last year, prompting grave concern from the government sector over Taiwan's competitive edge over the long term, ministry officials said.

To tackle the serious problem of a fast aging population, the ministry is slated to work out a demographic white paper in June that will suggest more handsome incentives and subsidies to encourage Taiwanese to have more children.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WARNS OPPOSITION LEADERS AGAINST FORGING AGREEMENTS WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: No political party in Taiwan is allowed to forge any agreement, either in verbal or written form, with China without the government's authorization, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman (MAC) Joseph Wu warned Monday.
Political parties must also obtain the government's authorization before negotiating with China on issues concerning government affairs, Wu said.

The warning was issued ahead of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong's planned visits to China. While Lien's trip is set for April 26 to May 3, that of Soong is scheduled for May 5-12.

According to Wu, it is the government's policy to promote normalized exchanges across the Taiwan Strait to enhance mutual understanding, and the government supports any civic exchanges that meet this purpose.

However, Wu said political parties are different from average civic organizations and that their visits to China cannot be considered average civic exchanges because political leaders have their due responsibilities for the country, society and the people.

Any political parties supported by Taiwanese voters are responsible to pass on to Beijing leaders the strong objections of the Taiwanese people toward the Anti-Secession Law that threatens the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan and its 23 million people, Wu said.

They must also tell Beijing leaders that the Republic of China is a sovereign state independent of the People's Republic of China and that only the 23 million people in Taiwan have the right to decide the fate of their country, Wu said.

Therefore, as a former vice president and an opposition leader, Lien should assume his responsibility and convey to Beijing the objections of the Taiwanese people toward the Anti-Secession Law during his trip, Wu said.

As to Lien's Monday talk with President Chen Shui-bian over the telephone to report the purpose and details of his China trip, Wu said this does not have any legal effect, because only an "authorization" issued through a formal process is legally binding.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Rice and Cheney Are Said to Push Iraqi Politicians on Stalemate.
The Bush administration has pressed Iraqi leaders in recent days to end their stalemate over forming a new government, with Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Vice President Dick Cheney personally exhorting top Kurdish and Shiite politicians to come together. The White Hous e pressure was a change in the administration's hands-off approach to Iraqi politics. Washington's approach to the political negotiations had emphasized that the Iraqis needed to form their own government without interference. Rice on Friday telephoned Iraq's new president, Jalal Talabani, a Kurd, to urge him to complete the government "as soon as they could" and "to get a status of where things were."
Wall Street Journal: Chain-Saw Reaction, Rules Restricting Canadian Loggers Backfire on.
Foreign loggers in Maine is caught in a national fight over how many foreigners, legal and illegal, should be allowed to work here. In the Maine woods, the debate on whether foreign workers has been stealing American jobs has been turned own its head. Meanwhile, the production has been drastically reduced. Paper mill owners pointed out that they needed to savings in wood costs and in Maine there were not enough workers cutting woods.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DONATES TO DISABLED FOLLOWING DOCUMENTARY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian was so moved by the stories of three blind young people in a documentary titled "Chasing Dreams in the Dark" that he donated NT$200,000 immediately after watching the film Monday, hoping to arouse more interest in the life of the disabled.

It took Professor Wan Ming-mei, a special education expert, 10 years to record the stories of the three blind students, all of whom also have to struggle with other physical disabilities. The documentary was screened at the Presidential Office.
Lu Wen-kui is blind and mentally challenged, yet he is gifted with a superb sense of music and can play any song on the piano after hearing it only two or three times.
Blindness and other disabilities have not daunted Lin Wei-chih from developing his talent in music and he can identify correctly any music that he has listened to before.
Chuang Fu-hua, also blind, paralyzed and unable to speak, yet with the help of a loving mother, has written stories that have won her media exposure.
Chen praised the three "brave soldiers in life" for their indefatigable quest to realize their dreams literally in the dark.

He also thanked their parents and teachers for their endless love and efforts to help them develop their potential. "On behalf of the government, I would like to give the highest regards to the parents and teachers of these young people," he added.
"The courage and hard work of the three brave young people have made up for the shortfalls of the government, of the law and of the gods," Chen said.
He mentioned two other documentaries that he has watched recently -- "Life" and "Stone Dreams" -- saying that from these films, "we have seen so many unsung heroes in our society."

DOC.HEADLINE: LANDMINE EXPLOSION KILLS 2 ZIMBABWEAN CLEARING EXPERTS ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: Two landmine clearing experts from Zimbabwe were killed Monday when they accidentally triggered a powerful explosion while removing landmines on the Republic of China-held Kinmen Island, according to police.
The police report also listed another technician, also a Zimbabwean, who was seriously injured in the accident.
Initial investigations show that the accident happened when the demining experts were handling landmines being removed, police said, adding that it remained unclear what triggered the explosion.
A British firm has sent 12 experts, all from Zimbabwe, to clear landmines at the site near Liaoluo Bay, where a reservoir is to be built.
Kinmen, which is controlled by the Republic of China but lies closer to Taiwan than to China, was heavily mined in the 1950s to fend off communist Chinese attempts to seize Taiwan.
With tension easing between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of National Defense has demined 16 areas of Kinmen since 1998 in response to demands from Kinmen residents.

The ministry has also decided to demine 12 additional areas on Kinmen in the next few years. A British firm has won the contract to clear landmines at the Kinmen Waterworks' new reservoir construction site.
Police said an investigation into the cause of the explosion was continuing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PLEDGES TO PROMOTE MARITIME AWARENESS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh pledged Monday that the government will continue to promote a series of meaningful activities in an effort to raise maritime awareness among the public.
Hsieh noted that the government has planned 251 activities for the "Taiwan Maritime Year 2005" and will work with the private sector to publicize the concept of "healthy oceans."
According to Hsieh, maritime affairs are not purely a security or economic issue but an important part of national development and national security.
The efforts made by the Cabinet's maritime affairs promotion commission will be historically significant in Taiwan's bid to become a maritime country, he said.
The premier made the remarks while hosting a meeting of the commission, during which a maritime policy and development plan was adopted.
He said the completion of the plan marks a major step forward in Taiwan's efforts to become a maritime country and a crucial milestone in the country's maritime policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER TO EMBARK ON THREE-NATION EUROPEAN TRIP

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh will embark on a European trip Tuesday, visiting Finland, Sweden and the Slovak Republic to seek two-way cooperative ventures with those three countries, a ministry spokesman said Monday.

According to the spokesman, the three countries complement Taiwan in different fields and Ho will take part in private sector economic meetings and visit top companies to search for cooperation opportunities for Taiwan businesses and lure investment to Taiwan.

Slovak is rich in high-quality labor and has vast amounts of cheap land, and Ho is hoping to help forge two-way business opportunities for Taiwan's makers of car accessories and parts and components, as Slovakia is particularly strong in the machinery and automobile industries and has an ideal location to edge into the vast European Union market, the spokesman said.

Sweden and Finland are both advanced in eco-friendly and knowledge-intensive industries and Ho is slated to visit Nokia in Finland and Volvo and SKF in Sweden, he said, noting that the two countries' highly advanced information and telecommunications sectors should provide many exchange and investment opportunities for Taiwan companies.

Since European countries have been keen on exploring Asian markets in recent years, Ho will also invite European pension fund managers to invest in Taiwan, which is the reason behind her decision to invite venture capital specialists to accompany her on the tour, he noted.

Ho's delegation will comprise officials from the Bureau of Foreign Trade, the Industrial Development Bureau, the Industrial Technology Research Institute, the Taiwan External Trade Development Council and executives from Taiwan's biotech, automobile, telecommunications, financial holding and venture capital industries. The group is slated to return to Taiwan May 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADERS' CHINESE TRIPS REGULATED BY LAW: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The administration is in no position to prohibit two opposition leaders from visiting China simply on the assumption that they will breach the law during their trips, but their behavior is governed by the law, Premier Frank Hsieh said Monday.

Speaking to leaders of the World Federation of Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce, the premier said that within the boundaries of the law, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party Chairman James Soong are free to do what they like but beyond that boundary, they cannot forge any valid pacts with their Chinese hosts without the government's authorization.

Noting that some critics of the opposition leaders are worried that they could betray the country during their association with China, the premier said his administration cannot stop their proposed visits simply because of concern on the part of such critics.

Hsieh said it is not appropriate for Lien and Soong to visit China at the present time, because they will undermine the country's protest against China's enactment of the Ant-Secession Law, which gives it an excuse to use force against Taiwan.

The visits will also provide Beijing with a much-needed opportunity to ease the backlash caused by its enactment of the law among global powers, which is why Beijing is rolling out the red carpet for them, the premier went on.

Both Lien and Soong are veteran politicians, should know their legal boundaries and should refrain from doing anything to the detriment of their country, or they will be called to account, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AFFAIRS COUNCIL URGED TO COMMUNICATE WITH OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: An advisory group urged the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Monday to communicate with the two main opposition parties and use the upcoming visits to China by their chairmen to gain a better understanding of China's latest approach toward Taiwan.

The MAC Advisory Commission said in its recommendation that using the opposition to contact China would give the MAC a valuable chance to gauge China's policy and formulate its own responses accordingly.

Instead of trying to stop the opposition chiefs from visiting China, the commission said, the MAC should establish channels of communication with the opposition parties and therefore make them part of the government's tentacles, which would be beneficial to both the two opposition parties and the government.

The commission said that as China is expanding its contacts with Taiwan by inviting local opposition parties and private groups to visit in attempts to shape bilateral ties, the best response on the part of Taiwan is to harness these parties and groups to develop cross-Taiwan Strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'JOURNEY OF PEACE' UNRELATED TO GOVERNMENT AFFAIRS: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan emphasized during talks with President Chen Shui-bian over the telephone Monday that his upcoming "journey of peace" to China will be personal and civic in nature and will not involve any government affairs, according to a statement released by the KMT.
During the conversation, Lien also offered to provide details of his discussions with Beijing leaders for the government's reference after his return, the statement said.

The 11-minute discussion, which the KMT described as being conducted in a natural and peaceful atmosphere, took place one day before Lien is set to leave for China for an eight-day trip during which he will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao.

Lien expressed his gratitude for Chen's support for his China trip and assured the president that the visit will be beneficial to cross-Taiwan Strait peace and Taiwan's development. The statement added that the KMT has always had a complete and clear policy toward China.

Lien reiterated that it is the KMT's long-standing China policy to safeguard the country's dignity, protect the well-being of the people and defend the constitutional system of the Republic of China and that he will follow these principles during his trip.

On the differences between the ruling and opposition parties over the so-called "1992 consensus" that the KMT claims was established between Taipei and Beijing during talks held in Hong Kong in 1992, Lien said it is a normal phenomenon in a democracy for different opinions to exist.

Lien urged the government to look from a positive point of view at a 10-point consensus reached between KMT Vice Chairman P.K. Chiang and the Beijing authorities during Chiang's China trip last month, saying that Chiang's efforts were made for the benefit of the Taiwanese people.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party insists that opposition parties must obtain the government's authorization before starting negotiations or forging any agreement concerning government affairs with China. Prosecutors have launched an investigation into Chiang for alleged treason for establishing his 10-point consensus with China without the government's authorization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPECTS TO MEET KMT CHIEF WHEN HE RETURNS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian told opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Monday that the government attaches great importance to Lien's upcoming visit to China and that he looks forward to discussing cross-Taiwan Strait policy with Lien when he returns home.

The president exchanged views with the opposition leader over the phone the day before Lien's departure for China, where he is scheduled April 29 to meet Communist Party of China General Secretary Hu Jintao, who is also China's president.

Chen wished Lien "every success" during the trip and reminded Lien that he has pledged to abide by the laws of the Republic of China, in addition to safeguarding national sovereignty, dignity and security, as well as seeking the maximum well-being for Taiwan's 23 million people.
Chen thanked Lien for understanding that he has not been authorized by the government to sign any deal with China that might involve national sovereignty or the exercise of public authority.
The president reaffirmed that the ROC is an independent, sovereign state whose jurisdiction covers an area different to that of the People's Republic of China.

When it comes to the ROC's position toward the PRC, Chen said, it has always been clear: The ROC hopes to improve relations with the PRC based on the principles of democracy, equality and peace. "We are looking to see if there is a chance of resuming dialogue that would lead to the establishment of a framework for cross-strait peace and stability," he added.

If Lien has the pleasure of sharing with Chen his observations and personal feelings about his China tour, slated for April 26-May 3, Chen said he will be more than glad to meet with him after his return.
If and when they do meet, "we can discuss cross-strait policy and ways of building a consensus between the ruling and opposition parties," said the president.

He acknowledged that there are many differences of views between the ruling and opposition camps in Taiwan but added that if both parties can do their best to reach a consensus on cross-strait policy, "we will be able to show greater strength."
To this, Lien responded by saying: "Let's work hard together. Let's make our efforts together."
Before they finished the rare conversation, Chen wished Lien a happy journey and a safe return.
Throughout the conversation, Lien did not call Chen "president." Instead, he used the Chinese-language term -- "Brother Shui-bian" -- a term of endearment.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO URGES CHINA TO GIVE TAIWAN MEDIA 100% FREEDOM OF PRESS

TEXT.P: Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao called on China Monday to give "100 percent freedom of the press" to Taiwan media workers covering opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's historic visit to China.
Yao made the appeal when an application from the Apple Daily, a Taiwan-based newspaper, to cover Lien's April 26-May 3 China visit, was rejected by the Beijing authorities.

China should realize that freedom of the press is an important aspect of Taiwan's democratic development, said the GIO chief, suggesting that China use Taiwan's experience in allowing press freedom as a reference for its future development.

Taiwanese media touring China along with Lien's entourage can give a "precious lesson" to China, he said. Instead of banning a Taiwan newspaper, China should seize the opportunity and learn a lesson from Taiwan's media, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CKS AIRPORT SECURITY TO BE TIGHTENED FOR KMT CHIEF'S CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: More than 1,100 police officers will be mobilized to maintain order at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport Tuesday when opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan is scheduled to leave for what he bills a "journey of peace" to China, officials said Monday.

Huang Chih-hsuan, deputy director of the Aviation Police Bureau, said police authorities have tightened security at the airport complex in Taoyuan County, some 40 km south of Taipei, in anticipation of protests by pro-independence activists against the visit.

Huang said the main goal of the police authorities is to protect inbound and outbound passengers' rights and safety. Vehicles entering the airport complex will be subject to traffic controls between 7 a.m. and noon, Huang said, adding that buses carrying protesters will be directed to a parking lot on the east wing, while buses carrying Lien's supporters will be ordered to park at the Aviation Science Museum parking lot.

Huang urged demonstrators to remain calm and refrain from acting "irrationally" during the rally. He reminded demonstrators that banners, signboards, posters, eggs, loudspeakers and other articles that can be used as weapons are banned at airport passenger terminals.

An estimated 5,000 protestors are expected to join the rally to be organized by pro-independence groups, while about 2,000 of Lien's supporters are also expected to turn up at the airport to see Lien off.
Lien, heading a large delegation of KMT officials and journalists, will depart for Nanjing Tuesday for an eight-day China visit during which he will meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
The trip will be the first time in 56 years that a leader of the once staunchly anti-Communist KMT has set foot in China.
His tour will mark one of the biggest political ironies in the past decade of dizzying change in Taiwan -- one of Asia's youngest and most dynamic democracies.

Lien, a former ROC premier and vice president, lost his presidential bids in 2000 and 2004. He has been unwilling to address Chen as president since losing the 2004 presidential election by a slim margin. He filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory, both of which have been rejected by the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: UTAH LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION VISITS KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A 18-member Utah legislative delegation visited the southern port city of Kaohsiung Monday to promote bilateral cooperation and exchanges.
The delegation, headed by Utah State Senate President John L. Valentine, first visited the Kaohsiung city council, where they were warmly greeted by Council Speaker Tsai Chien-hsin.

During the meeting, Tsai expressed his appreciation for the visit by the Utah lawmakers and thanked them for the support they have extended to Taiwan, particularly in terms of Taiwan's bids to join the World Health Organization and the United Nations.
Tsai also invited them to visit Kaohsiung again in 2009 when Kaohsiung will hold the Seventh World Games.

Valentine praised Kaohsiung city council for its democratic operation and expressed the hope that the city and the state of Utah can increase exchanges of experience in the construction of mass rapid transit systems, particularly in light of the fact that MRT systems in both Kaohsiung and Utah are presently under construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO SET UP NATIONAL PARK ON TUNGSHA ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Maritime Affairs Promotion Committee of the Executive Yuan approved a plan Monday to set up a national park on the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands in the South China Sea.
The plan was listed in a maritime affairs development program that covers a total of 105 working projects with a combined budget of NT$34.9 billion (US$1.1 billion), government officials said.
Also, the officials said, a maritime research station will be established on the Tungsha Islands under the program.
Premier Frank Hsieh, who presided over the meeting, instructed relevant government agencies to overcome every possible obstacle in carrying out the program, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL PARTIES LAUD OPPOSITION LEADER'S CALL TO PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A phone call made by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan to President Chen Shui-bian to brief the president about Lien's visit to China was lauded Monday by all Taiwan's political parties but the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

Lawmaker William Lai, the legislative caucus whip of Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), described the call as a sign of goodwill between the KMT and DPP that bodes well for future reconciliation.

Citing press releases issued separately by the offices of Chen and Lien about their talk on the phone, Lai said the call was more an exchange of views between the president and an opposition leader than an appeal made by a subordinate to his superior for permission or authorization for a trip.

Lai said the president, who initially insisted that Lien should visit him in person but later settled for a phone call, simply prodded Lien to keep the interest of the 23 million Taiwan people in mind during his dealings with his Chinese hosts.
The 11-minute phone call has, more than anything else, laid the groundwork for the two parties to have friendly engagements with each other, Lai said.

Meanwhile Lawmaker Tseng Yung-chuan, the director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Commission, said Lien's call proves that the KMT chief's itinerary and the party's stance toward China are transparent and consistent.
He quoted Lien as promising in his call to Chen that he will visit China as a private citizen and will not usurp the government's power in his dealings with the Beijing authorities.
Tseng said the KMT has never wavered in its China policy, which he claimed has long open to the public and has been "proved" to serve the best interests of the Taiwan people.
The opposition People First Party (PFP) described the call as "better than nothing."
PFP lawmaker Chen Chih-ping said the call signifies a good start for Lien's trip.

The TSU was the only party to see the call in a bad light. Its party convener at the Legislative Yuan, Lo Chih-ming, said the president made a mistake in giving his blessing to Lien's trip, because Lien believes there was an understanding reached in 1992 between Taiwan and China on "one China, " an understanding that the president denies exists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 26, or the 18th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard. There were only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the new defacto Philippine representative to the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei-tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
2001: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulates Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: STATE DEPARTMENT DECLINES TO PROVIDE DETAILS OF LIEN-PAAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 25 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. State Department on Monday declined to provide details of a recent meeting between opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Director Douglas Paal, saying only that the AIT chief frequently meets with Taiwan leaders.

"American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Director Paal meets frequently with leaders and senior representatives from Taiwan, including a number of recent meetings, to discuss a broad range of issues and current developments. We are not in a position to provide details, " the State Deparment said in a written answer.

The answer came after questions raised at a routine press briefing earlier in the day regarding whether Washington has played any role in Lien's upcoming visit to China and what did Lien and Paal discuss.
During the briefing, State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli said that he is not aware of the Lien-Paal meeting, promising that he would see if he could get any information on the meeting.
The KMT already made a statement regarding the Lien-Paal meeting April 22. Lien is scheduled to depart Tuesday for mainland China for an eight-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NOW IS NOT A GOOD TIME' FOR KMT HEAD'S CHINA VISIT: DISSIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 25 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A prominent mainland Chinese dissident said Monday in Paris that "now is not a good time" for opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to mainland China.

Wei Jinsheng, who is currently visiting Europe to lobby member states of the European Union not to lift their ban on arms sales to China, made the comments in an interview with the Central News Agency.
Lien is scheduled to depart Tuesday for mainland China for an eight-day visit which he has billed as a "journey of peace."

Wei, who now lives in the United States, said the timing of Lien's China visit is very bad as it is taking place only weeks after Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan. Wei said the visit might demonstrate that divisions exist among the Taiwan people.

Asked whether Lien will have the chance to push for cross-strait dialogue during the visit, Wei said that this depends on the will of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, adding, however, that "it is no use since China has no intention to treat Taiwan well."
Claiming that Chinese President Hu Jintao does not have a firm grip on power, the dissident said that Hu will try to consolidate his power by means of waging war.
"People should not think that war in the Taiwan Strait ahead of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games is impossible," Wei warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP-CPC TALKS WILL RESPECT CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO: PFP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong will hold talks with Communist Party of China (CPC) officials based on the principle of recognizing and respecting the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, PFP Legislator Lee Yong-ping said Tuesday.

Lee, one of the members of a PFP delegation that headed to mainland China Sunday to arrange a visit for Soong in early May, made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan after returning to Taiwan late Monday.
According to Lee, the Chinese side has made it clear that talks between Soong and CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao will be held based on that principle.

Noting that recognizing and respecting the existing situation between the two sides of the strait echoes the strong desire of the majority of the Taiwan people to maintain the status quo in terms of Taiwan-China ties, Lee said that the respective visits by Soong and Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan will help China better understand public opinion in Taiwan and that everyone should wish them a good trip.

A wide range of topics will be touched on during the Soong-Hu meeting, including the disputed "1992 consensus" and the 10-point agreement signed by Soong and President Chen Shui-bian following their Feb. 24 meeting, she said, adding that the results of the Soong-Hu meeting will be documented in written form but that the two will not ink any accord.
Soong is slated to depart for China May 5.
Meanwhile, Lien left for China Tuesday morning for a visit through May 3. He will make stops in Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai.

Lien's meeting with Hu set for April 29 in Beijing will mark the first between the leaders of the two rival political parties in 56 years after the KMT retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR INVITED TO ATTEND 'WORLD ENVIRONMENT DAY' ACTIVITIES

TEXT.P: The mayor of Tainan, southern Taiwan, received Tuesday an invitation from a representative of the United Nations to attend the U.N.-initiated World Environment Day 2005" activities to be held in the U.S. city of San Francisco June 1-5.
Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair met with visiting George Chao-chi Chu, chairman of the San Francisco-based Da Tung Int'l Group, Inc., at his office.
During the meeting, Hsu explained to the visitor Tainan's efforts in the promotion of environmental protection, a Tainan city official said.
Earlier, Chu invited Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to take part in the annual activity, the official said.

World Environment Day, established by the U.N. General Assembly in 1972 with the goal of raising global awareness of environmental issues and boosting political attention and public action, is hosted every year by a different city around the world
Mayors of over 40 major cities around the globe, including Hsu and Ma, will take part in the San Francisco event at the beginning of June, according to the Tainan City Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR 'JOURNEY OF PEACE' TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan departed for China Tuesday for what he has billed as a "journey of peace" aimed at creating a "win-win situation" for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In a pre-departure speech delivered at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport, Lien said he looks forward to getting a better understanding of China's latest developments and exchanging views with Chinese leaders on a range of issues of mutual concern, including cross-strait peace, trade and cultural exchanges, during his China visit.
The trip marks the first time a KMT leader will set foot on the mainland since the party, which once ruled all of China, lost a bloody civil war to the Chinese Communists and fled to Taiwan in 1949.
For himself, Lien said, this is the first time in 59 years that he will visit the mainland.
"I left the mainland 59 years ago. It's a long period of time. This was not the result of distance, but rather of our country's 'very heart-rending history,'" Lien said.
"We hope our friends on both sides can grasp this opportunity to move forward for our mutual benefit, peaceful coexistence and prosperity," Lien said before stepping on the plane.

Lien further said his aim is to help Taiwan avoid a disastrous war with communist China, located just 160 kilometers to the west. Beijing has repeatedly threatened to invade Taiwan if it refuses to unify and seeks a permanent split.

The eight-day journey will take Lien to four mainland cities -- Nanjing, Xian, Beijing and Shanghai. While in Beijing, Lien will deliver a speech at Beijing University and meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao.
Lien is being accompanied by his wife and four children as well as a delegation of KMT officials on the historic China trip.

Many KMT politicians, including the party's five vice chairmen -- P. K. Chiang, Wang Jin-pyng, Ma Ying-jeou, Wu Po-hsiung and Lin Cheng-chih -- saw Lien and his entourage off. Also among the well-wishers was opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong.
Lien's visit also marks one of the biggest political ironies in the past decade of dizzying change in Taiwan -- one of Asia's most dynamic democracies.

Pro-independence activists, angry over the opposition's engagement with Beijing, held up placards saying "Lien Chan is selling out Taiwan" and "Lien Chan get out". They also hurled insults at the KMT leader and pelted the airport building with eggs. About 1,000 police with batons and shields helped protect Lien as he boarded a jet for his eight-day journey.

Lien, a former ROC premier and vice president, lost both of his presidential bids, in 2000 and 2004. He has been unwilling to address Chen as president since losing the 2004 presidential election by a slim margin. He filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory, both of which have been rejected by the Taiwan High Court. However, he gave a rare phone call to President Chen Monday afternoon to brief Chen on his China trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT LOBBYING AGAINST LIFTING OF E.U. ARMS SALES BAN
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 25 (CNA) (By Y.S. Lo and P/C/Tang)

TEXT.P: A renowned mainland Chinese dissident now living in the United States said Monday that he is actively lobbying German politicians to change their stances in support of a lifting of the European Union's arms sales ban on China.

Wei Jinsheng, who is currently in Paris on his way back to the United States after his visit to Germany, where he had met with members of various political parties to explain the dangers of lifting the ban, also said that in order to prevent a lifting of the ban, the larger E.U. member states must voice their opposition, adding that the smaller members will then follow suit.

The dissident, who made the remarks in an interview with the Central News Agency, said that his current strategy is to do his utmost to try to influence German politicians, with the goal of having German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder withdraw his support for a lifting of the ban.
Saying that he thinks a lifting of the ban has been postponed by the E.U. until next year, Wei noted that the work of persuading the E.U. not to lift the ban should continue.

Despite the fact that Schroeder and French President Jacques Chirac are keen on supporting a lifting of the E.U. arms sales ban, the dissident, however, said that many people in Europe are opposed to a lifting the ban.
"If the opinions of those who do not agree with a lifting of the ban cannot be voiced at a time when they should be expressed, such opinions could be useless," Wei added.

Claiming that the E.U.'s intention of helping China rebuild its position in the world and normalizing its relations with China by lifting the ban is not logical, Wei said that lifting the ban would cause a division between the United States and Europe.
"China might use this division to stir up trouble in the region as both the United States and the E.U. would be unable to immediately react," he added.
Wei was a leader of Beijing's "Democracy Wall Movement" in the late 1970s. He was imprisoned for more than 14 years for speaking out against China's lack of democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HSIEH HAS NO PLANS TO VISIT CHINA NOW

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he neither has plans to nor wants to visit mainland China for the time being as there are a variety of domestic affairs important to the people's livelihood that need to be handled.

Hsieh made the remarks while answering questions from lawmakers during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan regarding the violent scuffles between "pan blue" and "pan green" supporters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport earlier in the day as Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan departed on his China trip.

Ruling out the possibility of a visit to China for the time being, Hsieh said he feels that it is more important to focus on issues of major concern and interest to the people, such as public order and government budgets.

He stressed that the government will deal with those who caused the violent scuffles at the airport according to the law, Hsieh asserted, adding that Lien's China visit is not in violation of the law and that Lien is entitled to go there under legal protection.

In a pluralistic society like Taiwan, the rule of law is a principle that everyone must follow, he said, adding that society would break down if people with different opinions handled their differences in an irrational way.

Lien's trip to China will run through May 3, during which he will make stops in Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai. The high-profile but controversial visit has been praised by "pan blue" supporters but has backfired among "pan green" backers who accuse Lien of selling Taiwan out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONDEMNS AIRPORT VIOLENCE AS LIEN BEGINS CHINA TRIP

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Tuesday condemned the sporadic violence at CKS International Airport that broke out as ruling and opposition parties scuffled while waiting for opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's departure for China.

Lien left for Nanjing via Hong Kong in the morning. Law enforcers made up of soldiers doing alternative military service tried in vain to separate frequent, but brief clashes between protestors mobilized by the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and supporters from the pro-unification New Party and other opposition members at the departure lobby.
The New Party is a minnow party that forms part of the "pan-blue alliance " that is primarily made up of supporters of the opposition KMT and its splinter group, the People First Party.

During the fracas, DPP Legislator Wang Shih-chien jumped onto a passenger advisory counter and shouted that Lien was "a traitor of Taiwan" to cheering protestors, while New Party supporters lambasted aviation police for allowing Wang to enter the off-limits area.
Police were clearly overwhelmed by the number of protestor and supports who showed up at the airport.

The premier condemned the outbursts of "irrational and violent" behavior, saying that any party, irrespective of its stance, will be dealt with equally by the law, and democracy on the island should be strengthened to mitigate such incidents.

The premier, speaking at a general interpellation session, said that the people who fought were part of the unfortunate few who are unruly and that they do not represent the people in general. "These people should be condemned for their actions and others should not be coerced into taking part in violent activities," he said.
Chen Chien-ming, TSU secretary-general, took the New Party to task for deliberately creating disturbances by attacking TSU supporters.

Chen said that police failed to maintain security at the scene. The TSU people stayed in their designated areas, but "pan-blue" supporters had unceremoniously attacked them, Chen claimed, adding that it was quite clear that a number of gangsters were there to foment trouble under the banner of the "pan-blue" supporters.
Chen said that several people were hurt in the melee, and that five TSU members were injured after being sliced by people's rings as they were assaulted.
The KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan asked the Ministry of Justice to deal seriously with those politicians who created disturbances at the airport.

KMT whip Chen Chieh said that aviation police had not handled the confrontation properly; the result was that DPP Legislator Wang and TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming were able to lead their supporters into the airport terminal.

Tseng Yung-Chuan, a legislator and executive director of the KMT's Central Policy Committee, noted that Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun assured KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng the previous day that Lien would have a smooth departure without incident.

Lien did in fact skirt both demonstrators and supporters by entering the airport via a different route. He greeted party luminaries in a section of the terminal unavailable to the public. Lien made a brief statement reiterating previous descriptions of his trip and then boarded his flight.
William Lai, DPP caucus whip, said that the party regretted the clashes at the CKS Airport, but Lien should shoulder the bulk of the responsibility.

Lai said that the DPP had stressed that Lien's visit to China, the first time for a KMT leader to visit China since the party fled the mainland in 1949, should first get the approval of the public. Failing that, his visit to China was bound to incite violence, he added.

On DPP legislators taking part in the protest, Lai said that the party had told them that they must not go in the name of the party, and that individual participants must abide by the law. The party will try to find out if these instructions were disobeyed.
New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming condemned the violence, adding that the TSU and the aviation police should take full responsibility.
Yok said that the New Party will "from this day on declare war on the TSU and there will be no end to the struggle."

Lee Sheng-feng, New Party secretary-general, echoed Yok's words that aviation police should take full responsibility because they couldn't stop people from taking banners, eggs, rocks, sticks and firecrackers into the airport, which contributed to the ensuing violent clashes.
Lee said that New Party supporters converged outside the airport terminal, but that aviation police had allowed protestors led by DPP and TSU political figures to enter the airport terminal.
When Lien returns from his eight-day visit in China on May 3, the New Party will again mobilize people to greet him, Lee added.
