DOC.HEADLINE: ONE 'VIRTUAL' ROC DESTROYER HOLDS OFF CHINESE ATTACKS FOR TWO WEEKS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense gave a passing grade Tuesday to the fighting power of the ROC Navy's Kidd-class destroyers after a computer simulation showed that a single vessel stopped the assaults of an entire enemy fleet and enabled the nation's armed forces to withstand Chinese attacks for at least two weeks.
The part of the "Hanguang No. 21" military exercise that ended on April 22 entailed two virtual Kidd-class destroyers in the sea north of Taiwan, the defense ministry announced Tuesday.

Director Lee Hao of the Joint Operations, Training and Exercise Center told the media that the Kidd-class destroyer successfully engaged 40 enemy fighter planes, bringing down 16 of them and intercepted 19 enemy missiles before being fatally hit by SU-30 warplanes.

The sunken warship saved the other destroyer, achieving its tactical goal of holding back enemy attacks and ensuring the security of a large part of the Taiwan Strait; therefore, Lee said, "[The loss of the destroyer] was absolutely worth it."
During the initial period of conflict, he said, 40 percent of China's amphibious forces were destroyed and its landing attempts were thwarted.

Minister of National Defense Lee Jye had previously claimed that Taiwan's armed forces could withstand Chinese military attacks for at least two weeks. Lee Hao said the war games showed that the People's Liberation Army would need at least two weeks to regroup along the Chinese coastline before launching a new round of assaults on Taiwan.

The "Hanguang No. 21" was an improvement over its annual counterpart last year, which was criticized for lacking in command performance and poor decision-making. The purpose of the latest war simulation was to enhance the joint combat capabilities of the armed forces, according to Lieut. Gen. Wu Sz-huai, deputy chief of he general staff for operations and planning.
The "Hanguang No. 21" will continue with live fire exercises from June to August that are are aimed at countering China's "unlimited or asymmetric warfare," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE OFFERING MEDICAL ASSISTANCE TO DOMINICAN PEOPLE
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 25 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A total of 38 Taiwanese voluntary workers are offering free medical assistance to thousands of Dominican Republic people suffering from harelip, burns and other medial problems.

The delegation of workers, organized by the charitable organizations Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps and Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation, are providing medical services at the city of Azua, southern Dominican Republic, April 24-28.
Nineteen members of Taiwan Root Medical Peace Corps, which visited the Dominican Republic last August, also offered free medical assistance and consultations to more than 2,100 Dominican citizens.
Ambassador John Feng of the Republic of China noted that those medical doctors and nurses who came to the city of Azua to offer their services paid for their own air tickets and other travel costs.
Under the coordination of Feng, many Taiwanese living in other areas of the Dominican Republic and ROC technical mission members also came to the city to offer assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUFFERS AGRICULTURAL TRADE DEFICIT OF US$1.5 BILLION IN Q1

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural trade totaled US$3.12 billion in the first quarter of this year, leaving a deficit of US$1.5 billion, officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Tuesday.

According to DGBAS statistics, Taiwan's exports and imports of agricultural products registered US$810 million and US$2.31 billion, respectively, in the first quarter of this year, with its deficit representing a growth of US$110 million over the same period of last year.

Japan was the major outlet for Taiwan's agricultural goods, absorbing products worth US$310 million, while China and Hong Kong together imported Taiwan agricultural products worth US$190 million in the first three months, an increase of 15.3 percent over the same period of last year.
Taiwan's agricultural exports to the United States totaled US$80 million from January to March, a decrease of 0.3 percent over the same period of last year, the statistics showed.
Among the categories of products, aquaculture and livestock products formed the bulk of Taiwan's exports in the period, with their exports worth US$610 million, or 75 percent of the total.
Meanwhile, Taiwan imported farm products worth US$1.39 billion in this period, followed by livestock products worth US$450 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May gained 37 points to close at 5,765, with 26,541 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June gained 34 points to close at 5,745, with 278 contracts traded, while September futures gained 18 points to finish at 5,605, with 307 contracts traded. March futures lost 14 points to finish at 5,619, with two contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,728 for May, 5,711 for June, 5,587 for September, 5,591 for December and 5,633 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

May TE futures moved up 2.6 points to close at 224.6, with 4,979 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained three points to finish at 224.3, with 63 contract transactions. December TE futures moved up 1.4 points to close at 222.15, with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for September and March.

May TF futures lost 2.6 points to finish at 916.4 , with 5,003 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved down 2.4 points to end at 916.4, with 40 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down one point to finish at 912.8, with 10 contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF LIEN CHAN ARRIVES IN NANJING, CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, April 26 (CNA) (By Yi-fong Lin and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and his entourage arrived in Nanjing, formerly the capital of the Republic of China, to a warm welcome by Chinese officials Tuesday.

Lien was a little emotional when he stepped into the city, which he said is "a linkage to lots of historical feelings." He vowed to use his "belated" visit to pursue a mutually beneficial, win-win situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait. It was over 60 years ago that he last visited Nanjing.
For the KMT, now an opposition party in Taiwan, Lien said Nanjing is the location of the Nationalist (KMT) government as well as the burial ground of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who founded the ROC.

On Wednesday, he will lead the KMT delegation to pay respects to the memory of Dr. Sun at his mausoleum, an act that he said has "long been hoped for" by many people, and so he felt this is a particularly precious chance to be able to make the visit.

Lien, who departed Taipei in the morning on what he calls "a journey of peace" to China, arrived at the Nanjing airport at around 5: 00 p.m. and was greeted by Chen Yun-lin, director of the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs of the Communist Party of China. Chen is also director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION POLICE OFFICE IN THE FIRING LINE AFTER AIRPORT CLASHES

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) said Tuesday that it is investigating if aviation police properly handled the sometimes violent clashes between supporters of the ruling and opposition parties at the CKS International Airport over opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China.
An NPA spokesman said that NPA Director-General Hsieh Ing-dan was miffed with the way that aviation police handled the scuffles that erupted between the two camps.
Hsieh wants to know as soon as possible if any of the aviation police were negligent, the spokesman said.

Several legislators have expressed their discontent over the way aviation police handled the scuffles between the rivaling supporters, noting that some people carried banners, sticks and firecrackers into the airport terminal, a violation of the law and a smirch on the image of the nation.
The medical aid station of the airport estimated that 15 people were injured during the melee, mostly head injuries, while two more seriously injured persons were taken to a hospital for observation.

Meanwhile, the Aviation Police Office expressed its sorrow to people who were injured in the incident, adding that it would track down those who triggered the disturbances by reviewing video tapes and photos taken during the fracas.
Chen Juei-tien, head of the Aviation Police Office, said that as the airport is an open space, it was not cordoned-off in consideration of the rights of passengers.
This was why some carried hazardous items, such as eggs, sticks and even a long-handled ceremonial knife, into the departure lobby, Chen said.
He admitted that there might have been negligence and lapses in the management of the situation.

Stressing that they had prior communication with all civic groups and had hoped that they would exercise self-restraint and that their supporters would be rational, he said that because of the lapses in control, sticks, rocks and even knives and firecrackers were brought into the airport terminal.

Supporters mobilized by the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , an ally of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and the pro-unification New Party and other opposition members converged at the airport well ahead of Lien's departure at 10:55 a.m.

Police deployed a large contingent of officers on peripheral traffic control, but because of the numerous hallways and corridors in the airport, they couldn't effectively enforce the law by separating the two rival camps.

Aviation police had originally hoped to have the "pan-blue alliance" stay outside of the departure lobby, while the "pan-green camp" was to stay in a parking lot in the west wing, but Legislator Wang Shih-chien of the DPP and his supporters were able to break through the police line and enter the departure lobby from the basement at the airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER ENCOURAGES TAIWAN-GERMANY COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday that economic cooperation between Taiwan and Germany is mutually beneficial and it will open avenues into the global market.
Ho made the remarks at a seminar hosted by the German Trade Office in Taipei to tout Taiwan investments in Germany, the largest single market in the European Union.

German Federal Vice Minister of Transport, Building and Housing Iris Gleicke and Taiwan Committee of German Economy President Michael Fuchs also took part in the seminar, which focused on introducing the investment climate in Germany and the legal process and tax system.

Praising Germany as a superpower in both high technologies as well as traditional sectors including automobiles, medicines, chemistry and basic metal industries and green businesses, Ho said that two-way cooperative ventures between Taiwan and German industries will create a win-win situation for the two sides, as the Taiwan and German economies are complementary in many fields.

She pointed to a company jointly set up by the Taiwan-based Nan Ya Technology and the German-based Infinion Technologies as an example and called the company the best example in the IC industries of the two countries.

Two-way trade totaled US$10.3 billion last year, with US$5.8 billion in inbound shipments from Germany and US$4.5 billion in outbound shipments to that European country, Ho said. Germany is Taiwan's largest trading partner in Europe, while Taiwan is Germany's fourth-largest trading partner in Asia.

Since March 1952, German investments in Taiwan have to date amounted to US$1.22 billion, the third-largest investor from Europe in Taiwan. At the same time, Taiwan investments in Germany totaled US$120 million from some 230 companies.

On the same occasion, Ho also conferred a medal on Hans-Jurgen Muller, managing director of the Taiwan Committee of German Economy, in recognition of his great contributions to economic exchanges and investment cooperation between the two countries.
Fuchs and Muller, who arrived in Taiwan Monday, are slated to leave Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REGRETS HK'S BAN ON ENVOY'S MEETING WITH KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) expressed regret Tuesday over the Hong Kong government's prohibiting Taiwan's envoy from greeting opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan at Hong Kong International Airport earlier in the day.

According to MAC Vice Chairman You Ying-lung, Pao Cheng-kang, Taiwan's representative in Hong Kong, was barred from entering a VIP room to greet Lien when Lien arrived in Hong Kong for a transit stop en route to China for his self-styled "journey of peace."

Lien, heading a large KMT delegation, arrived in Hong Kong at 12: 30 p.m. He was greeted by Xing Kueishan, director of the Taiwan Affairs Department under China's Liaison Office in Hong Kong, and Stephen Lam, director of Hong Kong's constitutional Affairs Bureau.

Pao, who is known as managing director of Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong, also went to the airport to welcome and offer assistance to Lien and his entourage. However, You said, Pao was barred by Hong Kong government staff from meeting Lien.

"We are baffled and regretful at Hong Kong authorities' handling of the matter, " You said, adding that the MAC, which deals with affairs related to China, Hong Kong and Macau, will seek an explanation from the Hong Kong government over the incident.

Lien departed Taipei at 11: 06 a.m. for an eight-day China visit via Hong Kong. The journey will take him to four mainland cities -- Nanjing, Beijing, Xian and Shanghai. He will deliver a speech at Peking University and meet with Chinese President Hu Jintao during his stay in Beijing.

Lien is the first leader from the once staunchly anti-Communist party to set foot in China since the KMT retreated to Taiwan 56 years ago after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese Communists on the mainland.
His visit also marks one of the biggest political ironies in the past decade of dizzying change in Taiwan -- one of Asia's most dynamic democracies.
Violent clashes erupted between supporters and opponents of Lien's China trip at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan prior to Lien's departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN THANKS WMA FOR SUPPORTING TAIWAN'S BID FOR WHA ENTRY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday extended his gratitude to the World Medical Association (WMA) for its support for the name change of Taiwan's membership in the international organization.

Chen made the remark while meeting with visiting chairperson of the WMA Council Yoram Blachar at the Presidential Office. He also said that he hopes the WMA will continue to support Taiwan in its bid to take part in the World Health Assembly (WHA), which is the highest governing body of the World Health Organization (WHO) . The WHO will meet in Geneva May 16-25.
The WMA approved of changing the name of its Taiwan branch from the Chinese Medical Association Taipei to the Taiwan Medical Association during its general assembly in Tokyo Oct. 5-9 last year.

Every year the WMA has passed a proposal to support Taiwan in its bid for WHA entry as an observer, Chen said, adding that he believes the global representative body for physicians will submit a similar proposal to the WHA this year based on the idea that medical treatment knows no boundaries.

The president indicated that many countries in the international community have noticed the fact that no political issues can erase the importance of "global medical treatment, " noting that many countries, including the United States and Japan, voted for Taiwan's bid for WHA observership last year.

The U.S., Japan and 23 of Taiwan's official allies voted for the "Taiwan issue" to be on the WHA agenda last year, but was met with harsh resistance from China. It marked Taiwan's eighth setback in a row.
Taiwan will relaunch its observership bid during the upcoming WHA meeting in May, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `JAPANESE', `AMERICAN' STREETS TO GIVE TAIPEI MORE DIVERSE LOOK

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou asked city planners Tuesday to create "Japanese and American style streets" in Hsimenting, a popular hangout for Taipei teenagers and youths, to give the city a more diverse look and attract foreign tourists.
Ma made the remarks when he presided over an urban rejuvenation project meeting.
At the request of the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei, Taipei has decided to create a "high-class European product street" around the posh Grand Formosa Regent Taipei.
Ma noted that many Western cities have Chinatowns that give the cities a more diverse aura and are often hot spots for foreign tourists.
He said that if Taipei could give the streets of Hsimenting a Japanese flavor, they would definitely lure more tourists and give a more cosmopolitan look to the cityscape.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANK EMPLOYEES TO STAGE DEMONSTRATION MAY 2

TEXT.P: Bank employees are to stage a demonstration May 2 to urge the government to care for their livelihoods, an executive of the National Federation of Bank Employees' Unions (NFBEU) said Tuesday.

NFBEU Chairman Huang Shuei-chuan said at least 6,000 union members will participate in the demonstration, in which they will protest against the conglomerates that they claim are planning mergers that will affect their livelihoods.

The bank employee representatives will present their opposition to a plan of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) to increase tax cuts on mergers of financial institutions, which they claimed will only benefit the conglomerates.

In addition to opposing bank acquisitions by the conglomerates, the union members will also urge the Ministry of Finance, the FSC and the Ministry of Justice to strengthen financial supervision and punish financial fraud, while demanding that the management and the workers sign agreements to safeguard the livelihoods of bank employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT STRESSES THE IMPORTANCE OF HUMAN RIGHTS FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that human rights should be on the minds of everyone in Taiwan and that the true history of how the Kuomintang (KMT) trampled human rights when it ruled Taiwan with an iron fist must be made clear.

Speaking at a news conference called by the Council for Cultural Affairs to mark the 50th anniversary of the first batch of political prisoners being send by the KMT government to the notorious jail on Green Island off the coast of eastern Taiwan, Lu urged the country to come to terms with the country's past poor human rights record.

Lu, who spend several years behind bars as a political prisoner during the KMT's rule, said the news conference is all the more significant because it coincides with KMT Chairman Lien Chan's departure for China.

Lu said it is ridiculous that Lien, whose party has claimed to be a firm defender of the Republic of China (ROC) , dared not carry ROC flags with him on his trip to China, while protesters at the airport where Lien departed Taiwan, who are mainly followers of the pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union, waved ROC flags.

She said the KMT, which fled to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Communist Party of China (CPC) , has turned around its political stance to befriend the CPC after losing power in Taiwan in a desperate attempt to save its political life.

Without naming anyone, Lu said some people are good at undermining democracy under the cover of democracy, and therefore are posing a serious challenge to the country, which might not prompt disaster, but will develop into a big problem.
At the news conference, officials from the Council for Cultural Affairs announced a plan to organize a music festival on Green Island from May 17 to celebrate human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS SPENT US$87.8 MILLION ON POST-TSUNAMI RELIEF AID

TEXT.P: The government has spent US$87.8 million on relief aid for countries affected by the tsunami disaster of last December, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Michel Lu said Tuesday.

The government announced Jan. 2 that it would offer US$50 million in humanitarian aid to South and Southeast Asian countries devastated by a magnitude-9.0 earthquake off the Indonesian island of Sumatra and subsequent tsunami Dec. 26, 2004, including Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand.

Lu said the government has so far spent or committed to spend a total of US$87.8 million on various post-tsunami relief projects that can be grouped into three categories -- food aid, medical assistance and community reconstruction.

With the extent of the devastation in various countries becoming ever clearer, Lu said, the affected countries have adjusted their post-disaster rehabilitation projects accordingly and donor countries have also adjusted their aid projects in line with the recipient countries' needs.

According to Lu, all short-term aid projects, such as dispatching of medical service missions and disinfection missions, as well as cooperation with private groups in delivering relief goods, have been completed.

For mid- and long-term aid projects, Lu said, the Department of Health will be responsible for assisting recipient countries in setting up community medical service centers, while the Public Construction Commission will help with community reconstruction projects.

Lu said the government will evaluate recipient countries' reconstruction plans before deciding the order of donations in order to make best use of the limited relief resources from the national coffers and private donors.

According to Lu, the government has received US$24.21 million in cash for the post-tsunami relief projects, with US$1 million from the MOFA's annual budget, US$10 million from the Cabinet's reserve funds, US$9.83 million in private donations and the remaining funds coming from various public agencies.
In addition, the Council of Agriculture provided US$20 million-worth of food aid.

Moreover, Lu said the Government Information Office launched a project to sponsor 10,000 orphaned children in disaster zones over three years. The program was not included in the original US$50 million aid project, Lu went on, adding that the MOFA will earmark NT$50 million annually from a special bank account opened last year to receive private donations for tsunami victims.

Lu said joining the global post-tsunami relief projects is conducive to the promotion of bilateral relations with recipient countries, participation in multilateral cooperative mechanisms and expression of humanitarian concern for the tsunami victims. He added that the MOFA will continue to closely monitor the implementation of the various aid projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-EU INFORMATION, TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY MEETING TO OPEN

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-European cooperation meeting on information and telecommunications technology will open in Taipei Thursday.

National Science Council (NSC) Chairman Wu Mao-kun will deliver a speech on Taiwan's policies on science and technology development at the opening ceremony, while Hseih Fa-ta, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will speak on topics related to Taiwan's economic development. Brian McDonald, head of the EU office in Taiwan, will also give a speech.

The two-day meeting will be divided into four areas -- information, telecommunications, optoelectronic and e-health -- with experts and scholars from Taiwan and the European Union submitting ideas on 80 different cooperation projects.

NSC officials said that over 800 people have registered to attend the meeting, nearly 90 of which are from EU member states, including those from new EU members -- Latvia, Lithuania, the Slovak Republic and Poland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONDITIONALLY SUPPORTS FORMATION OF TEACHERS' UNIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Tuesday that he will support the idea of teachers forming unions so long as "complementary measures" are presented.
Hsieh made the remarks in response to a question from opposition People First Party Legislator Lin Hue-kuan during an interpellation session.
The premier noted that teachers are still divided on whether to form unions or not, as some fear that if they are considered "laborers," their existing privileges will be revoked.
The Ministry of Education has been opposed to the idea of teachers' unions, fearing that teachers might stage strikes to the detriment of students' rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR 3-PARTY TALKS TO BUILD NATIONAL CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian proposed three-party talks Tuesday between himself and the leaders of Taiwan's two major opposition parties, the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP), in order to build a national consensus on China.

He made the suggestion during a meeting at the Presidential Office with officials of the World Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce, on the same day KMT Chairman Lien Chan led a large opposition delegation on a visit to China.
Soon after Lien completes his China tour May 3, PFP Chairman James Soong will also embark on a trip to China, supposedly also to seek peace for Taiwan and China.

Chen wished both Lien and Soong well in their historic visits and suggested that all three of them sit down as soon as possible for candid discussions about building a consensus on the country's cross-Taiwan Strait policy.

There can be only one voice from Taiwan when dealing with China, Chen said. Only when the ruling and opposition camps reach a consensus can the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reach a consensus, he claimed.
He said it will not be possible for Taiwan's political parties to bridge their differences in a short time, given the fact that they have been fighting each other over the past two decades.
Only through constant communication and negotiation can they begin to have faith in each other, he added.

Chen reiterated his "absolute sincerity" in seeking rapprochement and cooperation with all opposition parties. His 10-point consensus with Soong Feb. 24 is an initial result of the joint efforts of all parties concerned, and his telephone conversation with Lien a day earlier marked a new beginning, he said.

He admitted that "many people" have told him they are "extremely anxious" about the recent internal and external pressures on the government, particularly the possibility that Taiwan's opposition parties are using cross-strait relations as political tools to deal a blow to the government, giving Beijing even more advantages to "divide and conquer" Taiwan.

"I fully understand such worries and anxieties, " said Chen, who stressed that Taiwan must unite in the face of the ever-increasing threats and challenges from across the strait, and "this must be the common knowledge of all 23 million people of Taiwan."
He said democracy and peace must be the guiding principles of the government's cross-strait policy.
"The two principles not only serve the maximum interest of the people of Taiwan but also agree with the expectations of the international community," he said.
Therefore, the president said, he welcomes any effort that will help normalize relations and reduce tension across the strait.
He also repeated no political party or individual can sign a binding deal with China without prior authorization from the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR HELD TO MARK WORLD INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY DAY

TEXT.P: The municipal governments of Taiwan's two largest cities -- Taipei and Kaohsiung -- joined with a private intellectual property rights association in sponsoring a seminar Tuesday to mark the April 26 World Intellectual Property (IP) Day.

Addressing the seminar, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said big cities are hotbeds for the circulation of counterfeit goods. If the Taipei and Kaohsiung city governments can cooperate in crackdown on commercial piracy, Ma said, intellectual property rights issues in Taiwan could be largely resolved.

He pointed out that the United States' reluctance to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan lies in its perception that Taiwan has not yet made sufficient efforts to eradicate commercial piracy and protect intellectual property rights (IPR).
Against this backdrop, he said, the public and private sectors should step up concerted efforts to eliminate counterfeiting to facilitate trade and economic cooperation with other countries.

Speaking on the same occasion, John Eastwood, IPR section chief with the European Chamber of Commerce in Taipei, said Taiwan has made significant progress in IPR protection since its admission to the World Trade Organization. Taiwan has ranked fourth in terms of the number of patent applications approved by the U.S. government in recent years, he said, adding that the government has also revised copyright, patent and trademark laws to tighten IPR protection.
Eastwood said he hopes the government and people can work even harder to further improve IPR protection and clear Taiwan's name as one of the world's major piracy havens.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU PRESIDENT TO VISIT GREEN EXPO IN ILAN

TEXT.P: Palau President Tommy E. Remengesau, Jr. will arrive April 29 in Ilan, northern Taiwan, for a two-day visit, an Ilan county government official said Tuesday.

Remengesau, leading a 12-member delegation including officials in charge of cultural, educational and financial affairs, will meet Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng and visit Green Expo, in addition to attending the inauguration ceremony of a Hotel Royal branch in Chiao Hsi.
Remengesau will give a speech at the inauguration slated for April 30 on the tourist perspectives of Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LAWMAKERS TO MAKE MORE NON-POLITICAL LAWS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh called on the nation's legislators Tuesday to pass more laws, particularly those not related to political wrangling.

Tuesday marked the final day of the current legislative session's general interpellation session and at the end of the day, Hsieh was asked by Legislative Yuan Vice President Yung-chi Chung to make a comment.
He pointed out that he has made 105 promises to lawmakers, 47 of which have been kept, while he is still working on the other 58. "Even easy ones will take time to complete," he said.

Hsieh said he has heard comments that his efforts in seeking "rapprochement and symbiosis" with the opposition parties have gone nowhere, as the ruling and opposition camps remain divided on almost all issues, as seen from the legislative floor.
Now that the interpellation session has come to an end, Hsieh said, legislators should spend more time screening government bills and passing more non-political laws that affect people's daily lives.
He said he has seen many lawmakers putting forward "very progressive ideas" while others have shown their concern for the less privileged in society.
These lawmakers give him reason to feel happy about Taiwan, he said, saluting especially those "who have done their jobs well out of the limelight."

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 27 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Wednesday, April 27:
09: 00, The weekly Cabinet meeting will be held at the Executive Yuan.
09:00, The Legislative Yuan committees will start their sessions for the day.
10: 00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive ROC allies' permanent representatives to the United Nations at the Presidential Office.
10:00, The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union legislative caucus will hold a news conference at the caucus' office on Tuesday's riots at Chiang Kai-shek Airport.
10:00, The National Central University will issue reports on the consumer confidence index at the Fair Trade Commission.
14: 00, The Labor Legislation Action Committee will stage a protest at the Council of Labor Affairs.
14: 00, The Academia Sinica will hold a news conference at its administration building to publicize its research achievements.
14: 30, The Chinese National Federation of Industries will hold its national congress at the Taipei International Convention Center.
15: 00, The Presidential Office will hold a news conference on President Chen Shui-bian's planned trip to the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu.
16: 00, The Council for Economic Planning and Development will issue reports on Taiwan's economic performance in March at the council's headquarters.
18: 55, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will attend the 2005 Labor Day celebrations at the Taipei County Cultural Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION RETURNS HOME AFTER PAPAL INAUGURATION
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 26 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation wrapped up a visit to Tuesday after attending the inauguration of Pope Benedict XVI held April 24.

Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan, who led the delegation, said that during an audience with the pope, he gave him a letter from President Chen Shui-bian and conveyed the congratulations of the Republic of China.
During the meeting, Su also presented the pope with a recent edition of Time magazine, in which Chen and the pope were both selected as two of the 100 most influential figures in the world.

Su's delegation arrived in Rome April 23 and in addition to attending the papal inaugural mass held in St. Peter's Square, Su also visited ROC Embassy in the Vatican, the only European country that maintains diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SHOULD WAIT BEFORE TALKING WITH KMT, PFP HEADS

TEXT.P: An opposition People First Party (PFP) legislator said Tuesday that President Chen Shui-bian should wait until opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong have returned from China before discussing cross-Taiwan Strait issues with them.

Chen Chih-ping, PFP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, made the remarks after the president expressed the hope of discussing with Lien and Soong the establishment of a peaceful and stable cross-strait interchange framework and to formulate a consensus between the ruling and opposition on cross-strait policy.
"It maybe a bit too late" for the three-party talks, Chen said, adding that it would be better to wait for their return from China and that former President Lee Teng-hui should also join such talks.

Lien left for China earlier in the day for an eight-day visit. He will meet with Chinese President and Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao Friday, marking the first meeting of KMT-CPC leaders since the KMT fled China in 1949.
Chen also said that the president should have invited opposition leaders for talks before China's March 14 enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan.

Moreover, he claimed, the important thing in the cross-strait issue is not whether to talk with opposition leaders, but whether the government wants reconciliation or confrontation with the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile, PFP Secretary-General Chin Chin-sheng returned to Taipei that day after marathon consultations with Chen Yunlin, head of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, to arrange for Soong's itinerary in China.
Soong will depart for Xian May 5, and then visit Changsha, Xiangtan, Nanjing, Shanghai and Beijing before returning April 12.

Chin said that Soong met with President Chen Feb. 24, during which they reached a 10-point conclusion including no declaration of independence, no change of the nation's official name and no change of the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, which he said entails government policy.
Chin expressed the hope that China will understand Taiwan's mainstream views through a meeting between Soong and the Beijing leadership.
The main issue for Taiwan is cross-strait relations, Chin said, and Soong's visit to China aims to bring new hope for the wellbeing of the people, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVIATION POLICE OFFICE CHIEF APOLOGIZES OVER AIRPORT CLASHES

TEXT.P: The chief of the Aviation Police Office apologized to the public Tuesday in the wake of the violent clashes at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway to the world.

Chen Juei-tien's apology came after supporters of the pro-independence opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union and pro-unification New Party rioted while waiting for opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's departure for an eight-day visit to China.

Legislators questioned whether there was negligence on the part of aviation police in maintaining order and security at the airport and Premier Frank Hsieh has instructed the Ministry of the Interior to file a report on the clashes in the shortest possible time.

Chen said that the departure lobby was in good order before 8 a.m. until a group of people rammed through the east gate into the airport terminal, carrying with them weapons and firecrackers and triggering five or six rounds of clashes between rival supporters that left 15 people injured.

He reaffirmed that he had prior communications with the representatives of civic groups planning to go to the airport for Lien's departure and was given promises that they would "exercise self-restraint." He expressed regret that police failed to stop the clashes and asked for discipline for himself to his superior, National Police Administration Director-General Hsieh Ing-dan.
Chen also said his office is tracking down the people who triggered the disturbances by reviewing video tapes and photos taken at the scene.

On questions whether public officials -- councilors or legislators -- violated the law by leading their supporters into the departure lobby, Chen said only that the office is checking related information and will deal with the issue according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD'S CHINA TRIP MARKS SERIOUS BLOW FOR ROC DIPLOMACY: MOFA

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China has dealt a serious blow to the Republic of China's diplomacy, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen claimed Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks after Lien, a former ROC premier and vice president, departed for China earlier in the day on a self-styled "journey of peace."
Although President Chen Shui-bian has thrown his support behind Lien's China trip, the foreign minister said he personally opposes Lien's visit at this critical moment.
The trip comes shortly after Beijing's enactment of its so-called anti-secession law that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.

"While our diplomatic staff are busy explaining our stance on that ill-intentioned legislation to their host countries to win their support for our national cause, Lien's China visit has baffled those same countries, " he said, adding he is afraid that Lien's pandering to Beijing will make foreign officials wonder what exactly is Taiwan's stance toward the law.

Noting that Lien once served as minister of foreign affairs, premier and vice president, Tan Sun Chen said he simply cannot believe that Lien is unaware of how grave an impact his China visit could have on the nation's diplomatic work.

As an opposition leader, he went on, Lien is free to visit China. "But he should have considered the timing of his visit, " the minister said, adding that Lien's China visit at this moment has hurt Taiwan's national interests and international image.
He also said that American officials are divided over Lien's visit.
While some U.S. officials have made positive comments, Tan Sun Chen said some others have voiced negative opinions.

During the Vietnam War, he continued, some U.S. congressional members also traveled to then-North Vietnam in their private capacities. At that time, the American government criticized their acts as "a piece of showmanship" for personal limelight.
While the United States hopes to see direct dialogue across the Taiwan Strait, he said, it would be meaningful only if Lien were representing the government in his talks with the Chinese authorities.
The minister urged Lien to uphold the ROC's national dignity during his China visit and to courageously discuss the problems of the anti-secession law with the Chinese leadership.
"Only by so doing can our foreign friends continue to voice support for us in the international arena, " the foreign minister said.

Lien's visit also marks one of the biggest political ironies in the past decade of dizzying change in Taiwan -- one of Asia's most dynamic democracies. Violent clashes erupted between supporters and opponents of Lien's China trip at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan prior to Lien's departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CONDEMNS VIOLENCE AT CHIANG KAI-SHEK AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has condemned the violence that took place Tuesday at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and vowed to bring those responsible to justice, according to Cho Jung-tai, the spokesman for the Executive Yuan.

Cho said the premier also ordered a review of the policing at the airport after learning that the supporters of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's trip to China and demonstrators angered by his decision to make the visit clashed in the terminal building, despite the deployment of 3,031 policemen in addition to 640 police aides.
Offenders will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law regardless of their political position, the premier was quoted as saying.
Police officers found to have been derelict in their duties will also be punished, the spokesman said.

Saying that the airport is off limits to any public gathering, Cho said the premier was surprised that the police failed to take action to preempt the clashes despite learning from news reports that Lien's supporters would appear in force to see the KMT chief off at the airport while the protestors threatened to pack the airport to stop him from leaving.
Furthermore, Cho went on, many dangerous objects such as sticks and firecrackers, which are forbidden in the airport, were carried into the terminal building and used as weapons.

Although the security of Lien and his entourage was not threatened, the incident caused inconvenience and panic among other passengers and resulted in chaos that exposed the defects in the police efforts, Cho went on.

Citing a preliminary police report, the spokesman said the policemen on the scene were put off their stroke when a large group of people in the airport's parking lot dashed into the terminal to take refuge from a sudden rain shower before the riots erupted.

Also, Cho said, the police report pointed out that many young men bearing resemblance to habitual troublemakers in other political rallies were seen at the airport, which he described as more than mere coincidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO LOOK INTO FRAY AT CHIANG KAI-SHEK AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Three prosecutors from the Taoyuan District Court were instructed Tuesday to investigate a fray at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County between supporters of opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and demonstrators enraged by Lien's decision to visit China.

Chiang Kui-chang, a deputy chief prosecutor at the Taoyuan District Court, said the three prosecutors, whose names were not released, will subpoena and question those who took part in the melee and were caught by surveillance cameras carrying sticks, knives and firecrackers into the terminal building.
They will also review news footage of the riots to identify the troublemakers, Chiang said.
Several people were injured in the brawl in which Lien's supporters and the protestors fought with sticks, rocks and firecrackers in the airport's terminal building.
Thousands of Lien's supporters flocked to the airport Tuesday morning to see Lien off, as did the protestors, who condemned Lien as a traitor to Taiwan and tried to stop him from leaving.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CHINA WOULD NEVER GO TO WAR: EX-U.S. DIPLOMAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will never fight against each other, former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Richard Holbrooke said here last Friday, according to a transcript that was made available Monday.

Fielding questions after a speech to the Council on Foreign Relations, Holbrooke said he does not think either Taiwan or China will invade the other because Taiwan is never going to invade China, while China would destroy its international position if it were to invade Taiwan, he said.
By this reason, Holbrooke said, the Taiwan issue is manageable as long as the United States maintains its commitment to Taiwan and encourages cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 27, or the 19th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan-controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

Taiwan's opposition leader arrived in China on Tuesday on a historic trip aimed at easing tensions with Beijing, becoming the most prominent Taiwanese political figure to visit the mainland since the two sides split amid civil war in 1949.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. REITERATES SUPPORT FOR EXPANSION OF CROSS-STRAIT CONTACTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States government supports the expansion of cross-strait contacts, a U.S. State Department spokesman said Tuesday.
At a daily press briefing, Adam Ereli, a State Department deputy spokesman, described the contacts between Taiwan's opposition parties and the Chinese mainland as "positive developments."

Ereli was asked by a reporter whether the United States is concerned about escalating political tension caused by Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China as right before Lien's departure for the mainland, a violent pro-independence protest took place at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

"We believe that steps that increase dialogue, support dialogue, support a peaceful resolution of cross-strait tension are to be supported, are to be welcomed, and that's the case with this latest visit," Ereli answered.
"And we support the expansion of those kinds of contacts, " he added.

Ereli, however, declined to comment when he was asked if the United States has any concerns about whether the steps the KMT may take could undermine the U.S. policies or change the status quo since Taiwan's government has warned the KMT not to engage in state-related negotiations or sign any form of agreement with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Reclamation row is resolved.
Singapore and Malaysia yesterday formally ended a three-year dispute over reclamation in the Johor Straits.
What began in acrimony concluded in smiles yesterday morning as Ambassador-at-large Tommy Koh and Tan Sri Ahmad Fuzi, secretary-general of Malaysia's foreign ministry, inked a settlement agreement. It represents a full and final resolution to the dispute, a joint statement said.
The Lianhe Zaobao: S'pore and Malaysia ink a settlement agreement to end the reclamation row.
Singapore and Malaysia inked a settlement yesterday to end a three-year dispute over reclamation in Johor Straits.
Singapore can continue reclaiming in Johor Straits as planned but will take steps to minimize the environmental impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES PEOPLE TO FOLLOW ROC FOUNDING FATHER'S WILL
DOC.DATELINE: Nanjing, China, April 27 (CNA) (By Lin Yi-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, on the second day of his historic visit to China, called for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to answer Republic of China founding father Sun Yat-sen's will expressed 80 years ago for "peace, striving and saving China."

Lien, the first KMT chairman to visit Sun's mausoleum in Nanjing in nearly 60 years, said Wednesday that at this crucial juncture in history when Taiwan and mainland China remain in political deadlock, people from across the Taiwan Strait should follow Sun's will by "grasping the moment to create a brighter future for the Chinese people."

Addressing thousands of spectators at the Chuangshan Mausoleum, Lien exhorted the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to follow the ROC founding father's will by "enabling Taiwan to become a society of equal wealth and allowing the mainland to continue to flourish economically."

Lien said that it is of special significance for him to lay a wreath at Sun's tomb this year as it marks the 80th anniversary of the ROC founding father's death and the 60th anniversary of the end of Chinese fighting against the Japanese invasion.

Nanjing is the first leg of Lien's historic "journey of peace" to China, which began Tuesday. At the top of his itinerary will be a meeting with mainland Chinese President Hu Jintao in Beijing on Friday. The trip will also take Lien to Xian and Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP APOLOGIZES FOR AIRPORT CLASHES

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) apologized to the public Wednesday for the clashes between "pan-green" and "pan-blue" supporters a day earlier at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

DPP caucus whip Lai Ching-teh said the caucus apologizes for the damage to the country's image caused by the incident. He also urged judicial authorities to conduct an investigation and track down the troublemakers.

A demonstration at the airport organized by individual politicians from the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union to protest opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's China trip turned violent as the protesters clashed with supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance."
Lai claimed that it is unfair for the opposition to point the finger solely at the "pan-green camp, " especially at DPP Legislator Wang Shih-Chien, for starting the scuffles.
Lai said judicial authorities must determine the identity of a group of people dressed in black, suspected of being gangsters, who attacked "pan-green" protesters at the scene.
Meanwhile, DPP Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin said the party strongly condemns the incident, which he said has seriously damaged the democratic image of the country.

Yen called on judicial authorities to act against any organizations or individuals who were involved in inciting the violence and pledged to take disciplinary action against any DPP members or public office holders who engaged in any unlawful activities.
Yen said members of the underworld must not be allowed to take advantage of demonstration activities to make trouble.

According to Yen, the DPP had prohibited its members and public office holders from participating in the demonstration in the name of the party and had asked them not to resort to violence or other unlawful means in expressing their opinions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC-DPP TALKS WOULD BE GOOD FOR ALL: JAPANESE DAILY

TEXT.P: The mass-circulation Japanese daily Mainichi Shimbun urged China Wednesday not to use Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit as a "political tool to divide Taiwan."

Instead, Beijing should use the historic meeting between Lien and Hu Jintao, general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) , as a "strategic tool to enter into peaceful dialogue with Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , " the daily said in an editorial.

If the KMT-CPC summit can develop into cross-Taiwan Strait dialogue -- that is, the resumption of bilateral talks that have been suspended since the DDP came to power, then this will create a "win-win" situation not only for both sides of the strait, but also for the United States and Japan, the daily said.

The editorial said that Taiwan by no means has the capability to attack China and that it is China's Anti-Secession Law, which authorizes Beijing to use non-peaceful means to settle disputes with Taiwan, that has created tensions across the strait.

It is undeniable that China's "non-peaceful law" has invited world-wide condemnation, and so, the best way to settle cross-strait disputes is for China to resume talks with Taiwan's ruling party, the editorial said.

Besides the KMT's Lien, who is currently on an official visit to China, People First Party Chairman James Soong is also due to visit China. Indeed, there is public support for the opposition parties' China visits, but for Beijing, the most significant visit would be one by the ruling DDP, it said.

The editorial said that in order to avoid "unnecessary storms," China and Taiwan should shake off the "old pattern" of KMT-CPC dialogue and adopt a "new pattern" of formal dialogue between the two governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE SPELLS OUT BOTTOM LINES ON 'PEACE LAW'

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office has "three bottom lines" for the enactment of a proposed "cross-strait peace promotion law, " President Chen Shui-bian's chief of staff Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

At a party in honor of members of the media, Yu said that the bottom lines are that there is no "92 consensus" on soverignty or "one China" issues; that if there will be an office responsible for the implementation of the "peace law, " it is acceptable that the office be established under the Presidential Office; and that the contents or stipulations of the "peace law" should not infringe on the purview of the president and should comply with the principles of the Republic of China Constitution.

This marked the first time that the Presidential Office had made any statement on the proposed "cross-strait peace promotion law" initiated by the opposition People First Party and currently under debate in the Legislative Yuan.

Yu, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, reiterated that so long as the draft law complies with the three bottom lines, the Presidential Office will not interfere in its enactment and implementation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI READY TO WELCOME PANDAS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Zoo will be able to complete all necessary preparations in six months if China is willing to present pandas to Taiwan, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday.

Ma was referring to a local media report that China's President Hu Jintao is planning to give pandas to Taiwan through opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who is on a visit to China and is set to meet Hu Friday.
According to Ma, workers at the zoo have had contact with Chinese zoologists in the past and have undergone some basic training related to the care of pandas.
They will be ready to handle the job if given a further few months of intensive training, Ma said.
Ma said bamboo grown in Chutzuhu on Yangmingshan will supply food for the pandas, although more will have to be planted to meet the demand.

However, as the panda is one of the imperiled species protected under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) , it still requires the approval of the agricultural authorities of both sides before it can be exported from China to Taiwan, Ma noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS DEMAND POLITICIANS BROUGHT TO JUSTICE

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) on Wednesday requested that elected representatives who had caused disturbances in the bloody clashes at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport the previous day be brought to justice quickly.

The KMT and PFP legislative caucuses made the request at a breakfast meeting with National Police Administration (NPA) Deputy Director General Liu Shih-lin and Acting Aviation Police Office chief Hu Ya-ping.
They also requested that Interior Minister Su Jia-Chyuan and National Police Administration Director-General Shieh Yin-tang resign from their posts to take responsibility for the violent clashes.
Violence erupted at the airport between supporters of KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who departed for China Tuesday morning for a historic visit, and demonstrators protesting Lien's China visit.

The opposition legislators asked why the elected representatives involved in inciting the scuffles were not included on the first list of troublemakers published by law enforcement authorities Tuesday evening.

They claimed that the NPA had coordinated with Legislator Wang Shih-chien of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) before the incident, but they wondered if the NPA was trying to "give it a go" to the "protege of Premier Frank Hsieh" -- referring to Legislator Wang.

Chen Chih-ping, PFP caucus whip in the legislature, said that the administration is either incompetent or condoned the incident, saying that to condone those who had caused the scuffles at Taiwan's main gateway to the world will only keep foreign investors at bay.
"Premier Hsieh should deal with the bloody clashes at the airport resolutely," Chen urged.

Acting Aviation Police Office chief Hu said that more than 1,400 police were deployed at the terminal building, and the office had prior consultations with Legislator Wang that no one should carry weapons into the terminal building, but unfortunately, the police line was broken through during the demonstration.

Hu and Liu said that they are reviewing the surveillance camera videotapes as well as photos taken during the melee, and that they will interview the second list of troublemakers, which they said should have included Legislator Wang.

However, the Aviation Police Office said that those who broke through the police line to enter the terminal building via the basement, which foiled the police's original plan to keep the rival "pan-green" and "pan-blue" supporters separated, were not "recorded" by the surveillance cameras.
Liu said that the NPA's decision to transfer Aviation Police Office chief Chen Juei-tien to another post is to show responsibility for the airport violence.

Chen Chieh, KMT caucus whip in the legislature, then read a joint statement by the KMT and the PFP, in which they requested that DPP Legislators Wang and Hsu Kuo-yung as well as lawmakers Lin Kuo-ching and Lo Chih-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, be brought to justice and that the government promise that a similar incident will not occur when Lien returns from his China trip May 3 or when PFP Chairman James Soong departs for his China visit May 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU APOLOGIZES OVER AIRPORT RIOTS

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) apologized Wednesday over the bloody clashes that erupted between supporters of the "pan-green camp" and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" a day earlier at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport as opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan left for a visit to China.

A massive police presence deployed at the airport utterly failed to separate demonstrators protesting against Lien's visit and those who supported his historic trip, resulting in several waves of clashes that left 15 people injured.

Several TSU legislators called a press conference to condemn the violence. National Police Administration (NPA) Deputy Director General Liu Shih-lin and Acting Aviation Police Office chief Hu Ya-ping also attended.

TSU Legislator Liao Pen-yen pointed out that the bloody clashes at the airport have damaged the nation's image and he also urged the NPA to handle the aftermath properly and visit those who were injured, claiming that they were the victims of "gangsters."

TSU Legislator Huang Tsung-yuan claimed that the fights were caused by "gangsters" collaborating with the "pan-blue alliance," and he slammed the police incompetence, pointing out that the aviation police office had been warned in advance about possible disturbances, but failed to keep any form of control whatsoever.
Liu said that this was a painful incident for the police and he admitted that the police made a gross mistake by allowing the demonstrators to converge at off-limits areas in the airport.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: GOP to Reverse Ethics Rule Blocking New DeLay Probe; January Change Led Democrats to Shut Down Panel.
House Republican leaders, acknowledging that ethics disputes are taking a heavy toll on the party's image, decided yesterday to rescind a controversial rule change that led to the three-month shutdown of the ethics committee, according to officials who participated in the talks, the paper said.
