The Moscow Times: Putin Kicks Off Visit to Mideast.
Vladimir Putin arrived Tuesday in Cairo on his first visit to the Middle East as president, becoming the first Russian or Soviet leader in 40 years to make an official state visit to Egypt, once a close ally of the former Soviet Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 26.98 points to close at 5,778.27.
The bourse opened at 5,806.69 and fluctuated between 5,817.92 and 5,777.41 during trading. A total of 2.0 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$46.68 billion (US$1.48 billion).
Only one of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement issues moving up at 0.5 percent.

The other seven stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.5 percent, banking and financial issues at 1.1 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 0.7 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals, as well as textile shares, both at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 678 to 186, with 143 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OUTLINES CONDITIONS FOR REOPENING DOOR TO CHINESE MEDIA OUTLETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan would be willing to reopen its doors to two Chinese media outlets so long as Beijing lifts its blackout against the online versions of two Taipei-based newspapers and refrains from blocking its local press groups from posting reporters in Taiwan, a senior official said Wednesday.

David Wei-feng Huang, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks while delivering a report on the current state of journalistic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait at a Legislative Yuan Education Committee meeting.

The MAC suspended April 10 permits allowing China's state-controlled Xinhua news agency and People's Daily newspaper to post correspondents in Taiwan on the grounds that the two media outlets had repeatedly abused their privileges by turning out misleading reports about Taiwan.
Huang said the bans are temporary in nature and that the MAC will decide whether to lift the bans in terms of China's response to Taiwan's call for constructive cross-strait journalistic exchanges.

If China removes its blockade against the online editions of the Taipei-based China Times and United Daily News and refrains from obstructing its local newspapers from sending correspondents to Taiwan, Huang said, the MAC would be willing to consider resuming its permits for the two Chinese media outlets.

Speaking on the same occasion, Pasuya Yao, head of the Government Information Office (GIO) , said the Chinese authorities still regard their media outlets as party organs or propaganda machines dedicated to publicizing their policies and promoting their "united front" tactics.
As China has deliberately blocked Taiwan media outlets' Internet Web sites, Yao said, people there have had limited access to Taiwan-related information.

In the future, he went on, the GIO will continue to promote cross-strait journalistic exchanges in terms of the government's fundamental cross-strait policy of "active opening and effective management."

Taiwan first allowed Chinese media to post reporters in Taiwan in late 2000. Besides Xinhua and People's Daily, three other Chinese media outlets -- China Central Television, China News Agency and China National Radio -- have also posted journalists in Taiwan. Each of them is allowed to send two reporters to Taiwan, rotating them out each month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CIGARETTES TO LOSE 'LONGLIFE' NAME

TEXT.P: The name of Taiwan's major cigarette brand will not be called "Longlife" any more once a much-tougher amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Act is passed and implemented, government sources said Wednesday.

The amendment -- passed by the Executive Yuan Wednesday and to be soon submitted to the Legislative Yuan for approval -- stipulates that all words and phrases hinting that cigarettes are "mild, " "low tar, " or "may lead people to mistakenly believe that smoking does not impair health" will be banned from packs or containers of cigarettes.

Smokers and dealers' days in the future are seen to be more difficult, as the amendment to the Tobacco Hazards Act carrying much tougher articles than before, including that tobacco tax, imposed to finance the cash-strapped national health insurance program, will be raised from NT$5 to NT$10 per pack.

Premier Frank Hsieh has also instructed that in the future, tobacco tax will be imposed based on the unit price of the cigarette packs, meaning that smokers will have to pay more than NT$10 (US$0.317) for tax upon each purchase of higher-priced cigarettes.
The amendment also imposes much stricter regulations on tobacco advertising or sponsorship of events.
No-smoking areas will also be increased noticeably -- extending to college and university campuses, buses and MRT systems, taxi-cabs, karaoke clubs, Internet parlors and other indoor public places.

Violators, whether they are cigarette manufacturers or importers, will face fines ranging from NT$500,000 (US$15,800) to NT$2.5 million per violation. If they are advertising agents or media outlets, they will face fines ranging from NT$200,000 to NT$1 million per violation.
Selling cigarettes in places where smoking is prohibited will also be banned, with violators facing fines from NT$2,000 to NT$10,000 per violation, according to the amendment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May lost 20 points to close at 5,745, with 15,266 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for June dropped 13 points to close at 5,732, with 127 contracts traded, while September futures lost 10 points to finish at 5,595, with 89 contracts traded.
December futures moved down 33 points to finish at 5,596, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,765 for May, 5,745 for June, 5,605 for September, 5,628 for December and 5,596 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
May TE futures moved down 0.1 points to close at 224.5, with 3,664 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained 0.1 points to finish at 224.1, with 20 contract transactions.
September TE futures moved down 0.9 points to close at 223.4, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

May TF futures lost 7.8 points to finish at 908.6, with 3,100 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved down 6.8 points to close at 908.2, with 23 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down 9.6 points to finish at 900.2, with five contract transactions, while December TF futures dropped 6.6 points to close at 905, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, gaining NT$0.028 to finish at NT$31.441.
A total of US$673 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's low at NT$31.436 and reached a high of NT$31.513 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT POLICIES CONSISTENT ON OPPOSITION'S CHINA VISITS

TEXT.P: The attitudes of President Chen Shui-bian and the government toward opposition leaders' visits to China are steady and consistent, the president's chief of staff Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.

At a party for journalists, Yu said the government's position has been clear and consistent on opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China and a similar visit by opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong slated to begin May 5.
Yu said Taiwan and the United States have not raised the level of bilateral dialogue over Lien's or Soong's China visits.
Chen has also not met with American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office Director Douglas Paal for talks on the visits, Yu added.
Meanwhile, Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Ma Yung-cheng denied that the government attitudes toward the visits have been contradictory or have wavered.

Ma said that the law is clear. Citing the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area, he said the opposition leaders are prohibited from signing any kind of agreement or reaching any type of "oral" accord with the Chinese communist regime if they have not been authorized by the government on matters involving public authorization or national sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE SUPPORTS CABINET'S HANDLING OF AIRPORT CLASHES

TEXT.P: Presidential Office officials expressed support Wednesday for the Cabinet's handling of the clashes between "pan-green" and "pan-blue" supporters a day earlier at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

The violence broke out as a group of protesters from the ruling "pan-green" camp clashed with another group of supporters of the opposition "pan-blue" alliance while staging a demonstration at the airport against a trip to China by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.

While Premier Frank Hsieh vowed Tuesday to bring the troublemakers to justice, the National Police Administration also removed Chen Juei-tien, head of the Aviation Police Office, from his post for failing to maintain order at the airport.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun said the office regrets the clashes and supports the Cabinet's decisions in handling the aftermath of the incident.

According to Yu, the incident was the result of long-time confrontation between the two rival camps, and in light of this situation, President Chen Shui-bian has been promoting reconciliation between the two camps to try to bring an end to their confrontation.
Ma Yung-cheng, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, said it takes time, wisdom and patience to resolve the rivalry and restore mutual trust between both camps.
Ma said it does not help to put the blame on either side and proposed that both sides sit down for talks to seek a resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA CANNOT IGNORE PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR DPP: HK DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 27 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: By giving the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) leaders high-profile treatment, China is trying to marginalize Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , but can "never ignore" the public support in Taiwan behind the DPP, a Hong Kong newspaper said Wednesday.

The Hong Kong Economic Journal said China is using "exactly the same" strategy for Taiwan that it did for Hong Kong under British rule. China's present tactic toward Taiwan would be "deja vu" to Hong Kong people, it claimed in an editorial.

The journal said that while Beijing can claim Hong Kong's legislature did not have enough representation, as it was not popularly elected during British colonial rule, China can never ignore the fact that Taiwan's government has been popularly elected.

If China's "united front" efforts cannot boost KMT and PFP popularity, and China's evident support cannot help the two opposition parties win the next election, then visits to China by their chairmen will not work wonders, it added.
KMT Chairman Lien Chan is on a high-profile visit to China, and PFP Chairman James Soong is due to visit early next month.

The Journal said that if China really wants to boost popular support in Taiwan for the two opposition parties, China's leaders would do best by promising Lien they will take a series of actions that strongly demonstrate goodwill toward Taiwan, including dismantling missiles targeting Taiwan and allowing Taiwan to participate conditionally in international organizations.
The latter could deflate DPP accusations that China is bent on stifling Taiwan in its attempts to lead a normal international life, according to the editorial.
It further pointed out that Hong Kong's status as a major conduit for cross-Taiwan Strait contact will diminish and become irrelevant if political leaders in Taiwan keep visiting China.

If tension is lowered and direct transportation links are set up between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Hong Kong will lose not just its "historical status" as a conduit but also economic interests, said the journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA SEEKS REMEDIAL MEASURES AFTER BLOODY CLASHES AT AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) is seeking damage control measures following bloody clashes that erupted between supporters of the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance" a day earlier at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport as opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan left for a visit to China.

Faced with a barrage of criticism over the violent scuffles at the nation's main gateway that left 15 people injured while a massive police presence stood idly by watching, the NPA demoted Aviation Police Office chief Chen Juei-tien, while NPA Director General Shieh Yin-tang also asked the Ministry of the Interior for discipline to shoulder responsibility for the chaos that made international headlines.
During an overnight meeting to review crisis management operations, Shieh claimed that self-examination will be more important than meting out discipline for dereliction of duty.

Shieh noted that Lien will wind up his China visit May 3 and that opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong will leave for China May 5, and said the NPA will make preparations to brace for further protests.

On May 3, Shieh said, additional riot police will be deployed at the airport, while a police force formed by alternative military servicemen who were criticized for lacking experience in dealing with riots during the violent clashes the previous day, will be in the second line.

In view of a convoy of vehicles led by pro-independence activists that carried out a dangerous stunt in an attempt to intercept Lien's limousine on his way to the airport on the freeway, the NPA has also planned a rigorous security operation.
Shieh also gave strict orders that no more loopholes or negligence in security checks can be permitted at the airport and that any troublemakers must be arrested.
Meanwhile, a police task force, after reviewing video tapes of surveillance cameras and photos taken during the melee, said it had identified nearly 30 gangsters from the Bamboo Union criminal gang.
Task force officials said that the gangsters, most dressed in national flags or black, seemed quite young.
They carried weapons such as rocks and slingshots and broke through the inept police into off-limits areas of the terminal building whenever the chance arose, police said.
They seemed to be quite organized, they added. Police are now asking for arrest warrants from prosecutors to launch a series of arrests.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG LAWYER SUES DPP LAWMAKER, NEW PARTY CHAIRMAN OVER CLASHES

TEXT.P: A lawyer from central Taiwan filed a lawsuit Wednesday against Legislator Wang Shih-chien of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and opposition New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming for alleged violation of the law of assembly and demonstration.

Taichung lawyer Huang Ying-chieh said the two set the worst possible examples during the bloody clashes a day earlier between supporters of the "pan-green camp" and the "pan-blue alliance" at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that left 15 people injured.

Filing the lawsuit at the Taichung District Court, Huang claimed Legislator Wang directed supporters to the airport terminal building without prior legal application and did not try to restrain his supporters from violence, which inflicted immeasurable damage to the nation's image.
Huang said that although he belongs to the same party as Wang, he will nevertheless sue him.

Moreover, Huang said, Lien communicated with President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of his departure for China and obtained the president's blessing for his visit, but Wang led his supporters to protest against Lien, which he described as wrong.

Meanwhile, supporters led by Yok might have traded punches after provocation, but Yok also lacked manners and spoke such mob language as "returning blood with blood, " which Huang said was a serious provocation to ethnic harmony.

To avoid any repetition of similar violent confrontations when Lien returns May 3 after winding up his eight-day visit to China, Huang said that he decided to file suits against the two in the hope that the law will forestall potential troublemakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI OFFERS PRIZES FOR DISCOVERY OF MRT ENGLISH ERRORS

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government's Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORTS) will offer prizes to people who point out the errors on the English signs and in the printed materials relating to the city's mass rapid transit (MRT) system, officials said Wednesday.
The activity will run from May 1 to July 31, and the errors can include those of spelling, usage, grammar and translation, according to the officials.
Participants will win MRT-bus passenger passes with a credit value of NT$1,000 (US$31.84) or other souvenirs if their entries are determined correct by the DORTS' bilingual consultants, they said.

To create a Chinese-English bilingual living environment to upgrade the capital city's image as an international metropolis, the DORTS has recently completed a series of bilingual signs and issued some bilingual publications, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA LIFTS BAN ON U.S. APPLE IMPORTS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) lifted a four-month ban on apple imports from the United States Wednesday, saying that U.S. quarantine authorities have adopted measures to minimize the risk of moth larvae infesting their fruit.

The Cabinet-level council banned imports of U.S. apples Dec. 21, 2004 after discovering codling moth larvae in separate shipments from the United States in September, October and December last year. According to an agreement signed in 2003, the United States is required to suspend apple exports to Taiwan if codling moths are found three times in apple shipments within a year.
Over the past four months, a COA official said, the U.S. quarantine bureau has produced investigative reports and adopted improvement measures to prevent moth larvae infestation.

Yeh Ying, deputy director of the COA's Animal and Plant Quarantine and Inspection Bureau, said that COA quarantine officials have conducted many rounds of on-the-spot inspections in the United States in the past few months.

"The results of on-the-spot inspections show that the U.S. revised work procedure met with our quarantine demands and that related measures can effectively reduce the risk of apple infestation, " Yeh said, adding that the council has thus decided to lift the ban from April 27.
"Apples cleared by U.S. quarantine officials on or after April 27 are now eligible to enter Taiwan," Yeh said.
As to when U.S. apples can hit market shelves, Yeh said it will depend on how fast U.S. suppliers handle their export procedures.
The codling moth is considered a major pest affecting crops of apples, pears, quince and walnut in Europe, Asia and North America.

Taiwan consumes around 115,000 tonnes of apples annually, relying on imports to meet more than 90 percent of demand. Until the ban, the United States was the largest supplier. Taiwan had imported 10,800 tons of apples last year as of Dec. 20, 52 percent of which were from the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY SLUGGISH, BUT WILL REBOUND: CEPD

TEXT.P: A yellow-blue light was recorded for Taiwan's economy in March, meaning that it has gone from "stable" to "sluggish, " the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

According to the five-color rating system devised by the CEPD to gauge Taiwan's economy, red means an overheated economy, yellow-red represents a heating-up economy, green reflects stability, yellow-blue stands for sluggishness and blue points to recession.

But Hung Juei-ping, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that export orders in March setting a new monthly high coupled with a sliding unemployment rate should contribute to a building up of momentum for the economy, and predicted a clear economic rebound in the latter half of the year.
CEPD officials noted that the composite index for March was cut by 2 points from 23 to 21, making it the first time Taiwan's economy has flashed a yellow-blue light since June 2003.
The leading index in March slid to 106.3 from 106.7, down by 0.4 percent from February, marking the sixth consecutive monthly decline.
But Hung pointed out that domestic manufacturers have continued to be optimistic about the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 70% OF SECRETARIES WANT TO CHANGE JOBS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of secretaries responding to a survey said they had thought of changing jobs, although some 55.62 percent of the respondents said they like their jobs, according to the results of the survey released Wednesday, Secretary's Day 2005.
The online 1111 Job Bank, cooperating with a secretary association in Taipei, conducted the survey from April 1-26, receiving 1,140 valid samples.

Asked about the characteristics a secretary must possess, 80.88 percent cited "having the ability to communicate, " 78.25 percent mentioned "high emotional quotient and patience, " 56.32 percent pointed to the "ability to resolve problems, " while 51.93 percent of the respondents cited a "sense of responsibility."

The survey also found that 60 percent of the respondents cited the "petty and varied work agenda" as the most difficult parts of their jobs, 40.88 percent said there are few promotions for them, 33.68 percent complained of long workdays, heavy workloads and "the need to be ready to fight at any minute, " while 32.28 percent complained of low salaries.

Among the 69.82 percent of the respondents who said they want to change careers, 55.96 percent said "having a good communication capability with others" would be a plus for their next job, 44.04 percent cited the "ability to resolve problems" and 34.74 percent mentioned "good service attitude."

Asked what will be their preference for their next jobs, 20.04 percent said they will chose work related to office administration, while 11.23 percent said they would like to create a business of their own.

Referring to the question of who are the worst supervisors, 57.54 percent cited "narrow-minded" ones, 56.49 percent mentioned the ones that change their policies overnight and 33.33 percent pointed to those who are inexperienced.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALMOST 70% OF TAIWAN'S TEENAGERS UNHAPPY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of Taiwan's teenagers do not feel they are leading a happy life, and what troubles them most is academic performance, lack of communication with parents, and the inability to overcome depression and cope with pressures in life, a survey released Thursday found.

The Carnegie Training Center surveyed 2,167 young people aged between 13 and 18 last year and found that the traditional value of emphasizing academic achievement has become the top worry of Taiwan's young people.

Hei Yu-lung, an analyst with the training center, said most parents in Taiwan are willing to spend a great deal of money to get their kids into the best school, without realizing that it is self-confidence, communication ability and human relationships that affect a person's life at home, work and in society.

Looking into why Taiwan's teenagers do not usually have good communication skills, Hei found that they spend most of their time studying, and for fun, just surf the Internet, watch TV, play computer games or use their cell phones.

"They do not have a lot of chances to practice their communication skills, so they remain quite aloof from their peers and parents, " he said, suggesting they not just try to be "academic achievers" but rather be more creative in developing their potential and enjoy life.
He said if self-confidence comes only from a good academic record, wouldn't those not attending prestigious schools or not having good grades lose confidence?

Therefore, he said, it is the duty of parents and teachers to help their children build self-confidence in other ways, such as finding each person's strengths and developing his or her special talents.

As to improving communication skills, he suggested "practice more, praise more and interact more." Doing this in daily life will help a youngster regain confidence in life and further bring happiness and harmony to society as a whole, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAXIMUM SECURITY ORDERED FOR OPPOSITION LEADER'S RETURN

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan ordered stepped-up security at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Wednesday to brace for the May 3 return of opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan from a trip to China.

Su, who had just returned from a trip to Vatican City for the inauguration of Pope Benedict XVI, issued the instruction after being briefed by Vice Interior Minister Lin Yung-chien about the rioting that took place the previous day at the airport between Lien's supporters and demonstrators protesting against Lien's trip as he departed.

Lin quoted the minister as pointing out that the airport is off-limits to public gatherings and said the police will implement this rule May 3. He added that as the protesters fully expressed their opinion in Tuesday's clashes, there is "no need" to gather at the airport again over Lien's trip.
Lin said Su asked police to take every possible step to ensure security at the airport when Lien returns.

Dozens of people were injured in Tuesday's riots that erupted despite the deployment of more than 3,700 policemen. The police chief in charge of security at the airport was fired Tuesday for his ineptitude.
However, some anonymous senior police officers blamed politicians who led their supporters to the airport for failing to "keep their promises" to control their followers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MUST ACCEPT ROC AS EXISTENT POLITICAL ENTITY: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday expressed the hope that Beijing will seriously address the fact that the Republic of China (Taiwan) exists.
The president made the remarks when he received permanent representatives to the United Nations from Gambia, Chad, Guatemala, and Haiti at the Presidential Office.

China's persistent obstruction of the people of Taiwan's desire to join the international community will not help cross-strait relations, President Chen said, adding that the sense understood in the international community is that cross-strait disputes should be solved through dialogues and peaceful means.

Taiwan's efforts to join the United Nations are not aimed at challenging the People's Republic of China's seat, but at securing the rights of the 23 million Taiwan people to take part in international affairs, the president said.

He also said that China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law targeting Taiwan has ignored the political fact that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have separate rule and are independent of each other.
The Anti-Secession Law is only an attempt to make the cross-strait issue look like an internal affair and validate the use of force against Taiwan, the president added.

The law has unilaterally changed the status quo across the Taiwan Strait, threatened regional peace and stability in East Asia and drawn condemnation from the United States, Japan and the European Union, Chen said.

The president stressed that the "opening of a stable new situation of dialogue and consultations" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is his most sincere promise to the 23 million people on the island and the international community.

The government will continue to extend olive branches to the other side of the Taiwan Strait, but at the same time it will solemnly express to Beijing that over 93 percent of the Taiwan people are oppose to the Anti-Secession Law, the president said.

He cited a U.S. Defense Department report that China has deployed 725 missiles along its coastal areas against Taiwan, and that Beijing has never renounced the use of force to take Taiwan, even trying to change the status quo by its recently passed law to allow it to use "non-peaceful means" against Taiwan should it formally declares independence.

China is playing a dual role of "arbitrator" and "punishment dispenser, " which the president claimed makes it a time bomb threatening regional peace and stability, and which will only drive Taiwan further away from it and does not contribute to a better cross-strait relationship, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY TO HOLD THIRD 'PEOPLE'S DIPLOMACY' WORKSHOP

TEXT.P: The third "people's diplomacy" workshop aimed at training amateur diplomats is set to start April 28, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Wednesday.

The workshop will be attended by 125 trainees, who include officials of counties and cities in central Taiwan as well as leaders of international non-governmental organizations such as Lions International Taiwan, Rotary International Taiwan, Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, Taiwan Junior Chamber and Kiwanis Taiwan, the officials said.

The programs to be offered in the workshop will include keynote speeches by Foreign Minister Tan Sun Chen and Transportation and Communications Minister Su Cheng-tien, lectures by MOFA officials on the promotion of "people's diplomacy" and Taiwan's participation in international organizations, and courses on international protocol and etiquette, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Senate Panel Is Widening Its Review on Nominee to U.N.
In a widening inquiry into John R. Bolton's nomination to be U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee intends to conduct formal interviews in the next 10 days with as many as two dozen people, Congressional officials said Tuesday. Prospects for Bolton's nomination have appeared uncertain since last-minute qualms among some Republican senators forced the Senate committee last week to postpone a confirmation vote. On Tuesday, there were signs that the White House was stepping up its effort to rescue the nomination, with Vice President Dick Cheney placing calls to Republican senators and Bolton himself visiting Capitol Hill, apparently in a bid to shore up support.
Wall Street Journal: In Putin's Russia, Business Struggles for a Foothold.
Countless grass-roots entrepreneurs laid low by the resurgent forces of Russian officialdom. Investor confidence in Russia has been shattered by the Kremlin's legal campaign against oil Giant OAO Yukos and its top executives, while the crackdown on Yukos is no isolated incident. Across Russia, entrepreneurs who run afoul of local government can be targeted with tax audits, punitive fines and intrusive inspections. Some are forced to close. Capitalism has shallow roots in Russia.Private property and the free mar ket re-emerged only in the late 1980s, in the dying days of the Soviet Union. But, choked by growing state interference in the economy, they have struggled to take hold and flourish.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY EARMARKED FOR ID FINGERPRINTING THOUGH REQUIREMENT UNDECIDED

TEXT.P: About NT$120 million has been allocated for equipment that could be used to include citizens' fingerprints on new ROC ID cards, even though an amendment is now in the legislature that would not require the new feature.
Premier Frank Hsieh has approved the money out of government reserve funds to purchase the equipment, Cho Yung-tai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan, said Wednesday.
The Cabinet has forwarded to the Legislative Yuan an amendment to the " household registration act" that would rescind the requirement that new ID cards must contain the fingerprint of the owner.
The legislature, however, has not passed the proposed amendment.
The government is scheduled to issue new ID cards beginning on July 1, but the fingerprint issue is still being debated.
One school of thought is to have all new cards issued with fingerprints, while another says that only those 14-year-olds who will be getting their first ID cards need to be fingerprinted.
Hsieh is expected to meet with various Cabinet members to make a decision on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO DEPART FOR SOUTH PACIFIC VISIT MAY 1

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will depart for a three-nation South Pacific state visit Sunday, the Presidential Office announced Wednesday.

The five-day diplomatic tour will take Chen to three of the Republic of China's allies in the region -- the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu via the U.S. territory of Guam, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang said.
The three-nation tour is mainly aimed at cementing friendships and cooperation with the ROC's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, Huang said.

This will be Chen's third overseas trip so far this year. In January, he visited the ROC's two other Pacific allies -- the Solomon Islands and Palau. Earlier this month, he made an unprecedented trip to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, making him the first serving ROC president ever to set foot in Europe. The Holy See is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
During his visits, Huang said, President Chen will sign joint communiques with his counterparts of the three nations and deliver speeches at the parliaments of the Marshall Islands and Kiribati.

According to the itinerary unveiled by the Presidential Office, Chen will depart Taipei at 5 a.m. Sunday for the Marshall Islands by a chartered China Airlines plane. The plane will make a refueling stop at Guam before arriving at the Marshall Island at 6 p.m. local time.

At the invitation of Marshall Island President Kessai Note, Huang said, the ROC Navy has dispatched two Lafayette-class frigates to take part in the Pacific island nation's May 1-2 National Day celebrations.
The two ships left the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan April 19 and are scheduled to arrive at the Marshall Island's capital of Majuro April 30.

During his visit, Chen will breakfast with Note aboard one of the Lafayette frigates next Monday. Later in the day, Chen and Note will jointly preside over the opening of a canoeing contest and then embark on a canoe voyage. Chen will present a model of a traditional Tao tribal canoe to Note as a gift. The Tao is one of Taiwan's aboriginal tribes.
Chen is scheduled to fly to Kiribati May 3 where he will join with Kiribati President Anote Tong in presiding over the opening of a coastal "Taiwan Park" and addresses the country's parliament.

Kiribati is sometimes known as the country to see the first sunrise each day as it straddles the International Dateline. In 2000, many people traveled to Kiribati to appreciate the dawn of the new millennium. On May 4, Huang said, Chen and his entourage will get up early to appreciate the spectacular sunrise.

Later that day, Chen will fly to Tuvalu by a small plane for a half day visit. He will then return to Kiribati. Shortly afterwards, he will depart for Guam for an overnight transit stop via the chartered CAL plane.

Chen and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei May 5. Members of his entourage will include Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao and aboriginal Legislator Chen Ying.
According to a news release issued by the Navy General Headquarters, the two ships will be manned by more than 300 officers and enlisted soldiers.

In addition to celebrating the Marshall Islands' National Day, the news release said the purposes of the mission also includes promoting relations with the nation's diplomatic ally and honing naval personnel's long-haul navigation skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTRY NEEDS COMMON GOAL: ACADEMIA SINICA CHIEF

TEXT.P: Expressing his sadness over violent clashes at the airport, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh said Wednesday that cross-Taiwan Strait issues must ultimately be solved by those in power, and they should work to have everyone going in the same direction.

He was commenting on opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's departure for China Tuesday, when supporters and opponents battled each other at the airport, resulting in bloody injuries and a tarnished national image. It's unfortunate that Taiwan's democratization has not been smooth, he said.

Lee said peace across the Strait is related to peace in Taiwan's political circles. It would be better for opposition leaders to talk to ruling party leaders before visiting China, and fortunately Lien had done so and President Chen Shui-bian has also changed his attitude and gave his blessing to Lien's journey, he said.

Practically speaking, he said, a consensus needs to be reached with the ruling party after Lien returns from China so that the ruling party will be able to negotiate a deal for peace with China. "Otherwise, the issue can never be solved," he added.

He used an analogy to make his point: Some people are going east while others are going west. If the goal is for everyone to go east, you cannot just control those going east and ignore those going west. This will only make things difficult.
"If I were in charge, I would devote more time and energy trying to convince those going in the opposite direction, so that everybody will be going the same way," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA WOOS TAIWAN'S OPPOSITION TO ISOLATE PRESIDENT: FRENCH DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 27 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: China invited opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to visit in an attempt to isolate President Chen Shui-bian politically, the French daily Le Figaro said here Wednesday.

The paper said Lien's China trip will also offset some of the negative effects caused by Beijing's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which provides it with a legal basis to use force against Taiwan.
Le Figaro noted that the KMT fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to the Communist Party of China and lost power in Taiwan in 2000 after five decades of rule.
The paper said Lien's trip, which Lien describes as "a journey of peace," is intended by the KMT to improve the peace across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL OF NATIONAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION PASSES PRELIMINARY REVIEW

TEXT.P: The draft organic law of a national communications commission passed the review of the Organic Law and Statue Committee under the Legislative Yuan Wednesday.
However, some controversial articles were reserved for further consultations among different parties.

Notably among them is the composition of the proposed commission. The two opposition parties of the Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) requested that the members of the commission should be recommended by political parties in proportion to their representation in the legislature.
PFP Legislator Lu Hsue-chang and KMT Legislator Wu Chin-lin claimed that the unhealthy political environment in Taiwan obliges this method to ensure the commission's freedom from government control.

Legislator Kuan Pi-lin of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party disagreed, claiming that the commission to be created to independently regulate the country's mass media is part of the administration which should be supervised by the Legislative Yuan, and therefore there is no need to pattern it on the composition of the legislature.

Also held over for further discussion is a so-called revolving door clause which prohibits members of the proposed commission to work for any media regulated by the commission until five years after they leave their posts on the commission.
A similar clause which prohibits officials of any political party from serving on the commission until three years after they have left their party jobs has cleared legislative review

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ENDORSES TRANSFER OF AVIATION POLICE CHIEF OVER AIRPORT MELEE

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh said Wednesday he deeply regrets the outbursts of violence at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport the previous day over opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China.
Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Hsieh said he deplored the police handling of the melee at the nation's main gateway.
Noting that the "commanding officer" at the scene failed to exercise his public authority to maintain order, Hsieh said he was in serious dereliction of duty.

"It was outrageous and unthinkable that no rioters were caught red-handed and that no police officers held up warning placards to ask people to stop the violence. The commanding officer is no longer qualified for the post and has been transferred to another job," Hsieh said.
He was referring to Chen Juei-tien, head of the Aviation Police Bureau who was assigned to a research job Tuesday evening after 15 people were injured in the airport fracas.

The violence broke out as supporters from the pro-independence "pan-green" camp clashed with another group of supporters of the pro-unification "pan-blue alliance" while staging a demonstration at the airport against Lien's China trip.

Hsieh said grassroots police officers' must perform their duty to maintain public order in accordance with the law. They cannot afford to give up their public authority, otherwise, public order will deteriorate.

"Under our current law, the airport complex is off-limits to any public rally, parade or demonstration. I felt deeply regret over Tuesday's messy, incompetent handling of the incident, " Hsieh said, adding that the incident has tarnished the nation's image and undermined the government's authority.
Hsieh directed law enforcement authorities to bring to justice all law-breakers, including elected representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SINCERE IN CALLING FOR CROSS-PARTY SUMMIT: TOP AIDE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is sincere in calling for a cross-party summit to forge a consensus on relations across the Taiwan Strait, the president's chief of staff said Wednesday.
Presidential Office Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun made the remarks during an informal meeting with a group of local journalists.

Yu said President Chen looks forward to meeting with the two opposition "pan-blue alliance" leaders -- Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong -- after their China trips.
In a democratic society like Taiwan, Yu said, the president must play the role of "balancer" of "pluralistic voices or forces."

"Therefore, Chen will adopt an open-minded attitude toward the holding of a cross-party summit, " Yu said, adding that Chen will respect opposition leaders' opinions about the timing and format of the meeting.

According to Yu, Lien took the initiative during his brief phone conversation with Chen Monday on the eve of his departure for his self-styled "journey of peace" to China that he hopes to meet Chen after his return.
Yu said he is convinced that a much-anticipated cross-party summit should become a reality in the not-too-distant future.
Lien is scheduled to end his China trip May 3.

Asked whether the president will meet with PFP Chairman Soong prior to Soong's May 5-12 China trip, Yu said the Presidential Office has kept close contacts with the PFP headquarters since the Feb. 24 Chen-Soong meeting. If not necessary, Yu said, the Presidential Office will not arrange a special Chen-Soong meeting prior to Soong's departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Wu Rong-i predicted Wednesday that Taiwan's economy will enjoy a growth of around 4.5 percent for this year.

Addressing an annual congress of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, Wu said that following a growth rate of 5.7 percent recorded last year, Taiwan's economy is steadily expanding in light of the estimated 4.5 percent growth for this year.
The economist-turned-official described a 4.2 percent growth estimated by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics for this year as a modest figure.

Wu said, however, that there exists various factors that could affect Taiwan's economic performance, including a special budget for the country's new 10 major construction projects to be screened by the Legislative Yuan.

The special budget of around NT$93.1 billion (US$2.95 billion) will contribute to about 0.5 percentage points of the country's economic growth, according to an estimate by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT RECOMMENDS MAINTAINING ARMS EMBARGO ON CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 27 (CNA) (By Lo Yuan-shao and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament recommended the European Union (EU) Wednesday to keep its arms embargo against China in place until China's human rights record improves significantly.

In its annual report on global human rights for 2004, which was released Wednesday in Brussels, Belgium at the beginning of a plenary session of the European Parliament, the parliament said even the development of EU economic ties with China should depend on China's progress in human rights protection, such as the release of political prisoners and the affirmation of the 1989 Tiananmen pro- democracy demonstration.
Freedom of association and religion in Tibet and Xinjiang is also a cause of great concern to the European Parliament, according to the report.

The report hailed the start of regular dialogue between the EU and China over human rights issues, saying that it hopes the dialogue will push China to reduce the number of inmates it executes every year and give its people more freedom of association and religion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN URGED TO CONVEY TAIWAN'S PUBLIC OPINION TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) called on Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Wednesday to convey Taiwan's public opinion to Beijing during his tour of China between April 26 and May 3.

In a statement issued one day after Lien arrived in China, the MAC said political parties may vary in their political stances but that they should faithfully reflect Taiwan's public opinion during their association with their Chinese hosts.

By public opinion, the MAC said, it includes the fact that Taiwan and China are independent of each other and are ruled by separate governments with neither one belonging to the other, and Taiwan people firmly oppose China's Anti-secession Law and believe the country's future should be determined by its 23 million people.
This is the least any sensible political party should do for the country, the MAC said.
Lien, who arrived in Nanjing, central China Tuesday, visited the mausoleum of Dr. Sun Yet-sun Wednesday, to pay his respects to the founder of KMT. He is expected to fly to Beijing on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 28, or the 20th day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1442: King Edward IV, the Yorkist leader during the War of the Roses, is born. He was crowned king of England after defeating the Lancastrians at Mortimer's Cross and Towton in 1461.
1545: Yi Sun-shin, Korean admiral and national hero, is born.
1758: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States, is born. His administration is noted for the acquisition of Florida in 1819, and for the proclaiming of the Monroe Doctrine in 1823, which declared that no foreign power would be allowed to colonize any part of the Americas.
1789: On a return trip from Tahiti in the South Pacific, mutinous crew members of the British transport ship Bounty set Captain William Bligh and 18 sailors adrift in an open boat. Bligh and his royal crew manage to reach Timor Island near Java on June 14 after sailing 3,500 miles.
1788: Maryland becomes the seventh state of the United States.
1876: Queen Victoria of Britain is declared Empress of India.
1902: The U.S. Senate passes an anti-Chinese bill.
1922: War between Wu Pei-fu of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction breaks out.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto urging the reunification of China by peaceful means.
1937: Saddam Hussein, president of Iraq since 1979, is born.
1945: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini is shot by his countrymen, who then string up his body head down.
1952: At his own request, Dwight D. Eisenhower is relieved of duty as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe. He is succeeded by Gen. Matthew Ridgway.
1952: The Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is signed in Taipei by Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and Japan's special envoy, Isao Kawata.
1962: The Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd. is established in Taipei.
1963: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC's decathlon champion who won the first Olympic silver medal for his country on Sept. 6, 1960, sets a new world record in the sport in the United States with 9,121 points.
1963: Taiwan holds elections for the third Provincial Assembly.
1969: President Charles De Gaulle of France resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected chairman of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1976: Delegates headed by Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary president of the World Anti-Communist League, leave Taipei for Seoul and the Ninth General Assembly of the WACL.
1980: U.S. Secretary of State Cyrus Vance resigns.
1988: A Republic of China delegation attends the annual convention of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Manila.
1992: The Afghan government cedes power to Islamic guerrillas in Kabul, ending 14 years of armed resistance and civil war.
1992: Yang Chi-chang, a police officer, is killed in an explosion while trying to defuse a bomb placed by blackmailers near the McDonald's fast food branch on Minsheng East Road in Taipei.
1996: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that starting July 1, 1996, imports of another 1,609 categories of industrial commodities will be allowed into Taiwan from mainland China, marking the ROC government's largest ever relaxation of restrictions on mainland imports.
1998: David Hempleman-Adams, British explorer, reaches the geographic North Pole, becoming the first person to reach the Earth's northern magnetic and geographic poles.
2000: The Legislative Yuan passes an amendment to the Passport Law which extends the term of validity of Republic of China passports from the present six years to 10 years.
2001: Republic of China government spokesman Su Cheng-ping leaves for New York for a one-week speech tour of the United States.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE WELCOMES DIALOGUE BETWEEN BEIJING AND TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: The White House said Wednesday that it welcomes dialogue between Beijing and Taipei, expressing the hope that the current visit to China by the leader of Taiwan's main opposition party represents a start for Beijing to seek ways to reach out to Taiwan's president.

"We obviously follow developments very closely in the region, " White House spokesman Scott McClellan said at a routine press briefing while responding to a question regarding opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's China visit.
"We welcome dialogue between Beijing and major figures in Taiwan because we believe diplomacy is the only way to resolve the cross-strait issue," McClellan said.

"But we hope that this is the start of Beijing finding new ways to reach out to President Chen Shui-bian and his Cabinet because any long-term solution can only be found if Beijing negotiates with the duly elected leadership in Taiwan," the spokesman said.
Lien, at the head of a 30-member delegation, arrived in China Tuesday for an eight-day visit.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Last Syrian Troops Out of Lebanon. The last Syrian soldiers in Lebanon packed into ramshackle buses and rumbled homeward Tuesday, putting an end to 29 years of Syrian military domination of its neighbor.

DOC.TEXT:

The Philippines and China yesterday invigorated economic cooperation with the signing of 14 agreements worth at least $1.6 billion in investments and loans, wherein the two largest deals seek to develop the railway and mining sectors in the country.

HAYDEE Yorac, who spent her four years as chair of the Presidential Commission on Good Government hunting for the wealth stashed by the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos and prying ill-gotten assets away from his cronies, is leaving her post at the end of the month.
The Philippine Star: 'RP, China ties in a golden age'
Visiting Chinese President Hu Jintao pushed yesterday for greater cooperation between China and the Philippines and other members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), particularly in the area of trade.
The Manila Times: Pasay tells Jumbo Kingdom: Pay fee
The Pasay government has served warning it would slap legal sanctions on the operators of the floating restaurant Jumbo Kingdom, if they refuse to apply for a business permit from City Hall.

DOC.TEXT: The Moscow Times: Khodorkovsky Verdict Is Postponed The Meshchansky district court postponed its much-anticipated verdict in the trial of Yukos founders Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev by three weeks on Wednesday, sparing President Vladimir Putin from having to face any uncomfortable questions when he hosts world leaders for Victory Day festivities.

The Japan Times: Cabinet OKs postal reform package amid chaos in LDP
The Cabinet of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi finalized a package of postal privatization bills Wednesday night after executives of his Liberal Democratic Party rammed the bills through a series of internal meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SUPPORT OF TAIWAN'S WHA BID "FIRM:" ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By C.J. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top envoy in the United States said Wednesday that the U.S. government's stance in support of Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA), the highest decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WTO) , as an observer is "very firm."
David Lee, ROC representative to the United States, made the remarks in response to questions at a press conference held at the Twin Oaks in the U.S. capital.

Taiwan has failed for eight consecutive years dating back to 1997 to gain observer status in the WHA due to Beijing's fierce opposition, but it will try again at this year's annual meeting of the organization slated to be held next month.
Taiwan considers that it should be allowed to take part in the global health system in accordance with the WHO's "principle of universality" and that it's WHA bid should not be politicized.
Pointing out that high-ranking officials in Taipei attach great importance to the issue, Lee said that his office is actively drumming up support in the U.S. administration and Congress.

Saying that the United States' stance in support of Taiwan's WHA bid is "very firm, " the envoy noted that some U.S. lawmakers have even sent letters to WHO Director-General Lee Jong-wook expressing the hope that he can take practical steps in support of Taiwan's efforts to join the WHA.

Lee also said that currently, Washington, the WHO's Secretariat, Beijing and Taipei are holding separate talks on the matter, without any direct contact or talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

At last year's annual WHA meeting, both Washington and Tokyo voted for Taiwan's bid to join the WHA as an observer, saying that health and disease-prevention should know no boundaries and that Taiwan's human rights should be respected.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Asean wages war on child sex tourism.
Strong messages will go out from all Asean entry points by the end of the year, warning travellers not to have sex with children.
Asean officals are now working on the appropriate language for Asean Traveller's Code, the association's secretary-general, Mr Ong Keng Yong, told the Straits Times yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washinton Post: Iraqi Legislator Slain, Underscoring Danger.
Lamia Abed Khadouri Sakri, a longtime political activist elected to the National Assembly in January, was the first member of Iraq's three-month-old transitional government to be assassinated. To an insurgency that singles out Iraqis associated with the country's U.S.-backed leadership, the determined, middle-aged Shiite Muslim woman in a head scarf was a prime target, a soft target, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER'S RESIGNATION OFFER OVER AIRPORT CLASHES REJECTED

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh on Thursday rejected Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan's offer to resign over clashes between "pan-green" and "pan-blue" supporters at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport two days ago.

Asked about the issue while inspecting a landslide disaster prevention exercise in Miaoli County, Hsieh said Su should not be asked to take the responsibility for the incident because it is the supervisors on the frontline who are responsible for failure to maintain order at the airport.
Moreover, Su was not even in Taiwan when the incident occurred, Hsieh pointed out.

The violence broke out Tuesday as a group of protesters from the ruling "pan-green camp" clashed with another group of supporters of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" while demonstrating at the airport against opposition Kuomintang Chairman's China trip.
Aviation Police Office head Chen Juei-tien was removed from the post immediately after the incident.

According to Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai, Su rang up Hsieh and verbally offered to resign over the incident as soon as Su returned Wednesday from a trip to the Vatican for the inauguration of Pope Benedict XVI.
Hsieh turned down Su's offer immediately on the grounds that he was not to blame, Cho said.
Meanwhile, while attending a meeting of the legislature's Home and Nations Committee on Wednesday, Su confirmed that he had offered to resign but was asked to stay.
Su apologized to the public over the police's failure to fulfill their duty and pledged to bring to justice anyone who used violence, regardless of their political affiliation.
Su said he will continue to work to improve public order in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO OPEN OFFICIAL DIALOGUE WITH TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman You Ying-lung called on China Thursday to start official dialogue with the government of Taiwan to facilitate the normalization of relations between both sides.

You said only government-to-government dialogue, consultations and negotiations can lead to a pragmatic and effective solution to the cross-Taiwan Strait issue and that the United States shares a similar view with Taiwan on this point.

Commenting on the on-going China visit by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Wednesday that Washington welcomes dialogue between Beijing and major figures in Taiwan.

Also, McClellan said, the United States hopes that this is the start of Beijing finding new ways to reach out to President Chen Shui-bian and his Cabinet, because any long-term solution can only be found if Beijing negotiates with the duly elected leadership in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA LOOKS FORWARD TO POSITIVE DEVELOPMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) looks forward to a positive development of cross Taiwan-Strait relations despite Beijing's enactment of its Anti-Secession Law in mid-March, MOFA spokesman Michel Lu said Thursday.

The MOFA hopes that opposition leaders "will abide by Taiwan's laws" and do their best to "protect the national interests" when holding talks with officials of the Communist Party of China (CPC) , Lu said, referring to main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan who is currently on a visit to mainland China and People First Party Chairman James Soong who will depart for China May 5.

Lu made the remarks when answering reporters' questions after White House spokesman Scott McClellan said a day earlier that the United States "welcomes dialogue between Beijing and Taiwan, major figures in Taiwan, because we believe that diplomacy is the only way to resolve the cross-strait issue."

"But we hope that this is the start of Beijing finding new ways to reach out to President Chen (Shui-bian) and his Cabinet, because in the long term, a solution can only be found if Beijing negotiates with the duly elected leadership in Taiwan, " McClellan said at a regular press briefing in the U. S. capital.

The United States has made it clear that it encourages dialogue between Taiwan and China, and it has long been Washington's stance to secure peace and stability in the strait, Lu said, adding that the United States will not meddle in cross-strait affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO U.S. PRESSURE REGARDING KMT CHIEF'S CHINA VISIT: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By C.J. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top official in the United States rebutted Wednesday media reports that pressure from Washington had caused President Chan Shui-bian to change his attitude toward opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's China visit, describing the reports as "groundless."
David Tawei Lee, Taiwan's representative to the United States, made the rebuttal while meeting with reporters at a press conference held in the U.S. capital.

Lee said that the United Sates attaches great importance to the visits to China by Lien and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong and is closely watching the situation. He stressed that his office is also maintaining close contact with the relevant U.S. officials.

The U.S. stance in dealing with the China visits are to support and encourage cross-Taiwan Strait contact and dialogue, the envoy said, adding that besides the opposition leaders, Washington also hopes that Beijing will make contact with the duly elected government in Taiwan.

The stance actually corresponds to the basic and longstanding U.S. cross-strait policy -- encouraging dialogue between the two sides of the strait in order to resolve problems peacefully and supporting Taiwan's democracy, he said.
Washington considers that although it is good for Beijing to make contact with Taiwan's opposition leaders, China still needs to deal with the government if it wants to resolve problems.
Asked whether the United States put pressure on Chen or interfered in the Taiwan government's attitude toward Lien's visit, Lee said: "This is groundless" and "those media reports are not correct."

Saying that he does not know the decision-making process in Taipei regarding Lien's visit, Lee stressed that during his contact with U.S. officials, he was never told how Taiwan should act on the matter.
Describing Taiwan's internal politics as very complicated, Lee said U.S. officials feel they should not interfere in the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL VOLUNTEER BODY OPENS RESOURCES CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An International Resources Center (IRC) under the International Association for Volunteer Effort (IAVE) was formally established in Taipei Thursday, marking the first international non-governmental organization (NGO) to open an international resources center in Taiwan.

The IAVE-IRC -- the third office of its kind that the IAVE has established worldwide -- will mainly be a research and development center aimed at expanding Internet networks for international volunteer efforts, building an IAVE library, establishing a publication center, and sponsoring seminars and training camps on volunteering and youth services, said Liz Burns, IAVE president and chief administrator.

Burns, who has traveled to Taiwan for the opening of the center, and Li-chiun Cheng, chairwoman of Taiwan's Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC), jointly presided over a ceremony held at the NYC headquarters to kick off the IAVE-IRC's operations.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Burns expressed her keen expectations that the establishment of the IAVE-IRC will help beef up partnerships between international volunteers and their Taiwan counterparts and will obtain enthusiastic support from Taiwan society.

Also addressing the ceremony, Cheng said that the opening of the center in Taiwan represents a physical link-up between Taiwan's volunteers and their global counterparts, and a vision that more people in Taiwan will join the "volunteer family" so that they can carry out their responsibilities as members of the civilized world.

Chiang Kuo-chiang, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official in charge of international NGO affairs, who also spoke at the ceremony, said that the MOFA plans to publish a book to give an account of the ministry's efforts in NGO work over the last five years since the MOFA NGO Committee was established.

Wendy Stratton, the first executive director of the IAVE-IRC, expressed hope that Taiwan will be a base and a fresh starting point for her to further promote international volunteerism and youth services worldwide. Stratton, a retired geography teacher from Canada, has been involved in international volunteer services for more than 20 years.

President Chen Shui-bian, who has made known on many occasions his zeal in promoting volunteerism and youth services, met Burns in Taipei during a visit she made in 2004 at the invitation of the Asia Pacific Public Affairs Forum.
During that visit, Burns also presided over a ceremony marking the establishment of the IAVE Taiwan.
Burns, a teacher-turned-volunteer from Scotland, was elected director of the Volunteer Development Scotland in 1983. She was then chosen as chief administrator for the IAVE in 2001.
The IAVE office in Taiwan, according to Cheng, is a center of resources devoted to providing and assisting in Web site coordination and integration of the IAVE's organizational system.

Founded in 1970, the IAVE is the only international organization with the mission of promoting, celebrating and strengthening volunteerism worldwide. Working closely with the United Nations Volunteers, the group was instrumental in getting the U.N. General Assembly to declare 2001 the International Year of Volunteers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL SECRETARY-GENERAL TO VISIT WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Wennie Chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general of the Presidential Office, will arrive in Washington, D.C. May 19 for a three-day visit, David Ta-wei Lee, Republic of China representative to the United States, confirmed Wednesday.

Yu has kept a low profile on plans for his U.S. visit, telling Taiwan media that it will be mainly to attend the commencement ceremony for his eldest son and to visit friends, but he is expected to meet with U.S. government officials and think tanks.
Yu's eldest son is studying for a master's degree at Columbia University in New York. He will graduate May 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' FORMULA POINTLESS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification formula has been proven pointless since Hong Kong and Macau returned to Beijing's rule in 1997 and 1999, respectively, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting with a group of more than 30 Taiwan expatriates from Hong Kong and Macau at the Presidential Office. Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman You Ying-lung and Presidential Vice Secretary-General James Hung were also present at the meeting.

Describing it as "impossible" for Taiwan and China to undergo political consolidation before China implements democracy and allows direct elections, as well as freedom of religion and speech for its people, Chen said that the experience gained by Hong Kong and Macau during the past several years of being ruled by China is clear proof that the "one country, two systems" scheme is a lie.

The president said that the situation facing Hong Kong and Macau at present is not how many promises Beijing makes to them but is rather the problem of whether Beijing can brace for democracy and implement rule of law, he noted.

He called on the Beijing leadership to be wise and catch up with world trends and the globally recognized values of freedom and democracy, and to step up political reform and make China a democracy in order to write a new page of progress and prosperity in history for the Chinese people in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low but closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 64 points to close at 5,842.27.
The bourse opened at 5,775.25 and fluctuated between 5,842.27 and 5,755.08 during trading. A total of 2.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$50.2 billion (US$1.59 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.5 percent, banking and financial shares at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares, machinery and electronics shares, paper and pulp issues and construction issues all at 1.1 percent and cement stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 564 to 265, with 175 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX
