The greenback opened at NT$31.441 and fluctuated between NT$31.377 and NT$31.478.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May gained 35 points to close at 5,780, with 29,571 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June moved up 32 points to end at 5,764 , with 251 contracts traded, while September futures gained 21 points to finish at 5,616, with 203 contracts traded. December futures lost 24 points to finish at 5,570, with two contracts traded. March futures gained 63 points to finish at 5,639, with 51 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,745 for May, 5,732 for June, 5,595 for September, 5,594 for December and 5,576 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

May TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 225.8, with 4,607 contracts traded, while June TE futures gained 1.3 points to finish at 225.35, with 30 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 0.55 points to end at 221.5, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

May TF futures gained five points to finish at 913.6, with 3,608 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures moved up 5.8 points to end at 914, with 75 contracts traded. September TF futures moved up 1.4 points to finish at 905, with 77 contract transactions, while December TF futures lost 0.8 points to end at 902.6, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL EXPERTS URGE CHINA NOT TO MANIPULATE WHO ISSUE

TEXT.P: China should recommend immediately the granting of observer status to Taiwan in the World Health Organization (WHO) to show its goodwill toward the country, instead of manipulating the issue for political purposes, local medical experts said Thursday.

They were responding to a media report that China's President Hu Jintao will offer to help Taiwan participate in the World Health Assembly (WHA) "in an appropriate capacity" either during a meeting with opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan Friday or with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong next month.

Previous reports on a similar issue have said that Beijing insists that Taiwan must use the name "Taiwan, China" to participate in the WHA -- the WHO's decision-making arm. Taiwan has rejected the proposal on the ground that it would downgrade the status of the country to a part of the People's Republic of China.

According to Deng Jou-fang, president of the Taiwan International Medical Alliance, Taiwan's medical sector will welcome the move if China is truly willing to help Taiwan participate in the WHA as an observer.
Deng expressed the hope that the issue is not being manipulated by China for political purposes.
He said this is purely a humanitarian and medical issue and that Beijing should take substantial action if it is sincere about helping Taiwan.

Ho Mei-shang, an associate research fellow at the Academia Sinica's Institute of Biomedical Sciences, said Beijing will only damage its relations with Taipei if it insists on Taiwan participating in the WHA under the "Taiwan, China" model.
Ho urged both Taiwan and China to stop focusing their attention on the political side of the issue, saying Taiwan's participation in the WHA is based on professional and medical needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. BLASTS BEIJING'S CEPA OFFERING

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu fired a broadside Thursday at Beijing's alleged intention to offer Taiwan the opportunity to enter a Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) with China, saying that the offering is nothing but a scheme to dwarf Taiwan into a local economic entity.

Unconfirmed sources reported Thursday that Beijing may consider granting Taiwan a membership in the CEPA, which is China's free trade agreement with Hong Kong, via opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who is currently visiting China.
Lu urged the country to be watchful of the offering, saying that it is poised to reduce Taiwan into a Chinese local district at the level of Hong Kong and Macau.
Describing the CEPA as a sweetener used by Beijing to find favor in Hong Kong and Macau, Lu questioned whether it would be acceptable to the 23 million of Taiwan.
The Taiwan people should think deeply about the CEPA offering, she said.
Lu made the remarks while talking to the media after addressing the opening ceremony of the 2005 E.U.-Taiwan Information and Telecommunication Technology Cooperation Conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. URGES CLOSER TIES WITH E.U. IN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Thursday that Taiwan continues to try and further integrate itself into the international community and the European Union is a key focus of this endeavor.

Addressing the opening of the 2005 Euro-Taiwan IT Cooperation Event at the Grand Hotel, Lu urged closer science-technology and business cooperation between Taiwan and the European Union and called for both sides to create new values from closer cooperation.

Lu said that not only do Taiwan's display panels and notebook computers command 61 percent of the world market, its agriculture, including fruits and horticultural products, has also flourished and enjoys great potential for export.

Noting that the EU is currently the world's largest economic entity and the largest exporter, Lu said if EU and Taiwan cooperate, they will be able to dominate the global IT market in the near future.

Also addressing the opening of the conference, Lin Kuang-lung, a National Science Council (NSC) director in charge of international cooperation, said that the 2005 Euro-Taiwan IT Cooperation Event, jointly sponsored by the NSC and the DG Information Society under the European Commission, is the largest of its kind ever held in Taiwan.
Nearly 90 European research organizations and business corporations are represented at the two-day event, in which Taiwan alone has submitted 108 proposals for cooperation, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S PRESIDENT BIGGEST WINNER IN KMT HEAD'S CHINA TRIP: HK PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 28 (CNA) (By Lin Yu-kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Whether opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's historic visit to China will be an asset or a liability for him and his party is not yet apparent, but Chinese President Hu Jintao will emerge as the biggest winner from his trip, a Hong Kong daily said Thursday.

An article in the Apple Daily speculates that Hu will not only increase his say on Taiwan policy but will also consolidate his power base within the Communist Party of China (CPC) as he emerges further from the shadow of his predecessor, Jiang Zeming. Hu concurrently serves as CPC general secretary.

According to the article, the views of Nanjing citizens and messages left by Chinese citizens on the Internet "show clearly" that optimism of people in China for peaceful reunification between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has risen dramatically since Lien's arrival in Nanjing Tuesday, his first stop on a four-city April 26-May 3 visit.
The people's will for peaceful resolution of cross-Taiwan Strait issues is just what Hu needs most at present, the article says.

Over the past two years or so, Beijing has never relaxed its campaign of castigating Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and seeking to check the pro-independence forces in Taiwan, the article continues, and cross-strait tension has been persistent. China's enactment of the Anti-Secession Law, which codifies the use of force against Taiwan should the island formally declare independence, has pushed the tension to a new high, the article says.
According to the article, no matter how great the military pressure, Beijing still cannot change the political situation in Taiwan, and Hu's works on Taiwan have been stalemated.
Lien's visit has given Hu a chance to break through the stalemate and get him off the hook with regard to his Taiwan policy, the article claims.
It points out that if Hu wants to have a free hand in personnel arrangement and promotion of his policies, he has to establish his authority within the party.
Since Taiwan is an issue that most touches the nerves of the Chinese, anyone who can contribute to solving the Taiwan issue will see a rapid ascendance within the CPC, the article says.

With Lien's visit, the Beijing authorities have made a breakthrough in resolving the Taiwan issue by giving people in China the impression that there is light at the end of the tunnel in a peaceful resolution of the issue, according to the article.
Where previous Chinese leaders Deng Xiaoping and Jiang Zemin failed, Hu has succeeded, the article continues -- referring to securing the KMT chairman's visit to China.
For this reason, Lien's visit is deemed to be a political achievement for Hu, greatly raising his stature and authority within the CPC, according to the article.

Under these circumstances, the Beijing authorities will certainly treat him well. Moreover, Lien's trip will also help cushion animosity of the international community over the Anti-Secession Law. It is only natural for Beijing to provide Lien with the treatment accorded to a national leader under Beijing's logic, the article says.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS CROSS-STRAIT TRADE RELATIONS UNDER WTO FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Trade and economic relations with China must be based on the framework established by the World Trade Organization (WTO) , the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Thursday.

BOFT officials made the remarks amid reports that China might offer to establish a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) with Taiwan during opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's historic visit to China. Lien is scheduled to call on Chinese President Hu Jintao Friday, marking the first meeting between the leaders of the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) since the KMT fled the mainland in 1949.
The officials said that entering into a CEPA would denigrate Taiwan, and would be politically motivated.

They said that according to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the predecessor of the WTO, and the GATS, or the General Agreement on Trade in Services, which is an international trade agreement that came into effect in 1995 and operates under the umbrella of the WTO, WTO members have the right to sign free trade agreement or similar accords to promote bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
Given this, Taiwan would like to use the framework of the WTO to complete talks on a timetable for the opening of the service industry and a free trade zone, the officials said.
They noted that the CEPA signed between China and Hong Kong stipulates the adherence to "one country, two systems, " which obviously denigrates Hong Kong.

If China offers to sign a CEPA with Taiwan, it will be a sign that China is trying to bring Taiwan under its "one China" umbrella, which is its political "united front" approach, and Taiwan will never accept that, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S DEMOCRATIZATION KEY TO CROSS-STRAIT INTEGRATION: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Political integration is not possible between Taiwan and China until Beijing implements democratic elections, nationalizes its armed forces and grants full freedom of speech and religion to its people, President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday.

"The government of China hopes for the success of the so-called 'one country, two systems' model for dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait relations, " Chen told a group of visiting Taiwanese expatriates living in Hong Kong and Macau.
"But it has been proven that the biggest conflict across the Taiwan Strait is not the political separation but the different choices in terms of system of governance and lifestyle, " Chen added.

In what Chen called a lesson that Beijing's leaders should learn from and an alert for the 23 million people of Taiwan, Chen claimed that the integration of Hong Kong and Macau into China regardless of the huge gap that exists between them has led to a regression in the socio-economic development of the two special administrative regions.
With eight years since the handover of Hong Kong to China and six years of Macau's handover, the so-called "one country, two systems" model has been "proven to be nothing but a lie," Chen said.

While the National People's Congress (NPC) of China interpreted the Hong Kong Basic Law proactively in April 2004 to deny Hong Kong residents the right to directly elect their chief executive in 2007 and their legislative council in 2008, the NPC made a similar move earlier this month and issued its interpretation on the term of the next chief executive, he noted.
Chen said that by interpreting the law proactively, Beijing has deprived the Hong Kong courts of their right to interpret the law.

He argued that the problem faced by Hong Kong and Macau today is not how many promises China can make but whether China can practice democracy and rule of law, which he said are the most secure protections for human rights and the most effective deterrents to corruption.
Known for its integrity and efficiency in the past, Hong Kong has seen its luster as "the pearl of the Orient" fade since its handover to China in 1997, he said.

"The dictatorship of China is like a giant cage in which the freedom- and democracy-aspiring Hong Kong and Macau residents are confined. It is even more like a pair of heavy shackles that have seriously hampered Hong Kong's and Macau's pursuit of progress and development," Chen said.

The president urged Beijing's leaders to comply with global trends, embrace the universal values of freedom, democracy, human rights and peace, and speed up political reforms to allow democracy and rule of law to take root in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: House Overturns New Ethics Rule as Republican Leadership Yields.
The Republican-led House on Wednesday overturned contentious rule changes made to the House ethics process, with Republicans saying they surrendered to the Democrats to try to restore a way to enforce proper conduct in the House. After a closed-door meeting with House Republicans, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert indicated that the reversal was primarily motivated by a need to resolve the torrent of questions surrounding the conduct of Representative Tom DeLay, the majority leader. One of the most immediate effects of the House's reverting to the old rules will be the opening of an investigation into persistent questions about DeLay's overseas travel and his relationships with prominent lobbyists. His fund-raising operations are under investigation by a grand jury in Texas, and some of the lobbyists' roles have come under increasing scrutiny by federal investigators in recent months. DeLay has not been named as a target of tho se investigations, the attention paid to his troubles has proven disruptive in the House.
Wall Street Journal: Facing Lawsuits, Parmalat Auditor Stresses Its Disunity.
Deloitte & Touche, the U.S. unit of Parmalat SpA, one of Italy's largest companies, was once described a"crown jewel for the organization worldwide. Today, with plaintiffs in two U.S. lawsuits trying to tie the U.S. unit to the massive scandal at Parmalat, Deloitte is describing itself in very different terms. The accounting firm says it is a network of affiliated but legally separate national partnerships and that Deloitte & Touche SpA, its Italian arm, bears sole responsibility for the audit. The Big Four accounting firms -- Deloitte, PricewaterhouseCoopers, KPMG and Ernst & Young -- have long claimed in court cases that their units are independent and can't be held liable for each other's sins. U.S. courts to date have backed that argument. The firms say the distinction is important -- allowing them to boost the efficiency of the global economy by spreading uniform standards of accounting around the world, without worrying that one unit's missteps will sink the entire enterprise.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICALLY MOTIVATED CEPA UNACCEPTABLE TO TAIWAN: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: China's reported offer to sign a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) is unacceptable to Taiwan but the two sides should engage in mutually beneficial exchanges under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO), a veteran China analyst suggested Thursday.
Chang Wu-ueh, a professor at the Institute of China Studies under Tamkang University, made the comments during an exclusive interview with the Central News Agency.

Although Chang admitted that a CEPA is a good way to enhance two-way trade and economic exchanges, like the similar mechanism between Australia and New Zealand, he said, however, that inking a CEPA with China is risky for Taiwan due to its political connotation associated with the "one China" concept or "unification."

A CEPA allows China to grant privileged treatment to Hong Kong and Macau -- two former colonies that became special administrative regions after reverting to Beijing's rule in 1997 and 1999 respectively, and thus it would be unacceptable for Taiwan to sign such an agreement as it would downgrade Taiwan's status to that of Hong Kong and Macau, he explained.

Under the terms provided by the CEPA between China and Hong Kong and Macau, which took effect Jan. 1, 2004, more than 100 categories of products from the two territories are allowed to enter China duty-free.

However, Taiwan-China relations represent a far cry from the Hong Kong and Macau models, and against such a backdrop, he went on, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should use the WTO as a platform to conduct bilateral trade and economic exchanges because it is important for both to maintain links under a sound structure to engage in a division of labor from a global prospective.

In the face of China's CEPA with Hong Kong and Macau and the would-be "10 plus three" pact between China, Japan, South Korea and the member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, "a lack of a sound mechanism to boost and enhance the heavily interdependent trade and economic relations between Taiwan and China is impractical," he said.
Now that both Taiwan and China are WTO member states, it is important and appropriate to further promote Taiwan-China trade and economic cooperation through its channels, he suggested.

Chang's comments came after the local media reported earlier the same day that Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, who is currently visiting China, might talk about a CEPA between Taiwan and China with Communist Party of China General Secretary Hu Jintao when the two meet Friday in Beijing.
Lien's historic visit to China is the first by a KMT top leader in 56 years after Taiwan and China split in 1949 in the wake of the Chinese civil war.

The high-profile trip has won great support from KMT backers who are fervently hoping for a breakthrough in deadlocked Taiwan-China ties, but it has also backfield among the pro-independence camp out of strong fear that Taiwan might be sold out.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN TO PREPARE REFINED CUISINE FOR PALAU PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Ilan will fete Palau President Tommy E. Remengesau with refined cuisine based on local delicacies when he begins his two-day cultural and sightseeing tour of the northeastern county Friday.

An Ilan County Government official said that President Remengesau will lead a 12-member delegation that will include officials in charge of culture, education and finance to Ilan. During their stay, they will meet Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng and visit Green Expo, as well as attend the inauguration ceremony of a Hotel Royal branch in Chiao Hsi.
In order to host the distinguish guests, the county government has asked a local eatery to develop a refined cuisine based on local delicacies.
The eatery unveiled the menu Thursday, with one of the dishes prepared with the famous preserved Ilan duck and seafood, which are cooked with green vegetables.

DOC.HEADLINE: KUOMINTANG CHIEF ARRIVES IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan arrived in Beijing from Nanjing Thursday on the second leg of his China trip.

Lien and his entourage were greeted at the airport by Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, along with a group of children who presented Lien and his wife Lien-Fang Yu with bouquets.
Speaking upon his arrival in the Chinese capital, Lien said the trip "is not easy for me" and therefore especially valuable.

Describing Beijing as a hub of culture and politics and a melting pot of Chinese and Western culture, Lien said he was glad to be there and was looking forward to a visit the following day to Peijing University and a meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao, who Lien addressed as secretary general of the Communist Party of China.

Lien said reconciliation and dialogue between Taiwan and China is the common desire of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the irresistible trend of history. "We all have the responsibility to do our part to fulfill it," he added.
Lien's April 26-May 3 trip is at the invitation of Hu and the high point of his tour will be the meeting with Hu scheduled for Friday.
The first KMT chief to visit Beijing in 56 years will fly Sunday to the city of Xian in western China, where he will visit his grandmother's tomb. He will wrap up his trip with a visit to Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CARGO TRANSSHIPMENT POSTS SUBSTANTIAL INCREASE IN Q1

TEXT.P: Although the volume of Taiwan's air cargo transport posted a mere 0.4 percent increase in the first quarter of this year, the volume of transshipped cargoes in the same period soared 16.5 percent, government sources reported Thursday.

Taiwan's air cargo transport totaled 424,000 metric tons in Q1, up 0.4 percent over the same period of last year. Of the total, 135,000 metric tons were handled via transshipment systems, marking an increase of 16.5 percent over the year-earlier level, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) reported.

However, both international cargo transport and domestic cargo transport declined in Q1, down 5.6 percent to 279,000 metric tons and 9.4 percent to 9,000 metric tons, respectively, DGBAS officials quoted the latest tallies from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as indicating.
Meanwhile, DGBAS officials reported that Taiwan harbors handled a total of 3.09 million TEUs (20-foot containers) in Q1, down 0.6 percent from the same quarter of 2004.
Of the total, 2.31 million TEUs were handled in Kaohsiung Harbor, southern Taiwan, representing an increase of 0.1 percent over the same period of the previous year.
Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan handled 480,000 TEUs and Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan handled 300,000 TEUs in Q1, down 1.7 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively, from the same period in 2004.

Meanwhile, DGBAS officials reported that the number of people departing and arriving at airports nationwide totaled 10.50 million in Q1. Of the total, 5.8 million people departed the nation aboard international flights (including transit flights) and 4.7 million people took domestic flights. While the former registered an increase of an unknown percentage, the latter posted a decline of 8.1 percent.
In the same three-month period, the Taiwan Railway Administration offered transportation services to 41.70 million people, up 0.3 percent over the same period in 2004, DGBAS officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE COUNCIL LAUDS VETERAN INDIAN EXPERT WITH AVRDC

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) cited Subramanyam Shanmugasundaram, a veteran species engineer from India with the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) Taiwan, Thursday for his long-lasting contribution to Taiwan's agricultural development.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung conferred a National Agriculture Medal on Shanmugasundaram at a ceremony held at COA headquarters, in recognition of the contribution of the Indian expert, who is retiring from his AVRDC job this month after serving at the center for 33 consecutive years.
This marked the first time that the COA conferred a National Agriculture Medal, the highest honor in Taiwan's agriculture sector, on a foreign national.

According to the COA, Shanmugasundaram brought his family to Taiwan 33 years ago when the AVRDC located its research center in Shanhua, Tainan County. A breeding researcher with AVRDC's Soybean Cropping System, he successfully developed soybean No. 72 and mung bean No. 102, which are of the highest quality in existing species.

Results of Shanmugasundaram's research and development have not only helped improve the quality and quantity of Taiwan's agricultural production, they have also helped increase the island's revenue generated from exports of these produce, Lee said.
Speaking at the citation ceremony, Shanmugasundaram said Taiwan is his second home country and will be a source of good memories for him after he returns to India.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TURNS DOWN CHINESE OFFER FOR VISIT AS 'AMBIGUOUS' AND 'INFORMAL'

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has no desire to jump on the "visit China" bandwagon, despite the recent rush by opposition parties to visit China, a DPP official said Thursday.

Tung Li-wen, the director of the DPP's Chinese Affairs Department, turned down an offer made by Sun Yafu, the deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, for more contacts with the DPP, claiming that Sun's words were "ambiguous and not a formal invitation."

Tung said that the DPP will not be joining opposition parties in their scramble to visit China, least of all at a time when Beijing has recently enacted an Anti-Secession Law in an attempt to justify the use of force against Taiwan.

If Beijing is really interested in bettering ties with Taiwan and maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait, Tung said, it should start consultations with Taipei authorities without any preconditions and on the basis of parity and mutual respect.
Moreover, private exchanges with China should only be made in accordance with the law and policies laid down by the government, Tung added.

Tung said the DPP has always wanted to normalize relations with China, which would be the purpose of bilateral exchanges, but won't pursue this goal at a time when Beijing threatens to use force against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT'S AIDE PRODS BEIJING TO BE PRACTICAL IN DEALING WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An aide to President Chen Shui-bian urged Beijing Thursday to be practical in its approach toward Taiwan and heed a call by the United States for contacts with the duly elected government authorities on Taiwan, rather than opposition parties.

James Huang, the deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office, echoed U.S. White House Spokesman Scott McClellan's statement to Beijing the previous day to reach out to President Chen and his Cabinet on the grounds that a solution to the Taiwan issue can only be found through negotiations with the duly elected leadership on Taiwan.
Huang said Beijing should give up its attempts to engage Taiwan only to divide and annex it.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TOUTS NEW LABOR PENSION PROGRAM TO WORKERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made a pitch for his administration's new labor pension program Thursday, saying that he has delivered on yet another of his campaign promises.

Speaking to a group of model laborers, the president said the new pension system to be launched from July 1, will give the country's laborers better protection while increasing employers' costs by less than 1 percent.

The president said his administration has set aside NT$1 billion (US$ 31.9 million) to ensure a smooth transition from the old program to the new one, in addition to legal assistance provided by the Council of Labor Affairs to ensure that laborers' rights are fully protected during that time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INSISTS ON IDENTITY SEPARATE FROM CHINA IN WHA

TEXT.P: Taiwan should have an identity separate from China in the World Health Assembly (WHA) to enable it to exchange information with the health organization directly, immediately and freely, an official at the Department of Health said Thursday.
The anonymous official said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has made it clear that Taiwan will try to join the WHA as an observer as an entity under the name of Taiwan.

The official said the Department of Health welcomes any private groups or individuals to join the government in helping Taiwan, the result of which would be enabling the authorities to provide better medical care for the people.
The official made the remarks after news reports from Beijing said Chinese President Hu Jintao will show his goodwill toward Taiwan by allowing it to participate in the WHA in a "proper capacity."

Meanwhile Dr. Wu Shu-min, the head of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, a private group devoted to pushing for Taiwan's entry into world health bodies, said Hu should support Taiwan's bid to join the WHA under its own name.
If Hu's "proper capacity" is referring to "Taiwan, China, " it would be contemptible for Taiwan and would not improve Beijing's ties with Taiwan, Wu claimed.

As a state with sovereignty, Wu claimed, Taiwan is already humiliating itself by seeking only the status as an observer rather than as a full member in the WHA, and it would be all the more so by accepting observership under the name of "Taiwan, China."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 29, or the 21st day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Fox Moves to End Crisis. Mexican President Vicente Fox moved to defuse a political crisis that has consumed the country for weeks, accepting the resignation of the attorney general who had been leading the prosecution of Mexico City's popular mayor.
