DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 9 die in helicopter crash
Raymundo Punongbayan, former director of the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (Phivolcs) and Philippine National Red Cross governor, was killed along with eight others when the Philippine Air Force (PAF) helicopter they were riding crashed and burst into flames on a mountain near Gabaldon, Nueva Ecija yesterday morning.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Punongbayan killed
IT TURNED out to be his last mission to save lives. Philippine National Red Cross governor Raymundo Punongbayan and eight other persons were on their way back in a helicopter from an aerial assessment of a renewed potential danger of landslides in Dingalan, Aurora, when their time ran out.
The Philippine Star: Ex-Phivolcs chief, 8 others killed in Ecija chopper crash
CLARK FIELD, Pampanga -- A military helicopter carrying a group of government scientists crashed in a mountainous area in Nueva Ecija yesterday morning, killing all nine people on board, one of them former Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology (Phivolcs) chief Raymundo Punongbayan.
The Manila Times: Drug test for judiciary
CHIEF Justice Hilario Davide Jr. on Thursday ordered justices, judges and other court officials and employees of the judiciary to undergo drug testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Headline News
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Rescue teams end search after death toll hits 106
Rescuers called off the search for missing passengers Thursday evening as the death toll from the train crash in Amagasaki, Hyogo Pre- fecture, climbed to 106, including the driver of the ill-fated train.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE INTERIOR MINISTER RESIGNS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has approved the resignation of Vice Minister of the Interior Lin Yung-chien, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Friday.

According to Cho, Lin, who had been a deputy mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung before assuming his current post in February this year, offered to resign verbally to Hsieh earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times : Govt ups IT purchases by tender to $2.2b.
THE Government is going to spend $2.2 billion on computer products and services this year, a move that has sent a wave of excitement through the infocomm industry.
These purchases amount to three times more than the $700 million it put out on public tender last year.
The Lianhe Zaobao: SingTel wins the case but SCV no need to pay.
The Singapore High Court ruled on Thursday that StarHub Cable Vision (SCV) did indeed breach a Network Lease Agreement signed with SingTel 10 years ago.
But it also decided that SCV need not have to pay any damages to SingTel.
Both sides have claimed victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING AIMING TO CREATE DISSENSION WITHIN TAIWAN: U.S. SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's invitations extended to leaders of Taiwan's opposition parties to visit China are aimed at causing dissension within Taiwan, a U.S. scholar said Thursday.

June Teufel Dreyer, a professor in the University of Miami's Department of Political Science, also said that main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's current China visit has deflected criticism of Beijing over its anti-secession law targeting Taiwan.
Lien, at the head of a 30-member KMT delegation, arrived in China Tuesday for an eight-day visit. James Soong, chairman of the People First Party, is scheduled to leave for China May 5.

The professor said that Lien's visit "has already heightened cross-strait tensions by polarizing feelings within Taiwan, " referring to Beijing's move to try to cause dissension within Taiwan as "clever."

"What is shameful is that Lien would allow himself to be part of this. It is all the more amazing that Lien would make this trip so soon after Beijing passed its anti-secession law -- which most outsiders believ disturbs the status quo," Dreyer further said.

According to the professor, Lien's China visit has helped China deflect criticism of its anti-secession law and made it look as if the Taiwan people have no problem with the law and are longing for unification.

She also said that some of her students, who are largely ignorant of the situation in Taiwan and China, were "aghast" at seeing on TV that an opposition party leader had gone to his country's only enemy to hold talks and that they could not imagine Al Gore or John Kerry, the two Democrat candidates in the last two U.S. presidential elections, repectively, doing the same.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN SPEAKS AT PEKING UNIVERSITY
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 29 (CNA) (By T.L. Tseng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan spoke to the faculty and students at Peking University Friday.
Lien, the first KMT leader to set foot in mainland China since the KMT fled to Taiwan after being defeated by the communist Chinese in 1949, began his speech at 9:45 a.m.

In the speech, Lien referred to an Israeli memorial tablet commemorating the Holocaust that says all Jews have a responsibility to one another in stressing that everyone has a responsibility to the development of cross-strait peace.
Lien's 40-minute speech, interrupted several times by warm and enthusiastic applause, was followed by a 20-minute question-and-answer session.
After his speech, Lien received as a gift a copy of his mother Chao Lan-kun's academic records from the time when she studied at the prestigious university.
Lien is scheduled to meet with Chinese President and Communist Party of China General Secretary Hu Jintao in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROFESSOR TO RECEIVE PRESTIGIOUS ORDER OF THE RISING SUN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 29 (CNA) (By Amy Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Veteran Taiwan professor Tsai Mao-feng has been selected by the Japanese government to receive the prestigious Order of the Rising Sun in recognition of his contributions in the areas of culture and education.

Tsai, 71, who has been teaching the Japanese language in Taiwan for nearly 50 years, will be the first Republic of China citizen to receive the prestigious citation since the two countries severed formal diplomatic relations in 1972.

The Japanese government regularly confers the Orders of the Rising Sun every spring and autumn to recognize individuals who have made extraordinary contributions in the areas of Japanese law, academics, medicine and athletics.
Tsai will be among 34 foreign nationals from 21 countries and areas to be cited with the Order of the Rising Sun, Golden Rays with Neck Ribbon.
A total of 4,057 Japanese citizens will be cited with one of the various levels of the Order of the Rising Sun at a presentation ceremony to be held at the Royal Palace in Tokyo May 19.

A former Japanese supreme court judge will be the only recipient of the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun, Paulownia Flowers -- the top honor. Japanese Emperor Akihito will confer the medal on the judge in person.
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi will personally confer the Orders of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star, the second highest of the orders, on recipients of this citation.
Other Orders of the Rising Sun, including the Order of the Rising Sun, Golden Rays with Neck Ribbon that Tsai will be receiving, will be conferred by various ministers at the presentation ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.P. RECOMMENDS MAINTAINING E.U. BAN ON ARMS SALES TO CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 28 (CNA) (By Y.C. Lo and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament on Thursday strongly recommend that the European Union maintain its ban on arms sales to China until Beijing further improves its human rights record.
The E.P. made the recommendation in its annual report reviewing the human rights situation in 70 countries, including China.

The report says that major human rights concerns, including the use of the death penalty and the suppression of freedom of association and religion, continue to exist in China, stressing that the development of the trade relationship between the E.U. and China should be contingent on human rights reforms.
Touching on the E.U. ban on arms sales to China, the report strongly recommends that "the arms embargo remain intact until greater progress is made on human rights issues."

The wide-ranging report addresses a number of issues, including the relationship between human rights and the fight against terrorism, children's rights, the impact of conflict on women and children, abolishing the death penalty, trafficking in humans and human organs, the sex industry and child labor, the role of international business in human rights, and the role of the International Criminal Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING DPP CONTINUES TO LAMBAST KMT LEADER'S CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang continued to lambaste opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan Friday for the latter's visit to China shortly after Beijing's enactment of its anti-secession law authorizing the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan.
Lien arrived in China Tuesday for a historic eight-day visit, marking the first time a KMT chairman has set foot on mainland Chinese soil in nearly 60 years.

"All we've seen has been dining, drinking and gift exchanging, but we haven't seen Lien express a single word in China to reflect the Taiwan people's feelings about the anti-secession law, " Su said at a press conference marking the launch of a publicity campaign to drum up support for the ruling DPP in the May 14 election of mission-oriented National Assembly members.

Ridiculing an earlier news report that China may give Taiwan two pandas as a goodwill gesture in response to Lien's China visit, Su said that "what Taiwan needs is for China to destroy its missiles targeting Taiwan, and not a couple of pandas."

On remarks made by Sun Yafu, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, that "China wants to develop more relations with the DPP, " Su brushed off Sun's overture, saying the DPP would not accept invitations of any kind from Beijing at this moment, only 45 days after the anti-secession law's enactment, which brought hundreds of thousands of Taiwan citizens out into the streets in a protest rally shortly afterward.

Su called for all DPP supporters to strive to help the party win as many seats as possible in the upcoming National Assembly election. The National Assembly will be charged with the task of reviewing a package of constitutional amendments passed by the Legislative Yuan last August, including halving the number of legislators and overhauling the legislative electoral system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR DISCOURAGES POLITICIZATION OF PANDA ISSUE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that the reported coming to Taiwan of two pandas from mainland China has nothing to do with the current visit in China by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and urged the country not to politicize the panda matter.

Ma, himself a KMT vice chairman, stressed that Taipei City Zoo has been working for years to prepare for welcoming the Chinese pandas, and the matter is by no means related to KMT Chairman Lien's ongoing China visit.

Noting that the purpose of a city zoo is to conserve as well as display wild animals, Ma said that the Taipei City Zoo should strive to make itself like any other zoo in the world which is capable of accommodating all kinds of wild animals, including pandas.
It would be a nice thing for both Taipei and Taiwan if the Taipei City Zoo were able to have pandas, Ma noted.
If other zoos around the world are able to accommodate Chinese pandas -- actually 23 pandas are already kept in zoos in more than 10 countries -- why not the Taipei City Zoo? Ma asked.
The issue of whether Taiwan will accept pandas from China is quite simple if people don't politicize the issue, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE INTERIOR MINISTER RESIGNS OVER AIRPORT FRACAS

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh has approved the resignation of Vice Minister of the Interior Lin Yung-chien, Cabinet spokesman Cho Jung-tai said Friday.

According to Cho, Lin offered to resign verbally to Hsieh last night to assume political responsibility for the clumsy police handling of the fracas at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport earlier this week over opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China.
Lin, a former deputy mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, assumed the second-highest post at the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), which supervises police operations, in February this year.

Speaking at a news conference, Lin said he must take full responsibility for the flawed police handling of the violent clashes between opponents and supporters of Lien's China visit Tuesday at the nation's main gateway.
"The airport melee has tarnished our national image, " Lin said regretfully, adding that the MOI has apologized for the incident.
When the incident happened, Interior Minister Su Jia-chyuan was on a trip to the Vatican to attend Pope Benedict XVI's inaugural mass.
"At the time, I was in charge of ministry affairs. Therefore, I must step down to take the blame for the airport chaos," Lin said.
Lin recalled that he clearly issued two directives while attending a working meeting at the Aviation Police Bureau on the eve of Lien's departure.

"The directives were that nobody should be allowed to give a public speech at the passenger terminal because the airport complex is off-limits to any public rally, parade or demonstration and that police must promptly hold up warning placards when any law-breaking move was spotted," Lin said.

"I feel deep regret that the 'commanding officer' at the scene failed to exercise his public authority to respond properly when the violence broke out, " Lin said, referring to former Aviation Police Bureau Director Chen Juei-tien.

Chen was transferred to a research job shortly after the incident. Liu Shih-lin, deputy director-general of the National Police Administration, who was at the Aviation Police Bureau to supervise airport police operations that day, has also been slapped with a demerit.

Now that he has resigned, Lin said, he hopes "probes into police accountability can be stopped at this point" because police still have many tough jobs ahead, referring to Lien's return scheduled for May 3 and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong's departure for China May 5 for a visit.
"I'm very hopeful that the public will offer our police officers a chance to remedy Tuesday's flawed operations," Lin said.

Noting that Taiwan has come a long way in its democratic development, Lin said individual citizens and opinion leaders from the rival camps should learn to express their political opinions in a peaceful, rational manner.

"We may have different views about our nation's development course, but we all live on this island. We should never resort to violence against each other. Otherwise, out democratic way of life will be at stake," Lin added.

The violence broke out Tuesday as supporters from the pro-independence "pan-green camp" clashed with a group of supporters of the pro-unification "pan-blue alliance" while staging a demonstration at CKS Airport against Lien's China trip. A dozen people were injured in the chaos.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN URGES BOTH SIDES TO WORK FOR CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan on Friday stressed that both sides of the Taiwan Strait "have a responsibility toward each other" and that they must work toward cross-strait peace and development for their mutual benefit.

Lien, the first KMT leader to set foot in mainland China since the KMT fled to Taiwan after being defeated by Communist Party of China (CPC) in 1949, made the appeal during a speech he delivered to more than 500 faculty members and students at Peking University in Beijing.

He said that both sides must "insist on peace and maintain a stable status quo, " adding that maintaining a status quo is not a passive approach but aims to put aside differences and seek common ground so as to accumulate cross-strait goodwill "bit by bit" for the positive development of cross-strait relations.

Lien lauded two major figures that played key roles in the development of Taiwan and China, respectively, namely the late Republic of China President Chiang Ching-kuo and the late CPC General Secretary Deng Xioaping, saying that they had helped turn history in critical time.

Noting that Chiang promoted the "10 major-construction projects" which helped create Taiwan's economic miracle, while Deng championed reforms that led to an overall improvement in mainland Chinese living standards, Lien said that he hopes that the young students will learn from these sagacious foreleaders and become "navigators of their time."

As intellectuals, he asked the students to be determined and courageous to "find a way" for the vast majority of the people so that the Chinese people will never again have to go to war and shed blood.

On how to achieve cross-strait peace, Lien cited a memorial tablet in a museum in Tel Aviv, Israel commemorating the Holocaust that says Jews have a responsibility to each other, to stress that every Chinese person with wisdom and ability must dedicate themselves to a lasting cross-strait peace.

Lien also said that he has traveled to the mainland with the hope of seeing overall development proceed more quickly, noting that there has been rapid political development, such as the holding of local elections and the inclusion of protecting property rights into the constitution, which is moving China in the right direction.
Nevertheless, he added that ample room remains for further political reform.
Faced with globalization, the two sides of the strait can only succeed through cooperation to upgrade their competitiveness, he said.

Lien noted that the two sides are "complementary to each other, " adding that Taiwan is striving toward a second economic miracle, while China is witnessing an unprecedented opportunity, claiming that if both sides can cooperate, then achieving a modern and prosperous China "will no longer be an impossible dream."
"What's wrong with both sides cooperating to earn money from the world, " Lien asked, stressing that cross-strait cooperation will see its effect multiply and create a multiple-win situation.

He expressed the hope that the two sides not cling to the past lest they miss the opportunities that the future holds, saying that reconciliation is supported by the people and that no one wants to see cross-strait rivalry and confrontation.

Noting that some have voiced suspicions that his visit is a "third KMT-CPC negotiation" aimed at uniting the CPC to check the pro-independence forces in Taiwan, Lien said that this view is a serious distortion of the facts and represents a rigid mindset left from the civil war era.

Pointing out that the KMT has always supported the notion that following the right path will lead to opportunities and solutions, Lien said that Taiwan should not let populism take the place of democracy nor allow the timetable of Taiwan independence forces sabotage the people's well-being. He claimed that a majority of Legislative Yuan members support this position and that a significant majority of the Taiwan people support cross-strait dialogue.

Lien began his speech by saying that he was "warmed" with a homecoming feeling to step onto the campus of his 96-year-old mother Chao Lan-kun's alma mater, and recalling her youthful days at the prestigious school.
He also spoke about the spirit of freedom and tolerance championed by former Peking University President Tsai Yuanpei, adding that the school is the roots of modern China.
The 40-minute speech, interrupted several times by warm and enthusiastic applause, was followed by a 20-minute question-and-answer session.
After his speech, Lien received as a gift a copy of his mother's academic records during her time at the school.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD HOPES CHINA CAN OPEN UP MARKET TO TAIWAN AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan urged China Friday to open its market to Taiwan's agricultural products.

Lien, who is on a historic eight-day visit to China, made the appeal during a question-and-answer session after making a 40-minute speech to around 600 faculty members of Peking University in Beijing.

A Peking University professor noted that history has shown that the KMT used to face a big challenge in maintaining the livelihoods of farmers, and asked Lien about his views on how to promote cross-Taiwan Strait agricultural exchanges and enhance cross-strait cooperation and exchanges.

Lien said that agriculture has become weak in Taiwan in view of the nation's rapid industrialization and technological development, although the population of farmers still numbers several million, mostly in central and southern Taiwan.

But he noted that Taiwan has made substantial progress in agricultural technology over the years. In China, where there are excellent agricultural environments, many things that are not workable in Taiwan may still hold a promising future in China, he said.
Lien expressed the hope that China can open up its market to Taiwan agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRESSES TOLERANCE, TRANSPARENCY IN NEW TRADE TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, April 28 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan joined South Korea and Thailand Thursday to simultaneously emphasize the importance of "tolerance and transparency" in the multilateral Doha Round Trade Negotiations.

Speaking at a meeting of the World Trade Organization's (WTO's) Trade Negotiation Committee presided over by WTO Director-General Supachai Panitchpakdi, John C.C. Deng, Taiwan's deputy permanent representative to the WTO, said that Taiwan and many other WTO members are seriously concerned about the fact that a few WTO members have tried to monopolize some important trade talks while the voices of other WTO countries might not be heard.
These members are identified as FIPs, the group of "five interest parties" consisting of the United States, the European Union, Australia, India and Brazil.
During the meeting, Deng also stressed the importance of equilibrium of the negotiations, saying that otherwise, it will be very difficult to complete the process of the Doha Development Agenda.
Without concrete progress being made in the process of the Doha New Round of trade talks, Supachai said at the gathering that "we are close to a crisis. "
According to Supachai, the process of the Doha Round might continue to be delayed in the future.
"At the pace we are now moving, we will not make it in July and we will not make it in December," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S BEIJING SPEECH DISAPPOINTING: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu accused opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Friday of disappointing the people of Taiwan by failing to express their voice in a speech he made at Peking University earlier that day.
Instead, Wu said, Lien spoke ill of Taiwan's democratic development, when the island's democratic experience is supposed to be the most valuable model for China to follow.

In addition to calling for cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation for peace and stability in his speech, Lien also claimed that Taiwan's democracy is threatened by a rising trend of populism in the nation, while its people's happiness is at stake because of a pro-independence campaign trying to draft a new constitution and change the official name of the country.

According to Wu, it was disappointing that Lien did not seize the rare opportunity to elaborate on topics such as the cross-strait status quo in which Taiwan and China are independent of each other and the fact that the Republic of China is an independent, sovereign state whose fate is to be determined by its 23 million people.

Wu accused Lien of denigrating the democratic development of Taiwan on the soil of the undemocratic People's Republic of China, which he said is something a well-trained politician should not have done.

While it was highly significant for Lien to discuss freedom and democracy at Peking University -- the origin of liberalism in China, it was a pity that he restricted his discussion to the freedom and democracy advocated during the May Fourth Movement back in 1919, without mentioning anything about enhancing the democratic development of China, Wu said.

Saying that Lien did not link the concepts of peace, freedom and democracy together, Wu further expressed his disapproval of Lien's failure to point out Beijing's information blockade in China and China's military threat against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD PUTS FORWARD `NEW THINKING' AT PEKING UNIVERSITY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A speech made by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan at Peking University has won favorable responses from Chinese students because he put forward "new thinking" about developing cross-Taiwan Strait relations based on the values of peace and the people's well-being, a Taiwan scholar claimed Friday.

Andy Chang, a China studies professor at Tamkang University, also pointed out that Lien's speech to university faculty and students was broadcast live, an indication that China was trying to lead Taiwan people to believe that new thinking and a new strategy were being formulated in its policy toward Taiwan.
China apparently would like to use this occasion to change Taiwan people's "stereotyped" impression of China, Chang said.

While Lien was proposing peace and dialogue for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the spirit of "seeking peace through dialogue" actually is needed for both cross-strait relations and intra-party relations in Taiwan, he said.

If there is a need for the KMT and the Communist Party of China to seek reconciliation and dialogue, so much more the need for such "new thinking" for the ruling and opposition parties in Taiwan, Chang went on.

He said relations between Taiwan and China are now entering a "subtle and critical" point, from which both sides should look hard at the reality, focus on what the general public really wants and choose peace and cooperation as their prime values to jointly create a win-win situation for all.

The future development of cross-strait relations depends on more exchanges and interaction, he said, adding that if Lien's speech helps promote mutual understanding between the people of China and the people of Taiwan, it would show "constructive" significance.

As Lien has indicated he will step down as KMT chairman, some pundits have said that Lien is making his April 26-May 3 China visit his swansong, but Chang claimed that Lien's trip has created history not only for himself, but for the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 24.2 points to close at 5,818.07.
The bourse opened at 5,810.34 and fluctuated between 5,818.07 and 5,780.97 during trading. A total of 2.17 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.86 billion (US$1.56 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 3.1 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.4 percent, textile stocks at 1.1 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares at 0.9 percent.
Machinery and electronics shares moved down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.5 percent and banking and financial shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 593 to 248, with 172 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA NOT ONLY MARKET FOR TAIWAN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS: COA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agricultural products are targeted at the whole world for exports and China is not the only market, the head of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) pointed out Friday.

COA Chairman Lee Chin-lung made the remarks in the wake of a speech at Peking University made by opposition Kuomintang Lien Chan earlier in the day in which he said that while agriculture has become weak in Taiwan in view of the country's rapid industrialization and technology development, the island still holds an edge in agricultural technology and could have prospects in the vast China market. He also expressed the hope that China can open up its market to Taiwan agricultural products.

Lee noted that statistics show that Japan is the largest market for Taiwan's agricultural products, accounting for 40 percent, followed by Hong Kong and the United States, with China ranking fourth at around 9.2 percent.
"China is neither the biggest nor the only market for Taiwan agriculture," Lee added.

Lee said that although China reportedly expressed that it would help Taiwan agricultural products to be sold in China, the COA has yet to receive substantial proposals, whether orally or in written form.

At present, Taiwan fruit exported to China is subject to high tariffs and taxes, Lee said, adding that if China truly wants to open up its market to Taiwan agricultural products, it should propose substantial measures, simplify customs clearance and quarantine procedures.
Anything that concerns the exercise of authority of the government will still be dealt with by the government and related agencies that have been commissioned by the government, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ON RIGHT TRACK OF HISTORY: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday here that his insistence on peace and a win-win future in terms of Taiwan-China ties is on the right track of history.

Lien made the remarks at Peking University during a question-and-answer session after giving a speech that was warmly received by about 600 students and faculty members, including 23 students from Taiwan.

Claiming that history will eventually prove that this is the right direction, Lien said "he has seen the irresistible historical trends" and added that "we are pleased we have got on the bandwagon at the right time at this juncture of history."

"As long as one can catch up with the historical trends in a timely manner, success will come, " the KMT chief said, adding that the KMT will continue to work on the right path by building national identity, boosting cross-Taiwan Strait peace, cementing democracy, promoting ethnic equality and enhancing economic prosperity -- the KMT's five themes in last year's legislative elections.

Responding to a student's question about what he described as Taiwan's de-sinicization education policy, Lien said it is a radical and lamentable policy and claimed that it is not accepted by the majority of the people in Taiwan.

He also praised both Peking University and National Taiwan University (NTU) as cradles of liberalism of China and Taiwan, respectively, pointing out that many famous professors at Peking University transferred to NTU after retreating to Taiwan with the KMT in 1949. The two pioneers and bastions of liberalism echo each other on the two sides of the strait, he said.

Looking back to China's painful past, he encouraged the students to have broad vision and think about China's future, stressing that intellectuals should have the resolve and be brave enough to assume historical responsibility to search for the best avenue for the people.
"To avoid war and build peace for all the Chinese people and younger generations is the great task to which intellectuals should commit themselves," he said.
Lien is the first KMT chairman to visit China in nearly 60 years since 1949, when the KMT retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVIST GROUP ANNOUNCES SEPT. 8 AS 'TAIWAN NATIONAL DAY'

TEXT.P: A group of pro-Taiwan independence activists announced Friday that they would like to have Sept. 8 designated as Taiwan's national day.

Wang Hsien-chi, convener of the Taiwan Nation Movement Preparatory Committee and founder of the Alliance to Campaign for Rectifying the Name of Taiwan, claimed at a press conference that Taiwan has been independent since 1945, when Japan surrendered at the end of the World War II.

More precisely, Wang admitted, Japan merely gave up its territorial claims to Taiwan in the peace treaty it signed with the Allied nations in San Francisco Sept. 8, 1951 and did not give the island to any country. According to Wang, this means the island became independent.
This is the reason why the preparatory committee chose Sept. 8 as the national day of Taiwan, an independent sovereignty, Wang said.
Every Sept. 8, Wang said, the people of Taiwan should celebrate Taiwan national day on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office.

He said the committee will also strive to establish a national policy advisory group, enact a Taiwan Constitution and draft a national policy white paper -- all measures aimed at materializing and substantiating the national system of Taiwan, as well as detaching Taiwan from what Wang claimed is its current meaningless name of "the Republic of China."

However, Wu Li-pei, a senior adviser to President Chen Shui-bian, claimed that genuine materialization of Taiwan's independent sovereignty did not begin until 1996, when the people of Taiwan directly elected their president. "Lamentably, " he went on, the country has continued to use the unrealistic name of the ROC under an "untrustworthy" constitution authored by people in China more than 80 years ago.

Wu said that since historical facts "prove" that Taiwan is not a part of China, there should be a clear distinction between "independence" and "unification, " meaning that there should be no question that Taiwan is not an independent nation and that no issue of "unification with China" should be contemplated by the Taiwan people.
Rev. Lo Rong-kuang, a senior minister in the Taiwan Presbyterian Church, said that Taiwan continues to face diplomatic crisis in the international community because of the ambiguity of its identity.
Describing President Chen Shui-bian as the ROC president but not the president of Taiwan, Lo said the Taiwan people should re-elect another president who is the "Taiwan president."
Taiwan would have a good chance of joining the United Nations if it were called Taiwan, Lo claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for May lost 10 points to close at 5,770, with 18,029 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for June moved down 16 points to end at 5,748, with 205 contracts traded, while September futures lost 20 points to finish at 5,596, with 182 contracts traded. March futures lost 49 points to finish at 5,590, with 43 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,780 for May, 5,764 for June, 5,616 for September, 5,617 for December and 5,639 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

May TE futures moved down 1.3 points to close at 224.5, with 3,102 contracts traded, while June TE futures lost 1.45 points to finish at 223.9, with 24 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 1.9 points to end at 220.5, with three contracts traded, while December TE futures lost 1.35 points to finish at 220.55, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March.

May TF futures gained 3.4 points to finish at 917, with 2,307 contracts changing hands, while June TF futures remained unchanged at 914, with 27 contracts traded. September TF futures moved down four points to finish at 901, with 35 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December and March.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW HEAD TAKES OVER AVIATION POLICE BUREAU

TEXT.P: Chen Tzi-chin, the secretary-general of the National Police Administration (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior took the reins of the Aviation Police Bureau Friday

Chen Tzi-chin assumed the post in a handover ceremony presided over by NPA Director-General Shieh Ing-dan. His predecessor Chen Juei-tien has been transferred to the Police Administration Planning Committee after failing to stop extremists from entering the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Tuesday and rioting over a visit to China by opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan.
The bloody riot between supporters of the "pan-green camp" and the opposition "pan-blue alliance" left 15 people injured.

After graduating from Central Police University, Chen Tzi-chin served as supervisor of the now-defunct Taiwan Provincial Police Affairs Department, chief of the Tsoying and Linyea police stations in Kaohsiung, chief of the Nantou County Police Office and supervisor of the Taipei and the Tainan county police offices, before being promoted to NPA secretary-general last August.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT PROPOSES COMMUNICATION FRAMEWORK BASED ON '92 CONSENSUS'
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 29 (CNA) (By Lin Yi-fong and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan proposed to his Chinese hosts Friday that for the sake of long-term peace and prosperity, both sides should build a "framework of communications" based on the so-called "1992 consensus."

The consensus has been categorically denied by Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party, but Lien claimed that such a consensus does exist and it means both sides agreed there is only one China, but the interpretation of what "one China" actually means is up to each side.

Lien, speaking during a historic meeting with General Secretary Hu Jintao of the Communist Party of China (CPC), said that the "1992 consensus" was reached only after hard efforts by both sides and that it is "unfortunate" its meaning has been twisted over the past few years.

But he expressed confidence that as long as both sides can cast aside their bitter historical differences and turn the past "vicious cycle" into a "benevolent cycle, " the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to jointly create a bright future for themselves.

Echoing Hu's remarks, Lien said it is pointless to continue KMT-CPC confrontations of more than half a century. Instead, he said, both sides should demonstrate genuine goodwill toward each other in seeking rapprochement and dialogue based on mutual trust, for the sake of the long-term interests of the people.
Lien quoted Sun Yat-sen's will, saying: "Peace, struggle and save China" has not become invalid with the passage of time, "and I still am a believer in Dr. Sun's instruction."

In his opening remarks welcoming Lien and his KMT delegation, Hu repeatedly mentioned Sun, the founder of the Republic of China who died in 1925 in Beijing, praising him as a "great patriot and national hero" who led the Chinese in a democratic revolution and dedicated his life to promoting nationalism, freedom and democracy, the people's wellbeing, and national unity and prosperity.
According to Hu, members of the CPC have always been "staunch supporters, cooperators and inheritors" of Sun's grand revolution enterprise, while Sun himself looked upon the CPC as "a good friend."

In spite of the complexity and volatility of the situation in the Taiwan Strait, Hu said, both the CPC and the KMT fully realize the true wishes of the people and are determined to "take aggressive action" to demonstrate to the world that Chinese on both sides of the strait "have the ability and the wisdom to solve their own contradictions and problems."
The KMT's current visit and ensuing exchanges and dialogue have "injected a fresh air of spring" into cross-strait relations, which are bound to improve with the joint efforts of both sides, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEW

TEXT.P: The Moscow Times: Putin Defends Missile Sale to Syria

President Vladimir Putin faced down Israeli criticism Thursday, saying that Russia's planned sale of anti-aircraft missiles to Syria and supply of nuclear components to Iran does not threaten Israel's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Blair anoints Brown as the next Premier. Tony Blair anoints Gordon Brown as his successor today, telling The Times that he will make an excellent prime minister, as the Labour leader desperately tries to shift attention away from Iraq.
Frustrated at his inability to escape the row that has now rumbled for five days and knocked his party's campaign off course, Mr Blair warns the Conservatives that their character assassination will not work because of the decency and good manners of the public.
Financial Times: Brown comes to Blair's rescue.
Gordon Brown yesterday rode to Tony Blair's rescue over Iraq as he sought to stabilise a party unsettled by the leak of legal advice given to the prime minister in the run-up to war.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Bush Social Security Plan Would Cut Future Benefits.
President Bush called on Congress last night to curtail future Social Security benefits for all but low-income retirees in an urgent new effort to address the popular program's shaky finances, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RULES OUT SIGNING CEPA WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian ruled out the possibility Friday of Taiwan signing a Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) pact with China, saying that such a move would denigrate's Taiwan sovereign status and make it a "second Hong Kong."
Quoting media reports, Chen said "some people" are planning to push China to sign a CEPA with Taiwan.

"The proposal is unacceptable because signing such an agreement would downgrade Taiwan to a special administrative region under China like Hong Kong," Chen said, adding that Taiwan would be "thankful so long as China could stop opposing other countries signing free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan."
Chen made the remarks while receiving a group of pro-Taiwan parliamentarians of the Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ).

Under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework, Chen said, China should sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan, not a CEPA pact like the one it has signed with Hong Kong and Macau. Both Taiwan and China are WTO members.

While China is not expected to sign an FTA with Taiwan in the foreseeable future, Chen said he is hopeful that Beijing can at least refrain from opposing the United States and Japan signing FTAs with Taiwan.

Turning to Taiwan-Japan relations, Chen said he was grateful for the DPJ's concern about China's recent enactment of its anti-secession law that codifies the use of non-peaceful means against Taiwan. The DPJ has passed a resolution pushing the Japanese government to voice its concern the legislation.

Chen also expressed his gratitude for the inclusion of the Taiwan Strait peace as a common strategic goal during a U.S.-Japan security cooperation meeting earlier this year and for Japan's public opposition to a European Union plan to lift its arms embargo against China.

Meanwhile, Chen said he hopes Japan will continue to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the decision-making body of the World Health Organization -- as an observer when the world health promotion body holds its annual congress in Geneva next month. Japan voted for Taiwan's WHA bid last year, but the bid was blocked by China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PAN-GREENS' ACCUSE KMT CHAIRMAN OF CURRYING CHINA'S FAVOR

TEXT.P: The "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) accused opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan Friday of currying favor with China by giving a speech full of what they called "greater China nationalism" at Peking University earlier that day.
According to DPP Secretary-General Lee Yi-yang, Lien will "pay the price" for trampling on Taiwan's democratic development and betraying mainstream public opinion in Taiwan.

Lien claimed in his speech that Taiwan's democracy is threatened by a rising trend of populism in the nation, while its people's well-being is at stake because of a pro-independence movement trying to draft a new constitution and change the official name of the country.
Lee said the DPP despises Lien's flattery of China for its economic development and political reform, disregarding the despotic nature of the Chinese communist regime.
On the other hand, Lee said, Lien was denigrating and sneering at the democratic development of Taiwan, which Lee said has disgraced both Lien himself and the KMT.

DPP legislators dismissed Lien's speech as disappointing and regrettable, alleging that Lien, instead of asserting Taiwan's identity, treated China as his motherland and considered the DPP government his enemy.

Chao Yung-ching, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, said he wonders if Lien identifies with the Republic of China or the People's Republic of China when he kept emphasizing his connection with and aspiration for China, without mentioning a word about China's long-time military threat and international isolation of Taiwan.
Meanwhile, TSU lawmakers accused Lien of allying with the Chinese communists to sell out Taiwan.
While advocating the "greater China nationalism, " Lien was suppressing the Taiwanese identity and defaming the democratic development of Taiwan, they said.

Disagreeing with the DPP and TSU, the legislative caucus convener of the opposition People First Party, Lee Yung-ping, said the people of both Taiwan and China are "Chinese" in a broad sense and that it was very appropriate for Lien to appeal to the national sentiment in his speech.
Like the KMT, the PFP opposes a confrontation of Taiwan's nationalism with China's nationalism, Lee said.

Cho Po-yuan, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, claimed that Lien's speech has sown the seeds of democracy and freedom in China and will facilitate the development of a win-win situation across the strait.

Cho said Lien emphasized in his speech the democratic development of Taiwan that began with the lifting of martial law in 1987 and urged the "pan-green camp" to stop making "unfounded accusations" against Lien.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN 'HAS DONE HIMSELF JUSTICE' IN CHINA : TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan has done himself justice during his present visit to China, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who is also a vice chairman of the main opposition party, said Friday.
Ma made the remarks during a lunch gathering with a dozen township and village chiefs from across Taiwan in Fengyuan City, in central Taichung County.
Noting that Lien's visit has been warmly accepted by the Chinese people, Ma said that he strongly believes that Lien's trip will help reduce hostility and create amicability between Taiwan and China.

As Lien particularly underscored the Republic of China -- Taiwan's official title -- in Nanjing while signing a memorial after paying tribute to ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen at his mausoleum, Ma noted that Lien properly took the opportunity to display the Taiwan identity and voiced the hope for peace between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Peace should take precedence over all other matters and it is extremely important to help push for long-term stability across the strait, Ma said, adding that Lien's efforts to initiate the peace-making drive will be recorded in history.
"Everything will be in vain if peace is not maintained, " he stressed.

Voicing his belief that Beijing will not be willing to launch war to settle cross-strait disputes, Ma said the ROC will be the largest common ground shared by the two sides when seeking to mend their differences.

Lien departed for China April 26 on what he dubbed a historic "journey of peace" that will run through May 3 -- marking the first contact between the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) in nearly 60 years since 1949, when the KMT retreated to Taiwan after losing a civil war to the Chinese communists.
Lien gave a speech Friday morning at the prestigious Peking University and met CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao later the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD ESCORT SHIP SETS SAIL FOR NORTH PACIFIC

TEXT.P: An escort ship belonging to the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) set sail from the southern port of Kaohsiung for the North Pacific Friday on a fisheries escort mission, CGA officials announced that day.
The 496-ton Hsunhu No. 3 is scheduled to return to Taiwan July 27, the officials said.

The mission is one of the three to the North Pacific planned for this year, with the main purpose being to maintain order in the North Pacific fishing grounds and provide emergency aid to Taiwanese fishing boats operating there, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY WORKS WITH ETS TO ENHANCE STAFF'S ENGLISH ABILITY

TEXT.P: The Taichung County Government in central Taiwan signed a letter of intent on cooperation to enhance the English proficiency of its staff with the U.S.-based Educational Testing Service (ETS) on Friday.

Under the cooperation project, the ETS will provide a free English test for county government employees on May 29 and will offer openings free of charge for them to take part in the Test of English for International Communication (TOEIC), officials said.
Taichung Magistrate Huang Chung-sheng pointed out that all localities around Taiwan are promoting English learning to comply with the Cabinet's policy but that an evaluation mechanism is lacking.
The cooperation project will enable Taichung County Government employees to assess their level, Huang said.
He said it is never too late to learn and urged his colleagues to take the test.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW COAST GUARD PARTOL SHIP COMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh presided over the commissioning of a new locally built coast guard patrol vessel at a shipyard in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Friday.
Addressing the ceremony, Hsieh said he hopes the commissioning of the "Nantou" vessel will help beef up the coast guard's patrol ability to better protect the nation's maritime rights.
The 500-ton "Nantou" patrol vessel, carrying a price tag of NT$500 million (US$16.05 million), is capable of accommodating 38 coast guard officers and sailing at a maximum speed of 30 knots.

Hsieh said the Coast Guard Administration has increased patrols in Taiwan's territorial waters and its 200-mile exclusive economic zone, including waters surrounding the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands as well as the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands and the Nansha (Spratly) Islands in the South China Sea.

"With the 'Nantou' vessel commissioned into service, the coast guard will be able to further increase the frequency of patrols and more effectively protect our marine resources and other rights in the exclusive economic zones, the continental shelf and the open sea, " Hsieh said.

Speaking on the same occasion, Coast Guard Administration Director-General Shi Hwei-you said the "Nantou" vessel is designed to police the nation's territorial waters and exclusive economic zones as well as offer emergency relief services.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR CAN PIONEER TAIWAN-CHINA COMMON MARKET: KMT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 29 (CNA) (By Lin I-fung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The concept of a common market is a flexible way to further promote mutually beneficial economic ties between Taiwan and China, and the private sector can help clear the way if the governments of the two sides remain skeptical of the idea, visiting Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan said Friday in Beijing.
Lien made the remarks at a news conference after speaking with Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary Hu Jintao and releasing a five-point communique.

Pointing out that finding ways to help economic cooperation across the Taiwan Strait was the main topic during his discussion with Hu, Lien said that both sides hope to better cooperation. But if government authorities are uncertain about the issue, the private sector can take the lead to help open the way, he proposed.
Since a common market is a flexible concept to bolster bilateral economic links, Lien said that Hu agreed with him on promoting Taiwan-China exchanges based on this model.
Judging from the current cross-strait situation, it is more important for the two sides to "create peace, enhance development and enjoy prosperity," he said.

But the KMT chief made it clear that it is fully up to the government to decide while commenting on his agreement with Hu whether or not to set up a cross-strait peace-promoting structure, including establishing a military trust mechanism to avoid conflict.

Now is a good time to end confrontation and angst between Taiwan and China, and the government has all the power to decide whether or not it wants security and peace, he said, adding that "let bygones be bygones" and "we should seize the present and look to the future."

The Lien-Hu meeting was historic in that it was the first time since 1949 that top leaders of the two rival political parties had faced each other. Taiwan and China came under separate rule after the KMT was defeated by the CPC in a civil war on the Chinese mainland and fled to Taiwan.

Lien departed for China April 26 for what the KMT called a "journey of peace" through May 3 to help ease tensions between Taiwan and China amid fierce opposition among supporters of the pro-independence ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CALM OVER LIEN'S CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh urged the public Friday to look at Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's visit to China as "nothing unusual, " but many in the "green camp" apparently do not want to miss a chance to blast the opposition leader.

Many people in Taiwan are visiting China these days, and many things will just disappear after five minutes of enthusiasm, as the fad of buying egg tarts was a few years ago, said the premier in Kaohsiung. He suggested that people not discuss it deliberately, and "just let it be."

But Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Su Tseng-chang, DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) caucuses in the Legislative Yuan, and other politicians in the "pan-green camp" would not "let him be."

Su criticized Lien as being "absurd" for talking about "uniting with the Chinese Communists" in a speech at Beijing University and for recognizing "one China" in a meeting with Communist Party of China General Secretary Hu Jintao, also president of China.

For the last three generations, Su said, the Lien family has been prominent in Taiwan's ruling class and Lien himself has had an easy life as a high official and is a rich man, and as a retired vice president is still enjoying a fat government pension that produces 18 percent in annual interest.
Now Lien is denying Taiwan's democracy and cultural diversity simply because he has lost two presidential elections, Su said. "How can he return the favor of the Taiwan people?"
Li Yi-yang, DPP secretary-general, said Lien will be "spit at and dumped" by the people of Taiwan for trampling Taiwan's democracy and sacrificing Taiwan's national sovereignty.

William C.T. Lai, secretary-general of the DPP legislative caucus, accused Lien of trying to evade his legal responsibility by issuing a "joint press communique" with Hu that called for resuming cross-strait talks and reaching a peace pact, matters that affect governmental power.

Lien's insistence on the so-called "1992 consensus, " which Lai claims does not exist, will spark much controversy in Taiwan, Lai said. He said he fears that controversies over independence or unification, over the existence or non-existence of the "1992 consensus, " over protecting government authority or stripping it, will push Taiwan's political circles to the edge of an abyss of war of words.

The legislative caucus of the TSU, a minority party in alliance with the DPP on the political spectrum, went further by accusing Lien of "betraying Taiwan" by recognizing the "1992 consensus" and "one China."
Ho Min-hao, deputy convener of the TSU legislative caucus, vowed that people will stage a "firm but peaceful" protest against Lien upon his return on May 3.
TSU Legislator Lo Chih-ming was concerned that Lien and Hu talked for an hour-and-a-half behind closed doors this afternoon, an act of "betrayal of Taiwan."
Lee An-ni, daughter of former president Lee Teng-hui, ridiculed Lien for " having felt like a president in China, " a dream he has failed to realize over the past five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR DIANE LEE TAKES A LICKING IN COURT OVER DAMAGE CASE

TEXT.P: Former Minister of the Department of Health (DOH) Twu Shiing-jer won a damage suit Friday that he filed more than two years ago after being wrongly accused of sexual harassment.

According to the Taipei District Court's ruling, the defendants, Legislator Diana Lee and Taipei citizen Cheng Ke-jung, should pay Twu NT$600,000 (US$19,000) with interest as compensation for damaging his reputation.

Twu had demanded NT$48.75 million (US$1.56 million) , claiming that the accusation against him in October, 2002, caused enormous harm and untold losses for him, while a huge amount of social resources were wasted after the media used a great deal of manpower and money to follow the case.

Ultimately, the district court judge found that Lee and Cheng had besmirched the Twu's reputation when Lee held a news conference to accuse Twu of forcibly kissing Cheng and licking his ear in a Taipei KTV Aug. 6, 2002, without first finding out if there was any truth to the allegation.
As it turned out, the head of the DOH personnel department was the culprit in the incident. His surname is Tu, which is pronounced the same as Twu.
In response to the verdict, Lee said in a news release that she regrets the result and will appeal.
Lee said that being a lawmaker, it's her duty to fight for the public's benefit and do whatever it takes to help ordinary people air their grievances and obtain justice.

She said that she had in fact looked into the allegation before calling the news conference to condemn Twu. Although later she was proved to be wrong due to what she referred to as a series of "coincidences, " Lee said she was right about the fact that someone did harass Cheng sexually, and the real offender was sentenced to seven months' imprisonment.

She publicly apologized for the mistake and for making Twu and his family suffer soon after finding out that she had fingered the wrong person, Lee said, adding given the fact that she had helped bring the real offender to justice, she was cleared of criminal charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN GULLIBLE AS HE GROVELS IN FRONT OF COMMUNISTS: THINK TANK CHIEF

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan was duped by his Chinese hosts into debasing Taiwan without gaining anything in return in his discussion with Chinese President Hu Jintao, the head of a local think tank declared Friday.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of Taiwan Thinktank, said after watching Lien's televised new conference in Beijing that none of the points reached by Lien and Hu, including Beijing's promise to help Taiwan join the World Health Assembly, agricultural cooperation between Taiwan and the mainland, and the creation of a common market across the Taiwan Strait, could be realized in the next two or three decades.
Unfortunately, Chen said, for these unrealistic pies in the sky, Lien has debased his country by groveling to China for help in Taiwan's World Health Assembly (WHA) bid.

As a sovereign state, Chen said, Taiwan does not need to seek China's assistance for its WHA bid, the country can do this by itself. Instead of asking for Beijing's help, Chen said Lien should tell China to stop blocking Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations.

Chen dismissed Lien as being ignorant in coming to an understanding with Hu on a common market between Taiwan and China, saying that a common market means a market within which goods and workers can move freely. This is unimaginable even in China now, let alone across the Taiwan Strait.
Citing as an example, Chen said in China, people can only go and work in the special economic zone of Shenzhen after gaining government approval.
Chen asked how it would be possible for China to work with Taiwan in creating a market that cannot even exist on the mainland.
Lien should keep his feet firmly on the ground and talk with his Chinese hosts on issues that can be solved in the near future rather than have his head in the clouds and promise the moon, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN'S MOCKERY OF TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY DISTASTEFUL: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's making mockery of Taiwan's young democracy in his speech at Peking University Friday morning was distasteful and completely lacking in tact, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker said.

Legislator Julian J. Kuo was referring to Lien's remarks in his 40-minute speech that the KMT opposes populism taking the place of democracy in Taiwan, the writing of a new constitution, rectification of the nation's title and the formulation of a timetable for Taiwan independence.
In the civilized world, Kuo said, few sensible politicians would deride their domestic political foes or scorn their own countries abroad.

"We all know that former U.S. President Bill Clinton dislikes serving U.S. President George W. Bush. But Clinton would never be likely to make a mockery of Bush in a public speech in China, " Kuo said, adding that he hopes opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong does not repeat such a distasteful mistake during his May 5-12 China trip.

In his speech and a news statement issued after his discussion with Chinese President Hu Jintao Friday afternoon, Lien twice mentioned that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait reached a "one China, different interpretations" consensus in 1992, which he said served as a basis for the ice-breaking Koo-Wang meeting in 1993. However, Lien said he deplored that the so-called "1992 consensus" has been distorted in recent years and that the KMT will join with the Communist Party of China (CPC) to check pro-independence forces.

"Lien's remarks were inappropriate. Independence is Taiwan' s bargaining chip. Otherwise, Beijing authorities would not have offered Lien such high-level treatment during his current trip. Lien can say he is opposed to Taiwan independence or he supports the '1992 consensus.' But he should not have said that the KMT would join the CPC to check pro-independence forces in Taiwan. Such an overture could be interpreted as attempting to join the CPC to check the pro-independence DPP. It's tantamount to 'colluding' with foreign enemy forces to check domestic competitors. It's an outrageous overture," Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARINES FORM NEW RAPID-RESPONSE BRIGADE

TEXT.P: The Marine Corps formed a new rapid-response brigade Friday to cope with contingencies in northern Taiwan.
The new rapid-response brigade will be based at a military camp in Taoyuan County's Kueishan township, some 50 kilometers south of Taipei.
After the commissioning ceremony, the new brigade demonstrated its rapid-response combat prowess, including installing howitzers in three minutes to destroy invading enemy forces.

The formation of the new brigade is part of the military's efforts to build an elite deterrent force in the face of China's mounting military threat and to cope with decapitation strike strategies, marine sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO HEAD FOR ASIAN BANK MEETING IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan will head a 13-member delegation to attend the 38th annual meeting of the Asia Development Bank (ADB) board of governors May 4-6 in Istanbul, Turkey.

Deputy Minister of Finance Chen Shu and Taiwan's Representative to Turkey Liu Kuo-hsing will be part of the delegation, which is scheduled to depart for Turkey May 1, an official of the Central Bank of China said Friday.

The upcoming ADB meeting will focus on regional integration prospects, achieving sustained poverty reduction, and accelerating financial cooperation and bond market development, according to the multilateral development financial institution.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush Cites Plan That Would Cut Social Security Benefits
U.S. President George W. Bush called Thursday night for cutting
Social Security benefits for future retirees to put the system
on sound financial footing, and he proposed doing so in a way
that would demand the most sacrifice from higher-income people
while insulating low- income workers. Saying the retirement
program is he aded for " bankruptcy, " Bush edged tentatively -
but for the first time explicitly - into the most politically
explosive aspect of the debate over how to assure Social
Security's long-term health: the benefit cuts or tax increases
needed to balance the system's books as the baby boom
generation ages and life expectancy increases.
Wall Street Journal: Drilling for Natural Gas Faces A Sizable Hurdle: Fort Worth
The U.S.'s largest natural gas field lies under 1.6 Million People underneath Fort Worth, Texas. The Barnett Shale formation is a wedge of blackboar d-colored rock measuring 400 feet thick in places. It's packed with 27 trillion cubic feet of natural gas made from organic material that decomposed several million years ago, according to government scientists. That's enough to supply all gas- heated homes in the U.S. for more than five years. While it's directly underneath a metropolitan area home to 1.6 million people, extracting this gas is creating a peculiar set of challenges for energy companies and for the consumers whose properties lie above it.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEADER MAY HAVE VIOLATED LAW IN CHINA: TAIWAN OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan may have violated ROC law by making public the contents of his discussion with Chinese President Hu Jintao in the form of a news bulletin, Joseph Wu, chief of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) warned Friday.
However, the MAC chief said the case could not be determined precisely before Lien returns and provides the details of what he concluded with Hu.

Admitting that the MAC has no idea what was raised during Lien's close-door meeting with Hu, Wu said his office may have to call on Lien's party or ask Lien's aides to explain the KMT chairman's discussion with Hu after Lien returns.

Wu said the government was especially disappointed by the fact that Lien, in his talks with Hu, confirmed the existence of a consensus between Taiwan and China on the so-called "one China principle" in 1992 despite the fact that President Chen Shui-bian specifically told him before his trip that the government does not believe such a meeting of the minds was ever reached.

Also, Wu said, the government was disappointed with Lien's failure to convey to his Chinese host the government's views, including the existence of the Republic of China, Taiwan's desire to join international organization with dignity, local people's resentment toward the Chinese Anti-Secession Law, and the valuable democracy and freedoms that exist in Taiwan.
Exchanges with China should not run counter to the law, and no party can be exempted from this, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR APRIL 30 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, April 30:
08: 30, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will give a speech at a breakfast party with alumni of the Department of Economics, National Taiwan University at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
10: 00, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a conference of 300A2 Lion Club International at the Holiday Inn in Taipei.
10: 00, Premier Frank Hsieh will join a beach-cleaning event in Kinshan, Taipei County.
10: 30, Former President Lee Teng-hui will present his new book "Taiwanese of the New Era" at a news conference at the Sheraton Hotel in Taipei.
13: 30, The Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies
will hold a seminar on the prospects of ties with China at
the National Taipei University in Taipei.
15: 30, Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang will
attend a joint campaign for party candidates for National
Assembly members in Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 30, or the 22nd day of the third month of the Year of the Rooster according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO TALK WITH ROC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: China should engage in a dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian and his Cabinet, since only that can help find a long-term resolution of cross-Taiwan Strait differences, the U.S. State Department deputy spokesman said Friday.

Adam Ereli made the comments while responding to questions raised at a press briefing regarding a "five-point statement" made by Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao during their meeting held that same day in Beijing.
Lien, at the head of a 30-member KMT delegation, arrived in China Tuesday for an eight-day four-city visit.

Declining to respond to the specific points raised at the Lien-Hu meeting, Ereli noted that the United States has made clear its views and policy on cross-strait contacts and that dialogue is in the interests of both sides to achieve a peaceful resolution of their differences in a manner that is acceptable to both.
"That is how we view -- that is the context in which we view this ongoing visit," he said.

Talking about the importance of a dialogue between Beijing and Taipei, Ereli said: "We urge Beijing to reach out to President Chen Shui-bian and his Cabinet, and we note that any long-term solution to cross-strait differences can only be found if Beijing negotiates with the duly elected leadership of Taiwan."

Asked whether Washington endorses agreements reached by Lien and Hu on a resumption of talks based on the so-called "92 consensus, " the deputy spokesman said that Lien's visit is "notable and important."

In response to a question regarding whether the intent of Lien's visit was to undercut Chen, Ereli pointed out that he cannot speak for the KMT head and that the United States look at the visit as "an opportunity to pursue dialogue, which is in the interest of both sides."

Touching on whether China's reaching out to Taiwan's opposition parties might become a matter for Washington's concern that the new development across the strait will be out of U.S. control, Ereli noted that the development is already not under U.S. control.

"It's a process that we can support, it's a process that we can encourage, and it's a process that we can try to help the sides work toward. But it clearly requires a will and initiative and steps that they take themselves. It's not something that we can control or force, although we can certainly lend our influence and our voice to help move things in that direction," he said.
As to whether the United States wants to see Taiwan absorbed by China, Ereli said: "We want an outcome that reflects a resolution that is acceptable to people on both sides."
