DOC.HEADLINE: WEEK OF TAIWANESE AMERICANS TO KICK OFF IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 30 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The communities of Taiwanese Americans in the New York area are preparing various activities to celebrate the annual "Taiwanese American Heritage Week, " which will begin in the second week of May.

The planned activities include a photo exhibition, music seminars, Taiwanese glove puppet shows, magic performances, a koji ceramic works exhibition, and a painting exhibition dedicated to T.F. Chen, a renowned Taiwanese painter.
In addition, Taiwanese Americans in the area will also hold a "Passport to Taiwan" outdoor activity that has been the main event of the Taiwanese American week in the past four years.

In 1999, the U.S. Congress set the second week of May as a regular festival for the celebration of Taiwanese culture. Since then, Taiwanese Americans around the United States have celebrated the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN `INFALLIBLE' IN CROSS-STRAIT GOVERNMENT-TO-GOVERNMENT DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) claimed Saturday that Taiwan will "never fail" if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait engage in government-to-government dialogue.
William Lai, DPP caucus whip in the Legislative Yuan, was responding to urging by the United States that China start a dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian and Taiwan's ruling party.
Lai noted that such cross-strait dialogue would conform with the interests of the United States and Taiwan.
He said that the United States sees China as the biggest factor in peace and safety in the Asia-Pacific region, with Taiwan as the key force in maintaining regional peace and safety.

If China, taking advantage of the weakness of opposition parties for political gains, succeeds in its "united front" tactics, then either there will be an unstable Taiwan or China will achieve its end of unifying Taiwan -- both of which are developments that would not be welcomed by the United States, he claimed.

Lai said that Chen was elected by the people, with the people behind him, that cross-strait government-to-government talks would foil Beijing's attempts to splinter Taiwan, and that "Taiwan will not fail."

He also lambasted a meeting between Lien Chan, chairman of Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , and Hu Jintao, Chinese president and general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) , in Beijing Friday in which they agreed to set up a platform for communication between the KMT and the CPC in a five-point news bulletin released after the talks.

Lai noted that the DPP has long suspected a KMT-CPC cooperation trilogy -- the first being a Lien-Hu meeting, the second being an exchange of offices, and the third being the signing of a peace and trade agreement.
Lien only adjusted the "exchange of offices" part to a "communication platform, " and changed the "agreement" to a "news bulletin" for fear of violating Taiwan law, Lai claimed.

If the KMT, joining forces with other opposition parties to form a majority in the legislature, sets up a party-to-party communication platform, then China could bypass the government altogether, according to Lai.

If the KMT then pressures the DPP administration to accept its so-called "1992 consensus" -- meaning different interpretations across the Taiwan Strait on the meaning of "one China" -- as a premise for reopening bipartisan dialogue, clearing the budget and other prioritized proposals, then there will be no end to fighting in Taiwan politics and the nation will be "bound to go under, " Lai warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING, TAIWAN GOVERNMENT DIALOGUE `MOST IMPORTANT': WHITE HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The White House reiterated Friday its stance of welcoming dialogue between China and Taiwan party officials, but said it believes that dialogue between the Chinese leadership and the Taiwan government is "most important."
The remarks came after opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao met with each other that same day.

"We all have a shared goal of peace and stability in the region, and we believe cross-strait dialogue is important to promoting peace and stability in the region, " White House spokesman Scott McClellan said in response to questions at a routine press briefing.

Therefore, the spokesman said, the United States hopes that the current contact between Beijing and the KMT "would be a sign that Beijing will continue to move forward on a dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian and members of his government."
"We'll continue working with the parties in the region and continue to encourage them to engage in dialogue to promote peace and stability in the region," he further said.

The Lianhe Zaobao: Five common recognitions between Lien and Hu to promote the peace in cross-strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE URGES BEIJING TO DEAL WITH DPP ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: China should forsake its "united front" tactics and squarely face Taiwan's popularly elected government if it wants to resolve the longstanding disputes across the Taiwan Strait, the Presidential Office said Saturday.
Chen Wen-chung, director of the Presidential Office's Public Affairs Department, was echoing a U.S. call for China to engage in dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian and his government.

White House spokesman Scott McClellan and State Department deputy spokesman Adam Ereli made similar calls Friday after Chinese President Hu Jintao held a historic meeting with Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan in Beijing that same day.

Both McClellan and Ereli reminded Beijing that it will be able to sort out viable solutions to cross-strait disputes only by holding dialogue with Chen and members of his Democratic Progressive Party administration.
In response, Chen Wen-chung said the Presidential Office has taken note of the U.S. officials' remarks in the wake of the Lien-Hu meeting.

"We have on numerous occasions stressed that cross-strait problems can be resolved only through government-to-government dialogue and consultations, " Chen Wen-chung said, adding that the Beijing authorities should pragmatically deal with the DPP administration and drop its old-fashioned "divide-and-conquer" united front strategy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD OPENS ANOTHER OPTION TO TAIWAN PEOPLE: U.S. EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. expert on cross-Taiwan Strait relations said Friday that opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's remarks made during his current China visit have opened another option to the future of the people of Taiwan.

Alan Romberg, senior associate of the Washington, D.C.-based Henry L. Stimson Center, said that the remarks clearly distinguish between the differences of stances -- the so-called "92 consensus" versus "Taiwan independence" -- between the KMT and Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
In a five-point statement issued by Lien and Chinese President Hu Jintao after their meeting held earlier in the day, they reiterated their stances of sticking to the "92 consensus."

Pointing out that Hu and Lien were careful to acknowledge that the statement was an inter-party rather than a government-to-government issue, Romberg said it seems that the KMT head wants to defy President Chen Shui-bian to see whether the DPP, "in the interests of the Taiwan people, " will put the Lien-Hu consensus into practice.

Romberg predicted, however, that the DPP will say with certainty that the KMT leader has betrayed the interests of Taiwan and will emphasize that only Chen and his party can protect the Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN'S TALKS WITH CHINESE LEADER `INSUBSTANTIAL': VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu Saturday criticized opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan's talks with Communist Party of China (CPC) General Secretary and Chinese President Hu Jintao a day earlier, describing them as "insubstantial."

In a speech at a Lions Club meeting in Taipei, Lu said the discussion of cross-Taiwan Strait peace between Lien and Hu might sound pleasant to the ears, but she claimed it contained nothing substantial, with Lien not even demanding that China remove its missiles targeting Taiwan.
It would be more meaningful if President Chen Shui-bian were to hold talks with Hu, witnessed by the United Nations, Lu pointed out.
Lu noted that Chen has insisted that cross-strait talks must be conducted under the principles of peace, equality and dignity, none of which she said was followed by Lien during his visit to China.

In an introduction before Lien's speech at Peking University Friday, the host did not mention Lien's former positions as Republic of China premier and vice president, while Lien also avoided the term "Republic of China" except for one occasion when he visited the mausoleum of ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing, Lu pointed out.

Lu said she had expected Lien, as the leader of a party that claims it is safeguarding the ROC against Beijing's attempts to exterminate the country, to speak more of the term and even to bring some ROC flags to China.

Further expressing her disapproval of Lien's claim that Taiwan's democratic development is taking an unwelcome twist toward populism and his call for people to identify with "this country" at Peking University, Lu said she wonders which country Lien was referring to and if Lien agrees with Beijing that "Taiwan is part of China."
She also dismissed the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China" principle mentioned in a news statement released after the Lien-Hu talks as non-existent.

Lu recalled that Beijing asked Taipei to accept its "one China" principle during talks held in Hong Kong in 1992 during the rule of the former KMT government, but Taipei instead proposed that both sides be allowed to interpret the meaning of "one China" differently.

Noting that Lien has refused to address Chen as "president" since his first inauguration in 2000, Lu accused him of deliberately undermining the Democratic Progressive Party government, dividing the people of Taiwan, downgrading the status of the country and confusing international perception of the cross-strait situation during his China trip.
She reminded the KMT that its past cooperation with the CPC led to its loss of power in China, which forced the party to flee to Taiwan in 1949, and urged people to learn from history.

She stressed that the ROC is an independent, sovereign state whose fate must be determined by its 23 million people and that China must remove its missiles and military facilities targeting Taiwan before the two sides can start negotiations.

If Beijing is sincere about improving cross-strait relations, it should show its goodwill by allowing Taiwan to join international organizations such as the World Health Organization on an equal footing with China, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD BE INVOLVED IN CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: DPP

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait consultations must be conducted through the respective governments or channels commissioned by the governments of each side if the issues involve government authority, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday.

DPP Chairman Su Tseng-chang made the remarks after main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan met with Hu Jintao, China's president and general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), Friday in Beijing and issued a five-point consensus after the talks.
Su claimed that while China made no concessions during the meeting, Lien made too many concessions.

The "five-point" consensus has the so-called "1992 consensus" -- meaning different interpretations on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the definition of "one China" -- as its premise, which is an affront to the will of the Taiwan people, according to Su, whose party does not even accept that the "92 consensus" exists.
The KMT-CPC consensus gives Taiwan up to a framework set by China, Su claimed.

Noting that Lien failed to propagate democratic values in totalitarian China but instead mocked Taiwan's burgeoning democracy, Su described as "outrageous" Lien's remarks in a speech at Peking University Friday that the KMT opposes populism taking the place of democracy in Taiwan, the writing of a new constitution, changing the nation's official title and the formulation of a timetable for Taiwan independence.

"What's more deplorable is that the KMT failed to express to China the antagonism of Taiwan people toward China's recent enactment of the anti-secession law," Su said, which he claimed is "doing a big favor to China, cushioning the negative impact of the law and helping to realize China's aim of splintering Taiwan."

Su said that Lien should report to the government about the content of his talks with Hu after his return to Taiwan May 3, lest Taiwan remains in the dark even as it is being sold out to the communists by Lien and the KMT.

DPP spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said the KMT is dancing to the tune of the CPC and has not solicited any good for Taiwan. Instead, he claimed, it has fallen into the CPC's trap by endorsing the anti-secession law, which he said has undermined the "solidarity" of Taiwan.

He said that only the popularly elected government has representation and authority and that anything involving sovereignty and government authority can only be negotiated by the governments on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

The DPP opposes the opposition's approach to "bypassing the government and sovereignty issues, " as such an approach is "self-denial" and undermines Taiwan's sovereignty and the fact of the existence of the Republic of China, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HAPPY TO SEE U.S. PRODDING CHINA TO TALK WITH PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is happy to see that the United States is urging China to start a dialogue with President Chen Shui-bian, a KMT legislative caucus whip said Saturday.
Cho Po-yuan said it is quite a positive proposal that will help improve cross-strait relations.

Cho made the remarks amid reports that the White House and the U.S. State Department would welcome dialogue between China and Taiwan leaders, and that Beijing should move toward expanding dialogue to ruling party leaders rather than merely opposition figures.

According to Cho, this shows that the easing of cross-Taiwan Strait tension, the establishment of a communication platform and avoidance of war are not only the aspirations of people on either side of the strait but also the aspirations of the international community.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should realize that cross-strait peace is "a world trend" and cast aside its rigid ideology, Cho said, adding that "we need to understand our friends, but need more to understand our enemies."

Referring to a five-point consensus reached between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Hu Jintao, China's president and general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC) after their talks in Beijing Friday, Cho said it will require bipartisan consultations if the consensus is to be carried out.

The five tasks that the KMT and the CPC agreed to promote include a resumption of cross-strait talks, termination of cross-strait hostility, all-out cross-strait economic exchanges, Taiwan's participation in international affairs, and the establishment of a regular party-to-party communication platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASSOCIATION TO PROMOTE DEVELOPMENT OF WOMEN AND SPORT FOUNDED

TEXT.P: A group aimed at promoting sport among Taiwan's female citizens, boosting the level of development of women and sport, and enhancing women's rights in the field of sport and physical activities, which is dominated by men in Taiwan, was formally set up Saturday.

The first chairwoman of the Taiwan Association of Women and Sport (TAWS), Legislator Hsiao Bi-khim of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that she hopes the organization will help with the development of women in sport.

Many authorities and sporting celebrities took part in the inauguration ceremony, including Chen Chuan-shou, minister of the National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, Huang Ta-chou, chairman of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, Etsuko Ogasawara, co-chairwoman of the International Working Group on Women and Sports, Chi Cheng, Asia's top female track and field athlete of the 20th century, and Sun Shu-fang, general manager of ESPN Star Sports in Greater China.

Addressing the ceremony, Hsiao said there is insufficient public space in Taiwan for women to play sports or engage in physical exercise and she expressed hope that the new organization will help boost the number of female athletes in Taiwan, promote and facilitate the development of opportunities for women in sport.

Citing the Olympic Games as an example, Huang said the number of local female athletes in international competitions accounts for 53 percent of the Taiwan competitors on average. Despite this majority, female athletes do not enjoy equivalent attention and support, he noted, suggesting that more efforts be made to improve the environment for women and sport.
One of the TAWS's goals is to seek the right to host the Asia Conference on Women and Sport in 2007 as part of its efforts to lead the region's development in women and sport.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATES LAUNCH ELECTION CAMPAIGN ON BIKES

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidates for the May 14 mission-oriented National Assembly election biked along the Love River in the southern city of Kaohsiung Saturday to elicit voter support.

Chao Wen-chuo, head of the DPP's Kaohsiung chapter explained that campaigning by bicycle is aimed at demonstrating the party's vitality and declaring his party's determination to lead Taiwan along its own road, referring to the recent talks between the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China in Beijing.

Interpreting the April 29 talks between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese President Hu Jintao as an anti-Taiwan move, Chao said his party chooses to stay with the Taiwanese people and he urged voters around the nation to support the DPP and vote for its candidates in the upcoming election of the mission-oriented National Assembly.

Despite widespread voter apathy toward the elections, Chao said the results will affect the country's constitutional reforms, which will play a key role in the nation's development. He called on DPP candidates to win the election in order to give a green light to four major constitutional amendment proposals adopted by the Legislative Yuan last August.

Items in the package include reducing the number of legislative seats from the present 225 to 113 and adopting a "single seat, two votes" legislative electoral system starting with the seventh legislature to be elected in 2007, as well as phasing out the National Assembly to allow for popular referendums on future constitutional amendments.
The DPP's "Biking On The Road of Constitutional Reforms" campaign was launched islandwide, with similar activities taking place in other cities and counties at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES OPPOSITION PARTY TO EFFICIENTLY PROMOTE LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: Premier Frank Hsieh expressed hope Saturday that the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will display the same efficiency in promoting legislative bills as has in its talks with the Chinese leadership.

Speaking on the sideline of a beach-cleaning activity on Chinshan, Taipei County, Hsieh was commenting on KMT Chairman Lien Chan's meeting with Hu Jintao, China's president and general secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), in Beijing Friday.

During the Lien-Hu talks, both sides agreed to promote five tasks -- a resumption of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, an end to cross-strait hostility, all-out economic exchanges, Taiwan's participation in international affairs, and the establishment of a regular party-to-party communication platform.

The premier said that the government is already carrying out or promoting some of the points and added that "the government will continue to promote things that should be done." But the government will never act under pressure from the Lien-Hu meeting to implement anything that is improper or unfavorable for the Taiwan people, he said.
"Everything will have the interests of the public as the top priority concern," he added.
On the resumption of cross-strait talks, the premier stressed that this should be the government's business.

However, from the political viewpoint, he said, the opposition party should work toward regaining power because only after it becomes the ruling party will it be able represent the people and the government in talks with the other side of the strait.
It is not right for a vanquished political party to conduct consultations with Beijing, Hsieh said.
But he also said tongue in cheek that he envies the CPC, saying that it seems that Lien and Hu were able to reach consensus in just 40 or 50 minutes.

In comparison, the administration's proposal of new 10 major construction projects and a five-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.87 billion) stimulus plan aimed at propping up the country's sustainable development have been stalled in the Legislative Yuan for four or five months, the premier noted.
He expressed the hope that the KMT will demonstrate the same efficiency with which it dealt with the CPC when reviewing the legislative bills.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST MAINTAIN PROPER DEFENSE CAPABILITIES: KMT

TEXT.P: Taiwan must maintain proper defense capabilities to ensure its security until the termination of cross-Taiwan Strait military confrontation, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers said Saturday.

According to Cho Po-yuan, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, the establishment of a cross-strait military confidence-building mechanism proposed by KMT Chairman Lien Chan during talks Friday with Communist Party of China General Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing is a goal that the KMT hopes to achieve to reduce cross-strait hostility and halt the cross-strait arms race.
However, this does not mean Taiwan can stop all its arms procurement plans, Cho said.

Cho said the KMT will consult with the other parties to trim the NT$480 billion (US$15.19 billion) arms procurement package proposed by the Ministry of National Defense to make sure it fits the needs of Taiwan.
The package includes a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, six Patriot PAC-III anti-missile batteries and eight diesel-electric submarines from the United States.

KMT Legislator Shuai Hua-min, who is the former head of the National Defense Management College, said that while pursuing cross-strait peace, Taiwan needs to maintain sufficient defense capabilities to preserve its leverage to negotiate with China.
Shuai said it is necessary for the country to invest properly in arms procurement and to avoid any wasteful procurement items.
According to Shuai, Taiwan and China will have to exchange dialogue on the military issue sooner or later, depending on the cross-strait political atmosphere.

He said Taiwan's military deployment should be guided by the concept of "survival is victory" and that the governments on both sides of the strait should avoid any improper political manipulation to prevent military conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES TO FLY PRESIDENT TO SOUTH PACIFIC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's leading carrier, China Airlines (CAL) , will provide a charter service for President Chen Shui-bian for his upcoming state visit to three South Pacific nations.
Chen and his entourage are scheduled to leave Sunday for the five-day tour, which will take them to the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu.
Similar to an arrangement made for the last Pacific visit by the president in January, CAL has assigned a Boeing B737-800 aircraft for the flights, CAL officials said.
According to the officials, the tour will require only short to medium-range flights, with the flying times ranging between one and four hours.
After taking off from Taiwan Sunday, the plane will head for the U.S. territory of Guam for a refueling stop before arriving in the Marshall Islands.

The plane will fly the president and his entourage to Kiribati after staying two nights in the Marshall Islands, while three smaller planes rented by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs locally will fly the group between Kiribati and Tuvalu.
The president and his entourage are scheduled to depart Kiribati on the CAL plane May 4 for an overnight transit stop in Guam and is expected to return to Taipei May 5.
To ensure the trip is accomplished smoothly, CAL has dispatched staff to the South Pacific nations beforehand to make the necessary arrangements, CAL officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HOPES TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT GOVERNMENT-TO-GOVERNMENT TALKS

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) unveiled a "four-legged table" theory Saturday prior to the upcoming visit of party chairman James Soong to China, hoping that the visit will help promote direct contacts between the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and eventually lead to the signing of bilateral agreements.

PFP officials said the first leg of the theory is based on a meeting between President Chen Shui-bian and Soong earlier this year in which they reached a 10-point consensus that included President Chen's reaffirmation of no declaration of Taiwan independence, no change of the official title of the nation and no change of the status quo in the Taiwan Strait.

The PFP-initiated cross-strait peace promotion bill, which is yet to be reviewed by the Legislative Yuan, is the second leg and is designed to provide a framework for the direction and target of the cross-strait peace process through cross-party consensus.
The third leg is the exchange of visits of party leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the PFP officials said.

They said that such visits would allow people and leaders on either side to comunicante with each other on ideas and concepts that will mitigate friction and misunderstanding and enhance understanding so that both sides can find the maximum common ground.

The fourth leg is direct contacts between the respective governments on either side of the Taiwan Strait and will eventually lead to the signing of bilateral agreements, a move that will be welcomed by the U.S. government.
PFP officials said that this will allow an overall development of cross-strait relations, which they say will be "in the best interests of the people."

The PFP has already said that since the Feb. 24 Chen-Soong meeting, Chen has adjusted his independence-tilted policies to spell out the long-standing ideals of the opposition parties, which makes "anti-Taiwan independence" the mainstream view of the Taiwan people, and cross-strait peace as the most favored issue for all parties.
PFP officials said that Soong's trip, dubbed a "bridge-building journey, " aims at contributing to cross-strait positive development through communication with the Communist Party of China.

But in contrast with the Kuomintang (KMT) , which has taken the initiative on cross-strait issues in the hope of swaying the development of Taiwan's cross-strait policy, the PFP will define itself as the promoter and balancer of cross-strait relations and will keep Soong's trip moderate and low-profile.
Soong is scheduled to visit China May 5-12. KMT Chairman Lien Chan, currently on a four-city tour of China, will return home after winding up his historic eight-day visit May 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMATURE INFANTS FACE HIGH RISK OF GROWTH SLOWNESS: RESEARCH

TEXT.P: Domestic research shows that premature babies with birth weight of under 1,500 grams face a high risk of slowness in general growth, with some of them even likely to grow up with the problem of mental retardation.

In a long-term study conducted by the Premature Baby Foundation of Taiwan among 138 domestic preemies born with a birth weight of under 1,500 grams, researchers found that when they reach the age of eight, one third of the children show lower growth levels in terms of skull circumference, height, weight, intelligence, movement and attention than those of their normal counterparts.
The researchers also found that 8.8 percent of the preemies are assessed to be mentally retarded at the age of eight, while another 8.8 percent are at the critical point between retarded and normal.
The two figures are higher than the 2.2 percent and 6.7 percent seen among normal eight-year-old children, according to the study.

Pediatrician Tzou Kuo-su of the Taipei Municipal Hospital for Women and Children said that although the cause of growth slowness among premature infants is as yet unknown, many foreign and domestic research results show that the right brain of a preemie functions more slowly than that of a normal person.
Therefore, she said, the research explains why a preemie can have balance problems and difficulty understanding the concepts of space and graphic representation.

The podiatrist said that many parents of preemies are only concerned about their children's physical development and are reluctant to give their babies follow-up checks after being discharged from hospital, which she said is mostly the reason why premature babies miss the golden time for the best treatment for mental slowness.

She suggested that parents bring their children back to hospital for follow-up checks at the age of six months, 12 months, three years, five years and eight years. Meanwhile, they should also study how to raise a preemie, the expert added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD ARRIVES IN XIAN ON THIRD LEG OF CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan arrived in Xian in northern Shaanxi Province Saturday on the third leg of his self-styled "journey of peace" to China.
Lien said upon his arrival at Xian International Airport that he was excited to return to his birthplace after being away for nearly 60 years.
"I was born in Xian to Taiwanese parents. I didn't leave this ancient cultural city until I was eight years old. I have fond memories of my childhood here," an emotional Lien said.
Noting that Xian has a rich cultural heritage, Lien said the city is a symbol of cultural inclusiveness.

"I hope this spirit can bring inspiration to both sides of the Taiwan Strait. Cross-strait relations are at a critical juncture and I believe none of us would like to see this impasse continue endlessly," Lien said.
Later in the day, he visited his alma mater, Houcaimen Elementary School, where he received a red carpet welcome. Six school children recited a poem to welcome "grandpa Lien's return."
Lien presented a red envelope stuffed with cash, glassware and other gifts to his alma mater. Later, he visited the famed Terracotta Warriors Museum.
On Sunday, Lien will visit his grandmother's grave before departing for Shanghai on the last leg of his historic China visit.

Lien, a former Republic of China premier and vice president, is the first KMT leader ever to set foot in China since the party fled to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a bloody civil war to the Chinese communists.

He delivered a 40-minute speech at the elite Peking University in Beijing Friday and held a historic meeting with Chinese President Hu Jintao. According to a news bulletin issued at the end of the closed-door Lien-Hu meeting, the KMT and the Communist Party of China (CPC) will jointly promote an end to cross-strait hostilities, full-fledged cross-strait trade ties and the establishment of a military trust mechanism.
The meeting was the first in nearly 60 years between the leaders of the KMT and the CPC.
But the ROC government criticized the meeting, calling Beijing insincere and saying the talks would not improve frosty relations.
Lien, heading a large delegation of KMT officials and journalists, arrived in Nanjing Tuesday to start his high-profile China journey.

His visit marks one of the biggest political ironies in the past decade of dizzying change in Taiwan -- one of Asia's most dynamic democracies. Violent clashes erupted between supporters and opponents of Lien's China trip at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport prior to his departure.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CALLS FOR TALKS WITH CHINA OVER AGRICULTURAL ISSUES

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung urged Beijing Saturday to open talks with Taipei on issues concerning the granting of tariff-free treatment for Taiwan's agricultural products to protect the interests of Taiwanese farmers.
Lee was responding to a media report that China might announce a decision to exempt some Taiwan agricultural products from customs duties.

Lee said the COA would welcome the move, but pointed out that as customs and quarantine affairs involve the exercise of government's authority, China will have to hold talks with Taiwan to discuss related issues.

Moreover, a unilateral announcement by China will provide no guarantee for Taiwan's farmers, because Beijing might just as easily make another unilateral announcement to stop the preferential treatment someday, Lee said.

If both sides are not ready to start government-to-government talks at this point, the COA will not rule out the possibility of authorizing a civic group to negotiate with the Beijing authorities on behalf of the government, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA HAS NO GOODWILL IN HELPING TAIWAN'S WHA BID: MEDICAL EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan feels no goodwill on the reported willingness of China to help Taiwan join the World Health Assembly (WHA) , the decision-making arm of the World Health Organization (WHO), local medical experts claimed Saturday.

They were responding to reports that main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and Hu Jintao, China's president and general secretary of the Communist Party of China, reached a five-point consensus after talks in Beijing Friday that says China will make Taiwan's participation in WHO activities a priority, but the premise will be to "promote the resumption of cross-strait talks" first.
The medical experts claimed that China has nothing but slogans and said they feel no goodwill in the words. They urged the people of Taiwan not to harbor any false hopes on China's offer.
Wu Shu-ming, chairman of the Foundation of Medical Professionals Alliance in Taiwan, said it is the basic right of Taiwan to join the WHO and it should not be traded in any form of conditions.
Faced with this "lip service" from Beijing, Taiwan should know that it cannot hinge its expectations on joining the WTO upon assistance from Beijing, he claimed.
The 58th WHA conference is scheduled to be held in Geneva May 16-25. Taiwan has since 1997 solicited to become a WHA observer, but has suffered setbacks every year because of Beijing's opposition.

Wu said it is high time the government changed its mindset for future strategy and suggested that as the biggest hurdle is China, then Taiwan might as well work toward joining the WHO rather than the WHA.

Chang Wu-hsiu, director of the Department of International Cooperation under the Department of Health, said that if China really wants to extend an olive branch, it should promote Taiwan's WHA participation.
Any suggestions that Taiwan should join the WHA in the name of private group or non-governmental organization is not under consideration, he said.
"The government's stance is clear -- we'll join the WHA without undermining the nation's dignity," he added.

After the United States and Japan expressed their support for Taiwan's bid to join the WHA, the attitude of the 25-member European Union will play a key role, Chang said, adding that the DOH is actively lobbying for the support of E.U. members.
The DOH will continue to request that its allies support Taiwan's bid, and is optimistic about joining the WHO this year, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA REGRETS U.S. INCLUSION OF TAIWAN IN 'SPECIAL 301' LIST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) expressed regrets Saturday over the U.S. inclusion of Taiwan in its "Special 301" blacklist of copyright violators.

The U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) office released its 2005 "Special 301" report on the adequacy and effectiveness of protection for intellectual property Friday, in which Taiwan continues to rank in the "watch list." The report was based on an annual review un der the section of U.S. law for which it is named.
MOEA officials said Taiwan has made strenuous efforts over the past year to crack down on commercial piracy and improve intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.

The USTR "Special 301" report recognizes Taiwan's progress in IPR protection, including tightened law enforcement, completing revisions to the Copyrights Law and the Medical Service Law, installing an IPR police corps to enhance operational efficinecy, and strengthened personnel training.

Over the past year, the USTR report says, Taiwan's streamlined law enforcement helped reduce American firms' financial losses from piracy to an estimated US$315.5 million in 2004 from ahigh of US$847.9 million in 2002.

Nevertheless, the report says, there is still room for Taiwan to improve law enforcement in Internet copyrights infringement, circulation of pirated commercial software and exports of pirated or counterfeit goods.

MOEA officials said they will continue to coordinate with other relevant government agencies in crackdown on commercial piracy and IPR protection and keep the USTR informed of Taiwan's efforts in the field in the hope of having the nation removed from the "Special 301" watch list as early as possible.
The USTR uses a three-step warning list to designate countries according to the degree of abuses.

China ranks in the "priority watch" list this year. The "priority watch" list is the second most serious of the three, below the "Priority Foreign Countries, " which China was listed on in 1994 but then removed after striking a bilateral agreement with the US government.
Among the 36 trading partners on the "watch list" -- which entails "bilateral attention to address underlying IPR problems" -- were South Korea, Malaysia, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF URGES 'TAISHANG' TO PAY MORE HEED TO PERSONAL SAFETY

TEXT.P: Taiwan business people operating in China, known locally as "taishang, " should pay more heed to their own personal safety as well as investment risks, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Saturday.
The quasi-official intermediary body made the call after three "taishang" in Wujiang in the eastern Chinese province of Jiangsu were injured by gangsters earlier this week.

SEF Secretary-General Liu Teh-hsun said two of them were seriously injured and the third one sustained only minor injuries. All of the three are now in stable conditions after surgical operations and treatment, Liu added.
According to Liu, the injured didn't have any business disputes in China nor were they acquainted with the attackers.

Noting that public order in China has been deteriorating, Liu said "taishang" should keep alert on their own safety. Before venturing into China, he said, local business people should also carefully evaluate business risks there to avoid financial losses.

According to SEF tallies, the number of reported cases involving "taishang's" personal safety has been increasing steadily in recent years. In 2004, a record number of 124 cases were reported, marking a 15.88 percent rise from the 2003 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN MAY COMMENT ON LIEN-HU MEETING IN KIRIBATI

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is very likely to issue his first comment on the April 29 meeting between the leaders of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) during his upcoming visit to the Pacific island nation of Kiribati, political sources said Saturday.

Chen will depart for a three-nation South Pacific state visit Sunday. The five-day diplomatic tour will take Chen to three of the Republic of China's allies in the region -- the Marshall Islands, Kiribati and Tuvalu via the U.S. territory of Guam.

KMT Chairman Lien Chan, who is currently on a historic visit in China, held an unprecedented closed-door meeting with CPC General Secretary Hu Jintao in Beijing Friday. According to a "news bulletin" issued after the Lien-Hu meeting, the two parties vowed to promote five tasks under the so-called "1992 consensus" on the "one China principle."

While the Mainland Affairs Council already expressed the ROC government's stance immediately after the release of the "news bulletin" that the so-called "1992 consensus" is non-existence, both the Presidential Office and the Cabinet have not yet made any public comments on the Lien-Hu talks.

In addition to defining the Lien-Hu meeting as a party-to-party rendezvous, political sources said the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration has worked out response measures. Nevertheless, the sources said, the Presidential Office will not publicly comment on the event until after Lien's return May 3.

Party sources said Chen will hold an informal meeting with journalists during his state visit in Kiribati May 3. Chen is very likely to take advantage of the occasion to air his views on the five-point work plan issued after the Lien-Hu talks, the sources said.

Meanwhile, the sources said Chen's three-nation South Pacific visit is aimed at cementing the ROC's relations with its allies in the region and containing China's military expansion in the region for the sake of safeguarding Asia-Pacific peace and stability.

This will be Chen's third overseas trip so far this year. In January, he visited the ROC's two other Pacific allies -- the Solomon Islands and Palau. Earlier this month, he made an unprecedented trip to the Vatican to attend Pope John Paul II's funeral, making him the first serving ROC president ever to set foot in Europe. The Holy See is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
During his visits, President Chen will sign joint comuniques with his counterparts of the three nations and deliver speeches at the parliaments of the Marshall Islands and Kiribati.

According to the itinerary unveiled by the Presidential Office, Chen will depart Taipei at 5 a.m. Sunday for the Marshall Islands by a chartered China Airlines (CAL) plane. The plane will make a refueling stop at Guam before arriving at the Marshall Island at 6 p.m. local time.

Similar to an arrangement made for the last Pacific visit by the president in January, CAL has assigned a Boeing B737-800 aircraft for the flights because the tour will require only short to medium-range flights, with the flying times ranging between one and four hours.
At the invitation of Marshall Island President Kessai Note, the ROC Navy has dispatched two Lafayette-class frigates to take part in the Pacific island nation's May 1-2 National Day celebrations.
The two ships left the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan April 19 and are scheduled to arrive at the Marshall Island's capital of Majuro April 30.

During his visit, Chen will breakfast with Note aboard one of the Lafayette frigates next Monday. Later in the day, Chen and Note will jointly preside over the opening of a canoeing contest and then embark on a canoe voyage. Chen will present a model of a traditional Tao tribal canoe to Note as a gift. The Tao is one of Taiwan's aboriginal tribes.
Chen is scheduled to fly to Kiribati May 3 where he will join with Kiribati President Anote Tong in presiding over the opening of a coastal "Taiwan Park" and addresses the country's parliament.

Kiribati is sometimes known as the country to see the first sunrise each day as it straddles the International Dateline. In 2000, many people traveled to Kiribati to appreciate the dawn of the new millennium. On May 4, Huang said, Chen and his entourage will get up early to appreciate the spectacular sunrise.

Later that day, Chen will fly to Tuvalu by a small plane for a half day visit. He will then return to Kiribati. Shortly afterwards, he will depart for Guam for an overnight transit stop via the chartered CAL plane.

Chen and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei May 5. Members of his entourage will include Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen, Government Information Office Minister Pasuya Yao and aboriginal Legislator Chen Ying.
According to a news release issued by the Navy General Headquarters, the two ships will be manned by more than 300 officers and enlisted soldiers.

In addition to celebrating the Marshall Islands' National Day, the news release said the purposes of the mission also includes promoting relations with the nation's diplomatic ally and honing naval personnel's long-haul navigation skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR MAY 1 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, May 1:
05: 20, President Chen Shui-bian will depart for a three-nation South Pacific state visit.
10: 10, Vice Premier Wu Rong-i will inspect a flood-control project in Tungship, Chiayi County.

10: 30, Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Su Tseng-chang will attend a rally in Fengshan, Kaohsiung County to drum up support for the party's candidates for the mission-oriented National assembly election.
14: 00, Former President Lee Teng-hui will attend a forum against opposition party leaders' scramble to visit China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: President's Big Social Security Gamble
President Bush made two big bets in proposing on Thursday night to cut Social Security benefits for future generations of retirees, one political, one on the substance of his policy, and if he is to succeed in remaking the retirement system, both of them will probably have to break his way. Representative Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona, said Mr. Bush's strategy "has the potential" to create enough bipartisanship to move legislation through Congress, "but there are no guarantees." Kolbe has long called for benefit cuts to be part of a repair for Social Security.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Post vote hotline signals action on fraud. An emergency hotline will be set up this weekend so that returning officers can report postal ballot malpractice and fraud as fears grow that dozens of election results in marginal constituencies could be challenged, The Times has learnt.
Election officers have been told to call the police if anyone brings more than five postal ballot papers into a polling station.
Senior officials have also given warning that election staff are under enormous pressure because of the number of postal votes being cast. They believe that this will make it far harder to spot fraud.
Financial Times: Labour fears for its majority. Tony Blair, UK prime minister, enters the final weekend of the general election campaign on Saturday assured of victory but beset by fears his massive majority in parliament will be severely eroded, destroying his hopes of serving a full third term.
As the three main parties launch a final push for votes before the May 5 vote, the prime minister can be confident he will be back in Downing Street on Friday.
